site_title: No Microsoft remedies in first EU antitrust review of Activision deal: source
summary: Microsoft has not offered any remedies to EU antitrust regulators reviewing its proposed $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard ahead of a full-scale EU probe. The European Commission is scheduled to finish its preliminary assessment by November 8, and its website shows that Microsoft has not provided concessions. Microsoft is betting on the acquisition to compete with leaders Tencent and Sony, with Sony criticizing the deal. The company claims to be committed to making Call of Duty available on both Xbox and PlayStation on the same day.

site_title: Talent investor Entrepreneur First leaves Singapore, consolidates globally
summary: Entrepreneur First (EF), a talent investor, is leaving Singapore after six years, citing the city-state's limited talent pool and inability to support multiple programs concurrently. EF will focus on its hubs in London, Berlin, Paris, and Bangalore, and will cease its programs in Singapore after the current cohort graduates in April 2023. The decision is part of EF's strategy to consolidate its global operations, with the company aiming to run multiple programs in startup ecosystems with a larger talent pool.

images.alt_text: Lauri Lugna, CEO of Enterprise Estonia, was in town for the Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology (SWITCH).

site_title: South Korea begins probe into deadly Halloween crush
summary: South Korea launches a probe into the deadly Halloween crush in Seoul's Itaewon district, where 154 people died and 149 were injured in a surge of partygoers in narrow alleys. Authorities are reconstructing the chain of events leading up to the surge and investigating whether anyone triggered the crush. The investigation is focused on CCTV footage, witness statements, and potential hate speech and false information spread online. The country is in a week of mourning, with funeral preparations underway, and President Yoon Suk-yeol has designated Itaewon a disaster zone.

images.alt_text: The cordoned off area where a deadly stampede took place  Choi Sung-beom, head of the Yongsan Fire Station, says 151 deaths had been confirmed, including 22 foreigners and that 82 people were injured, 19 of them seriously

site_title: Value emerging in bonds, but focus on high-quality issues, says Pimco
summary: Pimco's CIO Dan Ivascyn expects a shallow recession in the US, with inflation trending lower than pre-Covid levels. He advises investors to focus on high-quality fixed income assets, such as agency mortgage-backed securities, and be patient, as value is emerging in these markets. Ivascyn expects a 75 basis point hike in the next Federal Reserve meeting and sees better valuations for fixed income, potentially leading to higher yields and diversification benefits.

images.alt_text: Investors remain deeply divided over what the Fed will do in December, with futures traders still pricing in the chance of another 0.75 percentage point rate increase.

site_title: Smoothing the way for O&M merger must also be about paving a green highway for Sembmarine
summary: Keppel and Sembmarine have announced a simplified deal to inject Keppel's offshore and marine operations into Sembmarine. The move aims to create a stronger green energy presence, with Sembcorp announcing support for green hydrogen and ammonia projects, and Keppel exploring green ammonia and renewable energy opportunities. The deal follows a series of developments in the clean energy sector, as both companies pivot away from carbon-intensive energy businesses. A post-merger Sembmarine will have over 30 green projects under execution, and investors will need to assess how the company plans to compete in the renewable energy space.

images.alt_text: The trading halts come amid talks of a potential merger between Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembmarine.
This revised deal is S$378 million lower than if the one-for-one share exchange option was pursued, as Keppel O&M was being valued at S$4.87 billion under the previous terms.

site_title: A plea for making virus research safer
summary: A growing debate surrounds the safety of scientific research on viruses that could potentially spark a pandemic. While most research on viruses has immense benefits and low risks, some experiments involve viruses that could plausibly cause widespread outbreaks. Virologist Jesse Bloom argues that such research should be done with caution and only when necessary, citing examples of lab accidents and the risk of engineered viruses. Bloom suggests that researchers should use safer methods whenever possible and that oversight and regulation are needed to prevent accidents. The debate highlights the need for a balanced approach that prioritizes both scientific progress and public safety.

images.alt_text: epa10115253 Research scientists and engineers at work in a cell culture suite in the CSIRO National Vaccine and Therapeutics Laboratory in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, 11 August 2022. Australia's national science agency CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation) has opened a new national lab in Melbourne that will strengthen the country's ability to produce vaccines and drug treatments onshore.  EPA-EFE/JOEL CARRETT AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT

site_title: Europe: Markets recede at open
summary: Europe's stock markets began the week with a subdued start, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,040.66 points, and the Paris CAC 40 falling 0.3% to 6,252.44 points. This comes as interest rate hikes loom in Britain and the US to tackle soaring inflation, with the US Federal Reserve expected to announce a fourth consecutive 75 basis point rate hike on Wednesday. Investors fear rising interest rates will curb consumer spending and contribute to a global recession.

site_title: iPhone maker Foxconn lifts wages, prepares backup for Covid-hit China plant
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest iPhone plant, is preparing to bring backup production online after an exodus of workers threatened to disrupt output ahead of the holidays. The company is raising hourly wages by up to 36% to roughly 38 yuan (S$7.37) an hour for key positions, amid mounting concerns over Covid flare-ups at its main Zhengzhou plant. The move aims to keep plants running at full speed, with Foxconn also boosting capacity at alternative sites and coordinating with local authorities to address worker discontent.

site_title: Oil falls on US output gains, Chinese demand doubts
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with global benchmark Brent crude futures dropping 94 US cents to $94.83 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling $1.37 to $86.53 a barrel. US production reached nearly 12 million barrels per day in August, the highest since the pandemic. Weaker economic data from China, due to strict Covid-19 curbs, and the US administration's plan to release supplies from the Strategic Petroleum Reserves, contributed to the decline.

site_title: Blackstone to buy majority stake in Emerson's climate tech unit in US$14b deal
summary: Blackstone to acquire a majority stake in Emerson's climate tech unit in a US$14 billion deal, with Blackstone receiving an upfront payment of US$9.5 billion. Emerson will retain a 45% stake and use the upfront payment to acquire more companies, particularly in the automation segment. The deal is part of Emerson's shift towards software and automation, as the company faces a shortage of factory workers. The Climate Technologies business generated US$5 billion in net sales in 2022 and is expected to drive accelerated growth in energy-efficient heating and cooling products.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has had a majority stake in the Burlington, Massachusetts-based company since 2020.

site_title: Bird keepers in England to keep flocks indoors due to avian flu
summary: The UK government has ordered all poultry and captive birds in England to be kept indoors starting November 7 to combat the country's largest-ever avian flu outbreak. Bird keepers must follow stringent biosecurity measures, including disinfecting equipment and vehicles, and keeping mortality records. The risk to public health from the virus is considered very low, according to the UK Health Security Agency. The measures aim to prevent the spread of the disease and protect the country's bird populations.

site_title: Germany finalises details of planned gas price cap
summary: Germany's expert gas commission recommends capping gas prices at 12 euro cents per kilowatt hour (kWh) for 80% of households' basic consumption until April 2024 and 7 cents per kWh for large industrial consumers until April 2024. The cap aims to help citizens cope with soaring energy prices and encourage companies to remain in the country. The proposal, part of a 200 billion euro package, also includes direct payments and savings incentives for consumers who reduce their gas consumption. The German government is expected to adopt the proposals, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz set to decide on the key points this week.

site_title: Instagram looking into issues after user complaints
summary: Instagram is investigating an issue affecting thousands of users, with nearly 7,000 impacted, according to outage-tracking website Downdetector. The problem led to some users' accounts being suspended, requiring them to provide their email and phone number to regain access. Instagram apologized for the inconvenience and stated it is looking into the issue.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.07 points to 1,460.38. A total of 2.888 billion lots worth RM1.940 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 450 to 365.

site_title: Securities Commission Malaysia to bolster capital market with new digital-related initiatives
summary: The Securities Commission Malaysia has introduced new digital-related initiatives to bolster the capital market, aiming to accelerate the country's economic recovery. The initiatives include the registration of a new Recognised Market Operators-Digital Assets Exchange (RMO-DAX) and a RM30 million Digital Innovation Fund to encourage digitalisation. These measures will give micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) and mid-tier companies better access to funding and promote "responsible innovation" in the digital asset space.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrencies: Just how much are they wrecking the environment?

site_title: Electronic Arts strikes three-game deal with Marvel
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) has formed a three-game deal with Marvel, granting access to the popular entertainment franchise. The first game, based on Iron Man, is a single-player action-adventure game for PCs and consoles with an original story. EA's Chief Operating Officer, Laura Miele, believes this partnership can attract Marvel fans who don't play other EA titles, such as the Fifa soccer franchise. This deal follows EA's partnership with Disney's Lucasfilm for Star Wars games, and is part of EA's intentional strategy to balance its portfolio with licensed franchises.

site_title: Zinc plunges as factory data fuels concerns over steel demand
summary: Zinc prices plummeted to their lowest since March 2021 due to China's economic contraction, which added to concerns over weakening demand in the world's second-largest economy. A rebound in the dollar also made commodities priced in the currency more expensive. The decline in zinc prices, along with iron ore and steel markets, was fueled by deepening losses for China's steel makers. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, potentially leading to a global recession.

images.alt_text: Closures of smelters in Europe led by the energy crisis are causing great uncertainty in the metals sector

site_title: China: Heavily discounted, significant pessimism
summary: The 20th Chinese Communist Party Congress has led to a sharp market reaction, with the Hang Seng Index plummeting 6% on its worst single-day decline since the Global Financial Crisis. Investors are concerned over President Xi Jinping's consolidation of power, national security emphasis, and lack of positive signals on zero-Covid policy and support for the ailing property sector. However, analysts believe the knee-jerk sell-off reflects excessive pessimism, and that Xi's allies have pro-growth track records, which will lead to effective policy execution and coordination. A relaxation of zero-Covid policy is expected to boost investor confidence and economic growth, making the Hong Kong and China equity markets a long-term constructive view.

images.alt_text: Fresh lockdowns come as infections start to rise again, with China reporting 1,321 new Covid cases for Thursday, the highest tally in two weeks.

site_title: EV battery production faces supply chain, geopolitical headwinds: report
summary: S&P Global Mobility warns that a fragile supply chain and geopolitical tensions could slow electric vehicle adoption, threatening the expansion of EV battery production. The industry faces challenges in securing critical battery metals, such as lithium, nickel, and cobalt, with soaring prices and production issues. The world's top automakers plan to spend $1.2 trillion through 2030 to develop and produce electric vehicles, but achieving volume goals will require a steep growth curve for the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with a loss
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.18% to 14,687.02, closing lower due to concerns over China's economy following weak data and COVID-19 containment measures. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.77%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.38%. The losses were attributed to worries about China's economic slowdown and the impact on global markets.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate eases to 66% in October
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation rate eased to 66% in October, down from 69.8% in September, with food prices jumping 85.6% and non-food prices climbing 56.3%. The Colombo Consumer Price Index (CCPI) reflects a slower pace of food inflation, which hit a record 94.9% in September. Experts expect inflation to continue dropping over the next few months, but it may not reach single digits until after the second quarter of next year.

site_title: Concerns swell as Thailand’s telco giants prepare for US$7.3b merger
summary: Thailand's National Broadcasting and Telecommunications Commission (NBTC) has approved a US$7.3 billion merger between True and DTAC, the country's second- and third-largest mobile operators. The merger, set to take place in January 2023, has drawn criticism from consumer protection groups and economists, who warn of a duopoly in the market, potentially leading to higher service fees and reduced competition. Analysts expect the merger to benefit the two companies in terms of pricing competition and profitability, but also raises concerns about the government's commitment to creating a level playing field for foreign investors and domestic newcomers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks next to the logo of the DTAC Public Company Limited and the logo of True Corporation at a department store in Bangkok, Thailand, November 22, 2021. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Ukraine makes for unpredictable G20 summit
summary: The G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, is expected to be the most unpredictable multilateral meeting of recent years due to the ongoing Ukraine conflict. Russian President Vladimir Putin's attendance, despite being shunned by Western leaders, poses a significant challenge. The summit will focus on the world economy, energy prices, and climate change, with the potential resumption of the Black Sea grain deal being a key centrepiece. Western leaders will renew their Ukraine strategy, while Chinese President Xi Jinping has expressed a desire to improve relations with the US. The event's outcome remains uncertain, with a possibility of significant agreements being made or the summit collapsing into rancour.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen walks to a meeting between G20 finance ministers and central bank governors at the 2022 IMF/World Bank annual meeting in Washington, DC on Oct 13, 2022,

Moscow suspended its participation in the Black Sea deal on Saturday, effectively cutting shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s top grain exporters, in response to what it called a major Ukrainian drone attack earlier in the day on its fleet near the port of Sevastopol in Russian-annexed Crimea.

site_title: China bars GSK from national drug bulk-buy programme over drug irregularities
summary: China has blocked British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) from participating in its national drug procurement programme from October 31, 2022 to April 29, 2024, following a batch of dutasteride soft capsules supplied by GSK failing a quality check by the National Medical Products Administration.

site_title: Saudi Q3 GDP grows 8.6%, boosted by higher oil prices
summary: Saudi Arabia's GDP expanded by 8.6% in the third quarter compared to the same period in 2021, driven by a 14.5% increase in oil activities. Non-oil activities also grew 5.6%. The country's fiscal figures showed revenues rose 24% to 301.87 billion riyals, while expenses increased 22% to 287.73 billion riyals. A budget surplus of 14.14 billion riyals was reported, with oil revenues reaching 229.02 billion riyals. Despite a slight pullback, Saudi is expected to achieve a healthy fiscal surplus in 2022 due to strong oil revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia has committed to rebuilding holdings depleted during years of subdued crude prices as it takes a different approach to spend its oil windfall.

site_title: Twitter to lay off 25 per cent of workforce in first round of job cuts: Washington Post
summary: Twitter plans to lay off nearly 1,500 employees, a quarter of its workforce, as part of its first round of job cuts. The move comes after billionaire Elon Musk's acquisition of the company. The layoffs are expected to be part of a broader restructuring effort. The number of employees at Twitter had reached nearly 7,000 at the end of 2021.

site_title: Indonesia revokes firms’ fever syrup licences amid inquiry into 150 deaths
summary: Indonesia's food and drug agency has revoked licenses for two local firms producing fever syrup due to manufacturing rule violations. The move comes amid an investigation into the deaths of over 150 children due to acute kidney injury (AKI) linked to the syrups. The agency found solvents in the syrups contained impurities, and the firms failed to report changes in ingredients and used excessive materials. The agency is pursuing criminal action against the firms and is also investigating distributors to see if they supplied materials to other pharmaceutical firms.

site_title: US dollar climbs as traders eye central bankers
summary: The US dollar is expected to decline in October for the first time since May, with only two instances this year, due to potential less aggressive rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The dollar advanced against the euro, sterling, and Japanese yen, as traders await central bank meetings, including the BOE and Fed policy meeting. The dollar's decline is attributed to expectations of a shift in the Fed's rate hike program.

site_title: Clear link between board diversity and corporate performance
summary: A study suggests that corporate performance is linked to board diversity, with diverse boards making more holistic and considered decisions. The absence of diverse perspectives may lead to faster, but less robust, decision-making. Experts emphasize the importance of a wide range of views, experience, and backgrounds in board composition, particularly in uncertain and rapidly changing environments. The push for board diversity has led to increased transparency and action from regulators and large institutional investors, with Singapore making progress in achieving targets for board diversity, from 20% to 30% among top listed companies and statutory boards.

site_title: Russian rouble weakens after Moscow suspends Black Sea grain deal
summary: The Russian rouble weakened 0.6% against the US dollar and 0.3% against the euro after Moscow suspended participation in the Black Sea grain deal, citing a major Ukrainian drone attack on its Black Sea fleet in Crimea. Global food prices rose, and analysts warned of another potential spike. The rouble also declined 1.2% against Brent crude oil, and experts predict it could fall to 65 against the US dollar by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of thousands of tonnes of wheat meant for Africa and the Middle East are at risk after Russia’s withdrawal from the grain shipment deal.
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority doesn’t maintain any form of sanctions or designations lists but said in March that it’s up to banks to assess such risks.

site_title: Lianhe Zaobao inks MOU to trial AI technology for visual content
summary: Chinese publication Lianhe Zaobao has signed a memorandum of understanding with AI company SenseTime to trial the use of artificial intelligence technology for visual content. The partnership aims to enhance visual content and provide audiences with a more immersive reading experience. Lianhe Zaobao will use SenseTime's AI technology to "enhance" its visual content, including photojournalists' work processes and experiments with augmented and mixed reality imaging technologies. The one-year MOU includes joint public seminars and AI boot camps for student correspondents.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
AI has the potential to inform users of their propensity to contract diseases such as diabetes.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as investors await Fed signal
summary: US stock markets opened lower on October 31, 2022, as investors await the US Federal Reserve's signal on inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 107.53 points, or 0.33%, to 32,754.27. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, with declines of 19.21 points, or 0.49%, and 74.02 points, or 0.67%, respectively. The mixed earnings reports and expectations of a potential easing of the Fed's hawkish stance on inflation contributed to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 07: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on October 07, 2022 in New York City. Stocks fell in early trading on Friday as new employment numbers show steady hiring which investors fear will lead to increased interest rate hikes.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: India’s April-Sep fiscal deficit touches 6.20 trillion rupees, tax receipts rise
summary: India's fiscal deficit for the April to September period reached 6.20 trillion rupees (S$106 billion), or 37.3% of annual estimates. Despite a higher subsidy bill, rising tax collections helped offset the deficit. Total expenditure for the first six months was 18.24 trillion rupees, up from 16.26 trillion rupees a year earlier. The government aims to spend nearly 40 trillion rupees in the current financial year, with inflation expected to slow down. The fiscal deficit target of 6.4% of gross domestic product for 2022/23 may be met despite growing concerns about a shortfall in receipts.

site_title: Atthaya Thitikul rises to No 1 in women’s world rankings
summary: Thailand's 19-year-old golfer Atthaya Thitikul has reached No. 1 in the women's world rankings, surpassing Jin Young Ko. Thitikul is the 16th player to achieve this feat and the second from Thailand, following Ariya Jutanugarn. She is also the second player under 20 to reach No. 1, joining Lydia Ko. Thitikul credits her team, family, and supporters for her achievement, stating she will continue to work hard to retain her position.

site_title: Italian economy unexpectedly grows in boost to new PM Meloni
summary: Italy's economy unexpectedly expanded 0.5% in the third quarter, defying expectations of stagnation. The growth was driven by gains in services and inventories, with trade acting as a drag. This surprise outcome is a boost to new Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's efforts to balance slowing growth with continued fiscal aid to households and businesses struggling amid the energy crunch caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Hong Kong economy shrinks 4.5% in Q3, outlook remains weak
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 4.5% in Q3, its third straight quarter of downturn, due to ongoing Covid-19 restrictions. The contraction was worse than projected, exceeding forecasts of 0.6-0.9% growth. This marks the deepest contraction since Q2 2020, when the city's GDP shrank 9.4% due to the pandemic. The weak external demand outlook remains a concern for the city's economy, which has been weighed down by Covid-19 restrictions since early 2020.

images.alt_text: Regulators are seeking to allow listings of bigger tokens but won’t endorse specific coins like Bitcoin or Ether.

site_title: Biden calls on oil, gas companies to stop ‘war profiteering,’ threatens windfall tax
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized major oil companies for making record profits while Americans struggle with high inflation and pump prices. He called on oil and gas companies to lower costs for Americans, increase production, or pay a higher tax rate. Biden accused the industry of "war profiteering" and threatened to urge Congress to consider tax penalties and restrictions if they don't comply. The White House will work with Congress to explore options, including a windfall tax, to address the issue ahead of the upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden delivers remarks at the Pennsylvania Democratic Party's third annual Independence Dinner in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S., October 28, 2022. Reuters/Tasos Katopodis

site_title: Malaysia questions 18 people arrested at LGBT Halloween party
summary: Malaysia's Islamic authorities questioned 18 people arrested during an LGBT Halloween party in Kuala Lumpur, amid concerns over the country's growing intolerance towards the LGBT community. The 20 arrested individuals were accused of violating Islamic laws on cross-dressing and indecent acts. The arrests come amid a dual-track legal system, with Islamic laws applicable to Muslims and civil laws running alongside. Human rights groups and activists have condemned the state's actions, calling it "state oppression" and "targeted persecution."

images.alt_text: Miss Universe's new owner Anne Jakkaphong Jakrajutatip and Thailand’s first transgender CEO also plans to roll out a new line of vitamin water in Thailand by early next year, before potentially expanding into Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Amazon says India’s Appario to stop selling on platform
summary: Amazon India is ending its relationship with Appario, a joint venture partnership between Amazon and India's Patni group, after allegations of giving preferential treatment to the seller. The move comes after a Reuters investigation revealed Amazon gave preferential treatment to a small group of sellers, including Appario, to bypass Indian laws. Amazon has maintained it complies with all laws, but agreed to end its relationship with another seller, Cloudtail, last year. Appario will cease listing products on Amazon India, effective immediately.

images.alt_text: The ranks of companies with valuations in excess of US$1 trillion have thinned this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise for 5th straight session amid Fed pivot hopes; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose for the 5th consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 1.1% to 3,093.11, driven by optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting this week. Investors are hopeful for a pivot in the Fed's monetary policy, which could lead to lower interest rate hikes. Key gainers included UOB, Raffles Medical Group, and Wilmar International, with some 1.82 billion securities worth S$1.68 billion traded locally.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Wellington all piled on more than 1 per cent, while Sydney and Jakarta stock markets were also up.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumped 1.78 per cent, or 482.26 points, to end at 27,587.46.
The S&P/ASX 200 index ends 1.2 per cent higher at 6,863.5.

site_title: Muay Thai's Olympic quest slowed by safety concerns
summary: Muay Thai, Thailand's national sport, is facing safety concerns that may slow its path to Olympic inclusion. A recent death of a 25-year-old fighter due to an elbow strike has highlighted the need for better safety measures, including more stringent rules and inspections. The International Federation of Muay Thai Associations (IFMA) insists the sport is safe, but acknowledges that bouts organized privately in rural areas can be harder to police. The Thai authorities have increased efforts to enforce rules and provide medical attention, but critics argue that stricter safety requirements would dilute the sport's character.

images.alt_text: Why SPH's Anthony Tan is hooked on Muay Thai
A different live atmosphere, but plenty of thrills and spills

site_title: Record plunge in China property giant's stock after chair quits
summary: China property giant Longfor Group Holdings saw its stock plummet 45% on October 31 after chairwoman Wu Yajun resigned due to age and health reasons. The company's share price rallied to close down 23.8% at HK$10 per share. Wu's departure comes amid a brewing crisis in China's real estate sector, with the firm citing a "clear development direction" and a "healthy and safe" financial position. Analysts have expressed concerns that the crisis could spread to the country's financial sector, further exacerbating the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Closing ceremony of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress on Oct 22. Investors were disappointed by the lack of positive signals on China's zero-Covid policy and support for the property sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher extending US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on October 31, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.78% to 27,587.46, and the Topix index rising 1.60% to 1,929.43. The gains were led by big gains from Apple, extending US rallies.

site_title: ANA Holdings posts half-year profit, raises full-year target
summary: ANA Holdings, Japan's largest airline, posted a half-year profit of 31.45 billion yen, up from a loss of 116 billion yen in the same period last year. The company raised its full-year earnings target to 65 billion yen, citing a recovery in travel demand due to relaxed Covid-19 border measures. ANA expects to return to pre-pandemic performance levels over fiscal year 2023-2025 and be back on a growth trajectory from fiscal 2026, although the Ukraine-Russia conflict poses a risk to this plan.

images.alt_text: To boost business, Narita Airport chief executive Akihiko Tamura said Narita needed to shift from being focused on Japanese consumers to offering a store line-up that serves overseas and transit travellers better.

site_title: Oil demand here to stay, say Saudi, UAE
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman and UAE's Sultan Al Jaber said the world needs to continue investing in oil production, despite climate concerns, as it's essential for energy security and meeting growing global demands. They emphasized that oil remains a cornerstone of energy supply, but are working to lower emissions and increase production from renewable sources. The two officials warned that underinvestment in oil production could cause a significant shock to the global economy, citing the need to cater to a growing population of 9.7 billion by 2050.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled up US$1.27, or 1.3 per cent, to US$96.96 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settled up US$1.17, or 1.3 per cent, to US$89.08 a barrel.
The Aramco sustainability fund will initially focus on carbon capture and storage, greenhouse gas emissions, as well as hydrogen, ammonia and synthetic fuels.

site_title: Amoxicillin in short supply in US, FDA says
summary: The FDA reports that four US drugmakers, Aurobindo Pharma, Hikma Pharmaceutical, Novartis' Sandoz unit, and Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, have limited supply of some liquid amoxicillin doses for kids, affecting nearly 99.8% of liquid amoxicillin prescriptions dispensed at US retail pharmacies this year. The shortage is attributed to supply constraints for certain formulations of the antibiotic, commonly used to treat conditions like ear infections and strep throat in children. Authorities in Australia and Canada are also reporting shortages of the medicine.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end month with biggest gain in nearly two years
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 25.21 points or 1.11% to 2,293.61 on October 31, ending the month with its largest gain in 22 months. The benchmark index jumped 6.41% in October, driven by tech giants Samsung Electronics and Naver, while heavyweights such as SK Hynix and LG Energy Solution fell. Foreigners purchased a net 3.3 trillion won in shares for the month, with the Korean won ending the month with a 0.41% gain, its first in five months.

images.alt_text: The benchmark KOSPI fell 20.38 points, or 0.89 per cent, to close at 2,268.40, but still notched a 2.50 per cent gain for the week.

site_title: China doubles down on coal despite its green ambitions
summary: China is building new coal-fired power stations, despite its goal of becoming a global leader in clean energy, as it seeks to address global energy supply concerns and create a buffer against volatile fuel prices. At least 165 gigawatts of new plants are expected to be built by the end of 2023, with a total of 270 gigawatts planned for the next five years. This move reflects China's strategy of gradually phasing out coal as a primary power source and transitioning to renewables, while also ensuring reliable energy supply during periods of high demand.

images.alt_text: High imports of liquefied natural gas means even more fuel is being injected into brimming storage sites.

site_title: Digital payments hold key to untapped e-commerce growth in S-E Asia
summary: A Google-led study predicts the digital payment market in South-east Asia will reach US$2 trillion by 2030, driven by a growing digital economy and increasing adoption of alternative payment options such as e-wallets and cryptocurrency. The study highlights the need for merchants to offer seamless and local payment options to consumers, who are increasingly looking for convenience and faster payment processes. To capitalize on this trend, businesses must invest in integrating local payment options and interoperability between payment providers, with regional collaboration and infrastructure development seen as key to unlocking the region's untapped e-commerce growth.

images.alt_text: Angel Zhao, president of Ant’s international business group, says e-wallets are a “valuable and effective” channel for digital marketing.
MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.

site_title: ‘Dreaming of the Heavens’: China launches final module to space station
summary: China launched the final module of its space station, the Mengtian, atop the Long March 5B rocket, marking the completion of the "Celestial Palace" space station. The 23-tonne module, a laboratory, is expected to dock with the main Tianhe module, and the station will be the second permanently inhabited outpost in low-Earth orbit after the International Space Station. The station is designed for a lifespan of at least 10 years and will host over 1,000 scientific experiments, with potential collaborations with international partners if the ISS retires.

site_title: Australia: Shares post best monthly gain since March; RBA decision in focus
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.2% to a 6,863.5 index value, posting their best monthly gain since March, ahead of a likely interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Retail sales rose 0.6% in September, despite high inflation and interest rates. Analysts expect ongoing interest rate rises to dampen discretionary spending growth. The RBA is set to raise interest rates for a seventh consecutive month, with a 25 basis point hike expected.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 1.2 per cent at 6,864.4 points, as of 0017 GMT on Monday.

site_title: London looks to drive New Delhi trade deal forward
summary: The UK and India are working to finalize a trade deal, with UK Trade Minister Greg Hands stating that 16 chapters of the 26 policy areas have been agreed upon. The deal aims to increase economic and security collaboration between the two nations, with a focus on defense manufacturing, international investment, and technology. However, challenges remain, including UK immigration reform to facilitate Indian businesspeople and students to travel to Britain. Despite these issues, the economic relationship between the two countries is dominating bilateral ties, overshadowing long-standing controversies over human rights in India.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past paintings of new Conservative Party leader and incoming British prime minister Rishi Sunak in Mumbai on Oct 25, 2022. Sunak on Thursday told his Indian counterpart Narendra Modi he “hoped” they could agree a trade pact, Downing Street said.

site_title: Sakae CFO wrongly bought back shares at a price above permissible level
summary: Sakae Holdings, a restaurant operator, has suspended its share buyback program after its CFO, Tan Yiok Ping, wrongly bought back shares at a price above the maximum allowed. The CFO purchased 500,000 shares at S$0.118, exceeding the 105% limit of the average closing price of S$0.104. The purchase was only realized at the end of the trading day, and the company has directed management and the board to suspend the buyback. The incident is considered insignificant, with the purchased shares representing only 0.35% of the company's total issued shares.

images.alt_text: The storefront of a Sakae Sushi outlet in Junction 8 shopping mall.

site_title: Chinese developer Greenland says it’s likely to default on bond
summary: Chinese developer Greenland Holding Group is likely to default on a $362 million dollar bond due November 13, citing significant declines in sales and operations due to the Covid-19 situation in Shanghai and negative market conditions. The company is also seeking to extend the maturity of other bonds by two years. This move threatens to exacerbate China's junk dollar bond market, which has suffered a 11% loss in October.

images.alt_text: China’s housing market remains fragile despite a wave of measures to restore confidence that’s been battered by Covid Zero and a debt crisis among cash-strapped developers.

site_title: Japfa 9M FY2022 net profit down 59% to US$46.3 million
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, reported a 59% drop in net profit to US$46.3 million for the first nine months of FY2022, despite a 10% increase in revenue to US$3.7 billion. Operating profit fell 16% to US$223.7 million, with a 1.9 percentage point drop in operating profit margin to 6%. The decline in net profit is attributed to higher operating costs.

images.alt_text: In a bourse filing on Friday (Oct 14) by Japfa's chief executive Tan Yong Nang, the company warned that there is no assurance that the proposed distribution or listing would materialise at all in due course.
Japfa chief executive officer, Tan Yong Nang says the company will remain focused being efficient and lowest cost producers in their markets

site_title: Firm property prices are a silver lining as rising interest rates batter listed property plays
summary: Singapore's listed property groups and trusts are experiencing a silver lining amidst rising interest rates, thanks to the resilience of property prices and rental rates. Despite higher interest rates adding costs and depressing profitability, the groups' pricing power and ability to sell overseas assets at above valuation help mitigate the impact. Some Reits have reported positive rental reversions and growth in net property income, and private home prices rose 13.6% in Q3 2022, with new home sales exceeding expectations. However, the equities market may be pricing in headwinds from higher interest rates, and demand for physical properties is expected to support capital values and rental rates.

images.alt_text: Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

site_title: Manufacturing expectations still pessimistic, services sector less upbeat: surveys
summary: Singapore manufacturers remain pessimistic about business conditions, with a net weighted balance of 20% expecting a less favourable situation in the next six months, up from 8% previously. Services firms are less positive, with a net weighted balance of 9% optimistic, down from 15%. Supply chain challenges, operational cost pressures, and weaker macroeconomic conditions are cited as factors weighing on demand. The economic climate is deteriorating, with most manufacturing clusters expecting output to fall and only transport engineering and general manufacturing expecting boosts to production.

images.alt_text: In 2023, Singapore's growth is likely to be dragged by the trade-related cluster amid weaker external demand., according to Monetary Authority of Singapore's half-yearly macroeconomic review.
Singapore factory output rises 0.9% in September but remains weak

“Many semiconductor companies operating in Singapore have manufacturing processes and products that rely on US technology, which may be subject to export controls imposed by the US government,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.
Overall, hotel room revenues surge to S$390.8 million for the month, surpassing August 2019’s S$383.4 million to mark a new high.

site_title: Macau reimposes Covid curbs as China loosens visa rules for gambling hub
summary: Macau authorities have reimposed COVID-19 curbs, including a 2-day lockdown of the MGM Cotai casino, after detecting a handful of cases. All 700,000 residents are mandated to take rapid antigen tests daily and an official PCR test on Tuesday. China has loosened visa rules for visitors to Macau, allowing mainland residents to use an online visa system starting November 1. This move is seen as a boon for Macau's return to normalcy, with shares in Hong Kong-listed Macau casinos rising. A decision on new casino licences may be made as early as this week.

images.alt_text: Government health workers were at the MGM Cotai site with no one allowed to enter or exit the building, industry publication Inside Asian Gaming says.

site_title: Europe: Shares notch monthly gain on Fed pivot hopes, robust earnings
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% to a six-week high, marking its first monthly gain in three, driven by a strong earnings season and hopes of a US Federal Reserve pivot on interest rate hikes. Despite record-high inflation in the euro zone, the ECB is expected to prioritize price stability and press on with rate hikes. Investors will also focus on the Bank of England policy meeting later in the week, with bets running high of it maintaining its hawkish stance.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1 per cent to 7,040.66 points, compared with the close on Friday.

site_title: Four Malaysian telcos agree to use state 5G network
summary: Four Malaysian mobile operators, Celcom Axiata, DiGi Telecommunications, Telekom Malaysia, and U Mobile, have signed agreements to access the 5G network run by state agency Digital Nasional Berhad for 10 years. This move paves the way for 5G services to be rolled out to customers after months of delayed talks. The government's state-owned 5G network aims to reduce costs, improve efficiency, and speed up infrastructure works, despite concerns about a nationalised monopoly.

site_title: Crop ships still leaving Ukraine despite Russian move to ditch grain deal
summary: Crop ships continue to leave Ukraine despite Russia's suspension of its involvement in the grain deal, with the UN and Turkey working to salvage the agreement. Wheat prices rose 6.5% on Monday, and US President Joe Biden warned it would increase starvation. The UN agreed to allow vessels carrying food to depart from Ukraine, with inspections continuing at the Istanbul coordination center. Russian delegates were informed that Russia has only temporarily suspended its participation in the deal, and new vessels are scheduled to arrive at Ukrainian ports.

images.alt_text: epa10080336 A truck unloading wheat on an agricultural farm not far from the front line in the Chuhuiv region of Kharkiv area, Ukraine, 19 July 2022 amid the Russian invasion. Ukraine faces logistic problems exporting its harvest to the world market due to the Russian invasion which is taking a toll on the country's exports of grains and vegetable oils. Turkish, Ukrainian, Russian, and UN officials on 13 July agreed on mesaures to facilitate Ukrainian grain exports. Turkish president Erdogan at a three-way summit on Syria on 19 July called Russia's approach to get Ukrainian grain stuck at Black Sea ports out of the country as "positive." Russian troops on 24 February entered Ukrainian territory, starting a conflict that has provoked destruction and a humanitarian crisis.  EPA-EFE/SERGEY KOZLOV

site_title: Australia’s housing downturn persists as RBA seen hiking further
summary: Australia's housing market continued to decline in October, with home prices falling 1.1% in major cities and 1.2% nationally. Sydney prices slid 1.3% for a ninth consecutive monthly fall, while Melbourne dropped 0.8% and Brisbane decreased 2%. The Reserve Bank is expected to hike interest rates by a quarter percentage point, further weighing on the market. Economists predict rates will exceed 3% in coming months, with some predicting a cash rate of 4% next year. The housing downturn remains "orderly" due to below-average new listings.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Dow snaps six-day streak
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, snapping the Dow's six-day winning streak, as markets await the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. China's manufacturing index fell to 49.2, and the Eurozone economic growth rate dropped to 0.2% due to inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes fell 0.8% and 1.0%, respectively. Analysts attributed the losses to profit taking after strong October gains, and investors expect the Fed to hike interest rates again to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 07: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on October 07, 2022 in New York City. Stocks fell in early trading on Friday as new employment numbers show steady hiring which investors fear will lead to increased interest rate hikes.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Senior citizens break digital barriers with help from DBS
summary: DBS Foundation's volunteer initiative, People of Purpose, has helped seniors over 60 years old adapt to the digital world through cybersecurity workshops and anti-scam education. The workshops, led by DBS volunteers, taught seniors how to spot and avoid common scams such as impersonation, phishing, and job scams. Additionally, DBS volunteers accompanied seniors on sponsored grocery shopping trips and provided them with Nets Flashpay cards to learn e-payment skills. The initiative aims to empower seniors with digital skills and knowledge to protect themselves from scams.

images.alt_text:
Cheah Kim Teck (first from left - back row), board member, Mapletree Investments with the champion team from
Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank who won the Mapletree Futsal Challenge 2022.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says Apple among high-profile tenants at new Riyadh economic zone
summary: Saudi Arabia has opened its first integrated special-economic zone in Riyadh, attracting high-profile tenants like Apple, which will base a regional distribution centre and may set up assembly line and repair work. The zone offers exemptions from certain taxes and labour regulations, aiming to lure international firms and attract foreign talent. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 agenda to diversify the economy and boost air-freight, aiming to increase it fivefold and open up the economy.

site_title: Eurozone’s inflation soars past forecasts to record high
summary: Eurozone inflation surged to a record high of 10.7% in October, surpassing forecasts and pointing to further interest rate hikes from the European Central Bank. Energy prices drove inflation, but food and industrial goods also pushed prices higher, despite a decrease in gas prices. The ECB has raised rates 200 basis points in the past three months and is expected to hike again in December, with policymakers concerned about broadening price pressures and the risk of entrenched high inflation.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) increased by 0.3 per cent compared to the previous quarter in seasonally adjusted terms, the Germany's federal statistics office.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust launches IFC’s first sustainability-linked bond in hospitality sector
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust has launched its first sustainability-linked bond in the hospitality sector globally, partnering with the International Finance Corporation (IFC). The 7-year, 157.4 million SGD bond has a fixed coupon rate of 1.05% and will be used to refinance existing borrowings and decarbonize three serviced residences in South-east Asia. IFC is the sole subscriber to the 16.5 billion yen bond, which matures on November 7, 2029.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.

site_title: Hong Kong’s negative equity mortgage cases surge in Q3
summary: Hong Kong's negative equity mortgage cases surged in Q3 with 533 cases estimated at the end of September, involving HK$3 billion. This represents a near ninefold increase from the previous quarter and the highest since 2016. The surge was attributed to a 3.8% fall in home prices during the period.

site_title: Capitaland Ascendas Reit posts 5.4% rental reversion in Q3
summary: Capitaland Ascendas Reit posted a 5.4% positive rental reversion for Q3, down from 13.2% in Q2. The Reit expects FY2022 rental reversion to be in the "positive mid-single digit range". Occupancy rose to 94.5% globally, with 91.8% in Singapore and 99.1% in Australia. Despite a decline in US occupancy, the Reit's portfolio occupancy and weighted average lease expiry (WALE) remained stable. The company has implemented a higher service charge in Singapore to mitigate rising expenses.

images.alt_text: Some S-Reits, such as CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, will be seen as a safe haven because it has demonstrated over time that it is very stable, says William Tay, CEO of the manager.
The office property at 6055 Lusk Boulevard in San Diego, to be converted into a life sciences building, will serve as Crinetics Pharmaceuticals new headquarters.

site_title: US suggests EU consider using export limits to target China
summary: The US has suggested to the European Union that it consider using export limits to target China, drawing from lessons learned from the export control regime used to punish Russia. US officials are exploring ways to reinforce bilateral restrictions on exports to China, but the EU is hesitant to follow the same approach due to differing circumstances. The US and EU are set to meet in December to discuss economic plans, including joint development of digital infrastructure projects and an artificial intelligence roadmap.

site_title: Swiss National Bank’s balance sheet shrinks nearly 8% in September, data shows
summary: The Swiss National Bank's balance sheet decreased by nearly 8% in September, with a 55.4 billion Swiss franc decline in foreign currency investments. The bank's balance sheet now stands at 889.5 billion francs, down from 964.6 billion francs in August. The decline was primarily due to the decrease in the value of foreign investments, resulting from a plunge in stock and bond valuations and the high value of the Swiss franc.

site_title: Japan likely spent record amount in October to prop up yen
summary: Japan is likely to have spent a record 5.4 trillion yen (S$51.6 billion) on currency intervention in October to prop up the yen, nearly double the previous month's amount. The intervention helped trigger an immediate drop in the dollar, but the yen has since come under renewed pressure. The Bank of Japan's ultra-low interest rates and solid US consumer spending data have contributed to the yen's decline. Japan's Ministry of Finance will announce the total amount spent on intervention from September 29 to October 27 on Monday.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan bucked the trend among other major central banks and stuck with ultra-low interest rates.

Authorities’ so-called stealth intervention in rapid succession has underscored their resolve in fighting what they have characterised as “intolerable and speculative” yen-selling, although the impact has proved short-lived.

site_title: Police arrest nine over Indian bridge collapse, toll reaches 134
summary: Indian police have arrested nine people, including ticketing clerks and contractors, over the collapse of a footbridge in Morbi that killed at least 134 people, including many children. The bridge, which was packed with sightseers celebrating holidays, ruptured on Sunday evening, sending people into the river. CCTV footage showed a group of young men taking photos while others tried to rock the bridge, leading to its collapse. The Indian government has condemned the tragedy, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi set to visit the area, and an investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: A damaged part of a suspension bridge after it collapsed in Morbi town in the western state of Gujarat, India, Oct 30, 2022.

site_title: Shanghai Disney Resort shuts over Covid, visitors unable to leave
summary: Shanghai Disney Resort suspended operations on October 31, 2022, due to Covid-19 prevention measures. The park locked its gates, and visitors were directed to stay until they tested negative for the virus. Those who visited since October 27 needed to test three times in three days. The closure follows the Shanghai government's decision to bar people from entering or exiting the park and awaiting test results. This marks the latest disruption for the resort, which was previously shut for over three months during Shanghai's lockdown earlier in the year.

images.alt_text: Shanghai's Disney resort shut amid record daily local Covid-19 infections
Parts of Shanghai began imposing new lockdown restrictions on Thursday.

site_title: China home sales drop 28% as Covid flare-up adds to risks
summary: China's home sales plummeted 28.4% in October, with new-home sales reaching 556.1 billion yuan, down from a year earlier. The decline widens from a 25.4% slump in September. Despite government measures to restore confidence, including easing home ownership rules and trimming interest rates, the housing market remains fragile due to the ongoing Covid Zero policies and debt crisis among cash-strapped developers.

images.alt_text: Longfor's plunge comes on the heels of billionaire founder and chairwoman Wu Yajun’s departure.

site_title: 'Black Adam' stays atop North America box office
summary: "Black Adam" remains atop the North America box office for the second weekend, earning an estimated $27.7 million in North American box office receipts. It is followed by Universal's "Ticket to Paradise" with $10 million, and Lionsgate's "Prey for the Devil" with $7 million. Horror films, including "Smile" and "Halloween Ends," also performed well, but overall box office earnings were down from the previous weekend, totaling $66 million.

images.alt_text: Black Adam, starring Dwayne Johnson, is the first live-action DC film since the closing of a merger in April to form Warner Bros Discovery

site_title: Japan looks 6,000m under the sea for rare earths to counter China, report says
summary: Japan plans to explore for rare earths 6,000 meters under the sea to counter China's dominance of the critical minerals used in electronics and weapons. The government aims to start developing extraction methods near the Ogasawara islands in fiscal 2024 and begin prospecting within five years. Private companies will be allowed to enter the market from fiscal 2028, following a technology tested in Japan's coastal waters. The move aims to reduce Japan's reliance on China for rare earths, which controls most of the world's mined output of the 17 elements.

site_title: Kitchen Culture affirms Nov 1 EGM will not proceed, says requisitioners ‘caused confusion’ with ad
summary: Kitchen Culture, a kitchen systems provider, announced that an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) intended to remove five of its six directors will not proceed as scheduled on Nov 1. The company criticized requisitioners for causing confusion among shareholders and the public with a misleading advertisement, which stated the EGM was postponed. Kitchen Culture claims the requisitioners failed to inform the board of directors of the change and that the advertisement was "sudden and without explanation." The company has received calls from shareholders expressing confusion and frustration, and will write to the requisitioners for clarifications.

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.
Kitchen Culture shareholders fail to confirm whether EGM notices have been sent out
Kitchen Culture is in the midst of taking legal advice on the validity of the EGM Notice by a group of shareholders.
Ooway's clarification comes nearly a week after Kitchen Culture's board claimed Ooway had made statements with various “factual inaccuracies and mischaracterisation of events”.

site_title: Gardenia bread-maker QAF appoints Philip Yeo as independent non-executive director
summary: QAF Limited, the manufacturer and distributor of Gardenia bread, appointed Philip Yeo as an independent non-executive director, effective Tuesday. Yeo, a former top civil servant, is known for his role in developing Singapore's economy while leading the Economic Development Board and A*Star. The appointment was made after considering his extensive global experience and network. This move is seen as an addition to Yeo's existing roles in more than 20 companies, including Accuron Technologies and City Developments Limited.

site_title: Bukalapak’s Q3 revenue rises 86% to 898b rupiah on lower cost base
summary: Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak reported an 86% growth in revenue to 898 billion rupiah in Q3, driven by a lower cost base and a 53% increase in its online-to-offline business segment. The company's nine-month revenue nearly doubled to 2.6 trillion rupiah, with a net profit of 3.6 billion rupiah. Bukalapak aims to focus on growing the top line while maintaining a positive contribution margin.

images.alt_text: President Joko Widodo said that the South-east Asian nation will shift its economy into producing more value-added goods and away from purely selling raw materials.
Indonesia is seeing new startups like Octopus, which aid recycling efforts through training leading to a less than 1 per cent rejection rate with recyclers.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival launches with over 850 speakers to feature in week-long programme
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival (SFF) has launched with over 850 speakers and 250 hours of content, marking its return as an in-person event after a two-year hiatus. The festival, which runs until November 4, features over 450 exhibitors and 25 international pavilions, with participants expected from more than 110 countries. The event aims to address the industry's shift towards Web3, digital assets, and an ESG-focused economy, with Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong set to open the conference on November 2.

images.alt_text: MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.

site_title: Credit Suisse plans to push ahead with China expansion after overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse plans to expand in China and Hong Kong despite a global overhaul that includes thousands of job cuts. The bank's Asia-Pacific chief executive, Edwin Low, said China and Hong Kong will be the biggest growth market for Credit Suisse in the next five years. A report in September forecast the number of Chinese millionaires will double by 2026, and Credit Suisse has struck a deal to buy out its Chinese partner in a local securities joint venture. The bank aims to simplify operations in Asia-Pacific and set up a locally incorporated bank in China.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse announced a radical restructuring programme on Thursday which basically marks a major retreat from investment banking for Switzerland’s number two lender.

site_title: South Korea mourns Halloween crowd surge victims
summary: South Korea mourns the 154 people killed in a deadly crowd surge at Halloween celebrations in Seoul on October 31, 2022. Authorities faced criticism for lax crowd control, with many accusing them of failing to prevent the disaster. Mourners paid tribute at memorials, with some calling for accountability and better policing measures. The government defended its plan, citing that deploying police and firefighters in advance couldn't solve the problem. The country is in a week of national mourning, with flags flying at half-mast and entertainment events cancelled.

images.alt_text: The cordoned off area where a deadly stampede took place  Choi Sung-beom, head of the Yongsan Fire Station, says 151 deaths had been confirmed, including 22 foreigners and that 82 people were injured, 19 of them seriously

site_title: Hong Kong’s number of unsold new homes rises to 15-year high due to downturn
summary: Hong Kong's unsold new homes reached a 15-year high of 15,000 in the third quarter, driven by Covid restrictions, rising interest rates, and economic downturn. Property developers have priced new projects lower to attract buyers, while secondary sales decreased by 37% and prices fell almost 9% since the beginning of the year. Goldman Sachs predicts a 30% drop in home prices through 2023. The rising inventory and economic woes underscore the challenges facing Hong Kong's property sector, which plays a significant role in the city's economy.

images.alt_text: Regulators globally are grappling with how to oversee the volatile digital-asset sector, which is picking up the pieces of a US$2 trillion rout over roughly the past year.
Hong Kong is anxious to maintain its standing as a global finance hub.

site_title: Hong Kong moves towards legalising retail-investor crypto trading
summary: Hong Kong is set to begin a consultation on legalizing retail-investor crypto trading, aiming to create a hub for digital tokens and restore its status as a financial center. The consultation will focus on giving retail investors a suitable degree of access, with the city open to listing crypto exchange-traded funds and reviewing property rights for tokenized assets. This move comes as regulators globally grapple with overseeing the volatile digital-asset sector, following a US$2 trillion rout over the past year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is anxious to maintain its standing as a global finance hub.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical, CapitaLand China Trust, CapitaLand India Trust, MPACT
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 62.1% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$38.3 million in Q3. CapitaLand China Trust and CapitaLand India Trust also saw gains, with 7% and 13% increases in gross revenue, respectively. Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust posted a 12.5% increase in distribution per unit, while Wilmar's net profit rose 34.7% to US$766.2 million.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index finished Friday’s (Oct 28) trading session 1.5 per cent or 43.95 points higher at 3,059.19.

site_title: UK business confidence drops to lowest since pandemic lockdown
summary: UK business confidence has dropped to its lowest level since March 2021, falling 1 point to 15% in Lloyds Bank's October survey. Despite this, some firms expect an improvement in trading prospects, with 49% reporting a better outlook. The drop in confidence comes after Liz Truss's resignation and the new government's reversal of tax cuts. Energy price increases and pressure on pay expectations are expected to worsen economic uncertainty in the winter months.

images.alt_text: Workers walk towards Tower Bridge in London, Britain, September 15, 2021. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Stellantis says Jeep joint venture in China to file for bankruptcy
summary: Stellantis' joint venture with Guangzhou Automobile Group (GAC) in China's Jeep production is filing for bankruptcy, following a sharp decline in sales over the past four years. The venture, which sold fewer than 2,000 vehicles in 2022, was terminated by Stellantis in July after it raised its stake in the business to 75%. Stellantis will continue to provide service to Jeep customers in China, while GAC has approved the bankruptcy filing. This move is part of a broader trend of foreign automakers struggling in China's market, where domestic brands have gained significant market share.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of Stellantis at the entrance of the company's factory in Hordain, France, July 7, 2021. REUTERS/Pascal Rossignol/File Photo
The deadline to seek a buyout is Dec 5.
Stellantis is mulling the potential exit as more established foreign auto brands have struggled to maintain their position in China’s market.

site_title: Australian dollar wobbles ahead of RBA, New Zealand dollar having best month in a year
summary: The Australian dollar wobbled ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy rate decision, trading around US$0.6414. The New Zealand dollar enjoyed its best month in a year, rising 3.6% for October on hawkish rate hike expectations. Analysts predict a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the RBA, with some economists calling for a 50 basis point rise, potentially narrowing the interest rate differential between Australia and the US.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices in Australia rose at the fastest pace in 32 years at 7.3 per cent, while core inflation accelerated to an annual 6.1 per cent - further away from the RBA’s target band of 2-3 per cent.
The RBA’s 2.5 percentage points of hikes over six months have sent house prices tumbling, reversing the wealth effect.

site_title: Apple workers in Australia gear up for more strike action
summary: Apple workers in Australia rejected a proposed workplace agreement, with 68% of employees voting against the deal. The agreement, proposed by management, included locked-in wage rises and conditions that unions claimed would lead to real wage cuts and poor work-life balance. The Retail and Fast Food Workers Union plans to discuss further strike action, with members having already staged walkouts and strikes in recent weeks. The unions want guaranteed wage increases and weekends of consecutive days, which Apple says its minimum pay rates already provide.

images.alt_text: Apple takes a commission of as much as 30 per cent on in-app purchases, meaning a company like Meta would lose a portion of its ad revenue to the iPhone maker.
Shipments of iPhones, whose latest generation was released earlier this year than last, were up slightly.
Discontent has been brewing among staff at Foxconn’s main factory in Zhengzhou, where the emergence of Covid cases saw it go into a closed loop system.

site_title: China’s economy weakens and signs point to more strain ahead
summary: China's economy is expected to contract in October with a manufacturing PMI of 49.2 and a non-manufacturing gauge of 48.7, indicating worsening strain ahead. Economists attribute the decline to rising Covid cases, a lackluster property market, and falling exports. The contraction is expected to be marginally less severe than September's 48.1 reading, but still suggests a slowdown in the country's growth momentum. This data may prompt policymakers to re-evaluate their economic strategies.

images.alt_text: The official non-manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) stood at 48.7 from 50.6 in September, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Monday.
As China’s economy grows, it requires ever more power, and it has said it plans to peak coal consumption only by the middle of the decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.41 points, or 0.44%, to 1453.72 on Monday, driven by a higher trading volume of 177.55 million lots worth RM64.35 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 237 to 87, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.22% to 14,830.69. This follows recent losses as investors await the Federal Reserve's key policy meeting later in the week. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped 0.79%.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades UOB to ‘buy’, views valuations as compelling
summary: RHB Research upgraded its rating on United Overseas Bank (UOB) to "buy" from "neutral" following the bank's record Q3 results, citing a 10% increase in earnings estimates for FY2022 and 3-4% for FY2023. Analysts revised net interest margin (NIM) estimates upwards, driven by lower expected provisions. This move comes after UOB's first nine months of earnings exceeded expectations, indicating a compelling valuation.

images.alt_text: UOB Plaza

site_title: CLCT’s 9M gross revenue rises 7% on positive rental reversions
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) reported a 7% increase in 9-month gross revenue to 1.4 billion yuan (S$272.3 million) for the period ended September 2022, driven by positive rental reversions. Net property income rose 7.5% to 970.8 million yuan (S$188.8 million). The Reit's new economy portfolio saw full contributions from business parks and logistics parks, with occupancy rates at 94.3% and 96.6% respectively, contributing to a +5.6% positive reversion.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
The China-focused real estate investment trust reported a net property income of S$139.5 million for the six months ended Jun 30, 15.9 per cent higher than the year-ago period.
The city of Shanghai finally re-opened on 1 June while some districts of Beijing are allowed to return to work. e
CAPITALAND China Trust (CLCT) posted a 30.4 per cent rise in its net property income to 344.5 million yuan (S$72.2 million) for its first quarter ended March 2022, from 264.2 million yuan a year ago.

site_title: Japan’s production falls as cars drag on solid third quarter
summary: Japan's factory output declined 1.6% in September, marking the first decline in four months, due to a slump in carmakers' output. The decrease accounted for most of the fall, dragging overall figures down by 1.85 percentage points. Despite this, production in the third quarter gained 5.9%, a positive sign for Japan's recovery from the pandemic. Economists expect a further decline in the fourth quarter, citing weak exports and production. The government has unveiled a 29.1 trillion yen economic-support package to support the recovery.

images.alt_text: Employees wearing protective face masks and face guards work on the automobile assembly line as the maker ramps up car production with new security and health measures as a step to resume full operations, during the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), at Kawasaki factory of Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corp., owned by Germany-based Daimler AG, in Kawasaki, south of Tokyo, Japan May 18, 2020. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: UOB sets decarbonisation targets for six sectors; ends financing for upstream O&G
summary: Singapore's third-largest lender, UOB, has set decarbonization targets for six sectors, including power, automotive, real estate, construction, steel, and oil and gas. The bank aims to reduce emission intensity in these sectors by 2050, with a focus on limiting new upstream oil and gas projects. UOB will stop financing new upstream O&G projects from 2023, while phasing out downstream O&G financing across sectors. The bank's targets are guided by internationally recognized climate science models and are part of its wider net-zero commitments by 2050.

images.alt_text: “Decarbonisation cannot be achieved in silos – the global banking and business community, and world leaders have a part to play in balancing the climate agenda, social equity and economic development. Collectively, we must exercise leadership by working towards a balanced, sustainable and just transition,” said Piyush Gupta, chief executive, DBS: “The decarbonisation targets will act as the ‘north star’ for our financing activities guiding us to net zero by 2050 through measurable change.”

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.17% to 27,423.59. This follows Wall Street's gains, driven by Apple's solid earnings release. The broader Topix index also increased 1.01% to 1,918.27.

site_title: UK house prices face 5% dip next year on mortgage rate rises
summary: UK house prices are expected to dip by up to 5% in 2023 due to rising mortgage rates, potentially wiping out 8 months of price gains. London properties would face the largest loss, with 13 months of capital gains erased. Mortgage rates are predicted to hover around 4% to 5% and could reach 6% in extreme scenarios, leading to double-digit price falls.

images.alt_text: UK mortgage rates have surged close to peaks last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The cost of a two-year fixed-rate mortgage is now 6.48 per cent, near the highest in 14 years and up from 2.34 per cent in December, according to Moneyfacts Group.
Almost one in four people with a mortgage is already finding it difficult to afford the repayments, according to one survey, as daily living costs rise at the fastest pace in four decades.

site_title: Hong Kong banking summit a post-pandemic sales pitch, but is anyone buying?
summary: Hundreds of top bankers are gathering in Hong Kong for a summit aimed at showcasing the city's status as a global finance hub despite lingering pandemic curbs and US-China tensions. The event comes under fire from US lawmakers who say Wall Street luminaries are whitewashing human rights violations and giving political cover to city leader John Lee, who is sanctioned by Washington for his role in cracking down on human rights in Hong Kong. Despite restrictions remaining in place, local industry leaders hope to maintain Hong Kong's standing as a global finance hub and paint a more positive picture of the city's economic situation.

images.alt_text: A woman sprays water on her pet bird at the West Kowloon Cultural district overlooking Victoria Harbour in Hong Kong on October 27, 2022.
The commercial downturn, combined with a tumbling residential market, is adding pressure on the city’s developers, which are already dealing with shrinking profit margins.
The city’s economy has been under strain for months from rising global inflation, a slowdown in China due to Covid Zero.

site_title: Hong Kong’s economy likely contracted again on global headwinds
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to contract for the third consecutive quarter, with a 0.8% decline in gross domestic product (GDP) from a year earlier, according to a Bloomberg survey. The city's recovery is hindered by weak global demand, a slow reopening from pandemic isolation, and rising global inflation. The government's measures to boost consumption and ease property pressures have been deemed insufficient, and the city's budget shortfall may triple this year. A stronger recovery is expected in the last three months of the year, but the city's international status remains uncertain without a timetable for lifting Covid curbs.

images.alt_text: The commercial downturn, combined with a tumbling residential market, is adding pressure on the city’s developers, which are already dealing with shrinking profit margins.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on rate hopes ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: Markets in Asia rose on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, and Wellington increasing by over 1%, while Sydney and Jakarta followed suit. Investors are hopeful for a less hawkish stance on interest rates, following a report suggesting the US central bank may slow its efforts to rein in inflation. Despite this, Shanghai fell due to concerns over China's economic growth and zero-Covid strategy. The Fed's policy meeting ends on Wednesday, with traders expecting a fourth consecutive 75 basis point hike, but looking for hints on potential rate adjustments.

images.alt_text: The yen was slightly lower against the dollar on Friday, though it has bounced since hitting a fresh 32-year low last week.

site_title: Freehold residential sites on Wilkie Rd up for collective sale at S$19.5m
summary: Two adjacent freehold residential sites on Wilkie Rd in District 9, Singapore, are up for collective sale with a guide price of S$19.5 million. The sites, totaling 5,849 sq ft, can be redeveloped into an eight-storey building with 26 units. The properties are zoned "residential" with a gross plot ratio of 2.1, offering a price of S$1,485 psf per plot ratio. Marketing agent PropNex expects keen interest from local developers due to its affordable pricing and attractive location. The tender exercise closes on Nov 22.

images.alt_text: Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.

site_title: Charities discover endless possibilities with design thinking
summary: The National Volunteer And Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) and BNP Paribas co-created the "Design for Community Action" (DCA) workshop, a design thinking program aimed at helping non-profits solve pertinent problems. DCA participants, including charities such as Love, Nils and YMCA of Singapore, collaborated with each other and with corporate partners to develop innovative solutions. The workshop, which ran for 60 days, focused on collaboration, and participants learned new ways of working, including analytical thinking, innovation, and creativity. The program has achieved positive outcomes, with charities gaining valuable experience and implementing solutions to their problems.
