images.alt_text: Since 2018, Certis has partnered like-minded organisations to develop inclusive programmes for the well-being of its beneficiaries, and drive employee engagement and volunteerism by organising regular outreach programmes to help the community.

site_title: Tribecar acquires Popular Rent a Car; enters corporate leasing market
summary: Tribecar has acquired car rental company Popular Rent a Car, entering the corporate leasing market. The acquisition, for an undisclosed eight-figure sum, includes WhizzCar, adding 400 cars to Tribecar's fleet. All Popular Rent a Car staff will join Tribecar, with Ho Kok Kee joining the board as an adviser. Tribecar expects its corporate leasing arm to contribute 20-30% of its revenue, with co-founder Adrian Lee predicting a 15-20 times growth in car-sharing business.

images.alt_text: Tribecar buys Singapore's oldest car-sharing firm
Car sharing platforms like Tribecar has tempered its fleet expansion in the face of high COE prices.
Car sharing heats up amid high COEs, generational shift in ownership mindset

site_title: Gold steady as investors brace for Fed policy meeting
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,642.59 per ounce, following a 1.3% decline in the previous session, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting for cues on interest rate hikes. US consumer spending rose more than expected, while underlying inflation pressures continued, keeping the Fed on track to hike rates again. The European Central Bank may also hike interest rates by 75 basis points in December. Meanwhile, physical gold demand in India surged due to the Diwali festival, while China's supply remained low, leading to elevated premiums.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
US gold futures were unchanged at US$1,666.00.

site_title: China’s services sector activity falls: official PMI
summary: China's services sector activity contracted for the first time since May, with the non-manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 48.7 in September from 50.6. The contraction was attributed to strict Covid-19 restrictions during the Golden Week holiday period. The official composite PMI also fell to 49.0 from 50.9. This marks a significant blow to consumption, highlighting the impact of pandemic-related restrictions on the country's economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday to track Wall Street gains; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, following Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.9% to 3,087.88. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 22, with Sembcorp Marine, ESR-Logos Reit, and local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC leading the gains. The gains were driven by robust US market performance, with stocks rallying on Friday after solid earnings and positive momentum amid hopes of a pivot in Federal Reserve policy.

images.alt_text: Raffles Medical reported a 62.1 per cent year-on-year increase in net profit to S$38.3 million in Q3, from the S$23.6 million posted in Q3 2021

site_title: URA launches residential sites at Lentor Gardens, Lentor Central for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two residential development sites, one at Lentor Gardens and the other at Lentor Central, for sale under the Government Land Sales (GLS) programme. The Lentor Gardens site, on the confirmed list, spans 21,866.7 sq m and is expected to yield around 530 housing units. The Lentor Central site, on the reserve list, spans 14,703.2 sq m and is estimated to yield around 475 housing units. Analysts expect lukewarm interest, with top bids potentially ranging from S$519 million to S$544 million for the Lentor Gardens site.

images.alt_text: Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.
URA said future residents at all 3 sites will enjoy direct access via public transport to Woodlands Regional Centre, the Central Business District and various parts of Singapore.

site_title: How ESG is transforming South-east Asia’s tech game
summary: South-east Asia's tech industry is shifting towards environmental, social, and governance (ESG) reporting, driven by global investment community demands. Since 2020, over $15 billion in green capital has been deployed in the region. Major cloud providers, such as Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, have pledged to decarbonize their data centers. However, a lack of consistency in measurement and reporting remains a significant challenge. To address this, tech companies are leveraging tools like the Upright Project's impact data platform to establish numerical baselines and report their net impact ratios. As ESG standards become increasingly standardized, companies that fail to adapt risk being left behind, potentially losing foreign capital and facing increased regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Most Asean economies’ industrial structures and carbon-intensive electricity generation will drive future credit risks related to their energy transition over the longer term, says Moody's Investors Service. (PHOTO: REUTERS)
From left to right - Frederick Chin, Head of Group Wholesale Banking and Markets, and Eric Lian, Head of Group Commercial Banking, launching the UOB Sustainability Compass.

site_title: Alta buys private securities platform Hg Exchange from Binance, others
summary: Alta, a Singapore-based digital marketplace, has acquired Hg Exchange, a private digital securities exchange, from Binance for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition aims to expand Alta's business lines and support tokenisation and digital custody of alternative assets. Alta has facilitated over 600 transactions worth $600 million and is working closely with regulators to allow investors to tokenise their shares, making alternative asset investments more accessible and bringing fresh liquidity to private markets.

images.alt_text: Binance acquires 18% stake in Singapore-regulated Hg Exchange
Early investor exits open up hot secondary market for startup equity

site_title: Li Ka-shing’s skyscraper is 21% empty as Hong Kong vacancies hit record
summary: Hong Kong's commercial real estate market is facing a record high of 11.9 million square feet of empty office space, with 21% of premium office space vacant at Cheung Kong Center, a skyscraper owned by billionaire Li Ka-shing. The city's developers are struggling with shrinking profit margins and a dwindling demand for office space due to lingering COVID-19 restrictions and a sealed border with China. The government's efforts to revive the city's business hub, including easing travel restrictions and offering concessions, are expected to take time to yield results.

images.alt_text: A woman sprays water on her pet bird at the West Kowloon Cultural district overlooking Victoria Harbour in Hong Kong on October 27, 2022.
Regulators are seeking to allow listings of bigger tokens but won’t endorse specific coins like Bitcoin or Ether.

site_title: HDB posts record deficit of S$4.4b in FY2021
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) posted a record deficit of S$4.4 billion in FY2021 due to a shortfall in its public housing programme. The deficit was largely driven by increased development projects, subsidies, and housing grants, which totaled S$2.3 billion. Despite this, HDB remains committed to keeping public housing "affordable, accessible, and inclusive" for Singaporeans, with Minister Desmond Lee stating that the board's efforts are a testament to its commitment to these values.

images.alt_text: The HDB resale price index and transaction volume climbed in Q4 2022, growing 2.6 per cent and 10.7 per cent quarter on quarter, respectively.
Since Sep 30, private home owners must wait 15 months after the sale of their current home before they can buy a non-subsidised HDB resale flat..
The Pinnacle@Duxton on 7 April 2021.
Million-dollar transactions were recorded in areas such as Bishan, Kallang/Whampoa, Bukit Merah, Ang Mo Kio and Clementi.
New HDB flats more affordable than housing in comparable cities: Desmond Lee

site_title: Inflation, economy are top of mind for US voters in midterm poll
summary: US voters are prioritizing economic issues ahead of the midterm elections, with 50% of registered voters citing the economy or inflation as their top concern. Half of independent voters also cite the economy or inflation. Republicans blame President Biden and Democrats for inflation, while Democrats defend their legislative record. Republicans are in a good position to win a majority of seats in the House, but the outcome remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The projects are funded by a US$1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure law signed into law by President Joe Biden in November 2021.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on financials boost ahead of central bank decision
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to 6,864.4 points on Monday, driven by gains in financial stocks ahead of a potential interest rate hike by the central bank this week. Despite high inflation, the S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.9% lower on Friday. The rise follows encouraging economic data in the US, which saw major indexes close sharply higher on Friday.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.9 per cent lower at 6,785.70, but rose 1.6 per cent for the week - its best since the week ended Oct 7.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust Q3 income up 13% on higher contributions
summary: CapitaLand India Trust reported a 13% increase in total property income for the third quarter ended Sep 30, reaching 3 billion rupees (S$53.5 million). The trust's net property income grew 8% to 2.4 billion rupees, driven by higher income contributions from its portfolio. Despite higher property expenses, the trust's portfolio occupancy stands at 91% and net gearing is 34%. The trust's total floor area is projected to rise 63% as construction works for more than half of its properties are underway and set to be completed by 2025.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Energy India's two thermal power plants in Nellore District, Andhra Pradesh, have four 660-megawatt supercritical coal-fired units and a total installed capacity of 2.64 gigawatts.

site_title: Won bears bet even the most hawkish BOK will fail to match Fed
summary: South Korea's won has slumped over 16% to 1,421.60 per dollar this year, with traders betting it may weaken further due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening campaign. The Bank of Korea is expected to raise its policy rate to 3.5% in the next six months, but analysts predict the Fed's benchmark rate will peak at around 5% in early 2023. The won's decline is also driven by a slowdown in South Korean exports, dwindling foreign reserves, and concerns about the country's credit market.

images.alt_text: “Recovery in private consumption is expected to weaken going forward due to slower growth in real purchasing power and a rise in interest rates,” the Bank of Korea (BOK) said.

site_title: Malaysia’s RHB aims to launch digital bank in 2023, CEO says
summary: RHB Bank, Malaysia's fifth-largest lender, plans to launch its digital banking platform in the second half of 2023 or by early 2024, according to CEO Mohd Rashid Mohamad. The bank, in partnership with Boost, aims to invest up to 1 billion ringgit (S$300 million) in the venture. The digital bank will focus on serving the unbanked and underserved community, providing financing and banking services. RHB also plans to expand its business in other South-east Asian countries, including Cambodia, Singapore, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Majority of the banks in Malaysia expect the rising interest rate will reduce the demand for loans as borrowing cost increased.

site_title: Australia retail sales up again in Sept as spending stays resilient
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.6% in September to a record A$35.1 billion, beating market forecasts, as consumers continued to spend on food, clothing, and dining out despite high inflation and interest rates. Consumer prices rose at the fastest pace in 32 years at 7.3%, while core inflation accelerated to 6.1%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates again, with a quarter-point hike likely, as analysts expect inflation to surpass the central bank's target band of 2-3%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man carries several shopping bags as he walks along George Street in Sydney's central business district (CBD) Australia, February 5, 2018. Picture taken February 5, 2018. REUTERS/Daniel Munoz/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Saudi net reserves surge near 1.69t riyals, highest since 2020
summary: Saudi Arabia's net foreign assets surged to 1.69 trillion riyals ($630 billion) in September, the highest level since 2020, driven by high crude prices. The country aims to rebuild depleted reserves and has changed its approach to managing its petrodollar wealth. Saudi Arabia's economy is growing rapidly, on track to run a budget surplus for the first time in nearly a decade this year, which will be used to replenish reserves, fund sovereign wealth funds, and diversify the economy.

site_title: China’s Evergrande delivers first electric vehicles
summary: China's Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group has started delivering its first electric vehicle, the Hengchi 5, to 100 customers. The company aims to shift its primary business from real estate to automobiles over the next decade, with plans to produce 1 million vehicles by 2025. The Hengchi 5, priced at 179,000 yuan, marks the beginning of mass production of its second EV model in 2023 and a third in 2024. This move is part of Evergrande's strategy to diversify its business and capitalize on the growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Outlook on GBP/USD still bearish, relief rally likely to last until Nov 17
summary: The GBP/USD currency pair is expected to continue a relief rally until November 17, driven by optimism surrounding the appointment of Rishi Sunak as UK prime minister and Jeremy Hunt's reversal of Kwarteng's "mini-budget". However, a bearish outlook is maintained due to poor UK economic fundamentals and expected fiscal and monetary tightening measures, which could lead to weaker growth and a deeper recession. The current rally is expected to be short-lived, with the currency pair potentially heading towards 1.140 after the release of Hunt's fiscal plan.

images.alt_text: The dollar is still king - an asset to hold for now

site_title: Raffles Medical reports 62.1% rise in Q3 net profit to S$38.3m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 62.1% year-over-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$38.3 million, driven by the return of foreign patients and increased elective surgeries. Revenue rose 6.5% to S$199.5 million. The company expects inflationary pressures and rising interest rates to dampen demand, but believes it will remain profitable for the rest of 2022. Year-to-date net profit surged 57.3% to S$98.2 million, while revenue climbed 9.6% to S$581.8 million.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB has maintained an “add” rating on Raffles Medicap Group at a higher target price of S$1.60, up from S$1.50.
Raffles Medical could be a key beneficiary as emergency cases spillover from public hospitals, said DBS analyst Rachel Tan.

RAFFLES Medical Group reported a profit of nearly S$60 million for the half year ended Jun 30, a 54.4 per cent rise as compared with S$38.8 million a year ago. This comes on the back of higher revenue from Covid-19 related services as well as a comeback in medical tourism as Singapore reopened its borders.

site_title: Global chip sales record first fall since 2020 in blow to South Korea
summary: Global chip sales declined 3% in September, the first fall since 2020, affecting South Korea's economy heavily reliant on the semiconductor industry. South Korean chipmakers manufactured 3.5% less than a year earlier, with inventory growth remaining elevated at 54.7%. The downturn adds to concerns for policymakers, who are struggling to recover from a credit rout and a deadly crowd crush. Demand is expected to recover only in the second half of 2023, according to Samsung Electronics.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of a chip on an electronic device at a shop in Brussels, Belgium, February 8, 2022. semiconductor REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo REUTERS

site_title: Fixing the solutions that dwell in the shallows
summary: Asian businesses have the potential to be leaders in shaping the future of sustainability, but they must act urgently to create deep change. Forum for the Future's Sumi Dhanarajan warns that piecemeal solutions can hinder systemic progress, and that a systemic approach to transition is needed. The organization is working with businesses, governments, and civil society to catalyze a deep sustainability transition in Asia, focusing on clean energy, food systems, and new economic systems. Dhanarajan emphasizes the need for businesses to be purpose-led rather than compliance-led, and for investors and governments to create an enabling environment for this change.

images.alt_text: The 3 Horizons framework allows a leadership team to explore what delivering on their purpose might look like in the future, versus relying on how they’ve succeeded in the past, says Ariel Muller, managing director, Asia, at Forum for the Future. (PHOTO: FORUM FOR THE FUTURE)

The government is looking at building a more effective and comprehensive SkillsFuture system, given the need for a "fundamental upgrading" of Singapore's training ecosystem, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Twitter owner Musk tweets conspiracy theory, then deletes it
summary: Elon Musk tweeted an anti-LGBT conspiracy theory about the attack on US Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul, but later deleted the post. The tweet, which linked to a conservative news outlet, sparked criticism and raised concerns about the direction Twitter will take under Musk's ownership. Musk, a self-declared "free speech absolutist," has vowed to dial back content moderation, but critics warn that without standards, the platform may become flooded with misinformation, posing a risk to democracy and public health.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An image of Elon Musk is seen on smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
Ex-CEO of Twitter, Parag Agrawal's “golden parachute” is valued at US$57.4 million.
Musk has been warned that his free-speech approach would have to follow the EU's Digital Services Act.

Musk’s US$44 billion takeover of Twitter is an individual buying something for himself that 240 million people around the world use regularly. He will have absolute control over the fate of the social media platform.

site_title: Brazil’s Lula defeats Bolsonaro to win presidency again in stunning comeback
summary: Brazil's leftist leader Luis Inacio Lula da Silva won the presidential election with 50.9% of votes, defeating incumbent President Jair Bolsonaro with 49.1%. This marks a stunning comeback for Lula, who had been out of office for nearly a decade. Lula's victory is seen as a rebuke to Bolsonaro's far-right populism, and his inauguration is scheduled for January 1, ending Brazil's most right-wing government in decades.

images.alt_text: Supporters of the Brazilian presidential candidate Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva celebrate the results of the second round of presidential elections, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Oct 30, 2022.

site_title: Singapore Deep-Tech Alliance partners EnterpriseSG for venture building
summary: Singapore Deep-Tech Alliance has partnered with EnterpriseSG for a nine-month venture building program under the Startup SG Accelerator. The program focuses on sustainability-focused deep tech ventures, providing access to mentors and partners, including Lenovo and Panasonic. The initiative aims to accelerate innovation and bring technology to market in three phases. This partnership is seen as a valuable addition to Singapore's startup ecosystem, bringing immense value through attracting investors and talent to solve market problems.

images.alt_text: Lauri Lugna, CEO of Enterprise Estonia, was in town for the Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology (SWITCH).
Four unicorns have been minted in Singapore this year, fewer than the 11 produced last year.

site_title: At least 130 dead in India bridge collapse
summary: At least 130 people were killed in India after a colonial-era pedestrian bridge collapsed in Morbi town in the western state of Gujarat, sending scores tumbling into the Machchhu river. The 233m suspension bridge, reopened just seven months ago, collapsed after cables snapped, with nearly 500 people on the bridge at the time. Authorities launched a rescue operation, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi announcing compensation for those killed and injured. This is the latest in a series of accidents from old and poorly maintained infrastructure in India, where such incidents are common.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past paintings of new Conservative Party leader and incoming British prime minister Rishi Sunak in Mumbai on Oct 25, 2022. Sunak on Thursday told his Indian counterpart Narendra Modi he “hoped” they could agree a trade pact, Downing Street said.

“As part of the annual strategic assessment activity and as a response to enhanced focus on our core business services, we closed the Mi Financial Services in March 2022,” the Xiaomi spokesperson said.

site_title: Australia set for another close call on interest-rate decision
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), is set to decide on interest-rate hikes, with most economists predicting a second consecutive quarter-point rise. The decision comes as inflation soared 7.3% in the third quarter, the fastest pace in 32 years. Despite this, some economists, including Westpac's Bill Evans and Commonwealth Bank's Gareth Aird, expect a fifth half-point hike to reinforce the RBA's inflation-fighting credentials. The RBA's decision will be closely watched, with markets predicting hikes through to mid-2023 and a peak of 3.9%.

images.alt_text: A flood-affected property in Echuca, Victoria, Australia, Oct 26, 2022. Major flooding continues along the Murray River at Echuca, Moama, Torrumbarry and Barham while moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River.

site_title: Explorer’s cameras found on Canada glacier – 85 years on
summary: Explorer Bradford Washburn's cameras and equipment, left behind in a Canadian glacier in 1937, have been discovered 85 years later. The equipment, including photographs taken by Washburn, was found on the Walsh glacier in Kluane National Park and Reserve. Washburn, a renowned mountaineer, photographer, and cartographer, was also the founder of the Boston Science Museum. The discovery was made by three athletes who embarked on a mission to find the historic equipment, marking a significant piece of history uncovered.

images.alt_text: The 12.2m-long skeleton is on public display at VCH’s atrium before it goes under the hammer on Nov 30 in Hong Kong.

site_title: Credit Suisse is said to tap 20 banks for capital increase
summary: Credit Suisse has invited at least 20 banks to join its US$4 billion rights issue to finance a multi-year restructuring programme, dubbed "project Ghana". The Swiss bank's new CFO, Dixit Joshi, held due diligence calls with a group of bankers, including Morgan Stanley and Royal Bank of Canada, to underwrite newly issued shares. This marks a major retreat from investment banking for the struggling lender.

images.alt_text: The Swiss investment banking and capital markets business will be moved to the company’s Swiss Bank to offer services in its home market.
It will cut 2,700 jobs or 5 per cent of its workforce by the end of this year, and ultimately reduce its workforce by roughly 9,000 to about 43,000 by the end of 2025.

site_title: Shophouse rentals extend gains in Q3 as landlords price up on strong demand
summary: Shophouse rental prices in Singapore continued to rise in Q3, with median rentals increasing to S$5.65 psf per month, a 15.3% year-on-year gain. Despite stable rental volume, total rent values fell 14% compared to the same period last year. Strong demand from food and beverage, retail, and hospitality operators has driven up prices, with landlords now holding more negotiating power. Experts predict further rent increases, especially with rising interest rates, and a decrease in shophouse sales, as investors seek to hedge against inflation.

images.alt_text: TOTAL property investment sales in Singapore dropped 48.9 per cent in the third quarter to S$4.8 billion, marking a negative turnaround from previous quarters of growth.

site_title: WealthBT: ESG investments - Hype or worth investing in? (Ep 19)
summary: Genevieve Cua's podcast series explores ESG investing, questioning whether it's truly effective in reducing carbon emissions and alleviating social issues. ESG funds underperform due to two main reasons: high fees and lack of transparency. Oil & gas companies may be excluded, but the true meaning of ESG ratings is unclear. Industry experts suggest ESG investing should be viewed as a process, not just a product. The effectiveness of ESG funds in delivering value is uncertain, and the industry is experiencing a shake-out due to ESG labels.

images.alt_text: Sustainable funds that avoided traditional oil and energy companies underperformed this year. Starving the sector of capital may be a disservice to the long-term energy transition.
Lignite-powered power plant (brown coal) in Western Germany. Coal price has skyrocketed this year, raising the urgency of the need to invest in clean energy.

site_title: Piyush Gupta counting on DBS’ AI and data capabilities to pull ahead of peers
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, is leveraging AI and data capabilities to gain a competitive edge. CEO Piyush Gupta believes the bank's AI initiatives have generated S$150 million in additional revenue and S$25 million in productivity gains in the past year. With over 1,000 employees working on data capabilities, DBS aims to increase its economic value to over $1 billion in the next five years. Gupta emphasizes the importance of transparency, respect, and explainability in data use, while acknowledging potential risks such as biased models and over-reliance on AI.

images.alt_text: DBS has launched DBS Quick Finance, which enables SMEs “almost instant” access to financing of up to S$300,000.

At DBS, we’ve created an internal data mart with 15,000 customer data points that stitch together a customer’s profile, including the pages he/she visits, the content he/she is interested in, the frequency of his/her visits, the amounts he/she spends on different categories, etc. We then convert the data into personalised, actionable insights - what we call “nudges” – to guide the customer in his/her transaction or investment decision.

site_title: Forget free coffee; what matters is if workers feel returning is worth it
summary: Many workers who transitioned back to office work after the pandemic found that having a reason to be there and maintaining some control over their time made the transition more manageable. Those who felt their jobs could be done remotely or returned to empty offices expressed resentment. Managers are advised to fully explain the value of in-person work to employees and involve them in the process. This includes highlighting benefits such as more efficient meetings, effective brainstorming, and easier collaboration, which can help workers feel more valued and understood.

images.alt_text: One college student who has started her own ghostwriting business says her content packages, which start at US$800 for one month and go up to US$9,000 for multi-month commitments, have afforded her the ability to buy a car and travel domestically and internationally.
Singapore Airlines cabin crew at the departure hall in Terminal 3 of Changi Airport on 24 May 2022.
Younger workers embraced the idea of a personal brand as a way to get ahead, and carve out some power and security in their careers. But posting through it has its drawbacks.

site_title: Job markets are defying central bankers’ efforts to cool demand
summary: Central bankers' efforts to cool demand are being thwarted by robust job markets, defying predictions of recession. Despite rising borrowing costs and slowing growth, unemployment rates are not increasing, and companies in developed economies are facing chronic worker shortages. This mismatch between demand and supply is supporting wages and shielding consumers from slowdowns, making it challenging for central banks to ease demand and cool inflation.

images.alt_text: The ECB says banks have to pay going rates on their TLTRO credit, rather than the average rate over the whole duration of the loans.

site_title: 5 things to look out for ahead of Malaysia’s Nomination Day
summary: Malaysia's upcoming general election, scheduled for Nomination Day on Nov 5, is expected to see intense competition with multi-cornered fights in some seats. The ruling Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition, led by former PM Muhyiddin Yassin, faces challenges from the opposition, particularly PKR and Umno. Notable candidates include PKR's Anwar Ibrahim, who will contest the Tambun seat in Perak, and Umno's Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, who will defend the state's Bagan Datuk seat. The election will also see a high number of young voters casting their ballots for the first time, with all parties rejuvenating their lists with fresh candidates.

images.alt_text: Although flight ticket prices fluctuate following market demand, Malaysia's Transport Ministry has instructed the Malaysian Aviation Commission to regulate the prices of flight tickets to ensure airline companies do not hike prices arbitrarily.
Better job opportunities and higher wages are the key changes that young voters would like to see in the future.

site_title: China is doubling down on coal despite its green ambitions
summary: China is investing heavily in new coal-fired power stations, with plans to build over 165 gigawatts by the end of 2023, despite its green ambitions. The country aims to peak coal consumption by the middle of the decade, but the plants will likely be underutilized as renewables continue to grow. China's strategy is to balance the need for energy with its climate goals, adding both clean power and coal to create a buffer against volatile fuel prices. The plan carries big risks, including stranded assets and increased carbon emissions, but China is making efforts to lessen the burden on coal power generators.

images.alt_text: A coal fired power plant in Jiayuguan, Gansu province. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Macau’s MGM Cotai casino locked down with guests, staff after Covid case
summary: MGM Cotai casino in Macau was locked down on October 30 after a dealer tested positive for Covid-19, with guests and staff ordered to stay inside until November 1. The closure is the third coronavirus case detected in Macau this month, amid the region's ongoing "dynamic zero Covid" policy. All 700,000 residents must take daily rapid antigen tests from October 30 to November 1, and the casino operators are awaiting a government decision on new licenses, which could come as early as this week.

images.alt_text: Fresh lockdowns come as infections start to rise again, with China reporting 1,321 new Covid cases for Thursday, the highest tally in two weeks.

site_title: Musk denies reports he is firing Twitter employees in attempt to avoid payouts
summary: Elon Musk has denied reports that he is firing Twitter employees to avoid hefty severance payouts. According to a New York Times report, Musk ordered job cuts across the company, with layoffs planned before November 1 when employees were scheduled to receive stock grants. Musk responded to a Twitter user's question about the layoffs, saying "This is false."

images.alt_text: FILE — Elon Musk in lower Manhattan on April 4, 2022. Twitter has filed documents asking to remove its shares from the New York Stock Exchange, the first official step toward becoming a private company under Musk’s ownership. (Jefferson Siegel/The New York Times)

site_title: Understanding geopolitical risk key in business strategy, says Rolls-Royce exec, SICC chief
summary: Bicky Bhangu, president of Rolls-Royce's South-east Asia, Pacific, and South Korea region, emphasizes the importance of understanding geopolitical risks in business strategy. As chairman of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, Bhangu highlights the need for companies to grasp the evolving global landscape, including the Ukraine war, supply chain disruptions, and energy crises. He notes that businesses must incorporate these risks into their strategic planning, taking into account the costs of operating in various markets. Bhangu also stresses the need for companies to invest in sustainability, with Rolls-Royce aiming to reduce carbon emissions to net-zero by 2030.

images.alt_text: Lim Chin Beng steered SIA through its early turbulent years with a calm demeanour and steady hand.
GuocoLand chief executive Cheng Hsing Yao says the group is keen to beef up its investment portfolio, which will set the stage for the growth of its asset management business.

site_title: Distressed assets drawing out bargain hunters in real estate, old-economy sectors as higher debt costs bite
summary: Bargain hunters are drawn to distressed assets in China and Southeast Asia as higher interest rates reduce buyer demand and increase debt costs. Private equity, family offices, and high net worth investors are eyeing assets trading at discounts, while distressed debt funds in the US and Europe also seek opportunities. Companies in old-economy industries or those with high debt levels are at risk, particularly those with bonds issued in "interest rate-friendly times" and nearing payment. Despite rising interest rates, there is sufficient appetite for distressed assets, with buyers including cash-rich companies and international distress funds.

images.alt_text: Properties such as warehouses and apartments are more likely to face these issues, given prices had soared as investors bet they could generate positive returns by raising rents.
Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), the world’s largest commercial lender by assets, said net profit rose 6.8 per cent year-on-year in the third quarter in a Friday (Oct 28) filing.
The stubborn rise in mortgage costs, which is sharply slowing demand in the property market, is one of the headaches Rishi Sunak will inherit upon replacing Liz Truss as UK prime minister.

Gross domestic product (GDP) rose at a 2.6 per cent annualised rate in the July to September period after falling for the first two quarters, US Commerce Department’s preliminary estimate showed on Thursday (Oct 27).

krlanded - Villa Verde

site_title: China shows the LME there are still buyers for Russian metal
summary: China continues to show interest in Russian metal, with over half of the copper in London Metal Exchange (LME) warehouses being ordered out for delivery to Chinese buyers in the past three weeks. This suggests that at least some global consumers are still willing to buy Russian metal, despite others shunning it due to sanctions and supply concerns. The move is seen as a counterpoint to the industry's debate over restricting Russian supplies, with Chinese buyers driving demand for the metal.

images.alt_text: The most-traded November copper contract on the Shanghai Futures Exchange declined 1.1 per cent to US$8,601.85 per tonne.

site_title: BT Podcast: Using product to deliver you the news better
summary: The Business Times podcast explores the concept of "product" in the context of news delivery, problem-solving, and value creation. Associate editor Christopher Lim discusses how product goes beyond tech and is not just about pleasing everyone. Newsrooms can adopt agile frameworks like Kanban and Scrum to improve their product. The podcast also clarifies that product is not just about delivering news, but also about solving problems and delighting users. The conversation highlights the importance of understanding the definition of product in the news industry.

site_title: Aspen says ‘extensive’ research done before entering glove market, after Sias notes poor results
summary: Aspen Holdings defended its decision to enter the glove manufacturing market after poor results led the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) to seek more information on the company's due diligence process. Despite conducting "extensive market research and studies," demand for gloves plummeted worldwide, resulting in a loss of RM180.1 million for the 18-month financial period ended June 2022. The company has sufficient funds for new projects and intends to rely on internally generated funds, but faces concerns over inventory management and suitability of board members.

images.alt_text: In its queries, SGX also asked Aspen about its acquisitions of property, plant and equipment worth some S$278 million for the 18-month period.

site_title: Wholesale power buyers expected to face new financial, consumption rules to deal with price volatility
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority plans to tighten eligibility criteria for companies on Wholesale Electricity Price (WEP) plans, requiring strong financial track records and high energy consumption to mitigate price volatility. The new rules aim to exclude smaller players and limit speculation, favoring larger companies with financial stability and diversified risks. Industry players suggest the criteria may include company turnover, paid-up capital, or a performance bond, and may favor industries with high electricity consumption, such as manufacturing and technology. The changes are expected to set the bar higher and provide better predictability for businesses.

images.alt_text: EMA is looking to strengthen consumer protection by enhancing regulatory requirements on electricity retailers and tightening the eligibility criteria for consumers on Wholesale Electricity Price (WEP) plans
Clean energy innovations will be test-bedded on Jurong Island and, if commercially viable, could be scaled up and deployed across more companies looking for cleaner energy solutions.

site_title: Elon Musk takes Twitter, and tech deals, to another level
summary: Elon Musk's $44 billion takeover of Twitter marks a significant shift in the tech industry, as individual billionaires are increasingly taking control of companies. Musk, who owns Tesla, has absolute control over the social media platform, which has 240 million users worldwide. This deal is unusual, with Musk's impulsive decision to buy the platform, and raises concerns about the impact on the platform's content and users. Experts see this as a new era of billionaire power, where tech titans are leading the way and potentially eroding traditional corporate influence.

images.alt_text: Ex-CEO of Twitter, Parag Agrawal's “golden parachute” is valued at US$57.4 million.
FILE PHOTO: An image of Elon Musk is seen on smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
Elon Musk took control of Twitter and fired its top executives, US media reported on Oct 27, 2022.

site_title: Creating a better future by first imagining it
summary: International sustainability non-profit Forum for the Future (FFTF) is using the "Three Horizons" framework to envision a "just and regenerative future." The framework, developed by Bill Sharpe, depicts three timeframes: the present (Horizon One), the desired future (Horizon Three), and the near-future innovation horizon (Horizon Two). FFFT's managing director, Ariel Muller, uses the framework to help leadership teams assess how to transform their businesses for the future context, with the goal of creating a better future by first imagining it.

images.alt_text: There are clear opportunities for Asian businesses to be leaders in shaping the future of sustainability, but that leadership will need to act urgently, and act to create deep change, says Forum for the Future's Sumi Dhanarajan. (PHOTO: FORUM FOR THE FUTURE)
There is growing acceptance among businesses that sustainability, as manifested in environmental, social and corporate governance factors, has to be at the top of management’s priorities.

site_title: UK starts to feel the pinch from biggest rate rises in 33 years
summary: The UK is experiencing its largest rate hikes in 33 years, with mortgage rates surging to 6.48% and expected to rise further. This has led to concerns that the economy is entering a recession, with economists predicting a "fairly nasty recession." The UK central bank is expected to raise its benchmark lending rate by three-quarters of a percentage point to 3% on November 3, the highest since 2008. This has resulted in higher borrowing costs for households and businesses, with house prices predicted to fall 7.9% next year.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt held a “sober” meeting on Thursday to run through their options.

site_title: Treasury market rally faces reality check as Powell sets path
summary: US Treasury market rallied last week, driven by speculation that the Federal Reserve will signal plans to scale back interest-rate hikes. However, investors remain divided over the Fed's December decision, with futures traders still pricing in a 0.75 percentage point rate increase. The Fed's stance will depend on inflation data and comments from Chair Jerome Powell, who must balance a message of terminal risks to the upside with a dovish tone on rate cuts. The market's recent rebound marks a turbulent year, with the deepest losses in at least half a century.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade in Washington, July 31, 2013. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo

site_title: Mapletree raises more than S$11,000 for underpriviledged youths
summary: Mapletree Investments raised S$11,102 for underprivileged youths through the fourth edition of the Mapletree Futsal Challenge, exceeding its target. The event, which involved over 90 employees and tenants, saw companies such as Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank and Google Asia-Pacific participate, each pledging a minimum donation of S$500 per team. The funds will benefit Mapletree's long-time beneficiaries, Beyond Social Services and Boys' Town.

site_title: Early birds to pay S$98 to catch World Cup action, a slight increase over 2018 prices
summary: Singapore's Singtel, StarHub, and Mediacorp have partnered to beam all 64 World Cup matches, with Singtel and StarHub offering a S$98 package for early bird customers, a slight increase from S$94 in 2018. Existing customers can re-contract for S$52.40 a month for two years, including access to Disney+ and fibre broadband. Mediacorp will air nine games on free-to-air TV, while fans can purchase a similar S$98 package for all matches on its meWATCH app. The price increase marks the general upward trend of costs for viewers over the last two decades.

images.alt_text: A signage of Qatar 2022 on display in Doha, Qatar, where the Fifa World Cup will be staged from Nov 20 to Dec 18.

site_title: S-Reits rebound amid less hawkish rates expectations
summary: Global Reits saw a stronger performance last week, with the FTSE EPRA Nareit Developed Index gaining close to 4% and Singapore's iEdge S-Reit Index booking its strongest week this year with 6% returns. Office Reits averaged 8% returns, followed by hospitality and industrial Reits with 7% and 5% gains, respectively. Several Reits, including Manulife US Reit and Keppel DC Reit, reported earnings or business updates, while others, such as CDL Hospitality Trusts, have refinanced debt and hedged interest rate exposures. The sector's rebound was driven by expectations of a less hawkish rate hike, but many Reit managers are proactively managing capital due to rising interest costs.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit says it will continue to pursue green initiatives across its portfolio as it looks to improve the assets’ operational efficiency over the medium-term

site_title: South Korea's Yoon declares mourning period after Halloween crush
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol declared a national mourning period after a deadly stampede during a Halloween celebration in Seoul's Itaewon district, killing 151 people, including 22 foreigners, and injuring 82, with 19 seriously. The tragedy occurred when a huge crowd surged into an alley, causing a crush that led to the deaths. Yoon expressed condolences to the victims and wished for a speedy recovery to the injured, calling the incident "tragic" and a "disaster that should not have happened."

images.alt_text: Authorities have jumped into action to try to nip the turmoil in the bud.

site_title: EU urges Russia to revoke Ukraine Black Sea grain deal suspension
summary: Russia suspended its participation in a UN-brokered grain deal, cutting shipments from Ukraine, in response to a drone attack on its fleet near Crimea. The European Union urges Russia to reverse the decision, which would undermine efforts to ease a global food crisis. The US and Ukraine also condemned the move, with US President Joe Biden calling it "purely outrageous" and Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba accusing Russia of using the attack as a "false pretext". The grain deal had restarted shipments from Ukraine, allowing sales on world markets and targeting the pre-war level of exports.

images.alt_text: Concerns are mounting anew over supplies out of the Black Sea region as the war in Ukraine escalates and there are questions over the future of the deal to ship grains out of Ukrainian ports.

site_title: London flats with pool, cinema show demand for retirement luxury
summary: The UK's senior housing market is experiencing a surge in demand, with a record £2 billion invested in the first nine months of 2022, set to rise to £3 billion by the end of the year. Luxury developments, such as Riverstone's 190 flats in London, are catering to the growing number of retirees seeking high-end amenities, with floor-to-ceiling windows and private cinema. Investors, including UK pension funds and private equity, are betting on the sector's growth, driven by the UK's rapidly ageing population and a lack of supply.

images.alt_text: Almost one in four people with a mortgage is already finding it difficult to afford the repayments, according to one survey, as daily living costs rise at the fastest pace in four decades.

site_title: BuzzFeed can block worker arbitration claims over IPO snafu
summary: A US judge ruled that BuzzFeed can block arbitration claims from employees who claim the company mishandled its initial public offering (IPO) and denied them the chance to sell shares before the stock crashed in value. The judge, Morgan Zurn, said BuzzFeed has the right to bar workers from having their allegations reviewed by American Arbitration Association (AAA) officials without causing "irreparable harm" to the company. The ruling blocks claims from over 70 current and former employees seeking almost $9 million in damages.

images.alt_text: The announcement came as the popular video snippet sharing service fended off concerns about the ability of engineers in China to access information about US users that isn’t public.
mlspac - For a time, SPACs were the preferred way for companies to go public. But changing market conditions and the threat of regulation are making Wall Street lose its appetite.

site_title: Why The Business Times has both a news editor and a product editor
summary: The Business Times has adopted a product thinking approach to deliver a tailored experience to its readers, combining news and product development. The new role of associate editor for product was created to oversee product development and management, focusing on solving problems and delivering value to readers. Integrating product with news has required a cross-functional approach, balancing the differing pace of ideation and work between tech and journalists. This has led to a more audience-driven newsroom strategy, incorporating behavioral data and informal feedback.

images.alt_text: By following keywords, myBT users can personalise their BT reading experience.

(Clockwise from bottom left) Wong Wei Kong, editor-in-chief of SPH Media's English/Malay/Tamil Media group, BT podcast editor Claressa Monteiro, SPH Media Trust chairman Khaw Boon Wan and SPH Media CEO Teo Lay Lim inside the newly built BT podcast studio.
Making change work is harder than change itself
While news is still our core, the new structure places audience strategy and product development as equally important elements and co-dependent with quality journalism.
SPH assistant general manager Cheah Cheng Poh at a briefing to launch BT Online in June 1995.

site_title: Yen falls on dovish BOJ as market awaits Fed decision
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) stuck with ultra-low interest rates, bucking trends among other major central banks, causing the yen to fall over 1% against the dollar. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 75 basis points at its upcoming meeting, but speculation of a "pivot" to slower rate hikes has weakened the dollar. The BOJ's decision was seen as dovish, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stating Japan is unlikely to raise rates anytime soon, and the euro rose against the dollar due to the European Central Bank's dovish tone.

images.alt_text: The yen hit a low of 149.70 per US dollar overnight before being swept to a high of 145.28 within minutes in a move that suggested the BOJ had stepped in for a second day.

site_title: Wages are soaring in US cities with the highest inflation
summary: US wages surged in cities with high inflation, with Miami and Phoenix posting record pay growth of 7.1% and 6.6% respectively. Nationwide, wages and salaries for non-government workers climbed 5.2% last quarter. This suggests underlying inflationary pressures that will not easily dissipate, likely leading to steep interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Art fundraiser raises S$230k for mental health non-profit, BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: A two-day art fundraiser, Souljourn, raised S$230,000 for the Singapore Association for Mental Health (SAMH) and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF). The event featured live performances, experiential spaces, and artworks by beneficiaries, with donations from OCBC Bank, Chemical Industries, and Standard Chartered Bank. Funds will support SAMH's mental health services and BT BAF's arts programs for young people from disadvantaged backgrounds, highlighting the intersection of arts and mental well-being. The event aims to bring communities together towards a shared future.

images.alt_text: Chairman of BT BAF, Wong Wei Kong (left) receiving the Title Deed for the 2 hectares of virtual real estate from director of business development of HATTENX, Edern Tan.

site_title: Workers leave world’s biggest iPhone plant to escape Covid curbs
summary: Workers at Foxconn's main iPhone plant in Zhengzhou, China, have begun departing the facility to escape Covid-19 curbs, which have led to inadequate living conditions. At least six counties in Henan province have asked residents to report to local authorities, and workers will be sent to mandatory isolation for several days. The move highlights the economic and social costs of China's Covid Zero policy and potential risks to global supply chains, particularly for Apple, which relies heavily on the plant for iPhone production.

images.alt_text: Table tennis is wildly popular in China, where 30 million people play what is considered by many to be the national sport at least twice a week.

site_title: Oil giants face backlash for handing record profits to investors
summary: Oil giants Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Shell, and TotalEnergies are facing backlash for handing record profits to investors, with critics arguing that the funds should be reinvested in drilling and refining to ease the energy crisis. The companies have allocated $100 billion to shareholders annually, while investing only $80 billion in core businesses. US President Joe Biden and other politicians have called for windfall taxes on oil companies to reduce prices at the pump, with some countries, including the UK and EU, considering similar measures.

images.alt_text: Exxon posted the highest profit in its 152-year history, while Chevron announced its second-best quarterly result as natural gas demand and prices surged.
ExxonMobil said it “safely exited” Russia after the government earlier this month “unilaterally terminated” its interests in the Sakhalin-1 oil and gas project, its largest in the country.

site_title: Like clockwork: World's longest passenger train winds through Swiss Alps
summary: A 1,910-meter (6,266-foot) train, composed of 25 separable multiple-unit trains or 100 coaches, successfully traveled through the Swiss Alps in Graubunden, setting a new world record for the longest passenger train. The Rhaetian Railway (RhB) announced the achievement on the 175th anniversary of Switzerland's famous railway system, beating the previous record. The train journeyed through breathtaking scenery, marking a notable milestone in the history of Swiss rail transportation.

images.alt_text: Retreating glacier, at Diavolezza ski area near the Alpine resort of Pontresina, Switzerland July 21, 2022.  REUTERS

site_title: Everybody wants to be a LinkedInfluencer
summary: A growing number of LinkedIn users are turning to ghostwriters to create content for their personal brand, with many opting for professional ghostwriting services due to the increasing competition on the platform. Aspiring LinkedInfluencers can now pay up to $9,000 for multi-month commitments to have their content spearheaded by ghostwriters. This trend has led to a surge in demand for ghostwriting services, with many ghostwriters doubling their business in recent years. By outsourcing content creation, individuals can focus on building their personal brand and leveraging their expertise, rather than trying to create engaging content themselves.

images.alt_text: Younger workers embraced the idea of a personal brand as a way to get ahead, and carve out some power and security in their careers. But posting through it has its drawbacks.
News sites like CNA, Mothership.sg and The Straits Times are courting Gen Z on TikTok.
In experiments conducted around the world from 2015 to 2019, LinkedIn randomly varied the proportion of weak and strong contacts suggested by its “People You May Know” algorithm
Stuart Kirk, previously global head of responsible investing at HSBC Asset Mangement, was "cancelled" after sclaiming that the climate risk to investing had been overstated.
Alicia Chia, 26, has amassed a large following on TikTok with her videos about life hacks, with a certain eccentric twist to them.

site_title: Crypto broker Genesis says lending plunged 80% in third quarter
summary: Crypto brokerage Genesis reported a 80% decline in lending to $2.8 billion in the third quarter, down from $8.4 billion in the prior quarter. Trading volumes also fell, with spot volume decreasing 44% to $9.6 billion. The company attributed the decline to a "sustained crypto winter" and a waning appetite for leverage due to deteriorating macro conditions. Genesis also reported an 8% increase in client signups for its custody services, but overall, the company's businesses experienced substantial declines.

site_title: Amazon slips below US$1t in value after bleak outlook
summary: Amazon's market value briefly fell below $1 trillion after its disappointing earnings report and outlook, with the stock declining 12% on Friday and closing 6.8% lower. The company projected slow holiday-quarter growth and missed sales estimates for its web services business. Despite a rebound, Amazon's shares have fallen 38% this year, and analysts say the stock could trade range-bound until a macroeconomic storm clears.

images.alt_text: Sales could grow as little as 2 per cent in the final three months of this year, Amazon said, crimped by a strong US dollar that makes products more expensive in other countries.

site_title: Commercial property market hits inflection point as debt cost outpaces rent
summary: The commercial property market has reached an inflection point due to rising debt costs outpacing rent. According to Moody's Analytics, 28% of new commercial mortgage-backed securities had negative leverage in the third quarter, with only 8% in the second quarter. This trend is affecting properties such as warehouses and apartments, which saw soaring prices as investors bet on rent increases. As a result, demand for warehouses is cooling and apartment landlords are facing pressure from renters reaching affordability limits.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Industrial Trust in 2021 acquired a portfolio of 29 data centres in the US - including 250 Williams Street in Atlanta (pictured) - for S$1.8 billion.
Analysts were optimistic on an upside for the Reit even as they assume that close to S$92 million would be raised in FY2023 to fund the remaining payment for Guangdong DC 3.
China’s real estate market has been rocked by a liquidity crunch fuelled in part by a clampdown started in 2020 on excessive borrowing by property firms and speculation by home buyers.
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.
Real estate deals will take many months longer to close, creating a “ripple effect” for developers and lenders.

site_title: The NBA is ‘open for business’, looks to invest in more startups
summary: The NBA has formalized its investment arm, NBA Equity, to actively seek equity stakes in startups globally. The league is open to investing in various categories, including apparel, media, and sports betting. With nearly 20 companies in its portfolio, valued at around $1 billion, the NBA aims to be a strategic investor that enhances the league and its products. The new division, led by David Lee, will focus on early-stage rounds but can consider larger deals if strategic fit is made.

images.alt_text: Harris is worth an estimated US$7.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: CNN cuts back on original series and films
summary: CNN is cutting back on original series and films as part of its cost-cutting efforts. The network will no longer commission third-party premium content, instead producing long-form content internally led by Amy Entelis. This decision was made due to the increasing cost of commissioning third-party content and the company's worsening economy and pressure from parent Warner Bros Discovery. The cuts will result in layoffs, but employees required to air shows and movies already planned for 2023 will remain. CNN had previously produced critically acclaimed films and series, including "RBG" and "Anthony Bourdain: Parts Unknown".

images.alt_text: AT&T’s WarnerMedia unit and Discovery completed their merger in April to form Warner Bros Discovery.
Donald Trump accused CNN of waging a campaign of “libel and slander” against him because it “fears” he will run for president again in 2024.

site_title: Private lender cuts Canada mortgage business as defaults rise
summary: Canadian private lender Romspen Investment has cut back on its mortgage business due to rising interest rates and defaults, with non-performing loans reaching 40% of its portfolio. The firm, backed by TIG Advisors, is being selective in financing deals to match the current economic environment. Rising interest rates have disrupted Canada's real estate market, causing delays in closing real estate deals, which will have a "ripple effect" on developers and lenders. Romspen aims to raise $500 million for its US vehicle and $200-250 million for its flagship fund.

images.alt_text: A residential housing neighborhood is seen in West Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada October 10, 2022. REUTERS/Chris Helgren
Ontario, home to Canada’s financial capital of Toronto, is projected to have more new households than new homes by 2030, according to Canada’s national housing agency.

site_title: Private equity firms probed by US on overlapping board seats
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating private equity firms Blackstone, Apollo Global Management, and KKR & Co for allegedly violating antitrust laws by placing executives on boards of companies in the same sector, potentially influencing competition and consumer prices. The firms received civil investigative demands, and the probe is part of the Biden administration's push to rein in corporate consolidation. The investigation looks broadly across many industries, including healthcare, where firms have assembled portfolios of providers. The firms deny any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has had a majority stake in the Burlington, Massachusetts-based company since 2020.

site_title: Crisis trauma haunts Korea as it confronts a credit meltdown
summary: South Korea is facing a credit meltdown, with yields on top-rated corporate debt spiking 157 basis points in three months, the worst on record. The crisis was triggered by a shock default in late September, and authorities have responded with a 50 trillion won aid package and a range of measures to stabilize credit markets. The government has pledged to support the local credit market, which has become increasingly fragile, and is working to prevent a broader financial crisis. Memories of past financial crises, including the 1997 crisis, are fresh, and policymakers are under pressure to respond quickly to prevent economic damage and political turmoil.

images.alt_text: South Korea's GDP grew by a seasonally-adjusted 0.3 per cent in real terms from the previous quarter, the Bank of Korea estimated on Thursday, marking the slowest growth since the third quarter of 2021.

site_title: Musk’s free speech plans for Twitter clash with EU content rules
summary: Elon Musk's plans for Twitter's free speech approach may clash with the European Union's Digital Services Act (DSA), which requires tech platforms to remove illegal content and follow content moderation rules. The EU's Internal Markets Commissioner, Thierry Breton, has warned Musk that his free-speech approach would have to follow the DSA, which could result in fines of up to 6% of global annual turnover. The DSA aims to ensure companies find and remove illegal content, but its application can differ between EU countries, and Musk's Twitter may face significant fines or even be barred from operating in the EU if it fails to comply.

images.alt_text: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal has made hundreds of millions of US dollars by investing in companies such as Uber Technologies to Twitter.
FILE PHOTO: An image of Elon Musk is seen on smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
Elon Musk took control of Twitter and fired its top executives, US media reported on Oct 27, 2022.
The deal’s completion would mark an end to a lawsuit by Twitter, which, along with investors, now expects the deal to be completed on its original terms of US$54.20 per share.

site_title: China eases strict Covid rules for table tennis tournaments
summary: China has relaxed strict COVID-19 rules for elite table tennis players competing in the 2022 World Team Table Tennis Championships Final in Chengdu. The event, the first major international sporting competition since the Beijing Winter Games, was held in a closed-loop system with nearly 1,300 athletes and staff in a bubble, allowing them to interact with each other while isolated from the general public. The relaxed rules are seen as a test for hosting major international events in China, with the International Table Tennis Federation's CEO citing the sport's popularity and favorable treatment in the country as key factors.

images.alt_text: The relaxed measures, effective from Nov 1, were announced after Qatar last month said Covid vaccinations were not mandatory for the expected million-plus fans.

site_title: US to spend US$703m on improving ports
summary: The US Transportation Department has awarded $703 million to 41 port infrastructure projects in 22 states and American Samoa, funded by the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure law signed by President Joe Biden in 2021. The projects aim to improve supply chain reliability, electrify equipment, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by boosting coastal, Great Lakes, and inland river ports, as well as enhancing rail and highway connections and supporting offshore wind projects.

images.alt_text: port, pier, cargo containers

site_title: EU to prolong state aid for firms impacted by Ukraine war
summary: The European Commission has extended state aid measures for companies impacted by the Ukraine war and soaring energy prices until December 31, 2023. The maximum limits on state support have also been raised, with companies in the agriculture and fisheries sectors eligible for up to 300,000 euros, while other sectors can receive up to 2 million euros. The measures also require companies to meet carbon footprint targets and energy efficiency measures to receive aid. This aims to incentivize the green transition while maintaining market incentives to reduce energy consumption.

images.alt_text: Ursula von der Leyen, President of European Commission, says: “It is logical that instead of outbidding each other, energy companies should leverage their joint purchasing power.”

site_title: CEO of Sabana Industrial Reit’s manager adds to his stake in the Reit
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.3% from Oct 21-27, while the Hang Seng Index fell 6.1% and the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI gained 0.5%. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the four sessions, with S$100 million of net outflows. UOB, Jardine Matheson, Singtel, and DBS led the outflows, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, OCBC, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Sembcorp Marine, and Singapore Airlines led the inflows. 20 primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, totaling S$10.4 million.

images.alt_text: Overall, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Oct 20, with close to S$40 million of net outflows.

site_title: Biden condemns ‘political violence’ after attack on Paul Pelosi
summary: US President Joe Biden condemned "political violence" after an intruder attacked House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul Pelosi, at their San Francisco home on October 28. The suspect, identified as David DePape, is in custody and faces charges including attempted homicide and elder abuse. Biden expressed concern over the growing threats against lawmakers, citing over 9,600 reported threats in 2021. He urged Americans to reject "political violence" and urged Speaker Pelosi to return to her husband, who underwent a successful operation to repair his injuries.

images.alt_text: Paul Pelosi (right) was sentenced to five days in jail and ordered to pay US$6,800 in fines and restitution on Tuesday after he pleaded guilty to causing injury by drunken driving.

site_title: Canada’s economy posts surprise 0.1% gain in August
summary: Canada's economy grew by a surprise 0.1% in August, driven by strong agricultural and retail activity. The growth was slightly above the Bank of Canada's forecast of 1.5% for the third quarter. Key sectors contributing to the growth included retail trade (1.2% increase) and agriculture (3.9% increase), while manufacturing and construction declined. The Canadian dollar was trading 0.3% lower.

site_title: Spanish prosecutors drop criminal charges against Neymar
summary: Spanish prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against Neymar, the Brazilian soccer star, and his family, citing lack of evidence in a 2013 transfer to Barcelona. The charges were related to a secret agreement between Neymar's family and Barcelona, which prosecutors claimed was a form of corruption. Neymar's legal team argued that private corruption is not a crime in Brazil, and the case may not be over, with DIS, a Brazilian sports investment company, continuing to pursue a civil damages claim for millions of dollars.

images.alt_text: A signage of Qatar 2022 on display in Doha, Qatar, where the Fifa World Cup will be staged from Nov 20 to Dec 18.
Neymar 'very keen' on playing in MLS

site_title: Blackstone to weigh sale of stake in HealthEdge Software
summary: Blackstone is exploring options for HealthEdge Software, including the sale of a 50% stake that could value the healthcare software company at about $3 billion. The company, which sells software to health insurers, is projecting revenue of $400 million next year and earnings of $60 million. Blackstone bought a majority stake in the Burlington, Massachusetts-based company in 2020 and is seeking another financial investor to help grow the business. Deliberations are in the early stages, and there's no certainty they'll result in a stake sale.

site_title: A healthy economy remains key to China’s goals
summary: China's 20th Communist Party Congress concluded with President Xi Jinping's re-election as party general secretary for a third term. Despite concerns about policy shifts, Xi reiterated the importance of growth in various sectors, including emerging industries and infrastructure. China is expected to increase its focus on green and low-carbon technology and continue opening up globally, with potential policy tweaks on the zero-Covid policy. Markets have sold off, but domestic investors have been net buyers, and the foreign selling may be overdone. A gradual economic recovery is expected, with key economic meetings in December to follow.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping speaks during the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022.
Chinese President Xi Jinping delivers a report to the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Oct 16.

site_title: Rich nations still far from funding target ahead of Cop27
summary: Rich nations are still far from meeting their $100 billion annual financing pledge for poor countries by 2025, according to a report released ahead of Cop27. Despite reaffirming their commitment, developed countries acknowledge the need for more work to reach the goal. Only five countries have made commitments over and above last year's projections, and multilateral development banks have approved over $50 billion in climate finance in 2021. The report highlights the need for increased transparency and private sector funding, with "trillions of dollars" needed to support adaptation and resilience efforts.

images.alt_text: US dollars, currency, money

site_title: World Cup favourites eye glory in Qatar
summary: The FIFA World Cup is set to begin in Qatar on November 20, with Brazil, France, Argentina, and England considered top contenders. Brazil, the five-time champions, boasts a talented squad led by Neymar and Vinicius Jr, while France aims to retain their title after a 36-year drought. Argentina, led by Lionel Messi, seeks to win their third title, and England looks to break their 56-year wait for a World Cup victory. The tournament will feature 32 teams competing in a unique November-December schedule.

images.alt_text: FIFA chief business officer Romy Gai said the bids did not reflect the popularity of women’s football and highlighted the 2019 World Cup’s record viewership figures.
Fifa has lauded Qatar’s preparations and the eight stadiums designed to highlight Arabic tradition and culture.
The Hayya Service Centre in Doha will provide direct support for fans; all travellers to Qatar will need the Hayya pass to enter from Nov 1, whether they intend to watch a game or not.

site_title: Japan asks Malaysia’s Petronas to help customers after LNG disruption
summary: Japanese Industry Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura requested Petronas CEO Tengku Taufik to continue efforts to mitigate the impact of a liquefied natural gas (LNG) disruption on Japanese customers. The disruption occurred at Malaysia LNG Dua due to a pipeline leak, and Petronas has declared force majeure on gas supply. Despite the disruption, major Japanese LNG buyers, including Jera and Tokyo Gas, expect minimal impact on their fuel procurement. Petronas assured that it will work closely with customers to mitigate and manage the situation.

site_title: Chrysler parent Stellantis offers US salaried buyouts
summary: Stellantis, parent company of Chrysler, has offered voluntary buyouts to 13,000 US salaried employees aged 55 or older with 10+ years of service. The deadline to seek a buyout is December 5. This move is part of Stellantis' transformation to become a sustainable tech mobility company, focusing on low-emission vehicles. The company plans to have 75 electric vehicle models on the market by 2030, aiming for 50% of US sales to be electric or plug-in hybrids by then.

images.alt_text: Leading the charge is Tesla, where chief executive Elon Musk has outlined an audacious plan to build 20 million EVs in 2030, requiring an estimated 3 terawatt-hours of batteries.
Stellantis is mulling the potential exit as more established foreign auto brands have struggled to maintain their position in China’s market.

site_title: Book review: The case for long-term value investing
summary: A book review of "The Case for Long-Term Value Investing" by Jim Cullen, a 60-year investment management veteran, is presented. Cullen advocates for long-term value investing, emphasizing the importance of discipline, valuations, earnings, and dividend growth. He presents data and analysis from 1968 to 2020, concluding that long-term value investing can produce satisfactory risk- and inflation-adjusted returns over a five-year period. The book also considers market timing, covered call writing, and its applicability to all capitalizations and geographic areas. The author recommends annual investment contributions until age 80, making the book suitable for all investors.

images.alt_text: Your Essential Guide to Sustainable Investing, by Larry Swedroe and Samuel Adams, provides a guide to the history and current practices of sustainable investing.

site_title: Zuckerberg to testify in US case against Facebook's virtual reality deal
summary: Mark Zuckerberg will testify in a US case against Facebook's virtual reality deal with Within Unlimited, a VR content maker. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) argues the proposed acquisition would "substantially lessen competition" in the VR market. Zuckerberg will also be questioned about Facebook's strategy for its VR business and plans to support third-party developers. The FTC claims the deal would create a monopoly in VR-dedicated fitness apps, while Meta argues the allegations are "conclusory, speculative, and contradictory."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Facebook Chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifies at a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, U.S., October 23, 2019. REUTERS/Erin Scott/File Photo

site_title: NextEra makes billion-dollar-bet on natural gas from landfills
summary: NextEra Energy, the largest producer of solar and wind power, plans to invest $1.1 billion to buy facilities that convert landfill gas into electricity and renewable natural gas. The company will refine the gas into a renewable form of natural gas, which can be sold to customers, and also produce hydrogen for synthetic jet fuel. The deal is expected to generate $220 million of adjusted earnings by 2025 and qualify the facilities for federal tax credits. NextEra aims to expand its renewable fuel business and meet growing demand for clean energy.

images.alt_text: Most pundits expect oil prices to remain high as a result of tight conditions but there are serious headwinds

site_title: Russian central bank holds key rate at 7.5%, noting high inflation expectations
summary: Russia's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 7.5% despite high inflation expectations, citing the partial mobilization as a deterrent to consumer demand and inflation over the coming months. The decision, which marks the end of a months-long rate-cutting cycle, also warned of long-term pro-inflationary effects from the mobilization. The move comes after the central bank previously cut rates six times since February 2022, when it hiked the rate to 20% to mitigate financial stability risks.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens lower after warnings from Amazon, Apple
summary: The Nasdaq Composite opened lower on October 28, 2022, due to gloomy forecasts from Amazon and Apple, despite US consumer spending increasing more than expected in September. The Nasdaq dropped 26.47 points, or 0.25%, to 10,766.20, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 171.03 points, or 0.53%, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 0.96 points, or 0.03%.

site_title: Credit Suisse's newly created investment bank lays out plans in memo
summary: Credit Suisse's newly created investment bank, CS First Boston, will advise on mergers and acquisitions, raise capital for clients, and provide leveraged finance, according to a memo. The unit will be carved out of the Swiss lender and will be moved to the company's Swiss Bank to offer services in its home market. The goal is to become an independent standalone investment bank, attracting third-party capital and employee ownership. The restructuring plan aims to reduce volatility in earnings and reallocate capital to the global wealth management business.

images.alt_text: It will cut 2,700 jobs or 5 per cent of its workforce by the end of this year, and ultimately reduce its workforce by roughly 9,000 to about 43,000 by the end of 2025.
Credit Suisse booked a 3.7 billion franc impairment on deferred tax assets related to the strategy review.

site_title: Red Bull to pay US$7m fine for F1 cost cap breach
summary: Red Bull has been fined US$7 million by the International Automobile Federation (FIA) for breaching the Formula One cost cap in the 2022 season. Despite the fine, Red Bull's titles were safe, as the team won the 2021 and 2022 drivers' championships with Max Verstappen. The team will also have 10% less wind tunnel time over the next year as a result of the breach.

images.alt_text: Red Bull’s Verstappen crossed the line first, and he was then awarded the title when second-place finisher Charles Leclerc was given a five-second penalty, dropping him to third.

site_title: China’s Citic Securities reports third-quarter profit dip
summary: Citic Securities, China's largest brokerage, reported a 1.4% fall in third-quarter profit to 5.37 billion yuan, down from 5.45 billion yuan in the same period last year.
