Revenue for the first nine months of the year fell 19.2% to 8.8 billion yuan, with commission fees in asset management declining 5.8%. However, investment banking commission fees rose 11.1%. The brokerage sector as a whole earned 81.2 billion yuan in net profit in the first half of the year, down 10.06% from the previous year.

site_title: Pioneering rocker Jerry Lee Lewis dead at 87
summary: Rock and roll pioneer Jerry Lee Lewis, known for hits like "Great Balls of Fire" and "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," died on October 28, 2022, at 87. Lewis' career spanned over half a century, despite being marred by scandals, including his marriage to his 13-year-old cousin. He suffered years of illnesses and injuries, which ultimately led to his death. Lewis' legacy as a trailblazing musician continues to inspire artists, including Elton John and Mick Jagger, who credited him as a key influence.

images.alt_text: CANNES is set to be shaken, rattled and rolled on Wednesday (May 25) as the world premiere of Elvis rocks the film festival on the French Riviera, in what is proving a vintage year for music-lovers.

site_title: Saudi’s Kingdom Holding company to maintain Twitter stake
summary: Saudi Arabia's Kingdom Holding Company, owned by Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, will maintain its $1.89 billion stake in Twitter following Elon Musk's takeover of the social media company. Despite Musk's plans to reduce content restrictions, Kingdom Holding has committed to holding its shares. The company is 16.9% owned by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, chaired by Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman.

site_title: Germany-Sweden subsea power cable delayed to 2028/29
summary: Germany-Sweden's subsea power cable project, Hansa PowerBridge, has been delayed to 2028/29 due to changes in construction contracts and grid requirements. The project, aiming to connect Sweden to Germany with a 700 megawatt capacity, was initially set to be operational by 2026. The delay is expected to be approximately two years, with procurement restarting in 2024. The new timeline aims to facilitate the transportation of renewable power from the Nordic region to Germany and ensure a more secure electricity supply in southern Sweden.

site_title: One million Belgian employees expected to get 11.6% pay raise due to inflation
summary: One million Belgian employees are expected to receive an automatic 11.59% pay raise on January 1, 2023, due to record inflation in the country. Annual inflation in Belgium hit 12.27% in October, its highest since June 1975. The pay raise is linked to inflation by law to maintain purchasing power. This is the second pay increase in a year, following a 3% raise in January 2022.

site_title: Oil futures ease 1% as China widens Covid curbs
summary: Oil futures eased 1% on Friday as China widened its Covid-19 curbs, despite strong economic data and supply concerns. Brent futures fell to $95.77 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $87.90. The International Monetary Fund expects China's growth to slow to 3.2% this year due to uncertainty over its zero-Covid policy. Despite this, PetroChina expects China's demand for refined fuel to grow year-on-year in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled up US$1.27, or 1.3 per cent, to US$96.96 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settled up US$1.17, or 1.3 per cent, to US$89.08 a barrel.
Exxon posted the highest profit in its 152-year history, while Chevron announced its second-best quarterly result as natural gas demand and prices surged.

site_title: Investor engagement critical to tackling climate change in South-east Asia
summary: Investors in South-east Asia can play a critical role in tackling climate change by taking strategic and effective action. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change predicts rising flood levels and heatwaves will become more common in Asia, emphasizing the need for sustainable investments. Investors can use various options, including voting at shareholder meetings, engaging with companies, and investing in sustainability opportunities like renewable energy. While divestment can be effective, it may not always be the best answer, and engagement can be a more impactful strategy for driving positive change. Effective engagement can lead to better long-term outcomes and create long-term stakeholder value.

images.alt_text: Sustainable funds that avoided traditional oil and energy companies underperformed this year. Starving the sector of capital may be a disservice to the long-term energy transition.
Shareholders are better educated and asking more critical questions as they demand accountability, says Sias president and chief executive David Gerald.

site_title: RWS hires Singapore Business Federation chief, MBS casino veteran
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has announced two key appointments: Lam Yi Young, the chief executive officer of the Singapore Business Federation, will join RWS as its deputy CEO in January, pending a suitability assessment. Andrew MacDonald, a casino veteran with over four decades of experience, has also been appointed as chief casino officer. The appointments are part of RWS' efforts to strengthen its leadership and operations.

site_title: Exxon, Chevron profits soar on natural gas export surge
summary: ExxonMobil and Chevron reported record-breaking profits in the third quarter, with Exxon's net income reaching $19.7 billion, the highest in its 152-year history. Natural gas demand and prices surged, contributing to the surge in earnings. The two companies' combined net income surpassed $30 billion, amid criticism from politicians and consumers struggling with inflation and energy shortages. Despite the pressure to lower prices, oil executives are under pressure to ease emissions and cut exploration costs, while shareholders demand higher returns.

images.alt_text: Chevron Corp posted its biggest quarterly earnings ever on Friday (Jul 29), built on strong fuel margins and high prices for natural gas and oil, and boosted its expectations for share buybacks in the coming months.
ExxonMobil said it “safely exited” Russia after the government earlier this month “unilaterally terminated” its interests in the Sakhalin-1 oil and gas project, its largest in the country.

site_title: US: Dow ends 2.6% higher, adding to weekly gains
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 2.6% higher, reaching 32,861.8, for its sixth straight positive session. Stocks rallied due to solid earnings from Apple, which surged 7.6% after reporting higher profits despite lower-than-expected iPhone sales. Other tech companies, including Microsoft and Alphabet, also advanced. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained 2.5% and 2.9%, respectively. The gains were partly driven by hopes of a Federal Reserve policy pivot to counter inflation.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite dropped 26.47 points, or 0.25 per cent, to 10,766.20 at the opening bell.

site_title: Media entertainment company NoonTalk lodges preliminary document for Catalist IPO
summary: Singapore-based media entertainment company NoonTalk has lodged a preliminary document for its initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company aims to raise funds for regional expansion in film and drama production, investment in multimedia technology, and other purposes. Led by CEO Dasmond Koh, NoonTalk has produced various events and films, including Chingay 2022 and "The Antique Shop", a collaborative film in Thailand. The company has a profit after tax of S$22,407 for the financial year ended June 30, and has a cash balance of S$1.8 million. NoonTalk is confident about gaining market share in South-east Asia and developing comprehensive marketing strategies for its clients.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo is also proposing a hard nine-year limit on the tenure of independent directors and the mandatory disclosure of the actual amount and breakdown of the remuneration of directors and chief executive officer on a named basis.

site_title: US pending home sales tumble in September
summary: US pending home sales dropped 10.2% in September, falling to 79.5, as the housing market continues to decline due to higher mortgage rates. This marks the fourth consecutive month of decline, with economists forecasting a 5.0% drop. The decline in signed contracts suggests existing home sales will continue to fall, with the housing market being the hardest hit by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, which have raised mortgage rates to 7.08% for the first time since 2002.

site_title: China's Giant Biogene to raise US$70m in HK IPO, according to sources
summary: Giant Biogene, a Chinese company specializing in medicinal skin care treatment, has priced its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) at HK$24.30 each, raising US$70 million. The company initially aimed to raise up to US$500 million but scaled back the deal due to volatile financial market sentiment. Giant Biogene sold 22.6 million shares in the IPO, which will start trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange next Friday.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is set to see billions of dollars flowing in from the mainland with more Chinese companies expected to upgrade their listings in the city to tap into a bigger pool of capital amid the looming threat of delistings in the United States.

site_title: Google plans legal challenge to India's antitrust crackdown on Android
summary: Google is planning a legal challenge to India's antitrust ruling that aims to change its approach to its Android operating system, citing concerns it will restrict how the platform is promoted. The ruling, which fined Google $275 million, seeks wider ranging remedial measures, including restrictions on pre-installing Google apps and sideloading. Google is worried that the decision could increase regulatory pressures in other jurisdictions and has already faced a record $4.1 billion fine in a European court.

images.alt_text: “In May 2022, the EC and the CMA each opened a formal investigation into Google Play’s business practices,” Google said in a quarterly earnings filing dated Oct 25.

site_title: Key US inflation measure keeps pace in September
summary: The US inflation measure, as measured by the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, rose 6.2% from a year ago in September, maintaining its pace from the previous month. Food prices increased 11.9% and energy prices surged 20.3% year-over-year. The data failed to provide relief to President Joe Biden ahead of the midterm elections, with price pressures still elevated. The slight 0.3% increase from August was in line with analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Durable goods orders increased 0.4 per cent last month to US$274.7 billion, picking up less than expected but still reversing the weaker showings of previous months.

site_title: ESG funds in Asia ex-Japan record US$660m in outflows in Q3, says Morningstar
summary: ESG funds in Asia (excluding Japan) experienced net outflows of approximately $660 million in Q3 2022, according to Morningstar. Excluding China, the region saw nearly $600 million in net inflows. Globally, sustainable funds attracted $22.5 billion in net new money, while global funds suffered a net outflow of $198 billion. Despite the outflows, ESG funds outperformed the global fund market, with asset sizes declining 1.6% to $2.2 trillion.

images.alt_text: Socially conscious stock funds often hold lots of growth stocks, especially tech shares. That’s been painful this year, as the stock market has favoured value stocks like energy and industrial companies.

site_title: 'Golden parachutes' for 3 fired Twitter executives worth US$122m
summary: Three former top Twitter executives, Parag Agrawal, Ned Segal, and Vijaya Gadde, who were fired by new owner Elon Musk, are set to receive separation payouts totaling $122 million. Agrawal's "golden parachute" is valued at $57.4 million, while Segal's is $44.5 million, and Gadde's is $20 million. The payouts are based on their compensation packages, which were reportedly valued before Musk's takeover.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk took control of Twitter and fired its top executives, US media reported on Oct 27, 2022.

site_title: Sinopec's profit falls as high oil prices, Covid curbs weigh
summary: Sinopec Group reported a 5.6% decline in net income to 56.66 billion yuan (S$11.03 billion) for the January to September period, driven by low domestic fuel demand and high global oil prices. Revenue rose 23% to 2.45 trillion yuan. Refinery crude throughput rebounded in the third quarter, but was still 8% lower than the same period last year. The company prioritizes domestic fuel supply and plans to optimize export plans based on domestic and overseas situations.

images.alt_text: The firm is based in the eastern city of Nanjing where Sinopec has the strongest reserve of carbon industry know-how.

site_title: Italian inflation surges in October ahead of eurozone figures
summary: Italian inflation surged to a record 12.8% year-on-year in October, the highest level since 1996, with energy price inflation jumping to 73.2% and core inflation climbing to 5.7%. The new Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni faces significant economic challenges, including a high public debt and recession concerns. The European Central Bank's deposit rate was hiked for the third time, and analysts predict more volatility in headline numbers, with the ECB's Survey of Professional Forecasters showing eurozone inflation will be higher than feared for years to come.

site_title: China’s largest banks weather property woes but margins narrow
summary: China's largest banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Agricultural Bank of China (AgBank), Bank of Communications (BoCom), and Bank of China (BOC), reported a 4-6% increase in net profit for the third quarter, despite property market woes. The banks' diverse lending portfolios helped insulate them from the turmoil. However, most banks saw a decline in net interest margins, a key indicator of bank profitability, due to weak loan demand. China's GDP data showed a slowdown in domestic demand and export growth, further exacerbating the pressure on banks' net interest margins.

site_title: Wilmar posts 34.7% rise in Q3 profit to US$766.2 million
summary: Wilmar International reported a 34.7% increase in Q3 net profit to US$766.2 million, driven by a 10.2% rise in revenue and higher sales from joint ventures and associates. The feed and industrial products segment saw an 8.5% rise in sales, while the food products segment posted a 3.2% growth. Operating cash flow jumped 68.2% to US$3.5 billion. Despite challenging global operating conditions, Wilmar remains confident in its diversified business model and risk management policies.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB's revised target price reflects the latest valuation of Wilmar's listed subsidiaries and is closer to the company's book value of S$4.39.

site_title: Dinosaur enthusiasts turn up in full force to view T-Rex skeleton in Singapore
summary: A 12.2m-long Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton, named Shen, is on public display in Singapore's Victoria Theatre and Concert Hall before being auctioned off in Hong Kong on November 30. The 67-million-year-old skeleton, estimated to be worth between $15 million and $25 million, is the first T-Rex to be auctioned in Asia. Dinosaur enthusiasts from children to retirees flocked to see Shen, with many hoping it will end up in a museum or public institution for research and education.

site_title: China ramps up lockdowns, Covid restrictions across the country
summary: China has intensified its COVID-19 lockdowns, with fresh restrictions imposed in Wuhan, Guangzhou, Beijing, and Shanghai. The country reported 1,321 new cases, the highest in two weeks, as infections rise again. Lockdowns affect 31 cities, covering 24.5% of China's GDP and 1 in 6 of its population. The strict measures, despite expectations of a policy change after the Communist Party congress, are being enforced more rigorously, with apartment blocks and neighborhoods subject to stay-at-home orders if a close contact has visited.

images.alt_text: China has repeatedly vowed to stick to its zero-tolerance response to Covid-19 and implement what the authorities say are necessary measures to contain the virus.

site_title: Japan stays put with negative interest rates; consumer inflation at a 33-year high
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates and kept the 10-year yield cap unchanged, as predicted by 49 economists surveyed. Core consumer prices in Tokyo rose 3.4% in October, exceeding the 2% target, but inflation is expected to cool below 2% next year. The decision came after Japan's government announced a fresh $200 billion spending package to alleviate inflation pain. The yen weakened after the announcement, reaching its lowest level in three decades, and the dollar gained over 1% against it.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect a portion of the package to be funded by additional debt issuance that would increase Japan’s already huge public debt which, at twice the size of its economy, is the biggest among major economies.

site_title: Salary range transparency for NYC job seekers
summary: New York City has implemented a law requiring nearly every company to include salary ranges for job postings on public sites and internal bulletin boards, starting Tuesday. The law applies to companies with at least four workers and covers base salaries, excluding benefits. The move aims to reduce gender and racial pay gaps, with research showing that salary disclosure laws elsewhere have helped narrow these gaps. The law is part of a growing trend in the US, with Colorado, California, and Washington state also implementing similar requirements, and some large companies, such as Citigroup, have already begun posting salary ranges for job openings.

images.alt_text: The worst-hit region is likely to be Europe, where real salaries – nominal wage growth minus the rate of inflation – are seen being driven down an average 1.5 per cent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's employment continued to grow in Q3 2022, reaching above pre-pandemic levels by 1.7%. However, early signs suggest the labour market improvement may be slowing due to easing economic growth. Meanwhile, HDB resale prices rose 2.6% in Q3, and hotel room rates reached a 14-year high in September, driven by F1 events. Private home prices grew 3.8% in Q3, while corporate earnings saw UOB's Q3 profit increase 34% and CDL Hospitality Trusts' net property income rise 54.4%.

site_title: Keppel Reit enters Japan office market with 8.8 billion yen purchase in Tokyo
summary: Keppel Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), has acquired a 98.47% stake in a Tokyo office building, Ginza 2-chome, for 8.83 billion yen (S$84.4 million). The eight-storey building has a net lettable area of 3,427.1 square meters and is located in the prime Ginza district. The acquisition strengthens Keppel Reit's geographical and income diversification, providing greater stability and enhancing its visibility in the Japanese market. The property is expected to generate a net property income yield of about 3.1% and pro forma distribution per unit accretion of 0.5%.

images.alt_text: 吉宝湾大厦（Keppel Bay Tower）外观。

site_title: ‘Unicorn factory’ Estonia makes its move on deep tech
summary: Estonia, known for producing 10 unicorns, aims to nurture more "deep-tech" startups in fields like agritech, cybersecurity, and autonomous vehicles. The country's venture capital arm plans to increase its investment to 300 million euros, focusing on sustainability and deep-tech startups. Co-investment is key, as investors are "reluctant to invest" in deep tech. Estonia seeks to collaborate with the Singapore startup ecosystem, with interest growing among Estonian startups to expand to Singapore or collaborate with the city-state's ecosystem.

images.alt_text: A whole slew of announcement are made  in Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's opening speech at SWITCH 2022

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 6.78 points to 1,447.31. A total of 2.384 billion lots worth RM1.651 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 450 to 393.

site_title: Toll Group looking to expand footprint across Asia
summary: Toll Group, a supply chain and logistics firm, is expanding its presence in Asia, with plans to invest US$1.2 billion in the region over the next three years. The majority of this investment will be in warehouses, with new facilities planned in India, Indonesia, Vietnam, China, and Singapore. Toll Group's group managing director, Alan Beacham, sees India as a key market due to its fast growth and neutral structure. The company is also investing in innovation and technology, including the launch of a S$20 million innovation centre in Singapore.

images.alt_text: It is too risky to keep supply chain eggs in just one basket, such as only relying on air or ocean freight. By ramping up on cross-border freight, you can implement a multimodal strategy that addresses your business goals and challenges says C.H. Robinson's Shawn Chen.

site_title: Air France-KLM, British Airways to lift capacity despite outlook
summary: Air France-KLM and British Airways owner IAG plan to lift passenger capacity close to pre-Covid levels despite economic concerns. IAG aims for 95% of 2019 capacity in the first quarter, while Air France-KLM targets 90%. The recovery is driven by a desire for vacations and visits after the coronavirus crisis, but business travel remains slow. Despite this, IAG reported a higher-than-expected operating profit for the quarter. The companies face challenges, including labor shortages and rising energy costs, which may impact their ability to meet full-year capacity targets.

images.alt_text: European airline stocks have plunged over the last six months over worries that rising household bills will dampen appetite for travel, but IAG said it was confident on future demand.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week on a high amid bargain hunting; STI up 1.5% on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week with a 1.5% gain, closing at 3,059.19, as investor sentiment improved ahead of the third-quarter corporate earnings season. Banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC were top gainers, with UOB announcing a 34% increase in Q3 earnings. Other notable performers included Keppel Corporation and Nio, while Nio was the biggest loser, falling 8.2%. Despite this, the STI still rose 3% for the week.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index tumbled 3.66 per cent, or 564.88 points, to 14,863.06.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 1.0 per cent to 7,002.83 points.
The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.9 per cent lower at 6,785.70, but rose 1.6 per cent for the week - its best since the week ended Oct 7.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,039.67 points.

site_title: Auditors should proactively consider companies’ climate-related risks: ISCA
summary: AUDITORS should consider climate-related risks when assessing companies' financial statements, according to the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA). The organization released a technical guidance, citing a study that found auditors rarely comment on discrepancies between financial statements and sustainability reporting. ISCA called for auditors to check if management's climate-related risk assessments are consistent with sustainability reporting and to consider the impact of climate-related commitments on financial statements. This change is necessary for financial statements to remain "useful and relevant" in light of shifting stakeholder focus on climate issues.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.
EY’s official announcement on Friday (Sep 9) has confirmed what the market had been speculating for months: that it would separate into 2 distinct, multidisciplinary organisations.

site_title: Japan’s PM Kishida spends to ease inflation, popularity woes
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced an economic stimulus package worth 71.6 trillion yen to ease inflation and boost growth. The package includes 39 trillion yen in fiscal spending, aiming to shave 1.2 percentage points off inflation and add 4.6% to GDP. Key measures include reducing energy costs, providing handouts for families, and promoting tourism and exports. The package's size suggests part of the spending will come from existing funds, and its effectiveness remains uncertain, with economists questioning the consistency of Japan's fiscal and monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Market participants await details of the Bank of Japan's  (BOJ) bond buying operations for next month due later in the day.
Inflation in the Tokyo area thus exceeded the central bank’s 2 per cent target for five straight months.

In fresh quarterly projections, the BOJ will slightly revise up its price forecasts but still project inflation to slide back below its 2 per cent target next fiscal year as commodity and fuel price rises peak, sources told Reuters.

site_title: Xiaomi shuts financial services business in India
summary: Xiaomi has shut down its financial services business in India, four years after its launch, as part of its annual strategic assessment. The company closed its Mi Financial Services in March 2022 and removed its Mi Pay app from the National Payments Corporation of India's website. This move comes amid government probes and alleged tax evasion by Xiaomi in India, where the company has been subject to a freeze on $676 million of its assets.

site_title: Iron ore crashes on economic gloom, supply pressures
summary: Iron ore prices plummeted 3.6% to a 2020 low of US$78.80 a tonne on the Singapore Exchange, amid economic gloom and supply-side pressures. Global steel demand is expected to weaken, and China's economy is hit by Covid-19 curbs and a property slump, with the International Monetary Fund predicting no year-end rebound. Supply-side issues, including increased production from Australia's Fortescue Metals Group and Brazil's Vale SA, also contributed to the price drop.

images.alt_text: This week traders look to Asia, with palm oil stockpiles in No 2 grower Malaysia seen hitting the highest in almost three years, industry estimates show.

site_title: T-Up programme to expand to Trade Associations and Chambers in 2023
summary: The Technology for Enterprise Capability Upgrading (T-Up) programme will expand to Trade Associations and Chambers (TACs) in 2023, allowing them to tap into A*Star's expertise in research and development. Over 1,000 scientists have been seconded to SMEs since 2003, and the programme aims to help SMEs stay competitive through R&D and innovation. The T-Up Eagles awards, launched this year, recognize promising students for their achievements and contributions to local companies. The programme is part of A*Star's efforts to support SMEs in a climate of economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Singapore's research, innovation and enterprise ecosystem has many offerings to support small and medium-sized enteprises, from the Centres of Innovation in polyclinics to government funding.

site_title: Vietnam central bank: difficult to cut interest rates at this time
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) has raised interest rates by 200 basis points due to a 4.01% rise in September consumer prices, close to the targeted 4.0% for the year. Governor Nguyen Thi Hong stated that it's difficult to cut interest rates at this time due to elevated inflation, citing the US Federal Reserve's faster-than-anticipated rate hikes and expected additional increases. This move aims to control inflation and maintain economic stability in Vietnam.

site_title: Did Ye and Adidas just collapse the ‘influencer’ market?
summary: Adidas ended its contract with rapper Ye, formerly known as Kanye West, after a series of public controversies that offended multiple groups. The partnership, which generated nearly 1.8 billion euros in revenue for Adidas, was highly profitable but ultimately became a liability due to Ye's changing public image. Adidas' decision has sparked concerns about the risks of not managing intangible assets properly, particularly in influencer marketing strategies, where companies rely heavily on celebrity endorsements. The incident may accelerate the decline of influencer marketing and prompt companies to reassess their intangible assets.

images.alt_text: In cutting ties with Ye, formerly Kanye West, Adidas will take a €250 million ($246.5 million) hit to net income in the current fiscal year.

site_title: UOB wins appeal against Lippo in furniture rebate case; Lippo said to have ‘distorted’ property market
summary: UOB has won an appeal against Lippo Marina Collection (LMC) in a dispute over "furniture rebates" granted to property buyers. The appellate division of the Singapore High Court ruled LMC must pay damages to UOB for allegedly distorting the property market. UOB claimed LMC conspired with property agents to offer excessive rebates, inflating sale prices and misleading the bank into granting housing loans based on inflated prices. LMC must pay damages and partial costs to UOB, with the damages amount to be determined at a later assessment.

images.alt_text: Facade of the Marina Collection condominium at Sentosa Cove taken on May 31, 2021.

site_title: Taiwan Q3 GDP grows faster than expected on lifting of Covid curbs
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 4.1% in the third quarter, exceeding expectations, driven by a resumption in domestic demand following the easing of Covid-19 curbs. This is the fastest pace since the fourth quarter of last year, with consumer spending making a significant return. Exports, however, slowed to 3.38% growth in US dollar terms due to high global inflation, lockdowns in China, and weaker demand. The country will release revised GDP figures on November 29, including full-year growth forecasts for 2022.

site_title: Sunak eyes as much as £50b of UK spending cuts, tax hikes
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is considering a £50 billion package of spending cuts and tax hikes to address the country's budget shortfall. The plan aims to restore calm to the financial markets, which were disrupted by his predecessor Liz Truss's unfunded tax cuts. Sunak and Chancellor Jeremy Hunt are seeking extra headroom in the public finances to build credibility with the markets. The package's details are still unpublished, but it is expected to include significant spending cuts and tax rises, with the goal of plugging Britain's £35 billion fiscal hole.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, alongside Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt holds his first Cabinet meeting in Downing street, London, Britain October 26, 2022.  Stefan Rousseau/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Norway's wealth fund posts US$43.5b Q3 loss
summary: Norway's US$1.15 trillion sovereign wealth fund reported a Q3 loss of US$43.47 billion, its largest ever quarterly loss. The fund's return on investment was minus 4.4% due to rising interest rates, high inflation, and war in Europe affecting markets. The loss was attributed to negative returns in equities, fixed income, and unlisted real estate. The fund's benchmark index returned 0.14 percentage points stronger than the fund's return.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.66% on Friday, October 28, 2022, following weak earnings from major US tech firms like Amazon and Meta. The Hang Seng Index fell 564.88 points to 14,863.06. Similar losses were seen in the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices. The losses wiped out a cautious recovery after a 6% rout on Monday due to China's economic slowdown and President Xi Jinping's tightened grip on power.

site_title: Appliance maker Electrolux to cut up to 8% of 50,000 staff
summary: Electrolux, a Swedish appliance maker, is cutting up to 8% of its 50,000-strong workforce, affecting 3,500 to 4,000 employees, as a result of a slump in demand for household appliances. The company, citing cost reduction measures, will take a restructuring charge of 1.2-1.5 billion krona and aims for total savings of over 7 billion krona. The move comes as appliance makers struggle amid worsening economic conditions, including surging inflation and deteriorating housing markets.

site_title: American burger chain Wayback Burgers to expand into Singapore, offer alternative meat products
summary: American burger chain Wayback Burgers is expanding into Singapore through a Japan-based partner, WB Burgers Asia, with plans to open 15-20 outlets in the region over the next four years. The company is also venturing into the alternative-meat space, partnering with two Tokyo-based ventures to produce cultured meat and alternative-meat products. Dr Foods Co, a subsidiary of WBBA, has set up a Singapore office and aims to produce alternative-meat products such as vegan foie gras and plant-based steak for the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: Good Meat broke ground for its new meat production facility on Friday (Jun 10). The facility will have the capacity to produce tens of thousands of pounds of meat per year.

site_title: Glencore's bid to expand New South Wales coal mine rejected
summary: Glencore's application to expand the Glendell coal mine in New South Wales was rejected by the New South Wales Independent Planning Commission due to significant impact on heritage values in the region. The commission concluded that allowing continued open cut mining was "not in the public interest, despite its likely benefits." The proposed mine site is near the Ravensworth Homestead complex, which comprises colonial buildings. The decision was made after a site inspection and public hearing.

images.alt_text: The Glencore Plc headquarters in Baar, Switzerland. Photographer: Alessandro Della Bella/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: European stocks slid at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 1.0% to 7,002.83 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX index falling 1.0% to 13,083.69 points. The Paris CAC 40 lost 0.8% to 6,195.04 points. The decline follows heavy losses in Asia due to rising fears of a global recession, with tech companies experiencing sharp declines. The US-EU trade talks are also in focus, adding to market volatility.

site_title: MPACT dragged by higher finance costs; Hong Kong’s Festival Walk weak even as VivoCity thrives
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) reported a 12.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0494 for the first half ended September, driven by contributions from VivoCity and Mapletree Business City (MBC). However, Festival Walk's performance weighed on the Reit's results, with shopper traffic and tenants' sales down 0.7% and 0.5% year-on-year, respectively. The Reit manager expects a miraculous recovery for Festival Walk to be unlikely until Chinese borders reopen. Rising interest rates and higher debt costs are also expected to impact MPACT's financial performance.

images.alt_text: RHB’s Vijay Natarajan says he will be looking at return-to-office trends and physical occupancy - such as at Manulife US Reit's Phipps Tower (pictured) - to assess potential leasing impact from the evolving hybrid working model.
Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.
VivoCity shopping mall

site_title: Japan’s 10-year bond yields fall to near 4-week lows
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yields fell to near 4-week lows, reaching 0.235% after the Bank of Japan kept its dovish stance unchanged. The central bank maintained ultra-low interest rates and yield curve control policy, cementing its status as an outlier among global central banks tightening monetary policy. Market participants await details of the BOJ's bond buying operations for next month.

site_title: Germany dodges recession but inflation climbs to 11.6%
summary: Germany dodged recession in the third quarter with a 0.3% growth in gross domestic product, beating analyst forecasts. However, inflation surged to 11.6% in October, the highest rate in over 25 years, driven by energy price spikes. Despite this, economists expect inflation to remain in double-digit territory for some time, pressuring the European Central Bank to continue raising interest rates. The economy is expected to contract in the fourth quarter, with some predicting a severe recession in the winter.

images.alt_text: The overture by the Chinese firm comes ahead of Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s visit to China next week as the first European Union leader to make the trip since November 2019.

site_title: 2022 Volkswagen Arteon review: Still an arty one
summary: The 2022 Volkswagen Arteon has undergone a mid-life refresh, introducing glitzier lamps, reshaped bumpers, and new cabin features. The car is described as an "avant-garde" grand tourer, offering a sleek and powerful driving experience with taut handling and comfort. Despite its practicality, the Arteon is designed to provide a unique driving experience, making it a great option for those who value the simple pleasure of driving. A facelifted version is now available, with a 190-horsepower engine and front-wheel drive, and a cosmetic package option that adds sporty flair and upgrades.

images.alt_text: Thanks to its station-wagon shape, the Octavia Combi RS is part family car, part pack mule.
The Volvo C40 Rechargeis based on the XC40, but has a slinkier silhouette, courtesy of a roof that swoops down fashionably towards a pert tail.

site_title: Consumer inflation in Japan’s capital hits 33-year high
summary: Japan's consumer inflation in the Tokyo area reached a 33-year high, exceeding the central bank's 2% target for the fifth consecutive month. Core consumer prices rose 3.4% from last year, the fastest annual pace since 1989. The Bank of Japan is expected to revise up its inflation forecasts but maintain ultra-loose monetary policy to support a fragile economic recovery. The latest data follows a 2.8% gain in September and a 3.1% forecast for October.

site_title: Why do Americans vote for extremists?
summary: The US Republican Party is poised to win the midterm elections, potentially gaining control of the House of Representatives and Senate, with a faction dominated by election deniers and conspiracy theorists. Despite this, swing voters prioritize economic issues over ideological concerns, citing concerns over inflation and recession. However, the actual economic record contradicts public perception, and the US economy is currently strong. The Republicans' economic track record under presidents like Trump and Reagan is also misinterpreted by voters, who mistakenly believe they have a better record than Democrats.

images.alt_text: The coming Republican Congress: Will Trumpists set the tone?
Prior research found that people are less likely to vote when polling places are further away, when polling stations’ opening hours are limited, and even when it rains.

US allies are keenly aware that the empowerment of Trump allies could have serious economic consequences, given that the former president imposed tariffs on the European Union and launched a trade war with China that had global ripple effects.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall nearly 1% as chipmakers slump
summary: South Korean shares fell nearly 1% on Friday due to chipmakers' slump, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix experiencing their largest daily losses since 2020. The benchmark KOSPI index still ended the week higher, up 2.50%, amid hopes for slower US monetary tightening. The Korean won weakened, and bond yields dropped, while Hyundai Motor and its affiliates rose on upbeat third-quarter results. Foreigners were net sellers of shares, but still bought a record amount last week.

images.alt_text: epa08305547 South Korean dealers react while they work at the Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 19 March 2020. The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) plummeted 133.56 points, or 8.39 percent, to close at 1,457.64 over coronavirus woes.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Miss Universe’s new owner eyes an empire of makeup to lingerie
summary: Miss Universe's new owner, Anne Jakkaphong Jakrajutatip, aims to build an empire of makeup to lingerie across Asia, seeking to tap into the region's pageant fandom despite declining interest in other parts of the world. The Thai company, JKN Global Group, plans to roll out new products, including vitamin water and potentially lingerie, cosmetics, and perfume, with a goal of generating $32 million in revenue by 2025. Jakapong, Thailand's first transgender CEO, plans to make the pageant more inclusive, including segments highlighting LGBTQ rights, and has already made progress by allowing mothers and married women to compete.

images.alt_text: The annual beauty contest run by the Miss Universe Organisation, which was co-owned by Donald Trump between 1996 and 2002, is broadcast in 165 countries and has been running for 71 years.

site_title: Will half a million free tickets save Hong Kong from tunnel vision?
summary: Hong Kong is distributing 500,000 free air tickets to encourage tourism, aiming to revive its economy. The city has implemented various measures to manage visitor numbers, including a zero-quarantine policy with three days of self-monitoring. However, this approach raises concerns about the strain on health workers and screeners. The distribution of free tickets may help kickstart the economy, but its impact remains uncertain, and the city's reliance on tourism growth rather than demand-driven models is a concern.

images.alt_text: Venice, a repository of centuries-old culture and bustling commerce
Shoppers in Janpath area in New Delhi, India, August 2022.
Retail sales value dropped 0.1 per cent in August from a year ago, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department said on Friday (Sep 30).

site_title: Who broke American democracy?
summary: The US political system has largely ignored the needs of Americans without college degrees, perpetuating policies that harm them in favor of corporate interests and better-educated Americans. This has led to deteriorating material, health, and social outcomes, including declining life expectancy, labor-force participation, and median wages. Many less-educated Americans feel disenfranchised, with a recent poll showing two-thirds believe government primarily benefits powerful elites. The erosion of trust in institutions, such as the healthcare system, has contributed to increased mortality rates, including deaths of despair from suicide, overdose, and liver disease. This has resulted in a frustrated democracy where citizens feel their voices are not being heard.

images.alt_text: The coming Republican Congress: Will Trumpists set the tone?

A pro-choice rally in Tucson, Arizona on Jul 4. Earlier expectations that the Republicans would emerge as clear winners in the United States' Nov 8 midterm elections are being eroded, partly due to the Supreme Court's decision to put abortion rights in the hands of US state legislators.

US allies are keenly aware that the empowerment of Trump allies could have serious economic consequences, given that the former president imposed tariffs on the European Union and launched a trade war with China that had global ripple effects.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q1 profit falls 14.6%
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a manufacturer of high-precision tools and parts for the semiconductor industry, reported a 14.6% decline in net profit to S$4.2 million for its first quarter ended Sep 30, compared to S$5 million the previous year. The decline was due to a slowdown in orders in the Chinese market and increased costs. Group revenue fell 1.3% to S$20.2 million, with double-digit growth in sales to customers in Singapore and the US offsetting the decline.

images.alt_text: Chris Borch, the chief executive of Micro-Mechanics, attributed the group's FY2022 performance to its operational resilience amid continued growth of the global semiconductor industry.
SEMICONDUCTOR play Micro-Mechanics (Holdings) posted a 5.8 per cent rise in net profit to S$4.4 million for its third quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, from S$4.2 million a year ago.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap 4 days of gains on China demand worries
summary: Australia's shares snapped a four-day winning streak on Friday, closing 0.9% lower on concerns about China's economy and demand for iron ore. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.6% for the week, its best since Oct 7. Mining giants Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue fell between 4.4% and 8.2% due to declining iron ore futures. Technology stocks also declined 2.2% ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike next week, while financials rose 0.4%.

images.alt_text:
A man stands next to Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) screens displaying falling stock prices in Sydney on February 6, 2018.
Australian stocks slumped 2.58 percent at the open on February 6 as they followed the lead of Wall Street which endured a brutal session with one of its steepest ever one-day point drops. / AFP PHOTO / SAEED KHAN

site_title: BT Market Focus: Macroeconomic data and rate hike expectations key drivers this week (Ep 18)
summary: Market Focus podcast by The Business Times analyzed the drivers of the market this week, finding that macroeconomic data and rate hike expectations were key drivers. SGX's wrap for the week highlighted market movements, while insights from BT's newsdesk provided analysis. Investors should consider the impact of inflation concerns and rate hike expectations on the market. The podcast also touched on company earnings reports and the overall market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Have rising interest rates fears dampened markets? Claressa Monteiro finds out.
Markets have had a bearish week and is there end in sight? Claressa Monteiro finds out.
How have market movements caused optimism to fizzle?

site_title: Elon Musk’s Twitter ownership begins with firings, uncertainty
summary: Elon Musk took control of Twitter, firing top executives and acquiring the social media platform for $44 billion. Musk aims to reduce spam bots, make algorithms publicly available, and prevent hate and division on the platform. He plans to cut jobs, but claims his goal is to "help humanity." Musk will assume the role of CEO, potentially ceding the role in the future, and has expressed plans to create a "super app" offering various services. Twitter shares rose 0.3% on the news, and the stock will be delisted from the NYSE on Friday.

images.alt_text: Twitter’s total purchase price is US$44 billion.
Elon Musk posted video of himself walking into the social network’s California headquarters carrying a sink on Wednesday.
Elon Musk will work with Philippine tycoon Henry Sy Jr to launch a satellite broadband service that will connect the Philippine archipelago to the rest of the world.
The deal’s completion would mark an end to a lawsuit by Twitter, which, along with investors, now expects the deal to be completed on its original terms of US$54.20 per share.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.88% or 240.04 points at 27,105.20, and the Topix index down 0.34% or 6.51 points at 1,899.05. The decline followed falls in US tech shares and was attributed to investor disappointment with losses in other Asian markets.

site_title: Singapore accountancy bodies launch initiatives to support small, medium audit firms
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) and the Singapore Accountancy Commission (SAC) have launched initiatives to support small and medium-sized audit firms. The initiatives include a newly launched SMP Centre of Excellence, which provides digitalisation, quality management, practice management, and talent management resources. The efforts aim to empower these firms to grow in a dynamic business environment, with a focus on upskilling professionals, strengthening digital capabilities, and enhancing competitiveness. The initiatives are supported by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) and backed by SGD 2 million from the Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG).

images.alt_text: As the focus of stakeholders shifts more towards climate-related issues, auditing practices have to change in order for financial statements to remain “useful and relevant”, said KPMG Singapore partner Reinhard Klemmer.

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.

site_title: The robber barons had nothing on Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk has acquired Twitter, raising concerns about his control over the "digital town square." As a tech genius and billionaire, Musk is exploiting opportunities in a deregulated state and has a history of breaking rules and exploiting employees. His ability to promote his businesses and ideas with a tweet makes him particularly powerful, and his opposition to censorship and regulation could lead to the spread of disinformation. Musk's influence is not just economic, but also political, as he has signaled his opposition to policing Twitter for political disinformation and misinformation, potentially allowing it to spread unchecked.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An image of Elon Musk is seen on smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Airbus raises cashflow target on strong dollar
summary: Airbus raised its 2022 free cashflow forecast by a billion euros to 4.5 billion euros, driven by a strong dollar. Quarterly revenues rose 27% to 13.31 billion euros, while adjusted operating earnings increased 26% to 836 million euros. The company also delayed the introduction of its A321XLR jet to the second quarter of 2024 due to certification issues. Airbus maintained its annual targets, including 700 jet deliveries, and reaffirmed its delivery and production targets.

site_title: VW misses expectations on cost pressures, Russia charges
summary: Volkswagen missed profit expectations in the third quarter due to cost pressures from supply-chain issues and one-off charges on its Russia and Porsche listings. Operating profit before special items rose to 4.3 billion euros, lower than forecast. The company cut its vehicle delivery forecast due to ongoing supply-chain problems, citing semiconductor shortages. VW also ceased its activities with US driverless vehicle company Argo AI, resulting in a 1.9 billion euros non-cash impairment charge. The company expects supply of semiconductors to improve in the fourth quarter.

site_title: UK lenders face the biggest mortgage test since financial crisis
summary: The UK's mortgage market is facing its largest test since the 2008 financial crisis, with nearly one in four mortgage holders struggling to afford repayments. Rising borrowing costs have tripled this year, prompting banks to prepare for a wave of repossessions. Measures to help customers include temporary payment breaks and extended loan durations, but experts warn that a downward spiral of underwater borrowers and reduced property prices could ensue. The Bank of England's affordability test will be put to the test as lenders assess borrowers' ability to pay higher mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: A Marsh & Parsons Ltd. estate agent "For Sale" sign displayed outside a residential property in London, UK, on Thursday, June 30, 2022. UK house prices slowed more than expected this month after a series of interest-rate increases raised the cost of mortgages. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets slip as rate hopes are offset by big tech sell-off
summary: Asia markets fell on Friday as disappointing tech earnings and a weakening economy offset expectations of a slowing interest rate hike campaign. The US Federal Reserve's next policy decision on Wednesday is expected to provide clues about its plans for December and 2023. Despite hopes for a softer outlook, the Nasdaq lost over 1% after forecast-missing earnings from tech giants like Apple and Amazon. The yen was slightly lower against the dollar, but has bounced since hitting a 32-year low last week.

images.alt_text: Tokyo and Singapore stock markets each rose more than 1 per cent while Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also up on Wednesday.

site_title: China expands list of sectors for foreign investment, focusing on manufacturing
summary: China has expanded its list of sectors for foreign investment, focusing on manufacturing, with 519 industries now eligible for foreign investment. This move aims to improve industrial and supply chains and further stabilize foreign investment. The decision was made after President Xi Jinping called for China to "win the battle" in core technologies during the recent Communist Party Congress. The expansion is seen as a key move to boost foreign investors' expectations and confidence, promoting a high-level opening up and accelerating the construction of a new development pattern.

images.alt_text: Fresh lockdowns come as infections start to rise again, with China reporting 1,321 new Covid cases for Thursday, the highest tally in two weeks.
China’s zero-tolerance approach to combating Covid infections has been a major drag on the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Thai finance ministry trims 2022 GDP growth outlook to 3.4%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has trimmed its 2022 economic growth outlook to 3.4% from 3.5%, citing a recovery in private consumption and the tourism sector. The country now expects 10.3 million foreign arrivals this year, up from 8 million, with a weak baht contributing to the tourism boost. Next year, the ministry forecasts 3.8% economic growth.

site_title: RBA to stick with modest rate hikes despite hot inflation: poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to maintain modest rate hikes despite high inflation, with 90% of economists predicting a 25 basis point (bp) increase at its November meeting. This puts the RBA out of step with global peers, which are raising rates in larger increments. Economists expect inflation to remain above target until early 2024, leading to further rate hikes, with some predicting a 50bp increase in December.

images.alt_text: Labourers work on a house under construction in western Sydney on August 2, 2022, as Australia's central bank raised interest rates taking the cash rate to 1.85 percent. (Photo by Saeed KHAN / AFP)

site_title: Porsche sees 40% rise in profits in first 9 months, confirms outlook
summary: Porsche reported a 40.6% rise in operating profit to €5.05 billion in its first results since listing on the stock exchange. The luxury carmaker's revenue increased 15.7% to deliver 221,500 vehicles, resulting in a 18.9% return on sales. Porsche stuck to its full-year outlook of a 17-18% return on sales, with mid-term and long-term targets of 17-19% and 20% respectively. The company attributed the increase to higher profitability per car, influenced by exchange rate effects.

site_title: China’s growth now seen below 5% through 2024 on Covid Zero risk
summary: China's economic growth is expected to be below 5% through 2024 due to its zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19, with frequent lockdowns and testing deterring consumer spending. The median forecast for this year was lowered to 3.3% from 3.4%, while next year's forecast was cut to 4.9% from 5.1%. Economists predict China will reopen its borders in the first half of next year, with most expecting a reopening only then. The country's housing market slump is also affecting sectors like construction and banking.

images.alt_text: While it’s impossible to mount a sustained defence against a stronger dollar that has steamrolled every other currency, the PBOC has rolled out a raft of measures, limiting its drop this year to 12 per cent.
In the first nine months, China shipped 2.26 million vehicles, up 51.6 per cent from a year earlier and surpassing the 2021 total, according to the General Admission of Customs.

People walking along a street in Shanghai. Slack consumption and a lack of effective demand will continue as long as the Zero-Covid policy remains in place - the ultimate hurdle in a meaningful and lasting recovery.

site_title: YouTube to certify healthcare providers’ accounts
summary: YouTube is introducing a certification program for healthcare providers to ensure high-quality health information on the platform. The certification will enable viewers to easily access trusted videos from verified healthcare professionals, aiming to reduce misinformation. The program will allow doctors, nurses, and other healthcare professionals to apply and receive certification, enhancing the credibility of health-related content on the platform.

images.alt_text: The streaming video platform said it will expand audio advertising globally to allow brands to market to people who use YouTube to listen to music or podcasts.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: YouTube logo at the YouTube Space LA in Playa Del Rey, Los Angeles, California, United States October 21, 2015. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: F1 drives Singapore hotels’ average room rate, revenues to new highs in September
summary: Singapore hotels saw a surge in room revenues and average room rates in September, driven by the F1 Singapore Grand Prix event, reaching a new high of S$390.8 million and S$284.37, respectively. This marks a 14.1% increase in ARR compared to August and a 24.6% increase in room revenues. Tourist arrivals also reached a record 778,141, with RevPAR surpassing the previous record in February 2014. The gains are attributed to the event's record turnout and pre-pandemic occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Visitor arrivals in September hit 752,305, from 728,744 in August, recording eight straight months of growth, according to data from the Singapore Tourism Board (STB).
Singapore has received some 3.7 million international visitor arrivals this year, with about 2.2 million arriving in Q3.

(From left) Janice Lee, event director for hospitality, food and beverage at Informa Markets, Singapore; Angeline Chan, director of food services at Enterprise Singapore; Ian Roberts, vice-president of Informa Markets, Asia; Alvin Tan, MOS for Ministry of Trade and Industry and Culture, Community and Youth; Yap Chin Siang, deputy chief executive of STB; Kwee Wei-Lin, president of SHA; and David Tan, president of Singapore Food Manufacturers' Association are at the opening ceremony of Food & Hotel Asia (FHA) - Hotel, Restaurant and Café 2022.

site_title: Pinocchio is the hero of our time
summary: The Disney remake of Pinocchio, starring Tom Hanks, explores the theme of lying and the blurring of lines between humans and artificial intelligence. The 1940 cartoon's central conceit of a talking, walking puppet has become more pressing in today's age of AI, raising questions about what makes a "real boy." The remake's darker and deeper version, directed by Guillermo del Toro, features a trans Pinocchio and a fascist boot-camp setting, highlighting the complexities of identity and morality. The story's themes of fame, autonomy, and submission are timeless and continue to resonate with audiences.

images.alt_text: Banks are now using AI to help them manage a broad spectrum of risks, streamlining everything from know-your-client (KYC) checks to identifying fraudulent behaviour among millions of transactions a day.
Has AI advanced beyond intelligence to becoming sentient? Perhaps the more important issue is how suggestible humans can be to AI already.

The GOP is now dominated by an extremist faction whose prominent members claim (or have claimed) not only that former President Donald Trump won the 2020 presidential election, but also that climate change is a hoax, Covid-19 is a conspiracy, and former President Barack Obama was not born in the US.

site_title: North Korea fires two ballistic missiles: South’s military
summary: North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles, according to South Korea's military, amid heightened tensions on the peninsula. The launch comes as the US and South Korea conclude joint military drills, which Pyongyang views as rehearsals for invasion. This latest incident follows North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's declaration of his country as an "irreversible" nuclear power, effectively ending negotiations over banned weapons programmes.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past a television report showing a news broadcast  of a North Korean missile test at a railway station in Seoul on Oct 6, 2022.

South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol mapped out details of the 639 trillion won proposal for next year to a half-empty National Assembly hall that was missing members of the Democratic Party, which holds a majority in the 300-strong Parliament.

site_title: Mussolini‘s ghost clings to Rome, 100 years after power grab
summary: Italy marks 100 years since Benito Mussolini's power grab in Rome, with many monuments and symbols still intact, including his photograph in the prime minister's residence. Unlike Germany, Italy has not rigorously removed fascist symbols, with some historians attributing this to a "forgiving city" attitude. The country's most right-wing administration in decades, led by Giorgia Meloni, has praised Mussolini in the past but has since distanced herself from his ideology. Historians estimate that up to 500,000 Italians died as a result of Mussolini's actions, and many consider the country's failure to confront its fascist legacy a missed opportunity for historical reckoning.

images.alt_text: The 45-year-old’s appointment is a historic event for the eurozone’s third-largest economy and for Brothers of Italy, which has never been in government.

site_title: Gold flat; set for weekly gain on hopes of less hawkish Fed stance
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,663.22 per ounce, but are expected to gain for the second week due to expectations of a less hawkish Federal Reserve stance. The US economy rebounded in the third quarter, but weak domestic demand and a shrinking trade deficit suggest the nation's economic health is overstated. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce another 75 basis-point rate increase next week, but may slow its aggressive pace in December, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold.

site_title: Singapore should exempt carbon credits from GST: KPMG
summary: Singapore should exempt carbon credits from Goods and Services Tax (GST) to foster the development of a carbon credit market, according to KPMG. Current exemptions are narrowly defined and exclude voluntary sales of carbon credits, which are subject to 7% GST. Charging GST on carbon credits can create cost barriers and a cascading effect, hindering market growth. KPMG recommends reviewing GST legislation to align with other jurisdictions that have exempted or zero-rated carbon credits, potentially making Singapore a carbon service and trading hub for the Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: The London Stock Exchange on Monday (Oct 10) published the final admission and disclosure standards for its voluntary carbon market designation.

Standard Chartered in September launched Trust Bank, a digital bank partnership with FairPrice Group aimed at supporting financial inclusion with cost-effective and innovative products and rewards through a strong ecosystem.
Singapore reduced its emissions to 52.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2020, equivalent to 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels, Wong said.

site_title: Australia producer prices rise at fastest annual pace on record in Q3
summary: Australia's producer prices rose 1.9% in the third quarter, the fastest annual pace on record, driven by labour shortages, rising material costs, and electricity charges. This lifted the annual growth rate to 6.4%, the highest since 1998. The largest contributors to the quarterly jump were building construction, civil engineering, and utilities. The upward pressure on consumer inflation remains a concern.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.30 points to 1454.39, a 0.02% gain. Volume was 34.97 million lots worth RM11.14 million, with 76 gainers and 72 losers.

site_title: Singapore employment rises 75,600 in Q3 but momentum may be easing
summary: Singapore's employment rose 75,600 in Q3, extending Q2's growth, but momentum may be easing. Total employment excluding migrant domestic workers reached pre-pandemic levels by 1.7%. Unemployment rates slightly increased, and retrenchments rose to 1,600. Despite a deteriorating global economic environment, employment growth may reach record levels, with sectors like hospitality and construction experiencing acute labor shortages.

images.alt_text: Pixgeneric/ generic pictures of office workers / PMET  in CBD along Cross Street . Photo taken on 4 March 2022.

Overall unemployment rate slid to 1.9 per cent in August; resident unemployment, to 2.7 per cent and citizen unemployment rate, to 2.8 per cent, according to the Ministry of Manpower's monthly unemployment situation report.

site_title: PBOC calls for more support for private builder bond sales
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has asked state-owned China Bond Insurance to step up support for private builder bond sales amid a deepening industry debt crisis. This comes as record defaults and a liquidity crisis have shut most private developers out of the market for bond financing. The PBOC deputy governor, Pan Gongsheng, praised the credit enhancement offered by China Bond Insurance, which has played a crucial role in stabilizing private builders' bond financing. However, the programme's effectiveness remains uncertain, and the PBOC is seeking more support to address the crisis.

images.alt_text: While it’s impossible to mount a sustained defence against a stronger dollar that has steamrolled every other currency, the PBOC has rolled out a raft of measures, limiting its drop this year to 12 per cent.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap winning streak as gold, miners tumble
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to weak prices of underlying assets, including iron ore and gold. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,811.70 points. Miners, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, tumbled 2.9-5.2% and gold stocks dropped 2%, while technology stocks fell nearly 2%. Financials advanced 0.6%, with Macquarie Group rising 2.6% after forecasting higher short-term income.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.5 per cent to 6,845.10 points at the close of trading.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 2.6% in Q3, rising at slower pace
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.6% in Q3 2022, the 10th consecutive quarter, but at a slower pace than Q2. Transaction volumes grew 10.7% to 7,546 cases, while year-on-year sales dropped 10.5%. Larger flats, such as executive and 5-room units, drove price growth. The Q3 data predated the recent cooling measures, which may moderate prices. Experts predict resale prices will rise by 9-10% this year, but some foresee a temporary moderation due to the market's resilience.

images.alt_text: According to data from Moody's, first-time private residential homebuyers required 19.4 per cent of their average monthly household income to meet the monthly mortgage repayments on new loans in August 2022.
Million-dollar transactions were recorded in areas such as Bishan, Kallang/Whampoa, Bukit Merah, Ang Mo Kio and Clementi.
New HDB flats more affordable than housing in comparable cities: Desmond Lee
HDB plans to launch up to 23,000 new flats in 2023.
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Sembmarine to ‘add’ on greater deal certainty
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded Sembmarine's stock to "add" with a higher price target of S$0.19, citing greater deal certainty for the merger with Keppel O&M and the enlarged entity's stronger order book of over S$18 billion. The analysts expect the deal to improve Sembmarine's pro-forma net tangible assets per share by about 5% and potentially lead to profitability by FY2024. The combined entity's order book and conservative net margin are expected to yield a profit ranging from S$160 million to S$280 million per annum.

images.alt_text: This revised deal is S$378 million lower than if the one-for-one share exchange option was pursued, as Keppel O&M was being valued at S$4.87 billion under the previous terms.
The projects involve the conversion of two Sevan cylindrical drilling vessels into floating liquified natural gas (FLNG) facilities.
Since becoming a direct shareholder of SembMarine, Temasek has made a significant investment of S$1.1 billion.
The company said a strong execution of multiple projects had contributed to continuing sequential improvement in its financial performance.

Both Sembmarine and KOM provide shipbuilding, conversion and ship repair services at their Singapore shipyards, with a specific focus on vessels and structures in the offshore, marine and energy industries.
Sembcorp has made steady and marked progress on its clean energy pivot since it bid Sembmarine farewell
Without the merger, Sembmarine said it will as a standalone entity have to navigate an “even more competitive landscape” .

site_title: iPhone is lone bright spot in gloomy quarter for smartphones
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments rose slightly in the third quarter, driven by its premium tier, as the global smartphone market declined by double digits. Samsung Electronics saw an 8% drop in sales, while Chinese vendors Oppo and Vivo each fell at least 20%. Xiaomi, with a wider international presence, fared better. Apple's strength in the premium segment helped it reach its best third-quarter share to date, closing the gap with Samsung. The company's focus on high-end offerings, including new foldable handsets, is seen as a key strategy for growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to falls in US tech shares, with investors awaiting a policy decision from the Bank of Japan. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.92%, or 250.72 points, to 27,094.52, while the Topix index dropped 0.54%, or 10.26 points, to 1,895.30.

site_title: Asia will be more severely hit by a world divided into trading blocs: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that Asia will be severely hit by a world divided into trading blocs, with the region's economies expected to decelerate to 4% in 2022 and 4.3% in 2023. Rising trade policy uncertainty and trade restrictions could derail global output, with Asia's significant role in global manufacturing and trade making it particularly vulnerable. The IMF also highlights the growing concern of financial fragmentation, with large cross-border holdings in the US and Europe adding to vulnerabilities.

images.alt_text:
MIAMI, FLORIDA - JUNE 09: A cargo ship sits at PortMiami on June 09, 2022 in Miami Beach, Florida. The US trade deficit shrunk in April, reflecting a drop in the value of imports amid COVID-19 lockdowns in China while exports climbed. The deficit dropped by 19.1%, to $87.1 billion.
