The Asian Development Bank cut China’s growth forecast for 2022 to 3.3 per cent from 5.0 per cent, as Beijing pursues a zero-Covid strategy that has devastated the world’s second-largest economy.
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan to keep ultra-low interest rates, defy global tightening trend
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to maintain ultra-low interest rates and keep its pledge to guide the 10-year bond yield around 0% at its quarterly meeting. Despite a slight revision up in its price forecasts, the BOJ still projects inflation to slide back below its 2% target next fiscal year. This decision will likely reinforce market expectations that the BOJ will stay the course in underpinning a fragile recovery with ultra-low interest rates, defying the global trend of central banks tightening monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Authorities’ so-called stealth intervention in rapid succession has underscored their resolve in fighting what they have characterised as “intolerable and speculative” yen-selling, although the impact has proved short-lived.
Investors have been testing the Bank of Japan’s resolve to pin down interest rates, sending yields on super-long ends to multi-year highs this week.

Analysts expect a portion of the package to be funded by additional debt issuance that would increase Japan’s already huge public debt which, at twice the size of its economy, is the biggest among major economies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the start of trade on October 28, 2022, as bargain-buying and hopes for slower rate hikes were offset by US tech firm sell-offs due to weak earnings reports. The Hang Seng Index decreased 3 points to 15,242.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.53% to 2,967.02.

site_title: Hit by game delays and cancellations, Ubisoft posts half-year net loss
summary: Ubisoft reported a half-year net loss of 190.2 million euros, citing accelerated research and development depreciation due to game delays and project cancellations. The company's shares have declined 38% this year. Ubisoft cited the cancellation of games like Splinter Cell VR and Ghost Recon Frontline as contributing factors. Despite this, the company confirmed its full-year guidance and projected third-quarter net bookings of around 830 million euros.

images.alt_text: Tencent also pledged not to increase its direct stake in Ubisoft beyond 9.99 per cent in capital for a period of 8 years.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust RevPAU up 88% in Q3 on higher occupancy, ADR
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust reported an 88% increase in RevPAU to S$132 in Q3, driven by higher occupancy and average daily rates. Gross profits rose 90% of pre-Covid levels, with stable income sources contributing 56% of Q3's gross profit. The company expects to benefit from improving travel outlook and robust leisure travel bookings, particularly in Japan. With majority debt refinanced and a gearing ratio of 35.8%, Clas will exercise financial discipline to adapt to macroeconomic headwinds.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.
Singapore Airlines (SIA) was one of the best performers in Q2, as it reversed out of the red and recorded the second highest quarterly operating profit in the group's history.

site_title: Interpol says metaverse opens up new world of cybercrime
summary: Interpol warns of new cybercrime risks in the metaverse, citing potential for phishing, scams, child safety issues, and facilitating physical world crimes. The virtual reality environment could enable terror groups to plan and simulate attacks, while extremist users may create virtual worlds with "extremist rules." Interpol's executive director notes that existing crimes may be enabled or taken to a new level in the metaverse, and that online immersive environments may create new kinds of cybercrime. This comes as the metaverse, once touted as a promising new stage in internet development, now faces skepticism from investors.

images.alt_text: Adobe’s “3D Capture” tool lets users take a series photos of a real-world object with nearly any camera and then melds the photos together into a three-dimensional digital object.
Technologies such as virtual reality headsets and blockchain are expected to push the boundaries of the metaverse beyond gaming.

site_title: Puerto Rico’s bad-governance limbo
summary: Puerto Rico, a US territory, faces governance and economic challenges. Despite being a US citizen, Puerto Ricans cannot vote in federal elections and lack representation in Congress. The island's economy has struggled, with a 12% decline in per capita income between 2004 and 2020, and a formal labor force participation rate of only 40%. The island's electricity system is also vulnerable to hurricanes, with frequent blackouts and generator failures. Puerto Rico's experience highlights the importance of building and maintaining institutions for economic policy decisions across layers of government.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden discusses American Rescue Plan investments in regional and community economic strategies at the White House in Washington on Sept 2, 2022.

site_title: Office rents in Singapore’s central region rise at a slower pace of 2.1% in Q3
summary: Singapore's central region office rents rose 2.1% in Q3 2022, a slower pace than the 2.4% increase in Q2. The total increase in the Urban Redevelopment Authority's rental index for office space in the central region reached 6.3% in the first three quarters of 2022. However, demand is expected to slow further in the fourth quarter due to macroeconomic uncertainties, with some property consultants predicting a slowdown in office rental growth in 2023. Despite this, the office rental growth was broad-based, with median monthly rent for Category 1 and 2 buildings increasing by 5.6% and 3% respectively.

images.alt_text: Knight Frank estimates that about 1.56 million square feet in office space is expected to be injected into the market in 2023, with a large chunk coming from IOI Central Boulevard Towers in the CBD.
Savills Research expects Grade A CBD office rent to grow at 3 per cent for the whole of 2022 and increase by 2 per cent year-on-year in 2023.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Sembmarine, Keppel, CDLHT, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, MPACT, Starhill Global Reit
summary: Keppel Corp posted a 24% year-on-year rise in revenue to S$6.8 billion for the first nine months of 2022. United Overseas Bank (UOB) saw its net profit rise 34% to S$1.4 billion in the third quarter. Sembcorp Marine announced a revised plan to merge with Keppel O&M, with Sembmarine acquiring Keppel O&M at an improved equity-value exchange ratio. CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 54.4% year-on-year increase in net property income to S$31.6 million in Q3 2022.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.2 per cent or 6.86 points to finish the day at 3,015.24.

site_title: Intel pledges more cost cuts as sales forecast misses estimates
summary: Intel announced plans to slash costs by $3 billion next year, with potential cuts of up to $10 billion by 2025, amid a slump in computer demand and revenue forecast misses. The chipmaker's third-quarter profit and revenue tumbled, with sales falling 20% to $15.3 billion. CEO Pat Gelsinger attributed the decline to a worsening macroeconomic environment, with no good economic news. Intel shares rose 5.4% in late trading following the announcement, which includes headcount reductions and slower spending on new plants. The company reduced its 2022 revenue forecast to $63 billion to $64 billion, a decline of up to 20% from 2021.

images.alt_text: Last week, Mobileye said it was targeting a valuation of nearly US$16 billion in its IPO, less than a third of what it had reportedly previously expected.
Intel is facing a steep decline in demand for PC processors, its main business, and has struggled to win back market share lost to rivals like AMD.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts’ net property income up 54.4% in Q3, bolstered by travel
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts posted a 54.4% increase in net property income in Q3 2022 to S$31.6 million, driven by the return of leisure activities and travel. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) for its Singapore hotels stood at S$199, more than double the S$76 in Q3 2021, thanks to a strong return in events. The trust's debt maturity is around 1.7 years, and refinancing efforts are underway to complete the refinancing of its remaining debt.

images.alt_text: W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.
Sabana Reit was among the S-Reits with the highest net institutional inflows in H1.
its lyf one-north, which obtained TOP in January 2022, also achieved strong occupancy of over 85 per cent in 1Q22.
W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.
CDLHT in £24.1m deal for 4-star hotel in Manchester, UK

site_title: Franck Muller: Theatre of dreams
summary: Franck Muller's women's watches are known for their show-stopping impact, blending technical sophistication and feminine elegance. The Vanguard Rose Skeleton Black Diamonds and Vanguard Skeleton Colour Dreams feature intricate designs, including rose motifs, diamonds, and skeletonized movements. The Cintree Curvex CX offers a curvaceous elegance with a redesigned tonneau-shaped case and automatic movement. Franck Muller's ladies' watches are highly regarded for their mechanical complexity, making them a standout in the world of haute horlogerie.

images.alt_text: Like the Royal Oak introduced in 1972, the Code 11.59 line provoked extreme reactions when it was unveiled.

site_title: Keppel Data Centres partners Shell to study feasibility of low-carbon energy hub
summary: Keppel Data Centres and Shell have signed a memorandum of understanding to study the feasibility of developing a low-carbon energy hub and microgrid system in Singapore. The hub will leverage sustainable energy sources, such as imported renewable power and hydrogen, to power both entities' assets. The project aims to explore commercial and technical practicalities of establishing a low-carbon energy hub, with a focus on energy-related infrastructure components and a self-contained power supply system.

images.alt_text: Keppel Data Centres in tie-up to explore Australia liquid hydrogen supply chain

A German offshore wind farm that Keppel has invested in. The floating hybrid renewable energy system in Singapore consists of integrating offshore floating solar panels with other renewable energy technologies.
Shell said the initiative could potentially form part of a carbon capture and storage (CCS) hub in South-east Asia.
Keppel data centre fund hits US$1.1b of commitments at final close

site_title: Singapore central region retail rents down 0.4% in Q3, recovery on the cards
summary: Singapore's central region retail rents declined 0.4% in Q3, marking the third consecutive quarter of falls. Despite this, analysts expect a recovery in the sector driven by tourist arrivals, resumption of MICE events, and business travel. Retail sales continued to grow, with a 14% year-on-year increase in August. Occupancy rates improved, with the islandwide vacancy rate decreasing to 7.8% by the end of September, the lowest level since the pandemic. Experts predict prime retail rents will recover, with growth ranging from 2% to 10% for 2022 and 3% to 9% for 2023.

images.alt_text: Retail prices in the central region also tumbled by 1.2 per cent in Q2 after it dipped by 1.4 per cent in Q1.

Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.
Islandwide occupancy rate ....

site_title: Biden touts high-tech manufacturing resurgence ahead of midterm elections
summary: US President Joe Biden touted investments in semiconductor manufacturing ahead of midterm elections, citing a rebound in GDP growth and a $100 billion Micron manufacturing plant. The investments aim to rebuild blue-collar communities and demonstrate the US's ability to produce high-tech products. Biden's efforts come as Democrats face a tough election, with some polls showing they may lose the House and Senate. Biden is leading a late push to attack Republicans on the economy, an area where Democrats have been on the defensive due to high inflation.

images.alt_text: Durable goods orders increased 0.4 per cent last month to US$274.7 billion, picking up less than expected but still reversing the weaker showings of previous months.

Gross domestic product (GDP) rose at a 2.6 per cent annualised rate in the July to September period after falling for the first two quarters, US Commerce Department’s preliminary estimate showed on Thursday (Oct 27).

site_title: The future looks bright
summary: The Swiss watch industry is on track for a record year, with exports reaching CHF2.2 billion in September, a 19.1% increase from the previous year. Demand in Singapore alone saw a 38.9% increase, making it the highest among the six main markets. This strong demand is expected to continue, putting the industry in a positive position for another record-breaking year.

images.alt_text: The LAB during the Watches and Wonders GENEVA, in Geneva, Switzerland, Thursday, March 31, 2022. The Master Event of the Watches and Wonders ecosystem brings together the leading names of the Watchmaking and luxury industry from March 30 to April 5, 2022 at Geneva Palexpo. site_title: Housing slump takes deepest cut from US GDP since end of 2007
summary: US housing slump takes deepest cut from GDP since 2007, with residential investment plummeting 26.4% annually in Q3. This marks the sixth consecutive quarterly decline, subtracting 1.37 percentage points from GDP, the largest since 2007. The decline is attributed to surging mortgage rates, which have topped 7% for the first time since 2002, and a 36.6% annualised drop in single-family home construction.

site_title: Taiwan’s economy faces mounting risks from demand slowdown
summary: Taiwan's economy is facing mounting risks due to a demand slowdown, high global inflation, and geopolitical tensions. The country's GDP is projected to grow 3.2% in the July-to-September period, a slight improvement from the prior quarter, but still lower than the 6% growth recorded last year. The decline in exports, driven by sluggish demand in China and the US, has weighed on manufacturing output and industrial production. Economists warn that the economy could enter recession if tech exports remain weak, affecting wages and employment.

images.alt_text: Export orders, a bellwether for global technology demand, shrank 3.1 per cent in September from a year earlier to US$60.93 billion, Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs said.

site_title: China faces tough choices in currency defence as yuan weakens
summary: China faces tough choices to defend its currency, the yuan, as it weakens near the lower end of its 2% daily trading band against the dollar. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has cycled through its policy tools, leaving it with options such as intervention, narrowing the trading band, or adjusting the currency's fixing. However, these measures come with significant downsides, including draining foreign reserves and raising fears of stronger capital controls. Analysts suggest these options are likely to be a last resort, with the PBOC instead focusing on deeper market-based foreign-exchange reforms.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities have struggled to make ends meet this year as massive tax rebates and the persistent housing market crisis have cut government income sharply.
The onshore yuan still remains on track for the worst annual loss since 1994.

site_title: UK’s Sunak and India’s Modi talk trade in first call: Downing Street
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak held his first call with Indian counterpart Narendra Modi, discussing a potential trade pact and strengthening ties between the two nations. Despite missing a Diwali deadline, Sunak expressed hope for a comprehensive free trade agreement, focusing on areas such as security, defence, and economic partnership. The two leaders agreed to work together to support developing economies worldwide and will meet in person at the G20 summit in Indonesia next month.

images.alt_text: About half of small and medium-sized businesses said the pricing and availability of loans was “poor” in the three months through September.

epa10266761 British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak departs 10 Downing Street ahead of his first prime minister's questions at parliament in London, Britain, 26 October 2022. New British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has held his first cabinet meeting.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
“No options are off the table given the economic circumstances,” Sunak’s spokesman, Max Blain, told reporters on Thursday
Britain says it will be fully represented by other senior ministers, as well as COP President Alok Sharma at the summit.

site_title: Amazon warns of meager holiday season sales growth
summary: Amazon predicted a slowdown in sales growth during the year-end holiday shopping season, with sales potentially growing as little as 2% in the final three months of the year. The strong US dollar makes products more expensive in other countries, contributing to the slowdown. Despite this, Amazon returned to profit in the third quarter with a net profit of $2.87 billion. The company's shares dropped 20% in after-market trades but regained some ground.

images.alt_text: The investment would include construction of data centres and purchase of goods and services from regional businesses.
Amazon has made millions of customers pay more by hiding better deals on platforms to boost its own products, Hausfeld, the law firm behind the case, alleges.
Windows licences form about 12 per cent to 13 per cent of Microsoft’s revenue and the PC market downturn is expected to dent its sales by 100 basis points.

site_title: US expects deal with allies on China chip curbs in near term
summary: US chip-equipment suppliers have stopped employees from working with China's top memory chipmaker and expect a deal with global allies to limit shipments of chip-production equipment to China in the near term. This move aims to keep cutting-edge semiconductor technology out of China and away from the country's military, expanding Washington's efforts to restrict China's access to advanced technology.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) rose at a 2.6 per cent annualised rate in the July to September period after falling for the first two quarters, US Commerce Department’s preliminary estimate showed on Thursday (Oct 27).
“In China, we will focus our R&D investments on local customers and the China market,” Stacey Keegan, vice-president of Corporate Marketing at Marvell said.

People walking along a street in Shanghai. Slack consumption and a lack of effective demand will continue as long as the Zero-Covid policy remains in place - the ultimate hurdle in a meaningful and lasting recovery.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday’s open, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% at the opening of Friday's trading, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,033.57. Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 49, with 108 million securities worth S$81.4 million changing hands. The rally comes after a mixed global market performance.

images.alt_text: A view shows the Singapore Exchange (SGX) offices in Singapore, in this January 28, 2015 file picture. Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) may have just begun its search for a new CEO but investors and brokers already know what change they want to see: the bourse stripped of its regulatory powers and a rebuilding of its stock market business.  REUTERS/Thomas White/File (SINGAPORE - Tags: BUSINESS)

site_title: Private home prices up 3.8% in Q3, but price growth seen easing amid headwinds, cooling measures
summary: Private home prices in Singapore rose 3.8% in Q3, driven by non-landed homes, with prices up 4.4% in Q3 after a 3.6% gain in Q2. However, growth is expected to slow in Q4 due to economic headwinds, cooling measures, and a seasonal lull. Analysts forecast 1-2% growth in Q4 and 9-10% full-year growth. Landed properties edged up 1.6% in Q3, while rental growth accelerated to 8.6% in Q3, the fastest pace since 2007. Supply remains low, with 15,777 unsold units as of Q3, and developers are cautious about acquiring sites amid high inflation and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Prices of retail space in the central region falls by 3.2 per cent in Q3 after it dipped 1.2 per cent in Q2.
Islandwide occupancy rate ....
A 7% jump in suburban condo prices leads a 3.4% qoq rise in Singapore’s Q3 private home prices: URA

site_title: Apple slips after iPhone and services revenue comes in light
summary: Apple's latest quarter saw weaker-than-expected iPhone sales, with $42.6 billion in revenue, missing analyst estimates. Services sales also fell short, with $19.2 billion, below the projected $20 billion. Despite overall revenue exceeding expectations, the results dashed hopes for a strong quarter and raised concerns about the tech industry's outlook, following gloomy earnings reports from other major companies.

images.alt_text: Apple takes a commission of as much as 30 per cent on in-app purchases, meaning a company like Meta would lose a portion of its ad revenue to the iPhone maker.
Apple had previously asked suppliers to commit to 100 per cent renewable energy for Apple’s production.

site_title: Pinterest surges on revenue beat as social peers struggle
summary: Pinterest reported third-quarter revenue that beat analysts' estimates, growing 8% to $684.55 million. This surpassed average analyst estimates and stood out in a challenging market for social media peers. Monthly active users also increased slightly to 445 million, ending three quarters of declines. The stock surged over 15% in post-market trading, reversing a 40% decline this year.

images.alt_text: Pinterest is a digital pin-board platform which serves its users ads linked to the searches they have done on the platform. Facebook and Snapchat, on the other hand, target ads to their users based on their activity on the sites, a model that has since become less effective.

site_title: UOB’s Q3 profit up 34% to S$1.4b on record net interest income
summary: UOB's quarterly net profit rose 34% to S$1.4 billion, driven by record net interest income. The bank's annualized earnings per share increased to S$3.30, surpassing consensus estimates. Net interest income grew 39% to S$2.2 billion, with margins expanding 40 basis points year-over-year. CEO Wee Ee Cheong expects ASEAN markets to slow down but avoid recession, benefiting from fund flows into the region. UOB shares surged 4.7% after the results announcement, with its acquisition of Citi's consumer business in Thailand and Malaysia set to complete on November 1.

images.alt_text: Many analysts have maintained their “buy” calls on the three Singapore banks, on higher absolute dividends for FY2022.

site_title: MAS’ Ravi Menon sees opportunities in digitalisation, sustainability amid ‘tough’ global outlook
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon warns of a tough global economic outlook in the first half of 2023, with high inflation and slowing growth posing a risk of stagflation. However, he sees opportunities in Singapore's fintech sector, particularly in digitalisation, sustainability, and human capital. Menon emphasizes the need for central banks to stay resolute in tackling inflation and for businesses to adapt to structural shifts by investing in these areas. He notes that countries and businesses that thrive in this environment will have more discipline in their strategies and prudent financial management.

images.alt_text: “We have entered the age of stakeholders, not just shareholders,” says Rebecca Martin, head of strategy at Elevandi, adding that companies with a focus on partnership would also perform better.

Maintaining price stability will “give confidence” and ensure necessary technological advancements and adjustments are not disrupted due to liquidity shocks, said Ravi Menon, managing director of MAS.
“(Consumers) seem to be irrationally oblivious about the risks of cryptocurrency trading,” Menon said at a seminar on the digital asset ecosystem in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recoup losses after ECB hikes rate as expected
summary: European stocks closed nearly flat on Thursday after the European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points as expected, signaling a slower pace of rate hikes. The ECB also cut subsidies to banks, which analysts saw as a positive move. Banking-heavy Italian and Spanish indexes outperformed, while technology stocks remained under pressure. Despite a boost from energy stocks, the Stoxx 600 index ended the day down 0.1%. The ECB's decision was seen as a dovish pivot, with analysts warning that external factors could act as a circuit-breaker to the hiking cycle.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,039.67 points.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets digest earnings
summary: US stocks were mixed on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index closing 1.6% lower to 10,792.68, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% to 32,033.28. The tech-rich Nasdaq slumped on weak results from Facebook parent Meta, while Alphabet and Microsoft also reported weak earnings. The S&P 500 Index lost 0.6% to 3,807.30. Despite this, hopes for a shift in the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy after the Bank of Canada's smaller-than-expected rate hike boosted market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 223.03 points, or 0.70 per cent, at the open to 32,062.14.

site_title: Lange watches stay the course
summary: A. Lange & Sohne will continue to produce most of its watches in precious metals, such as gold and platinum, with stainless steel reserved for special occasion timepieces like the Odysseus collection. CEO Wilhelm Schmid stated that the brand has seen no change in its policy and will not dilute the value of its existing collections by adding more steel watches. Despite market demand for steel watches being high, Schmid believes there is enough demand to keep Lange busy and has no plans to "opportunistically" start producing more steel timepieces.

images.alt_text: The 1815 Chronograph “Hampton Court Edition” will be put up for bidding by US-based auction house Phillips, in association with Bacs & Russo on Nov 6 in Geneva.
Sincere’s chief executive Ong Ban at the newly-opened SHH (Sincere Haute Horlogerie) boutique at Marina Bay Sands.
Perfectly timed comeback for Watches And Wonders Geneva
Can't find a Rolex or Patek Philippe? Blame the Reddit crowd

site_title: Tag Heuer: Blast from the past
summary: TAG Heuer releases a nostalgic collection of vintage watches, including the Heuer Carrera 1158, a 1969 Formula 1 racing-inspired watch gifted to legendary drivers. The Carrera 2447, launched in 1963, is another notable model, praised for its clean design and utilitarian dial layout. The Monaco 1131, famously worn by Steve McQueen in the 1971 movie Le Mans, is also highlighted as a radical sports watch with an angular square case and automatic Calibre 11 movement.

images.alt_text: Despite the Gucci 25H Skeleton Tourbillon's heavyweight complication, the slim case measures just 8 millimetres wide.

site_title: Enabling innovation with fewer risks through dialogue
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) chief fintech officer Sopnendu Mohanty emphasizes the need for dialogue between policymakers and investors to foster innovation in the financial sector. The two parties often appear at odds, with investors seeking growth and policymakers focusing on stability and risk protection. However, Mohanty believes that a collaborative approach can lead to a win-win situation, where investors can understand policymakers' concerns and policymakers gain insight into innovative products. MAS is exploring ways to facilitate this dialogue, including a regulatory sandbox to test products and services, to promote efficient capital allocation and innovation.

images.alt_text: Temasek's managing director of blockchain investments Pradyumna Agrawal said the company has a “dual approach” which allows it to build capabilities and ventures in promising areas.
The Singapore Fintech Festival returns as an in-person event for the first time since 2019 (pictured) as Covid-19 restrictions are eased.

site_title: Ant Group eyes opportunities in SME digital payments in South-east Asia
summary: Ant Group sees opportunities in digital payments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in South-east Asia, aiming to build an ecosystem of digitalisation services to meet their needs. The company's Alipay+ solution enables cross-border mobile payments and digital marketing services, allowing SMEs to tap into international markets and capture more revenue opportunities. Ant Group believes digital payments can drive the digitalisation of business activities and expand to the "awareness phase" of the purchase journey, connecting merchants and consumers. The company has launched an SME-focused digital bank, Anext, to serve regional micro, small-and-medium enterprises.

images.alt_text: Jia Hang, Ant’s regional manager for South-east Asia, said the region is the most important market for the group outside of China.
ANEXT is the latest digital bank to be unveiled in Singapore.

site_title: Macquarie profit beats estimates as market volatility spurs trading
summary: Macquarie's profit for the six months to September 30 beat estimates, rising to A$2.31 billion, driven by a 28% surge in its infrastructure investing arm and a 15% increase in its commodities trading arm's net profit contribution. Market volatility and energy price shocks contributed to the surge. Despite the increase, Macquarie's shares rose only 2% due to the company maintaining a cautious stance and analysts warning that the income surge won't be sustained. The bank's outlook remains unchanged, with CEO Shemara Wikramanayake stating the firm is well-positioned for superior performance in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Signage is displayed outside the Macquarie Group Ltd. headquarters in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Oct. 25, 2010. Three of Australia's four largest banks are set to post second-half profits that match or exceed earnings before the global financial crisis as bad debts ease in an economy benefiting from the biggest mining boom in a century. Photographer: Sergio Dionisio/Bloomberg

Macquarie analysts Ari Jahja and Akshay Sugandi set a 324 Indonesian rupee target price for GoTo, pointing out that growth execution, cost cuts and fundraising progress will be key to the stock’s re-rating.

site_title: Crypto.com doubles down on security to rebuild trust in sector
summary: Crypto.com, a Singapore-headquartered cryptocurrency exchange, has been investing heavily in security technologies following a $35 million hack earlier this year. The company has secured various certifications and licenses, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Major Payment Institution license, to rebuild trust in the sector. Crypto.com aims to demonstrate its commitment to security and has also launched initiatives to build Web3 talent in Singapore, including hackathons and internships. The company's Singapore general manager, Ang Chin Tah, emphasized the importance of security and compliance in the business of trust, highlighting potential applications of blockchain technology in areas such as health passporting and record-keeping.

images.alt_text: Crypto.com also got regulatory approval in the United Kingdom and Italy earlier this year.
Singapore-based Crypto.com CEO says regulators haven't reached out after hack

site_title: Chromatic allure of the Santos-Dumont
summary: Cartier has released three new lacquer-coloured Santos-Dumont watches, named after aviation pioneer Alberto Santos-Dumont. The models, available in burgundy, beige, and black, feature hollowed-out components and coloured lacquer finishes. The watches are crafted in platinum, rose gold, and steel, respectively, and come with manual-winding movements. Limited editions include a platinum model on burgundy leather with ruby cabochon, a rose gold piece on dark green alligator leather with blue sapphire cabochon, and a stainless steel model with blue synthetic spinel cabochon.

images.alt_text: Jake Gyllenhaal wears a previous generation of the Santos de Cartier.

site_title: Australia to spend A$500m to move or flood-proof homes in inundated areas
summary: Australia will spend A$800 million to repair, retrofit, and buy back homes in flood-prone areas. The program aims to help 2,000 homeowners in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, with those in the most at-risk areas eligible for a government buyback. Others will receive up to A$100,000 to raise or retrofit their homes. The package also includes A$100 million to buy land in flood-safe areas for development. The move comes as Australia recovers from its third bout of flooding this year and amid concerns about climate change.

images.alt_text: epa10266156 A flood affected property in Echuca, Victoria, Australia, 26 October 2022. Major flooding continues along the Murray River at Echuca, Moama, Torrumbarry and Barham while moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River.  EPA-EFE/JAMES ROSS  AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT

site_title: Tudor: Born to dive
summary: Tudor introduces the Pelagos 39, a smaller-sized dive watch that adds versatility to the collection. The watch is designed to appeal to a wider audience, including non-divers, with its unisex design and dress-inspired aesthetic. The brand collaborates with free-diving world champion Morgan Bourc'his and the French Navy on various models. Tudor's goal is to make its high-performance watches accessible to a broader audience, allowing them to experience the thrill of underwater adventures without needing to be expert divers.

images.alt_text: Wilhelm Schmid, CEO of A. Lange & Sohne

site_title: A rare destro and more Nautilus from Patek Philippe
summary: Patek Philippe has released three new Nautilus models, including the first left-handed split-seconds monopusher chronograph with perpetual calendar, the first stainless steel version of the Ref 5990 Travel Time Chronograph, and a rose gold Nautilus Ref 5712. The Ref 5373P-001 boasts a rare lefty design with a perpetual calendar complication, while the Ref 5990/1A-011 features a new sunburst blue dial and a self-winding calibre. The Ref 5712 now comes in rose gold with a matching bracelet, showcasing the brand's innovative approach to watchmaking.

images.alt_text: Patek Philippe's President Thierry Stern says the 5811 could be his new favourite Nautilus.
The Patek Philippe Nautilus 5811 comes in white gold and has a sunburst dial with a black gradient rim.
Thierry Stern's philosophy is to make beautiful watches first before worrying about the bottomline

site_title: Digital currency an integral part of the future, but adoption remains a challenge
summary: Digital currencies, including stablecoins, have seen significant growth, with over 200 projects worth $140 billion in total market capitalization. However, adoption rates remain slow due to regulatory challenges, a "chicken and egg problem" where clarity on regulations hinders widespread acceptance, and lack of clarity hinders widespread adoption. Jeremy Fox-Geen, CFO of Circle, believes regulation is key to helping stablecoins gain wider acceptance, making the next 10 years crucial for digital currencies.

images.alt_text: Mastercard Asia-Pacific president Ari Sarker believes that more can be done to address the relatively untapped B2B payments space.
USDC, which is principally issued by Circle, is the second largest stablecoin with over US$50 billion in circulation today.

As part of industry engagement, emphasis must be placed on DLT and tokenisation education, its distinction from cryptocurrencies and awareness to build trust in these technologies, gain stakeholder acceptance and drive adoption.
The proposals seek cross-border consistency to regulating crypto-assets, particularly as the European Union finalises groundbreaking rules to regulate the sector from 2024.

site_title: Omega: Over the moon
summary: Omega unveiled its new Speedmaster X-33 Marstimer, a cutting-edge tool watch that's the most advanced Speedmaster yet. This model features a 41mm case and a helium-escaping valve, paying homage to the iconic Speedmaster's space exploration heritage. The watch also includes a range of ladies-focused timepieces that showcase timeless elegance with broad-based appeal.

images.alt_text: The De Ville Trésor collection has been expanded too, with Omega adding a new line of 26-millimetre De Ville Mini Trésor timepieces.

site_title: Flying colours
summary: IWC's Top Gun line has unveiled several new models featuring coloured ceramics and the brand's proprietary Ceratanium composite. The Pilot's Watch Chronograph 41 Top Gun Ceratanium boasts a sleek, understated design, while the Big Pilot's Watch 43 Top Gun features a minimalist classic with a black ceramic case. Two new additions, "Woodland" green and "Lake Tahoe" white, offer high-contrast alternatives to the traditional Top Gun aesthetic. The limited-edition timepieces will have annual production of 1,000 pieces each.

images.alt_text: Mark Ong, aka Mr Sabotage, is the first Singaporean to design a watch strap for IWC.
Cortina Holdings has been granted an option to purchase the fourth level of 15 Scotts Road (pictured) for S$49 million.
Sincere’s chief executive Ong Ban at the newly-opened SHH (Sincere Haute Horlogerie) boutique at Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Investing into private markets would improve portfolio quality and returns
summary: High net worth individuals (HNWIs) should consider investing in private markets to improve portfolio quality and returns, especially in a volatile public market environment. Marco Bizzozero, head of international at iCapital, believes that private equity and other alternative investments can offer attractive opportunities to diversify away from public markets and improve risk-adjusted returns. HNWIs currently allocate less than 5% of their portfolios to private markets, while institutional investors allocate between 15-30%. iCapital's technology solutions aim to connect wealth managers and HNWI clients with asset managers, making it easier to access private markets.

images.alt_text: Marco Bizzozero, head of International of fintech company iCapital
“We have entered the age of stakeholders, not just shareholders,” says Rebecca Martin, head of strategy at Elevandi, adding that companies with a focus on partnership would also perform better.

site_title: Tissot’s latest PRX is a 70s inspired beauty
summary: Tissot's latest PRX Automatic Chronograph features a 70s-inspired design with a sporty 42mm case and Valjoux A05.H31 Calibre, offering a 60-hour extended power reserve. The watch boasts high-quality finishing, intricate detailing, and a well-built metal bracelet, making it a well-rounded timepiece. The PRX collection also comes in various dial and case colors, offering a range of options for those looking for a stylish and functional watch.

images.alt_text: The Tissot Seastar was born in the mountains but is destined for the sea.

site_title: Girard-Perregaux: A true child of the 1970s
summary: Girard-Perregaux's Laureato watch, launched in 1975, is a child of the 1970s and a response to the quartz watch revolution. Its iconic design features a steel integrated bracelet, octagonal bezel, and angular tonneau-shaped case. Originally a quartz watch, the Laureato was later adapted to mechanical movements. The brand has continued to evolve the design, with recent additions including the Laureato Chronograph and Laureato 42mm Green and Pink Gold & Onyx models. Despite changes, the essence of the original Laureato remains recognizable.

images.alt_text: Patrick Pruniaux, Chairman & CEO of Sowind

site_title: Twitter shares to be suspended on NYSE as Musk nears takeover
summary: Twitter shares will be suspended from trading on the NYSE on October 28, as billionaire Elon Musk faces a court-ordered deadline to close his $44 billion deal to buy the social media company. The deal's completion would mark an end to a lawsuit by Twitter, which now expects the deal to be completed on its original terms of $54.20 per share. Musk's lawyers have submitted the required financing paperwork to equity investors, and Twitter's shares have surged nearly 65% from a four-month low hit in July.

site_title: Assertive elegance
summary: Longines has released 190th Anniversary commemorative editions featuring elegant feminine iterations of their Master collection. The 34mm watches boast quiet power despite their diminutive dimensions, driven by the Calibre L888 movement offering up to 72 hours of power reserve. The timepieces feature mechanical movements, diamonds hour markers, and a range of dial colors, paired with leather straps in various colors. These watches embody the Master collection's reputation for technical excellence and poise, making them a masterful expression of style and strength.

images.alt_text: To mark its 190th anniversary, Longines has elected the Master collection to headline its commemorative offerings, by way of three exclusive and distinguished creations.

site_title: Zenith goes pink for a good cause
summary: Zenith has released a special edition Chronomaster Original Pink watch to support Breast Cancer Awareness Month. The 38mm watch features a pink dial and a sporty-chic design with the brand's iconic 70s tonneau-shaped case and ladder-style bracelet. Twenty percent of the watch's proceeds will go to Susan G Komen, the world's leading non-profit breast cancer organization. The watch will be available for purchase in October and is a limited-edition release, making it a highly exclusive collector's item.

images.alt_text: Caption to come from dylan

site_title: Gucci celebrates 50 years of watchmaking with high complication novelties
summary: Gucci celebrates 50 years of watchmaking with its 2022 haute horlogerie collection, featuring high complication novelties with unparalleled Swiss technical know-how and Italian design. The collection includes three advanced technology watches: the Gucci 25H Skeleton Tourbillon, G-Timeless Planetarium, and G-Timeless Moonlight. The watches showcase intricate designs, gemstones, and innovative mechanisms, including a flying tourbillon and a movement that dictates its own time based on the lunar month. The collection also includes the G-Timeless Dancing Bees Tourbillon and Grip Sapphire, featuring unique designs and materials.

images.alt_text: The Chronomaster Original Pink is a special edition of one of Zenith’s most recognisable icons.

site_title: Local streetwear designer makes history with IWC
summary: Local streetwear designer Mark Ong, aka Mr Sabotage, has made history by becoming the first Singaporean to design a watch strap for IWC Schaffhausen. Ong, the founder of SBTG, has collaborated with IWC since last year and this marks his first creative project with the luxury brand. The limited edition watch strap reflects IWC's interest in streetwear vibes, with Ong expressing his surprise and honor at being approached by the local IWC team in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Pilot’s Watch Chronograph 41 Top Gun Ceratanium
New innovative material takes centre stage

site_title: All about performance in Tissot’s latest collection
summary: Tissot's latest Seastar collection and Telemeter 1938 models showcase the company's dedication to sports and timekeeping. The 42mm Telemeter 1938 features a mechanical chronograph with a 68-hour power reserve, while the 46mm Seastar 2000 Professional Powermatic 80 is an ISO 6425-certified diver's watch with a marine-inspired dial. The 36mm Seastar 1000 Quartz is designed for everyday wear, available in various colors and strap options. Both collections prioritize high performance and wearability, making them suitable for various sports enthusiasts and individuals.

site_title: Ulysse Nardin: Still innovative and disruptive
summary: Ulysse Nardin, a pioneering watchmaker, has regained its independence after a management buyout deal in June. The brand has unveiled six new timepieces, including the Blast Tourbillon Rose Gold and Blast Moonstruck, which feature innovative designs and cutting-edge technology. The Blast collection boasts a triple-toothed bezel, a self-deploying buckle, and a tourbillon movement powered by a platinum micro rotor. Other new models, such as the Blast Moonstruck and Freak X Carbonium, incorporate silicon escapement components and environmentally friendly materials. These watches showcase Ulysse Nardin's commitment to innovation and disruption.

images.alt_text: Patrick Pruniaux, Chairman & CEO of Sowind

site_title: A CEO to watch
summary: Patrick Pruniaux, former CEO of Sowind, has successfully led a management buyout of Swiss watch brands Girard-Perregaux and Ulysse Nardin from Kering. The deal allows Pruniaux and senior managers to have total control over the brands' long-term strategy and operations. Analysts view the sale as a positive move, citing a recovering watch market and the brands' historic names with rich heritage. Pruniaux aims to protect the brands' legacies, engage with stakeholders, and focus on customer storytelling, transparency, and innovation. The new owners are poised to outperform the market, with Girard-Perregaux and Ulysse Nardin already showing positive results.

images.alt_text: Laureato 42mm Pink Gold & Onyx

site_title: Old is gold for this young vintage expert
summary: Tag Heuer's heritage director, Nicholas Biebuyck, shares insights on vintage watch collecting and the brand's legacy. Biebuyck, 36, has vast experience in the vintage watch trade and an encyclopedic knowledge of horology. He oversees Tag Heuer's archives dating back to 1860 and perpetuates the brand's legacy through various initiatives. Biebuyck emphasizes the importance of condition and rarity in determining a watch's value, advising buyers to focus on what they like and to research thoroughly. He highlights the Heuer Carrera and Monaco as iconic watches that showcase the brand's innovative spirit.

images.alt_text: An archival photo of Jack Heuer (left) with F1 drivers Nicky Lauda (right) and Clay Reggazoni (middle) from the 1970s.

site_title: Hublot’s colourful world of watches
summary: Hublot has released the Big Bang Integrated Ceramic, a sporty watch featuring a mono bloc architecture with an integrated bracelet, crafted from ceramic with the exception of composite lugs and pushers. The collection comes in four limited-edition colourways inspired by cities and natural environments, showcasing the brand's pursuit of innovation in materials and movement. The watches feature the UNICO V2 movement with 72 hours of power reserve and are paired with rubber or diamond-studded straps. The Big Bang collection has been a platform for Hublot's expertise in fusing unlikely materials, and this release solidifies the brand's position in haute horlogerie.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Thierry Stern's philosophy is to make beautiful watches first before worrying about the bottomline

site_title: The Cartier Santos Skeleton reveals its colourful side
summary: Cartier has released new Santos Skeleton timepieces featuring colourful designs, including green, grey, and blue models. The watches showcase creative uses of colour to highlight key features, create optical illusions, and add an element of playfulness. The models feature Roman numerals painted with lacquer, PVD coatings, and interchangeable straps made from various materials, including leather and rubber. This new collection is part of Cartier's trend of incorporating bold colours into luxury watches.

site_title: There’s never been – or ever will be – an 1815 Chronograph like the ‘Hampton Court Edition’
summary: A unique, one-of-a-kind A Lange & Sohne 1815 Chronograph "Hampton Court Edition" watch will be auctioned off on November 6 in Geneva by US-based auction house Phillips, in association with Bacs & Russo. The charity watch, created for the Concours of Elegance, will benefit The Prince's Trust, a youth charity founded by Prince Charles. The watch features a white-gold case, black dial, and intricate hand-wound movement, launched in 2010. Proceeds will support the charity's work, with Lange's CEO expressing pride in supporting the organization's important cause.

images.alt_text: Sincere’s chief executive Ong Ban at the newly-opened SHH (Sincere Haute Horlogerie) boutique at Marina Bay Sands.
Can't find a Rolex or Patek Philippe? Blame the Reddit crowd
Perfectly timed comeback for Watches And Wonders Geneva

site_title: Code 11.59 by Audemars Piguet is here to stay
summary: Audemars Piguet's Code 11.59 collection continues to expand and gain popularity, with three new models unveiled in September. The collection, which debuted in 2019, features a round bezel and case-back with an octagonal middle case, and is known for its unique aesthetic. The new models include a hand-wound tourbillon openworked in electric blue ceramic and white gold, an automatic flying tourbillon with a black onyx dial, and an automatic flying tourbillon paired with a chronograph. The collection's success is attributed to its constant evolution and expansion, with new dial designs, material combinations, and complications being added regularly.

images.alt_text: The new BR-X5 combines the aviation-inspired origins of the BR-01 and the urbane elegance of the BR-05; and elevates both with modern, industrial-inspired design and technical dynamism.

site_title: Aircraft, autos boost US manufactured goods orders in September
summary: US durable goods orders increased 0.4% in September to $274.7 billion, driven by a double-digit jump in non-defence aircraft segment and autos. However, excluding transportation, orders fell 0.5% due to weakening demand for manufactured goods. Analysts predict weaker growth in the fourth quarter and a recession in the first half of 2023, citing inflation, interest rates, and softening earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product (GDP) rose at a 2.6 per cent annualised rate in the July to September period after falling for the first two quarters, US Commerce Department’s preliminary estimate showed on Thursday (Oct 27).

site_title: Shell and Total, oil giants, report huge profits on high energy prices
summary: Europe's energy giants, Shell and Total, reported huge profits in the third quarter, with Shell earning $9.45 billion and Total earning $9.9 billion. The profits are partly due to high oil and natural gas prices fueled by the war in Ukraine and Russia's squeeze on gas flows to Europe. Shell plans to increase its dividend by 15% and buy back $4 billion worth of shares, while Total will reward employees with a bonus equivalent to one month's salary.

site_title: Bitcoin miner Core Scientific says it may seek bankruptcy
summary: Core Scientific, a leading Bitcoin miner, warns it may seek bankruptcy protection by the end of the year due to cash shortages and increased competition. The company's shares plummeted 77% after a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing revealed operating performance and liquidity were severely impacted by the prolonged drop in Bitcoin price. If Core Scientific files for bankruptcy, it would be the first large publicly traded Bitcoin miner to do so, weighing on the entire crypto mining sector.

site_title: Google Play in EU antitrust sights as Android fine appeal pending
summary: EU antitrust regulators are investigating Google Play Store for allegedly forcing app developers to use its billing system, potentially leading to another billion-euro fine. This follows Google's 4.1 billion euros EU antitrust fine, which was reduced to 4.125 billion euros by the Luxembourg-based General Court. Google plans to appeal the decision, citing matters of law. The European Union is also introducing new landmark tech rules to curb online gatekeepers and companies controlling access to platforms and data.

site_title: Sunak pulls out of attending COP27 summit to focus on domestic issues
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has pulled out of attending the COP27 climate summit in Egypt due to domestic issues, including a cost-of-living crisis and an autumn fiscal statement. He will be represented by senior ministers, including COP President Alok Sharma. This decision comes as Sunak seeks to tackle his short tenure's credibility damage and address pressing domestic commitments.

site_title: Sunak keeps option of UK windfall tax on banks, energy open
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is considering a windfall tax on banks and energy firms to address a £35 billion budget shortfall. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt has delayed the Autumn Statement, and Sunak's spokesman, Max Blain, said "no options are off the table" given the economic circumstances. This move aims to balance the books while avoiding deterring investment needed to stimulate growth. The decision is sensitive due to the UK's high tax burden and the legacy of former Prime Minister Liz Truss's low-tax policies.

images.alt_text: About half of small and medium-sized businesses said the pricing and availability of loans was “poor” in the three months through September.

site_title: Omega expands women’s collections
summary: Omega has expanded its women's collections, introducing new timepieces to its De Ville Prestige and De Ville Trésor lines. The De Ville Prestige features slimmed-down cases with prominent curves, available in 34mm, 30mm, and 27.5mm sizes, while the De Ville Trésor collection has been expanded with a new 26mm line featuring Moonshine Gold cases and Toile de Jouy straps. These additions offer a wider range of options for female watch enthusiasts, with various case materials, dial, and strap options available.

site_title: Rolex is flying high with novelties
summary: Rolex unveiled six new watch models in a post-Covid rebound, sending a sense of optimism and innovation to the watchmaking world. The new collection includes the Oyster Perpetual Air-King, paying tribute to pilots of the 1930s golden age of flying. The release marked a significant moment for the luxury watch brand, following a period of anticipation and excitement. The new models showcase Rolex's commitment to innovation and style, marking a promising start to the brand's continued growth and success.

images.alt_text:
Oyster Perpetual 
Air-King

site_title: Tech rout widens as Meta sinks after results
summary: Meta's shares plummet 20% after the company reports costly metaverse bets and soaring inflation's impact on ad spending, potentially losing US$78 billion in market value. The company's shares hit their lowest since 2016, with analysts warning of a decline in the ad market and Meta's capital-intensive metaverse projects. Despite this, data center-focused companies like Broadcom and Nvidia may benefit from Meta's plans.

images.alt_text: Meta is gradually losing favour with brokerages with at least two investment banks – Morgan Stanley and KeyBanc Capital Markets – cutting their rating on the stock, citing the rising costs.

site_title: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s H1 DPU rises by 12.5%
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) posted a 12.5% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half of its fiscal year, reaching 4.94 Singapore cents. The increase was driven by contributions from properties under Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust and core assets, including VivoCity and Mapletree Business City. Net property income rose 44.9% to S$275.2 million, while gross revenue grew 44.9% to S$353.2 million. The trust's total assets grew to S$17.2 billion and its net asset value per unit rose 4.0% to S$1.81.

images.alt_text: Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.

RHB’s Vijay Natarajan says he will be looking at return-to-office trends and physical occupancy - such as at Manulife US Reit's Phipps Tower (pictured) - to assess potential leasing impact from the evolving hybrid working model.

site_title: Mega merger of Sembmarine, Keppel O&M simplified to ensure deal certainty, quicker completion
summary: Singapore's Sembcorp Marine and Keppel O&M are merging in a revised deal that simplifies the process and reduces costs. The revised terms lower the purchase consideration by S$378 million, making it more attractive for Sembmarine shareholders. Under the deal, Sembmarine will acquire Keppel O&M, retain its listing status, and issue new shares. The combined entity will be controlled by Sembmarine shareholders, with Keppel owning 54% of the enlarged entity. The merger is expected to be completed within two months and may take place by year's end, despite uncertain macroeconomic conditions.

images.alt_text: Since becoming a direct shareholder of SembMarine, Temasek has made a significant investment of S$1.1 billion.
SCM is showing promising signs of recovery, but is still in the red

Both Sembmarine and KOM provide shipbuilding, conversion and ship repair services at their Singapore shipyards, with a specific focus on vessels and structures in the offshore, marine and energy industries.
Sembcorp has made steady and marked progress on its clean energy pivot since it bid Sembmarine farewell
Without the merger, Sembmarine said it will as a standalone entity have to navigate an “even more competitive landscape” .

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as GDP data keeps recession worries at bay
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, October 27, as GDP data showed the US economy rebounded in the third quarter, easing recession worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 223.03 points, or 0.70%, to 32,062.14, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The strong economic data kept investors optimistic about the market, despite ongoing concerns about aggressive monetary policy tightening and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Dreamhers comes to Singapore
summary: The Zenith Dreamhers Project, a campaign celebrating visionary and trailblazing women, has arrived in Singapore. The project, launched in 2020, aims to build a platform where independent and inspirational women can share their achievements, hopes, and dreams. The campaign features a series of interviews with women from around the world, including local personalities such as Lola Rodriguez, Sheila Sim, and Melody Hsu. The initiative aligns with Zenith's commitment to women's empowerment through its Zenith Horiz-On initiative.

images.alt_text: The Chronomaster Original Pink is a special edition of one of Zenith’s most recognisable icons.

site_title: Patek Philippe is not that expensive: Thierry Stern
summary: Thierry Stern, president of Patek Philippe, emphasizes the importance of creativity and innovation over increasing profit margins. He prioritizes making beautiful watches, personally overseeing the production of every minute repeater. Stern's hands-on approach allows him to focus on the company's product line rather than its financial side. His dedication to craftsmanship and design is reflected in Patek Philippe's globally loved watches, showcasing the brand's commitment to excellence in watchmaking.

images.alt_text: The Ref. 5373P-001 is the first Patek Philippe destro chronograph in 95 years and its first ever lefty that also boasts a perpetual calendar complication.
Patek Philippe's President Thierry Stern says the 5811 could be his new favourite Nautilus.
The Patek Philippe Nautilus 5811 comes in white gold and has a sunburst dial with a black gradient rim.

site_title: Ultra-rich UK PM to move into small Downing Street flat
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his family will live in the flat above Number 10 Downing Street, despite owning luxury properties in California, London, and Yorkshire. Sunak's portfolio includes a penthouse and a mansion, but the prime minister's secretary confirmed he will move into the smaller No 10 flat, which has been the London home of British leaders in the past.

images.alt_text: “My record is, when times are difficult in this country, I will always protect the most vulnerable,” Sunak said to vociferous support from the Conservative benches in the House of Commons.

site_title: US economy rebounds as consumers, businesses show resilience
summary: The US economy rebounded in the July to September period with a 2.6% annualized GDP growth rate, ending two quarters of contraction. Consumer spending and business investment drove the growth, despite inflation and higher interest rates posing challenges. The housing sector was a significant drag on growth, while the volatile net exports category contributed to the increase. However, economists expect the economy to slow in the coming months due to the Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation, which may push the economy into recession in the coming year.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit net property income rises 8.4% in Q1
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 8.4% increase in net property income to S$37.2 million in its Q1, driven by the removal of rental rebates and lower rental assistance. Gross revenue rose 6.2% to S$47.6 million, with occupancy standing at 96.9% and weighted average lease expiry at 7 years. The Reit attributed the growth to a gradual recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with shopper traffic improving at Wisma Atria. However, geopolitical tensions and rising interest rates continue to temper the economic recovery, and the Reit has an outstanding debt of S$1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings says Reits with exposure to prime retail malls, such as Starhill Global Reit, will take longer to reach pre-pandemic earnings than its suburban peers.
Starhill Global REIT has said that lower rental contributions from Wisma partially offset net property income for FY2021/22
In Singapore, Wisma Atria saw NPI for the 3 months rise 3.2 per cent, while that of Ngee Ann City remained unchanged.
There are fewer people as usual outside Ngee Ann City and along Orchard road on 7 Apr 2020, as Singapore enter Day 1 of 'Circuit breaker' mode to deal with the current coronavirus situation.

site_title: Mastercard’s profit rises in Q3 on buoyant spending
summary: Mastercard reported a Q3 profit of US$2.5 billion, or US$2.58 per share, exceeding analysts' expectations of US$2.56 per share. Revenue jumped 15% to US$5.8 billion, driven by resilient consumer spending despite rising economic concerns. The company's earnings were not significantly impacted by inflation and interest rate hikes, which typically reduce spending. Mastercard's strong performance is attributed to the reopening of borders and a stronger dollar encouraging travel overseas.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard dominate cross-border card payments, and Brussels hopes that IP, combined with reforms such as “open banking”, or fintechs using a customer’s bank data to offer a range of services, will boost competition.

site_title: Bell & Ross: The X-factor
summary: Bell & Ross has released the BR-X5, a watch that combines the brand's aviation-inspired heritage with modern, industrial-inspired design and technical dynamism. The BR-X5 features a new COSC-certified automatic movement, the Calibre BR-CAL.323, and a semi-hollowed-out case that amplifies the watch's contemporary spirit while ensuring lightness and water resistance. The watch's design and construction reflect the collaboration between Bell & Ross and Kenissi, a joint-venture between Tudor, Chanel, and Breitling. The BR-X5 is available in two dial colors and comes with a five-year warranty, exceeding the standard two-year warranty for other collections.

site_title: Toyota lowers 2022 output target to 9.5 million units, it tells suppliers: sources
summary: Toyota has lowered its 2022 global production target to 9.5 million units, exceeding the previous year's output by 10%. The new target is lower than the previous year's record 9.7 million units, which was unlikely to be met due to a chip shortage. The company told suppliers of the revised target, which could be further lowered depending on the supply of electromagnetic steel sheets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Toyota's logo is seen at a Toyota Society Motors showroom in Karachi, Pakistan, July 27, 2022. REUTERS/Akhtar Soomro/File Photo

site_title: France pledges billion euros to help small firms with energy bills
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire announced a pledge of billions of euros to help small and medium-sized firms struggling with soaring energy bills. The support will come in the form of an electricity guarantee based on a price corridor, with a floor price of 325 euros per megawatt. The move aims to substantially reduce energy bills and provide visibility to these firms.

site_title: Beyond resilience – building smarter business together
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital adoption in finance, enabling businesses to continue operating despite lockdowns and closed borders. Financial institutions, including HSBC, have transformed to co-create innovative products and services with customers. Digitalisation has improved customer experiences, streamlined processes, and enhanced working capital management. HSBC has worked with clients to automate payment processes, shorten account-opening times, and provide fast access to trade working capital. Digitalisation has also enabled companies to capture cross-border opportunities and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: Encouraged by easier access to investment platforms and by the previous years’ bull run, many people have started investing. Despite markets being down in the short term, there’s strong reason to believe that investors are here to stay – and that their numbers will even grow. Including here, in SEA.

site_title: Activist glues his head to 'Girl with a Pearl Earring' painting in The Hague
summary: A climate activist glued his head to the glass covering Johannes Vermeer's "Girl with a Pearl Earring" painting at the Mauritshuis museum in The Hague, while two others glued their hand to the wall and threw an unidentified liquid. The protest, which came less than two weeks after similar actions at the National Gallery in London, was meant to highlight the destruction of priceless art compared to the planet's destruction. Fortunately, the painting was not damaged, and three people were arrested by Dutch police.

images.alt_text: "Sleeping Venus" by Chinese artist Ai Wei Wei on display at the German gallery Neugerriemschneider booth during the Paris+ par Art Basel art fair in Paris on Oct 22, 2022.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic growth is expected to slow to below trend in 2023 due to weaker external demand, particularly in key sectors such as manufacturing and financial services. Core inflation is also expected to slow but remain high, driven by domestic factors. Meanwhile, Singapore banks are expected to deliver solid Q3 earnings as interest rate hikes take hold. Two-thirds of local firms are financially resilient but lack productivity and innovation.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure to develop floating renewable energy system with NUS, NTU
summary: Keppel Infrastructure, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, is collaborating with the National University of Singapore (NUS) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) to develop a floating hybrid renewable energy system in Singapore. The system integrates offshore floating solar panels with ocean wave energy conversion systems, tidal energy turbines, and wind turbines. The study aims to design and deploy a 100-megawatt pilot system, which can be scaled up to provide continuous power output, higher capacity factor, and lower energy costs. The project's success will enable the deployment of the floating hybrid renewable energy system in other Asian regions and beyond.

images.alt_text: Keppel has also signed revised agreements in connection with the proposed O&M transactions.

site_title: Germany reviewing possible Chinese takeover of chip factory
summary: Germany is reviewing a possible sale of its chip factory, Elmos, to a Chinese-owned firm, Silex, a unit of Sai MicroElectronics. The deal comes ahead of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's visit to China and amid concerns about critical infrastructure and intellectual property falling into foreign hands. The government is assessing the potential impact of the takeover, with some officials expressing concerns about the risks of Chinese control. The Office for the Protection of the Constitution has warned against the sale, citing the potential for Beijing to apply pressure on Germany.

site_title: US dollar rebounds after recent sell-off as traders await ECB
summary: The US dollar rebounded 0.54% to 110.14 against a basket of currencies after falling to a one-month low of 109.53 ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) decision on interest rates. The ECB is expected to raise its deposit rate by 75 basis points to 1.5%, a 13-year high, and reel in a key subsidy to commercial banks. The euro peaked at a one-month high of $1.0094 before falling, while the eurozone's single currency was down 0.47% to $1.0032.

site_title: Sheng Siong net profit dips 4.6% in Q3 on easing of Covid-19 curbs
summary: Sheng Siong's net profit declined 4.6% to S$32.8 million in Q3, down from S$34.4 million a year ago, due to normalizing revenue levels after Covid-19 restrictions were lifted. Revenue fell 4.2% to S$333.5 million, but the company expects to capture consumers' shift into savings mode due to its value offerings. The company also faces challenges from high inflation, supply-chain disruptions, and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Goods importers like Sheng Siong could benefit from the stronger Singapore dollar, given that its import costs would now be lower.

Sheng Siong's other income tumbled 27.3 per cent to S$5.5 million in H1 due to the reduction of Covid-19-related grants from the government. This category comprised 26 per cent of total contributions, down 48.4 per cent during the same period last year.

RHB analyst Jarick Seet said investors can best take advantage of the food inflation theme by seeking out companies that have demonstrated the ability to pass on costs to consumers without affecting demand., and Sheng Siong is one such stock.

site_title: Robust regulation key to limiting fallout from repeat of crypto winter
summary: A functioning digital asset ecosystem cannot develop overnight due to the need for robust regulation, technical services, and a stable legal framework. The "crypto winter" of 2022, triggered by a major stablecoin's failure, highlighted the risks of hubris, excessive leverage, and systemic risk. Despite valuations still being down, innovation and development continue, and regulators are working to develop a regulatory architecture that balances financial stability, investor protection, and the benefits of digital assets. Well-crafted regulation will mitigate the damage of future "crypto winters."

site_title: ECB raises interest rates again, trims bank subsidies
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points to 1.5% to combat historic inflation, marking the fastest pace on record. The move is expected to lead to further hikes and may start shrinking the ECB's balance sheet. The bank also cut a key subsidy to banks, indexing interest rates on Targeted Longer-Term Refinancing Operations. ECB President Christine Lagarde stressed the need to fight inflation, despite concerns about recession risks, and urged governments to carefully target support for citizens to prevent inflation worseness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: New Bali visa won’t attract wealthy investors in droves: analysts
summary: Indonesia has introduced a "second home" visa for Bali, offering 5-year and 10-year residency for those with at least $180,711 in their bank accounts. Analysts predict the policy will have a positive impact but won't attract wealthy investors in massive numbers. The visa is aimed at professionals and highly skilled workers, and its details remain unclear, with potential limitations on travel and business activities. The scheme is competitive with other countries offering similar arrangements, and its effectiveness will depend on future amendments and changes.

images.alt_text: Indonesia adds to a list of countries from Costa Rica to Mexico offering long-term stays to lure professionals, retirees and other affluent people.

site_title: UK healthcare workers and teachers to vote on strikes
summary: UK healthcare workers and teachers will vote on strike action over pay, with over 350,000 workers set to be balloted by union Unison. The move comes amid rising inflation and stagnant wage increases, with the government offering a £1,400 pay rise to NHS workers. The strike vote is the latest challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak as he grapples with an economic crisis, with workers from various sectors already walking out in protest.

images.alt_text: About half of small and medium-sized businesses said the pricing and availability of loans was “poor” in the three months through September.
The cost of key UK mortgages remains close to a peak last seen in the 2008 financial crisis, which is reducing the number of people who can afford to buy property.

site_title: China’s auto exports jump 51% in first three quarters
summary: China's auto exports surged 51.6% in the first nine months of the year, reaching 2.26 million vehicles, surpassing the 2021 total. Exports of new-energy vehicles grew 93% to 656,000 units. The top five exporters were SAIC Motor, Chery Automobile, Chang’an Automobile, Dongfeng Motor, and Tesla. The growth is attributed to demand from the European market, partly due to inadequate supplies in the overseas market affected by a semiconductor shortage, energy crisis, and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Keppel posts 24% rise in revenue to S$6.8 billion
summary: Keppel Corporation posted a 24% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$6.8 billion for the first nine months of 2022, driven by stronger performance from its energy and environment, asset management segments. The company also announced revised agreements for proposed O&M transactions and signed a share buyback program. Net profit rose year-on-year, but net gearing increased to 0.79 times due to dividend payments and share repurchases.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure looking to import renewable energy from Laos and Cambodia to Singapore
Keppel DC Reit's aggregate leverage rose to 37.5%, mainly due to the financing of the acquisition of Guangdong Data Centre 2 and the premises of Guangdong Data Centre 3.
吉宝湾大厦（Keppel Bay Tower）外观。

site_title: STI continues upward trend as investors keep eye on corporate earnings
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,015.24, driven by investors capitalizing on market opportunities amid Q3 corporate earnings announcements. Despite inflation and interest rate concerns, investors remain optimistic. Expectations are growing that the Fed may slow down its rate hike process after the November meeting, potentially supporting the market upward trend.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index added 0.72 per cent, or 110.27 points, to 15,427.94.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,039.67 points.

site_title: McDonald’s beats sales estimates on boost from pricier menu
summary: McDonald's reported beating quarterly comparable sales estimates, driven by higher menu prices and increased restaurant traffic from inflation-weary customers. The company's global same-store sales rose 9.5% in the third quarter, surpassing estimates of a 5.8% rise. Comparable sales in the US increased 6.1%, while total revenue fell 5% to $5.87 billion due to a stronger US dollar. McDonald's shares rose 2.2% to $262.30 following the news.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The McDonald's company logo is seen on the front of a restaurant in London, Britain, December 10, 2021. Picture taken December 10, 2021. REUTERS/May James/File Photo

site_title: Tesla’s Model Y tops new car registrations in Europe in September: report
summary: Tesla's Model Y led new car registrations in Europe in September with 29,367 units registered, a 227% increase from last year. This marks the first time the mid-sized SUV has topped the rankings. The surge in sales underscores Tesla's effort to ramp up production at its Berlin plant, which now produces 2,000 cars per week. The Model Y's success also contrasts with Tesla's earlier warning of logistical challenges that may impact vehicle deliveries in the near term.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to legalise retail crypto trading to become hub
summary: Hong Kong is planning to legalize retail cryptocurrency trading, with a mandatory licensing program set to be enforced in March 2023. The program will allow listings of bigger tokens, but regulators will not endorse specific coins like Bitcoin or Ether. A public consultation is required before the details and timetable are finalized. This move is a significant shift in Hong Kong's regulatory stance, contrasting with its recent skepticism and mainland China's ban on cryptocurrency trading.

images.alt_text: A functioning digital asset ecosystem cannot develop overnight.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished with a 0.72% gain on Thursday, adding 110.27 points to 15,427.94, following bargain-buying after a hefty drop at the start of the week. This is in line with gains across most of Asia.

site_title: Meta’s US$677b rout boots it out of world’s top 20 stocks
summary: Meta's stock has plummeted 25% due to ballooning costs for its virtual reality efforts and declining revenue, resulting in a US$677 billion loss of market value, dropping it from the world's top 20 stocks. At the start of the year, Meta was the sixth largest US company by market capitalization, but now its market value is smaller than companies like Chevron and Eli Lilly & Co.

images.alt_text: Instagram, acquired in 2012, built an advertising business that is a major revenue driver for Meta.

site_title: Elon Musk taps tycoon Sy for Philippine satellite Internet
summary: Elon Musk has partnered with Philippine tycoon Henry Sy Jr to launch a satellite broadband service, connecting the Philippine archipelago to the rest of the world. Data Lake, a company owned by Sy, has signed an agreement with SpaceX, making it the first Starlink integrator in the country and South-east Asia.
