The 29-day tournament will be the first major global sporting event with fans since the Covid pandemic.

site_title: Europe’s power generators return to burning gas as prices drop
summary: Europe's power generators are shifting back to burning gas due to low prices, which have dropped by nearly half this month. Warm weather and full storage tanks have reduced demand for gas, making it more cost-effective to use. This shift comes after months of coal being the cheaper fuel, with Germany and the UK extending the life of gas-fired plants to secure winter energy supply. Gas prices are expected to normalize again when colder weather increases demand.

images.alt_text: Lignite-powered power plant (brown coal) in Western Germany. Coal price has skyrocketed this year, raising the urgency of the need to invest in clean energy.

site_title: Chipmaker UMC cuts capex in readiness for prolonged downturn
summary: Taiwanese chipmaker UMC has cut its capital expenditure by almost a fifth, citing a prolonged downturn in smartphone and personal computer demand, and weak consumer spending due to inflation and interest rate hikes. The company expects demand weakness to continue into the first half of next year with no signs of recovery. UMC has revised its 2022 capital expenditure to $3 billion, down from a previous plan of $3.6 billion, and will continue to monitor developments and take risk-management measures.

site_title: US: Nasdaq tumbles as downbeat tech earnings fuel growth fears
summary: The US stock market experienced a decline on October 26, 2022, with the Nasdaq index falling 2% due to disappointing tech earnings from Microsoft and Alphabet, sparking concerns of slowing economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also fell, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 2.05%. These losses raised fears about the overall health of the US economy and the tech sector.

site_title: Saudi Aramco launches US$1.5b fund, says energy transition plan flawed
summary: Saudi Aramco launched a $1.5 billion sustainability fund to support a global energy transition, with a focus on carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and synthetic fuels. However, Saudi officials, including CEO Amin Nasser, warned that the transition plan is flawed and will take decades, necessitating continued investment in conventional resources. They cited underinvestment in fossil fuels and thin spare production capacity as concerns, contradicting predictions that the transition will take 30 years.

images.alt_text: The full supply allocation comes despite a decision by the Opec+ to lower their output target by 2 million barrels per day.

site_title: US slaps sanctions on Iranian officials over protest crackdown
summary: The US imposed new sanctions on Iran, targeting Iranian officials and entities for internet censorship and a crackdown on protesters following the death of Mahsa Amini. The sanctions include freezing assets and banning Americans from dealing with those named, including officials from the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps and Iranian prison officials. The US action comes as demonstrations sparked by Amini's death pose a challenge to Iran's clerical leadership. The sanctions aim to disrupt digital freedom in Iran and pressure the government to stop its crackdown on protesters.

site_title: All systems go: How a local space tech firm and F&B startup are scaling new heights
summary: A local space technology company, Aliena, is set to partner with the European Space Agency (ESA) in 2023, marking the first time a Singaporean space propulsion company will collaborate with the ESA. Aliena designs thrusters for satellites, and its latest innovation uses water as a fuel source, making it more sustainable. The company's success is attributed to co-innovation networks, such as the Global Innovation Alliance, which facilitate expertise sharing and expansion overseas. This collaboration highlights Singapore's growing space technology sector.

site_title: iFast Q3 2022 net profit plunges 72.6% on higher expenses, tough market conditions
summary: iFast Corporation, a fintech platform, reported a 72.6% decline in net profit to S$2.1 million in Q3 2022, due to higher expenses and tough market conditions. Gross revenue fell 3.9% to S$53.5 million, and net revenue declined 1.3% to S$30.1 million. The company attributed the decline to the impairment charge from its India business and higher operating expenses. Despite this, net inflows of client assets remained healthy, and recurring net revenue increased 5.9% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: iFast is also in talks with potential buyers for “parts” of its India associate’s business, and hopes to “recoup something back” from the exit although the loss will still be significant, Lim said.
Lim Chung Chun, chief executive officer of iFast Corporation

site_title: Boeing takes US$2.8b hit in defence business, keeps cash flow goal
summary: Boeing reported a $2.8 billion charge in its defence business due to cost overruns, despite generating $2.9 billion in free cash flow in the third quarter. The company attributed the losses to fixed-price contracts, and appointed a senior troubleshooter to address the issue. Boeing maintained its cash flow goal for the year, despite struggling with labour and supply shortages affecting commercial jet production. The company's shares fell 4% following the results.

site_title: World Bank projects energy prices to decline 11% in 2023 after 60% jump in 2022
summary: The World Bank projects energy prices to decline 11% in 2023, after a 60% surge in 2022, with a Brent crude average price of $92 a barrel in 2023 and $80 in 2024. Slower global growth and continued Covid restrictions in China pose key downside risks. Russia's oil exports could drop by 2 million barrels per day due to EU sanctions. A proposed Group of Seven oil price cap may be effective if large emerging markets participate.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 3.2% decline in DPU for Q2 2022
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 3.2% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.36 Singapore cents in Q2 2022, primarily due to higher property operating expenses and borrowing costs. Despite this, net property income rose 8.3% to S$130.3 million, and gross revenue grew 12.8% to S$175.5 million. The manager attributed the decline to headwinds from rising energy prices and interest rates, and plans to adopt cost-mitigating measures while focusing on tenant retention.

images.alt_text: Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.
Fitch Ratings says Reits with exposure to prime retail malls, such as Starhill Global Reit, will take longer to reach pre-pandemic earnings than its suburban peers.

site_title: US alleges Seagate broke export rules to sell Huawei hard drives: source
summary: The US alleges Seagate Technology Holdings violated export control laws by selling hard drives to Huawei, a Chinese company on the US Commerce Department's entity list. Seagate received a "proposed charging letter" from the Commerce Department in August 2022, stating it may have broken rules by providing hard disk drives to Huawei between 2020 and 2021. Seagate claims the drives were not subject to US export regulations and denies engaging in prohibited conduct. The company is cooperating with the Commerce Department and faces potential civil penalties of up to $300,000 per violation.

site_title: US dollar slides on expectations of less hawkish Fed, euro at 1-month high
summary: The US dollar fell against major currencies, including the euro and Japanese yen, as markets anticipate a potential slowdown in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The euro rose to a 1-month high above parity against the US dollar, while sterling and the Canadian dollar also strengthened. Traders expect another 75 basis point interest rate hike next week, but some predict a possible slowdown to 50 basis points by December. This follows poor US economic data and Fed officials' hints at slowing rate increases.

site_title: Hilton raises annual forecast as profit jumps on strong travel demand
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings raised its annual profit forecast, citing strong travel demand despite recession worries. The company expects net income between $1.22 billion and $1.24 billion for 2022, a 6% increase from its previous forecast. Hilton reported a 44% rise in third-quarter profit, driven by pent-up demand for cross-border travel, which boosted its pricing power. The hotel industry benefits from consumers eager to travel, offsetting concerns about the economic recession.

site_title: Chinese automaker Geely’s new energy brand Farizon raises over US$300m
summary: Geely's new energy brand Farizon has raised over $300 million in funding from investors including Transfar, CITIC Securities, and GLP's Hidden Hill Capital. The capital will be used for research and development, ecosystem development, and promoting the rental and sales of urban logistics vehicles and refrigerated cars. This funding comes as Geely steps up its new energy vehicle development, aiming to increase electric vehicle sales to 50% in 2023. Farizon will further consolidate its market-leading position in new energy commercial vehicles with the new investment.

site_title: Sunak cheers his gloomy lawmakers with Parliament debut
summary: Britain's new Prime Minister Rishi Sunak made his parliamentary debut, earning cheers from his lawmakers and plaudits from commentators. Sunak struck a confident tone, defending his record on protecting the vulnerable and refuting Labour's claims of sharp public spending cuts. He also fended off criticism over his decision to reappoint a right-wing figure as interior minister. The mood in the Conservative benches was transformed, with Sunak's lawmakers frequently demanding "More!" in approval, marking a turnaround in the party's fortunes.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles III greets newly appointed Conservative Party leader and incoming prime minister Rishi Sunak during an audience at Buckingham Palace in London on Oct 25, 2022.

site_title: Bill Gates’ climate fund joins Temasek and venture builder to launch agritech startup
summary: Bill Gates' climate fund, Breakthrough Energy Ventures, is partnering with Temasek, Wavemaker Impact, and GenZero to launch an agritech startup focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions in rice cultivation, the second-largest source of emissions in agrifood. The startup aims to identify strategies to reduce emissions through economic incentives for sustainable cultivation techniques, targeting 400 million smallholder farmers in Asia. The partnership seeks to create innovative, scalable solutions with a sustainable model of incentives to drive adoption of green solutions.

images.alt_text: The Climate Action Data Trust will be an independent entity domiciled in Singapore.

site_title: Expired doses make up 10% of Covid-19 vaccine stock in Singapore: MOH
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) reports that about 10% of the country's Covid-19 vaccine stock has expired. To minimize wastage, MOH has swapped vaccine stocks with other countries and worked with manufacturers to extend shelf life. As newer, more effective vaccines are rolled out, older stocks will not be fully utilized. The ministry secures early access to vaccines, including bivalent vaccines, and has contractual obligations limiting further information disclosure.

site_title: Xi’s vow of world dominance by 2049 sends chill through markets
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has solidified his power, setting a goal to make China a modern socialist power by 2035 and a global leader by 2049, raising investor anxiety. A shift in priorities from economic development to security has heightened concerns about an unrestrained Xi, who may risk a catastrophic war over Taiwan. The country's actions, including boosting per capita income and modernizing the armed forces, are seen as contradictory to economic development and market confidence. Investors remain skeptical about Xi's ability to achieve his vision, with markets experiencing a sell-off following the party congress.

images.alt_text: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indexes in Shanghai. Cihnese markets could remain volatile in the coming weeks as investors continue to parse what the new leadership has in mind for the economy.

site_title: Keppel divests whole stake in Shanghai unit that developed luxury housing
summary: Keppel Land, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, is divesting its entire stake in Shanghai Jinju Real Estate Development for 967 million yuan (S$190 million). The deal involves selling shares to Shanghai Maowei and repaying loans extended to Shanghai Jinju. The divestment is part of Keppel's 2030 vision to monetize assets and unlock capital for new growth opportunities, expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: MOU signing ceremony between Keppel Infrastructure and Greenko. Standing: Keppel's chief executive officer Loh China Hua (first from left), Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (second from right), High Commissioner of India to Singapore, Periasamy Kumaran, (third from left), Greenko's joint managing director and founder Mahesh Kolli (fourth from left). Seated: Keppel Infrastructure's CEO Cindy Lim (left) and Greenko's chief executive and founder Anil Kumar Chalamalasetty (right).
Keppel Infrastructure looking to import renewable energy from Laos and Cambodia to Singapore

site_title: 'Seismic shift' in bank payments will help business and consumers, says EU
summary: The European Union plans to mandate instant payments in euros, forcing banks across the 27-country union to offer and receive "instant payment" (IP) services for a fee comparable to traditional credit transfers. The move aims to boost competition and efficiency in the economy, with EU officials citing the potential to increase competition in payment services and provide consumers and merchants with a lower-cost choice. The proposal, which needs approval from EU states and the European Parliament, would require euro area banks to receive euro IPs within six months and send them within a year.

images.alt_text: The EU wants to modernise payments so that money can be transferred from one account to another in seconds, at any time of the day or night.

site_title: Adjusting to a new world of persistent inflation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) recently re-centered the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band upwards, indicating a shift in the economy's outlook due to rapidly changing growth and inflation projections. This move suggests the end of the era of low interest rates and may require consumers and businesses to adjust their expectations of acceptable inflation levels. Economists expect headline inflation to moderate to 3.8% in 2024, but caution against the risk of stagflation, where growth stagnates while prices rise.

images.alt_text: Singapore core inflation climbs to 5.3% in September; headline inflation steady at 7.5%
The Monetary Authority of Singapore tipped core inflation to "remain high" in the first half of the year, before "slowing more discernibly in the second half as cost pressures gradually ease".

site_title: Barclays to create 1,000 jobs as bank helps customers in inflation crisis
summary: Barclays plans to hire over 1,000 staff to help customers manage their finances amid the looming inflation crisis and recession. The bank aims to improve its capacity to discuss finances with UK customers, who are making overpayments on mortgages to reduce debt. This move follows similar initiatives by HSBC and Virgin Money UK, as consumers struggle with high mortgage costs, energy bills, and falling consumer confidence. Barclays already has 8,000 staff available to discuss finances with customers.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to quit Russian market, sell shares to local investor
summary: Mercedes-Benz will exit the Russian market by selling shares in its local subsidiaries to car dealer chain Avtodom, following Nissan and Renault's similar moves. The company will retain its 15% stake in Russian truckmaker Kamaz and suspend manufacturing operations in Russia, which saw a 72.8% decline in Mercedes vehicle sales from January to September. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Mercedes' profitability and financial position.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit’s Q3 DPU up 5% to S$0.02585
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02585 for Q3, driven by contributions from new acquisitions and asset enhancement initiatives. Distributable income rose 9% to S$46.9 million, while gross revenue and net property income grew 1.4% and 0.5%, respectively. Aggregate leverage increased to 37.5% due to financing of new acquisitions, with 74% of loans hedged to fixed interest rates.

site_title: Pound slump hands UK shareholders a £5.7b  dividend boost
summary: The British pound's slump against the dollar has boosted UK shareholders, adding £5.7 billion to dividends this year. According to a report from Link Group, sterling's decline against the greenback has increased an estimate of 2022 payouts by 11% to £97.4 billion. The report highlights the international makeup of the UK stock market, with three-quarters of FTSE 100 members' revenue generated abroad.

site_title: Digital Core Reit misses forecasts for distributable income for first 9 months of 2022
summary: Digital Core Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported distributable income of US$34.4 million for the first nine months of 2022, 3.4% lower than forecast. Net property income rose 5.7% to US$53 million, while revenue increased 1.6% to US$80.7 million. The Reit's occupancy rate remains 100% and its weighted average lease expiry is 5 years. Despite one tenant filing for bankruptcy, the Reit's distribution per unit is expected to remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: The manager of Digital Core Reit has proposed to acquire the data centre property located at 1215 Integrity Drive in Richardson, Texas.
T

site_title: Brokers’ Take: Analysts lower target prices on CICT, but remain positive on prospects
summary: Analysts from DBS, OCBC, and UOBKH lowered their target prices on CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) due to rising interest costs and increased leverage, but remain positive on the counter's prospects. Despite these adjustments, the analysts maintained their "buy" ratings and projected higher distribution yields, citing benefits from post-pandemic reopening and rental reversion. CICT's shares closed 4.4% higher on the day.

images.alt_text: The publicly accessible Sky Garden on Level 51 of the Capita Spring integrated development offers a 360-degree view of the surroundings, and is also home to Singapore’s tallest urban farm.
Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.

site_title: Wealthy foreigners can own land in Thailand
summary: Thailand has approved a plan allowing wealthy foreigners to own land for housing in Bangkok and Pattaya. The program targets top professionals, high-net-worth individuals, and retirees, who must invest at least 40 million baht (S$1.49 million) for three years. This move aims to boost the economy by attracting international investors, following a new visa program that allows qualified foreigners to stay for up to 10 years with various benefits. The proposal will be further assessed before final approval.

images.alt_text: Tourists at Maya Bay early this year, after Thailand reopened its world-famous beach after a three-year-long closure wrought by the pandemic. Thai finance minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith says the nation appeals to travellers looking for bargains, and that the baht’s prolonged weakness will  help bring more foreigners back,

site_title: Builder Skanska says rising rates, costs dim outlook in Europe
summary: Swedish builder Skanska reported a third-quarter profit and lowered its market outlook for construction in Eastern Europe and residential developments due to cost inflation and higher interest rates. Order bookings rose 50% from a year earlier to 43.8 billion Swedish crowns (S$5.7 billion) adjusted for currency effects. Skanska's operating profit slipped to 1.52 billion crowns, topping expectations. The company expects its markets to remain negatively affected for some time, citing reduced consumer confidence and slower sales.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore electronics sector saw a 7% year-on-year contraction in the latest data, with factory output growth in Singapore rising to 0.9% in September. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released a consultation paper on crypto consumer protection, while a taskforce pushed for unemployment benefits for white-collar workers. Singapore Airlines may resume dividend payments this fiscal year, and a global carbon credit registry data platform will be domiciled in Singapore. Local shares ended higher, driven by market hopes that the Federal Reserve may adopt a less aggressive monetary stance.

site_title: Global energy transition might take 30 years, Saudi finance minister says
summary: Saudi Arabia's Finance Minister Mohammed al-Jadaan says the global energy transition away from fossil fuels may take 30 years, necessitating continued investment in conventional resources. This assessment is made despite the global economy facing a difficult six months. Al-Jadaan emphasized the need for continued investment in energy security while addressing climate change. Saudi Arabia aims to reach net-zero emissions by 2060, and the country is investing in both conventional energy and climate change initiatives.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher as Fed rate hike fears recede; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 0.8% to 3,008.38, driven by market hopes that the Federal Reserve may adopt a less aggressive monetary tightening stance. Winners outpaced losers 309 to 191, with Jardine Matheson Holdings and iFast Corporation among the top gainers. The FTSE ST Reit Index rose 3.5% as investors sought earnings expectations and less hawkish interest rate predictions.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.00 per cent, or 152.08 points, to 15,317.67.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index lost 0.2 per cent to 7,000.75 points.

site_title: Ping An profit falls on weak sales and market turmoil
summary: Ping An Insurance's net income fell 6.3% to 76.5 billion yuan in the first nine months, impacted by a slump in the stock market and economic slowdown. The company's core insurance arm is undergoing painful reform, and weakening demand amid the pandemic and a slowing economy are also contributing factors. This marks a contrast to the 3.9% gain in the first half.

site_title: Kore posts 8.1% decline in Q3 distributable income
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported an 8.1% decline in distributable income to US$14.6 million for Q3 2022, despite a 3.2% increase in gross revenue to US$37.2 million. The decline was attributed to a base fee payment of US$1.7 million in cash. The Reit's manager cited the acquisitions of Bridge Crossing and 105 Edgeview as positive factors, and noted the Reit had sufficient cash and undrawn facilities.

images.alt_text:
0728 Darwis
Keppel Pacific Oak US REIT_105 EdgeviewCaption: 105 Edgeview is a freehold asset and is one of the newest, highest quality office buildings in Northwest Denver. The property has obtained the US Green Building Council’s LEED Platinum certification in recognition of its myriad sustainable features.
Keppel Pacific Oak US REIT to expand portfolio with acquisitions of Nashville and Denver assets for US$105.1 million
Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.

site_title: Japan eyes US$170b spending to ease inflation pain: Kyodo
summary: Japan is set to spend around $170 billion in a fresh stimulus package to ease inflation, with analysts expecting a portion to be funded by additional debt issuance that would increase the country's already massive public debt. The package, which includes state outlays and municipal government expenditures, aims to cushion the economic blow from rising raw material costs and curb rising energy costs for households and businesses. The move comes after Britain's former prime minister Liz Truss's fiscal plans jolted investors, making markets sensitive to any big spending plans.

site_title: Luxury watch sales take off post-pandemic
summary: The Swiss watch industry is set for a record year, with exports reaching CHF 18.1 billion (S$25.8 billion) from January to September, a 12% increase from last year. The surge in sales can be attributed to the release of luxury watch novelties, including the left-handed Rolex Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II and Patek Philippe's white gold Nautilus Ref. 5811. The industry's growth is expected to continue, driven by consumer demand for high-end timepieces.

images.alt_text: Learn what goes into the making of a Lange timepiece at The Mechanical Masters exhibition.
The Patek Philippe Nautilus 5811 comes in white gold and has a sunburst dial with a black gradient rim.

site_title: Putin is onto us
summary: US President Joe Biden's plan to release 15 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to lower fuel prices may inadvertently help Russian President Vladimir Putin assemble an "oil and gas bomb" that could disrupt the global energy market. Putin is trying to break through Ukraine's lines and drive up energy costs for Western allies by manipulating oil and gas supplies, while also trying to destroy Ukraine's ability to generate electricity. The US and EU are trying to counter this by imposing sanctions on Russian oil exports, but Putin's strategy may involve price fixing and other market distortions. The situation could lead to a global energy crisis, with oil prices potentially rising to $200 a barrel and natural gas prices increasing to $10-12 a gallon.

images.alt_text: The decision to make the biggest ever dip into the emergency oil reserves – usually kept for responding to situations such as hurricane-related shutdowns at oil refineries – was Joe Biden’s gambit to calm energy markets and shield the US economy from Ukraine war shocks.

Oil pumpjacks in California. The most effective way that the US could respond to rising oil prices would be by encouraging domestic production, but this runs counter to the views of the environmentalist lobby and progressive Democrats.

Russia's President Vladimir Putin said that Russian gas could still be supplied to Europe through one remaining intact part of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline but the ball was now in the EU’s court on whether it wanted that to happen.

site_title: Inflation to dent global salaries in 2023
summary: Soaring inflation is set to dent global salaries in 2023, with 37% of countries expecting real-term wage hikes. Europe is expected to be the worst-hit region, with real salaries declining by an average 1.5%. In the UK, salaries fell 5.6% in real terms despite a 3.5% nominal pay increase, and are set to tumble another 4% in 2023. Only 8 Asian nations are forecast to see real salaries rise, with India leading the way at 4.6%.

images.alt_text: (Above) People having lunch at Waterway Point in October. Some starting salaries of F&B staff have risen by more than a fifth in recent months.

site_title: Meta slams Apple for ‘undercutting others’ with ad policy
summary: Meta criticized Apple for changing its App Store terms to take a 30% commission on in-app purchases, including social media advertising revenue. The policy change requires users and advertisers to make an in-app purchase to "boost" posts, potentially reducing Meta's ad revenue. Meta's shares fell 3.4% after the announcement, citing that Apple had previously stated it didn't take a share of developer advertising revenue. Apple argued that the change is an extension of its existing policies, and other apps already comply.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.57 points to 1,454.98. A total of 2.608 billion lots worth RM1.800 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 521 to 354, indicating a positive trend.

site_title: US mortgage interest rates jump to 7.16%, highest since 2001
summary: US mortgage interest rates have reached 7.16%, the highest since 2001, due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes to combat high inflation. Since the beginning of the year, mortgage rates have more than doubled. The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose 22 basis points, while mortgage application activity has slowed to its lowest pace since 1997.

site_title: Oman's sovereign wealth fund eyes tech investments in UK
summary: Oman's sovereign wealth fund, the Oman Investment Authority, is considering investing in UK technology firms to take advantage of market opportunities amid rising interest rates and sterling's fall. Director General of Private Equity Ibrahim Al Eisri stated that the fund is looking at unlisted technology firms for expansion, with plans to list 30 companies over the next five years. This move comes as the UK faces a cost-of-living crisis, and the fund is also exploring opportunities in the mining and fisheries sectors.

images.alt_text: This handout image provided by the UAE Ministry Of Presidential Affairs shows the flag of Oman flying above al-Alam Royal Palace in the capital Muscat on September 27, 2022. site_title: Freehold boutique hotel in Little India up for sale at S$35m guide price
summary: A freehold boutique hotel in Little India, Singapore, is up for sale at a guide price of S$35 million. The 3-storey hotel, Sandpiper Hotel, sits on a 2,750 sqft freehold land area and features 29 hotel rooms. The property benefits from its location in a heritage district, with recent easing of border restrictions expected to attract international tourists. Foreigners and companies are eligible to purchase, with no additional stamp duties imposed. An expression of interest (EOI) exercise will close on December 2.

images.alt_text:
To date, the domestic market has witnessed almost S$1.2 billion worth of transactions, led by the sale of 28 & 30 Bideford Road at effectively S$1.3 million per key and SO/ Singapore effectively at S$1.2 million
per key.

site_title: Heineken sees slowdown in demand for some European markets
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, reported slower-than-expected sales growth in some European markets, with beer volumes rising 8.9% on a like-for-like basis in the third quarter. Despite this, the company retained its full-year outlook for operating margin to be stable or increase modestly. The brewer cited macroeconomic concerns and rising inflation as reasons for caution, and shares fell 8.1% in early trading. The company's Asia-Pacific region saw a 68% increase in beer sales, driven by Vietnam.

site_title: Eurozone credit growth rises again, despite gloomy outlook
summary: Eurozone credit growth accelerated to 8.9% in September, the fastest pace since early 2009, driven by businesses' increased need for liquidity to cover energy costs. However, lending to companies slowed sharply, and credit demand is expected to fall in the fourth quarter due to rising interest rates, recession, and firms clawing back investments. Household credit growth slowed to 4.4% from 4.5% in the previous month.

site_title: Germany allows China’s Cosco to take 24.9% stake in largest port: sources
summary: Germany's Cabinet approved a 24.9% stake in Hamburg's largest port terminal for China's Cosco, a compromise reached after significant political resistance. The deal was initially planned for a 35% stake, and comes ahead of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's trip to China. The move aims to allow Hamburg to keep pace with rival ports vying for Chinese trade, despite concerns from Economy Minister Robert Habeck about avoiding Chinese investment in critical infrastructure.

site_title: Canada’s Ontario ups foreign home buyers’ speculation tax to 25%
summary: The Ontario government has increased the real estate speculation tax for foreign buyers from 20% to 25% in an effort to tackle Canada's housing crisis. This move comes as the province is projected to have more new households than new homes by 2030, according to the national housing agency. Housing Minister Steve Clark stated that the tax change will help make housing more affordable for Ontarians, including young people, newcomers, and seniors.

images.alt_text: Owner sale listings almost doubled to 91 listings in Q3 2022, from the previous quarter's 62. It also comprised more than two thirds of the sale listings this quarter, which totalled at 131.

site_title: Smartphone storage space is where the turf war for game makers is happening
summary: Mobile game studios are facing a storage crisis as their increasingly complex games consume more space, forcing players to choose between fewer, larger games. Japanese games publisher Gree Inc. expects this trend to worsen, citing the need for more intricate graphics, voice acting, and storylines to compete. The situation could lead to consolidation in the industry, with smaller studios struggling to compete against larger, more budgeted titles. Cloud gaming has yet to provide a solution, and handset makers are needed to offer larger storage models to alleviate the issue.

images.alt_text: Growing Western interest in Chinese games reflects a maturing of China’s game development industry.

site_title: Puma confirms operating profit, sales outlook after Q3 results
summary: Puma reported its best third quarter in history, with earnings before interest and taxes (Ebit) rising 12.6% to 258 million euros and currency-adjusted sales growing 16.9% to 2.35 billion euros. Despite ongoing Covid-19 lockdown measures in China, Puma saw sales growth in the Asia/Pacific region for the first time this year. The company reiterated its full-year operating result and currency-adjusted sales outlook, indicating confidence in its market performance despite global uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks enjoy healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced healthy gains on October 26, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.00% to 15,317.67. The gains followed strong performances on Wall Street due to hopes for a positive corporate earnings season. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw increases, with the latter rising 1.79%. The gains were likely influenced by the strong US stock market and optimism about future corporate earnings.

site_title: Emperor penguins are protected under US Endangered Species Act
summary: The US has listed emperor penguins as a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act due to the decline of their sea ice habitat caused by human-induced climate change. Experts predict that 99% of the world's population will disappear by 2100 without significant carbon pollution reduction. The Antarctic sea ice, essential for breeding, chick-rearing, and predator escape, is melting at an alarming rate. The listing reflects the "growing extinction crisis" and calls for international cooperation on conservation strategies.

images.alt_text: Bushland burned out by wildfires in New South Wales, Australia, in 2020.

site_title: Audi partners with Swiss Sauber for Formula One
summary: Audi has agreed to take a stake in Swiss-based Sauber Group, which will become Audi's works entry in Formula One from 2026. Sauber will continue to use Ferrari engines for the next three seasons. Audi's entry into Formula One is part of its plans to build its own power unit in Neuburg, Bavaria, under new engine rules coming in 2026. The partnership aims to achieve a net zero carbon footprint by 2030, a boundary condition for Audi's entry. No financial details were disclosed.

images.alt_text: The latest Audi S8 has a flashy new grille and redesigned bumpers.

site_title: Spotify criticises Ye's comments, keeps his music
summary: Spotify has decided not to remove Kanye West's music from its platform despite the rapper's recent promotion of antisemitic conspiracy theories. According to Spotify CEO Daniel Ek, West's music does not violate the company's anti-hate policies, which prohibit hate speech. West's label, Universal Music's Def Jam, has condemned his remarks, but has not requested the removal of his music. This decision comes after West has lost high-profile partnerships, including Adidas and Creative Artists Agency.

images.alt_text: In cutting ties with Ye, formerly Kanye West, Adidas will take a €250 million ($246.5 million) hit to net income in the current fiscal year.

site_title: A reboot for NFTs?
summary: The NFT craze may have collapsed, but luxury brands, businesses, and celebrities continue to support the digital platform. Notable examples include a private members' club creating its own digital universe, a wedding in the metaverse, and an NFT bar and lounge. Celebrities like Bella Hadid and Paris Hilton have also joined the NFT bandwagon, defying the fading hype. Despite the collapse, the digital platform remains a hub for creativity and innovation, with various projects and ventures emerging globally.

site_title: Owner sales surge in Q3 property auction market: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank reports that owner sale listings nearly doubled to 91 in Q3 2022, a 46.3% increase from the previous quarter and a 7.1% increase from the same period last year. This accounts for more than two-thirds of total sale listings this quarter. Residential, industrial, and retail listings also saw significant growth, with increases of 38%, 53%, and 61% respectively. The surge in owner sales reflects a shift towards auctions as a method of sale.

images.alt_text: Owner sale listings more than doubled to 62 properties last quarter, up 121.4 per cent from Q1’s 28.
Knight Frank’s auction and private treaty sales on Wednesday (Jun 29) also boasted several luxury properties.
A retail unit in Sim Lim Tower sold for about S$1.46 million (S$2,049 psf), 9.5 per cent lower than the average price of S$2,252 psf for retail units in the building
Slower property auctions in March; sole sale is a freehold retail shop in Sim Lim Tower transacted at S$1.455m
Singapore property auction listings likely to gain pace as rates rise

site_title: Global platform to unify carbon credit registry data to be domiciled in Singapore
summary: Singapore will host the Climate Action Data Trust, a World Bank-backed platform to unify carbon credit registry data and facilitate Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. The platform aims to address double counting in international carbon markets by linking and harmonizing registry data. It will be an independent entity, not governing data validity, and will be launched in early December. The platform is a joint initiative involving the International Emissions Trading Association, World Bank, and Singapore government, among others.

images.alt_text: Scale will be the new umbrella trust fund for the bank’s results-based climate finance activities.

World Bank's report warned that temperatures in the Philippines will continue to rise and rainfall could become more intense due to climate change, putting at risk the country’s ability to meet its development goals.

site_title: UOB and NAC want to strengthen artists’ financial knowledge
summary: UOB and the National Arts Council (NAC) have signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen artists' financial knowledge and resilience. The UOB-NAC Acceleration Programmes will equip 150 artists and 60 arts groups with skills in business finance, management, and digital marketing over three years, with a co-funded budget of S$240,000. The program aims to help artists navigate the post-pandemic landscape and expand their exposure to new audiences. The partnership also includes collaborations on art experiences, self-guided art trails, and art appreciation initiatives to promote mental, emotional, and physical wellness.

images.alt_text:
The 7th edition of the Singapore Biennale is set to open on 16 Oct 2022, with works by more than 50 artists spread over 13 locations. 




Credit : SINGAPORE ART MUSEUM
Pandemic-themed art emerges tops again

(from left) Ms Janice Leong, Executive Director, Corporate Wealth Management, Commercial Banking, UOB Ltd, presented a cheque donation of $500,000 to ChildAid, represented here by Mr Phan Ming Yen, Chief Operating Officer of The Rice Company Ltd, which manages The Business TImes Budding Artists Fund, and Mr Helmi Yusof, co-chair of the Organising Committee of ChildAid 2022.

site_title: StanChart beats estimates with 40% profit jump, raises income outlook
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 40% increase in quarterly profit, beating estimates, due to higher interest rates boosting emerging markets-focused income. The bank upgraded its revenue outlook to 13% growth this year, exceeding the previous forecast of 10%. CEO Bill Winters remains confident in delivering 2024 financial targets. The bank's profit growth comes despite the global economy's struggles with volatile energy costs and the Russia-Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: Lye, a former Mediacorp actor, brings over 20 years of banking experience to Standard Chartered.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's stock markets declined at the open on October 26, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% to 7,000.75 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also dropped 0.2% to 13,032.20 and 6,240.66 points, respectively. The euro remained stable ahead of the European Central Bank's expected interest rate hike to combat inflation. The decline was attributed to mixed earnings and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Taking the innovation plunge to emerge stronger
summary: Singapore's research, innovation, and enterprise ecosystem supports small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through various offerings, including Centres of Innovation, government funding, and national platforms. Companies like JM VisTec and Flexmech Engineering have successfully innovated to stay competitive, with JM VisTec developing an automated machine vision system for Procter & Gamble and Flexmech improving its forecast bottom line by 20% through Industry 4.0 solutions. The ecosystem provides support, including strategic technology road mapping, access to leading scientists and engineers, and licensing of proven technology, allowing SMEs to fast-track their innovation journey and seize new opportunities.

images.alt_text: Singapore to continue investing in talent to benefit from opportunities in advanced manufacturing
As announced in Budget 2022, more SMEs will be able to tap on the capabilities of over 80 technology, innovation and enterprise centres, including Centres of Innovation.

site_title: Shell to explore carbon transport and storage options in Brunei and Singapore
summary: Shell Eastern Petroleum has signed a memorandum of understanding with Brunei Shell Petroleum to explore carbon transport and storage options in Brunei and Singapore. The agreement aims to evaluate the technical and commercial feasibility of carbon storage and transport solutions. As part of Shell's goal to become a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050, this initiative could potentially form part of a carbon capture and storage hub in South-east Asia. The partnership will help reduce emissions from industries such as those on Jurong Island in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Shell Energy will hold the rights to charge and dispatch energy once the project becomes operational.

site_title: Thai Sep exports rise 7.8 per cent y-o-y, beat forecast
summary: Thai exports rose 7.8% in September from the previous year, beating the forecast of a 4.20% increase, according to the commerce minister. This growth is attributed to increased shipments of food and industrial goods. In the first nine months of 2022, exports rose 10.6% from the same period last year. September imports increased 15.6% from the previous year, less than the forecasted 20.0% increase. Thailand posted a trade deficit of $853 million in September. The ministry expects exports to continue expanding and achieving its target, driven by a weakening baht and improving supply chain.

site_title: PME taskforce says it has not made progress on its unemployment benefits recommendations
summary: A Singapore PME taskforce has expressed frustration over the government's lack of response to its recommendations for unemployment benefits, citing the rising costs of living and worsening labor market conditions. The taskforce, which has made progress on eight of its nine recommendations, is pushing for temporary unemployment benefits to support workers who are involuntarily unemployed. However, the government has yet to respond to the proposal, citing affordability and sustainability concerns.

images.alt_text: Unemployment benefits proposal 'interesting to watch' due to past policy resistance

site_title: Barclays traders beat estimates as uncertainty freezes deals
summary: Barclays' traders exceeded estimates with a 45% increase in trading revenue to £2.26 billion, driven by higher interest rates. However, investment banking fees fell 45% to £533 million, missing estimates. The bank's domestic unit saw a 17% rise in income due to interest rates, but increased charges against potential loan losses by £381 million. Barclays' chief executive, CS Venkatakrishnan, stated the bank is ready to provide support for customers in an uncertain economic environment.

images.alt_text: Barclays paid undisclosed fees to Qatari funds involved in its rescue, the FCA said, which were calculated “specifically by reference to the Qataris’ demands” rather than advisory services.

site_title: SK Hynix to halve 2023 capital spending after profit plunge
summary: SK Hynix, a South Korean chipmaker, plans to cut its capital spending for 2023 by half after reporting a 60% decline in third-quarter profit due to plummeting memory chip demand. The company attributed the decline to decreased shipments of PCs and smartphones, major buyers of memory chips. This move reflects growing pessimism about the electronics demand outlook, fueled by a potential recession and uncertainty over the US-China tech industry's impact.

images.alt_text: South Korean rival SK Hynix has purchased Intel’s Nand flash memory chip manufacturing business in Dalian and produces Dram chips at another China-based facility.

site_title: A clean energy super grid across Asia is closer to reality
summary: A clean energy super grid across Asia is becoming more feasible, with plans to connect power plants and customers from Japan to India. A study by the Asia Green Grid Network finds that high-voltage direct current technology and sub-sea cables can make long-distance energy transmission economical. The estimated cost of the main transmission lines is between $77 billion and $116 billion, lower than previous estimates. The project aims to shift renewable energy generated in one region to consumers thousands of miles away, turbocharging the green transition and integrating grids in Asia.

images.alt_text: Apple had previously asked suppliers to commit to 100 per cent renewable energy for Apple’s production.

site_title: Australia admits cyber defences ‘inadequate’ as medical hack hits millions
summary: Australia's cyber defences have been deemed "inadequate" following a massive medical hack at private health insurer Medibank, exposing the personal data of 3.9 million policy holders, or 15% of the population. The company estimates the breach could cost up to A$35 million. This is the latest in a series of hacks targeting millions of people in Australia, prompting calls for increased cyber security measures and tougher fines for companies failing to protect customer data.

images.alt_text: Cyber attacks are becoming increasingly common in Australia, with last month’s major hack of mobile phone provider Optus spurring national outcry.
Companies ought to provide more prompt disclosures of the cyber breaches they have been afflicted by.
UOBKH forecasts a provision of around S$240 million for Singtel — including an anticipated regulatory fine of A$2.2 million (S$2 million) — in Q2 2023

site_title: In-person events still in demand as Singapore Mice activity rebounds
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival 2022 returns as an in-person event after a 3-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Over 60 international events, including prominent shows that used to be held in other major cities, will be held in the second half of 2022. The festival's organizer, Constellar, expects events to continue in high demand, citing the strong need for in-person connections post-pandemic. The festival marks the industry's recovery and growth in the meetings, incentives, conferences & exhibitions (Mice) sector in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez (left) leads at the start of the Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sunday.

Signatories at the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding between Singapore Tourism Board and key Mice industry players to establish the Global MICE Sustainability Alliance (L-R): Jean Chia, group president at PICO World (Singapore); Jean Francois Quentin, Constellar Group CEO at Constellar Venues; Richard Ireland, president at SACEOS; Keith Tan, chief executive at STB; Charlie McCurdy, president and CEO at Informa Markets; Mark Kemper, group chief corporate and financial officer at Cityneon Holdings; and Sarah Chew, executive director at Kingsmen Exhibits.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as investors shrug off dismal inflation data
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to close at 6,810.9 points on Wednesday, driven by bets of a less-aggressive US Federal Reserve rate hike, despite dismal inflation data. The S&P/ASX 200 index had risen 0.6% earlier in the day, with slowing home price growth and souring consumer confidence in US data easing concerns about economic softness. This trend is seen as evidence of abating Fed hawkishness, supporting investor confidence.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6 points to 6,840.30 by 2157 GMT on Wednesday, with most sub-sectors trading in the positive territory.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, October 26, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.67% to 27,431.84, driven by drops in US and UK yields. Investors are reassured by expectations of a slowdown in rate hikes. The broader Topix index also rose 0.58% to 1,918.21.

site_title: What’s driving the rich world’s falling fertility?
summary: The rich world's falling fertility rates are resistant to measures aimed at increasing family incentives and welfarist policies. Data suggests that educated women, particularly those in the middle and upper classes, are more likely to remain childless, with nearly twice as many childless households among degree-educated women. The real cause is believed to be the poor economic deal for working women, particularly the loss of income and prestige at work. Policymakers are urged to address this issue by making childbirth a better deal for professional women, as the global fertility rate decline poses a significant threat to the future of the planet.

images.alt_text: bird, nature, wing

site_title: Temasek’s 65 Equity Partners invests S$150m in Cityneon
summary: Temasek's 65 Equity Partners has invested S$150 million in Cityneon, a company providing immersive experiences. This follows a previous funding round in April, where Cityneon raised S$235 million. The collective funds will be used to strengthen growth, expand into new markets, and build technological capabilities. Cityneon plans to rebrand as "Neon" to offer new experiences. The investment aligns with 65 Equity Partners' mandate of supporting high-growth businesses led by founders and entrepreneurs.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on US Fed pivot hopes, earnings in focus
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.65% to their highest in a week, led by chipmakers and battery manufacturers, amid hopes of slower US monetary tightening. The Kospi benchmark closed at 2,249.56, driven by Samsung Electronics' 2.95% gain and LG Energy Solution's 3.52% jump after beating earnings forecasts. US consumer confidence fell in October, supporting views of a slower Fed policy pace. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 612 billion won, and the won strengthened against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ends down 1.09 points or 0.05 per cent at 2,235.07.

site_title: Crypto industry disappointed as Australia looks to enshrine tax rules
summary: Australia's government has decided to treat digital currencies like Bitcoin as assets for tax purposes, resulting in investors paying capital gains tax on profits from selling crypto assets. This move, announced in the budget, removes uncertainty following El Salvador's adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender. However, central bank digital currencies will be treated as foreign currency. Industry experts, including a former cryptocurrency exchange operator, expressed disappointment and concern that the move may hinder Australia's ability to keep pace with other countries in regulating digital assets, potentially leaving it behind in the industry.

images.alt_text: MAS intends to first issue a set of guidelines for crypto service providers after this consultation, and later legislate them.

site_title: Rebranded Singapore Fashion Council pursues innovation, tech, sustainability
summary: The Singapore Fashion Council (SFC) has rebranded itself as a trade association focused on innovation, technology, and sustainability in the fashion industry. The SFC signed 10 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with partners including StarHub, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, and Deloitte Singapore, aiming to drive growth and transformation in the industry. The council will provide support for capability development, industry mentorships, and market development, with a focus on addressing the challenges driving conversations in the fashion industry.

images.alt_text: Almost all retail sales categories saw growth in August, with the exception of supermarkets and hypermarkets; motor vehicles; and mini-marts and convenience stores.

site_title: MAS launches crypto consumer protection playbook, seeks public feedback on proposals
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a consultation paper to protect retail customers from risks associated with cryptocurrency trading. The proposals include restricting cryptocurrency trading via credit, implementing customer-knowledge assessments, and prohibiting crypto service providers from lending out customers' digital-payment tokens. The MAS aims to draw up guidelines and later legislate them, with a six to nine month timeline for service providers to meet the requirements. The regulator is seeking public feedback on the proposals, which also include measures to promote fair and transparent trading and detect unfair practices.

images.alt_text: The proposals seek cross-border consistency to regulating crypto-assets, particularly as the European Union finalises groundbreaking rules to regulate the sector from 2024.
MAS managing director Ravi Menon at the media conference on July 19, 2022.
THE ongoing cryptocurrency rout, triggered in part by the collapse of popular stablecoin TerraUSD, has sent regulators around the world scrambling to strengthen investor protection.

site_title: New visa to let tourists with 2b rupiah live in Bali for 10 years
summary: Indonesia introduces a new "second home visa" offering 5- and 10-year stays for affluent individuals with at least 2 billion rupiah (S$183,015) in their bank accounts. The policy aims to boost the country's economy and attract wealthy global citizens, particularly to Bali, which is a major source of foreign exchange earnings. The visa launch coincides with a rebound in foreign tourist arrivals and the upcoming G20 Summit in Bali, expected to put the island in the international spotlight.

site_title: SIA may resume dividend payout this fiscal year, redeem 2021 bonds
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) may resume dividend payments for its fiscal year to March 2023, following the redemption of its zero-coupon mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) issued in 2020. Analysts at Citi and DBS expect the airline to redeem the 2021 MCBs before they mature in 2030, fueling optimism among investors. The redemption announcement has pushed up the prices of both MCB tranches, with the 2020 tranche reaching a record high. SIA's cash flows and favorable medium-term prospects suggest it could redeem the 2021 MCBs as soon as next year or in 2024.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines announced in a Tuesday bourse filing that it will be redeeming all of its mandatory convertible bonds for S$3.86 billion.

site_title: China’s economy slows in October as business confidence slumps
summary: China's economy slowed in October as business confidence fell, with small business confidence contracting for the first time since May due to Covid Zero restrictions. Export orders rose, but domestically focused companies showed weaker demand, leading to a contraction in the manufacturing sector and accommodation and catering. The National Day holiday period also failed to boost spending, with the COVID resurgence and private consumption growth remaining a concern. The slowdown signals China's grim economic picture, with no indication of changes to the Covid Zero strategy from the recent Communist Party congress.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities have struggled to make ends meet this year as massive tax rebates and the persistent housing market crisis have cut government income sharply.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall Street on rate hope, healthy earnings
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday, building on a strong performance in New York, driven by healthier earnings from big-name firms and hopes for a slowdown in Federal Reserve rate hikes. Hong Kong and Shanghai were among the best performers after China's central bank pledged support for the country's equities, bonds, and yuan. The prospect of a slowdown in US rate hikes weakened the dollar, lifting the yen and euro. Despite a few economic reports showing a weakening economy, investors welcomed better-than-expected profits from Coca-Cola and General Motors, leading to a 2% gain on the Nasdaq.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta stock markets all rose on Tuesday, though Taipei fell.

site_title: Offerer for Asian Healthcare Specialists receives additional irrevocable undertakings
summary: Labrador Park, the offerer for medical group Asian Healthcare Specialists, has received additional irrevocable undertakings from shareholder Lim Cheok Peng, increasing the total to 87.16% or 504,101,246 shares. This brings the company's value to S$109 million. The voluntary cash offer is conditional upon receiving 90% of shares and securing necessary approvals.

site_title: Singapore factory output rises 0.9% in September but remains weak
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 0.9% year on year in September, reversing a slowdown since May, but remained weak. The electronics sector contracted 7% year on year, while the biomedical cluster declined 3.5%. The petroleum segment grew 12.1% due to higher jet fuel demand. Manufacturing growth for Q3 is expected to be 0.8%, below flash estimates of 1.5%. Analysts predict a downgrade to 2023's GDP growth to around 4.2% due to high inflation and demand dampening.

images.alt_text: Global markets are still grappling with high inflation, qualitative tightening and the geopolitical uncertainties of Russia's war in Ukraine, said SPIMM's industry engagement and development vice-president Sophia Poh.
Many billions of dollars are needed to develop the latest generation of semiconductors.

“Many semiconductor companies operating in Singapore have manufacturing processes and products that rely on US technology, which may be subject to export controls imposed by the US government,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.

site_title: Toyota slashes leasing fee for troubled EV to rekindle orders
summary: Toyota has reduced the leasing fee for its troubled electric vehicle, the bZ4X, by half to 385,000 yen (S$3,755) to rekindle orders. The automaker previously charged a one-time fee of 770,000 yen and a monthly lease of 107,800 yen. The discount aims to attract interest in the car, which suffered a safety recall after two months on the market and halted production. The move is seen as a cost-cutting measure to turn a profit, despite the discount being "painful" and unlikely to generate significant sales.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 2023 Toyota bZ4X all-electric SUV is displayed during the 2021 LA Auto Show in Los Angeles, California, U.S. November, 17, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
The bZ3 was developed jointly by Toyota and BYD.

site_title: Luna token’s vexed legal status dogs prosecutors chasing Kwon
summary: South Korean prosecutors are investigating Do Kwon, the founder of Terraform Labs, over the $60 billion collapse of his crypto project. A recent court decision appears to support Kwon's defense, as a judge questioned whether the TerraUSD and Luna tokens, which Kwon created, can be regulated as securities. The case highlights disputes over the legal status of cryptocurrencies in South Korea, with the country yet to implement a clear regulatory code. Kwon faces multiple charges, including fraud and illegal fundraising, and his whereabouts remain unclear.

images.alt_text: Kwon refrained from revealing his whereabouts in a podcast earlier this week, citing threats he’s received.
Kwon refrained from specifying his whereabouts during the discussion, citing threats he’s received.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.46% decline, or 69.27 points, to 15,096.32, following a rout at the start of the week due to concerns over Xi Jinping's economic policy plans. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.28 points to 2,977.56, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.14% to 1,926.21.

site_title: Japan to extend petrol subsidy to first half of next fiscal year: Kyodo
summary: The Japanese government plans to extend a petrol subsidy until the first half of the next fiscal year to curb rising energy costs. The subsidy, part of an economic stimulus package, aims to ease living costs. The package, totaling around 26 trillion yen, will also include support for alleviating rising electricity bills, set to be implemented in January. The government aims to reduce the subsidy from the middle of the next year, with a cabinet meeting scheduled for October 28 to approve the package.

site_title: Gold subdued as dollar ticks higher; investors eye Fed outlook
summary: Gold prices were flat at $1,653.06 per ounce due to a firmer dollar, with investors awaiting guidance on the US Federal Reserve's policy tightening. The dollar index rose 0.1%, reducing gold's appeal for overseas buyers. US consumer confidence fell in October amid rising inflation concerns, and China's net gold imports via Hong Kong halved from the previous month. The Fed is expected to deliver a fourth straight interest-rate hike in November, which may further dim gold's appeal.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the zero-yield bullion, while boosting the dollar and bond yields.

site_title: Bank of Japan increases bond buying, yields fall sharply
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) increased its bond buying operations to curb a surge in yields, with the 30-year JGB yield falling 10 basis points to 1.475% and the 20-year JGB yield slipping 6.5 basis points to 1.130%. The BOJ also increased its purchases of bonds with 3- to 5-year maturities and those with maturities over 25 years. The move was in response to investors testing the central bank's resolve to pin down interest rates, which had sent yields on super-long ends to multi-year highs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.75% or 203.39 points at 27,453.67. The gains followed Wall Street rallies fueled by a drop in US Treasury yields and solid corporate earnings. The broader Topix index was also up 0.66% or 12.55 points at 1,919.69.

site_title: Singapore stocks start Wednesday stronger after Wall Street gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks began Wednesday with a 0.4% gain, mirroring overnight US gains. The Straits Times Index rose 11.61 points to 2,995.76, driven by gains in local banks, including DBS, which rose 0.4% to S$32.88. CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding also saw brisk trading. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Dow Jones, finished higher, while European stocks rose 1.4% on better-than-expected earnings reports.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines announced in a Tuesday bourse filing that it will be redeeming all of its mandatory convertible bonds for S$3.86 billion.

site_title: Toku raises US$10 million Series A funding for APAC expansion
summary: Cloud communications provider Toku has secured US$10 million in Series A funding, bringing the total to US$10 million. The extension was co-led by Delivery Hero Ventures, OSK Ventures International, and Betatron Venture Group. The funding will be used to establish local presence in Malaysia, Indonesia, and other APAC markets, and to double the company's headcount to 200 by 2024. Toku's solutions allow customers to connect with each other through various channels, collecting data to provide insights and improve customer experience. The company aims to facilitate regulatory compliance across markets and help companies differentiate themselves through excellent customer support.

images.alt_text: Airwallex was founded in 2015 by the owners of a Melbourne coffee shop, including chief executive officer Jack Zhang (above). According to its website, the company now employs over 1,000 people across 19 international officers in 11 territories.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, up 3.09 points or 0.21% to 1447.50. Volume reached 124.61 million lots worth RM66.61 million, with 170 gainers outnumbering 96 losers.

site_title: Australia inflation races to 32-year high, sounds rate alarm
summary: Australia's consumer price index (CPI) surged 1.8% in the September quarter, reaching a 32-year high of 7.3%, surpassing forecasts. Core inflation also rose 1.8% to 6.1%, above expectations of 5.6%. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) may need to reconsider its rate hike strategy, with some analysts predicting a more aggressive tightening of monetary policy. The news comes as the RBA downshifted to a quarter-point rate hike in October, and the country's inflation concerns are exacerbated by recent flooding and soaring food prices.

site_title: Charting the future of finance professionals
summary: Finance professionals must adapt to add value beyond just providing reports. They must ask relevant questions, organize internal systems and processes, and measure and manage what matters. To remain relevant, accountants need to acquire broader skills in strategic communications, efficiency, and business planning. The pandemic has accelerated the shift towards a new economy, where human judgment and interaction are more valuable than technology. Accountants must adopt a lifelong learning mindset to stay current and showcase their abilities, including their value in driving digitalization, sustainability, and environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) strategies.

images.alt_text: Today, the decreasing costs of renewable energy generation, coupled with better efficiency and storage solutions, is making clean energy more accessible than ever.

site_title: China budget deficit nears record 7.16t yuan amid slowdown
summary: China's fiscal deficit reached a record 7.16 trillion yuan in the first nine months of the year, surpassing the 2.6 trillion yuan shortfall in the same period last year. The deficit was driven by sharp declines in tax revenue and land sales, as well as increased spending on Covid-19 controls and infrastructure projects. Economic growth rebounded to 3.9% in the third quarter, but household consumption remains weak. To address fiscal stress, China is expected to increase its official deficit to over 3% of GDP next year, with policymakers seeking to boost revenue through infrastructure projects and special bonds.

site_title: FCT’s H2 DPU edges up to S$0.06091; manager warns cost of debt could hit above 3% in FY2023
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a flattish DPU of S$0.06091 for the second half of FY2022, largely due to rising interest rates. The manager warned that the average cost of borrowing is expected to rise by at least 50 basis points to above 3% in FY2023, potentially impacting DPU growth. Despite a 7.9% increase in gross revenue and a 6% rise in net property income, the distribution to unitholders for H2 edged up 0.2% to S$103.8 million.

images.alt_text: Ascendas Reit spent S$1.2 billion in the first quarter acquiring 11 data centres in Europe and 1-5 Thomas Holt Drive in Sydney’s Macquarie Park. Acquisitions are an effective way to grow Reits' DPU.

RHB’s Vijay Natarajan says he will be looking at return-to-office trends and physical occupancy - such as at Manulife US Reit's Phipps Tower (pictured) - to assess potential leasing impact from the evolving hybrid working model.

site_title: Sunak’s government reverts to Johnson era
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has appointed over a dozen cabinet ministers who served under Boris Johnson, a significant number of whom were in "political exile" under Liz Truss' administration. Sunak's government is seen as a continuation of Johnson's policies, with the new PM drawing on the success of the 2019 election. However, critics argue that Sunak's judgment is questionable, particularly with the appointment of Home Secretary Suella Braverman, who resigned from the same post last week. Sunak's government faces a daunting task, including high inflation, rising interest rates, and a divided Conservative Party, with many questioning whether he can avoid a general election.

images.alt_text: A newspaper, featuring an image of former British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, rests on a fence outside 10 Downing Street in London, October 21, 2022.

Standing in front of his Downing Street office, Sunak paid tribute to Liz Truss, whose economic programme roiled the markets, saying the mistakes she made were not “born of ill will or bad intentions”.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on signs of easing Federal Reserve hawkish tone; CPI data in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,840.30 on Wednesday, driven by soft US economic data and hopes of less aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a three-day high, with financials and miners leading gains. However, Medibank Private tumbled 14.7% due to a data breach warning. Consumer price index figures later in the day will provide further cues on the Reserve Bank of Australia's stance on interest rate hikes.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit reports S$69.9m in Q3 net property income post-merger
summary: ESR-Logos Reit reported a 57.4% increase in gross revenue and 59.2% increase in net property income to S$96.2 million and S$69.9 million, respectively, for Q3, driven by contributions from ALog Trust after the merger in April 2022. The Reit's YTD gross revenue rose 34.8% to S$243.9 million and YTD NPI increased 32% to S$172.7 million. However, net asset value (NAV) per unit fell 7.6% to 36.6 Singapore cents due to transaction costs and premium paid over ALog Trust's NAV. The Reit's portfolio achieved a positive rental reversion of +11.4% and has a weighted average lease expiry of 3.2 years.

images.alt_text: An ESR-LOGOS Reit property at 2 Jalan Kilang Barat in Singapore's Bukit Merah district.
The property at 2 Jalan Kilang Barat is a 9-storey purpose-built industrial building located in Singapore’s Bukit Merah district.
A-Reit on Aug 4 said it is acquiring the Philips Apac Center in Singapore for S$104.8 million.

Adrian Chui, chief executive officer of the Reit’s manager said: “We are pleased to expand the Reit’s footprint into Japan, our second overseas market, with the acquisition of ESR Sakura DC, a freehold asset that will ride on the strong logistics growth trends in the Greater Tokyo area.”

site_title: Saudi fund invests in luxury sustainable hotel chain
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund and A&K Travel Group have invested $50 million in luxury hotel chain Habitas, supporting its global expansion. Habitas, which operates seven eco-friendly lodgings, plans to open four more properties by the end of 2022 and 10 by the end of 2023. The investment brings Habitas' total fundraising to over $85 million, with earlier investors including Travis Kalanick and Barry Sternlicht.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit posts DPU of S$0.047 in H1
summary: Aims Apac Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.047 for the first half of FY2023, marginally down from S$0.0475 in the same period last year. The Reit's gross revenue increased 27.5% to S$83.2 million and net property income rose 28.2% to S$61.1 million, driven by the acquisition of Woolworths' headquarters. The amount distributable to unitholders inched up 0.4% to S$33.7 million. The Reit's manager aims to capitalize on rental escalations and reversions to improve revenue growth, while exploring sustainability-linked loans to reduce carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Rooftop solar PV panels will be installed atop AA Reit’s largest logistics and warehouse property in Singapore at 20 Gul Way.
AA Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose by 1.3 per cent to S$0.0228 in the first quarter of FY2023, from S$0.0225 in the year-ago period.
The Sime Darby Business Centre along Alexandra Road.

site_title: New Zealand inflation expectations jump back above 6%, ANZ says
summary: New Zealand's inflation expectations surged back above 6% in October, according to ANZ Bank New Zealand. The year-ahead inflation expectations rose to 6.13% from 5.98% in September, driven by a 7.2% increase in consumer prices in the third quarter, a 32-year high. Economists predict the Reserve Bank will implement a more aggressive monetary policy response, starting with a 75 basis point interest rate hike in November, to combat inflation. Business expectations for the general economy fell to minus 42.7, with pessimistic views on activity and higher inflation.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand dollar rose slightly after the data showed inflation was hotter than expected.

site_title: Apple announces new clean energy investments, asks suppliers to decarbonise
summary: Apple announced new clean energy investments, aiming to power 100% of its European operations with low-carbon electricity by 2025. The company is also requiring suppliers to decarbonize production, with over 200 suppliers representing 70% of its direct manufacturing spending committing to 100% renewable energy. Apple's goal is to reduce its carbon footprint by 22% by addressing emissions from electricity customers. The company plans to invest in solar and wind projects in Europe, adding 3,000 gigawatt hours of new renewable energy per year.

images.alt_text: Apple charges a typical 30 per cent fee on payments it handles.
Apple’s push into streaming in recent years is part of a broader effort to generate more revenue from services.

site_title: Fear of catching Covid has cost US economy US$250b this year
summary: Persistent fears of catching COVID-19 have cost the US economy $250 billion in the first half of 2022, according to new research. Approximately 3 million Americans remained out of the workforce due to these concerns, with 60% of respondents unwilling to return to pre-pandemic activities. This phenomenon, dubbed "Long Social Distancing," affects people with underlying health conditions and those who are cautious, resulting in a significant loss in gross domestic product.

images.alt_text: Consumers’ 12-month inflation expectations rose to 7.0 per cent from 6.8 per cent last month.

site_title: Spotify tops subscriber forecasts, sees margin pressure this quarter
summary: Spotify reported 456 million monthly average users for the third quarter, beating analysts' projections. The company's profit margins may narrow due to programming costs, and it's considering raising prices in the US. Despite a 19% increase in ad revenue, sales were slower than expected, and the company forecast a gross margin of 24.5% and an operating loss of 300 million euros in the fourth quarter. The sell-off in shares reflects investors' focus on profitability over subscriber growth.

images.alt_text: spotify Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Suntec Reit’s Q3 DPU slips 6.6% to S$0.02084 despite higher earnings
summary: Suntec Reit's Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 6.6% to S$0.02084, despite a 15.7% gain in gross revenue to S$107.3 million and a 12.1% increase in net property income to S$77.1 million. Higher financing costs and asset management fees contributed to the decline. The Reit's occupancy and rent across its office, retail, and convention properties improved, but were affected by higher interest rates and exchange rates. A distribution of S$0.02084 will be paid out on Nov 29.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has the highest gearing ratio among the S-Reits, at 43.9% as at Jun 30.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bags maiden contract for LNG carriers
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured its first contract for liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers, a 175,000 cubic meter order for two vessels from an unnamed European customer. The ships will be equipped with GTT Mark III Flex membrane tanks and are scheduled for delivery between 2025 and 2026, marking the company's first GTT Mark III LNG carrier order after obtaining its GTT license in September 2022.

images.alt_text: Two 24,000 TEU (20-foot equivalent unit) containerships under construction in the dry dock at Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Xinfu Yard. The group has secured its first GTT (Gaztransport & Technigaz) Mark III LNG (liquefied natural gas) carrier order.
Michelle Zhu

site_title: Fossil fuel dependence risks current and future health: experts
summary: An international team of experts warns that over-reliance on fossil fuels exacerbates the health impacts of global crises like climate change, pandemics, and food security. 69 out of 86 governments subsidize fossil fuel production and consumption, amounting to $400 billion in 2019. This supports extreme heat, leading to nearly 100 million additional people facing severe food insecurity, compared to 2010-1981.
