images.alt_text: Preliminary data reported by EU member states showed that greenhouse gas emissions rose by 5 per cent in 2021 from 2020, mainly due to the post-Covid economic recovery, a new EEA report showed.

GIC’s head of sustainability and total portfolio sustainable investing Rachel Teo and her associates laid out their method, the carbon earnings-at-risk scenario analysis, in a paper published on Tuesday (Oct 25).
Singapore reduced its emissions to 52.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2020, equivalent to 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels, Wong said.

Solar and wind energy took over a decade to transform the renewable energy landscape; hydrogen could reach maturity over a shorter period given ambitious climate goals amid the global race to hit net-zero

World Bank's report warned that temperatures in the Philippines will continue to rise and rainfall could become more intense due to climate change, putting at risk the country’s ability to meet its development goals.

site_title: Global economy approaching a recession, central banks unchained: poll
summary: The global economy is approaching a recession, according to a Reuters poll, with economists predicting inflation won't fall until it reaches around half its current level. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates for a fourth consecutive time on November 2, and central banks are keeping rates high to combat inflation. This is despite some major economies starting recessions with relatively low unemployment, marking the smallest gap between growth rates and joblessness in at least four decades.

images.alt_text: An electronic board shows Shanghai and Shenzhen stock indexes in Shanghai. Cihnese markets could remain volatile in the coming weeks as investors continue to parse what the new leadership has in mind for the economy.
Economic conditions are going to “tighten meaningfully from here,” Goldman Sachs Group chief executive officer David Solomon said at Saudi Arabia’s Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, MLT, YZJ Shipbuilding, Keppel Reit, Suntec Reit, FCT, ESR-Logos Reit
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced it will redeem all its mandatory convertible bonds for S$3.86 billion. Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) increased its distribution per unit (DPU) by 3.5% to S$0.02248 for the second quarter. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding clinched an order for two liquefied natural gas carriers, boosting its orderbook to over US$10 billion. Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit reported positive quarterly results, while Frasers Centrepoint Trust and ESR-Logos Reit also posted gains.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.5 per cent or 14.2 points to end Tuesday at 2,984.15.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet drops as earnings, sales miss estimates
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported revenue and earnings that fell short of analyst expectations, with third-quarter sales coming in at $57.27 billion and net income at $1.06 per share less than estimates. The decline is attributed to spiraling inflation crimping growth in digital advertising, with Google's search business and YouTube ad sales missing estimates. Shares plummeted over 6% as the company faces increased competition from rivals like TikTok and Meta Platforms' Facebook. Analysts warn that Google's reliance on search advertising makes it vulnerable to economic downturns.

images.alt_text: The CCI ordered Google to allow app makers to use third-party billing systems and treat rival payment processing services on equal footing.

Verily, formerly Google Life Sciences, was a division of the semi-secret research and development group at the company called Google X, until it split off as an independent subsidiary of Alphabet in 2015.

site_title: Square Peg raises US$550 million for fifth venture capital fund
summary: Square Peg, a venture capital firm, has raised US$550 million for its fifth fund, surpassing its previous funds with over US$1.6 billion in total investments. The firm has returned over US$580 million to investors with a 42% internal rate of return. The capital will be deployed into seed to Series B rounds and late-stage rounds of emerging companies in fintech, edtech, and SaaS sectors, with a focus on Australia, Israel, and South-east Asia.

site_title: Musk tells bankers he plans to close Twitter deal on Friday
summary: Elon Musk has pledged to close the acquisition of Twitter by Friday, according to a video conference call with bankers. The banks, providing $13 billion in debt financing, have completed the final credit agreement and are in the process of signing documentation. Twitter shares jumped after the news, trading as high as $53.18. The banks, which are facing potential paper losses of $500 million, are expected to receive a borrowing notice on Tuesday and the cash to be held in escrow on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The billionaire earlier this month said he would follow through with his agreement to take Twitter private.
The world’s richest person is pursuing the Twitter purchase after earlier trying to back out of the US$44 billion deal.

site_title: Europe’s emissions rise post-Covid, won’t meet targets: EEA
summary: Europe's greenhouse gas emissions rose by 5% in 2021, mainly due to the post-Covid economic recovery, exceeding the EU's target of a 55% reduction in net emissions by 2030. According to the European Environment Agency, emissions remain 6% below the 2019 pre-pandemic level. To meet the target, the EU must double its efforts on greenhouse gas emissions every year from 2021 to 2030, with a focus on increasing renewable energy, particularly wind and hydro power, to reach 45% of energy consumption by 2030.

images.alt_text: Lignite-powered power plant (brown coal) in Western Germany. Coal price has skyrocketed this year, raising the urgency of the need to invest in clean energy.
SMEs account for most of the businesses in South-east Asia, and helping them to decarbonise can have major impact on the total ecosystem.

Solar and wind energy took over a decade to transform the renewable energy landscape; hydrogen could reach maturity over a shorter period given ambitious climate goals amid the global race to hit net-zero

site_title: Lack of legacy and succession planning can hurt businesses, family harmony
summary: High-net-worth individuals in Singapore are often unprepared for legacy and succession planning, which can lead to family harmony issues and business disruptions. A survey found 57% of Asia's HNW individuals have not planned for their succession, while only 40% of clients have planned or are formulating a plan. Insurance can be used to meet legacy planning needs, such as universal life insurance and participating whole life insurance, which can provide guaranteed payouts and equalize wealth distribution. Experts recommend working with professionals to navigate complex legacy planning strategies.

images.alt_text: Piggy bank with stacked coins. Pig with money savings on blue background.

site_title: Visa’s spending growth slows as consumers hit by inflation
summary: Visa's spending growth slowed to 10.5% in the fiscal fourth quarter, missing analysts' expectations of 11% due to inflation weighing on consumers. Despite this, shares gained 1.3% as profit exceeded expectations. Revenue jumped 23% and earnings reached $4.1 billion, while Visa shelled out more in rebates to persuade banks and retailers to route transactions over its network. CEO Al Kelly expressed confidence in Visa's long-term growth trajectory, but noted that a potential economic downturn could impact growth.

images.alt_text: Airwallex provides services including cross-border end-to-end payments and collection solutions for customers.

site_title: Why interest rates will peak long after inflation
summary: Central banks are unlikely to halt rate hikes despite early signs that inflation may have peaked, as persistent high inflation and ongoing supply chain challenges are expected to continue. The IMF's economic counsellor warns that central banks must keep a steady hand with interest rates to maintain credibility. Key factors contributing to this stance include heatwaves affecting grain harvests, higher energy costs, and a robust jobs market, which may not lead to a downward growth spiral. As a result, central banks are expected to continue raising rates, particularly in Asia, until inflation is brought under control.

images.alt_text: Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 1.4 per cent up at its highest level in nearly a week, with utilities, media and travel and leisure sectors leading the gains.

site_title: Disclosing remuneration of directors would ‘adversely impact’ business: Sakae Holdings
summary: Sakae Holdings, a Singapore-based restaurant operator, has stated that disclosing the exact remuneration of its directors, including chairman Douglas Foo and CEO Foo Lilian, would "adversely impact" its business due to competitive reasons. The company cited the sensitive nature of remuneration and the need to retain key personnel in the competitive food and beverage industry. Remuneration bands were disclosed in the 2022 annual report, ranging from S$500,000 to S$1 million for Foo Lilian and S$750,000 to under S$1 million for Douglas Foo.

images.alt_text: Sakae Sushi’s outlet in Junction 8, which closed in March 2022. Third-quarter revenue took a hit from the reduction in the number of physical stores.
Douglas Foo steps down from SMF presidency

site_title: Walmart to raise up to US$3b for Flipkart: Mint
summary: Walmart-backed Flipkart is considering raising up to $3 billion at a valuation of over $40 billion to expand its product range in India. The company may dilute around 7% of its value for the fundraising. Flipkart's current valuation is over $40 billion, and it has already raised $3.6 billion in funding last year. Walmart acquired a 77% stake in Flipkart for $16 billion in 2018 and had previously stated it could take the company public in four years. The fundraising plan is aimed at bringing in strategic investors and challenging rivals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A mobile phone showing an image of Indian online retailer Flipkart is seen in front of a Walmart Inc logo displayed in this illustration picture taken July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

Walmart's plan is to engage younger shoppers through its virtual universes, where they will find elements of video conferencing, gaming, social media and e-commerce, and entice them to move beyond avatars and shop at Walmart’s stores and website.  It is also about building brand equity.

Discount store T.J. Maxx, which is owned by TJX Cos Inc, is expecting to have some of the best branded content among its stocks, said TJX chief executive Scott Goldenberg. Retailers who can't sell off their stocks typically sell them to off-price retailers like TJX Cos.

site_title: Zara-owner Inditex says to sell Russian stores
summary: Spanish fashion retailer Inditex, owner of Zara, has reached an agreement to sell its stores in Russia to Daher group, a retail and real estate company. The deal will terminate Inditex's operations in Russia, where it had halted its business seven months ago following the Ukraine invasion. The sale will preserve a substantial number of jobs through lease transfers to Daher.

images.alt_text: epa10252402 Customers walk in front of a closed  Zara shop at a Mega mall in Moscow, Russia, 19 October 2022. The Spanish multinational clothing company Inditex group, owner of several fashion retailers including Zara, Pull&Bear, Bershka, Oysho and Massimo Dutti suspended business in Russia on 2022.  EPA-EFE/MAXIM SHIPENKOV
With online operations in about 200 countries, Zara’s products are already among the most resold brands on the web.

site_title: Microsoft tops profit estimates even as strong dollar hurts sales growth
summary: Microsoft reported its weakest quarterly revenue growth in five years, with sales rising 11% to $50.1 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. However, the company's revenue from Windows software sales plummeted 15% due to a strong US dollar and a global PC slump. Azure cloud services revenue decelerated to 35%, despite demand remaining strong for cloud services, including Office 365. Despite this, Microsoft's net income rose to $17.6 billion, and the company expects to maintain full-year revenue growth guidance despite economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Growing Western interest in Chinese games reflects a maturing of China’s game development industry.

site_title: India fines Google US$113m for 'unfair' payment system
summary: India's antitrust watchdog fined Google $113 million for "unfair" payment policies, forcing the company to allow app makers to use third-party billing systems and treat rival payment processing services on equal footing. The fine comes after a week of a similar penalty of $162 million for abusing its market dominance. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) ruled that Google's billing practices left developers without choice, restricting their ability to use alternative payment processors.

images.alt_text: “The CCI’s decision is a major setback for Indian consumers and businesses, opening serious security risks for Indians who trust Android’s security features, and raising the cost of mobile devices for Indians.” a Google spokesperson said.

site_title: Global Covid-19 cases will increase in coming months, but at a slower pace: report
summary: Global Covid-19 cases are projected to increase slowly to around 18.7 million daily infections by February, driven by students returning to schools and cold weather-related indoor gatherings. This represents a slower pace than last winter's peak daily average of 80 million cases in January 2022. Deaths are expected to average 2,748 people per day globally, a decrease from around 11 million in January. The increase is attributed to Omicron subvariants BQ.1 or BQ.1.1 in Germany, which may spread to Europe, and XBB in Singapore, which is more transmissible but less severe.

images.alt_text: All primary and middle schools in Haizhu district, where about 10 per cent of the city’s total population lives, will halt in-person lessons from Monday.
Wednesday’s case figure to be in the 11,000 to 12,000 range, similar to the last two Tuesdays.

site_title: US: Stocks rise again as pound rallies on new PM
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive day, with the S&P 500 gaining 1.6% amid hopes for moderation in Federal Reserve policy. The dollar slid as investors welcomed the prospect of slower rate hikes. The British pound rallied on news of former finance chief Rishi Sunak becoming Britain's prime minister, with bond yields falling. European stocks rose, with Frankfurt and Paris indices increasing 0.9% and 1.9%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Traders work during the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Wall Street in New York City on August 16, 2022. - Wall Street stocks were mostly lower early Tuesday following lackluster housing data and as Walmart results highlighted how inflation is altering consumer behavior. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Wall Street bankers see darker economic outlook, political risks
summary: Wall Street bankers predict a darker economic outlook, with recession in the US and Europe increasingly likely. Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon warned that economic conditions will "tighten meaningfully" and the Fed may raise interest rates further. Geopolitical risks, including the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, are also seen as a major concern. Many economists predict a US recession within the next 12 months, while the European energy crisis is expected to lead to an unprecedented surge in inflation.

images.alt_text: The steepest downturn came in manufacturing, especially energy-intensive sectors like chemicals and plastics. Services also shrank at a faster rate as consumers struggle with the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: UPS beats profit estimates on higher parcel delivery prices
summary: UPS reported a stronger-than-expected quarterly adjusted profit, beating estimates, as higher delivery prices and cost controls offset softening e-commerce demand. The company reaffirmed its full-year forecast, citing a dynamic macro environment. UPS shares rose 2.9% to $172.43, while rival FedEx last month pulled its annual forecast. The company expects volume in the holiday season to soften due to package limit agreements with Amazon, but expects busier days leading up to Christmas.

site_title: Oil prices rise on weaker dollar, supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures increasing 26 cents to US$93.52 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 74 cents to US$85.32. The price gains were attributed to a weaker US dollar and supply concerns highlighted by Saudi Arabia's energy minister, who stated that energy stockpiles are being used to manipulate markets. However, uncertain economic activity in the US and China limited the gains, with the US Federal Reserve potentially raising interest rates if it doesn't see changes in behavior.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for December delivery settled at US$93.26 a barrel, down 24 cents, 0.3 per cent, after rising 2 per cent last week.

site_title: Italy’s new PM Meloni snipes at ECB in maiden speech
summary: Italy's new Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni criticized the European Central Bank (ECB) for its recent interest rate hikes, which she said are hurting high-debt countries like Italy. The ECB has raised interest rates by half a percentage point in July and 75 basis points in September, with another expected hike on Thursday. Meloni stated that these decisions have created difficulties for countries with high public debt, citing Italy's debt of 150% of national output. The comments come as inflation in Italy runs at almost five times its 2% reference ceiling.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits over one-month high as earnings offset economic gloom
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.4% to its highest level since September 20, driven by strong earnings reports from real-estate, technology, and financial sectors. UBS, SAP, and Logitech International led gains after beating market expectations. Despite worries about a European recession, the quarterly updates lifted sentiment. Earnings from tech giants Microsoft, Alphabet, and Apple will set the tone on Wall Street this week, with analysts expecting a slowdown in macroeconomic momentum.

site_title: Saudi energy minister warns against depleting crude buffers
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz Salman, warned against depleting crude buffers, citing concerns that major importers are using emergency stocks to manipulate markets. The OPEC+ decision to cut production, announced last week, has been criticized by the US, with President Joe Biden saying there would be "consequences" for Saudi Arabia. Prince Abdulaziz defended the move, saying it was justified by a weak economic outlook and the need to preserve spare buffers, amid looming potential supply shortages and global inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Oil is still facing headwinds from a stronger dollar and fears that a slowdown will sap energy demand.

site_title: SIA to redeem mandatory convertible bonds for S$3.86b
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will redeem its S$3.86 billion 10-year mandatory convertible bonds at a 110.408% redemption rate, with payouts made on Dec 8, 2022. This move is seen as a result of the airline's improved balance sheet following the resumption of air travel since the end of last year. The redemption will be funded by existing cash reserves, supporting the airline's balance sheet recalibration as it recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: SIA was asked by Sias how it manages the interests of its equity holders versus those of its MCB holders
A Singapore Airlines plane plies along the tarmac of Changi International Airport in Singapore on May 13, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia’s Yinson Green Technologies to expand EV charging business to Singapore
summary: Malaysia's Yinson Green Technologies plans to expand its electric vehicle (EV) charging business to Singapore, following the country's government efforts to encourage EV adoption. The company, which operates the largest EV charging network in Malaysia, aims to establish a network of charging hubs and stations in Singapore, with a target of fast-charging facilities offering 200 kilowatts of power. YGT's expansion comes as Singapore aims to have 60,000 charging points islandwide by 2030, and the company sees opportunities to tap into the growing demand for EVs in the region.

images.alt_text: Leading the charge is Tesla, where chief executive Elon Musk has outlined an audacious plan to build 20 million EVs in 2030, requiring an estimated 3 terawatt-hours of batteries.

ships / ST20210823_202127136955 / Alphonsus Chern //

Hong Kong bulk carrier Cherry Point bunkering in Singapore waters 23 August 2021.

site_title: Fed is losing billions, wiping out profits that funded spending
summary: The US Federal Reserve is facing significant losses due to high inflation and aggressive interest-rate hikes, with the potential to wipe out profits that funded spending. The bond market is experiencing its worst selloff in a generation, resulting in paper losses on massive holdings accumulated during the rescue efforts in recent years. This could lead to a shift in countries, including the US, where central banks are no longer significant contributors to government revenues, and may fuel criticism of monetary policymakers' independence.

site_title: Coca-Cola beats profit estimates, raises full-year guidance
summary: Coca-Cola surpassed profit estimates in the third quarter, with organic revenue increasing 16% due to value-conscious products amid inflation. The company raised its full-year guidance to 14-15% organic revenue growth, driven by bundling products for inflation-wary consumers. This beat Bloomberg's consensus estimate of 9.8% growth. The company also reported strong results from its ready-to-drink alcohol beverages and maintained demand despite freight costs remaining high in the US.

site_title: US home price growth slows in August, surveys show
summary: US home prices showed a slowdown in August, with the S&P CoreLogic Case Shiller national home price index dropping 0.9% on a seasonally adjusted basis. This marked the first decline in monthly house prices since late 2018. Home prices increased 13.0% on a year-over-year basis, down from July's rise of 15.6%. The decline is attributed to surging mortgage rates and decreased demand for housing, as the Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: Broker Hamptons International has warned that home prices are likely to decline if the Bank of England’s base rate exceeds 2.5 per cent. It’s already at 2.25 per cent, and expected to rise to at least 3 per cent early next month

site_title: Singapore eyes hydrogen in net-zero quest
summary: Singapore aims to power up to half of its power sector with low-carbon hydrogen by 2050, in line with its net-zero emissions goal. The city-state joins 26 countries with national plans for low-emission hydrogen, and its Energy 2050 Committee Report suggests a possible range of 10-60% hydrogen in the energy mix. Despite limited commercial opportunities and a nascent stage of development for hydrogen technologies, Singapore's move is part of the global push to decarbonize and hit net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.
SMEs account for most of the businesses in South-east Asia, and helping them to decarbonise can have major impact on the total ecosystem.

site_title: Chinese markets to remain shaky as investors study Xi’s leadership reshuffle
summary: Chinese markets may remain volatile in the coming weeks as investors study the new leadership under President Xi Jinping, who was voted in for an unprecedented third term and unveiled a top governing body stacked with his loyalists. Despite a slight recovery on Tuesday, macroeconomic and political concerns could cloud investors' decisions over Chinese stocks. A property market slump and muted economic growth also weigh on investors' confidence in China, with Chinese firms' US dollar-denominated bonds selling off. The US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates is expected to influence market movements.

images.alt_text: Mobility statistics have worsened in October despite falling local coronavirus cases, suggesting Covid-19 preventive measures, or fear of those measures, are still stifling economic activity.
Founders of major Chinese tech firms including Alibaba have exited their leadership roles.

China will encourage foreign enterprises to invest in high-tech equipment and components, according to a statement published on the website of National Development and Reform Commission, China’s planning agency.

site_title: US consumer confidence ebbs in October; inflation expectations rise
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 102.5 in October, down from 107.8 in September, amid rising concerns about inflation and a possible recession. 12-month inflation expectations rose to 7.0%, while the present situation index and expectations index declined sharply. The decline suggests the risks of a downturn could be rising, with inflationary pressures posing strong headwinds to consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Shoppers cross 34th Street in New York, U.S., on Monday, Dec. 27, 2021. U.S. holiday sales jumped 8.5% from last year as consumers spent more money on clothes, jewelry and electronics, a report from Mastercard SpendingPulse showed. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: Can PM Sunak bring stability to Britain at last?
summary: Rishi Sunak, Britain's youngest prime minister in over 200 years, has taken office, vowing to restore stability to the country and his Conservative party. He faces significant economic hurdles, including a £40 billion budget deficit, and has issued a warning to Tory MPs to unite or face consequences. Sunak plans to appoint a new Cabinet, led by Chancellor Jeremy Hunt, and has vowed to prioritize economic stability and confidence. His administration must also navigate Brexit negotiations with the EU, particularly the Northern Ireland Protocol, to avoid a trade war.

images.alt_text: Sterling edged towards this month’s highs, up 0.4 per cent at US$1.1330 by 1112 GMT, but currency strategists expect the pound to remin under pressure.
The stubborn rise in mortgage costs, which is sharply slowing demand in the property market, is one of the headaches Rishi Sunak will inherit upon replacing Liz Truss as UK prime minister.
The 42-year-old incoming UK prime minister spent the bulk of his private sector days working for hedge funds.

site_title: Moody’s cuts Fosun International’s rating, revises outlook to ‘negative’
summary: Moody's downgraded Fosun International's rating to B2 from B1 and revised its outlook to 'negative' due to insufficient cash to cover short-term debt maturing in 12 months. The downgrade follows divestment of assets and a significant decline in market value of Fosun's key holdings. Moody's expects Fosun to face difficulties in refinancing its sizable short-term debt in public bond markets.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts 3.5% rise in Q2 DPU to S$0.02248
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 3.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02248 for the second quarter, driven by higher revenue from existing properties and accretive acquisitions. Gross revenue rose 11.4% to S$183.9 million, while net property income increased 10.8% to S$160 million. Despite a 23.2% decline in unit price, MLT's portfolio occupancy remained resilient at 96.4%. The trust's aggregate leverage ratio improved to 37% and debt outstanding decreased by S$96 million.

images.alt_text: The Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road on 26 July 2019.

site_title: GM’s strong Q3 results ease investor fears of slowdown
summary: General Motors (GM) reported a strong third quarter, beating analysts' estimates with a net income of US$3.3 billion and revenue of US$41.9 billion. The company reaffirmed its full-year guidance and cited strong North American truck sales and pricing as key drivers. GM's shares jumped over 5% in premarket trading. The automaker's confidence in the short-term environment and lack of direct impact from a US economic slowdown eased investor fears of a global recession.

site_title: Hydrogen the key puzzle piece for Singapore’s decarbonisation
summary: Singapore aims to decarbonize its power sector by 2050, with hydrogen fuel being a key puzzle piece. The country currently relies on natural gas for 95% of its energy needs, but hydrogen offers a cleaner alternative. To achieve its goal, Singapore will need to invest in green hydrogen production and importation, as it lacks sufficient renewable energy capacity. The country is exploring various transport methods, including liquefied and liquid organic hydrogen carriers, and is positioning itself to lead a regional hydrogen economy in Asean, with partnerships with Japan and other importing nations.

images.alt_text: Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.
Today, the decreasing costs of renewable energy generation, coupled with better efficiency and storage solutions, is making clean energy more accessible than ever.

site_title: Rishi Sunak pledges to fix Britain’s many problems
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has pledged to fix Britain's economic crisis and restore trust in government after becoming the country's third prime minister in two months. Sunak, 42, has vowed to slash spending to plug a $45 billion hole in public finances, despite facing growing calls for an election if he moves too far from his party's 2019 policy manifesto. Sunak has warned his colleagues of an "existential crisis" if they fail to help steer the country through surging inflation and record energy bills.

images.alt_text: The 42-year-old incoming UK prime minister spent the bulk of his private sector days working for hedge funds.

site_title: British sci-fi series ‘Doctor Who’ set to premiere globally on Disney+
summary: Disney+ to exclusively stream British sci-fi series 'Doctor Who' globally, starting in late 2023. The collaboration between BBC and Disney Branded Television will allow Disney to stream the series outside the UK and Ireland, while BBC will continue to stream it exclusively for UK audiences. Ncuti Gatwa will replace Jodie Whittaker as the Doctor, with David Tennant set to play the 14th Doctor for three specials before Gatwa takes over, coinciding with the 60th anniversary of the series.

site_title: Private dealmaking set to rise, widening public markets gap
summary: Private capital investors expect to increase their dealmaking globally in the coming months, widening the gap with moribund public markets. Two-thirds of 30 investment firms surveyed by Numis Securities anticipate an increase in private companies raising capital, despite nine in ten expecting worse macroeconomic conditions. Even large startups are turning to deep private capital pools, with some firms swallowing hefty markdowns due to stock market volatility. Investors now prioritize profitability, expecting valuations to stabilize and market conditions to become attractive, but dealmaking levels are unlikely to return to last year's record levels.

images.alt_text: A key trend amid record dealmaking is the accelerating shift to ESG investing.

site_title: 2,994 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, figure set to pass 10,000 after long weekend
summary: Singapore reported 2,994 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, October 25, the lowest figure on a Tuesday in October. Experts attribute the lower number to Deepavali on Monday, causing people to delay medical visits. Wednesday's case figure is expected to be in the 11,000 to 12,000 range, similar to previous Tuesdays. The ongoing XBB sub-variant may peak earlier than mid-November, according to Health Minister Ong Ye Kung. The country has recorded 2,070,784 Covid-19 cases and 1,666 deaths.

images.alt_text: Exterior facade of the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID), taken on Sept 7, 2021.
There are 661 Covid-19 patients currently being hospitalised and of these, 58 patients need oxygen supplementation and 14 are in the Intensive Care Unit.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq rise at open amid mixed earnings reports
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Tuesday, October 25, 2022, rising 2.10 and 44.35 points respectively, amidst mixed earnings reports. Microsoft and Alphabet rose ahead of their results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 35.97 points, or 0.11%, to 31,463.65.

site_title: China’s net gold imports via Hong Kong fall 50% in September
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong fell 50% in September to 33.896 tonnes, the lowest since May. Total gold imports dropped 48% to 37.271 tonnes. Analysts attribute the drop to logistical issues caused by China's zero-Covid policy. Chinese dealers sold gold at elevated premiums, with prices ranging between $18 and $45 an ounce above global benchmark spot prices, in an effort to control the yuan's value. The data may not provide a complete picture, as gold is also imported via Shanghai and Beijing.

site_title: Value could be emerging for some S-Reits after the sell-off
summary: At least half of Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are trading at or near 52-week lows amid a massive sell-off, with 12 S-Reits hitting their lows last Friday. A dozen more are close to their 12-month troughs. Only four S-Reits, Elite Commercial Trust, Dasin Retail Trust, EC World Reit, and BHG Retail Reit, remain above their 52-week lows, with all but four closing within 10% of their lows.

images.alt_text: Exterior facade of Raffles City, the side where Robinsons formerly used to be.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 5.3% in September, while headline inflation remained steady at 7.5%. The country's energy regulator will introduce new rules to ensure secure and sufficient gas supply and power generation. Singapore aims to commit to net-zero emissions by 2050, with accelerated targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The government also announced plans to explore ammonia-fuelled power and develop hydrogen infrastructure.

site_title: Israel to spend millions on Einstein museum
summary: The Israeli government has allocated approximately $18 million to build a museum on the Hebrew University's Givat Ram campus in Jerusalem to house the world's largest collection of Albert Einstein documents. The museum will feature the entire Einstein archive, with 85,000 items, and serve as an innovative space for scientific and technological education. Einstein's contributions to science, including his theories of relativity and quantum mechanics, will be showcased through cutting-edge exhibitions and demonstrations. The museum is expected to highlight Einstein's impact on our lives today and his involvement in key historical moments during his lifetime.

images.alt_text: A James Webb Space Telescope photo of the Carina Nebula, provided by NASA, showing the earliest stages of star formation.

site_title: Apple is cutting back production of iPhone 14 Plus due to weak demand: TrendForce
summary: Apple is cutting back production of the iPhone 14 Plus due to weak demand, while increasing production of the more expensive iPhone 14 Pro series, which now accounts for 60% of total output, up from the initially planned 50%. The trend suggests the mid-range model is not selling as well as expected, with production potentially rising to 65% of total output in the future.

site_title: Keppel Reit’s distributable income up 3.4% over first 3 quarters of 2022
summary: Keppel Reit's distributable income grew 3.4% year-over-year to S$165.4 million over the first three quarters of 2022. The increase was driven by the acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower and adjustments in income tax expense. To celebrate its 20th anniversary in 2026, the Reit will distribute an additional S$100 million from its accumulated capital gains. The Reit's assets under management increased to approximately S$9 billion, with over 78% of assets in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Keppel REIT reported a 1 per cent jump in DPU driven by contribution from newly acquired Keppel Bay Tower

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure to explore green ammonia and renewable energy opportunities with Greenko
summary: Keppel Infrastructure is partnering with Greenko to explore green ammonia and renewable energy opportunities. The collaboration aims to develop a 250,000-tonne per year green ammonia production facility and identify 1.3-gigawatt solar and wind energy projects to power it. The partnership supports India's goal to manufacture five million tonnes of green hydrogen per annum by 2030 and aims to reduce carbon emissions globally. The collaboration is expected to have no material impact on Keppel's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: KIT received its first distribution from Aramco Gas Pipeline Company, which helped to boost distributable income for 3Q 2022.

site_title: EU to propose banks offer mandatory ‘instant payments’ in euros
summary: The European Union is set to propose new rules requiring banks in the eurozone to offer "instant payments" in euros 24/7, with the goal of modernizing payments to transfer money in seconds. The new rules aim to increase competition and promote pan-European market-based payments solutions, as the US dominates cross-border retail payments. Currently, only 11% of euro credit transfers are in the form of instant payments, and the draft law sets a mandatory deadline for banks to comply, with longer deadlines for banks outside the euro area.

site_title: China stocks sell-off a buying moment, says JP Morgan strategist
summary: JP Morgan strategist Marko Kolanovic views China's stock sell-off as a buying opportunity due to an expected growth recovery, gradual COVID reopening, and monetary and fiscal stimulus. He expects a strong US dollar to boost international markets like Japan, the eurozone, and the UK's FTSE 100. Kolanovic, who has been a vocal bull this year, cut his 2023 earnings-per-share estimates for the S&P 500 Index to flat year-over-year, citing a more challenging earnings backdrop.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index closed down by 0.10 per cent, or 15.10 points, to 15,165.59, after tanking more than six per cent on Monday.

site_title: Sterling rises as Sunak becomes PM while euro steadies
summary: Sterling rose 0.4% to US$1.1330, near this month's highs, after Rishi Sunak became Britain's prime minister, supporting improved risk sentiment. The euro steadied ahead of the European Central Bank's rate hike on Thursday. The US dollar edged up but remained near its weakest level in October amid slowing US economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds British pound banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China regulator highlights resilience of economy, yuan’s strengthening trend
summary: China's banking regulator reassured the markets that the country's economy is resilient and the yuan's strengthening trend will continue. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) stated that financial risks are being contained and the financial system is stable. The regulator also pledged to strengthen efforts to avoid risks and guarantee financial stability. Despite a sell-off in Chinese assets and a near 15-year low for the onshore yuan, the CBIRC emphasized that the long-term trend of a strengthening yuan will not change, citing the country's balance of payments surplus and foreign investment net assets.

images.alt_text: Mall in Beijing. Inflation in China is more muted than in the US or UK but the zero-Covid policy is a challenge
Mobility statistics have worsened in October despite falling local coronavirus cases, suggesting Covid-19 preventive measures, or fear of those measures, are still stifling economic activity.

China will encourage foreign enterprises to invest in high-tech equipment and components, according to a statement published on the website of National Development and Reform Commission, China’s planning agency.

site_title: UBS exhausts inventory of Tencent long DLCs following China’s overnight slump
summary: UBS, the designated market maker for Tencent's 5xLongUB241231 DLC, has sold all its inventory following a 11% decline in Tencent's Hong Kong-listed shares, alongside other China-focused tech companies. The move comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping secured an unprecedented third term, sparking market concerns. UBS will provide a continuous bid while making intermittent offers on the certificates until further notice, with analysts predicting volatility and potential opportunities in the Chinese market for long-term investors, but cautioning those without stomach or holding power to stay away.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping delivers a report to the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Oct 16.

site_title: Adidas to end Kanye West partnership after controversies
summary: Adidas is ending its partnership with Kanye West, formerly known as Ye, due to his recent offensive behavior and comments that violate the company's values. The partnership, which has accounted for 8% of Adidas's total sales, will end production of Yeezy-branded products and stop payments to Ye and his companies. Adidas will take a 250-million-euro hit to net income in the current fiscal year. This decision follows weeks of deliberations and comes as Adidas joins Gap Inc and Kering's Balenciaga fashion label in severing ties with Ye, amid growing criticism and boycott calls.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Kanye West, now known as Ye, in New York, Sept. 12 2022. Antisemitic outbursts and provocations by the artist have raised questions about how much offensive behavior companies are willing to tolerate from a proven moneymaker. (Nina Westervelt/The New York Times)

site_title: UK mortgage rates hover near 14-year highs as Sunak takes reins
summary: UK mortgage rates hover near 14-year highs, averaging 6.54% for a two-year fixed-rate loan and 6.41% for a five-year fixed-rate deal, according to Moneyfacts Group. This rise is sharply slowing demand in the property market, a challenge Rishi Sunak will face as the new UK prime minister. Mortgage costs are also putting extra strain on borrowers, on top of inflation running at a 40-year high.

site_title: Japan likely spent around 900 billion yen for Oct 24 suspected FX intervention
summary: Japan likely spent up to 900 billion yen (US$6 billion) on its second straight day of suspected currency intervention on October 24, bringing the total to as much as 9.2 trillion yen since last month. The intervention aimed to combat "intolerable and speculative" yen-selling, but its impact has been short-lived. Japan's central bank has intervened with a total of 2.8 trillion yen in its first intervention since 1998 and an estimated 5.4 trillion to 5.5 trillion yen last Friday, in an effort to stabilize the yen's value.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.01 points to 1,444.41. 2.262 billion lots worth RM1.763 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 445 to 420.

site_title: Violet Oon and family file suits to take control of eponymous restaurants
summary: Chef Violet Oon and her children are seeking to take control of their restaurants through a winding-up case against their 50-per-cent shareholder, Group MMM. The family, holding 20 per cent of Violet Oon Inc, filed the application in the High Court on October 28. Despite the proceedings, the family assures customers that the restaurants will continue to provide high-quality service and authentic culinary experiences. Group MMM, owned by Manoj M Murjani, disagrees with the allegations and plans to defend its legal rights.

images.alt_text: Lena Sim (second from right), has been declared bankrupt following a suit against her on a loan amount of US$5 million.

site_title: GE cuts annual forecast, posts 19% drop in adjusted profit
summary: General Electric cut its annual forecast, citing a 19% drop in adjusted quarterly profit and supply snarls, inflationary pressures, and weakness in its renewable energy business. The company lowered its full-year adjusted profit forecast to $2.40-$2.80 per share, down from $2.80-$3.50. Shares fell 7.3% and free cash flow dropped 11% to $1.19 billion in the third quarter. GE is struggling with supply-chain bottlenecks and poor results in its renewable energy business, which was hit by policy uncertainty following the expiry of renewable electricity production tax credits.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of U.S. conglomerate General Electric is pictured at the site of the company's energy branch in Belfort, France, February 5, 2019. REUTERS/Vincent Kessler/File Photo

site_title: We may have only a few months to prevent the next pandemic
summary: A growing number of global health emergencies, including Ebola and monkeypox outbreaks, have highlighted the need for better pandemic preparedness. Craig Spencer, an emergency medicine physician, warns that the window to act is closing, with only a few months to lay the groundwork for the next pandemic threat. Key areas requiring immediate attention and investment include disease surveillance, strengthening the global healthcare workforce, and ensuring equitable access to treatments and vaccines. The World Health Organization estimates that 15 million more health workers are needed by 2030, and a massive scaling up of disease surveillance is also required.

images.alt_text: WHO says while cases are falling in parts of the world, countries still need to maintain their vigilance and push to get their most vulnerable populations vaccinated.

site_title: Nowhere to hide: Are alternative investments the answer?
summary: Alternative investments, such as private equity and hedge funds, may provide diversification benefits and improve risk-adjusted returns in a portfolio. However, these assets come with illiquidity and high fees, and investors should be cautious of the "J-curve" effect and potential losses. Private equity has historically delivered strong returns with lower volatility, but its performance can be harder to interpret due to lack of transparency. Hedge funds have lagged equity market performance in the past but can outperform in volatile markets. Investors should conduct thorough due diligence and diversify their exposure to different strategies and vintages to mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: Blackstone invests in everything from apartments to offices to warehouses to biotech businesses to power transmission projects.

site_title: Climate inaction risks damaging Philippines growth: World Bank
summary: The World Bank warns that the Philippines' inability to address climate change will risk damaging its growth, with temperatures expected to rise and rainfall becoming more intense. This could result in a 13.6% loss of economic output by 2040, disproportionately affecting the country's poorest households. The report suggests that adopting measures such as renewable energy, energy efficiency, and smart city development could reduce economic losses from climate change by two-thirds.

site_title: Hedge funds get their first prime minister in UK’s Rishi Sunak
summary: Rishi Sunak, the 42-year-old incoming UK prime minister, has a background in working for hedge funds, where he likely learned the art of using the markets to push for change. His private sector experience may have contributed to his success in winning the prime ministerial job, which has brought calm to the UK bond markets.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak’s top priority is solving the economic crisis, with inflation exceeding 10 per cent, the highest in any G7 country, owing to soaring energy tariffs and food prices.

site_title: Australia faces swelling debt, deficits even as spending curbed
summary: Australia's debt and deficits are expected to widen, reaching 23% of GDP this fiscal year and 28.5% in 2025-26, despite Treasurer Jim Chalmers' efforts to curb spending. The government's budget deficit will increase from 1.5% to 2% of GDP, driven by high commodity prices and an ultra-tight labor market. Chalmers aims to establish the Labor government's fiscal credibility by avoiding further fueling inflation, contrasting with the former UK administration's mini-budget.

images.alt_text: Sky-rocketing rents in one of the world’s frothiest housing markets mean many Australians are struggling to find somewhere suitable to live.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses a day after rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.10% on Tuesday, following a 6.12% drop on Monday, amid concerns over China's economy after Xi Jinping's power consolidation. The Hang Seng Index fell to 15,165.59. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 1.27 points and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.46%. The losses are linked to the economic outlook following Xi's tightened grip on power.

site_title: Indonesia expects new gas supply contract with Singapore next week: minister
summary: Indonesia is set to sign a new long-term contract next week to supply Singapore with piped natural gas via the Grissik-Batam-Singapore Pipeline. The 20-year term contract is due to expire next year, and some details are still being ironed out. Gas supplies to Singapore commenced in 2003, and the new contract will ensure a stable source of natural gas for the island nation.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on first trading day of the week; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 2,984.15, driven by a rally in key global markets amid expectations of a Federal Reserve pivot. The local stock market shrugged off concerns over Singapore's core inflation rising to 5.3% in September. Top gainers included Jardine Cycle & Carriage, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, with Sembcorp Marine being the most heavily traded counter.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index closed down by 0.10 per cent, or 15.10 points, to 15,165.59, after tanking more than six per cent on Monday.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index opened flat at 7,012.85 points.

site_title: Inflation, regulation and depreciation: Is it the right time to invest in Chinese equities?
summary: China's inflation rate remains lower than in the US and UK, at 2-3%, but the zero-Covid policy poses a challenge. To invest in Chinese equities, focus on high-quality companies that can pass on higher production costs to customers, taking a long-term approach. This approach can help mitigate the impact of rising raw material prices and inflation.

site_title: Xi’s third term leaves the tech industry cold
summary: Chinese tech sector executives are left disappointed after Xi Jinping secured a third term as leader, stacking his leadership ranks with loyalists. None of the seven members of the Politburo's Standing Committee can be considered tech cheerleaders, and the industry faces continued turmoil due to strict regulations. The lack of clarity on the sector's future has led to a rush for exits among major companies, including Alibaba, ByteDance, JD.com, and Pinduoduo. The industry's uncertainty has also affected technology stocks, which plummeted on Monday in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: A bottle of Moutai Liquor on display in a showroom at Moutai Liquor Culture centre in Renhuai, Guizhou province, China; June 2017.

An index tracking the nation’s shares listed in Hong Kong sank more than after any Communist Party congress since its inception 1994 and foreigners sold a record amount of stocks via trading links in the city.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB ups target price on Raffles Medical Group amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB has upgraded its target price for Raffles Medical Group to S$1.60 from S$1.50, citing the company's role in supporting Singapore's public health efforts amid the recent surge in Covid-19 cases. Analyst Tay Wee Kuang expects increased demand for Covid-19-related services and a higher market share for the company. The new target price is based on a 15 times EV/Ebitda valuation, representing a lower trading band over the past two years.

images.alt_text: The group also announced the resignation of chief executive Wong Chiang Yin, who is leaving to pursue personal interests.
Raffles Medical could be a key beneficiary as emergency cases spillover from public hospitals, said DBS analyst Rachel Tan.

site_title: Philippines’ central bank governor favours matching Fed hike
summary: Philippines' central bank governor Felipe Medalla expressed support for matching the US Federal Reserve's (Fed) upcoming 75 basis-point rate hike to support the peso. Medalla stated that the BSP can afford to be more aggressive in policy tightening and that the economy is strong enough to absorb the impact of higher rates. The BSP's penultimate meeting will be on November 17, coinciding with the Fed's policy review on November 2. Medalla's comments indicate a possible alignment with the Fed's monetary policy, which aims to tame inflation.

site_title: Apple issues new App Store rules for crypto and NFT payments
summary: Apple has updated its App Store guidelines to clarify its policy on cryptocurrency trading and non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The company allows crypto exchanges and trading apps with regional licenses, but requires NFT-related apps to use Apple's in-app purchase system. This means NFT holders can no longer unlock features or functionality within the app, potentially affecting some projects that use tokens as membership cards. Apple still allows users to display and share their NFT collections.

images.alt_text: Apple’s push into streaming in recent years is part of a broader effort to generate more revenue from services.

site_title: Smoothing the way to decarbonisation
summary: Shipping industry efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions are shifting focus to hull maintenance, with effective antifouling coatings crucial for minimizing drag and fuel consumption. A new IMO report highlights the significant impact of biofouling on ship efficiency, with a thin layer of slime potentially increasing GHG emissions by 25-30%. The report emphasizes the importance of biofouling management measures to support anti-fouling coatings and reduce fuel consumption. As the shipping industry transitions to low-carbon fuels, maintaining a clean hull is seen as a vital component in achieving emissions reductions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese container ship "Cosco Shipping Aries" is unloaded at a loading terminal in the port of Hamburg Germany July 27, 2018. Picture taken July 27,2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: UK financial watchdog proposes rules to stamp out 'greenwashing'
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority proposed new rules in 2023 to combat "greenwashing" in environmentally friendly investments. The rules aim to stop consumers from being misled by exaggerated claims and ensure that products actually meet their ESG credentials. The measures include sustainability labels, restrictions on using terms like ESG and "green," and a more general anti-greenwashing rule. The public consultation on the proposals is open until January 2023, with the final rules set to be finalized by the end of the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: More than ever, we need the companies making progress on sustainability to inspire their peers - this is impossible if progress is happening in silence, says Renat Heuberger, CEO of South Pole. (PHOTO SOUTH POLE)

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mostly rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on October 25, 2022, driven by earnings reactions. London's FTSE 100 index opened flat, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices gained 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. Meanwhile, traders awaited an address from Britain's new Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who was expected to provide stability for the pound. The markets will continue to watch US-EU trade talks and the impact of tariffs.

site_title: Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai found guilty of fraud
summary: Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai was found guilty of two counts of fraud for making false statements to a landlord about business activities, violating a special-purpose lease. Lai, 74, had pleaded not guilty and is already serving 20 months in prison for his role in unauthorized assemblies during 2019 protests. The conviction adds to his mounting cases, which have raised concerns about press freedom in the city. Lai faces additional charges under the national security law, including a possible life sentence for collusion.

site_title: Singapore core inflation climbs to 5.3% in September; headline inflation steady at 7.5%
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 5.3% in September, while headline inflation remained steady at 7.5%, according to the Department of Statistics. Food inflation increased to 6.9%, driven by higher prices for services and retail goods. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their full-year inflation forecasts, with core inflation expected to average 4% and headline inflation at 6%. Economists predict that core inflation will stay elevated in the next few quarters before moderating in the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: DBS and SMU said in the Monday (Oct 17) report that consumers attribute Singapore's economic growth and inflation rate to global uncertainty and economic disruptions, such as the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict and supply chain disruptions.
People shopping for bread and biscuits at Vivocity, Harbourfront on March 10, 2022.

site_title: Five ways to protect your portfolio in a recession
summary: Investors can protect their portfolios during a recession by taking strategic steps. Companies with low or no debt, such as Vicom, Haw Par Corporation, and HRNetGroup, can withstand rising interest rates and continue to pay healthy dividends. Blue-chip stalwarts like DBS Group, Singapore Exchange, and Singapore Technologies Engineering can also weather the storm. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) with strong sponsors and quality assets, such as Mapletree Logistics Trust and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, can benefit from rising interest rates. Additionally, dividend kings like Procter & Gamble, PepsiCo, and Johnson & Johnson can provide a stable source of income. By trimming the weak businesses and redeploying capital, investors can better position their portfolios for a recession.

images.alt_text: Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as China caution offsets Wall Street boost
summary: South Korea's Kospi index ended flat on Tuesday, down 1.09 points or 0.05% at 2,235.07, as investors' cautiousness over Chinese market volatility offset overnight Wall Street gains. The Korean won strengthened, while bond yields dropped following the finance minister's remarks on cutting bond issuance. Heavyweights like Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and LG Energy Solution rose, but only 335 shares rose out of 932 total traded issues. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 78.7 billion won.

images.alt_text: Among heavyweights, technology giant Samsung Electronics rose 2.50 per cent and peer SK Hynix gained 1.88 per cent, while battery maker LG Energy Solution advanced 1.40 per cent.

site_title: HSBC elevates Elhedery to CFO in surprise CEO-in-waiting move
summary: HSBC named Georges Elhedery as its new chief financial officer, elevating him to the position in a surprise move that puts him in line to succeed CEO Noel Quinn. The change comes after Elhedery took a six-month sabbatical and follows a 42% slide in third quarter profit due to loan losses and charges from the sale of its French business. Elhedery's elevation is seen as a strategic move, with Quinn stating that there is no change in strategy, but rather a shift in succession options.

images.alt_text: HSBC said pre-tax profit fell by US$2.3 billion to US$3.1 billion while reported revenue dipped 3 per cent to US$11.6 billion.

site_title: China to promote foreign investment in manufacturing
summary: China plans to promote foreign investment in manufacturing industries, focusing on high-tech equipment and components. This move comes after President Xi Jinping's call to "win the battle" in core technologies. The country will also strengthen financial support for foreign enterprises, including listing on China's stock markets and facilitating the entry and exit of multinational companies' executives and their families. This initiative aims to boost China's economy, which grew 3.9% in the September quarter despite challenges from the global economic downturn and Covid-19-related curbs.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher on tech, banking boost; all eyes on annual budget
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% to close at 6,798.6, driven by gains in technology and financial stocks amid hopes of a softer US Federal Reserve tone. Investors await the annual budget, which is expected to focus on easing the cost-of-living crisis without fueling inflation. Tech stocks, including Block, rose 0.2%, while financials rose 1% with the "Big Four" banks gaining between 0.1 and 1.3%. The country's inflation print on Wednesday is also expected to be closely watched.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6 per cent to 6,818 by 2349 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: The coming Republican Congress: Will Trumpists set the tone?
summary: Republicans are gaining electoral momentum in the upcoming midterm elections, with Americans most concerned about inflation and economic issues. Opinion polls indicate Republicans are ahead, despite some voters initially opposing the decision to overturn abortion rights and President Joe Biden's 2020 election. The issue of inflation, particularly at the pump, has become the dominant concern, potentially influencing independent voters.

images.alt_text: US allies are keenly aware that the empowerment of Trump allies could have serious economic consequences, given that the former president imposed tariffs on the European Union and launched a trade war with China that had global ripple effects.
Wesley Hunt (left), a Republican who is likely to win his House race, during a campaign event in Cibolo, Texas., April 13, 2022.
Prior research found that people are less likely to vote when polling places are further away, when polling stations’ opening hours are limited, and even when it rains.

site_title: Singapore to explore ammonia-fuelled power, develop hydrogen infrastructure: MTI
summary: Singapore will launch initiatives to prepare for hydrogen deployment, including a small-scale commercial project on ammonia-fuelled power generation and the development of a hydrogen supply chain in Asia. The country aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, with hydrogen emerging as a top pick to diversify the power mix. The government will also support workforce training and develop land and infrastructure needed to import, store, and transform hydrogen into power.

images.alt_text: Carbon capture and storage technology, which captures carbon dioxide from a range of sources and stores it underground, usually in depleted oil or gas reservoirs, has proved a controversial technology.
Today, the decreasing costs of renewable energy generation, coupled with better efficiency and storage solutions, is making clean energy more accessible than ever.
Singapore’s Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Australia’s Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell signed the GEA in the presence of both prime ministers.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
A smart energy meter, used to monitor gas and electricity use, is pictured in a home in London. The world is currently facing its most severe energy crisis since the 1970s.

site_title: WhatsApp restored after outage, says Meta
summary: Meta announced that it has fixed an issue with its messaging service WhatsApp, which experienced an outage affecting users in Europe, Asia, and the UK. Over 68,000 users reported problems, with 19,000 in Singapore and 15,000 in South Africa. The outage occurred during the festive season in India, where WhatsApp is its largest market. Meta apologized for the inconvenience and attributed the issue to being "fixed." The outage comes after a similar incident in October, which impacted trading of assets and led to traders switching to alternative platforms.

images.alt_text: Wall Street institutions faced challenges in tracking staff communications in the work-from-home pandemic era, particularly over personal devices.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on hopes for slower US rate hikes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.02% on October 25, 2022, driven by hopes for slower US rate hikes and the start of Japan's corporate earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 275.38 points to 27,250.28, while the Topix index advanced 1.06%. Investors are shifting focus away from interest rate concerns and towards corporate earnings, with Japan's corporate earnings season set to begin.

site_title: BMW supplier European Lithium is in talks to merge with Sizzle SPAC
summary: European Lithium, a BMW supplier, is set to merge with Sizzle SPAC, a blank-cheque company, to become Critical Metals. The deal values the combined business at $972 million. The merged entity will own European Lithium's lithium project in Austria, which could be Europe's first licensed lithium mine. The project aims to supply battery-grade lithium concentrate to support the production of 200,000 electric vehicles per year by 2025, meeting growing demand for lithium forecast to triple by mid-decade.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk called lithium prices “crazy expensive”.

site_title: ‘Rishi Rich’ Sunak on his way to 10 Downing Street
summary: Britain's Rishi Sunak is set to become the country's third prime minister this year, with an estimated net worth of over $800 million, making him one of the wealthiest people to occupy 10 Downing Street. Sunak has faced criticism for his wealth, with some questioning whether he can relate to ordinary Britons struggling with a cost-of-living crisis. Despite his attempts to appear down-to-earth, a recent photo opportunity at a gas station went awry when he struggled to pay for a can of Coke with his bank card.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak’s top priority is solving the economic crisis, with inflation exceeding 10 per cent, the highest in any G7 country, owing to soaring energy tariffs and food prices.

Sunak, the 42-year-old former finance minister, becomes Britain’s third prime minister in less than two months, tasked with restoring stability to a country reeling from years of political and economic turmoil.

site_title: HSBC says pre-tax profit fell to US$3.1b in Q3
summary: HSBC reported a pre-tax profit of US$3.1 billion in the third quarter, down from US$5.4 billion in the same period last year, due to an impairment on the planned sale of its French retail banking operations. Reported revenue dipped 3% to US$11.6 billion. The bank cited global economic uncertainty and macroeconomic headwinds as factors, but remains on track to achieve a returns target of at least 12% for next year. HSBC also explored the potential sale of its Canadian division.

images.alt_text: HSBC breached the so-called CAP Code, which relates to non-broadcast advertising and direct and promotional marketing.
This is not the first time that Major has said the market is overestimating future rates.

site_title: Katong Point to launch for sale via tender at S$100m
summary: Katong Point, a four-storey freehold commercial development in Singapore, will be launched for sale via tender on October 26, 2022, at a price tag of S$100 million. The property, formerly known as Katong Junction, has undergone significant refurbishments and now boasts a basement carpark, unit re-configuration, and electrical/plumbing works. It is 100% occupied and has a site area of 13,346 sq ft and a gross floor area of 47,450 sq ft, with a catchment of families and proximity to popular schools and amenities.

images.alt_text: Located at 451 Joo Chiat Road, Katong Point is a four-storey freehold commercial development with a basement carpark.

site_title: Australia asks its biggest investors to help fix housing crisis
summary: Australia's government is partnering with institutional investors to build 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years, starting from 2024, to address the nation's housing crisis. The A$350 million funding will incentivize investors to provide below-market rents to qualifying tenants. With record-low vacancy rates and soaring rents, the government aims to build one million new homes over five years. The plan has secured support from state and territory governments and will expedite zoning, planning, and land release in strategic locations.

images.alt_text: Broker Hamptons International has warned that home prices are likely to decline if the Bank of England’s base rate exceeds 2.5 per cent. It’s already at 2.25 per cent, and expected to rise to at least 3 per cent early next month

site_title: BlackRock raises US$4.5b for infrastructure investments
summary: BlackRock has raised US$4.5 billion for its new infrastructure fund, targeting a total of US$7.5 billion, to invest in low-carbon energy assets. The fund will benefit from the global shift to renewable energy, with investors drawn to the relatively robust performance of utilities and infrastructure assets in recessions. BlackRock's head of diversified infrastructure, Mark Florian, cited the firm's use of long-term fixed-rate debt to mitigate against inflation and interest rate rises. The fund's total target is forecast to grow to US$1.87 trillion by 2026.

images.alt_text: “We regularly evolve our management team to grow leaders in new roles across the firm,” BlackRock chief executive officer Larry Fink and president Rob Kapito wrote in a separate memo to employees.
BlackRock is aiming to track companies that have exposure to the metaverse via the iShares Future Metaverse Tech and Communications ETF.

site_title: Updated hotel roadmap targets new concepts, sustainability and retraining for growth
summary: Singapore has launched a refreshed Hotel Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, focusing on new hotel concepts, sustainability, and workforce retraining to support long-term growth. The roadmap aims to boost hotel value-add to 5.9% by 2025, driven by a projected tourism recovery and growth in international visitor arrivals.

images.alt_text: At ITAP 2022, DPM Heng announced an investment into a new semiconductor materials centre, green commitments, the launch of a handbook for talent attraction and retention and five refreshed industry transformation maps (ITMs).

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise on Federal Reserve bets as Hong Kong, Shanghai struggle
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, and others gaining, despite a decline in Taipei. Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks struggled, with the Hang Seng Index experiencing wild fluctuations, and the onshore yuan hitting a record low. Optimism about the Federal Reserve slowing down interest rate hikes and corporate earnings supported the gains, while uncertainty over China's economic future weighed on markets.

images.alt_text: The onshore yuan still remains on track for the worst annual loss since 1994.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start day with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day with small gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.40% to 15,242.10. Despite this, traders remain concerned about the economic outlook following Chinese President Xi Jinping's tightening grip on power. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index extended losses, dropping 0.28% and 0.51% respectively.

site_title: South Korea’s economy likely ground to near halt in Q3: poll
summary: South Korea's economy is likely to have slowed to a near halt in the third quarter due to weakening exports and rising interest rates. A Reuters poll of economists forecasts a seasonally-adjusted 0.1% quarterly growth in exports, down from 0.7% in April-June. The economy is also expected to have expanded 2.8% on an annual basis, down from 2.9% in the second quarter. The slowdown is attributed to the global economic outlook, China's economic slowdown, and the Bank of Korea's interest rate hikes to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: A truck driver works in front of shipping containers stacked up at Pusan Newport Terminal in Busan, South Korea, July 1, 2021. Picture taken on July 1, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Sembcorp in strategic partnerships with Japan government, companies for hydrogen initiatives
summary: Sembcorp Industries has entered into strategic partnerships with the Japanese government and various corporations to further hydrogen and decarbonization initiatives. The partnerships include memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, Sojitz Corporation, and heavy-industry manufacturer IHI Corporation. These partnerships will focus on green hydrogen and ammonia supply chains, renewable energy projects, and hydrogen imports via liquid organic hydrogen carriers. Sembcorp aims to transform its portfolio from "brown to green" and is "naturally positioned" to produce and import green hydrogen, with 7.1 gigawatts of solar, wind, and energy storage capacity.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is staring at S$54 million in fines and civil claims for its water-treatment joint venture in China's illegal discharge of wastewater.

site_title: OCBC joins Net-Zero Banking Alliance, to announce targets by H1 2023
summary: OCBC has joined the Net-Zero Banking Alliance, committing to achieve net zero by 2050 and unveil sectoral financed emission targets by mid-2023. As a signatory, the bank will set 2030 targets and develop a systematic plan to achieve net zero, aligning with pathways to net-zero by 2050 or sooner. The move is part of OCBC's commitment to working with industry peers and policymakers to transition to a low-carbon world.

images.alt_text: Sunny Quek will take charge of OCBC's consumer banking and wealth management business in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Greater China.
OCBC's SME Index report indicates positive readings in Q3 across all industries except for the Information, communications and technology (ICT) sector.
OCBC head of group audit Goh Chin Yee will be appointed as the lender's chief financial officer on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades CICT to ‘buy’ on recovery prospects
summary: RHB analyst Vijay Natarajan upgraded CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) to a "buy" call, raising its target price to S$2.30 from S$2, citing a recovery in 2023 due to committed leases and a 12.7% increase in quarterly gross revenue and net property income. Four key assets, including CapitaSpring, are expected to see a significant increase in cash flow in FY2023, driven by higher occupancy rates and rental income. Despite a 16% decline in shares in the last month, Natarajan believes the current share price is a good entry point for the long term.

images.alt_text: The publicly accessible Sky Garden on Level 51 of the Capita Spring integrated development offers a 360-degree view of the surroundings, and is also home to Singapore’s tallest urban farm.
Simon Claude Israel, chairman of SingPost
Artist's impression of the revamped CQ @ Clarke Quay.

CICT’s sustainability initiatives towards its 2030 targets include a pilot with Tampines Mall as one of the  eight buildings to be part of Singapore’s first brownfield distribution district cooling (DDC) network pilot  by SP Group to allow for more efficient chiller systems operations.
Moody's is expecting certain Reits to benefit from a recovery in both retail and office demand amid the significant easing of Covid-19 restrictions in Singapore.

site_title: UBS profit beats estimates as rate hikes help buck market slump
summary: UBS Group posted a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit of US$1.73 billion, driven by surging rates and cost control. The wealth management unit saw a 23% increase in profit before tax, while the investment-banking unit declined 19%. Despite a slowdown in trading activity in Asia, UBS confirmed plans to return around US$5.5 billion to investors this year, citing a favorable macroeconomic environment. CEO Ralph Hamers attributed the results to strong cost control and a growing presence in the US market.

images.alt_text: David Chin's retirement from banking comes at a time when global investment banks are roiled by increased geopolitical tension between the US and China as well as a sharp slowdown in the world’s second-largest economy.
Ralph Hamers has been pushing his vision of a new style of banking, one fit for the digital age.

site_title: Vietnam raises key rates by 100 basis points as dong slumps
summary: Vietnam's central bank unexpectedly raised interest rates by 100 basis points for a second consecutive month to combat a record-low currency, the dong, which plummeted 2.3% last week. The refinance rate will rise to 6% and the discount rate to 4.5%, aiming to ease pressure on the currency and maintain a stable macroeconomy. The move follows aggressive Federal Reserve tightening and pressures on Asian currencies, including the dong.

images.alt_text: The government sees 2023 inflation at about 4.5 per cent, compared to 4 per cent this year.

site_title: South Korea opposition boycotts Yoon budget speech in battle of wills
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol delivered his first budget speech to a half-empty National Assembly hall due to an opposition boycott, amid a battle of wills over a criminal probe surrounding the Democratic Party leader, Lee Jae-myung. The opposition boycotted the speech to protest against the probe and Yoon's conservative government will need the Democrats' support to fund spending on post-coronavirus recovery and a response to North Korea's nuclear threats.
