This margin surpasses previous records during Prime Minister Liz Truss's tenure, suggesting a potential electoral wipe-out for the Conservatives in the 2025 general election. The poll's findings reflect the damage caused by Truss's short tenure, marked by economic instability and policy reversals.

site_title: Renault says Q3 revenue up but supply woes remain
summary: Renault reported a 22% increase in revenue to €9 billion in Q3, missing analyst projections. The company attributed the decline to supply-chain constraints affecting demand for battery-powered vehicles. Commercial sales fell 2.4% due to a semiconductor shortage. Renault confirmed its 2022 guidance and is in talks with Nissan to rebalance their alliance, with potential changes to the company's stake. The company will hold a capital markets day on November 8 to provide more details on its financial targets and carve-out plans.

site_title: Japan’s inflation to jump to highest level since 1982, Citi says
summary: Japan's inflation is expected to jump to its highest level in 40 years, according to Citigroup economists. Consumer prices excluding fresh food are projected to rise 3.5% in October, driven by the yen's historic slide and mobile phone fee cuts. The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its easing stance despite the expected price growth, which is comparable to the impact of the 2014 sales tax hike. The inflation boost is also influenced by the start of Japan's fiscal year and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's travel campaign.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust obtains S$67.5m bridging loan facility
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has secured a S$67.5 million bridging loan facility from BNP Paribas and CIMB to refinance existing debt obligations of Perpetual Asia, a trustee of the trust. The loan is expected to be drawn down on Oct 28 and repaid by Nov 9 next year. If the manager of LMIRT changes or Lippo Karawaci loses control of the trust, the banks can cancel their loan commitments or demand repayment. A default could affect up to S$1.1 billion of facilities.

images.alt_text: Lippo Mall Puri has a total net lettable area of about 115,600 sq m. It comprises two eight-storey buildings and two lower ground floors, with its retail space distributed over five floors and the two lower ground floors.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower on Fed rate-hike fears, rise in bond yields
summary: South Korean shares ended the day 0.22% lower, falling 4.97 points to 2,213.12, amid concerns over the US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary tightening. The benchmark bond yield hit an 11 1/2-year high, while the Korean won weakened. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 22.5 billion won, and technology giant Samsung Electronics rose 0.72%. The most liquid three-year Korean treasury bond yield rose 18.1 basis points to 4.5%, its highest since March 2011.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 19.35 points or 0.86 per cent at 2,218.09.

site_title: Insurers eye taking on more UK pension risk after bond turmoil
summary: UK corporate pension programmes are increasingly transferring risk to insurers, with demand expected to reach up to £100 billion per year over the next decade. The shift follows recent bond turmoil and market volatility, making it easier for insurers to meet future liabilities. Insurers like Pension Insurance Corporation (PIC) are seeing more requests for full buyouts, where corporate pension programmes are wound up and the insurer takes on future payments. This trend is driven by companies seeking to insulate themselves from market turbulence and protect their balance sheets.

images.alt_text: Britain’s Treasury department said the November announcement would detail government plans to cut debt in the medium term.

site_title: Millennials who buy SMEs
summary: Millennials in Singapore are increasingly turning to acquiring and managing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as an alternative to starting their own businesses from scratch. Potter Capital, founded by Amelia Lee, Aileen Seah, and Goh Xin Ying, has fully acquired a chiropractic chain, dental chain, and osteopathy and physiotherapy chain. The trio's approach, known as a self-funded search, involves using personal savings and capital from investors after identifying a target. This method offers more negotiating power and allows the team to be the majority shareholder. Despite its potential, self-funded searches remain relatively obscure in Singapore, and more awareness is needed among aspiring entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: Up to US$30m raised by South-east Asian search fund

site_title: What to watch as China's Communist Party Congress nears finish
summary: China's 20th Communist Party Congress is nearing its end, with the appointment of the Central Committee and Politburo Standing Committee expected to provide insight into President Xi Jinping's bid to secure a historic third term as Communist Party chief. Analysts predict a significant turnover in key positions, with as many as four top positions on the Politburo Standing Committee expected to change hands. The composition of the new elite bodies will determine the extent of Xi's consolidation of power, with some speculating that he may change his title to "People's Leader" or "Party Chairman" to further cement his legacy.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping arrives for the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: Europe's stock markets slid at the start of trading on Friday, October 21, 2022, following overnight losses in Asia and on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 index dropped 0.5% to 6,909.89 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices retreated 0.9% and 1.1%, respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns over Britain's political crisis and weak UK economic data, with the pound also lower versus the US dollar and euro.

site_title: Adani group said to consider raising US$10b debt in lower-cost debt, green bonds
summary: Gautam Adani's Group plans to raise up to US$10 billion in new debt over the next year to refinance high-interest debt and fund projects. The group will use foreign currency debt and green bonds, aiming to raise US$6 billion to swap existing debt with lower-cost borrowings. The move is intended to lower the conglomerate's overall debt burden, which has been under scrutiny as Adani pursues ambitious acquisitions.

site_title: Up to US$30m raised by South-east Asian search fund
summary: A search fund in Vietnam, LT Partners, has raised up to $30 million in committed capital from over 15 international and local investors, aiming to fund its acquisition of small businesses. The fund, launched by Eduardo Batista and Thai Nguyen, has been given up to two years to complete its first acquisition, with a target of six months. The investors, including global search fund investors AIJ Holdings and Ambit Partners, will provide mentorship and help secure better performance for the entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text:
plbrunch22 - 

credit: LT PARTNERS
From left: Potter Capital’s Aileen Seah, Amelia Lee and Goh Xin Ying. The trio, all aged 33, fully acquired a chiropractic chain in May 2019.

site_title: The ruination of Britain
summary: The British Conservative Party, once considered the most successful in the Western world, has been marred by chaos and incompetence under recent leadership. The resignation of Liz Truss after just 44 days as prime minister is a symptom of the party's chronic crisis of governance, which has reduced Britain to a global laughing stock. The party's detachment from reality, infighting, and ideological disagreements have made it ungovernable. A general election is now in the national interest, with Labour leader Keir Starmer appearing more competent and patriotic than the Conservative Party.

images.alt_text: Speaking outside the door of her Number 10 Downing Street office, British PM Liz Truss says she has accepted that she could not deliver the promises she made when she was running for Conservative leader, having lost the faith of her party.
According to The Times, Boris Johnson intends to join the race to succeed Liz Truss, believing that it is in the “national interest”.
Former British finance minister Sunak has emerged as an early favourite to succeed Liz Truss.

site_title: Winning the war against drug abuse
summary: The US spends over $51 billion annually on its "war on drugs," with little success in reducing demand or disrupting the lucrative global trade. Since 1971, the US has incurred over $1 trillion in costs, yet the problem persists. A more effective approach may be to focus on reducing demand, rather than relying on suppression. This could involve education and social programs aimed at addressing poverty and lack of opportunities, which contribute to drug abuse. Decriminalization has also been proposed as a potential solution, as it could reduce the number of people involved in the trade and drive down prices.

images.alt_text: A cannabis logo is seen at a shop in Bangkok, Thailand July 20, 2022. Malaysia plans to learn from the cannabis policy of neighbouring Thailand in its effort to legalise use of the drug for medical purposes
Singapore swimmer Joseph Schooling before the victory ceremony of the Men’s 100m Butterfly Finals during the SEA Games in Hanoi in May.
Marijuana stocks, which have a history of high volatility, posted steep declines on Friday after an initial jump following Biden’s announcement.

site_title: China property stocks rise after easing of share financing rules
summary: China's property shares surged on Friday after the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) announced plans to ease share financing rules for certain real estate-related firms. The move allows companies with small property interests to raise money by selling A-shares, but with restrictions on investment in the real estate business. Analysts expect these companies to benefit from the rule changes, which could aid firms struggling with financing and debt. The easing of rules aims to stabilize the economy and support real financing for firms, crucial for China's political and economic stability.

images.alt_text: China’s home sales have been falling for more than a year, hurt by a crackdown on leverage and the nation’s Covid Zero policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after US losses
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Friday, October 21, 2022, extending losses after US Treasury yields rose, reflecting fresh rate hike worries. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.43%, or 116.38 points, to 26,890.58, while the Topix index fell 0.71%, or 13.43 points, to 1,881.98.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass by an electronic screen showing Japan's Nikkei share price index inside a conference hall  in Tokyo, Japan June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on hawkish US Fed narrative
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Friday, marking the second weekly loss, due to a hawkish US Federal Reserve narrative and risk sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,676.8 points. Healthcare and financials led the losses, while the resources sector provided some respite. Analysts expect a short-lived recovery due to a rising interest rate scenario. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive rate-hike path has dampened global risk appetite, with Treasury yields and the US dollar considered safe-haven bets.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.7 per cent to 6,686.4, as of 0001 GMT on Friday.

site_title: China needs to lift veil of secrecy on zero-Covid policy
summary: China's President Xi Jinping's zero-Covid policy has sparked concerns over the country's economic recovery, with the Shanghai Composite Index performing lacklustre and GDP figures delayed until after the Party Congress. Economists expect China's real GDP growth in Q3 to be 3.5% on year, but a clear exit strategy from zero-Covid policy is needed for sustained recovery. The US Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes also pose significant risks to China's exports and global demand, further exacerbating the economic challenges.

images.alt_text: The nation’s markets have been among the worst performers globally this year, leaving investors looking to the leadership gathering for policy signs to drive a recovery.
Semiconductor chips are seen on a circuit board of a computer in this illustration picture taken February 25, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
Neighbourhood and even apartment block committees have the power to refuse people entry if officials are concerned about their virus exposure.
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: ECB seen sending rates to higher peak in face of recession risk
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates more aggressively than initially anticipated to combat record inflation, despite a looming recession risk. The ECB's deposit rate is forecast to reach 2.5% by March, with a 75-basis-point hike on October 27 and another 50-basis-point step in December. More than two-thirds of economists surveyed believe the ECB is behind the curve in battling price gains, and some warn that the bank may overshoot, leading to a premature pivot.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Christine Lagarde, European Central Bank (ECB) president addresses a news conference following the ECB's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, September 8, 2022.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo
Record inflation and the danger of winter energy shortages are sinking confidence in the euro-zone economy.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Sentiment cautious as inflation concerns rise (Ep 17)
summary: Rising inflation concerns have led to cautious market sentiment, with investors bracing for potential interest rate hikes. According to SGX's wrap, the market experienced volatility, while the newsdesk highlights inflation as a key driver of the current market movement. Investors are advised to consider the impact of inflation on their portfolios, and the podcast concludes with a look ahead to the week's market trends.

images.alt_text: Markets have had a bearish week and is there end in sight? Claressa Monteiro finds out.
How have market movements caused optimism to fizzle?
What's causing intensifying fears and volatility?

site_title: Enjoy an afternoon of shochu with The Business Times
summary: The Business Times is offering six pairs of tickets to a Real Shochu Masterclass, worth $120, to its subscribers. Conducted by Singapore's only shochu advisers, Olivia Chey and Cedric Tan, the event will take place on October 29 at Workhorse Izakaya and will showcase the diversity of shochu through five types of Honkaku Shochu. To enter, subscribers must register and answer a simple question correctly, with winners notified via email by October 26.

images.alt_text: Learn what goes into the making of a Lange timepiece at The Mechanical Masters exhibition.
The first guest on Mark to Market 'Live' will be OCBC Bank's Group Chief Executive Officer, Helen Wong.
Straits Developments' chief executive officer Eric Teng is the guest on the Oct 5 instalment of Mark to Market 'Live'.

site_title: Automakers to double spending on EVs, batteries to US$1.2t by 2030
summary: Top automakers plan to spend nearly $1.2 trillion through 2030 to develop and produce millions of electric vehicles (EVs), along with batteries and raw materials. This dwarfs previous investment estimates and represents over 50% of total vehicle production. Companies like Tesla, Volkswagen, Toyota, and others have forecast plans to build 54 million battery electric vehicles by 2030, with leading manufacturer Tesla aiming to build 20 million EVs. This unprecedented growth will come at a significant cost, with Tesla alone expected to spend hundreds of billions of dollars.

images.alt_text: The Silicon Valley automaker sells a US$15,000 software add-on called “Full Self-Driving” which enables its vehicles to change lanes and park autonomously.

site_title: Money market woes cast shadow over US$1.6t UK commercial property sector
summary: The UK's £1.6 trillion commercial property sector is facing significant challenges due to rising financing costs and a potential recession. Years of low rents and business demand have left owners vulnerable to a decline in prices, potentially by up to 20%. The reversal of ultra-loose monetary policy has triggered a repricing of sterling money markets, with lenders and investors reassessing their appetite for commercial property. This has been exacerbated by the ongoing economic uncertainty and concerns over rents for some Reits, which were further reduced by the pandemic's impact on businesses.

images.alt_text: The average five-year fixed-rate home loan has risen to 6.51 per cent on Thursday, the highest since September 2008, said financial information company Moneyfacts Group.

site_title: Glaciers in the Alps are melting faster than ever – and 2022 was their worst summer yet
summary: Glaciers in the Alps have experienced their worst summer on record, with an average ice loss of 6.2% in Switzerland, exceeding the previous extreme melt season in 2003. Climate change is driving this rapid glacier melt, with temperatures reaching record highs across Europe, including 40°C in the UK. The loss of glaciers not only threatens the environment but also affects the country's energy supply, as melting glaciers contribute to hydropower production. Experts warn that if this trend continues, many more glaciers could be lost within a generation.

images.alt_text: Glaciologist Andrea Fischer from the Austrian Academy of Sciences explores a natural glacier cavity of the Jamtalferner glacier near Galtuer, Austria. Giant ice caves have appeared in glaciers, accelerating the melting process  as warmer air rushes through the ice mass until it collapses.

site_title: UniCredit Bank’s US$37m claims against Glencore over Hin Leong’s transaction dismissed
summary: UniCredit Bank's US$37m claims against Glencore over a transaction related to Hin Leong, a liquidated oil trader, were dismissed by Singapore's High Court. The court ruled that Glencore did not defraud or deceive UniCredit into issuing a letter of credit, and did not conspire with Hin Leong to cause harm to the bank. The judge found that Glencore was not obligated to inform UniCredit about a simultaneous buyback of goods, and that the bank was entitled to receive payment for the letter of credit.

images.alt_text: Judicial managers of Ocean Tankers and Xihe Holdings in legal tussle over priority of charter claims

site_title: Beyond borders: A deep dive into the nomadic way of life
summary: Anthony Sattin's new book "Nomads: The Wanderers Who Shaped Our World" explores the contributions of traditional nomadic cultures to human progress and development. Through his research, Sattin highlights the importance of nomadic peoples in shaping the way we live, including their dependence on the natural world, their ability to live lightly, and their flexibility in thinking. These traits are also relevant to modern-day travellers and digital nomads, who can learn from the nomadic way of life by being more mindful of their impact on the environment and being adaptable in their thinking.

images.alt_text: A Ukrainian police officer guards as refugees from the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol arrive at a registration and humanitarian aid centre for internally displaced people, amid Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine, in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine May 8, 2022.

“I am increasingly convinced the number of foreign tourists who are interested in staying in Indonesia will increase and will automatically have an impact on economic revival,” Indonesia Tourism Minster Sandiaga Uno said.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar Ibrahim named PM candidate as election nears
summary: Malaysia's opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has been named as the Pakatan Harapan coalition's prime minister candidate ahead of the November 19 general election. Anwar, 75, is the second politician to offer himself as premier, pitting him against caretaker premier Ismail Sabri Yaakob. Anwar vows to combat corruption and tackle poverty, stating his battle is not for power but against corruption and racial politics. This marks Anwar's second attempt to lead the opposition, following his previous bid in 2020.

site_title: Raffles Medical, IHH to benefit from hospital bed crunch: DBS
summary: Raffles Medical and IHH Healthcare are expected to benefit from Singapore's current hospital bed crunch, driven by a surge in Covid-19 cases and long waiting times at public hospitals. The Ministry of Health has set aside over 800 beds to mitigate congestion, while private hospitals are filling up with non-urgent treatments being deferred. Analyst Rachel Tan predicts a "buy" rating for Raffles Medical and IHH Healthcare, citing the government's experience in managing similar situations in the past.

images.alt_text: Raffles Medical located at Raffles Holland V taken on 7 Feb 2018
At present, the bed occupancy of hospitals stands at about 93 per cent, with 200 additional beds already activated.
Bringing back stricter mask mandates or other safe management measures cannot be ruled out, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung.
While locals will continue to form the bulk of the nursing workforce, the number and role of foreign nurses will grow.

site_title: Malaysia inflation eases to 4.5% in Sep, below economists’ forecasts
summary: Malaysia's inflation eased to 4.5% in September, below economists' forecasts of 4.6%. The country's central bank had predicted inflation to peak in the third quarter before moderating. Food prices rose more slowly, slowing to 6.8% from 7.2% in August, while other segments, such as restaurants and transport, saw slightly higher inflation. The result suggests the economy is showing signs of resilience despite global economic uncertainty and tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Higher food prices remained the main cause of the high inflation, contributed by food and non-alcoholic beverages which recorded an increase by 7.2 per cent in August.

site_title: UK Tory rivals open truncated leadership race
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has stepped down after only 44 days in office, citing her inability to deliver the mandate on which she was elected. Former finance minister Rishi Sunak has emerged as a likely candidate to succeed her, but opposition parties demand an immediate general election, pointing to the governing party's "soap opera" at the top and the country's economic crisis. The Conservative leadership contest will be truncated, with a result expected on October 28, and will involve a vote by MPs and a subsequent online ballot by party members.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Conservative leadership candidate Rishi Sunak arrives at Broadcasting House ahead of his appearance on BBC's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg show in London, Britain September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Overlapping crises add urgency for IMF, World Bank resources, reforms
summary: Global financial leaders are urging the IMF and World Bank to increase lending capacity and private capital mobilization to address overlapping crises such as climate change, inflation, and debt problems. The IMF has created new lending tools, including a war-related food shock facility, but faces growing demands on its resources. World Bank president David Malpass has committed to using private finance to unlock larger volumes of funding for sustainable infrastructure. Reforms are needed to address the inadequacy of the IMF's and World Bank's current structures to deal with current global calamities.

images.alt_text: Many Asian currencies depreciated “quite sharply” as US monetary tightening led to widening interest rate differentials, helping push up import costs for the countries, Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific Department said.
Scale will be the new umbrella trust fund for the bank’s results-based climate finance activities.

The IMF calculates that about one-third of the world economy will have at least two consecutive quarters of contraction this year and next, and that the lost output through 2026 will be US$4 trillion.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Lim & Tan Securities initiates coverage on IReit Global with ‘accumulate’
summary: LIM & Tan Securities has initiated coverage on IReit Global with a "accumulate" rating and a target price of S$0.69, implying a 40.8% upside. The analyst believes IReit's valuation is cheap, trading at its highest discount to net asset value of 35.2% since listing, and praises the company's strong sponsor backing and robust financial position.

site_title: Gold set for second weekly fall as Fed hawks lift Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices are set for a second weekly decline due to rising US Treasury yields and hawkish comments from Federal Reserve officials. Despite being a hedge against inflation, gold's zero yield increases its opportunity cost, making it less appealing. Spot gold is flat at $1,627.20 per ounce, and US gold futures are down 0.4% at $1,630.10. Higher interest rates and strong labor market data are contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the bullion, which yields nothing.

site_title: With so much riding on the Fed’s moves, it’s hard to know how to invest
summary: The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on inflation has led to a market downturn, with the S&P 500 losing 5.3% in the third quarter. Investors are uncertain about the Fed's next moves, with some predicting a dovish turn and others expecting more rate hikes. A credit event, such as a default by a large investment firm, could trigger a pivot. High interest rates and a strong dollar are also causing concern, with some predicting a recession in the US. Experts recommend remaining cautious towards stocks and risky corporate bonds, and consider investing in Treasuries and other high-quality bonds.

site_title: Apollo targets Asia’s rich from Singapore in retail ramp up
summary: Apollo Global Management plans to raise US$50 billion from retail investors in Asia over the next five years, targeting private banks and investment advisers in Singapore, China, Indonesia, and India. The firm has managed to tap nearly US$2 billion in Asia in a year, with its wealth strategy based out of Singapore. Apollo aims to offer country-specific products and target major financial centers like Tokyo and Hong Kong. The firm seeks to provide bespoke solutions for high-net-worth individuals and investment-grade companies in the region.

images.alt_text: Apollo Global Management and Sixth Street Partners are no longer providing financing to Elon Musk earlier this year for his proposed US$44 billion buyout of Twitter, two sources revealed.

site_title: US Treasuries tumble into longest slump since 1984 on hawkish Fed
summary: US Treasuries have entered a 38-year-long slump, with benchmark 10-year notes reaching a 4.23% yield on October 21. This marks a 12-week streak of increases, matching the 1984 episode under Paul Volcker. Global markets are experiencing a selloff, with similar-dated Australian yields reaching 4.16%. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates to "well above" 4% this year, with a terminal rate projected to top out at 5% in the first half of 2023, according to market-implied projections.

images.alt_text: The US has ramped up actions to stifle China’s ability to develop certain technologies that it sees as key in the competition with its top strategic rival.
Home resales, which account for the bulk of US home sales, decreased 23.8 per cent on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Dollar extends gains on Federal Reserve rate hike expectations
summary: The US dollar extended gains against the yen on Friday, reaching a 32-year high of 150.20 yen, amid expectations of further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Analysts predict the Fed will continue to raise rates to combat inflation, potentially reaching 5% by the end of the year. Meanwhile, Tokyo is expected to intervene to support its currency, but analysts warn such moves rarely have a lasting effect. The dollar also rose against sterling, following the resignation of UK Prime Minister Liz Truss, which has created uncertainty in Westminster.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led losses, shedding almost 3 per cent, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington and Taipei were all off at least 1 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower at Friday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% or 8.89 points to 3013.81 at 9:04 am on Friday, October 21, 2022, following a mixed day for global stock markets. The index saw 71 losers and 43 gainers, with Sembcorp Marine and Thai Beverage being the most actively traded counters. In contrast, shares of Singtel declined 0.4%, while OCBC rose 0.1% and DBS shed 0.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average in the US dipped 0.3% amid weak housing data and rising US Treasury yields.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Trust has reported a 12.1 per cent increase in Q3 2022 distributable income to S$50.1 million from S$44.7 million in Q3 2021.

site_title: Alternative assets remain key driver of Singapore asset management industry in 2021: MAS
summary: Singapore's asset management industry grew 16% in 2021, driven by the alternative assets sector, which expanded 30% to reach $0.9 trillion. Private equity and venture capital AUM grew 42% and 48% respectively, while traditional retail segment AUM grew 13%. ESG-focused assets made up 58% of total AUM. Despite expected moderation in 2022 due to investor caution, Singapore remains a key hub for asset managers, with over 600 variable capital companies and 420 regulated fund management companies.

images.alt_text: PwC projected that ESG AUM in Asia Pacific will grow at a faster clip than Europe and the US, more than tripling to US$3.3 trillion by 2026, from a low base of US$1 trillion in 2021.
The Asia Pacific accounts for a quarter of Citi Private Bank's topline revenue and 40 per cent of headcount.

Blackstone headquarters in New York. Private market investors may have to tamp down expectations of returns going forward.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB shaves Aztech Global target on global economic uncertainties
summary: CGS-CIMB has reduced its price target for Aztech Global to S$0.96 from S$1.22 due to continued margin pressures and uncertain global economic outlook. The brokerage cut gross profit margin estimates by 0.5 to one percentage point, resulting in 3.8-7.5% lower earnings per share (EPS) projections. Despite this, CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" call on Aztech, citing a strong net cash balance sheet and projected dividend yields of 8-10% over FY2022-2024.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect demand to slow as consumers tighten their wallets going amid a weaker macroeconomic environment.
Chipmakers around the world have already begun to trade at significantly lower valuations, and that negative sentiment is spreading to Singapore’s shores.
Both research houses maintained a “buy” call on the company, although UOB Kay Hian reduced target price on the company due to derating in peers’ valuation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.41 points or 0.24% to 1434.31. The market saw 223.81 million lots traded worth RM86.96 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 171 to 161.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Friday, October 21, 2022, following two days of heavy losses. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.31% to 16,331.11, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.10%. The Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.05%. Traders remain cautious due to ongoing interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: China’s yuan nears 2008 global financial crisis era lows
summary: China's yuan dropped to an intraday low of 7.2479 against the US dollar, nearing a 14-year low of 7.2521 set in late September. The yuan's decline follows heightened expectations of US interest rate hikes and China's weakening economy. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 7.1186 per dollar, 2 pips firmer than the previous fix. The yuan's weakening trend has been ongoing, approaching lows seen during the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: The nation’s markets have been among the worst performers globally this year, leaving investors looking to the leadership gathering for policy signs to drive a recovery.
Neighbourhood and even apartment block committees have the power to refuse people entry if officials are concerned about their virus exposure.
Pan Gongsheng, deputy governor of PBOC, says: “We will better implement the prudent monetary policy, strengthen cross-cyclical and counter-cyclical adjustments.”

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Friday after Wall Street losses
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending losses after US Treasury yields rose, reflecting fresh rate hike worries. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.37%, while the Topix index fell 0.44%. The losses follow Wall Street falls, which were attributed to US-EU trade tensions and rate hike concerns.

site_title: UK consumer confidence lingered near historic lows in October
summary: UK consumer confidence remains near historic lows in October, with a GfK measure of sentiment rising 2 points to minus 47. The cost-of-living crisis and ailing UK economy continue to affect consumer spending intentions, with a decline in plans to buy larger items. This could lead to further economic slowdown and hurt business profits in the final quarter of the year, according to GfK. The UK's economic woes come amid turmoil in the gilt market and uncertainty over mortgage rates and energy prices.

site_title: US airlines cheer travel boost from shift to hybrid work
summary: US airlines are experiencing a travel boost due to the shift to hybrid work, allowing employees to travel more frequently as COVID-19 restrictions ease. Carriers like American Airlines, United, and Delta reported strong travel demand, with increased flexibility leading to longer get-away weekends and more travel outside traditional holiday periods. The trend is expected to hold for at least a while longer, including the upcoming holiday season, enabling airlines to spread out their labor and increasing revenue from premium tickets.

images.alt_text: Ñ EMBARGO: NO ELECTRONIC DISTRIBUTION, WEB POSTING OR STREET SALES BEFORE 3 A.M. ET ON FRIDAY, OCT. 21, 2022. NO EXCEPTIONS FOR ANY REASONS Ñ FILE Ñ Travelers at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York on April 19, 2022. Remote work and hybrid work have allowed Americans to travel more and combine personal and professional trips. (Gabby Jones/The New York Times)
Rex will still use turbine-powered Saab 340s on longer regional flights.
American Airlines say an unquenched thirst for travel, hybrid work arrangements and limited airline capacity would keep their business humming.

site_title: Foxconn imposes restrictions on iPhone assembly plant in China’s Zhengzhou
summary: Foxconn has imposed Covid-19 control restrictions on its Zhengzhou plant in China, which assembles Apple's iPhones, requiring workers to take meals back to their dormitories. The move comes as production ramps up for the latest iPhone 14 models. Despite the restrictions, production remains normal, according to Foxconn. The factory has banned eating in, with no reported impact on production.

site_title: US eyes expanding China tech ban to quantum computing and AI
summary: The US is considering expanding export controls to limit China's access to quantum computing and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. This move comes as part of the Biden administration's efforts to stifle China's development of key technologies in the competition with its top strategic rival. The potential controls, still in an early stage, would focus on the experimental field of quantum computing and AI software, with industry experts weighing in on how to set the parameters of the restrictions.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor chips are seen on a circuit board of a computer in this illustration picture taken February 25, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
Semiconductor chips are seen on a circuit board of a computer in this illustration picture taken February 25, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
ASML has told its workers in the US to refrain from servicing customers in China.
The US planned to review licences for non-Chinese factories in China hit by the new restrictions on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Elon Musk says Tesla will be bigger than Apple. Analysts say not so fast
summary: Elon Musk stated that Tesla will surpass the combined valuation of Apple and Saudi Aramco. However, analysts are skeptical, citing the company's lackluster third-quarter results and cautious demand outlook. Despite this, analysts maintain a longer-term bullish outlook for Tesla, with some lowering their price targets due to valuation concerns. Tesla's market capitalization stands at around $650 billion, while Apple's is over $2.3 trillion.

images.alt_text: Tesla cited higher costs related to a slower-than-expected ramp up in output at the new factories, as well as difficulties shipping vehicles.
The latest iPad Pro now sports the same M2 chip used in recent Mac computers, while the entry-level iPad is getting a fresh design and new charging port.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as financials drag on Federal Reserve rate-hike fears
summary: Australia's shares dropped 0.7% to 6,686.4, their biggest weekly decline in four, due to financial and real estate stocks. Overnight US Federal Reserve comments reinforced expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes, boosting fears of a recession. The country's "Big Four" banks fell 1.3-1.6% and insurance company Insurance Australia Group dropped 2% after receiving over 2,000 flood claims. Broader mining and gold stocks rose 0.1%, while lithium miner Allkem fell 5.8% after its revenue declined.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1 per cent lower at 6,730.7.

site_title: South Korea’s early exports sink in sign of weakening demand
summary: South Korea's early exports declined 9% on average in October, the first time in two years, due to weakening demand from China and a slowdown in the global economy. This decline is attributed to factors such as Russia's war on Ukraine, Covid lockdowns in China, and interest-rate hikes. The country's chip sales dropped 12.8% and shipments to China declined 16.3%, while exports to the US increased 6.3% and those to Vietnam edged up 1.7%. This weakening trend is expected to continue due to geopolitical tensions and rising trade barriers.

images.alt_text: “Recovery in private consumption is expected to weaken going forward due to slower growth in real purchasing power and a rise in interest rates,” the Bank of Korea (BOK) said.
South Koreans currently rely on resident registration cards - similar to a US social security card - to identify themselves.

site_title: Instacart shelves plans for 2022 IPO, citing market turmoil
summary: Instacart, the US's largest online grocery-delivery company, plans to delay its initial public offering (IPO) until at least 2023 due to market turmoil. The company, valued at $39 billion in 2021, had filed confidentially to go public earlier this year but reconsidered amid market volatility. CEO Fidji Simo cited "extremely tumultuous" markets as the reason for the delay, stating it's "highly unlikely" the IPO will occur in 2022. Despite this, the company's fundamentals remain strong, with sales and gross profit increasing over 40% and 45%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Grocery delivery startup Instacart is planning to slow the pace of hiring as it prepares for an initial public offering, focusing instead on profitability.

site_title: Oil near flat, inflation worries counter potential boost in China demand
summary: Oil prices remained near flat on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at $92.38 a barrel after earlier gains. Inflation concerns weighed on prices, but news of China considering easing Covid-19 quarantine measures for visitors supported prices. The US Federal Reserve's plan to slow the economy and raise interest rates also contributed to the market's nervousness. Meanwhile, China's potential relaxation of quarantine measures and Opec+ production cut are seen as positive indicators for the market, although the European Union's ban on Russian crude and oil products continues to support prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for December settlement ended up US$2.38, or 2.6 per cent, to US$92.41 a barrel.

US President Joe Biden has announced a plan to sell off the rest of his release from the nation’s Strategic Petroleum Reserve by year’s end, or 15 million barrels of oil, and begin refilling the stockpile as he tries to dampen high petrol prices ahead of midterm elections on Nov 8.

site_title: Australia aims for ‘responsible’ budget after UK mayhem
summary: Australia's Labor government will present its first budget next week, focusing on "responsible" spending to combat inflation and support the economy. The budget deficit for the year to June 2022 is A$32 billion, less than half the initial projection, thanks to strong commodity exports and a low unemployment rate. The government expects the deficit to widen as commodity prices ease and spending pressures mount, particularly in healthcare and childcare. Treasurer Jim Chalmers aims to avoid the UK's recent budget chaos and is committed to maintaining a triple-A credit rating.

images.alt_text: epa09661045 Members of the public gather along the usually packed The Rocks foreshore ahead of New Year's Eve celebrations in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 31 December 2021. Fireworks at 9pm and midnight in Sydney will be displayed against the backdrop of the Sydney Opera House and Sydney Harbour Bridge with crowd numbers expected to be low due to increasing COVID-19 case numbers in the country.  EPA-EFE/BIANCA DE MARCHI AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT
The nation’s fiscal position is being buffeted by floods at home and the risk of a global downturn. A hiring slowdown only adds to those challenges.
The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.7 per cent to 6,686.4, as of 0001 GMT on Friday.

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs convertible bond to help pay for overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse is considering issuing convertible bonds or preferred shares to help pay for its overhaul and strengthen its balance sheet. The move comes after the collapse of Archegos Capital Management, which cost the firm about US$5.5 billion, and analysts estimate a capital hole of US$4-9 billion. The bank is working with Royal Bank of Canada and Morgan Stanley on a potential capital increase, and has reached out to key shareholders such as the Qatar Investment Authority to gauge interest in a capital injection.

images.alt_text: The latest staff departures at Credit Suisse’s Asia unit come on the heels of Singapore-based Jin Yee Young resigning from her role as the deputy head of Credit Suisse’s Asia Pacific wealth management business.
The potential sale comes as Credit Suisse prepares to unveil a turnaround to investors next week, as the bank looks to simplify and pare down following scandals and losses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infrastructure Trust
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 12.1% increase in Q3 2022 distributable income to S$50.1 million, driven by a 15.4% growth in operational cash flows to S$65.5 million. The trust expects assets under management to reach S$6.1 billion after new acquisitions in Q4 2022, but its units closed unchanged at S$0.525.

site_title: New NTUC journal brings academics, practitioners together for labour research, strategies
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) launched the first volume of the Singapore Labour Journal, a yearly publication that brings together academics and practitioners to promote labour research and strategies. The journal covers topics such as continuing education, digitalisation, and youth empowerment, and features contributions from NTUC officials and academics. The publication aims to provide a well-balanced content that reflects on current labour issues and reimagines new approaches to help workers earn a better living.

images.alt_text: The feedback-gathering exercise, titled #EveryWorkerMatters Conversations, was launched by labour chief Ng Chee Meng on Thursday (Aug 11) evening during a closed-door dialogue for over 100 union leaders.

site_title: The stubborn persistence of paper in a digital world
summary: Despite the widespread adoption of digital tools, many Americans still prefer to meet with tax professionals in person, with H&R Block reporting that the majority of clients prefer face-to-face interaction. The company's CEO, Jeff Jones, attributes this to the importance of trust and the tactile nature of paper, citing studies that suggest paper evokes emotions and conveys a sense of permanence and control. This phenomenon is not unique to tax services, with other industries such as medical and conference services also showing a preference for in-person interactions.

images.alt_text: business, computer, mobile

site_title: SoftBank forms committee to oversee Vision Fund 2, Latam funds
summary: SoftBank has appointed an executive committee to oversee its second Vision Fund, Latin America (Latam) funds, and future vehicles. The committee, led by chairman Masayoshi Son, includes Alex Clavel, Greg Moon, and Navneet Govil. The move follows SoftBank's decision to establish a new firm, One Investment Management, and step back from some responsibilities at the Japanese conglomerate. The committee will oversee investments in over 400 companies, with a total commitment of $160 billion. This comes after SoftBank laid off employees within its Vision Fund unit last month, citing a record $23 billion loss.

images.alt_text: While it is unclear exactly how much SoftBank lost on the deal, the THG stake was worth over £500 million (S$805.7 million) when it first announced its shareholding last year
The cuts will affect staff in the investment teams and back-office staff in departments such as finance and legal.

site_title: It’s live and let live for Singapore’s ever-shrinking 3-bedroom condos
summary: Singapore's three-bedroom condominium units are shrinking, with median floor areas falling from 1,700-1,800 sq ft in the 1980s to around 1,000 sq ft in 2018. Supply and demand pressures, including rising land acquisition and development costs, contribute to the decline. While some analysts suggest the government may intervene, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has guidelines in place but does not prescribe minimum sizes for unit types within a development. Experts expect unit sizes to remain relatively small, around 850-900 sq ft, as buyers adapt to smaller living spaces and market forces dictate the trend.

images.alt_text: Homes in the Central Area will need to be at least 70 square metres for developments seeking approvals from 18 Jan 2023 onwards.

site_title: China locks down parts of Xi’an as Covid Zero policy reinforced
summary: China has locked down parts of Xi'an, confining 13 million people to their homes for at least a week, as the country reinforces its strict Covid Zero policy. The lockdown applies to high-risk areas, where residents must stay home for seven days without new infections, and medium-risk areas, where movement is restricted within neighborhoods until no new infections are reported. President Xi Jinping signaled no looming change to the Covid Zero approach, disappointing investors who had hoped for signs of loosening.

images.alt_text: Neighbourhood and even apartment block committees have the power to refuse people entry if officials are concerned about their virus exposure.

site_title: South Korea says report Do Kwon transited via Dubai ‘not false’
summary: South Korea has confirmed that Do Kwon, a cryptocurrency fugitive, did transit through Dubai after leaving Singapore, contrary to previous claims. Prosecutors stated that a report of Kwon's travel to Dubai was not false, although his final destination remains unknown. Kwon faces charges in South Korea for breaching capital-markets law and is the subject of an Interpol red notice. He has denied wrongdoing and cited threats for his lack of cooperation.

site_title: Zara to start repairing, reselling clothes in UK pre-owned push
summary: Zara, owned by Inditex, is introducing repair, resale, and donation services for its UK customers. Starting next month, customers can repair and resell worn Zara clothing online or in-store, and donate any brand clothing to charity through a secure platform. This move aims to extend the life of garments and reduce carbon emissions, a departure from Zara's traditional fast-fashion approach. The initiative follows growing pressure to become more sustainable, with the textile industry responsible for 10% of global carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Third-quarter net sales at the Swedish group were up 3 per cent from a year earlier at 57.5 billion kronor (S$7.6 billion), short of the 5 per cent which analysts polled by Refinitiv had forecast for the June-August quarter.

site_title: Japan inflation at highest level since 2014
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 3% in September, the highest level since 2014, driven by a falling yen and rising energy costs. This exceeds the Bank of Japan's 2% long-term inflation goal. Despite this, the central bank believes the increases are temporary and has declined to boost interest rates. Economist Taro Saito attributes the price rises to raw material price increases, not wage-driven inflation. The yen has slumped to a decades-low level against the dollar due to the bank's differing policy stance from other central banks.

images.alt_text: The Togoshiginza shopping district in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, Oct. 19, 2022. September figures due Friday are expected to show Japan’s key inflation gauge hitting 3%, the highest in about 30 years after factoring out tax distortions. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg
The yen hit 149.91 to the dollar in overnight trading, its weakest since 1990. The greenback stood around 149.84 in early Asia trading on Thursday.
The yen currency teetered at the break of 150 to the dollar, a level that would mark a 32-year-low and has been seen as psychologically important for market players.
The fragile yen briefly weakened past 150 per US dollar in early European trading for the first time since August 1990.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise after UK’s Truss resigns as prime minister
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 rose 0.3% after UK Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned, citing her economic program's impact on markets. Truss was forced to abandon her tax cuts and sack her finance minister after the pound and bonds crashed. A leadership election will be completed within a week, with markets craving stability. Nokia and Ericsson shares slumped 7.6% and 14.8% respectively due to weaker-than-expected earnings.

site_title: Blackstone’s profit falters as rising rates chill dealmaking
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, reported a 16% decline in distributable earnings to $1.37 billion in its third-quarter profit, beating analyst expectations. The decline was attributed to rising borrowing costs and a slowdown in dealmaking due to wild markets. Blackstone's earnings per share were $1.06, surpassing expectations. The industry's growth is expected to slow as banks become more cautious about providing cheap debt, making it harder for dealmakers to secure financing.

images.alt_text: Blackstone, in a statement, said it and Home Partners continue to actively buy homes in more than 20 of the country’s highest-growth markets.

site_title: Adidas sneakers going unsold as demand weakens, hitting profit
summary: Adidas has issued a fresh profit warning due to weak consumer demand in China and western markets, resulting in unsold goods piling up. The company now expects an operating margin of 4% for the fiscal year, down from 7%, and its full-year revenues will grow at a mid-single-digit rate. The warning follows earlier issues with Kanye West and CEO Kasper Rorsted's departure in 2023. The company's stock price fell 5% after the update, while shares of rival Nike dropped 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Pilipinas Shell has also added electric-vehicle (EV) charging points at some of its stations in anticipation of a growth in EV use in the Philippines.

Adidas said Rorsted and its supervisory board had mutually agreed that the CEO would hand over his position during the course of 2023. He will remain in office until a successor has been appointed, it added.

site_title: Instagram to make it easier to avoid trolls
summary: Instagram is expanding its features to make it easier for users to block trolls and abusers. Users can now block all existing accounts of a person, reducing the need to block 4 million fewer accounts per week. The platform has also upgraded its message filtering feature and expanded "nudges" to protect creators from harassment. These changes aim to tackle hate speech and online abuse on the platform, which is popular among teens and young adults.

site_title: 2022 Volvo C40 Recharge review: Seen and not heard
summary: The Volvo C40 Recharge is a stylish and appealing electric car based on the XC40. It boasts a sleek silhouette, a novel startup system, and impressive performance with 408 hp and 660 Nm of torque. The car offers practicality with a small compartment in the nose and a low roof, but some drawbacks include a firm ride and heat buildup in the cabin. With an electric range of 450 km and a top speed of 180 km/h, the C40 Recharge is a compelling option for those seeking a stylish and efficient vehicle.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble a car at the Volvo Cars manufacturing plant in Daqing, Heilongjiang province, China June 8, 2018.  REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: Energy crunch pits Germany against frustrated EU leaders seeking gas cap
summary: The European Union is struggling with high energy prices, driving inflation and recession concerns, amid Russia's gas flow cuts following its Ukraine invasion. EU leaders are frustrated with Germany's refusal to cap gas prices, hindering a consensus on the bloc's response. The 27 countries have agreed to fill gas storages and claw back revenues to help consumers with high bills. A stalemate on gas price caps may exacerbate the energy crisis, with the EU seeking a unified approach to address the crisis.

images.alt_text: EU member states have earmarked more than 500 billion euros to cushion the impact of the energy crunch on consumers and businesses.
Ursula von der Leyen, President of European Commission, says: “It is logical that instead of outbidding each other, energy companies should leverage their joint purchasing power.”
Brent crude futures fell 3 cents to settle at US$92.38 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Pfizer expects to hike US Covid-19 vaccine price to US$110-$130 per dose
summary: Pfizer Inc expects to increase the price of its Covid-19 vaccine to $110-$130 per dose after the US government's current purchase program expires, roughly quadrupling the current price of $30 per dose. The vaccine will remain free for those with private insurance or government-paid insurance. The move is expected to take effect in 2023, when the US public health emergency expires, and is intended to ensure the vaccine's cost-effectiveness and accessibility.

images.alt_text: The recommended dosage of the Moderna vaccine for those aged six months to five years is two doses of 25 micrograms each, spaced eight weeks apart.
The Moderna bivalent vaccine targets the original Sars-CoV-2 strain of the virus as well as the Omicron BA.1 variant.
Pfizer said data from a trial in adult patients showed that the booster dose led to a substantial increase in neutralising antibody levels against the BA.4/BA.5 variants.

site_title: L’Oreal sales rise as lower-priced cosmetics gain ground
summary: L'Oreal's sales rose 9.1% in the third quarter, driven by strong performance from its mass-market consumer-products arm, which outperformed its luxury arm. Despite soaring inflation and a worsening global economic outlook, the company's mass-market division saw "spectacular" gains in India and Mexico. In contrast, the L'Oreal Luxe division, which includes luxury brands, took a hit due to lockdowns in China and sourcing issues. The company's resilience highlights the continued demand for beauty products, with CEO Nicolas Hieronimus stating that consumers' appetite for beauty products remains intact.

images.alt_text: Sales in Europe, the United States and Japan were up sharply since the start of the year.

site_title: Snap’s slowing ad growth sends inflation fears through tech sector
summary: Snap Inc. reported no revenue growth in the holiday quarter, sparking concerns over inflation and the war in Ukraine's impact on the tech sector. The company's shares dropped 27% in after-hours trading, wiping out nearly $4 billion from its market capitalization. This warning signal may cast a shadow on other major tech firms, including Meta Platforms, Alphabet's Google, and Pinterest, which report their results next week, as they also rely heavily on advertising revenue.

images.alt_text: As digital advertising enters a period of transformation, the challengers to the duopoly of google and Meta look well-placed to increase their gains.
Snap Inc is planning layoffs, the Verge reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the plans.

site_title: China’s central bank says it will better implement monetary policy
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, announced plans to better implement its monetary policy to support economic growth and employment. Deputy governor Pan Gongsheng stated that the bank will strengthen cross-cyclical and counter-cyclical adjustments to create a sound monetary environment. The bank aims to keep the yuan exchange rate stable and address financial risks. This move comes as China's economy faces challenges, including a shallow recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic and a deepening property slump.

site_title: China's margin loan provider lowers refinancing rates for brokerages
summary: China's margin loan provider, the China Securities Finance Co (CSF), has cut brokerages' borrowing costs by 40 basis points in an effort to promote stock investment and stabilize China's capital markets. The move is part of a series of measures by Beijing to address the country's struggling stock market amid economic challenges. The CSF also introduced a market-oriented reform of the margin refinancing business, allowing brokerages to borrow money at more flexible maturities and market-competitive rates. The goal is to safeguard stable and healthy development of China's capital markets.

site_title: Times Square may get one of the few spectacles it lacks: a casino
summary: Times Square in New York City may get a casino, proposed by developer SL Green Realty and Caesars Entertainment, as the city seeks to secure one of three new casino licenses. The project faces substantial obstacles, including competition from another casino bid in nearby Hudson Yards and potential opposition from the Broadway League. Critics worry that the casino would alter the character of the neighborhood and overwhelm the area, while proponents promise to use casino revenues to fund safety and sanitation improvements.

images.alt_text: Working from home is much more common in major cities than in smaller cities and towns.

site_title: Thai telco regulator gives conditional clearance to True, DTAC merger
summary: The National Broadcasting and Telecommunication Commission (NBTC) in Thailand has given conditional clearance to the merger of True Corporation and DTAC, the country's second and third largest mobile operators. The combined entity will have 55% of the market, surpassing AIS as the market leader. Conditions include a price ceiling, price controls, and independent verification of cost structure and service fees for at least five years. The decision comes after nearly a year of delays due to concerns about reduced market competition.

site_title: Meta oversight board can now apply warning screens on content
summary: Meta's independent oversight board can now apply warning screens to "disturbing" or "sensitive" content, including photos and videos, when "leaving up or restoring qualifying content". The board, which received 347,000 appeals from Facebook and Instagram users in the second quarter, has the ability to make binding decisions on content moderation and advises on site policies. The move aims to address users' demand for independent review of content moderation decisions, following a ruling last month that backed users' freedom of expression.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again on interest rate angst
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% at 30,333.59, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes down 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively. The decline was driven by rising US Treasury yields, which rose above 4.0% as investors expect more aggressive Federal Reserve interest rates to combat inflation. Weak housing data, including a 0.8% drop in existing home sales, also weighed on the market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 11.89 points, or 0.04 per cent, at the open to 30,411.92.

site_title: India competition regulator fines Google 13.38b rupees for anti-competitive practices
summary: India's competition regulator fined Alphabet's Google 13.38 billion Indian rupees (S$230 million) for anti-competitive practices related to Android mobile devices. The fine was imposed due to Google's alleged unfair business practices, such as favoring its own services over those of competitors. This marks the latest move in the ongoing global scrutiny of Google's dominance in the tech industry.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US jobless claims fell to 214,000 for the week ended Oct 15, a seasonally adjusted number. This indicates the labor market remains tight despite cooling demand for labor amid higher interest rates. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening campaign has led to a decline in job openings, but economists do not expect widespread layoffs due to companies' caution in releasing workers after past hiring difficulties.

site_title: Musk plans to cut Twitter workforce by 75%, Washington Post says
summary: Elon Musk plans to slash Twitter's workforce by nearly 75% to around 2,000 employees, according to documents obtained by the Washington Post. This reduction in staff would be necessary to cut costs, even if Musk doesn't end up owning the company. Musk had previously mentioned this plan to prospective investors, stating he aimed to shrink staff in his initial funding pitch. The planned staff reduction is part of Musk's overall plan to take Twitter private and follow through with his agreement to end the company's months-long court battle.

site_title: US existing home sales slide again in September
summary: US existing home sales dropped 1.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.71 million units in September, marking the eighth consecutive month of decline. Surging mortgage rates and elevated selling prices are pushing affordability beyond the reach of many prospective buyers, with the median existing house price increasing 8.4% from a year earlier to $384,800. Economists expect the rate-sensitive housing market to continue to be impacted by the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes, which are likely to end the year in the mid-4% range.

images.alt_text: Applications to build, a proxy for future construction, rose to an annualised 1.56 million units, led by multifamily properties.

site_title: AT&T raises annual profit forecast on strong wireless additions
summary: AT&T raised its annual profit forecast after adding 708,000 net new monthly bill paying wireless phone subscribers in the third quarter, surpassing estimates. The carrier's promotional offers and strong demand for 5G plans contributed to the growth. AT&T also added 338,000 fibre Internet customers and is on track to achieve its annual free cash flow target. The company's shares rose 2.8% and its adjusted profit per share is now expected to be US$2.50 or higher for the full year, exceeding earlier expectations.

site_title: India’s Tata Consumer Products posts strong profit growth on higher demand
summary: Tata Consumer Products reported a 22.4% rise in quarterly profit to 3.28 billion Indian rupees, driven by higher demand for its products such as Tata Salt and Himalayan mineral water. The company attributed the growth to discretionary spending rebounding as offices reopened and Indians prepared for the first festive season without Covid curbs in two years.

site_title: American Airlines forecasts stronger fourth-quarter profit on travel demand
summary: American Airlines forecasts a stronger fourth-quarter profit due to an unquenched thirst for travel, hybrid work arrangements, and limited airline capacity. The carrier expects adjusted profit between 50-70 cents per share, exceeding analyst estimates of 22 cents per share. Total revenue is projected to rise 11-13% and capacity is estimated to be down 5-7% compared to the same period in 2019. This optimism comes despite growing risks of an economic recession.

site_title: Boris Johnson comeback bid adds drama to UK political soap opera
summary: Boris Johnson is reportedly planning to join the UK's prime ministerial race to succeed Liz Truss, citing it as being in the "national interest". This move has sparked controversy, with supporters demanding his return and critics labeling it an "insult" to the British people. Johnson's announcement comes after he dropped hints during a parliamentary question session in July, declaring "hasta la vista baby". The UK's economic struggles, including a second consecutive month of contraction, have been cited as a key factor in Johnson's decision.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson makes a statement at Downing Street in London, Britain, July 7, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: BMW launches its new 7 Series with a snazzy lifestyle programme
summary: BMW has launched its new 7 Series, priced from S$578,888 with Certificate Of Entitlement, available only as a 735i with a 3.0-litre, six-cylinder engine. The car features luxury features such as crystal lights, touchscreens, and electric doors. To entice customers, BMW has introduced the BMW Excellence Club, a privilege program offering perks like free airport transfers, special care packages, and exclusive access to cultural events. The program is designed to appeal to high-end customers, with a focus on added value beyond the vehicle itself.

images.alt_text: The luxury automaker plans to build at least six fully electric BMW models in the United States by 2030.

site_title: New code of conduct to lay out standards for providers of ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ services
summary: Singapore has unveiled a new code of conduct for "Buy Now, Pay Later" (BNPL) providers, setting standards for restrictions on outstanding payments, fee transparency, and an accreditation scheme. The code, developed by industry players and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, aims to mitigate debt accumulation and protect consumers. Key components include capping outstanding payments at S$2,000, transparent fee structures, and ethical marketing practices. Accredited providers will undergo regular audits and must confirm compliance with the code annually. Existing providers have 12 months to come into full compliance.

images.alt_text: credit squeeze, taxation, purse

site_title: A 1990s relic, floppy disks get second life at California warehouse
summary: Floppy disks, a relic of the 1990s, are experiencing a resurgence in demand. Tom Persky's California-based online disk recycling service, floppydisk.com, processes around 500 disks a day. The service sells disks to industries such as embroidery, tools, and airline maintenance, which rely on the technology for data storage. Despite the rise of cloud storage and more advanced devices, the demand for floppy disks remains steady, with Persky's business continuing to thrive.

site_title: UK mortgage rates continue to increase amid political chaos
summary: UK mortgage rates have reached a 14-year high of 6.51% for a five-year fixed-rate home loan, according to Moneyfacts Group. This increase comes amid political chaos in the UK, with PM Liz Truss' premiership facing a potential implosion due to a failed economic growth plan and criticism from Tory lawmakers. The turmoil has led to a slowdown in new home sales and a drop in buyer demand, with mortgage costs also rising for shorter duration products.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as UK’s Truss resigns as PM
summary: US stocks opened lower on Oct 20 after UK Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned, adding uncertainty to markets. The Dow Jones fell 11.89 points, or 0.04%, to 30,411.92, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. The resignation follows a series of positive earnings forecasts from US companies. The decline in US stocks follows a similar trend in Europe, where stocks were dragged down by bank and healthcare shares. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's economic future is expected to impact US-EU trade talks.

site_title: UK PM Truss says she will resign
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss announced her resignation, citing the loss of faith from her party and inability to deliver promised economic policies. She accepted her party's mandate was not working and agreed to a leadership election to be completed within the next week. Truss is the shortest-serving prime minister in British history, following George Canning, who served 119 days in 1827. New Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt will lead efforts to find spending cuts to reassure investors and rebuild the country's fiscal reputation.

images.alt_text: The average five-year fixed-rate home loan has risen to 6.51 per cent on Thursday, the highest since September 2008, said financial information company Moneyfacts Group.
Polls show that British Prime Minister Liz Truss’ personal and party ratings have plummeted, with YouGov saying on Tuesday that she had become the most unpopular leader it has ever tracked.

site_title: Oil rises on China possibly easing Covid curbs
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Thursday after China considered easing Covid-19 quarantine measures for visitors, boosting hopes for increased energy demand. Brent crude futures rose $1.30 to $93.71 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.76 to $87.31 per barrel. The news comes as China, the world's largest crude importer, has stuck to strict Covid curbs this year, weighing on fuel demand. A looming EU ban on Russian crude and Opec+ production cut also supported prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Crude oil storage tanks are seen from above at the Cushing oil hub,  the delivery point for U.S. crude futures in Cushing, Oklahoma, March 24, 2016.   REUTERS/Nick Oxford/File Photo

site_title: Most Singapore households able to continue servicing mortgages amid rising interest rates
summary: Singapore households can continue servicing their mortgages despite rising interest rates, with most households able to pay their home loans. Stress tests by the Monetary Authority of Singapore found that most households can service their loans, even with a 400 basis point interest rate hike and a 10% income reduction. The proportion of non-performing mortgages is low at 0.3%, and the number of foreclosures has trended down since 2021. The government has introduced measures to tighten housing loan limits and impose a 15-month waiting period for private property owners to buy HDB resale flats.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore sold a total of 987 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), with more than 913 units launched in September.
Since Sep 30, private home owners must wait 15 months after the sale of their current home before they can buy a non-subsidised HDB resale flat..

Despite the rising rental prices, volumes for both the HDB and condo markets remain strong as “it is still a landlord’s market now”, said Christine Sun, Orange Tee & Tie’s senior vice president of research and analytics.
According to Huttons, rents of private homes are estimated to increase up to 10 per cent in H2 2022.
HDB plans to launch up to 23,000 new flats in 2023.

site_title: Six more artists reimagine Louis Vuitton Capucines bags
summary: Louis Vuitton's fourth annual Artycapucines collection features six reimagined Capucines bags by renowned artists, including Daniel Buren, Kennedy Yanko, and Ugo Rondinone. Each artist brings their unique style and vision to the project, resulting in striking designs that blend art and fashion. The limited edition bags, available in 200 pieces per design, will be released worldwide on October 21 and are expected to sell out quickly.

images.alt_text: Sales in Europe, the United States and Japan were up sharply since the start of the year.
Lego brights by Burberry

site_title: New contemporary art event boosts Paris scene
summary: Paris is positioning itself as a global center for contemporary art sales with the revamped "Paris+ par Art Basel" event, attracting international buyers and building on the city's rich cultural legacy. The event, held at the Grand Palais Ephémère, features works by renowned artists such as Picasso, Matisse, and Giacometti, with prices ranging from €1,000 to €30 million. Organizers expect bumper sales, with gallery owners expressing optimism about the event's success, citing the in-person art scene's reawakening and the influence of social media.

images.alt_text:
A visitor walks past the "Buste de Diego" (1961) by artist Alberto Giacometti as Paris+ par Art Basel international contemporary art fair opens in Paris, France, October 19, 2022. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann

NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES
Paris+ par Art Basel director Clement Delepine poses during an interview with Reuters as the international contemporary art fair opens in Paris, France, October 19, 2022. REUTERS/Christian Hartmann

site_title: Sweden’s home price slump worsens to reach double digits
summary: Sweden's housing market has experienced its largest decline since the 2008 financial crisis, with single-family home prices plummeting 11.2% in September, according to the HOX Sweden housing-price index. The decline is attributed to higher energy costs and mortgage rate increases, which are deterring buyers. The Riksbank, Sweden's central bank, has forecast a peak-to-trough fall of 18% in housing prices, and analysts predict a potential downside risk to this projection. The Swedish housing market is now among the bellwethers for the global housing cooldown.

images.alt_text: The funding squeeze faced by Sweden’s property companies stems from their floating-rate bonds and near-term maturities in an environment with rising interest rates.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reports higher Q3 2022 distributable income
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 12.1% increase in Q3 2022 distributable income to S$50.1 million, driven by a 15.4% growth in operational cash flows. The growth was attributed to all three business segments, with the energy transition segment boosted by the first distribution from Aramco Gas Pipeline Company. KIT expects assets under management to increase to S$6.1 billion after new acquisitions in Q4 2022.

images.alt_text: Jopy Chiang assumed the role of chief executive at KIT’s trustee-manager just over a year ago.
KIT, KAIF and KI are acquiring South Korean waste management platform EMK.
Running since 2019, BKR2 has an operating capacity of approximately 465 MW and is located off the coast of Lower Saxony in the North Sea, Germany.

site_title: The Polestar 3 is an SUV for people who care
summary: Polestar, a Volvo spin-off, has unveiled its new SUV, the Polestar 3, to sustain sales growth and join the premium electric vehicle market. With a target of 125,000 cars in 2023, Polestar aims to reach 290,000 vehicles by 2025. The 3 features a low drag coefficient, efficient range, and advanced safety features, including autonomous driving capabilities. Despite being part of a crowded market, Polestar's focus on sustainability and performance is seen as a key factor in its success. The company's CEO, Thomas Ingenlath, is confident that the Polestar 3 will meet its sales targets and propel the company's growth.

images.alt_text: Polestar said its global order intake rose to more than 50,000 since the start of 2022 - a 350% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Meet the new home design talents
summary: Home design content creators in Singapore are gaining popularity on social media platforms, with many sharing renovation tips, housekeeping hacks, and personal experiences. Influencers like Ange Foong, Ying, and Mary have amassed large followings, with Foong's account having over 21,800 followers and Mary's having over 2 million views on a viral reel. While professional interior designers are concerned about the rise of content creators, many see it as an opportunity for egalitarian design. Content creators emphasize authenticity, sharing real-life experiences and tips, and are often sponsored by brands for cleaning supplies and home appliances. Some are making a full-time profession, with Foong reportedly landing monthly brand deals.

images.alt_text: WY-TO Singapore has designed six flats in Tiong Bahru, including this one.

site_title: OCBC appoints new head for global consumer financial services
summary: OCBC appoints Sunny Quek as head of global consumer financial services, overseeing consumer banking and wealth-management business in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Greater China. Quek, a former head of consumer financial services in Singapore, led the digital transformation of customer interaction points and grew the Premier Banking business. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to drive the businesses further, with OCBC's CEO praising Quek's innovative leadership and team-building skills.

site_title: Yen softens past 150 per US dollar for first time since 1990
summary: The yen briefly weakened past 150 per US dollar in early European trading for the first time since August 1990, due to the US dollar's support from high Treasury yields. This move kept markets on high alert for potential intervention from Japanese authorities. Meanwhile, the euro rose 0.5% and the pound remained soft due to turmoil in British politics. The yen's brief weakening was a significant event, marking a rare instance of the currency falling past the 150-yen mark since 1990.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat on Thursday; most Asian markets decline
