summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat at 3,022.7, with a slight decline in local banks DBS and UOB, but a 6.1% gain for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Most Asian markets declined due to ongoing inflation worries, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng falling 0.9% and 1.4% respectively. Yeap Jun Rong, a market strategist, attributed the decline to higher-than-expected inflation numbers and increasing growth risks.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index slipped 0.1 per cent or 3.02 points to open at 3,019.78 as at 9.02 am.

RHB’s Vijay Natarajan says he will be looking at return-to-office trends and physical occupancy - such as at Manulife US Reit's Phipps Tower (pictured) - to assess potential leasing impact from the evolving hybrid working model.
Investors have reacted especially badly to the prospect of Sats raising money for a big acquisition

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as recession fears loom
summary: Australia's shares closed 1% lower at 6,730.7, snapping a two-session gain streak. Investors sought safe-haven assets amid US Federal Reserve rate-hike concerns. A disappointing jobs report supported a slower RBA rate hike in November, but a Q3 CPI data release next week will be crucial. Miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, fell 1.9-3.9%, while technology stocks dropped 3.8%. Woodside Energy rose 6.2% after raising its annual production forecast.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index slid 0.9 per cent to 6,736.2 points by 0010 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's semiconductor sector may be impacted by US export controls on China due to its reliance on US technology. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan stated that the sector's complex globalised supply chains could be affected. In other news, Singtel is expected to take a 7% hit on FY23 earnings from the Optus data breach, and Chinese markets are sinking due to a disappointing Communist Party Congress. Additionally, a Pasir Panjang redevelopment site was sold for S$1,128 per square foot, and Malaysia's election is scheduled for November 19.

site_title: UK PM on brink as political chaos deepens
summary: British Prime Minister Liz Truss faces increasing calls to resign amid plummeting personal and party ratings, following a series of controversies including a market-melting tax cut and the departure of two key ministers. Suella Braverman, the interior minister, quit after a heated row with Truss and her economic team, while another minister, Kwasi Kwarteng, was sacked and replaced by Jeremy Hunt. Truss has refused to step down, despite widespread criticism, and is facing a potential Tory leadership contest.

images.alt_text: UK Home Secretary Suella Braverman is reported to have left the government, dealing a blow to Liz Truss' government.
Truss is trying to shore up support from within the party after she was forced to scrap a vast tax-cutting plan, leading some Conservative lawmakers to call for her to be replaced.

Truss held a private meeting with members of the pro-Brexit right-wing of her party late Tuesday as she sought to steady the ship following a desperate start to the week that saw Tory MPs openly plot her downfall.

site_title: GoTo in talks with Alibaba, SoftBank for US$1b stake sale
summary: GoTo, Indonesia's largest tech company, is in talks with early backers including Alibaba and SoftBank to sell around $1 billion of their stakes to new investors. The move aims to prevent a potential stock crash when a lock-up on their holdings ends on November 30. GoTo has also discussed with investors to keep their shares for at least six months, amid concerns about a large sell-off by major shareholders. The company's market value is around $15 billion, and it has engaged Citigroup and Goldman Sachs to manage the potential sell-down.

site_title: Fifa urges broadcasters to ‘pay what women’s game deserves’ for 2023 World Cup rights
summary: FIFA has rejected bids from Italy, Germany, France, and the UK for 2023 Women's World Cup broadcast rights, citing low offers that do not reflect the popularity of women's football. FIFA's chief business officer Romy Gai said the bids are a result of a lack of willingness to pay for the women's game, despite the 2019 World Cup's record 1.12 billion viewers. Gai called on broadcasters to "pay what the women's game deserves" and seize the opportunity to grow the women's game, with the tournament set to take place in Australia and New Zealand next year.

images.alt_text: Soccer Football - FIFA Women's World Cup - UEFA Qualifiers - Scotland v Republic of Ireland - Hampden Park, Glasgow, Scotland, Britain - October 11, 2022 Republic of Ireland's Diane Caldwell shoots at goal REUTERS/Molly Darlington

site_title: Year-end novelties
summary: Luxury watch brands unveil year-end novelties as the festive season approaches. De Bethune releases the DB Kind of Two Jumping GMT, a reversible watch featuring two dials to mark its 20th anniversary, with a price tag of S$300,000. Additionally, Chopard introduces the L U C Skull One Calavera Pop Art, a 25-piece limited edition timepiece inspired by the Day of the Dead, priced at S$15,700.

images.alt_text:
scfeature20 - Profile




Credit: Ochre Home

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 22.62 points to 1,437.72. A total of 2.707 billion lots worth RM2.596 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 493 to 365.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down again
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.40% on October 20, 2022, as global markets were affected by fresh inflation and interest rate worries. The Hang Seng Index fell to 16,280.22, while China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was partially offset by reports that China was considering easing quarantine rules.

site_title: Kitchen Culture taking legal advice on shareholders’ letter on convening EGM
summary: Kitchen Culture is taking legal advice after receiving letters from shareholders questioning the validity of an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) notice. The shareholders claim the notice was not published by October 17, violating Covid-19 regulations. The company has asked shareholders to confirm if the notice was published on time, with the shareholders threatening to sue if they do not comply. Kitchen Culture has stated it is taking full advice on the matter, including SGX Catalist Rule 704(14).

images.alt_text: Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture
Ooway's clarification comes nearly a week after Kitchen Culture's board claimed Ooway had made statements with various “factual inaccuracies and mischaracterisation of events”.
Kitchen Culture was listed on SGX Catalist as a provider of solutions and products for kitchens and wardrobes.
A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.

site_title: Mercedes signs 1.5 billion euros deal with Rock Tech Lithium to push e-car drive
summary: Mercedes-Benz has signed a 1.5 billion euros deal with Rock Tech Lithium to secure 10,000 tons of battery-grade lithium hydroxide per year, starting in 2026. This will enable the luxury carmaker to rapidly scale up production of fully electric vehicles. The deal will cover enough lithium for 150,000 cars per year and support Mercedes-Benz's goal of going fully electric by the end of the decade. The supply will come from a converter in Guben, Germany, helping to localize European battery cell production.

site_title: Amazon faces UK class action suit over ‘secretive’ algorithm
summary: Amazon faces a UK class-action lawsuit over claims it uses a "secretive" algorithm to abuse its dominant position in the online marketplace. The law firm Hausfeld alleges that Amazon makes millions of customers pay more by hiding better deals on platforms to boost its own products. Amazon has denied the claim, stating it is "without merit" and confident that the issue will become clear through the legal process.

images.alt_text: That mission, the debut orbital flight of a new rocket that will compete with launchers from Elon Musk’s SpaceX, is set for the first quarter of 2023.
Amazon launched Explore in 2020, targeting those suffering cabin fever during pandemic lockdowns.
Amazon launched Prime Day in 2015 to attract new subscribers who now pay US$139 a year for shipping discounts, video streaming and other perks.

site_title: Satellite shows at Singapore Biennale
summary: The Singapore Biennale 2022 art show features satellite exhibitions at Tanjong Pagar Distripark, including "Travel Agency" by A+ Works Of Art, showcasing 11 Malaysian artists tackling various aspects of life in Malaysia. Other notable shows include "Landscape: Reinvention" by 39+ Art Space, featuring Balinese artist Kemalezedine and Laotian-born artist Savanhdary Vongpoothorn, and works by former Olympian sailor Charles Lim Yi Yong. The exhibitions run until November 6 and offer a diverse range of artistic perspectives on Malaysia and its culture.

images.alt_text:
The 7th edition of the Singapore Biennale is set to open on 16 Oct 2022, with works by more than 50 artists spread over 13 locations. 




Credit : SINGAPORE ART MUSEUM
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.

site_title: Turbulent politics threaten election gains for Malaysian markets
summary: Malaysia's general election on Nov 19 may not result in an outright majority for a single party due to a turbulent political landscape involving four competing coalitions. Investors are at risk of disappointment as the nation struggles with high inflation and a falling currency. The country's main stock gauge has been heading towards a bear market since the historic defeat of the Barisan Nasional coalition in 2018, with global investors selling Malaysian shares. A post-election rally is possible if there's a stable verdict, but uncertainty prevails.

site_title: German government bond yields hit fresh multi-year highs
summary: German government bond yields hit fresh multi-year highs, with the 10-year yield rising 8.5 basis points to 2.453% and the two-year yield up 8 basis points to 2.158%. The move comes as investors assess potential new tightening measures at the upcoming European Central Bank policy meeting, where a 75 basis point rate hike is expected. Analysts also focus on changes in rules governing long-term refinancing operations and possible quantitative tightening.

site_title: AUM Biosciences to list on Nasdaq via SPAC merger at US$400m pre-money valuation
summary: AUM Biosciences, a Singapore-headquartered biotech firm, plans to go public on Nasdaq via a SPAC merger with Mountain Crest Acquisition Corp at a pre-money valuation of $400 million. The deal, expected to close in Q1 2023, will raise approximately $69 million in cash for the company. AUM Biosciences will trade as a combined entity, Holdco, under the ticker symbol AUMB, and its CEO, Vishal Doshi, will retain his title at the new holding company.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s food and drugs agency greenlighted the use of Walvax Biotechnology’s mRNA vaccine.

site_title: Pasir Panjang redevelopment site sold at S$1,128 psf
summary: A redevelopment site at 303/305 Pasir Panjang Road in Singapore has been sold to luxury home developer Silver Edge Investment Holdings for S$475,000 above its S$18 million guide price, translating to a land rate of about S$1,128 per square foot. The site, which houses a single-storey bungalow and outhouses, was zoned "residential" and received keen interest from buyers looking to redevelop it into apartments or landed homes. Silver Edge Investment plans to redevelop the site into "niche landed homes" for homebuyers.

images.alt_text: The site has direct access to the West Coast Park and is 2 kilometres from the National University of Singapore and National University Hospital.
Homes in the Central Area will need to be at least 70 square metres for developments seeking approvals from 18 Jan 2023 onwards.
Investors should therefore not assume that Singapore property prices are a one-way street and will continue to rise unhindered.
Knight Frank’s auction and private treaty sales on Wednesday (Jun 29) also boasted several luxury properties.

site_title: Singapore’s container port operating at 85% of maximum capacity: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's container port is currently operating at 85% of its maximum capacity, with a record high container throughput of 37.5 million TEUs in 2022. Senior Minister of State for Transport Chee Hong Tat stated that the port has a buffer to meet short-term increases in demand and is expected to increase handling capacity further with the completion of additional berths. Despite global supply chain pressures, Chee noted that Singapore's strong tripartite partnerships and deployment of technology, such as autonomous vehicles, have helped maintain the port's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Exports to Singapore’s top 10 markets fell as a whole in September, dragged by a 33.8 per cent year-on-year contraction in shipments to China, compared the previous month’s 18.2 per cent decline.
Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in September grew 3.1 per cent year on year, down from the 11.4 per cent expansion in the previous month, data from Enterprise Singapore showed.

site_title: Hermes sales soar despite cost-of-living crisis and China Covid restrictions
summary: Hermes International reported a 24% revenue increase to 3.1 billion euros in the third quarter, beating analysts' estimates. Luxury shoppers in China returned to stores after Covid-19 restrictions eased, driving sales growth. The company plans to accelerate recruitment and open new stores, including a flagship in Shanghai, despite a cost-of-living crisis and geopolitical uncertainty. Hermes also plans to raise product prices by 5-10% in 2023.

site_title: Insurers should leverage technology to support wealth, health needs in Singapore: Prudential CEO
summary: Prudential Singapore CEO Dennis Tan advocates for insurers to leverage technology to support customers' health and wealth needs, particularly in Singapore's digitally savvy and ageing society. With rising longevity, Tan believes digital tools can enable proactive measures to remain healthier and be financially prepared for a longer life. Insurers can offer better advice, predict health outcomes, and provide personalized information, improving customer satisfaction and efficiencies. Tan emphasizes the importance of human touch in insurance, while technology streamlines processes and enables real-time support.

images.alt_text: Prudential has also joined the Hang Seng Composite Index, it said on Monday.
Annual premium equivalent sales - a measure of new business activity - were up 9 per cent to US$2.2 million, as conditions started to normalise in most markets.

site_title: Indonesia central bank raises benchmark interest rate by 50 bps to 4.75% as expected
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.75% as expected, aiming to curb inflation and slow capital outflows. This move follows a 50 bps increase in September, marking the first consecutive 50 bp increases since 2016. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated the decision was to bring inflation back within target in the first half of next year and ensure the rupiah reflects its fundamental value against the US dollar.

site_title: English winemakers toast summer heatwaves
summary: English winemakers are benefiting from the country's warmer climate, which has led to ideal growing conditions for grape varieties such as pinot noir, chardonnay, and riesling. The perfect climate and long growing season are allowing England to produce exceptional sparkling wines, with Gusbourne Estate's head winemaker Charlie Holland comparing the current conditions to those in 1970s and 80s Champagne. However, climate change poses a threat to the industry, with forecasters warning that England's vineyards may need to adapt to new grape varieties by 2040, potentially altering the country's wine-making landscape.

site_title: Warburg Pincus invests US$350m to form South-east Asian digital insurance firm with ex-FWD exec
summary: Warburg Pincus has invested US$350 million in Oona Insurance, a digital general insurance firm in South-east Asia. The firm, co-founded by former FWD Singapore CEO Abhishek Bhatia, aims to grow through a "buy-and-build" strategy, acquiring businesses in Indonesia and the Philippines to introduce products such as travel and health insurance. General insurance is seen as an underpenetrated industry in the region, ripe for digital disruption. Oona plans to leverage technology to create a customer-focused organization with a strong tech and brand spine.

images.alt_text: “With rising longevity, it is essential that we take  proactive measures to remain healthier and be financially prepared for a longer life,” said Dennis Tan, chief executive of Prudential Singapore.

site_title: Bills tabled in Parliament to repeal Section 377A, amend Constitution to protect definition of marriage
summary: Singapore Parliament has tabled two bills to repeal Section 377A, which criminalizes sex between men, and amend the Constitution to protect the definition of marriage as between a man and woman. The bills, set to be debated on November 28, will be voted on separately, with the repeal requiring a simple majority and the amendment requiring a two-thirds majority. The move aims to address concerns that the law could be struck down by the courts and follows Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's decision to repeal the law, citing shifting societal attitudes.

site_title: Europe: Markets open mixed after US, Asia losses
summary: European markets opened mixed on October 20, 2022, following losses in Asia and the US due to concerns over inflation and rising interest rates. The FTSE 100 in London fell 0.3% to 6,904.82 points, while the Frankfurt DAX shed 0.5% and the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.3%. The US Federal Reserve warned of "more pessimistic" economic prospects amid heightened inflation and rising interest rates.

site_title: Taiwan September export orders contract, but strong electronics sales reported
summary: Taiwan's export orders contracted 3.1% in September to $60.93 billion, a slightly less severe drop than expected. Strong sales of new consumer electronics, such as iPhones, supported the decline. Orders for telecommunications products rose 5% and electronic products jumped 6%, driven by demand for high-end computing and stockpiling. The government expects the year-end holiday season to boost momentum, but notes uncertainties like global inflation, the war in Ukraine, and China's lockdowns.

site_title: Proportion of non-performing loans in corporate sector falls despite rising interest rates: Alvin Tan
summary: The proportion of non-performing loans in the corporate sector in Singapore has decreased to 2.5% in June, down from 3.1% a year ago, according to Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. This decline occurred despite rising interest rates, with SME loan volumes expanding by 11.5% year-on-year in August. Tan noted that most companies are resilient to further interest rate increases and earnings shocks, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's stress tests showing that most corporates would be able to weather the economic storm.

images.alt_text: Singapore-denominated issuance volume reached a 9-year high at S$30 billion, mostly from corporate issuers.
The June 2022 edition of Atradius Payment Practices Barometer survey also reported that in Asia, business-to-business (B2B) debt write-offs have risen by 60 per cent compared to a year ago.

site_title: Eurozone's current account deficit widens on soaring energy bill
summary: The eurozone's current account deficit widened to 26.32 billion euros (S$36.7 billion) in August, up from a 19.96 billion euro deficit in July, due to soaring energy costs. This represents a 0.1% deficit of the gross domestic product, down from a 2.8% surplus in the previous year. The increase is attributed to the bloc's reliance on imported energy.

site_title: Hong Kong’s July-September unemployment eases to 3.9%
summary: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate eased to 3.9% in the July-September quarter, improving for the fifth consecutive period. This decline is attributed to economic activities reviving in an easing Covid situation, supported by a consumption voucher scheme. The unemployment rate stood at 4.1% in the June-August period. The labour market outlook depends on further domestic economic revival, according to the Hong Kong government.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall, losses capped by hopes of China Covid rules easing
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi fell 19.35 points, or 0.86%, to 2,218.09, tracking Wall Street weakness. Shares recovered from early losses on reports of China's possible Covid-19 restriction cuts. The Korean won weakened, and bond yields rose. Security brokerages slumped amid concerns of a liquidity crunch. Foreigners sold shares worth 24 billion won, snapping a 13-session buying streak.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 12.51 points or 0.56 per cent at 2,237.44.

site_title: Kinuyo Tanaka: Japan’s original screen queen
summary: Japanese actress and director Kinuyo Tanaka, known as the "screen queen" of her time, is being celebrated in a Singapore retrospective of her films. Born in 1909, Tanaka appeared in over 250 films, working with renowned directors like Kenji Mizoguchi and Yasujiro Ozu. She was also a pioneering female director, making groundbreaking cinema in the 1950s and 1960s that highlighted the female experience. Tanaka's films, including "The Life of Oharu," "Ugetsu," and "Mother," are being screened with new 4K digital restorations, offering a rare opportunity to experience her work on the big screen.

images.alt_text: Mina Kaye plays the iconic Judy Garland in End Of The Rainbow.

The 7th edition of the Singapore Biennale is set to open on 16 Oct 2022, with works by more than 50 artists spread over 13 locations. 




Credit : SINGAPORE ART MUSEUM

The Singapore Writers Festival, headed by Pooja Nansi (centre), returns post-pandemic more ambitious than ever. This year's festival stretches over 3 weekends and has more than 200 in-person programmes.

site_title: China debates reduction of quarantine for inbound travellers
summary: China is debating a reduction in mandatory quarantine time for inbound travelers, potentially cutting the current 10-day period to 2 days in a hotel and 5 days at home. The move, part of a new Covid-protocol iteration, aims to ease China's isolation from the world. However, the changes may not be enough for a sustained market rebound, with experts suggesting a complete lifting of Covid measures is needed. The decision will need approval from senior leaders, and its impact on China's economically damaging Covid-zero strategy remains unclear.

images.alt_text: The current seven-day hotel quarantine period for travellers from Hong Kong could be cut to four days by the end of the year because the incubation period for most Covid variants is about three days.

site_title: Singapore semiconductor sector may be hit by US export controls on China: MTI
summary: Singapore's semiconductor sector may be impacted by US export controls on China, despite not having "granular information" on the extent of the impact. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan said the sector's reliance on US technology could be affected by the new regulations. The government is working to strengthen business continuity plans, diversify supply chains, and attract leading global companies to anchor investments. The electronics sector is a significant contributor to Singapore's manufacturing output, and the government aims to develop more semiconductor research and engineering talent.

images.alt_text: ASML has told its workers in the US to refrain from servicing customers in China.
Yangtze Memory was among more than 30 organisations that the US Commerce Department put on its so-called unverified list, which restricts their ability to buy American technology.

site_title: Electric planes in Australia seen halving costs on short flights
summary: Australian regional airline Rex plans to introduce electric- and hydrogen-powered aircraft in 2024, reducing operating costs on short flights by up to 50%. The converted Saab 340 aircraft will be suitable for routes under an hour, such as Sydney-Wagga Wagga. Rex will still use turbine-powered planes on longer flights. The partnership with Dovetail Electric Aviation aims to achieve certification within four years, opening up new routes and potentially lower fares. This move is expected to increase service frequency and accessibility.

site_title: Tesla flags its cars not ready to be approved as fully self-driving this year
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said the company's advanced driver assistant software won't gain regulatory approval in 2022, indicating its cars are not yet ready to be driven without human oversight. The company's "Full Self-Driving" (FSD) software, which enables features like lane changing and parking, will be upgraded at the end of the year but won't have full autonomous vehicle approval. Musk acknowledged the technology still needs improvement, and regulators will scrutinize its safety. Tesla aims to provide an update to FSD in 2023 to demonstrate its safety.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk called lithium prices “crazy expensive”.
Tesla cited higher costs related to a slower-than-expected ramp up in output at the new factories, as well as difficulties shipping vehicles.

site_title: Protect the ocean, protect the economy
summary: The global ocean's economic value is equivalent to the world's seventh largest economy, estimated at US$24 trillion. Its annual value is at least US$2.5 trillion, with seafood, shipping, and tourism contributing significantly. However, ocean health is under threat due to climate change, nature loss, and pollution, posing substantial risks to its long-term survival. A WWF study found that a business-as-usual approach could leave the world's economy US$8.4 trillion out of pocket over the next 15 years, emphasizing the need for a sustainable blue economy transition.

images.alt_text:
strait16 - Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Dr Vivian Balakrishnan,




Credit: United Nations Ocean Conference

site_title: China gathers chip firms for emergency talks after Biden curbs
summary: China's top technology overseer has convened emergency meetings with leading semiconductor companies, including Yangtze Memory Technologies and Dawning Information Industry, amid US President Biden's sweeping chip restrictions. The meetings aimed to assess the damage and pledged support for the critical sector. However, officials appeared uncertain about the way forward and refrained from hinting about counter-measures. The US curbs, which limit the sale of semiconductors and chip-making equipment to Chinese customers, are expected to have a significant impact on China's chip industry, potentially forcing the country to focus on mature technologies and rely on domestic demand.

images.alt_text: The nation’s markets have been among the worst performers globally this year, leaving investors looking to the leadership gathering for policy signs to drive a recovery.
ASML has told its workers in the US to refrain from servicing customers in China.
Yangtze Memory was among more than 30 organisations that the US Commerce Department put on its so-called unverified list, which restricts their ability to buy American technology.
The US planned to review licences for non-Chinese factories in China hit by the new restrictions on a case-by-case basis.
South Korean rival SK Hynix has purchased Intel’s Nand flash memory chip manufacturing business in Dalian and produces Dram chips at another China-based facility.

site_title: Tokenize Xchange eyes institutional clients and safeguarding assets as priorities
summary: Hong Qi Yu, CEO of Tokenize Xchange, emphasizes the importance of safety and security in the digital asset ecosystem, citing the need for stricter frameworks and regulation. The company has prioritized security and is adapting to the industry's shifts, focusing on institutional investors and building a separate platform for over-the-counter trades. Tokenize aims to become the dominant player in the Web3 space in Asia, leveraging the potential use cases of blockchain technology and token-based economics.

images.alt_text: “(Consumers) seem to be irrationally oblivious about the risks of cryptocurrency trading,” Menon said at a seminar on the digital asset ecosystem in Singapore.
Blockchain.com, which was valued at US$14 billion in March views Singapore as an attractive location to grow its institutional customers and team.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB maintains ‘add’ on Wilmar, cuts target price as valuations weaken
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB have maintained their "add" rating on Wilmar International, despite cutting its target price to S$4.68 from S$5.69 due to weakening valuations of its listed subsidiaries. The company's share price has declined 15% to S$3.52 year-to-date, but analysts expect strong earnings in the first half of FY2022, with a core net profit of US$600-650 million in Q3. They believe Wilmar's long-term business prospects remain strong, but market sentiment is weak due to inflationary pressures and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: CPO futures contracts on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives market are up 6.6 per cent since the beginning of the year. But since late April, the commodity is down about 33.3 per cent.
Maybank has lowered Wilmar's projected net profit after tax for FY2022 to FY2024 has been lowered by 1-11 per cent.

site_title: Nokia quarterly operating profit lags expectation as margin drops
summary: Nokia reported a quarterly operating profit of 658 million euros, below market expectations, despite strong demand for 5G equipment. The company expects growth in its markets in 2023, driven by new 5G deals in regions like India. Net sales grew 6% in constant currency, beating estimates, but the comparable operating margin fell to 10.5% due to timing effects. CEO Pekka Lundmark believes Nokia is on a path to outperform the market and achieve long-term margin targets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Thursday, October 20, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.92% to 27,006.96, and the Topix index falling 0.51% to 1,895.41. Renewed concerns over inflation and the Chinese economy outweighed a boost from the weakening yen, which boosted Japanese exporters.

site_title: South Korea central bank says private consumption to weaken, but not steeply
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, expects private consumption to weaken modestly due to slower growth in real purchasing power and rising interest rates. The recovery is expected to be gradual, with services spending softening and goods spending remaining weak. However, overseas expenditure is likely to increase with countries opening up borders. The bank warns that private consumption may face heavier downward pressure depending on the speed and degree of interest rate rises and global economic slowdown. A 50-basis-point rate hike is expected to drag down private consumption by 0.06 percentage points.

site_title: Standard Chartered hires James Lye as global head of international banking
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed James Lye as its global head of international banking, effective November 1. Lye, a former Mediacorp actor, brings over 20 years of banking experience, most recently as head of markets for Citibank International Personal Bank Singapore. He will lead the bank's international banking team, focusing on driving focused execution to turbocharge the business. This appointment comes as the bank has doubled its international banking team in the last three years, responding to growing demand from affluent clients for cross-border wealth management.

images.alt_text: Transformational and structural trends present an attractive set of opportunities especially in Asia, says Benjamin Hung, CEO, Asia, Standard Chartered.
Efforts to reassure bankers that they can continue to finance oil, gas and even coal come less than a month before the COP27 climate summit in Egypt.
DBS, HSBC, Standard Chartered bank buildings in the CBD area.
Standard Chartered Vietnam chief executive officer Michele Wee notes many potential synergies between Vietnam and Singapore.

site_title: India’s economic growth outlook stagnates, stuck in lower gear: poll
summary: India's economic growth outlook is expected to stagnate, with inflation staying above the Reserve Bank of India's tolerance band, according to a Reuters poll. The economy is forecast to grow below its potential, with annual growth rates of 6.0% in the third quarter and 4.4% in the fourth quarter. Despite recent interest rate hikes, inflation is expected to average 6.7% in 2023 and 5.2% in 2024, driven by a falling rupee and soaring energy prices.

images.alt_text: The RBI last month cut its economic growth outlook for the current financial year to 7 per cent from a previous 7.2 per cent.
Transformational and structural trends present an attractive set of opportunities especially in Asia, says Benjamin Hung, CEO, Asia, Standard Chartered.

site_title: China city eases rules to address population, property slowdown
summary: China's city of Ningbo has relaxed rules to allow property owners to become permanent residents, aiming to boost housing sales and address slowing population growth. The new rule, posted last week, removes the requirement for applicants to work in the city, making it easier for buyers to obtain a regional permit. This move may help Ningbo maintain residents, as China's population is poised to peak this year, and could add incentives to purchase a home in the city.

images.alt_text: The 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) opened on Oct 16 in Beijing.

site_title: America and China don’t need to knock each other out to win
summary: US-China competition has intensified with the House speaker's visit to Taiwan, prompting China to conduct live-fire military exercises and missile tests in the Taiwan Strait. The Biden administration has also imposed sweeping export controls to prevent China from acquiring advanced semiconductors and equipment. This development is part of the US's efforts to outcompete China and shape the future of the international order, particularly in response to China's growing cooperation with Russia. The US is seeking to maintain its influence and security in a world where China and Russia are increasingly assertive.

images.alt_text: On Oct 7, the US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security announced major controls on exports to China of advanced semiconductors, chip-making equipment and supercomputer components.
The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index sank 7.1 per cent, its steepest one-day decline since May 9, putting the gauge at its lowest closing level in more than nine years.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop and dollar rises as inflation, rate fears return
summary: Asian markets plummeted, with Hong Kong shedding 3% and Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei all losing at least 1%. The decline follows a sell-off on Wall Street and is driven by surging inflation, interest rate hikes, and recession fears. The dollar regained strength, adding to inflationary pressure, while concerns about the Chinese economy and a delay in releasing third-quarter growth data fueled the sell-off. Investors are also bracing for potential earnings misses and a weak GDP outlook.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed in early trade, with profit-takers weighing on Hong Kong after a healthy three-day run-up, while there were also losses in Shanghai, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: Chinese markets are sinking fast as Xi fails to boost confidence
summary: Chinese markets are experiencing a significant selloff due to the disappointing outcome of the Communist Party Congress, which failed to provide relief from strict Covid-Zero policies and address the country's property crisis. The benchmark CSI 300 Index has fallen over 2% this week, while high-yield dollar bonds have declined for seven straight days to a record low. Analysts attribute the weakness to slower economic growth, both cyclically and structurally, and the lack of measures for the crisis-hit property sector.

images.alt_text: The PBOC may delay a cut to the reserve requirement ratio, or the share of cash banks must put in reserves, to November as the liquidity gap is small currently.
The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index sank 7.1 per cent, its steepest one-day decline since May 9, putting the gauge at its lowest closing level in more than nine years.

site_title: Musk says excited by Twitter deal despite overpaying
summary: Elon Musk expressed excitement about his pending Twitter acquisition, despite acknowledging that himself and other investors are overpaying for the social media company. Musk described Twitter as an asset that has "languished" for a long time, with long-term potential greater than its current value. He also spoke optimistically about Tesla's future, stating it could be worth more than the combined value of Apple and Saudi Aramco. A Delaware judge has paused Twitter's lawsuit against Musk, giving him until October 28 to close the deal.

images.alt_text: The social media company updated its employee FAQ page this week to alert staff that they won’t be able to access or trade shares from the Equity Award Centre.
Elon Musk has raised the prospect of reducing Twitter’s reliance on advertising, and instead incorporating it into an “everything app”, known as X, with online payments.

site_title: Australia’s stalled hiring supports shift to slower rate hikes
summary: Australia's job market showed signs of slowing down in September, with employment advancing by just 900 people, far shy of the forecast 25,000 gain. The jobless rate remained at 3.5% and unemployment held steady. This data suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is unlikely to hike interest rates further this year, contradicting the consensus view of two more quarter-point hikes. The RBA is expected to keep interest rates steady next month, with a pause in hikes possible by December.

images.alt_text: GIC chief executive Lim Chow Kiat told Reuters in an interview that rising inflation poses a big risk and that central banks needed to get it under control to ensure global economic stability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.13 points or 0.08% to 1413.97. Volume reached 89.54 million lots worth RM51.40 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 132 to 106.

site_title: Ooway says no conditions tied to S$1.5m interest-free loan offered to Kitchen Culture
summary: Ooway Group has clarified that its S$1.5 million interest-free loan to Kitchen Culture did not come with any pre-conditions, contrary to Kitchen Culture's previous claim. The loan offered by Ooway Group included no interest payable and an option to extend or convert the loan to equity shares after the initial term expires. Kitchen Culture's board claimed Ooway had made "factual inaccuracies and mischaracterisation of events," but Ooway has disputed these claims, stating that the terms were as previously stated.

images.alt_text: Kitchen Culture was listed on SGX Catalist as a provider of solutions and products for kitchens and wardrobes.
A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.
Lau Kay Heng has been appointed vice-chairman and non-executive director of the group’s board, while Peter Lim joins Kitchen Culture as an independent director.
Two employees had informed the company that they were not the recorded recipients of the cash cheques, Kitchen Culture said in an April 2022 filing.
Kitchen Culture's subsidiary goes into liquidation
Kitchen Culture's AGM to review a turbulent FY2021

site_title: Gold at three-week lows as dollar, bond yields stay elevated
summary: Gold prices dropped to a three-week low, reaching $1,624.98 per ounce, amid rising US dollar and Treasury yields. The dollar index held steady, while 10-year Treasury yields hit a peak since mid-2008. The Federal Reserve's report on US economic activity showed firms growing more pessimistic, increasing expectations for a fourth straight 75-basis-point rate hike next month. Gold is considered a hedge against inflation, but higher interest rates increase its opportunity cost.

images.alt_text: Although traditionally seen as a hedge against inflation, interest rate hikes to control soaring prices have reduced bullion’s appeal since it yields no interest.

site_title: Singtel to take 7% hit on FY23 earnings from Optus data breach: UOBKH
summary: Singtel is forecasted to take a 7% hit on FY23 earnings due to a data breach by Optus, with a provision of around S$240 million anticipated in Q2 2023, including a regulatory fine of A$2.2 million (S$2 million). The hit is smaller than expected as Optus will only bear the cost of passport replacements for 100,000-150,000 affected customers, rather than the previously estimated 1.4 million customers.

images.alt_text: Optus said it intends to “fully engage with the OAIC and ACMA as they undertake investigations”.
Companies ought to provide more prompt disclosures of the cyber breaches they have been afflicted by.

site_title: Bank of Japan to conduct emergency bond buying as yen teeters near 150
summary: The Bank of Japan announced emergency bond-buying operations to stabilize the yen, which teetered near a 32-year-low of 150 to the dollar. The central bank will buy $667 million in government debt to put a floor under bond prices, maintaining its "yield curve control" policy. The move came as the yen was affected by the widening interest rate difference between the US and Japan. The BOJ will buy 100 billion yen of bonds with maturities of 10-20 years and another 100 billion of bonds with maturities of 5-10 years.

site_title: Japan’s extended trade gap reinforces pressure on tumbling yen
summary: Japan's trade gap widened for the second consecutive month, reaching a record 2.09 trillion yen, as the weaker yen pushed up import costs. Exports rose 28.9% due to increased shipments to China, the US, and Europe, but the prolonged trade deficit will weigh on Japan's economic recovery from the pandemic. The yen's slide has also triggered government intervention, with officials warning of potential additional measures if the currency continues to fall.

images.alt_text: The yen hit 149.91 to the dollar in overnight trading, its weakest since 1990. The greenback stood around 149.84 in early Asia trading on Thursday.

site_title: Vietnam sees fastest growth in South-east Asia for two years
summary: Vietnam is projected to maintain its title as South-east Asia's fastest-growing economy through 2023, with a 8% GDP growth in 2022 and 6.5% in 2023, according to Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh. The government expects 2023 inflation to reach 4.5%, compared to 4% this year. Despite challenges and a worsening global outlook, Chinh believes the projections are "reasonable" and aims to balance economic recovery with inflation control. The government will manage policies to support economic growth while strictly controlling loans to prevent fuelling inflation.

images.alt_text: Investors are getting increasingly optimistic about Vietnam, partly due to rising consumption driven by a middle class population expected to expand by as many as 36 million people by 2030.
SEA is projected to grow by four to five per cent annually over the next 10 years, led by Vietnam.

site_title: Chinese banks maintain benchmark lending rates as yuan slides
summary: China's central bank maintained benchmark lending rates for the second month, with the one-year loan prime rate remaining at 3.65% and the five-year rate unchanged at 4.3%. The decision follows a weakening yuan and a delay in monetary easing, with the People's Bank of China possibly delaying a cut to the reserve requirement ratio to November. The move aims to maintain liquidity and counter capital outflows fueled by the widening interest rate divergence between the PBOC and the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 500 billion yuan (S$99.2 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.75 per cent

site_title: Malaysia votes on Nov 19; nominations for candidates on Nov 5
summary: Malaysia will hold its 15th general election on November 19, with nominations for candidates taking place on November 5. Approximately 21.1 million Malaysians, including 5 million first-time young voters, are eligible to vote. The campaign period will last 14 days, longer than the 11 days in the 2018 election. The election will determine 222 parliamentary seats and 113 state seats, with the ruling coalition, Barisan Nasional, contesting 191 parliamentary seats. Two-time former prime minister Mahathir Mohamad will defend his Langkawi parliamentary seat, while opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has turned down a proposed coalition with Mahathir.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Election Commission (EC) chairman, Abdul Ghani Salleh speaks during a press conference in Putrajaya on October 20, 2022. - Malaysia will hold elections on November 19, officials said on October 20.
About 21.1 million Malaysians, including five million first-time young voters, are eligible to vote in the upcoming polls.

site_title: Focusing on a path to profitability key for fintechs amid weaker economy
summary: Singapore Fintech Festival 2022 focuses on fintechs' path to profitability amid weaker economy. Industry expert Rebecca Martin emphasizes the need for companies to adapt and prioritize profitability. She notes that companies with a focus on partnership will perform better in the current environment, shifting from growth-oriented models. This year's festival highlights the importance of financial stability in the face of global market volatility and economic challenges.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Fintech Festival returns as an in-person event for the first time since 2019 (pictured) as Covid-19 restrictions are eased.

site_title: Key iPhone supplier warns smartphone demand will continue to fall
summary: Murata Manufacturing, a key iPhone supplier, expects a drop in smartphone sales to continue into 2023, led by a downturn in China. The company's president, Norio Nakajima, attributes the decline to consumers' reluctance to upgrade during an economic downturn, fueled by interest rate hikes and intellectual property issues with Chinese firms. Despite sustained demand for high-end phones, Murata's shares have slumped 20% this year due to declining shipments. The company forecasts a global handset market of 1.2 billion units for the current fiscal year, down from 1.36 billion last fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Demand for higher-priced iPhone 14 Pro models is stronger than for the entry-level versions.
Apple made the announcement on Monday (Sep 26), less than 3 weeks after the iPhone 14’s unveiling.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as miners weigh; Woodside climbs
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.9% to 6,736.2 points on Thursday, dragged by mining and tech stocks. Woodside Energy surged 7.27% after raising its annual production forecast and posting record quarterly revenue. Energy stocks gained 3.5% due to firmer oil prices, while mining stocks fell 1.2% due to weaker iron ore and copper prices. The tech sub-index fell 3.1% and Zip Co rose 8.6% after reporting strong transaction volumes.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index finishes 0.3 per cent higher.

site_title: Japan’s Sept imports jump 45.9% y-o-y to record: MOF
summary: Japan's imports surged 45.9% in September, a record high, driven by a 49.9% increase in August. Exports rose 28.9% in the same period, exceeding the median estimate. The trade balance turned into a deficit of 2.094 trillion yen, higher than expected.

site_title: Britons skipping meals in cost of living crisis: poll
summary: Millions of Britons are skipping meals due to the cost-of-living crisis, with half of UK households cutting back on meal frequency and 80% finding it difficult financially. The UK's decision to curb its energy price freeze is expected to leave millions at risk of fuel poverty. Consumer group Which? warned that the crisis is leading to devastating impacts, including struggling to eat healthily. The group calls for the government to clarify support for those struggling to make ends meet and ensure consumers are not left out in the cold.

images.alt_text: The average weekly number of homes reserved at its sales sites in the nine weeks since Aug 1 fell to 191 per week, compared with 218 per week in the same period last year
Truss is trying to shore up support from within the party after she was forced to scrap a vast tax-cutting plan, leading some Conservative lawmakers to call for her to be replaced.
UK Home Secretary Suella Braverman is reported to have left the government, dealing a blow to Liz Truss' government.

site_title: Tesla confirms plans to build lithium refinery in Texas
summary: Tesla has confirmed plans to build a lithium refinery on the Texas Gulf Coast, with CEO Elon Musk calling lithium prices "crazy expensive". The Austin-based company aims to gain control over the electric vehicle battery supply chain. The project, which would process raw ore material into production-ready lithium hydroxide, was previously considered in Louisiana but now appears to be focused on Texas. Musk has encouraged entrepreneurs to refine lithium to ease supply bottlenecks, a move that could help stabilize the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.70% at the open on October 20, 2022, due to lingering worries about surging inflation and interest rate hikes potentially tipping economies into recession. The Hang Seng Index fell to 16,230.79, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The declines were attributed to concerns over global economic instability.

site_title: BMW invests US$1.7b to build electric vehicles in US
summary: BMW is investing US$1.7 billion to build electric vehicles in the US by 2030, with plans to produce at least six fully electric models. The company will spend US$1 billion on a Spartanburg, South Carolina plant and US$700 million on a battery assembly facility in Woodruff, South Carolina, creating at least 300 jobs. The investment aims to increase energy density, charging speed, and range by up to 30% with a new battery format.

images.alt_text: Like other carmakers, BMW has had to contend with shortages of semiconductors and supply chain disruptions related to the pandemic that have slowed the production of EVs.

site_title: US awards US$2.8b for EV battery, grid projects
summary: The Biden administration is awarding $2.8 billion in grants to US companies to boost electric vehicle battery and mineral production. The American Battery Material Initiative aims to strengthen critical mineral supply chains, with 20 companies in 12 states winning grants for projects such as battery-grade lithium and nickel production, recycling, and commercial-scale facilities. The goal is to secure a reliable and sustainable supply of critical minerals for US electric vehicles by 2030, with President Biden aiming for 50% of new vehicles to be electric or plug-in hybrid by then.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Thursday after US losses
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday due to US stock losses, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.01% to 26,981.75. US Treasury yields jumped as recession worries deepened. The broader Topix index also fell 0.76%. The decline was attributed to the US stock market's downturn, with the benchmark index losing ground from its recent records.

site_title: Geely’s Chinese billionaire eyes bigger stake in Aston Martin
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Shufu is considering increasing his stake in Aston Martin to nearly 10% in a bid to foster collaboration and share technology and electrification expertise. Li's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group currently holds a 7.6% stake in the luxury car maker, which has struggled since its 2018 IPO. A larger stake could help Geely tap into Aston Martin's brand appeal and expand into new markets. However, any significant increase in stake may face opposition from existing shareholders, including Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund and Canadian billionaire Lawrence Stroll.

site_title: GM considers adding midsized plug-in pickup to its Hummer line
summary: General Motors is considering adding an electric midsized pickup truck to its Hummer line, aiming to cater to demand for lower-emissions cars. The smaller Hummer is still a design concept, but it has a good chance of going into production and is seen as a priority project. This move aligns with GM's $35 billion electric vehicle strategy, which includes building 30 EVs by 2025. A mid-sized Hummer would compete with other electric pickup trucks, such as Rivian's R1T and Ford's F-150 Lightning, and would help GM expand its market presence in Europe.

images.alt_text: The Changwon facility, which will build GM’s so-called next-generation vehicles including an all-new Chevrolet crossover, is currently being remodeled and expanded as part of a plan that kicked off last year.

site_title: Japan’s finance minister vows ‘appropriate steps’ to tackle volatile yen moves
summary: Japan's finance minister, Shunichi Suzuki, vowed to take "appropriate steps" against excessive yen volatility, following its 32-year low and a slide towards the $150 psychological barrier. The yen hit 149.91 to the dollar in overnight trading, its weakest since 1990. Suzuki emphasized that rapid and one-sided yen declines are undesirable and that the government will monitor currency market developments with urgency.

images.alt_text: The yen has fallen against the US dollar, to its lowest level since 1990.
The yen traded near a 32-year trough to the dollar at 149 yen on Wednesday, putting the major psychological barrier of 150 in focus.
Japan's imports rose 45.9 per cent in September from a year earlier to the highest on record, government data showed on Thursday.

site_title: Chip industry’s China crisis hammers lam but may spare ASML
summary: The Biden administration's trade restrictions on China are affecting the global chip-equipment industry, but not equally. ASML, a Dutch company, expects a "fairly limited" impact from the export controls, which will spare it from the brunt of the restrictions. In contrast, Lam Research, a US-based company, will see its revenue from China decrease by $2 billion to $2.5 billion in 2023 due to the restrictions, which require it to halt supplying gear and services to some Chinese customers.

images.alt_text: ASML has a near monopoly on the manufacture of lithography systems, machines vital for chipmakers such as Intel, TSMC and Samsung

site_title: Fed says economy grew modestly but recession worry dims outlook
summary: The US Federal Reserve reported the economy expanded "modestly" through early October, but recession concerns grew amid slowing activity. US core consumer prices rose 6.6% in September, the highest level since 1982, while labor demand cooled and some districts reported a hiring freeze amid recession fears. The Fed is on track for a fourth consecutive 75 basis-point interest-rate hike in November, aiming to cool demand and bring down inflation. Recession concerns have increased, with some districts noting flat or declining activity, and investors expect interest rates to approach 5% next year.

images.alt_text: Applications to build, a proxy for future construction, rose to an annualised 1.56 million units, led by multifamily properties.

site_title: SpaceX rolls out Starlink Internet service for private jets
summary: SpaceX has launched Starlink Aviation, offering private jet internet connectivity for $12,500-$25,000 per month, plus a $150,000 one-time hardware cost. The service will begin delivering terminals in mid-2023, with reservations requiring a $5,000 payment. This move expands SpaceX's satellite internet unit into in-flight WiFi services, competing with companies like Inmarsat and ViaSat. The service will provide up to 350 Mbps internet speed, suitable for video calls and online gaming.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 28, 2021 the Space Exploration Technologies Corp. (SpaceX) headquarters in Hawthorne, California. - Elon Musk's SpaceX satellites will connect directly to T-Mobile cellphones to provide service access even in the most remote places beyond the reach of cell towers from next year, the two companies announced August 25, 2022. (Photo by Patrick T. FALLON / AFP)

site_title: Oil up in tight market as US sets release of more reserves
summary: Oil prices rose 2.6% to $92.41 a barrel, driven by US plans to release more crude from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, despite uncertain demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 3.3% to $85.55 a barrel. The release, announced by President Joe Biden, aims to stabilize prices and is expected to be repurchased if prices fall. The move counters the negative impact of a pending European Union ban on Russian crude and a 2 million barrel per day production cut by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$1.59, or 1.7 per cent, to US$90.03 per barrel on Tuesday.

The decision to make the biggest ever dip into the emergency oil reserves – usually kept for responding to situations such as hurricane-related shutdowns at oil refineries – was Joe Biden’s gambit to calm energy markets and shield the US economy from Ukraine war shocks.

site_title: Chinese stocks in US skid to lowest in more than nine years
summary: Chinese stocks listed in the US plummeted 7.1% on Wednesday, the largest one-day decline in over nine years, due to concerns over China's economic outlook and rising Covid cases. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index has dropped 75% from its peak in February 2021. Key tech companies such as Nio, Li Auto, and Alibaba Group Holding also saw significant losses. The market's sentiment remains fragile as President Xi Jinping holds the Communist Party Congress meeting, which is due to end this week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.3 per cent at 30,423.81 on Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Sembmarine, Stamford Land, Raffles Education
summary: Sabana Reit reported a record-high occupancy of 89.1% in Q3 2022. The trust signed 83,588 sq ft of new leases and renewed 71,266 sq ft of leases. Sembcorp Marine secured agreements for the conversion of two vessels into FLNG facilities. Meanwhile, shares of Sabana Reit and Sembcorp Marine declined 1.2% and 0.9%, respectively, after the announcements.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands’ net revenue more than trebles to US$756m in Q3
summary: Marina Bay Sands' net revenue more than tripled to US$756 million in Q3, driven by a tourism recovery in Singapore. This represents a significant increase from US$249 million in the same period last year. Adjusted property earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) also rose 22 times to US$343 million. However, most other properties under Las Vegas Sands saw a fall in net revenue collected.

images.alt_text: andBeyond's Africa foundation lends assistance to community gardens.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.1% to 3,019.78 at opening, following overnight losses on Wall Street. Trading was light with 92 million securities worth S$72.6 million changing hands. Gainers and losers were evenly matched at 61 to 61. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS down 0.6% and OCBC up 0.1%. The decline follows a two-day rally on Wall Street, which was driven by recession worries.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit said on Wednesday its occupancy has hit a high of 89.1 per cent in Q3 2022.

site_title: US charges Russians for shipping military equipment, Venezuelan oil
summary: US prosecutors have charged five Russian nationals, including Yury Orekhov and Artem Uss, for sanctions evasion and violating US export controls by shipping military technologies to Russian buyers. The technologies, including semiconductors, radars, and satellites, were purchased from US manufacturers and used in Russian weapons platforms seized in Ukraine. The defendants also shipped millions of barrels of Venezuelan oil to Russian buyers, working with sanctioned companies controlled by Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaska. The charges and sanctions aim to pressure Russia to stop its invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The severing of trade links and access to multinational production may cut real income by almost 12 per cent and result in a “permanent decline in real gross domestic product” for Russia.
The US believe Iranian drones were used on Monday in a morning rush hour attack on the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

site_title: US: Stocks drop on worries over inflation, rate hikes
summary: US stocks dropped 0.3% on Wednesday, snapping a two-day rally, amid concerns over inflation and potential interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 30,423.81. A jump in 10-year US Treasury yields above 4% exacerbated recession worries, despite generally strong earnings reports. Experts, including Tom Cahill, expressed concerns that inflation is unlikely to improve.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 84.8 points, or 0.28 per cent, at the open to 30439.04.

site_title: Tesla sales fall short of estimates as stronger dollar bites
summary: Tesla reported third-quarter sales of $21.5 billion, below analyst estimates, due to a stronger US dollar and production bottlenecks. Revenue rose, but profit excluding certain items exceeded expectations. The company cited higher costs related to slower-than-expected ramp up at new factories and shipping difficulties. Tesla aims to increase output and meet its target of 50% annual vehicle deliveries, but shares fell 3% following the results.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s battery-electric registrations jumped nearly 50 per cent from the January-September period last year.

site_title: Greenpeace set sights on ‘polluting’ jetsetters
summary: Greenpeace has criticized the rising number of polluting private flights from Dutch airports, with a recent study showing emissions equivalent to almost 40,000 cars per year. The study found that one out of every three private flights from Schiphol or Rotterdam Airport were used for trips under 500km. Greenpeace is calling for the aviation industry to "stop polluting and finally have climate targets," with a focus on scrapping short flights and luxury private jets for the wealthy. The issue highlights the gap between the Dutch government's climate targets and the aviation industry's emissions.

images.alt_text: A wind turbine is seen in front of a coal-fired power plant operated by German energy supplier RWE in Niederaussem, Germany.
Oxfam says “rich country contributions not only continue to fall miserably below their promised goal but are also very misleading.”
Italy is already feeling the effects of a changing climate and in July, the government declared a state of emergency in areas surrounding the river Po in the north.

site_title: Copper pushes lower on inflation, recession fears
summary: Copper prices declined 1.1% to $8,601.85 per tonne on the Shanghai Futures Exchange due to inflation and recession fears, while a strong dollar also weighed on the market. British inflation hit a 40-year peak, and a US Federal Reserve official discussed further rate hikes to contain inflation. Sentiment is negatively influenced, leading to a decline in industrial metals, including aluminum, which fell 0.6% to $2,180 per tonne.

images.alt_text: Workers inspect the production of copper cathodes at a Jinlong Copper plant in Tongling, Anhui province, China August 16, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer
Trading volumes of copper have tumbled by up to a third on global commodity exchanges so far this year.

site_title: Is CPF Ordinary Account’s peg to banking trio’s interest rates still relevant today?
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) ordinary account (OA) interest rate, pegged to banking trio rates since 1999, may no longer be relevant due to evolving bank products. The interest rates on high-interest savings accounts offered by the banks can reach 4.06 per cent, potentially surpassing the 2.5 per cent OA rate. This could prompt CPF members to consider investing their OA savings in Treasury bills if yields are higher. Reviewing the peg to ensure it remains relevant is necessary.

images.alt_text: CPF interest rate floors being maintained: Tan See Leng

site_title: Macron rams budget through divided French parliament
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's government has successfully passed its 2023 budget through the parliament without a vote, using a constitutional clause that allows for automatic law passage unless the opposition passes a no-confidence motion. The move comes as the country faces an economic squeeze, industrial action, and street protests. Macron's administration had faced opposition from various parties, including the left-wing NUPES alliance and the far-right National Rally, but the budget is now set to be implemented. The government has promised to introduce changes, including tax breaks, but Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has warned that any amendments that would blow holes in the budget will not be accepted.

images.alt_text: A banner for the Force Ouvriere (FO), the Totalenergies Carling’s trade unionists, hangs at the entrance to the petrochemical site of Carling, north-eastern France on Sept27, 2022, as workers demand an increase in wages, an unwinding of profit-sharing, the resumption in hiring.
French President Emmanuel Macron and Britain's Prime Minister Liz Truss meet at the Prague castle where the European Summit will take place in Prague, Czech Republic,  Oct 6, 2022.

site_title: Truss team fears Cabinet exodus as Braverman reportedly leaves
summary: UK Home Secretary Suella Braverman has reportedly left the government, a blow to Prime Minister Liz Truss' government. Truss' advisers fear a Cabinet exodus as Education Secretary Kit Malthouse and Trade Secretary Kemi Badenoch are seen as potential resigners. Malthouse delivered a critical assessment of Truss' leadership on a Cabinet call, citing plans to rip-up her economic program. The departure of Braverman and potential Cabinet resignations raise concerns about Truss' ability to maintain control and stability in her government.

images.alt_text: Truss is trying to shore up support from within the party after she was forced to scrap a vast tax-cutting plan, leading some Conservative lawmakers to call for her to be replaced.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 snaps four-day rally on inflation, growth angst
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe fell 0.5% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day rally, due to concerns over runaway inflation and interest rate hikes. UK inflation hit a 40-year high of 10.1% in September, and Euro zone consumer inflation remained at a record high of 9.9%. More than half of the Stoxx 600 sectors declined, with real estate and retailers leading losses. Strong earnings reports from ASML and Just Eat Takeaway.com partially offset the declines. Investors expect central banks to aggressively hike interest rates to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index gained 0.1 per cent to 6,942.61 points, as traders digested official data showing UK inflation back above 10 per cent.

site_title: Beijing in Brussels’ bad books at EU summit
summary: The European Union's relations with China have frayed since the pandemic, and a recent EU summit may formalize a hardening of the EU's foreign policy stance toward China. The EU may maintain a three-part assessment of China as "partner", "competitor", and "systemic rival", but with a focus on the "competitor" label, reflecting China's increasing global competitiveness. This shift comes as China's President Xi Jinping secures a third term, and the EU's diplomatic body advises member states to prioritize competition over cooperation in bilateral relations.

images.alt_text: EU member states have earmarked more than 500 billion euros to cushion the impact of the energy crunch on consumers and businesses.
Ursula von der Leyen, President of European Commission, says: “It is logical that instead of outbidding each other, energy companies should leverage their joint purchasing power.”

site_title: Sembcorp Marine secures floating LNG facilities conversion projects
summary: Sembcorp Marine secured two floating liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities conversion projects from New Fortress Energy (NFE). The projects involve converting two Sevan cylindrical drilling vessels into floating LNG facilities, hosting the NFE-designed Fast LNG liquefaction production facility with a capacity of approximately 1.4 million tonnes per annum. The first facility is scheduled for delivery in the first half of 2024, with the second project to be contracted at a later date. The contract is expected to have a minimal impact on Sembcorp Marine's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

images.alt_text: The Sembcorp Marine sign is pictured at the shipyard in Singapore, May 23, 2019. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Billionaire Steve Ballmer invests US$400m in Black fund managers
summary: Billionaire Steve Ballmer has invested $400 million in funds tied to Black venture-capital and private equity managers. The largest single commitment is $200 million to Project Black, a private equity fund managed by Ariel Investments. Ballmer, the former Microsoft CEO, is investing alongside his wife Connie through the Ballmer Group, which aims to improve economic mobility in the US. The investments align with the organization's goal and demonstrate the value of giving Black investment managers access to capital, according to Ballmer.

site_title: Voyager crypto customers may recover 72% from bankruptcy sale
summary: Voyager Digital, a bankrupt crypto lender, has agreed to sell itself to FTX US for $1.4 billion, with customers potentially recovering 72% of their account values. The sale is contingent on US Bankruptcy Judge Michael E. Wiles' approval of a creditor payment plan, which includes the option for customers to vote on the deal. If approved, Voyager can cancel the sale if a higher offer is received, and the company has agreed to change its fiduciary out clause to allow for consideration of better offers.

images.alt_text: Voyager Digital pricing. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Foreign investors eye Vietnamese startups despite funding slowdown
summary: Foreign investors are increasingly optimistic about Vietnam's startup ecosystem, driven by a growing middle-class population expected to expand to 36 million by 2030. Despite a funding slowdown, Vietnam has seen a surge in funding, with startups raising $1.4 billion last year, 1.6 times the previous peak in 2019. Foreign investors, including those from Korea, America, Russia, and the Middle East, are cutting checks of $500,000 to $1 million in early-stage startup deals and opening offices in Vietnam to get closer to entrepreneurs. Local investors are also becoming more active, with firms like Touchstone Partners and VinaCapital Ventures raising funds from international investors.

images.alt_text: The Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park's (VSIP) decision to not exit despite the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis likely helped  co-developer SembCorp Development to "score points" and gain trust from its Vietnamese partners, VSIP co-chair Kelvin Teo said.
As macroeconomic headwinds and inflation impact Indonesia, the startups there are feeling the pinch even as long term prospects still appear bright.
Indonesia is seeing new startups like Octopus, which aid recycling efforts through training leading to a less than 1 per cent rejection rate with recyclers.
Industry watchers said companies used to a more structured and predictable way of doing business, like the way it is in Singapore, would also be in for a culture shock.

site_title: People of Ukraine win EU rights award
summary: The European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize for human rights to the people of Ukraine for their resistance to the Russian invasion. The prize, established in 1988, recognizes those fighting for human rights and democracy. The award was given in recognition of the Ukrainian people's bravery in the face of "acts of pure terror" in Ukraine, with President Volodymyr Zelensky, elected representatives, and civil society being represented. The prize was chosen by consensus among the Parliament's political groups.

images.alt_text: The US believe Iranian drones were used on Monday in a morning rush hour attack on the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

site_title: Italian economy faces threat from climate change: central bank
summary: Italy's economy faces significant threats from climate change, according to a Bank of Italy research project. Rising temperatures and extreme weather events could stunt economic growth, with sectors like agriculture and tourism particularly vulnerable. The study found that businesses in areas prone to landslides and flooding are more likely to fail, and high temperatures and poor air quality negatively impact workers and students. The country's GDP per person could fall by 2.8-9.5% by 2100, with winter sports tourism also at risk due to reduced snowfall.

site_title: Hollywood’s Anna May Wong to become first Asian American on US currency
summary: The US Mint will feature actress Anna May Wong, the first Asian American to be honored on US currency, on a quarter-dollar coin as part of the American Women Quarters Program. Wong, a Hollywood star in the 1920s and 1950s, faced racism and stereotyping despite her success. Her image will be featured on the coin, which will begin circulating on October 25, 2022. The coin honors Wong's courage in advocating for increased representation and more diverse roles for Asian American actors.

site_title: Payments tech firm Super Apps to list in US via US$1.1b SPAC deal
summary: Payments tech firm Super Apps Holdings is set to list on the US Nasdaq exchange via a $1.1 billion merger with Technology & Telecommunication Acquisition Corporation (TETE Technologies). The combined company will expand its headcount with the proceeds from the merger. Super Apps will acquire 60% of fintech firm MobilityOne's stake in OneShop Retail before the deal closes. The merger will see Super Apps valued at $1.1 billion and list on Nasdaq under the name TETE Technologies.

site_title: Bright spots in Asia remain
summary: Asia remains a bright spot despite global economic challenges, driven by strong economic fundamentals, intra-Asian trade, and investment. The region's three key economic engines - Greater China, Asean, and South Asia - continue to fuel growth. Despite near-term challenges, Asia is expected to maintain a positive long-term outlook, with growth rates projected at over 4% in 2022 and 5% in 2023. Standard Chartered CEO Benjamin Hung attributes this to transformational and structural trends, including the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and the growing inter-connectivity of intra-Asian trade and capital flows.

site_title: US housing starts decline as mortgage rates weigh on demand
summary: US housing starts declined 8.1% in September to 1.44 million annualized units, with single-family homebuilding at its slowest pace since May 2020. Mortgage rates, the highest in two decades, are weighing on demand. Permit applications for single-family homes fell 3.1% to a two-year low. The housing market is expected to face more pain due to rising interest rates, with homebuilder sentiment at its worst level since the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage jumped another 13 basis points to 6.94 per cent in the week ended Oct 14, marking the ninth-straight increase, according to MBA.

site_title: IBM gains after sales top estimates amid currency headwinds
summary: IBM reported better-than-expected sales in its third quarter, with revenue rising 6.5% to $14.1 billion. The company affirmed its full-year revenue growth guidance and free cash flow forecast of $10 billion. Mainframe sales increased 15% and software sales jumped 7.5%, driven by steady IT spending. However, currency fluctuations and inflation in Europe are expected to impact margins. IBM's shares rose 4% in extended trading, and the company's focus on mission-critical services and cloud computing is seen as a key driver of its resilience in the tech market.

images.alt_text: The IBM office in Foster City, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Thailand says weak baht aiding tourism resurgence and growth
summary: Thailand's finance minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith says the country's weak baht is aiding tourism's resurgence and growth, making Thailand an attractive destination for travelers looking for bargains. The prolonged weakness in the local currency may continue through 2024, supporting foreign visitors and boosting the economy. Gross domestic product is expected to rise 3.7% next year, faster than projected, thanks to the return of foreign visitors, with economists forecasting further growth traction.

images.alt_text: People wait to watch musical fountains on a pier outside a shopping mall along the Chao Phraya river in Bangkok on August 7, 2022. (Photo by Manan VATSYAYANA / AFP)
The BOT last month raised its key interest rate for the first time in nearly 4 years.
A Tuk-tuk driver waits for customers along the popular Yaowarat street in the Chinatown area of Bangkok on September 5, 2022. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)
Rising costs and slower global demand were among factors to be monitored, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said in a statement.

Phuket was Thailand’s test case for the revival of its tourism industry last year, as the province was used for the government’s “sandbox” project that allowed fully vaccinated foreigners to visit starting in July 2021.

site_title: Bonds winning over fans on rising yields but experts warn against over-exuberance
summary: Interest rates have risen in Singapore, making government-backed bonds more attractive to investors. Despite this, experts warn against over-exuberance, advising a balanced allocation to mitigate risks. Monthly demand for bonds has soared, with subscription rates exceeding the available amount.
