Experts recommend considering relative return and liquidity when investing, with shorter-duration bonds like T-bills and SSBs being more popular than longer-duration SGS bonds. Inflation remains a concern, with core inflation at 5.1% and headline inflation at 7.5%.

images.alt_text: Singapore has enjoyed a strong post-pandemic rebound, despite repeated rounds of monetary tightening
Fund managers and financial sponsors are expected to soon deploy their high levels of cash, industry watchers said, although they will likely look for opportunities among the more defensive plays.
Yields on fixed income products have risen in the last few months as a result of rising interest rates.

site_title: Rich nations use ‘dishonest’ climate finance claims, Oxfam says
summary: Rich countries are failing to meet their climate finance commitments to poor nations, using "misleading" and "dishonest" accounting to inflate their contributions. In 2020, wealthy nations provided less than $25 billion in public finance, despite announcing almost $70 billion. This is forcing countries further into debt, crippling their ability to cope with climate shocks. Oxfam urges rich countries to scale up grant-based support and fix their reporting practices, warning that the current system is worsening the problem.

images.alt_text: Despite more companies disclosing environmental data, few are providing sufficient information.

site_title: Stamford Land responds to SGX RegCo on proposed disposals, waiver
summary: Stamford Land responded to Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) queries on its proposed disposals of Stamford Plaza Auckland and the business of SPAK, citing confidentiality obligations and commercial sensitivity. The company reported excess book values and expected net gains of S$74.4 million and S$14.5 million, respectively, after deducting expenses. Stamford Land also stated it was unable to seek shareholders' approval due to a non-bidding process and time-sensitivity, and will reallocate rights proceeds to other properties.

images.alt_text: Stamford Land previously announced that it has entered into a valid binding agreement for the sale and purchase of Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, its 10-storey freehold property located in Sydney's central business district.
Stamford Land is divesting Stamford Plaza Auckland, a five-star hotel in Auckland's city centre, for a total of NZ$170 million.

Stamford Land said it has entered into a valid binding agreement for the sale and purchase of Sir Stamford at Circular Quay, its 10-storey freehold property located in Sydney's central business district.

site_title: Global CO2 emissions to grow less than 1% this year thanks to renewables: IEA
summary: Global carbon dioxide emissions are projected to rise by nearly 300 million tonnes to 33.8 billion tonnes this year, a 1% increase, driven by power generation and the aviation sector. This marks a smaller rise compared to the 2021 jump of nearly 2 billion tonnes. The growth is attributed to the expansion of renewables and electric vehicles, outweighing coal demand.

site_title: WHO says Covid-19 is still a global health emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared that Covid-19 remains a global health emergency, nearly three years after its initial declaration. Despite falling cases in parts of the world, countries must maintain vigilance and prioritize vaccination of vulnerable populations. The WHO notes that weekly deaths are at their lowest since the pandemic began, but remain high compared to other viruses. Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warns that the pandemic "may again" surprise the world, emphasizing the need for continued public health measures.

images.alt_text: A healthcare worker directs residents at a Covid-19 testing facility in Hong Kong in February. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

site_title: I'm a fighter not a quitter, says PM Truss
summary: British Prime Minister Liz Truss is facing growing pressure to step down after scrapping a tax-cutting plan, leading to a 30-point gap in opinion polls between her Conservative Party and the main opposition Labour Party. Truss admitted her economic plans went "too far and too fast," causing investors to dump the pound and government bonds. Despite efforts to shore up support, her ratings remain low, and some Conservative lawmakers are calling for her replacement, with a vote on fracking set to test her leadership.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt ripped up virtually all the libertarian growth policies of Prime Minister Liz Truss in his presentation to a rowdy parliament on Oct 17, 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan names Qian as South-east Asia equity capital markets chief
summary: JPMorgan Chase has appointed Sophie Qian as the head of its Equity Capital Markets (ECM) team for South-east Asia, effective immediately. Qian, who has been with JPMorgan for nine years, will relocate to Singapore from New York later this year. She previously joined JPMorgan's US ECM team, focusing on US/Asia cross-border deals and SPACs. Qian will report to Peihao Huang and Sunil Dhupelia, co-heads of ECM for Asia exJapan.

site_title: Three Credit Suisse private bankers in Singapore leaving: sources
summary: Three Credit Suisse private bankers in Singapore are leaving, managing about $1 billion in client assets. Gautam Anand, a managing director, and Akshay Menon, a private banker, are joining a rival global private bank. The departures come after Singapore-based Jin Yee Young resigned as deputy head of Credit Suisse's Asia Pacific wealth management business. The move follows recent departures and concerns among wealth management clients about Credit Suisse's turnaround plan, with some moving funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen at an office building in Zurich, Switzerland September 2, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Mortgage rates in US extend climb to 6.94%, highest since 2002
summary: US mortgage rates reached a 20-year high of 6.94% in the week ended Oct 14, marking the ninth consecutive increase, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This surge pushed down home buying applications by 4.5%, the lowest level since 1997. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate has jumped 13 basis points, with the ninth straight increase, causing a downturn in the US housing market.

site_title: US: Wall St drops at open as Treasury yields soar
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, October 19, 2022, as Treasury yields surged to 14-year highs, denting gains from streaming giant Netflix. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 84.8 points, or 0.28%, to 30,439.04, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline was attributed to rising interest rates, which had previously boosted Netflix's stock.

site_title: Lionel Messi launches investment firm targeting sports and tech
summary: Lionel Messi has launched Play Time Sports-Tech HoldCo, a holding company based in San Francisco, to invest in sports, media, and technology globally. The company, led by Razmig Hovaghimian, will explore stage-agnostic opportunities, including football-tech startups and team investments. Messi's vision is to have a direct and lasting impact on and off the pitch, with the company already holding stakes in football-tech startups Matchday.com and AC Momento. Details on the amount to be invested are not disclosed.

site_title: How can local startups scale up even as global markets cool down?
summary: Singapore plans to support local startups as global markets cool down, with Enterprise Singapore chairman Peter Ong attributing the willingness to invest in high-growth enterprises to their potential to meet future demand for green, urban, and digital technologies. Amid expectations of a challenging 2023, the Asia-Pacific is still projected to be the world's fastest-growing investment region, with opportunities to innovate abound. The government will inject about 1% of the nation's GDP, or about S$25 billion, into deepening enterprise innovation capabilities between 2021 and 2025, and will foster more innovative partnerships across public and private stakeholders to increase growth-stage funds.

site_title: A £52b jump in mortgage costs fuels risk for UK lenders
summary: A £52 billion increase in mortgage costs in the UK over the next three years threatens to fuel defaults among lenders, with estimated personal debt service burden reaching 10% of post-tax income. This surge in borrowing costs, driven by higher interest rates, may lead to impairments and negatively impact bank earnings, with analyst Ed Firth cutting his estimated earnings for British banks by 38% for 2023 and 26% for 2024.

images.alt_text: The average weekly number of homes reserved at its sales sites in the nine weeks since Aug 1 fell to 191 per week, compared with 218 per week in the same period last year

site_title: Global steel demand downgraded, to drop 2.3% in 2022
summary: Global steel demand is expected to decline 2.3% in 2022 due to surging inflation and climbing interest rates, according to the World Steel Association. This downgrades the forecast from a 0.4% increase earlier in the year. Despite this, a global recovery in steel demand is still expected for 2023, mainly driven by infrastructure spending, with a 1% growth forecast instead of 2.2%. Steel demand is also impacted by supply chain constraints and China's strict Covid-19 containment policies, which are expected to result in a 4% drop in Chinese steel demand in 2022.

images.alt_text: Iron ore remained supported by restocking demand ahead of China’s Golden Week holiday beginning Oct 1, analysts said.

site_title: Red-hot inflation knocks sterling, US dollar holds at 32-year peak vs yen
summary: The US dollar holds at a 32-year peak against the yen, while the British pound weakens 0.57% due to higher-than-expected UK consumer price inflation. Investors expect the Bank of England to hike interest rates by 75 basis points in November, rather than 100, amid a recession in Britain. The US dollar also rises from a two-week trough against a basket of major peers, driven by expectations of aggressive US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia’s trade surplus in September hits record high
summary: Malaysia's trade surplus hit a record high of RM31.7 billion in September, driven by a 30.1% year-on-year increase in exports to RM144.2 billion. The country's total trade expanded 31.4% to RM256.9 billion, with exports growing 38.3% and imports rising 46.5% to RM355.3 billion. The trade surplus increased 5.6% to RM64.3 billion in the third quarter, marking the 14th consecutive month of double-digit growth.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's exports continued recorded double-digit growth for consecutive 13 months, thanks to higher exports of electrical and electronic products, petroleum products, optical and scientific equipment as well as machinery, equipment and parts.

site_title: Corporate climate disclosures jump again in 2022: CDP
summary: More than 18,700 companies, worth $60.8 trillion, disclosed environmental data in 2022, a 42% year-on-year rise, according to CDP. However, 29,500 companies failed to respond, and only 1% of those submitting climate change data provide sufficient information for investors to assess low-carbon plans. The top disclosing countries were the US, China, Japan, Britain, and Brazil, with manufacturing, services, and materials being the top disclosing industries. CDP is calling on the remaining non-disclosing companies to report and prepare for mandatory disclosure on the horizon.

images.alt_text: PwC projected that ESG AUM in Asia Pacific will grow at a faster clip than Europe and the US, more than tripling to US$3.3 trillion by 2026, from a low base of US$1 trillion in 2021.

site_title: Sweden’s US$41b property debt is alarming Europe
summary: Sweden's property companies face a funding squeeze due to rising interest rates and near-term maturities, with $10 billion in debt repayments and $41 billion refinancing demands by 2026. The sector's stock market values have halved this year, and some companies may need to tap the stock market to raise funds. The Swedish central bank and Financial Supervisory Authority have warned about the risks of commercial property debt, which could have a spillover effect on Swedish banks and the wider European sector.

images.alt_text: The annual decline in the cost of flats is now the fastest since August 2018.

site_title: Procter & Gamble beats sales estimates on price hikes
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) beat quarterly sales and profit estimates, driven by 9% average price hikes across its product lines and a 3% decline in sales volumes. Despite a stronger dollar weighing on international revenue, the company reported adjusted earnings of $1.57 per share on $20.61 billion in net sales. P&G now expects fiscal 2023 sales to fall 1-3% and full-year earnings to come in at the low-end of its previous guidance of flat to 4% growth.

images.alt_text: P&G, household-products shares see haven appeal dimmed by lofty valuations

site_title: Exclusive A. Lange & Sohne gift for The Business Times readers
summary: A. Lange & Sohne is hosting "The Mechanical Masters" showcase at ION Orchard in Singapore from Oct 27-30, featuring rare insights into luxury timepiece making. The first 30 readers who sign up and indicate they found out about the event from The Business Times will receive a special souvenir. The showcase will include live demonstrations by Master Watchmaker Robert Hoffmann and Master Engraver Robert Arnold, highlighting the brand's innovations and hand decorations.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange proposes looser IPO rules for tech firms as profit falls
summary: Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing (HKEX) proposed looser IPO rules for tech firms, aiming to revive falling listing revenue. The move comes as the exchange posted a 30% drop in Q3 profit, beating analyst expectations. The proposed rules, which would apply to companies in emerging technologies, would reduce the revenue requirement for commercialized tech firms to HK$250 million, down from HK$500 million. The goal is to drive growth in talent and investment across these industries, despite a slowdown in the IPO market due to global market fragility and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the entrance to the Hong Kong Exchange in Hong Kong, China January 21, 2016.   REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: Upcoming Q3 results will be pivotal following one of the worst market routs since S-Reits’ inception
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are set to release their Q3 results, which will be pivotal following one of the worst market routs since S-Reits' inception. The FTSE ST Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) Index has tumbled over 20% since April, with the current correction being the third longest in S-Reit history. Analysts will monitor metrics such as cost of funds, interest cover, gearing ratio, and physical occupancy to assess the resiliency of the Reits. Key results announcements include Sabana Industrial Reit, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and several foreign Reits.

images.alt_text: The Reit's Paragon mall recorded a 16.4 per cent increase in footfall to 13.3 million
Across the broader market, decliners outnumbered gainers 255 to 251 after 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion were traded on Oct 14.
Sabana I

site_title: Private equity’s rainmakers struggle to raise cash in Asia
summary: Private equity fund managers in Asia struggled to raise cash at recent conferences in Singapore, with thousands of investors and money managers attending but few committing funds. The industry faces challenges, including slumping financial markets and valuations, making it harder to exit investments. Smaller firms, in particular, are struggling to establish relationships with limited partners. Despite Asia being a growing private equity market, many institutional investors are cautious, pushing more funds into cash amid fears of potential losses, and are favoring established managers.

images.alt_text: Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez (left) leads at the start of the Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sunday.

site_title: UAE seeks to lure tech firms with long-term residency, financing
summary: The UAE is launching a program to attract advanced technology companies by offering fast-tracked business licenses and long-term residency for employees. Over 300 digital firms are targeted, with around 40 companies already in the process of moving, including Change Foods, Gecko Robotics, and fintech firms Currency.com and Capital.com. The program aims to create high-skilled jobs in futuristic industries, leveraging the UAE's nimble handling of the pandemic and liberal visa policies. The move seeks to diversify the country's economy away from oil income and compete with global hubs such as Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Raffles Education tells SGX RegCo it is in compliance with board diversity policies
summary: Raffles Education has confirmed it is in compliance with board diversity policies after responding to queries from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo). The company's board consists of four independent and non-executive directors and one non-independent and non-executive director, with diverse backgrounds and skills. The board evaluates composition at director appointments and on an ongoing basis to achieve diversity. Raffles Education plans to appoint younger directors as part of its renewal process.

images.alt_text: A shocking announcement by Raffles Education (REC) that its auditors had highlighted material uncertainty on its ability to continue as a going concern has added another chapter to the ongoing saga of the troubled company.

site_title: Invoice financing and credit insurance: Is the problem with the product or the conduct?
summary: The collapse of invoice financing company Greensill has highlighted the importance of aligning credit insurance products with their conduct. Credit insurance is a useful product providing coverage for non-payment, but its misuse as a financial guarantee has led to over-leveraging and risks. The lack of transparency in transactions, including the physical flow of goods and commercial rationale, can create opportunities for unscrupulous traders to exploit the system. To address these issues, there is a need for better information sharing between funder, lender, and insurer, as well as robust due diligence and responsive credit management procedures.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse warns Greensill investors of long legal fight

Singapore has sought to address market reluctance around electronic trade documents by amending its laws to give certain transferable documents, like electronic bills of lading, the same legal status as their paper counterparts.

site_title: Netflix targets global TV ad market as next business to disrupt
summary: Netflix plans to launch an ad-supported version of its service in the US and 11 other countries in November, priced at $6.99 a month, 30% less than its basic ad-free tier. The move aims to disrupt the global TV ad market, which is shrinking due to declining TV audiences. Netflix forecasts 4.5 million new customers in the fourth quarter, and analysts see the ad-supported service as a way to lift revenue as customers trim spending amid economic gloom. The company plans to eventually offer personalized advertising, potentially cannibalizing its existing market but making up for it through revenue from the ad-supported version and account-sharing fees.

images.alt_text: While Netflix isn’t growing as it was a couple years ago, the world’s most popular TV network is back on a positive trajectory after erasing customer losses in the first half of the year.

site_title: Local market would benefit from companies having a formal statement of purpose
summary: A shift in corporate thinking has led to a movement away from prioritizing shareholder value, as companies now recognize the importance of pursuing broader goals that include a role in the community and employee welfare. In 2019, the Business Roundtable association, representing 181 CEOs of America's largest corporations, adopted a new Statement on the Purpose of a Corporation, declaring that companies should deliver value to customers, invest in employees, and support the communities in which they operate. Oxford University professor Robert G Eccles advocates for boards to issue statements of purpose, outlining the company's overarching reason for existence, how it should conduct itself, and its impact on stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Inflation is not a simple story about greedy corporations
Buying shares of ExxonMobil in the secondary market does not benefit Exxon in any way. Subscribing to a new bond or a new share issuance, however, does benefit Exxon.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grade A office rents in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) are expected to grow at 3% for 2022 and 2% in 2023, according to Savills Research. Vacancy levels are expected to contract further in Q3. Local SMEs have been expanding for the seventh consecutive quarter, driven by a healthy pick-up in consumer demand and international air travel. Meanwhile, Malaysia's trade surplus hit a record high of RM31.7 billion in September, and Mastercard aims to capture a US$5.5 trillion opportunity in B2B procurement settlements.

site_title: Honda Motorcycle & Scooter India to launch flexi-fuel model by end-2024
summary: Honda Motorcycle & Scooter India plans to launch a flexi-fuel model of motorcycle in India by end-2024, according to CEO Atsushi Ogata. The company is waiting for a clear roadmap from the government on flexi-fuel vehicles and believes that 20% ethanol-blending can be applied to all engine line-ups. India aims to introduce 20% ethanol blending with petrol in some parts of the country from April 2024, with a nationwide roll-out planned for 2025/26. This move is part of the country's efforts to encourage the blending of higher proportions of ethanol and vegetable oil with petrol and diesel.

site_title: UK inflation returns to double digits as food prices soar
summary: UK inflation rose to 10.1% in September, its highest level in over 40 years, driven by soaring food prices and rising costs for furniture and household goods. The Office for National Statistics reported a 14.8% increase in food prices, the strongest in more than 40 years, while producer prices rose 15.9% from a year ago. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates significantly next month to combat inflation, which has left the government and central bank under pressure to act.

images.alt_text: The sales are the latest sign that the turmoil that rocked the UK pension industry in recent weeks is still reverberating through financial markets.

site_title: Sabana Industrial Reit’s occupancy hits 89.1% for Q3 2022
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit reported a 89.1% occupancy rate for Q3 2022, the highest since Q3 2017. The Reit signed 83,588 sq ft of new leases and renewed 71,266 sq ft, with a 10.2% rental reversion. The weighted average lease expiry is 2.7 years, and the aggregate leverage ratio stands at 33.7%. A proposal to convert 1 Tuas Avenue 4 into a new warehouse and logistics facility is underway, subject to approval.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
Sabana Reit was among the S-Reits with the highest net institutional inflows in H1.
151 Lorong Chuan, a 6-storey industrial building, is the largest property of Sabana Industrial REIT by gross floor area.

site_title: Brokers’ Take: Deutsche Bank dismisses GoTo financing worries, initiates coverage with ‘buy’
summary: Deutsche Bank has initiated coverage on Indonesian digital-services company GoTo Group with a "buy" rating, citing strong growth prospects and a unique business portfolio. Analyst ReenaVerma Bhasin set a target price of 250 rupiah, implying a potential upside of 20-21% from the current share price. Despite market worries about GoTo's financing requirements, Bhasin believes the company's peak financing requirement will be less than $500 million, within existing credit lines. GoTo's e-commerce, on-demand, and financial services are expected to drive growth, with Bhasin forecasting a compound annual growth rate of 38% in gross revenues and 64% in net revenues from 2022 to 2025.

images.alt_text: Macquarie analysts Ari Jahja and Akshay Sugandi set a 324 Indonesian rupee target price for GoTo, pointing out that growth execution, cost cuts and fundraising progress will be key to the stock’s re-rating.
TBS Energi, which wants to stop mining coal in five years, will set aside US$350 million of its own funds for Electrum up to 2025.

site_title: Home design influencers
summary: Home design influencers are turning their passion into a side hustle as more homeowners seek inspiration on social media. With the pandemic and work-from-home shift, homeowners are turning to social media for decorating ideas and renovation tips. This rise in home design content creators is changing the way people decorate, offering a new platform for sharing renovation experiences and housekeeping hacks. As a result, design content creating has become a viable business for many.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year government bond yields hit BOJ’s policy ceiling first time since June
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yields surpassed the Bank of Japan's policy limit for the first time in four months, reaching 0.255%, exceeding the 0.250% ceiling. The yield fell back to 0.250% after the event. The move is seen as a test of the central bank's commitment, with some traders speculating the BOJ may not alter its policy next week. This comes amid rising overseas yields and a weakened yen, driven by the BOJ's unique monetary policy stance.

site_title: Temasek eyes openings in emerging technologies such as blockchain, AI amid market volatility
summary: Temasek, Singapore's state investor, is identifying opportunities in emerging technologies such as blockchain and AI amid market volatility. Managing director of blockchain investments Pradyumna Agrawal stated the company has a "dual approach" to build capabilities and ventures in promising areas, focusing on "highest-quality projects" and ensuring regulatory compliance. Temasek is optimistic about blockchain and AI, citing their "proven benefits" and "high conviction" technology areas, and will continue to invest in areas such as digitalising capital markets workflows and improving over-the-counter and fixed-income segments.

images.alt_text: The new fund’s size will exceed an initial target of US$400 million, compare with an earlier, similar fund that raised US$275 million, said Tay Choon Chong, managing partner at Vertex Ventures China.
Jacquelyn Tan, UOB’s head of group personal financial services, said personalisation could take an educational slant in the future, delving into dishing out financial and wealth planning tips.
Mastercard Asia-Pacific president Ari Sarker believes that more can be done to address the relatively untapped B2B payments space.

site_title: Healthier SG’s emphasis on preventative care is step in right direction
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG reform aims to shift the healthcare system towards preventative care by mobilizing family doctors to partner patients and focus on prevention. The capitation model will pay doctors an annual service fee for each patient under their care, incentivizing them to keep residents healthy through preventive care. The reform is expected to slow the rate of health deterioration and achieve sustainable healthcare, potentially reducing costs. Enrolment for the program is set to start next year for those aged 60 and above, with three healthcare clusters overseeing the system.

images.alt_text: Healthcare cluster funding to be based on number of residents; new polyclinic in Taman Jurong
While locals will continue to form the bulk of the nursing workforce, the number and role of foreign nurses will grow.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply down
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.38% on Wednesday, October 19, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index falling 403.30 points to 16,511.28. The decline comes despite city leader John Lee's policy address, which vowed to boost the economy, amid a political crackdown. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also fell, with losses of 1.19% and 1.16%, respectively. The declines are attributed to a lack of investor confidence in the city's economic prospects.

site_title: Property funds to sell assets to help stricken UK pensions
summary: UK property funds are selling assets to meet redemption requests from pension plans, amid turmoil in the pension industry. Real estate funds, including CBRE UK Property PAIF and Legal & General Group's Industrial Property Investment fund, have appointed brokers to sell properties such as a London warehouse and 1 Albemarle Street. These sales are a sign that the financial market impact of recent pension industry turmoil is still being felt.

images.alt_text: The average weekly number of homes reserved at its sales sites in the nine weeks since Aug 1 fell to 191 per week, compared with 218 per week in the same period last year

site_title: HK tries to reverse expat exodus with housing tax cut, new visa
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee announced a plan to reverse the city's brain drain by cutting property duties for non-permanent residents and relaxing visa rules. The measures include a two-year visa program for individuals earning at least HK$2.5 million annually and a refund of extra property stamp duties for eligible buyers after seven years of residency. The proposals aim to attract foreign talent and ease housing woes, but economists say the plans lack a major policy shakeup and may not address the underlying issues.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee gave a debut policy speech that focused heavily on both reviving the economy and maintaining security.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,033.8 at 9:03 am on Wednesday, driven by global market rallies. The index saw significant trading activity in stocks such as Genting Singapore, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust. US stocks, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average, rose for a second straight session, while European shares also gained for the fourth straight session.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit’s manager does not expect the transaction to have a material effect on the Reit’s net tangible assets.

site_title: Twenty French nuclear reactors affected by strike, union says
summary: A strike by the FNME-CGT union has affected nearly a third of France's nuclear reactors, with 20 out of 56 reactors impacted, and 17 having their maintenance schedules delayed. This has resulted in a total 1.8 gigawatts of reduced power production. The strike, which began over wages, has further disrupted France's already struggling nuclear output, which was expected to hit a 30-year low in 2022. The power grid operator RTE warned that prolonged strikes could have "heavy consequences" for electricity supply over the winter.

site_title: China auto market faces slowdown as inventory builds: CMBI
summary: China's auto market is expected to face a slowdown in 2023 due to inventory builds, despite a record 1 million vehicle deliveries to dealers in the first nine months of the year. Retail demand slowed, with deliveries to dealers rising 33% and retail sales climbing only 9%. Analysts at China Merchants Bank International (CMBI) warn that this trend could lead to an overhang, weighing on sales next year. CMBI expects China's wholesale volume to fall in 2023, with a more significant decline for internal-combustion engine vehicles.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Wednesday amid mixed regional trading; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,022.8, amid mixed regional trading. Losers outnumbered gainers 315 to 209, with 964 million securities worth S$856.5 million changing hands. Top losers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while ST Engineering was the top gainer. Analysts attributed the decline to global bond yields rising amid strong CPI data in the UK, but noted "nascent signs" of a better global activity-to-inflation composition.

images.alt_text: As at 9.03 am, the Straits Times Index gained 7.92 or 0.3 per cent to 3,033.8 after 37.1 million securities worth S$44.6 million changed hands.

site_title: Australia: Banks, healthcare stocks lift shares
summary: Australian shares closed 0.3% higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in the healthcare and financial sectors, despite losses in gold and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.7% on Tuesday. Strong US corporate earnings and positive financial results from Wall Street also boosted sentiment. Financials led gains, with the "Big Four" banks rising 0.7-1.4%, while the healthcare sector rose 0.5% due to a higher US dollar.

images.alt_text: The S&P ASX 200 index rose 0.1 per cent, or 6.8 points, to 6,786 by 2348 GMT on Wednesday, after ending 1.7 per cent higher on Tuesday.

site_title: Abu Dhabi airline Etihad gets new CEO after wealth fund ADQ’s takeover
summary: Abu Dhabi state carrier Etihad has appointed Antonoaldo Neves as its new CEO, replacing Tony Douglas after the emirate's government transferred ownership to wealth fund ADQ. Neves, former CEO of TAP Portugal, expressed confidence in Etihad's sustainable growth journey. Douglas will serve as an adviser to ADQ Aviation and Aerospace Services Company. The move comes as Etihad scales back its ambitions after a five-year turnaround plan. ADQ aims to transform Abu Dhabi into a global aviation hub through strategic acquisitions and privatising assets.

site_title: Grade A office rents to maintain strong growth trajectory as vacancies fall: Savills
summary: Grade A office rents in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) are expected to maintain a strong growth trajectory, with a 3% increase in 2022 and 2% in 2023, according to Savills Research. Vacancy rates have contracted for the second consecutive quarter, with a 1.2 percentage point jump to 5.6%. Net demand for CBD Grade A offices increased to 417,000 sq ft in Q3, driven by inflationary pressures, higher interest rates, and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Cushman & Wakefield data shows that CBD Grade A office rents rose 1.8 per cent quarter-on-quarter to S$10.35 per square foot (psf) per month in Q3 2022 while vacancy rates tightened to 3.6 per cent from 5.1 per cent in the last quarter.
According to Huttons, rents of private homes are estimated to increase up to 10 per cent in H2 2022.
Generic pix of Singapore  for upcoming budget speech on the 18 Feb 2022

site_title: What the eclipse of Tencent by a liquor company says about Xi’s China
summary: Kweichow Moutai, a Chinese liquor company, has overtaken Tencent as the country's most valuable company, surpassing it in market capitalization. This shift is seen as a reflection of China's economic priorities under President Xi Jinping, who is set to embark on a third term as Communist party leader. Moutai's success is attributed to its strong brand and sales, while Tencent's dominance in the tech sector is waning. The move highlights China's preference for traditional industries over technology and innovation.

images.alt_text: Tencent is now aggressively seeking to own majority or even controlling stakes in overseas targets, notably in gaming assets
Moutai, the maker of potent baijiu liquor that’s a staple in Chinese banquets, is considered a defensive stock at a time when Covid lockdowns cloud the growth outlook of many domestic firms.

site_title: S Korean markets shrug off tax cuts on bond investments
summary: South Korea's tax cut on foreign bond investments, announced to attract overseas money and defend its weak currency, showed initial hesitation with foreign investors purchasing fewer contracts than expected. Despite this, the move aims to meet requirements for inclusion in the FTSE Russell's World Government Bond Index, which could bring in $89.6 billion in capital inflows. The yield on Korean treasury bonds rose to 4.3%, and local investors remained sellers, making it difficult to expect a dramatic change in the market.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 12.51 points or 0.56 per cent at 2,237.44.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap three-session gaining streak as dollar firms
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Wednesday, reversing a three-session gaining streak, due to a strengthening dollar and rising US treasury yields. The Kospi benchmark fell 0.56% to 2,237.44, while the won weakened and bond yields rose. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell, but LG Energy Solution advanced. Foreigners were net buyers of shares for the 13th session, while the won ended 0.25% lower at 1,426.2 per dollar.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi rises 30.24 points or 1.36 per cent to close at 2,249.9.

site_title: Truss commits to pension spending, but silent on benefits, foreign aid
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has committed to increasing state pension payments in line with inflation, but declined to give similar reassurance for welfare payments and foreign aid. The move comes as Truss seeks to steady her government following a week of Tory MPs plotting her downfall. Truss's new finance minister, Jeremy Hunt, has dismantled her economic policy, and the government is now forced to hunt for deep spending cuts. The triple lock, which guarantees state pension rises in line with inflation, earnings, or 2.5%, remains intact, but the government is exploring alternative approaches to welfare payments.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt ripped up virtually all the libertarian growth policies of Prime Minister Liz Truss in his presentation to a rowdy parliament on Oct 17, 2022.

site_title: GM’s new South Korea plant to boost capacity to 500,000 cars in nation
summary: General Motors' Changwon plant in South Korea is being remodeled and expanded to increase its capacity to 500,000 cars per year. The plant will build GM's next-generation vehicles, including an all-new Chevrolet crossover, with an investment of around $897 million. The upgrade is expected to support Korea's transition to electric vehicles by introducing 10 EVs by 2025, following the success of the Chevrolet Trailblazer.

images.alt_text: Gneneral Motor's Changwon factory. Source: GM Korea

site_title: Turning food waste into food-grade medical products
summary: N&E Innovations, a Singapore-based medtech company, is turning food waste into medical-grade products such as masks, disinfectants, and wet wipes. Founder Didi Gan's team converts cashew nut skins, durian husks, and banana peels into antimicrobial compounds like Vikang99, effective against 99.99% of bacteria and viruses. The company aims to create sustainable products, with a goal of obtaining halal certification and entering international markets by 2023. N&E Innovations has already won the Green Innovations Award for SME category in Singapore's Environmental Achievement Awards.

images.alt_text: Incorporating rain gardens helped naturalise this concrete canal at Tampines. Such nature-based solutions are increasingly used to create "green-grey" infrastructure to help cope with the impact of climate change, said Koh Lian Pin, director of NUS' Centre for Nature-Based Solutions.

Profile of managing director of FlexMech, Tan Ru-Ding.

By adopting the SS 668 cold chain management standards, Jurong Cold Store implemented automatic temperature controls that ensure the end-to-end cold chain management of chilled and frozen products.

site_title: Malaysia says Opec+ decision to cut output made to address market uncertainties
summary: Malaysia has backed a steep cut to Opec+ oil production, joining other member states in addressing market uncertainties. The decision, which was unanimous, aims to stabilize the global oil market amid concerns of prolonged uncertainties. Malaysia's Economy Minister Mustapa Mohamed stated that Opec+ countries considered market fundamentals, including global supply and demand, before making the decision. The move follows criticism from the White House, which accused Saudi Arabia of coercing other nations into supporting the cut. Malaysia will continue to collaborate with Opec+ to ensure global oil market stability.

site_title: ‘Hyper-personalisation’ growing sophisticated
summary: UOB has developed close to 70 machine-learning models to anticipate customers' needs since 2019, resulting in "hyper-personalisation" experiences such as insight cards delivered on the UOB TMRW app. The bank's head of group personal financial services, Jacquelyn Tan, notes that personalisation can take an educational slant, focusing on financial and wealth planning tips, particularly for younger customers. This approach aims to build trust and drive customer satisfaction in an era of instant gratification.

images.alt_text: Digital banks seen debuting strongly in 2022, but 'long and difficult' path to profitability
DBS, OCBC and UOB ATMs at Tang Plaza near Orchard MRT on July 30, 2020.
Shoppers in Singapore have high expectations of retailers. They also want personalised experiences.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics bribery scandal widens with mascot allegations
summary: Tokyo Olympics bribery scandal widens with allegations of bribery by former board member Haruyuki Takahashi, who accepted 54 million yen in bribes from a major advertising firm and a merchandise company. This is the fourth arrest for Takahashi, who has also been accused of taking bribes from other companies. Three other people, including ADK Holdings president Shinichi Ueno, were also arrested. The total sum of bribes allegedly taken by Takahashi now stands at 196 million yen.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a protective face mask walks in front of a wall decoration featuring Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games mascot Miraitowa and Paralympic mascot Someity, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Tokyo, Japan December 24, 2020.  REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Indonesia’s central bank governor sees no need for aggressive monetary tightening
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the country does not need aggressive monetary tightening despite high inflation levels, the highest since 2015. Warjiyo cited Indonesia's inflation being below other countries' price pressures and comparing it to the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. He plans to announce the interest rate review result at a news conference on Thursday.

site_title: For Secretlab, an ‘obsession’ to produce the world’s best chairs
summary: Secretlab, a Singapore-based furniture manufacturer, has achieved exponential growth since its founding in 2014 by Ian Ang and Alaric Choo. The company's focus on research and development, internationalization, and hard work led to its expansion into Europe and the UK, and its products gained traction worldwide, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic. Today, Secretlab is a leading manufacturer of chairs for gamers and professionals, with a presence in the European Union, North America, and Singapore. The company has invested in S$50 million in R&D and has partnered with top brands and e-sports organizations, including The International tournament. Ang attributes the company's success to its obsession with producing the world's best chairs and its willingness to take calculated risks.

images.alt_text: Jackson Aw, chief executive officer, Mighty Jaxx International.

EDPR Sunseap's Business CEO Frank Phuan in its current monitoring room. The company which won an Emerging Enterprise Award in 2014 as a solar lessor, now has a comprehensive range of green products and services.
(l-R) Sebastian Shen, Co-Founder and Chief Product Officer ; Alvin Ea, Co-founder and Chief Executive Officer of Singapore’s largest digital trucking platform, Haulio

site_title: Hot stock: Biolidics nears four-month high; up 118.4% in early trade
summary: Biolidics, a diagnostic solutions provider and Covid-19 test kit distributor, saw its shares reach a four-month high, trading at S$0.072, up 118.4% from its previous close on June 24. The company's shares were heavily traded, with 25.5 million shares changing hands by 2:23 pm. This surge in share price follows the company's production and distribution of Covid-19 test kits, which contributed to a 7.2% increase in revenue to S$685,000 in the half year ended June 30, 2022.

site_title: Geo-economic hegemon no more?
summary: The US is no longer the dominant global economic force, as evidenced by the lack of a "Committee to Save the World" to address global crises. The 1999 Time magazine cover featuring Alan Greenspan, Larry Summers, and Robert Rubin, who prevented a global economic meltdown, is now a relic of the past. Today, the US faces rising inflation, economic instability, and fears of a global recession, with the IMF and World Bank lowering their global economic growth estimates for 2023. The US Treasury secretary and Fed chairman's policies are seen as contributing to the current economic turmoil, and the US is no longer willing or able to provide the necessary funding to support global economic stability.

images.alt_text: On Oct 7, the US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security announced major controls on exports to China of advanced semiconductors, chip-making equipment and supercomputer components.

Oil pumpjacks in California. The most effective way that the US could respond to rising oil prices would be by encouraging domestic production, but this runs counter to the views of the environmentalist lobby and progressive Democrats.
hands, world, map

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher at open
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on October 19, 2022, following gains in Tokyo and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1% to 6,942.61 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index rose 0.1% to 12,781.79 points and the Paris CAC 40 won 0.2% to 6,080.43 points, driven by UK inflation data showing the UK's inflation rate back above 10%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.37% to 27,257.38, driven by robust US corporate earnings and rising Wall Street futures. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.19%. The gains followed a positive trend in US markets, where stocks edged towards records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Global smartphone demand continues fall as economic woes hit
summary: Global smartphone shipments fell 9% in the third quarter, marking the worst performance since 2014. Economic headwinds, including interest rate hikes and rising energy prices, led to a decline in demand. Domestic players like Xiaomi, Vivo, and Oppo saw double-digit drops in sales, while Apple's iPhone remained resilient. Samsung maintained its leading global position with 22% market share, aided by discounts and promotions. Analysts predict a slow but steady festive sale in the fourth quarter, with consumers seeking steep discounts and promotions.

site_title: In first policy address, Hong Kong leader prioritises talent, security
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee delivered his first policy address, focusing on reviving the economy and maintaining security. Lee prioritized improving competitiveness and attracting overseas talent, while also strengthening national security. He pledged to tighten control, referencing Chinese President Xi Jinping's directives, and proposed new laws to regulate areas such as cybersecurity and false information. This move comes as Western governments have expressed concerns about the erosion of rights and freedoms in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee speaks to the media before an Executive Council meeting in Hong Kong on September 6, 2022. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)
Hong Kong has trailed the reopening efforts of all of its major financial hub rivals, especially regional rival Singapore.
Daily trading averaged HK$98.3 billion a day during the third quarter, down 40 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Mastercard eyes US$5.5t opportunity in B2B procurement settlements
summary: Mastercard is targeting a $5.5 trillion opportunity in the B2B procurement space, with 24% of annual B2B spend in the Asia-Pacific region potentially being settled on cards. The company is working with financial institutions to improve efficiency and connectivity for businesses, and has launched the Track Business Payment Service, which provides a built-in business directory to match buyers and sellers based on their working capital requirements. Mastercard aims to shift the narrative around the use of cards, seeing them as a means of freeing up working capital for businesses, and is partnering with fintech companies to help bridge the gap between buyers and suppliers who are unwilling or unable to accept card payments.

images.alt_text: (from left) Anton Ruddenklau, global head of innovation for financial services at KPMG; Jaelle Ang, founder of The Great Room; MAS managing director Ravi Menon; Darian McBain, adviser to MAS; Sherie Ng, country director for Singapore and Malaysia at Google Cloud; and Maya Hari, CEO of Terrascope.
Mastercard said spending on its network jumped 18 per cent as US consumers battle once-in-a-generation levels of inflation.

site_title: Four partners join sustainability collaboration, ink MoU with A*Star, JTC, TÜV SÜD
summary: Singapore's Green Compass collaboration has expanded with four new partners - Enterprise Singapore, the Singapore Manufacturing Federation, the Singapore Precision Engineering and Technology Association, and Singapore Polytechnic - signing a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to further develop the Green Compass environmental sustainability assessment and roadmapping tool. The tool aims to help businesses understand and improve their environmental sustainability journey, reducing costs and improving resource efficiency. The partnership will bring the tool to more companies in Singapore, supporting their sustainability transformation and future-proofing against supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: At ITAP 2022, DPM Heng announced an investment into a new semiconductor materials centre, green commitments, the launch of a handbook for talent attraction and retention and five refreshed industry transformation maps (ITMs).

site_title: Easier to justify construction greening costs in Singapore: Lendlease CEO, Asia
summary: Lendlease's CEO for Asia, Justin Gabbani, says the company strategically focuses on larger projects in more expensive markets like Singapore to justify the costs of greening the built environment. In Singapore, 60-70% of a building's cost is land, making it easier to amortize construction costs. Lendlease aims to be one of the industry's first to achieve net-zero carbon for construction delivery in Asia, working with the supply chain to advance low-carbon material uptake and innovation. The company has emerged as a regional leader in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) rankings and has launched a sustainability-linked loan in the Singapore Reit market.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.
JLL's study found that 42 per cent of corporates has already signed a lease incorporating green clauses as at June 2022.

site_title: Simon Cowell’s new TikTok project gives users unreleased music
summary: Simon Cowell is partnering with TikTok to launch StemDrop, a service that gives users access to new, unreleased songs by famous producers. Users can interpret and reinterpret the songs in any way they like, with the goal of creating something special and potentially getting noticed by a talent scout. The first song is written by Swedish producer Max Martin, who has worked with stars like Britney Spears and Bon Jovi. No guaranteed record deal is offered, allowing users to gain a head start in their careers without a set outcome.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Producer Simon Cowell and a judge for the upcoming season of the Fox television network reality series "The X Factor", poses during a photo opportunity in Los Angeles July 11, 2013. REUTERS/Fred Prouser (UNITED STATES - Tags: ENTERTAINMENT)/File Photo
ByteDance is counting on its e-commerce foray to help commercialise TikTok and finally turn a profit in the face of pressures from tightening regulations and mounting geopolitical risks
News sites like CNA, Mothership.sg and The Straits Times are courting Gen Z on TikTok.

site_title: SMEs in expansionary territory for seventh straight quarter: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have expanded for the seventh consecutive quarter, according to OCBC's SME Index. The index scored 51.9 in Q3 2022, marking a broad-based expansion across industries except for the information, communications, and technology sector. The growth rate is attributed to sustained demand and the reopening of international borders, with the business services and manufacturing sectors showing strong growth. However, the bank warns that business sentiment may be weighed down by rising inflationary pressures and softening global demand, expecting the SME Index to moderate downwards in Q4.

images.alt_text: As announced in Budget 2022, more SMEs will be able to tap on the capabilities of over 80 technology, innovation and enterprise centres, including Centres of Innovation.
Grab riders and taxi drivers in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Consumer digital services will be one of the major growth drivers for Asean in the post-Covid future.

site_title: Indonesia tells tin industry to be prepared for an export ban
summary: Indonesia is preparing for a potential export ban on tin, the country's top metal export, as authorities assess industry conditions and develop domestic processing capabilities. The country consumes only 5% of its tin production and exports ingots with over 90% purity. A ban could require significant investment and time to process the metal domestically. The government has already halted shipments of other metals to develop processing capabilities, and a similar policy for tin is being considered. Authorities are assessing the time needed to develop industries that can absorb tin ingot production.

images.alt_text: Stacks of refined tin blocks, ready to be exported, are seen inside a warehouse in Pangkal Pinang, on the island of Bangka, Indonesia, May 4, 2021. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan
A flag-raising ceremony at ground zero of Indonesia's future capital in Sepaku, Penajam Paser Utara, East Kalimantan on Aug 17, 2022, on the country's 77th Independence Day.

site_title: Qatar’s glitzy World Cup is ready and expensive
summary: Qatar's highly anticipated World Cup, set to begin on November 20, is expected to cost an estimated $300 billion, surpassing previous estimates. The country's wealth from natural gas has enabled significant spending on infrastructure, including stadiums, hotels, and roads, designed to showcase Arabic tradition and culture. However, human rights groups have raised concerns about the treatment of migrant workers and criticism of Qatar's human rights record, prompting calls for increased compensation for those affected. Despite these concerns, fans and organizers are optimistic about the event's success, with expectations centered around the host nation's football team's performance.

images.alt_text: Qatar will host the Nov 20-Dec 18 tournament with about 1.2 million visitors.
The Hayya Service Centre in Doha will provide direct support for fans; all travellers to Qatar will need the Hayya pass to enter from Nov 1, whether they intend to watch a game or not.

site_title: New Adobe software tools aim to aid 3D content creation for metaverse
summary: Adobe has released two new software tools to aid 3D content creation for the metaverse. The "3D Capture" tool allows users to take multiple photos of a real-world object with any camera and merge them into a 3D digital object. The second tool enables artists to edit 3D objects on a desktop computer and manipulate them in virtual reality headsets, providing a similar experience to sculpting clay. These tools aim to make 3D content creation faster and easier, with early applications in e-commerce and virtual try-on experiences.

images.alt_text: Adobe is looking to expand its web-based products to attract more casual designers and small businesses.
Technologies such as virtual reality headsets and blockchain are expected to push the boundaries of the metaverse beyond gaming.

site_title: GIC says global recession scenario possible, eyes Australia opportunities
summary: GIC, the world's fifth-largest sovereign investor, says it's preparing for a possible global recession, citing rising inflation as a major risk. Chief executive Lim Chow Kiat warned that central banks need to control inflation to ensure global economic stability. Despite this, GIC remains optimistic about Australia's economy, which it sees as relatively resilient. The fund is exploring opportunities in Australia's renewable energy industry and related sectors. Meanwhile, GIC continues to focus on China, which it expects to continue its growth and reform policies.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang’s chief executive officer and chief investment officer, Vincent Toe, believes her appointment would serve to  strengthen the company’s market position, given her “close relationships with leading fund managers”.
Adani Group will invest more than US$100 billion over the next decade, most of it in the energy transition business'

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders struggle to keep rally’s momentum
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session, with Hong Kong and Shanghai facing losses, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul rose. The rally's momentum was weighed down by profit-takers, and analysts warned that the current rally could soon turn due to central banks' interest rate hikes and inflation concerns. The yen edged closer to 150 per dollar, with Japanese officials ready to intervene if necessary, and investors focused on the upcoming earnings season and US data to determine the market's direction.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shed more than 1 per cent and Shanghai was also in the red on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.98 points or 0.07% to 1401.34. Volume was 162.49 million lots worth RM75.81 million, with 205 gainers outnumbering 102 losers.

site_title: Air India plans to triple its fleet of 113 jets in five years
summary: Air India plans to triple its fleet of 113 aircraft to 300 over the next five years. The airline has restored 17 grounded planes and is in talks with manufacturers to procure new aircraft. Air India aims to increase its domestic and international market share to 30% by 2027, with a focus on improving on-time performance, food, and refunds. The airline will also accelerate investment in people, systems, and equipment in the second phase of its transformation plan, aiming to become a "world-class" airline by the end of the five-year overhaul period.

site_title: Indonesia to offer tax holiday to companies investing in new capital
summary: Indonesia is offering a 30-year tax holiday and a 350% "super-tax deduction" for companies investing in the US$32 billion Nusantara new capital city project. The incentives aim to attract investments in healthcare, education, and entertainment. President Joko Widodo hopes to celebrate Indonesia's independence day at a new presidential palace in the new capital by August 17, 2024. The project has faced uncertainty, with a June survey showing 59% of experts were unsure about its materialization.

images.alt_text: Joko Widodo, President of Indonesia, says: “Kanjuruhan stadium in Malang...we will demolish it and rebuild according to Fifa standards.”
Transformational and structural trends present an attractive set of opportunities especially in Asia, says Benjamin Hung, CEO, Asia, Standard Chartered.

site_title: Hong Kong to lift public gathering limit to 12 in reopening push
summary: Hong Kong has lifted its public gathering limit to 12 people, a significant step towards reviving its reputation as a financial hub. The change, effective October 20, brings the rule in line with other public places and marks a gradual easing of Covid restrictions. The move is seen as a response to criticism from health professionals and business groups, which have called for the scrapping of remaining restrictions to boost the economy. Hong Kong's reopening efforts trail its financial hub rivals, including Singapore, which has also eased its Covid Zero regime.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee speaks to the media before an Executive Council meeting in Hong Kong on September 6, 2022. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)

site_title: Thailand’s finance ministry sees economic growth of 3.0-3.5% this year
summary: Thailand's finance minister predicts the country's economic growth will reach 3.0-3.5% this year, driven by the key export and tourism sectors. The economy is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels late this year or early next, lagging neighboring countries due to slow tourism recovery. Last year's growth was 1.5%, and the economy grew 2.5% in the April-June period. The ministry also expects 8-10 million foreign tourists this year, up from a COVID-19 low of 2.5 million in 2021.

site_title: Gold prices edge lower on steady dollar, Fed rate-hike jitters
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,650.75 per ounce, weighed down by a steady dollar and concerns over the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. Despite predictions of a price rise to $1,830.50 per ounce in a year, US gold futures rose 0.1%. The dollar index also edged higher, while manufacturing sector production in the US rose in September, indicating the sector remains strong despite rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US rates, which increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Forging connections for a greener future
summary: Singapore Fintech Festival 2022 launched an ESG Impact Hub, a collaboration between financial institutions, regulatory bodies, and tech companies to drive a greener future. The hub aims to foster connections between stakeholders, including MAS, KPMG, Google Cloud, and Terrascope. Founders and industry experts emphasized the importance of community-driven initiatives to drive innovation and sustainability in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Jacquelyn Tan, UOB’s head of group personal financial services, said personalisation could take an educational slant in the future, delving into dishing out financial and wealth planning tips.
ABS’s new sustainable guidelines, which were developed with technical input from WWF-Singapore, cover private banking activities ranging from wealth planning and investments to financing.

site_title: Twitter locks staff stock accounts in anticipation of deal
summary: Twitter has frozen employee stock accounts as the deadline to seal a deal with Elon Musk approaches. The move, made in anticipation of the acquisition, will prevent employees from accessing or trading shares from the Equity Award Centre. The deadline to finalize a $44 billion sale is October 28. Employees are concerned about potential job cuts, with some on the anonymous app Blind sharing tips on how to prepare for layoffs. The freeze is seen as a signal that Twitter is moving forward with the proposed deal, which has caused Twitter's shares to jump 1.9%.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has raised the prospect of reducing Twitter’s reliance on advertising, and instead incorporating it into an “everything app”, known as X, with online payments.
Twitter users have for years demanded the ability to edit their tweets after publishing them, mostly to fix errors such as typos.

site_title: Qatar Airways cuts flights to make space for World Cup fans
summary: Qatar Airways has cut flights from 18 destinations to accommodate the influx of visitors for the upcoming World Cup, with about 1.2 million expected to attend. The airline's CEO, Akbar Al Baker, prioritized accommodating hundreds of flights for the tournament. The World Cup will take place from November 20 to December 18, with shuttle flights, charter flights, and private jets expected to arrive daily.

images.alt_text: The Hayya Service Centre in Doha will provide direct support for fans; all travellers to Qatar will need the Hayya pass to enter from Nov 1, whether they intend to watch a game or not.

Airbus has revoked its entire outstanding order from Qatar Airways for A350 jets, severing all new jetliner business with the Gulf carrier in a dramatic new twist to a dispute clouding World Cup preparations, two industry sources said.

site_title: Powering the future of business with renewables
summary: The global transition to renewable energy is gaining pace, driven by decreasing costs, improved efficiency, and storage solutions. Cleaner energy sources are becoming more accessible, with technological innovations and policy frameworks such as carbon taxes and green project incentives making renewables more competitive. However, challenges remain, including limited availability and affordability, and the intermittent nature of renewable energy sources. Sustainability-conscious businesses are incentivized to go green, with some signing up to commitments like RE100 and greening their energy supply. As the world shifts towards cleaner energy, the long-term trade-offs in terms of cost and benefits must be considered.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as strong US corporate earnings boost banks, tech stocks
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.1% to 6,786, driven by strong US corporate earnings boosting banks and tech stocks. The S&P ASX 200 index rose for a second session, with financial shares up 0.4% and tech stocks up 0.4%. Heavyweight mining firms fell 0.5%, while energy stocks dropped 1.8% due to lower oil prices. Australia's No.2 power producer, Origin Energy, expects a sharp rise in underlying earnings from its energy markets business in the 2023 financial year.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.7 per cent with all sectors but one closing in positive territory.

site_title: Netflix returns to growth, saying the worst of slowdown is over
summary: Netflix reported its third-quarter results, surpassing expectations with 2.41 million new subscribers and revenue growth of 5.9% to $7.93 billion. The company expects to sign up 4.5 million more globally this period. Despite a slow growth pace, Netflix sees a path to reaccelerate growth and shares rose 12% in extended trading. The company will no longer provide subscriber forecasts and plans to introduce an advertising-supported version of the service in November.

images.alt_text: Newly released films will have limited advertising to preserve the cinematic experience.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange poised for record streak in profit declines
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange (HKEX) is poised to report its sixth consecutive quarterly profit decline, the longest slump in its history, due to market turmoil and global economic concerns. Daily trading averaged HK$98.3 billion, down 40% from the previous year, and initial public offerings (IPOs) recovered slightly. Analysts predict a 31-37% decline in net income, citing further downside risks to HKEX's share price and the need for reforms to expand the IPO regime.

site_title: Bankrupt crypto lender Celsius facing US federal ‘investigations’
summary: Celsius Network, a cryptocurrency lender, is facing US federal investigations amid its bankruptcy filing. The company, which paid interest on coin deposits, is under scrutiny from at least 40 states and federal government agencies, including the SEC, CFTC, and FTC. Celsius froze withdrawals in June and filed for bankruptcy in July, with many creditors accusing the company and its CEO of misleading them about risks involved. An examiner has been appointed to investigate issues, and the committee of unsecured creditors is seeking to limit the examiner's focus on government investigations.

images.alt_text: Celsius suspended customer withdrawals in June and filed for bankruptcy protection the following month after making risky bets before the broader crypto market soured.
Bankman-Fried already scooped up the assets of bankrupt crypto brokerage Voyager Digital in an agreement valued at about US$1.4 billion.

site_title: HSBC breached advertising code with green posters, watchdog says
summary: HSBC has been reprimanded by the UK's Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) for breaching environmental advertising rules with its "green" posters, which were deemed misleading to consumers. The bank's advertisements claimed it would provide $1 trillion in financing for net-zero projects, but failed to disclose its significant financing of carbon-intensive industries. The ASA has ordered HSBC to ensure the posters do not appear again and to adequately qualify future environmental claims. This ruling follows a trend of "green hushing" among companies, with research suggesting firms are shying away from promoting their green credentials due to stigma associated with exaggerated claims.

images.alt_text: HSBC said it plans to explore opportunities in China’s southwest region. Its existing branches are located in eastern areas where more high net worth (HNW) individuals live.

More than ever, we need the companies making progress on sustainability to inspire their peers - this is impossible if progress is happening in silence, says Renat Heuberger, CEO of South Pole. (PHOTO SOUTH POLE)

site_title: Offices in New York, nationwide hit peak post-pandemic occupancy
summary: US offices in New York and other major cities have reached their highest post-pandemic occupancy levels, with New York offices at 47.8% full and a 10-city average at 49%. This marks a significant increase from previous weeks, but still falls short of the 50% mark. Meanwhile, work patterns are stabilizing, with hybrid schedules dominant, and working from home is more common in major cities than smaller towns. Occupancy rates are influenced by factors such as school holidays and RTO mandates, with some cities, like Austin, Texas, seeing nearly two-thirds full offices.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on US earnings, global rallies
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.35% in early trade on Wednesday, driven by strong US corporate earnings that boosted global markets. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 95.56 points to 27,251.70. This follows a global rally, with the broader Topix index also edging up 0.12%. The gains come as investors monitor US-EU trade talks and await GDP data from Singapore.

images.alt_text: epa10151563 People stand next to a display showing the foreign exchange rate (R) between Japanese yen and US dollar and the Nikkei Stock Average during an afternoon trade session in Tokyo, Japan, 01 September 2022. The US currency rose to a mid-139 yen level in concern over interest rate gaps between Japan and the US.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) announced the acquisition of a freehold, five-building light industrial complex in Copenhagen for 117.4 million Danish kroner (S$22.3 million). The acquisition consideration represents a 7% discount to the asset's independent valuation. The Reit's manager does not expect the transaction to have a material effect on its net tangible assets. The acquisition was announced on Tuesday, resulting in a 1.9% increase in the Reit's closing price to 1.59 euros.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped at the open on October 19, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.64% to 16,805.91. The decline follows a three-day run-up and traders await the first policy speech by city leader John Lee later in the day. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.25% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.29%. The decline is attributed to market uncertainty and anticipation of policy changes.

site_title: Japan authorities keep up warning against sharp yen decline
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned about the yen's sharp decline against the dollar, trading near a 32-year low at 149 yen. Suzuki said the government would "properly respond" in the foreign exchange market based on existing policy. Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda characterized the yen's recent softening as "extremely important" and "one-sided". The warnings come as the yen approaches a psychological barrier of 150.

images.alt_text: The extract from pressed red grapes being released from large containers ahead of fermentation at Chateau Mercian in the city of Koshu in Japan's Yamanashi prefecture, the birthplace of viticulture in Japan and the country's most iconic wine.
The Japanese yen has weakened dramatically relative to the US dollar this year
The yen has fallen against the US dollar, to its lowest level since 1990.

site_title: Apple unveils upgraded iPads and lower-cost set-top TV box
summary: Apple has introduced upgraded iPads, including a new iPad Pro with the M2 chip, a refreshed entry-level iPad with a fresh design and new charging port, and a lower-cost TV set-top box. The changes aim to revitalize products overshadowed by the iPhone, which generates 9% of Apple's revenue. The new iPad Pro boasts faster Wi-Fi connectivity and support for ProRes video recording, while the entry-level iPad features flat edges and a USB-C connector. The new Apple TV box starts at $129 and has improved high-dynamic-range video.

images.alt_text: The chips were initially planned to be used only for iPhones sold in the Chinese market.

site_title: Australia’s central bank breaks ranks with peers on fallout fear
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has broken ranks with other central banks by down-shifting its pace of policy tightening, citing better-behaved wages and heavily indebted households. The RBA, led by Governor Philip Lowe, has surprised markets with a quarter-point hike, contrasting with the Federal Reserve's 3-point hikes in eight months. Lowe has emphasized the need to balance inflation control with economic stability, highlighting Australia's unique economic conditions, including lower wages and a rapid recovery in overseas arrivals. The RBA now expects to end its tightening cycle around 3.3% compared to 4.7% in the US.

images.alt_text: The pace of declines eased after prices dropped in August by the most in four decades.

site_title: BOE to start asset sales in two weeks, exclude long-dated debt
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) will start asset sales in two weeks, excluding long-dated debt, as part of its quantitative tightening (QT) plan. The move aims to reduce the central bank's balance sheet by £80 billion annually, with sales to be distributed evenly across short and medium maturity sectors. The announcement comes after the BOE delayed bond sales due to market chaos, and follows a new fiscal policy focused on reducing public debt. Governor Andrew Bailey's plan is seen as a pragmatic compromise, allowing the bank to unwind its balance sheet without risking market stability.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in the City of London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Hyundai lobbies US to ease EV rule that hurts foreign carmakers
summary: Hyundai Motor and the South Korean government are lobbying the US government to ease restrictions on electric vehicle (EV) tax credits, which could hinder Hyundai's growth in the US market. The US climate law, passed this year, limits the $7,500 tax credit to EVs built in North America, as Hyundai won't have a US plant until 2025. Hyundai is seeking a delay, arguing the rule would leave the automaker at a disadvantage against US and European EV makers. The South Korean government is also pressing for more lenient provisions or an extended timeline, citing the importance of trade and supply chains.

images.alt_text: A shop sign of Hyundai is seen outside a car showroom in Bletchley, Milton Keynes, Britain, May 31, 2020. REUTERS/Andrew Boyers
The groundbreaking comes amid anger from Korea and the European Union over US electric vehicle tax policy.

site_title: US: Stocks climb again after solid earnings on Tuesday
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session on Tuesday, driven by solid earnings from companies like Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 1.1% to 30,523.80, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 1.1% and 0.9%, respectively. Despite concerns about a challenging earnings period, the strong bank earnings have boosted investors' mood, with some analysts predicting an impressive bear-market rally.

images.alt_text: Strong earnings from Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson lifted hopes that upbeat corporate reports could soothe market worries of a potential recession due to rising inflation and interest rates.

site_title: Enhancing shareholders’ voting process through blockchain
summary: Blockchain technology could enhance shareholder voting processes by reducing costs and increasing transparency. Currently, only 12% of retail shareholders vote in US companies, and this can be attributed to "rational apathy." Implementing blockchain-based voting systems could spur participation by making voting easier and more accessible, as well as eliminating the need for intermediaries. A semi-private blockchain run by a central authority could be developed to facilitate this transition, and Estonia has already implemented a similar system. This technology has the potential to improve the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of shareholder decision-making, particularly in annual general meetings and extraordinary general meetings.

images.alt_text: Shareholders are better educated and asking more critical questions as they demand accountability, says Sias president and chief executive David Gerald.

site_title: Analysts urge investors to pay closer heed to risks of rising leverage
summary: Analysts warn investors to closely monitor the risks associated with rising leverage in companies, particularly those with high gearing ratios. ST Engineering, Wilmar International, and Olam Group are among the Singapore-listed companies with the highest leverage ratios, up from a year-ago. As interest rates rise, investors should be cautious of potential stress in these companies, which have increased their debt levels to grow operations.

images.alt_text: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has the highest gearing ratio among the S-Reits, at 43.9% as at Jun 30.

site_title: Iran agrees to ship missiles, more drones to Russia
