summary: DBS has launched DBS Quick Finance, an AI-driven working capital solution for Singaporean SMEs, offering up to S$300,000 in financing with "almost instant" access. The solution uses hyper-personalised AI and data analytics to streamline the application process, reducing it to one minute and approval to one second. This move aims to address the working capital needs of micro and small businesses amid inflationary pressures, supply chain challenges, and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: In the digital economy, the businesses that adapt to changes quickest will thrive. As disruption continues, CEOs who previously delegated their digital strategy want to take direct leadership today, says Sujith Abraham, senior vice president and GM, Asean, at Salesforce.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Sinarmas Land, Colex, Bonvests
summary: Singapore Airlines' operating results for September showed an increase in passengers and passenger capacity, driven by tailwinds. Sinarmas Land partnered with K2 Data Centres to develop hyperscale data centers in Indonesia. Colex, a waste management company, resumed trading after a proposed privatization offer by Bonvests and Coop International was announced.

site_title: Luxury condo sales hold up in Q3 even as top-end GCB market softens
summary: Luxury condo sales in Singapore remained strong in Q3 2022, with 110 non-landed homes sold at a total quantum of S$1 billion, a 15.5% increase from Q2. Ultra-luxury condos like Les Maisons Nassim saw significant sales, with units selling for up to S$68 million. Foreign buyers, particularly Chinese nationals, Americans, and Malaysians, were the top buyers of luxury properties. In contrast, the Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market softened, with only 12 deals in Q3 and a 47.6% decrease in sales year-to-date. Analysts predict the GCB market will remain strong in Q4.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore sold a total of 987 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), with more than 913 units launched in September.
Condo resale prices for the rest of the central region (RCR) and the core central region (CCR) were up 1.3 per cent and 1.1 per cent, respectively, on a month-on-month basis.

In Q2 2022 and for the period July and August 2022, the percentage of foreign buyers of non-landed properties in the CCR was 12.3 per cent and 11.9 per cent respectively, according to Savills. The highest percentage recorded in 2021 was 10.2 per cent.
GuocoLand to launch preview for Lentor condo project; prices start from S$1,880 psf
With the increase in the RCR’s psf price since Jun, the median price paid for a new non-landed home there has exceeded that in the CCR., says Huttons.

site_title: SoftBank sells THG stake to online retailer’s founder, Qatar after share drop
summary: SoftBank is selling its stake in British online shopping firm THG to founder Matthew Moulding and Qatar Investment Authority after the company's share price collapsed by over 90% in a year. The stake, valued at over £500 million, was initially worth £36 million by the time of sale. The sale marks the end of a disastrous investment by SoftBank, which began in 2021 as part of a $1 billion fundraise.

images.alt_text: The cuts will affect staff in the investment teams and back-office staff in departments such as finance and legal.

site_title: Asia: Markets up, sterling holds gains after UK budget U-turn
summary: UK's new finance minister Jeremy Hunt unveiled a spending package, scrapping tax cuts and warning of lower spending, after a volatile few weeks that saw the pound hit a record low. Sterling rose 2% and government borrowing costs fell, while the FTSE 100 jumped, followed by gains in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and other Asian markets. However, analysts warn that the advances may not be sustained due to broader worries about inflation and rising interest rates, and some markets, like Shanghai and Singapore, dipped.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shed more than 1 per cent and Shanghai was also in the red on Monday.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs surges 18% to 2-month high, gets queried
summary: Medtecs International, a medical consumables distributor, surged 18% to S$0.144, its highest in nearly two months, due to an SGX query about "unusual price movements" and potential non-compliance with listing rules. The company's last announcement was the opening of a glove manufacturing facility in Cambodia, which may have contributed to the price increase. The SGX query also sought confirmation on whether Medtecs has complied with Catalist Rule 703.

site_title: Singapore stocks inch up 0.6% at Tuesday open
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% at the Tuesday open, following overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index gained 19.42 points to 3,035.17, with banking stocks and active index counters including Sembcorp Marine and CapitaLand Investment leading the gains. European shares also rallied, and Tokyo markets opened higher as investors took heart from Wall Street's gains, easing concerns over corporate earnings.

images.alt_text: Tailwinds continue to push Singapore Airline's operating results for September, with demand and passenger capacity up.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.29 points or 0.6% to 1394.56. The market saw 101.96 million lots traded worth RM44.06 million, with 221 gainers and 53 losers.

site_title: Gold steady as tepid US dollar counters rate-hike woes
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,651.75 per ounce on Tuesday, despite the US dollar's decline, as the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest hikes limited gains. The dollar index and US 10-year Treasury yields eased, while benchmark US inflation showed no signs of abating. The IMF's Gita Gopinath urged the Fed to continue tightening monetary policy to maintain credibility, setting the stage for a potential fourth consecutive 75-basis-point interest rate hike next month.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US rates, which increases the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Mercedes pledges robust results regardless of gloomy conditions
summary: Mercedes-Benz CEO Ola Kaellenius stated that the company aims to deliver robust financial results even in an economically-challenged environment, with operating margin goals of 14% in a favorable setting and 8% in poor conditions. Despite a decline of 18% in shares this year, Kaellenius believes there is value to unlock in the stock, citing the company's focus on moving upmarket and its ability to weather economic cycles. Mercedes has no dominant anchor investor, unlike some German peers, and will continue to invest in its portfolio and electric vehicle business.

images.alt_text: The EQE SUV will edge out the cheaper Model Y with 590 kilometres of driving range and start at around 70,000 euros (S$97,115) when sales begin late this year. I

site_title: Asia-Pacific real estate investment growth dips in Q3 amid cautious sentiment: JLL
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment growth dipped in Q3 due to cautious sentiment, according to a report by JLL. Despite robust activity in Singapore, where large office transactions saw a 116% hike, overall investment volumes fell 29% to US$28 billion. The decline was attributed to macroeconomic factors, including rapid currency depreciation and rising interest rates, which prompted investors to adopt a more cautious approach to capital deployment.

images.alt_text:
generic / ST20210126_202104438482 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Saint Andrew's Cathedral and the City Hall area with the Padang, Singapore. 26 January 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher extending US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following US rallies, as investors eased concerns over corporate earnings. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.54% to 27,189.35, while the Topix index increased 1.29% to 1,903.81. The gains came as investors took heart from Wall Street's recent rallies, despite ongoing worries over US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Boeing offers 737 Max jets to Air India amid US-China trade tensions
summary: Boeing is offering 737 Max jets to Air India, a potential customer amid US-China trade tensions, as the planemaker seeks to offload aircraft it's not allowed to deliver to China. Boeing has about $5 billion in cash tied up in the jets, and as many as 50 planes may be resold on an "as-is" basis. Air India is overhauling its fleet under new owner Tata Group and is seeking to order up to 300 narrowbody aircraft, with most appraisers considering the 737s built in 2018 or 2019 as brand new.

images.alt_text: Boeing, which hasn’t signed a major plane deal with China since 2017, took the unusual step of issuing a statement after the July Airbus order was announced.

site_title: YouTube expands audio and podcast advertising for brands
summary: YouTube is expanding audio and podcast advertising globally, allowing brands to target users who listen to music or podcasts on the platform. This move comes as the advertising industry faces challenges due to inflation and supply-chain disruptions, prompting brands to focus on new customer acquisition and sales. The expansion aims to provide brands with more opportunities to reach music and podcast listeners, potentially driving product sales.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logos of Google and YouTube are seen in Davos, Switzerland, May 22, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 1.49% gain, driven by a global rally following the UK's decision to scrap its debt-fuelled mini-budget. The Hang Seng Index rose 247.30 points to 16,860.20. China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.32% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.45%. The gains were attributed to the global market's reaction to the UK's decision, which helped to calm financial markets.

site_title: Singapore, Australia sign Green Economy Agreement with 17 initial projects
summary: Singapore and Australia signed a Green Economy Agreement (GEA) on Oct 18, aiming to boost job opportunities and growth in green sectors through 17 joint projects. The agreement covers seven areas: green finance, clean energy, and skills development. It also includes cooperation on standards and regulations, climate-related financial disclosures, and regional energy connectivity. The GEA is seen as a pathfinder for other countries and could be used as a blueprint for future agreements. The agreement was signed by Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong and Australia's Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell, with both prime ministers present.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the joint press conference for the 7th Annual Leaders' Meeting in Canberra on Oct 18.

Clockwise from left: Australia's Minister for Industry and Science Ed Husic and Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong, witness the signing of the Australia- Singapore Synchrotron Access Agreement by Prof Chen Tsuhan, deputy president of the National University of Singapore, and Shaun Jenkinson, chief executive officer of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.
From left: Patrick Gorman, Australia's Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, welcomes Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Madam Ho Ching to Canberra.

site_title: Chinese junk bonds set record low as property crisis spreads
summary: Chinese junk dollar bonds have hit a record low of 55.7 US cents, down 0.3 cents on the dollar, amid a worsening property crisis. The slump is driven by a government crackdown on excessive borrowing and speculation, resulting in record defaults by developers like China Evergrande. Investors await further policy steps, but recent efforts have shown insufficient support for the struggling sector. The sector's gauge has reached its lowest since January 2012, and Chinese developers' shares have also been suffering.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 500 billion yuan (S$99.2 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.75 per cent

site_title: US banks’ credit-card businesses are enjoying Goldilocks moment
summary: US banks' credit card businesses are experiencing a "Goldilocks moment" with spending up 13% and average outstanding balances increasing 12.4% at Bank of America, despite the Federal Reserve raising interest rates. Low delinquencies and consumers borrowing again after years of paying off balances contribute to the growth. Bank of America added 1.25 million new credit card accounts, with average Fico scores at 770, indicating a relatively stable and profitable portfolio. The bank's risk-adjusted margin, a measure of profitability, decreased to 10.07% from a year ago.

site_title: Singapore, Australia to explore ‘new areas of cooperation’ such as supply chain resilience: PM Lee
summary: Singapore and Australia will explore new areas of cooperation, including supply chain resilience, following the signing of a landmark Green Economy Agreement. The partnership aims to strengthen the security and resilience of supply chains for food and energy, as well as connectivity to the global market. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced the move at a joint press conference in Canberra. This cooperation is part of the two countries' Comprehensive Strategic Partnership and seeks to enhance their economic and security ties.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from left: Australia's Minister for Industry and Science Ed Husic and Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong, witness the signing of the Australia- Singapore Synchrotron Access Agreement by Prof Chen Tsuhan, deputy president of the National University of Singapore, and Shaun Jenkinson, chief executive officer of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.
Singapore’s Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Australia’s Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell signed the GEA in the presence of both prime ministers.

site_title: US investigating bankrupt crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital
summary: The US is investigating bankrupt crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, which filed for bankruptcy in July after a broad sell-off in digital assets. Regulators, including the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) and Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), are scrutinizing the firm's handling of investor funds and its failure to register. The founders, Su Zhu and Kyle Davies, remain unknown and have not cooperated with liquidators. The investigation may lead to monetary fines and penalties for the firm and individuals involved.

images.alt_text: Three Arrows, which operated from Singapore until earlier this year, collapsed after the implosion of the Terra algorithmic stablecoin in May sent cryptocurrencies tumbling.

site_title: Lufthansa doubles 2022 profit forecast on surge in bookings
summary: Lufthansa has raised its 2022 profit forecast to over $1.4 billion, twice its initial estimate, due to a surge in bookings and higher ticket prices. The airline's adjusted earnings before interest and taxes are now expected to be more than $1 billion, up from previous guidance of $500 million. Revenue doubled to $10.1 billion in the third quarter, while adjusted EBIT jumped to $1.1 billion. Strong demand for travel is expected to continue, with the cargo division anticipated to deliver a record result.

images.alt_text: Carsten Spohr, CEO of Lufthansa, says: “We have finally left the crisis behind, after two and a half years.”

site_title: EU to propose 40b euros fund to mitigate energy price fallout
summary: The European Union plans to propose a 40 billion euro fund to help mitigate the energy price fallout on consumers and businesses. The EU's executive arm, the European Commission, will allow member states to tap existing cohesion funds to support small- and medium-sized companies and vulnerable households. The plan, part of a broader package of measures, aims to address high energy costs fueled by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and will be discussed at an EU summit on October 20-21.

images.alt_text: The EU is currently negotiating a proposed package of climate proposals, which includes an effective ban on the sale of new fossil-fuel vehicles from 2035.

site_title: Bank Indonesia playing catch-up, to deliver another 50 bps rate hike on Thursday: poll
summary: Bank Indonesia is set to deliver a second consecutive 50 basis point interest rate hike on Thursday to combat inflation, which reached 5.95% in September, the highest since 2015. The central bank aims to catch up with peers and curb inflation driven by a weaker rupiah. This move follows a modest quarter-point rate rise in the previous cycle, and marks a shift towards a more aggressive monetary policy to control inflation.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia’s largest economy has been enjoying an export boom due to high commodity prices globally, reporting a trade surplus every month since May 2020.

site_title: New Zealand third-quarter inflation outpaces expectations
summary: New Zealand's consumer inflation rose 7.2% in the third quarter, exceeding expectations and remaining at historically high levels. The annual inflation rate slowed from 7.3% in the second quarter, but the quarter-on-quarter increase of 2.2% was higher than forecast. The main drivers of the inflation were rising construction, local government taxes, and housing rentals. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has raised interest rates to combat inflation, and the New Zealand dollar rose slightly after the data release.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ends 1.4 per cent lower at 6,664.4 points.

site_title: UK PM Truss ‘sorry’ for economic ‘mistakes’ but vows to stay on
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has apologized for her government's "mistakes" in economic policy, which led to market turmoil. Her government axed nearly all debt-fuelled tax cuts to avert further market chaos. New finance chief Jeremy Hunt took control, estimating the tax changes would raise £32 billion annually, but economists estimated a £60-billion black hole. Truss vowed to remain leader despite questions over her control of government policy, as her position becomes increasingly precarious amidst calls for her resignation.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends a news conference in London, Britain, Oct 14, 2022.
Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt notes that there will be more difficult decisions ahead on both tax and spending.
The Stoxx 600 index ended 1.8 per cent higher, extending gains for a third straight session.

site_title: Bonvests proposes privatisation offer of Colex via scheme of arrangement
summary: Bonvests Holdings has proposed a scheme of arrangement to take waste management company Colex private, offering S$0.23 in cash per share, a 25% premium to the last traded price. The offer aims to provide Colex with operational and financial flexibility in a challenging operating environment, marked by increased competition for waste collection licenses and declining revenue. The proposed privatisation is seen as an opportunity for shareholders to exit at a premium, with a total return of 80.2% over a 36-month period.

images.alt_text: These companies tend to provide more inelastic services to industrial customers with headroom for growth.

site_title: Oil steady as recession woes counter positive Chinese signals
summary: Oil prices held steady on Monday, recovering from a 6.4% fall last week, as fears of a global recession offset China's continued loose monetary policy. Brent crude futures rose 1 cent to $91.62 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 15 cents to $85.46. The mixed signals from China, combined with concerns over inflation and energy costs, led to choppy trading. Despite the steady prices, the global economy remains uncertain, with recession worries lingering.

images.alt_text: The United States said on Thursday that the oil production cut would boost Russia’s foreign earnings and suggested it had been engineered for political reasons by Saudi Arabia, which on Sunday denied it was supporting Moscow in its invasion of Ukraine.
Oil supply is due to remain tight after Opec+ on Oct 5 pledged  to cut output by two million barrels per day.

site_title: Digital media firm Stability AI raises funds at US$1b value
summary: Stability AI, the parent company of Stable Diffusion, an AI tool for digital art, has raised $101 million in a seed round, valuing the company at around $1 billion. The funding will be used to deploy custom versions of the model for larger-scale users, invest in supercomputing power, and hire more employees. Stable Diffusion's open-source software allows users to create realistic or surrealistic images, with over 1.5 million users on its Web application and more than 10 million daily users across all channels.

site_title: US: Hopes about earnings lift stocks
summary: US stocks rose 1.9% on Monday, lifting hopes for a strong earnings season. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 30,185.82, following better-than-expected bank results from Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, and others. Analysts are optimistic that a successful third-quarter earnings season could boost the market, which has been affected by inflation and interest rate hikes in 2022.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 424.8 points, or 1.43 per cent, at the open to 30,059.58.

site_title: Trump aides blocked accurate Covid information: US probe
summary: A congressional report found that former US President Donald Trump's administration attempted to block accurate COVID-19 information from being released to align with the president's public downplaying of the crisis. Trump aides bullied CDC staff, tried to rewrite reports, and inserted political appointees into the publication process. They also edited or blocked articles in the CDC's weekly scientific journal, resulting in at least five instances. The report described an "unprecedented campaign of political interference" in the pandemic response.

images.alt_text: Wesley Hunt (left), a Republican who is likely to win his House race, during a campaign event in Cibolo, Texas., April 13, 2022.

Google said Truth Social has since been updated to comply with its policies barring objectionable posts, and has built in effective systems for reporting and removing unwanted content as well as blocking abusers.

site_title: SIA could be biggest winner as larger airlines lead gains from air travel rebound
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is poised to be the biggest winner in the air travel rebound, according to analysts. The airline's strong financials, intact pilot force, and moderate dependence on mainland China make it well-positioned to benefit from the easing of border restrictions in Taiwan, Japan, and Hong Kong. In contrast, Cathay Pacific faces challenges due to its limited passenger capacity and dependence on mainland China, which still has restrictions in place. Analysts predict SIA will lead the recovery, with Changi Airport's capacity expected to reach pre-pandemic levels by 2023.

images.alt_text: Passengers, part of the first tourist group arriving from Thailand, pose for the media at Taoyuan International Airport in Taoyuan on Oct 13, 2022, after Taiwan reopened its borders by ending mandatory Covid quarantine for arrivals.

Asia’s aviation recovery has lagged other parts of the world in large part because of China’s ongoing border closures that have kept its international passenger numbers averaging only 2 per cent to 3 per cent of pre-pandemic levels, according to Iata data.
Cathay Pacific has held a recruitment drive in Hong Kong on Friday (Oct 7); the airline is also adding passenger aircraft and freighters.
Virgin Atlantic hasn’t operated any passenger flights to Hong Kong since December, after the city banned all flights from the UK during the depths of Covid.

The number of flights that airlines have filed to operate at Changi Airport by year is more than 80 per cent of pre-Covid-19 levels, and Transport Minister S Iswaran expects this to increase further following an easing of border restrictions in Hong Kong, Japan and Taiwan.
Along with its subsidiaries, the company had 20,800 employees globally by Jun 30, after cutting thousands of roles during the pandemic.
SIA will, from Oct 30, mount an additional daily service to Tokyo’s Haneda Airport – SQ636 – on top of the existing daily SQ634 service to Haneda, and daily SQ638 service to Tokyo’s Narita Airport.

site_title: The long shadow of the Fed’s rate hike on emerging Asia
summary: The US Federal Reserve's recent interest rate hike has raised concerns for emerging Asian economies, which face challenges including liquidity contraction, debt-servicing burdens, and inflation. As the US rate hikes trigger financial market volatility, emerging economies risk slower growth and increased debt servicing costs. The region's reliance on foreign capital and currency fluctuations exacerbates these challenges. To mitigate these impacts, emerging economies may need to look to promising new industries such as virtual reality and artificial intelligence for growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was up 0.33 per cent at 113.18 on Monday, off lows around 110 last week and creeping back toward last month’s 20-year high of 114.78.
Several Fed policymakers have said they want to see a decline in core inflation, a measure excluding volatile food and energy prices, before they slow the pace of rate increases.

site_title: ExxonMobil exits Russia empty-handed with oil project ‘unilaterally terminated’
summary: ExxonMobil has safely exited Russia after the government unilaterally terminated its interests in the Sakhalin-1 oil and gas project, its largest in the country. The termination followed seven months of discussions over an orderly transfer of its 30% stake in the project. ExxonMobil valued its assets at over $4 billion, but did not disclose if it received any compensation. The company declined to comment on whether it will contest the seizure through international arbitration.

images.alt_text: Exxon has been trying to exit its Russia operations and transfer its role in Sakhalin-1 to a partner since March, after international sanctions were imposed against Moscow.
Brent crude futures were down 1 cent, or 0.01 per cent, to US$91.62 a barrel on Monday, recovering from a 6.4 per cent fall last week.

site_title: ‘Green-hushing’ may be the new concern with climate disclosures, study finds
summary: A study by South Pole found that many companies setting net-zero targets are choosing not to publicly disclose their progress, potentially hindering decarbonization efforts. 87% of surveyed organizations globally have set a net-zero target, but 23% of those with science-based targets do not plan to publicize them. This "green hushing" could limit knowledge sharing and opportunities for collaboration. Singapore companies performed well in this respect, but still had a significant number of organizations reluctant to share their net-zero targets.

images.alt_text: The panel on why ESG matters in business valuation, organised by the Institute of Valuers and Appraisers and International Valuation Standards Council, was moderated by BT correspondent Wong Pei Ting.
Countries typically take a “production-based” accounting approach in quantifying their greenhouse gas emissions.
A Harvard report published on Tuesday highlights rampant greenwashing by leading companies on social media.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as investors cheer UK policy reversal
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.8% on Monday, extending gains for a third straight session, as investors cheered the UK's policy reversal. The UK's ITV rallied after a report suggested it could sell its stake in a production arm. Banks and real estate companies drove the gains. The Stoxx 600 index has recovered from recent losses, with investors optimistic about the UK's fiscal plan reversal and its potential impact on the region's markets.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends a news conference in London, Britain, Oct 14, 2022.
London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index gained 0.2 per cent to 6,871.29 points, after the Treasury revealed that some of its fiscal measures will be announced two weeks earlier than originally scheduled.

site_title: Airbus aims smallest A220 business jet at US after Russia loss
summary: Airbus aims to capitalize on the US market for its smallest A220 business jet, which will enter service in the first half of next year. The company lost significant sales to Russia due to sanctions, but expects the US market to compensate for the loss. Airbus has seen improved demand from China and the Middle East, and is investing in promoting the A220. The corporate version, ACJ220, has garnered four sales this year, including two from US lessor Azorra. Airbus is confident that the A220 is better suited for the US market than its larger models.

images.alt_text: A new Airbus SE A220 narrow-body passenger jet during its unveiling by Air France-KLM at Paris Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris, France, on Wednesday, Sept. 29, 2021. The A220s will replace 51 Airbus A318s and A319s with an average age close to 17 years that operate a significant chunk of Air France’s intra-European operations. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: Credit Suisse said to begin sale of US asset management arm
summary: Credit Suisse is considering the sale of its US asset management business, CSAM, as part of its efforts to simplify and pare down following scandals and losses. The Swiss bank has begun a sales process for the US operations, which is expected to draw interest from private equity firms and other asset managers. The move comes ahead of Credit Suisse's turnaround announcement to investors next week.

images.alt_text: The bank is less than two weeks away from revealing details of its latest restructuring, including the potential separation of the advisory and leveraged finance business.

site_title: As carmakers unveil new EVs, France ups subsidies for poorer buyers
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has announced increased subsidies for poorer households to buy electric vehicles (EVs), with subsidies rising to 7,000 euros next year. Macron also introduced a "social leasing" scheme to help low-income families access EVs for 100 euros per month. As part of the plan, French carmakers unveiled new EV models, including Renault's Renault 4 EV and Stellantis' Peugeot 308 sedan, which will be assembled in France. The goal is to boost local production and make EVs more affordable for French buyers.

site_title: Credit Suisse investment bank sees Abu Dhabi, Saudi interest
summary: Abu Dhabi and Saudi Arabia are exploring potential investments in Credit Suisse's investment bank and other businesses, taking advantage of depressed values. Sovereign wealth funds, including Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, are considering investments through various vehicles. The bank is set to reveal details of its restructuring, including a potential separation of its advisory and leveraged finance business, in two weeks. This could alleviate the cost of retaining talent in a business driven by key relationships.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen at a branch office in Bern, Switzerland September 26, 2022.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: China’s BYD expects quarterly profit to surge as EV sales hit record
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD Co expects its third-quarter profit to surge 365% as sales of electric and hybrid cars hit a record 537,164 units, a 197% increase from the same period last year. Net income is forecast to be between 5.5 billion and 5.9 billion yuan, a record. BYD's strong sales and ability to manufacture its own batteries and semiconductors are helping it avoid supply-chain disruptions that have affected rivals, including Tesla.

images.alt_text: BYD’s push into India also comes at a time when the South Asian country continues to maintain tight scrutiny of investments coming from bordering nations, including China.
BYD plans to invest about 30 billion baht (S$1.2 billion) in production of electric vehicles.
Nio (above) and XPeng tumbled over 6 per cent while sector bellwether BYD declined 3.7 per cent.
The EU is currently negotiating a proposed package of climate proposals, which includes an effective ban on the sale of new fossil-fuel vehicles from 2035.

site_title: Kevin Spacey wins dismissal of one of sex abuse accuser's claims
summary: A US judge dismissed one of the sex abuse claims against Kevin Spacey, brought by actor Anthony Rapp, who alleged Spacey made an unwanted sexual advance in 1986. The claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress was dismissed due to repetition of Rapp's allegations of battery. Rapp testified that an intoxicated Spacey, 26 at the time, climbed on top of him at a party in his Manhattan apartment when Rapp was 14.

site_title: Sinarmas Land and K2 Data Centres partner to develop data centres in Indonesia
summary: Sinarmas Land and K2 Data Centres have partnered to develop hyperscale data centres in Indonesia, with the first development, K2 JKT 1 Campus, set to exceed 5,000 servers and 10,000 square feet. The campus will have 58.8 megawatt of IT capacity and is expected to be ready by early 2024 with a LEED Gold certification. The joint venture also has another similar scale campus development in the pipeline, and both companies aim to support Indonesia's transformation into a digital powerhouse.

images.alt_text: Revenue rose on higher sales of commercial and industrial land parcels in BSD City and Kota Deltamas in Indonesia, as well as higher revenue recognised from residential and apartment units.
33 Horseferry Road, a freehold prime commercial building in London.
Living Lab Ventures will focus on 3 key verticals: technologies related to smart city living, digital life and mobility.

site_title: UK consumer industries warn curbing energy support will hit demand
summary: The UK's finance minister, Jeremy Hunt, has announced plans to reverse an income tax cut and end a two-year energy subsidy scheme, citing concerns over consumer demand and high energy prices. The move is expected to exacerbate worries about consumer demand, with confidence levels already at record lows. Industry leaders, including the British Beer and Pub Association, the Night Time Industries Association, and the British Retail Consortium, have criticized the decision, warning of potential economic damage and calling for urgent reform of business rates and tax policies.

images.alt_text: Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt notes that there will be more difficult decisions ahead on both tax and spending.

site_title: PA to have new chief executive director; new secretary-general for SCCCI
summary: The People's Association (PA) and the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) are set to undergo leadership changes in November. Jimmy Toh Yong Leng, current deputy chief of government communications, will become PA's chief executive director designate on Nov 1 and take over fully from Jan 1. Lim Hock Yu, who will step down from PA, will join SCCCI as secretary-general on Jan 1. SCCCI president Kho Choon Keng praises Lim's experience and operational capabilities, expecting him to play a pivotal role in the chamber's transformation.

site_title: Mastercard debuts service offering crypto-trading tied to bank accounts
summary: Mastercard has introduced Crypto Source, a service allowing consumers to buy and sell digital assets through their bank accounts. The service, set to launch in the US, Israel, and Brazil in early 2023, is a partnership with Paxos Trust Co. and aims to pave the way for thousands of finance firms to offer crypto trading. This move addresses regulatory concerns and consumer demand, potentially increasing mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Fintech can help banks go beyond offering mobile services to provide custom prompts and suggestions with the power of artificial intelligence.
Hackers have become adept at exploiting weaknesses in the security, coding and structure of DeFi marketplaces.
The heist began with two accounts funded with the stablecoin USD Coin. The accounts took large positions in Mango perpetual futures, causing the price of the Mango token to spike.

site_title: Bank of America profit drops on loan-loss reserve build
summary: Bank of America reported a 9% drop in third-quarter profit due to a US$378 million increase in loan-loss reserves, anticipating a weakening economy. The second-largest US bank is bracing for potential soured loans amid the US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy actions to combat inflation, which may lead to a recession.

site_title: Maturing startup ecosystem brings new business models to Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's startup ecosystem is maturing, with new business models emerging to tackle problems not covered by established players like Grab, Gojek, and Bukalapak. Octopus, a recycling-focused startup, has achieved a less than 1% rejection rate with recyclers and created over 20,000 jobs in the last two years. The company has secured a $5 million funding round and is expanding into the B2B segment. Another startup, Clockster, a human resource management platform for blue-collar workers, has secured $750,000 in Series A funding and is targeting the micro, small, and medium-sized enterprise market.

images.alt_text: Waste management platform Waste4change will utilise the new funding to increase its waste management capacity to 100 tonnes a day.
A slowdown in funding for Indonesian startups is giving founders a taste of a downturn, and potentially giving rise to companies that will make an impact
As macroeconomic headwinds and inflation impact Indonesia, the startups there are feeling the pinch even as long term prospects still appear bright.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as BofA gains on earnings beat
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by Bank of America's earnings beat and the Federal Reserve's rapid rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 424.8 points, or 1.43%, to 30,059.58, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, reaching 3,638.65 and 10,575.647 respectively. The strong opening comes amid uncertainty over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Pound bounces after new UK finance minister ditches most of ‘mini-budget’
summary: The pound surged 1.2% against the US dollar after UK finance minister Jeremy Hunt reversed most of the government's £45-billion mini-budget, alleviating market turmoil. The pound has regained almost 10% in value since hitting a record low. Hunt vowed to increase taxes and cut spending to rebuild stability and confidence. The Japanese yen hit a 32-year low, prompting concerns of central bank intervention.

site_title: Lyft hikes service fee for rides as insurance costs rise
summary: Lyft is increasing its service fee for US rides to cover higher insurance costs, averaging less than $0.50 per trip nationally. The increase, averaging around $0.60 per trip, is a 3% increase in the cost of an average ride and an 18% increase in the service fee. The change aims to offset inflation pressures on insurance costs. Lyft also previously introduced a fuel surcharge that went directly to drivers, now replaced by a cash back offer.

images.alt_text: Chief operating officer Alex Hungate, has spearheaded a push away from low-margin business lines as Grab races to turn profitable.
Uber has contacted law enforcement, froze all Slack communications while it investigates the hacker’s claims.

site_title: Hunt ditches entire Truss programme in bid to save UK credibility
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt scrapped nearly all of Prime Minister Liz Truss' economic programme, reversing £45 billion in tax cuts and energy support, amid a backlash against the plan that pushed up borrowing costs. The £32 billion package aims to restore order to the public finances, but economists say it falls short of addressing the UK's debt. The move is seen as a blow to Truss' authority, with Hunt signaling further difficult decisions ahead on tax and spending.

images.alt_text: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt said changes to planned tax cuts would raise £32 billion every year.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees deeper UK recession after tax U-turn
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its UK economic forecast, predicting a 1% contraction in 2023 due to a tax U-turn made by Prime Minister Liz Truss' government. The bank had earlier forecast a 0.4% drop. Core inflation is expected to be 3.1% at the end of 2023, down from 3.3%. Goldman analysts believe a more significant recession is likely, with tighter financial conditions and higher corporation tax. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates further, but at a slower pace than previously thought.

images.alt_text: Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt notes that there will be more difficult decisions ahead on both tax and spending.
British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends a news conference in London, Britain, Oct 14, 2022.
UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt said changes to planned tax cuts would raise £32 billion every year.
The Energy Markets Financing Scheme will help firms facing temporary short-term financing problems and allow commercial banks to provide larger credit lines to approved companies.

site_title: BP to buy US biogas producer Archaea for US$4.1b
summary: BP has agreed to acquire US biogas producer Archaea Energy Inc for approximately $4.1 billion, including debt, as part of the UK energy giant's expansion into lower-carbon fuels. The acquisition will accelerate BP's growth in bioenergy and increase the role of renewable natural gas in helping customers reach their climate goals. Archaea, formed in 2021, captures waste-gas emissions from landfills and farms and processes them into pipeline-quality natural gas, offering a lower climate impact than venting methane into the atmosphere.

images.alt_text: Oil had been rising this week in anticipation of the cuts, said Fiona Cincotta, senior financial markets analyst at City Index.
A vessel docks along the Shell Petroleum refineries on Pulau Bukom in Singapore; June 2022.
In the absence of collection, plastics are finding their way into our waterways and oceans and, increasingly, into the global food chain.

site_title: British police probe beating of protester on China consulate grounds
summary: British police are investigating an assault on a protester who was beaten by several men after being dragged into the grounds of the Chinese consulate in Manchester, Britain. The incident occurred during a demonstration against President Xi Jinping on the first day of the Chinese Communist Party's congress. The protester, in his 30s, suffered several injuries and remains in hospital. No arrests have been made, but the police are conducting a full investigation. The Chinese consulate has not commented on the incident.

images.alt_text: A digital billboard displaying a message celebrating the opening of the 20th National Congress of CPC in Shanghai, China.  In he meantime, the country’s vast financial bureaucracy has been busily tamping down ripples of turmoil across its currency and stock markets.

A robotic dog at the Digital Media Experience Space following a press conference at the Hotel Nikko New Century in Beijing on Monday (Oct 17). Reporters were briefed on how the Communist Party of China (CPC) will continue to exercise its strict self-governance over the party.

Pedestrian traffic along Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Oct 2.  Economists polled by Bloomberg had expected a rebound in China’s third-quarter GDP to 3.3 per cent after near-zero growth in the April-June period, when major cities including Shanghai were in lockdown.

site_title: Indonesia forms 15 trillion rupiah fund to improve clean water access
summary: Indonesia has formed a 15 trillion rupiah ($1.4 billion) fund to improve clean water access across the country, managed by state fund management firm Danareksa Persero. The funds, sourced from private investors, will be used to build water access facilities without increasing the burden on the state budget. Only 20% of Indonesians currently have access to clean water, with many relying on expensive jerrycan deliveries in the capital Jakarta. The new fund aims to address this issue and improve water access for the majority of the population.

site_title: Kanye West agrees to buy social network Parler
summary: Kanye West has agreed to buy social network Parler, which gained popularity among US conservatives. The deal's value was not disclosed, but it is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2022. Parler, launched in 2018, was shut down by Amazon Web Services over allegations of failing to stop incitement of violence before the 2021 US Capitol siege. The platform, which calls itself "the world's pioneering uncancellable free-speech platform," currently ranks 108th for news apps in the US iOS app store.

images.alt_text:
epa09664290 (19/24) (FILE) - Pro-Trump protesters occupy the grounds of the West Front of the US Capitol, including the inaugural stage and viewing stands, in Washington, DC, USA, 06 January 2021 (reissued 03 January 2021). Following the November 2020 US presidential election, a tone set by supporters of defeated US President Donald Trump escalated further. Trump, who was refusing to concede the victory of Joe Biden, claiming voter fraud and rigged elections, told supporters and white nationalist extreme-right group Proud Boys to respectively 'Stop the Steal' and to 'stand back and stand by'. His social media accounts were suspended and the alt-right platform Parler gained in user numbers.

On 06 January 2021, incumbent US vice president Pence was due to certify the Electoral College votes before Congress, the last step in the process before President-elect Biden was to be sworn in. In the morning, pro-Trump protesters had gathered for the so-called Save America March. Soon after Trump finished his speech at the Ellipse, the crowd marched to the Capitol. The attack had begun.

Rioters broke into the Capitol building where the joint Congress session was being held. Lawmakers barricaded themselves inside the chambers and donned tear gas masks while rioters vandalized the building, some even occupying offices such as House Speaker Pelosi's. Eventually in the evening the building was cleared from insurrectionists, and the Congress chambers reconvened their session, confirming Joe Biden as the winner of the 2020 US presidential election.

In the aftermath, more than 600 people were charged with federal crimes in connection to the insurgency, and close Trump aides such as Steve Bannon, Mark Meadows and Roger Stone were subpoenaed by the House select committee investigating the attack. Trump himself was acquitted by the Senate in his second impeachment trial, this time for "inciting an insurrection".  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS  ATTENTION: This Image is part of a PHOTO SET

site_title: Only a new policy regime can stop rampant inflation, but don’t count on it yet
summary: Central banks' expansionary monetary and fiscal policies have fueled inflation, shattering the assumption that they can coexist with low inflation. A long-term, pro-inflationary trend in monetary and fiscal policy has contributed to shaping long-term inflation expectations, making it unlikely for inflation to return to low levels without a serious policy contraction. The "Great Paradox of Monetary Tranquillity" requires a new policy regime to stop rampant inflation, but this is unlikely due to the unsustainable legacy of the past regime and the need for new public goods and priorities.

images.alt_text: coins, calculator, budget

site_title: New UK Finance Minister Hunt reverses tax plan, reins in energy support
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt reverses nearly all of Prime Minister Liz Truss's mini-budget, including tax cuts and a two-year energy subsidy scheme, to stabilize the economy and regain investor confidence. The changes are expected to raise £32 billion annually. The plan now includes a more targeted energy subsidy scheme that will cost significantly less than planned, and government spending cuts to narrow a £72 billion hole in public finances. The moves aim to halt a bond market rout and prevent borrowing costs from rising further.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.80 points to close at 1,386.27 on Monday, October 17. The market saw 1.976 billion lots traded worth RM1.489 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 443 to 363.

site_title: Thai central bank flags inflation risk from further baht decline
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, warns of the risk of inflation quickening further if the baht continues to weaken, reaching a 16-year low. The baht has lost 7% in the second half and is South-east Asia's worst-performing currency. The central bank has raised its policy rate by 50 basis points and will stick to its gradual tightening approach, citing robust foreign currency reserves and a drop in stockpiles due to asset revaluation. Assistant governor Piti Disyatat emphasized that the bank will not aim to slow economic growth to curb inflation.

site_title: Buying term insurance is not so that you can ‘invest the rest’
summary: Christopher Tan, CEO of Providend, argues that term insurance is the most affordable and suitable way to adequately and immediately insure oneself, contrary to the common objections that it lacks a cash value component. He addresses five objections: wasting money, not saving for retirement, policy lapse, lack of investment knowledge, and not mitigating inflation. Tan concludes that term insurance is not meant for long-term savings, but rather for immediate protection, and that the benefits of term plans outweigh the drawbacks, especially when compared to the high costs and limited returns of whole life plans.

images.alt_text: Most insurance needs are temporary except for medical expenses and hospitalisation.

site_title: Better jobs, higher pay, a visionary government: What Malaysia’s young, first-time voters want to see
summary: Malaysia's first-time voters, aged 18-20, are expected to make a significant impact in the upcoming general election, with around 1.2 million of them casting their ballots. Young voters are looking for better job opportunities, higher wages, and a visionary government, with 70% of candidates in the recent state elections being under 45 years old. Political parties have adjusted their strategies to appeal to younger voters, and organizations like Undi18 are mobilizing young voters to participate in the election. The turnout is expected to be high, with 54% of 18-21-year-olds voting in the recent Johor state election, and Undi18 aims to achieve a 70% turnout.

images.alt_text: Malaysian ringgit has hit another new low of close to RM4.70 against the greenback, and RM3.30 against Singdollar on Friday (Oct 14) morning.
Malaysians celebrating National Day in August. About 21.1 million Malaysians are eligible to vote in the upcoming election, with some 5 million voting for the first time

site_title: As Xi opens congress, China's state hands keep markets steady
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping opened the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party, and the country's vast financial bureaucracy has been taming down market turmoil. State banks are intervening to defend the weakening yuan, while state-run asset managers have pledged confidence in China's capital markets. The Shanghai Composite Index has staged a robust recovery, with shares now 50% more expensive than their Hong Kong-traded peers. The yuan has also held steady, trading within a narrow band between 7.10 and 7.20 per dollar, as analysts attribute recent stability to the central bank's unchanged daily fixings.

images.alt_text: A robotic dog at the Digital Media Experience Space following a press conference at the Hotel Nikko New Century in Beijing on Monday (Oct 17). Reporters were briefed on how the Communist Party of China (CPC) will continue to exercise its strict self-governance over the party.

Pedestrian traffic along Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Oct 2.  Economists polled by Bloomberg had expected a rebound in China’s third-quarter GDP to 3.3 per cent after near-zero growth in the April-June period, when major cities including Shanghai were in lockdown.
China's President Xi Jinping arrives for the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore developers sold 987 non-executive condominium units in September, exceeding the 913 units launched in August. Inflation expectations rose to 11-year high of 4.6% in September, up from 3.9% in June. Key exports growth eased to 3.1% in September due to a contraction in electronics shipments. Sembcorp obtained an investment licence to develop an industrial park in Vietnam. Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Monday amid mixed regional trading.

site_title: Liz Truss under threat: How UK Tories get rid of their leaders
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss's premiership is in jeopardy after she was forced to abandon her economic agenda and ditch her chancellor amid a market rout. The opposition Labour party has opened a record lead in opinion polls, and Truss's approval ratings are at an all-time low. Despite party rules protecting her from a leadership challenge for 12 months, Tory MPs are openly moving against her, potentially triggering a confidence vote or a leadership contest. The 1922 Committee, a key group of Conservative MPs, may consider changing the rules to allow for a vote, paving the way for Truss's potential ouster.

images.alt_text: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt said changes to planned tax cuts would raise £32 billion every year.
British Prime Minister Liz Truss at a news conference in London, Britain, October 14, 2022.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Monday amid mixed regional trading, STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Monday, led by losses from Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC, amid concerns over persistent inflation. Regional indices were mixed, with Asian stocks declining due to disappointment over Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech and rising inflation concerns. Analysts expect macro headwinds to persist, with elevated volatility and a potential destabilization of the 10-year bond market.

images.alt_text: Singapore has enjoyed a strong post-pandemic rebound, despite repeated rounds of monetary tightening
The Straits Times Index slipped 0.5 per cent or 14.49 points to 3,025.12 as at 9.02am. Losers surpassed gainers 70 to 41, after 30.4 million securities worth S$46.4 million changed hands.

site_title: Philippine government to sell sugar at fixed price to curb inflation
summary: The Philippine government plans to sell refined sugar at a fixed price of 70 pesos per kilogram to curb inflation and ensure a stable supply. The measure, effective until most sugar mills start operating, aims to reduce prices by 40% after they jumped to over 100 pesos per kilogram. The country is importing 150,000 tonnes of sugar this year, with 75,000 tonnes allocated to industrial users. The government's market intervention is a rare move, usually undertaken by the private sector, to address the country's four-year high inflation rate driven by skyrocketing food prices.

site_title: Singapore exports set to slow further in Q4, may even contract: economists
summary: Singapore's exports are expected to slow further in Q4, potentially contracting due to a prolonged electronics downturn and global economic slowdown. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 3.1% year-on-year in September, easing from an 11.4% expansion in the previous month. Electronics exports decelerated for a second straight month, with a 10.6% contraction in September. Economists expect NODX to decelerate further in Q4, with some predicting a contraction, and have downgraded their 2023 forecast to -4 to -1%.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in September grew 3.1 per cent year on year, down from the 11.4 per cent expansion in the previous month, data from Enterprise Singapore showed.

Global markets are still grappling with high inflation, qualitative tightening and the geopolitical uncertainties of Russia's war in Ukraine, said SPIMM's industry engagement and development vice-president Sophia Poh.
Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 11.4 per cent year on year in August, faster than the previous month’s 7 per cent expansion, on the back of an increase in non-electronics shipments.

site_title: Some ECB officials see legal basis to toughen banks’ long-term lending rules
summary: European Central Bank officials consider changing their long-term lending rules for banks due to rising inflation and interest rates. The existing contracts, agreed on during sluggish price growth, are no longer feasible. Officials weigh options such as treating TLTRO funds as minimum reserve requirements or introducing staggered interest rates. ECB President Christine Lagarde has promised a TLTRO review, with the next meeting on Oct 26-27, but no changes are imminent. The move aims to address the issue of banks earning risk-free returns while fueling inflation, which is five times the ECB's target.

images.alt_text: Record inflation and the danger of winter energy shortages are sinking confidence in the euro-zone economy.

site_title: Tailwinds continue to push SIA’s operating results for September
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 2.5% increase in passenger capacity in September, driven by tailwinds in the travel recovery. The airline carried 2.1 million passengers, a 111.8% jump from the previous year, with a group passenger load factor of 87% for the month. SIA reinstated services to East Asia, including Beijing, and Scoot resumed flights to Fuzhou and Osaka. Demand remains strong across most routes, with the exception of East Asia due to ongoing travel restrictions.

site_title: Credit Suisse pays US$495m to settle legacy US case
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to pay US$495 million to settle a case related to mortgage-linked investments in the US, resolving a legacy issue linked to the 2008 financial crisis. The bank has been paying out billions of dollars to resolve similar cases, including a US$5.3 billion deal with the Department of Justice in 2017. The settlement marks another step in Credit Suisse's efforts to resolve litigation and legacy issues, with five remaining cases expected to be resolved in the next six months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Switzerland's national flag flies above the logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse at its headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland April 18, 2021. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Prime Orchard area retail rents on the rise, outpacing other areas despite headwinds
summary: Retail rents in Singapore's prime Orchard area experienced the strongest quarter-on-quarter growth, rising 2.9% to S$38.40 per square foot. This growth outpaced other areas, with average monthly rents increasing 1.1% in city areas and 2.2% in fringe/suburban areas. Analysts attribute the growth to increased tourist footfall and easing travel restrictions, with new retail space expected to be completed from 2022 to 2025. Despite challenges such as economic headwinds and competition from e-commerce, retail rents are expected to continue on an uptrend in the coming months.

images.alt_text: VivoCity Mall, a key retail mall in Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s portfolio, saw shopper traffic  grow 50.9 per cent  yoy and tenant sales increase 53.3 per cent yoy in Q1 FY2022/2023.

site_title: UK opens £40b emergency programme for strained energy firms
summary: The UK has launched the £40 billion Energy Markets Financing Scheme to support energy traders facing temporary short-term financing problems due to volatile European energy-market prices. The scheme allows commercial banks to provide larger credit lines to approved companies and the Treasury will pay out in the event of non-payment. The Bank of England will act as an agent for the scheme, aiming to smooth liquidity conditions and prevent a worsening crisis.

site_title: Investors in Asian stocks need patience – until China economy and equities improve
summary: Asian markets face headwinds due to weaker economies, higher US interest rates, and a strong dollar. Despite this, the Chinese equity market is over-sold and priced for a negative economic environment, offering potential for higher returns in the medium term. Asian equities, particularly North Asia, continue to underperform, with the main constraint being the Chinese market. India remains a key structural overweight, while Japanese equities offer good value with robust earnings. Asean equities are well-placed to benefit from reopening and positive commodity prices, with Indonesia being a key overweight.

images.alt_text: The Shanghai Composite Index lost more than 5 per cent over the past month, its worst pre-Congress showing since the gauge’s inception in 1991.

site_title: Umno looks set to stay on top of the political heap
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob's decision to dissolve parliament and hold the country's 15th general election in mid-November has been met with little surprise, as Umno, the dominant partner in the current coalition government, is confident of its chances. The coalition's splintering and the public's anger over the 1MDB scandal are expected to hurt the opposition. Umno's own issues, including the ongoing trial of its president and the missing naval vessels, may not be enough to sway voters. The next government will need to address the country's shrinking revenue base and huge federal debt burden.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on front foot
summary: Hong Kong shares closed on a positive note, reversing early losses, ahead of the corporate earnings season. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.15% to 16,612.90, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: China showed ‘significant’ Q3 rebound, but faces challenges, says state planner
summary: China's economy showed a significant rebound in the third quarter, with consumer prices rising modestly and employment remaining stable despite challenges from stringent Covid curbs and a deepening property slump. Policymakers have rolled out over 50 economic support measures, including infrastructure projects and tax cuts. However, the economy still faces multiple headwinds, including weak consumer and business confidence, and youth unemployment remains high. China's growth is expected to be around 3.4% for the third quarter, which could be one of the weakest in nearly half a century.

images.alt_text: China’s gross domestic product (GDP) likely grew 3.4 per cent in July-September from a year earlier, quickening from the 0.4 per cent pace in the second quarter, according to the median forecast of 40 economists polled by Reuters.
Transformational and structural trends present an attractive set of opportunities especially in Asia, says Benjamin Hung, CEO, Asia, Standard Chartered.

The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 500 billion yuan (S$99.2 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.75 per cent
The Shanghai Composite Index lost more than 5 per cent over the past month, its worst pre-Congress showing since the gauge’s inception in 1991.

site_title: ‘Halloween Ends’ starts strong, topping North America box office
summary: "Halloween Ends" topped the North American box office with an estimated US$41.3 million, beating industry predictions. The film, starring Jamie Lee Curtis, was released simultaneously on Peacock and had a production cost of US$30 million, considered "excellent" given its budget. The movie's success comes after a strong start for horror films in the weeks leading up to Halloween.

site_title: K-pop stars BTS to serve military duty
summary: K-pop boy band BTS will serve mandatory military duty, starting with oldest member Jin, 29, who will enlist in late October 2022. All seven members will follow their respective plans, with the commitment expected to last nearly two years. The move is in line with South Korea's law requiring able-bodied men to serve in the military between 18 and 21 months. BTS had announced a break from group activities in June, but plans to reunite in 2025 after their service commitment.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on recession fears
summary: Australian shares ended 1.4% lower at 6,664.4 points, as recession fears and high inflationary pressures weighed on investor confidence. Commodity companies led the decline, following a drop on Wall Street due to worsening inflation expectations and concerns about a potential global recession. The benchmark had risen 1.8% on Friday.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 1.6 per cent to 6,651.4, as of 0018 GMT on Monday.

site_title: China halts LNG sales to foreign buyers to ensure own supply
summary: China has instructed its state-owned gas importers to stop reselling LNG to European and Asian buyers to secure its own supply for the winter heating season. This move could drain shipments to Europe and exacerbate the region's energy crunch in case of a cold winter. The decision was made by the National Development and Reform Commission, citing forecasts of a small gas supply deficit and Beijing's pledge to keep houses warmed this winter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are seen in silhouetted near a liquified natural gas (LNG) storage tank at PetroChina's receiving terminal at Rudong port in Nantong, Jiangsu province, China September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: Germany faces US$85b hit as labour shortages deepen
summary: Germany is facing a significant labor shortage, estimated to cost the economy $85 billion annually, as manufacturers struggle to find qualified workers amid an aging population and pandemic-induced shortages. The shortage is exacerbating the country's energy crisis, with workers in high demand and inflation jumping to 10.9%. German public sector staff are seeking pay increases, while firms are getting creative with benefits and training programs to attract workers. The shortage is expected to worsen, with the European Commission estimating a shortfall of 500,000 workers by the end of the decade, and the government is seeking changes to immigration law to attract more workers.

images.alt_text: Some 45 per cent of German manufacturers complained about a lack of workers.

The outlook for Germany’s economy has darkened in recent weeks as the country’s important manufacturing sector suffers from input shortages and record prices pressures resulting from the war in Ukraine.
Germany needs greater immigration to avoid labour shortages

site_title: Thailand’s Jan-Sep investment value down, but applications rise
summary: Thailand's investment applications for the January-September period decreased 14% to 439 billion baht, but the number of applications rose 8.5% to 275.6 billion baht. Foreign direct investment applications from China, Taiwan, Japan, the US, and Hong Kong were the main sources, with EV manufacturing projects being a key focus. Despite the decrease in overall value, major EV investments were announced in Thailand this year, including plants by BYD and Foxconn.

site_title: The Great Decoupling – ‘Chimerica’ no more
summary: The US has taken a significant step towards a geoeconomic decoupling with China, imposing major controls on exports of advanced semiconductors, chip-making equipment, and supercomputer components to China. This move, announced on October 7, 2022, marks a shift away from globalization and towards a zero-sum game, where the US seeks to outcompete China and limit its access to advanced technologies. The controls are part of a broader strategy to restrict China's growth and development, and may lead to a costly Cold War between the two nations, potentially slowing global economic growth.

images.alt_text: The White House emphasised risks from China, warning that its rapid advances in technology aimed to mold the world order in support of “its own authoritarian model.”

American companies aren’t the world’s leading manufacturers of the chips Washington is seeking to deny to China; firms in other markets such as Japan and especially Taiwan are. But US firms and technology are deeply involved in designing high-end semiconductors, which gives Washington influence over the entire supply chain.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after US falls
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on October 17, 2022, after US stocks fell, despite solid bank earnings. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.16%, and the Topix index lost 0.98%. Investors remained cautious over bond yields and recession risks.

site_title: Xi's call to win tech race points to new wave of Chinese state-led spending
summary: President Xi Jinping's call for China to "win the battle" in core technologies could signal an overhaul in Beijing's approach to advancing its tech industry, with increased state-led spending and intervention to counter US pressures. The Communist Party's emphasis on self-reliance in technology, with 40 mentions in the full work report, suggests a shift in strategy. The move comes days after the US imposed new regulations aimed at undermining China's efforts to develop its own chip industry, prompting analysts to warn of a new wave of Chinese state-led spending.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping arrives for the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)
Chinese President Xi Jinping speaks during the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Oct 16, 2022.
The Shanghai Composite Index lost more than 5 per cent over the past month, its worst pre-Congress showing since the gauge’s inception in 1991.

site_title: Sembcorp obtains investment licence to develop industrial park in Vietnam
summary: Sembcorp Industries has obtained an investment licence to develop a 293.7-hectare industrial park in Can Tho City, Vietnam. The project is part of the Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park (VSIP) Group's portfolio, which includes 11 large-scale developments across eight provinces. The development is expected to have no material impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset value. This project follows Vietnam's central government's announcement of a new master plan to establish Can Tho as a centre for trade and services by 2023, along with infrastructure investments.

site_title: OCBC Bank unveils first community urban farm in CBD
summary: OCBC Bank has unveiled its first community urban farm in the Central Business District (CBD), covering a quarter of the OCBC Centre car park roof. The farm, using a hydroponic system, aims to produce 140 kg of vegetables annually to support Singapore's "30 by 30" goal of strengthening food resilience. The initiative reduces water consumption and carbon emissions, with solar energy powering the hydroponic system. The farm's produce will be donated to a charity soup kitchen, providing approximately 3,000 meals, and is seen as a step towards achieving Singapore's goal.

images.alt_text: Volunteer from the Agape-Barclays partnership sharing resume editing and interview tips with a beneficiary.

site_title: EU needs to up electric vehicle support to fend off Chinese competition: NGO
summary: The EU needs to increase support for electric vehicle (EV) production to prevent losing market share to Chinese rivals, according to a study by Transport & Environment. EU EV sales growth has slowed, with fully-electric cars making up 11% of sales in the first half of 2022, compared to expected 13%. Chinese carmakers like BYD and Great Wall Motor are gaining a foothold in the EU market, with an estimated 18% share of the market by 2025. The EU should maintain its ban on new fossil-fuel vehicles by 2035 and use EU funds to accelerate EV production.

images.alt_text: EU car makers are affected by the US legislation, which covers a host of other products.
In August, the eurozone increased its exports of goods by 24 per cent compared to the previous year, totalling 231.1 billion euros, roughly in line with the volume of exports in July.

site_title: Thai central bank says gradual rate hikes appropriate for now
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) stated that Thailand's economy will recover this year and in 2023 with gradual interest rate hikes remaining appropriate, despite inflationary pressures. Economic growth is projected at 3.3% this year and 3.8% next year. The central bank aims to balance risks and ensure an economic recovery without adding to inflation. Inflation is expected to gradually fall from the fourth quarter of this year, with a rebound in the tourism sector being key to the recovery. The BOT will review policy on November 30, potentially leading to further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s key interest rate is just 1.00 per cent.
Supply chains problems in the automobile and electronics sectors, are affecting exports, Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith told a business seminar.

site_title: Liberty House at 51 Club Street put up for sale at S$120m
summary: Liberty House, a five-storey commercial building at 51 Club Street, has been put up for sale via expression of interest at S$120 million, equivalent to around S$4,155 per square foot. The building, which has a 999-year tenure, was extensively refurbished in 2011 and features office specifications, a passenger lift, and a private parking facility. The sale price reflects the building's prime location and modern amenities.

site_title: Blibli owner seeks 8.17t rupiah in Indonesia’s second-largest IPO of 2022
summary: Digital Niaga, owner of e-commerce group Blibli, is set to raise up to 8.17 trillion rupiah (S$752.5 million) through an IPO, Indonesia's second-largest this year. The firm is offering up to 17.77 billion new shares at a price between 410-460 rupiah apiece, valuing the group at up to US$3.5 billion. Proceeds will be used to repay debt and for working capital, with a 12-month voluntary lock-up period for the company and an eight-month mandatory lock-up for existing shareholders.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in funding for Indonesian startups is giving founders a taste of a downturn, and potentially giving rise to companies that will make an impact
Indonesia's largest IPO turns into a flop as Bukalapak falls

site_title: From mediocre to medal-winning: Japan's koshu wine
summary: Japan's koshu wine has gained international recognition, surpassing expectations despite the country's challenging climate. Produced in the Yamanashi prefecture, koshu is a light, dry white wine that complements Japanese cuisine. With its history dating back to the 1870s, koshu has fine-tuned its craft to adapt to the region's abundant rain and humidity. The wine has received acclaimed international awards, solidifying its place as Japan's most iconic wine.

images.alt_text: A non-alcohol "beer garden" in Tokyo, Japan, Aug 26, 2022. Facing a steady decline in revenue from alcohol sales, Japan’s tax office in July launched a contest seeking ideas on how to stimulate demand among younger people.
A tasting of bottles from the war years, produced under often brutal circumstances, brings life to history.

A variety of Beaujolais in New York, Sept. 12, 2022. A number of terrific wines from the region are available now and range from the simple thirst-quenchers of old to the surprisingly complex. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)
The hot, dry summer has led to an early start to grape picking across France, with the harvest getting under way in late August in Champagne.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise, with focus on UK budget drama
summary: European stocks rose on Monday, October 17, 2022, after the UK government announced it will unveil some taxation and spending plans two weeks earlier than scheduled to ease market turmoil. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.2% to 6,871.29 points, while the British pound advanced against the US dollar and 30-year UK bond yields fell. The eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices remained flat. The news boosted market sentiment and led to a slight increase in UK bond yields.

images.alt_text: A Lime electric hire bicycle outside the London Stock Exchange Group Plc's offices in London, UK, on Friday, Aug. 12, 2022. London Stock Exchange Plc Chief Executive Officer Julia Hoggett said the IPO pipeline in London remains robust, despite a slowdown this year that’s been felt at many exchanges globally. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia books nearly US$5b September trade surplus, above forecast
summary: Indonesia reported a US$4.99 billion trade surplus in September, exceeding forecasts, driven by high commodity prices globally. The country's export boom has continued, with exports growing 20.28% year-over-year to US$24.80 billion, but at a slower pace than expected. Imports increased 22.02% to US$19.81 billion. The surplus was partly cushioned by a decrease in palm oil shipments, while coal exports remained high. The results are a testament to Indonesia's resilience in the face of moderating commodity prices.

images.alt_text: During the Federal Reserve’s previous tightening cycle in 2018, the rupiah fell to multi-decade lows. During the 2013 “taper tantrum”, it plunged 20 per cent.

site_title: Despite travel recovering, listed hospitality plays are unloved and may be privatised
summary: Singapore's hospitality sector is recovering, with events like the Singapore Grand Prix and relaxation of dining-in restrictions boosting hotel occupancy and room rates. However, listed hospitality plays, such as Frasers Hospitality Trust and Mandarin Oriental International, are trading at discounts to their adjusted net asset values, indicating unloved assets. The sector's prospects are also hindered by risk aversion among investors and rising interest rates. Privatisation of listed hospitality plays may be a viable option, as seen with the successful delisting of GL Limited and Fragrance Group in 2021, and could attract greater interest from institutional investors if existing trusts bulk up and improve their free float.

images.alt_text: Visitor arrivals in September hit 752,305, from 728,744 in August, recording eight straight months of growth, according to data from the Singapore Tourism Board (STB).
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore is one of the 12 properties in FHT's initial IPO portfolio.
