site_title: Six category winners named for EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2022 awards
summary: EY has named six recipients of the 21st EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2022 Singapore awards, representing Singapore at the annual EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year (WEOY) in 2023. The winners are Lim Wai Mun (healthcare services), Akshay Garg (financial technology), Julian Ng (advanced manufacturing), Kane Black (biotechnology), Jonathan Lim (food and beverage solutions), and Melissa Tan (environmental solutions), chosen from 140 nominations based on entrepreneurial spirit, growth, purpose, and impact.

images.alt_text: Nominations open for EY Entrepreneur of the Year awards

site_title: Apple freezes plans to use China’s YMTC chips: Nikkei
summary: US tech giant Apple has put on hold plans to use memory chips from China's Yangtze Memory Technologies (YMTC) in its products due to tightened export controls against Chinese technology companies. Initially planned to start using YMTC's Nand flash memory chips for iPhones sold in the Chinese market, Apple now considers purchasing up to 40% of the chips needed for all iPhones from YMTC. The US added YMTC and 30 other Chinese entities to a list of companies that US officials have been unable to inspect, escalating tensions with Beijing.

images.alt_text: The partnership could encourage users to store the cash they get back with Goldman rather than Green Dot Bank, Apple’s existing partner for its legacy credit card.
Google’s new smartphones are available in 17 markets, including France, Germany, some of the Nordics and the UK in Europe alongside Japan, India, Singapore and Taiwan in Asia.

“We are working with our carrier partners in India to bring the best 5G experience to iPhone users as soon as network validation and testing for quality and performance is completed,” Apple said in a statement.

site_title: PM Lee’s visit set to yield landmark Green Economy deal with Australia
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is set to sign a landmark Green Economy deal with Australia, as part of his 7th Leaders' Meeting with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese. The agreement, which began negotiations in 2021, aims to promote trade in environmental goods and services, technology development, and cooperative projects in the green economy. The deal is expected to strengthen economic and trade ties between the two countries, with total bilateral trade reaching S$27.2 billion in 2021.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's Labor government came into power in May.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher, focus on Britain's fiscal plan
summary: South Korean shares ended higher, reversing early losses, after investors awaited developments on Britain's tax cuts, which had caused global market turmoil. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.32% to 2,219.71, with foreigners buying shares worth 264 billion won. The won closed 0.47% lower, while bond yields were unchanged. The British finance minister will announce tax and spending measures earlier than expected, sparking hopes for a reversal of the government's fiscal plans.

images.alt_text: epa08918179 A South Korean dealer works in front of monitors at the Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 04 January 2021. The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 70.98 points, or 2.47 percent, to close at 2,944.45.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Comprehensive air transport pact inked between Asean and European Union
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and the European Union (EU) signed a Comprehensive Air Transport Agreement (AE CATA) on October 17, 2022, allowing airlines from both blocs to operate up to 14 weekly passenger services and any number of cargo services between their member states. The agreement, the world's first bloc-to-bloc air transport agreement, aims to enhance cooperation in aviation safety, air traffic management, consumer protection, and environmental and social issues. The pact is expected to provide direct access to new destinations, more flights, and a greater network of flights between the two regions.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister S Iswaran delivering his speech at the signing of the Comprehensive Air Transport Agreement .

site_title: Fosun halts trading pending ‘inside information’ release
summary: Fosun International, a Chinese conglomerate, has halted trading of its shares pending the release of "inside information" related to a stake sale of its 60% holding in Nanjing Iron & Steel United. The stake is set to be sold to Jiangsu Shagang Group for 15 billion yuan (S$3 billion) to meet debt repayment needs. The move comes after Moody's Investors Services downgraded Fosun's flagship operation to junk territory due to refinancing pressure. Fosun's dollar bonds have been volatile, and its shares have plunged 35% amid liquidity concerns.

images.alt_text: Fosun said in a statement media reports saying Chinese regulators have told the country’s biggest banks to start a round of checks on their financial exposure to the company were “sheer nonsense”.
Fosun said in a statement media reports saying Chinese regulators have told the country’s biggest banks to start a round of checks on their financial exposure to the company were “sheer nonsense”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, AEM, UG Healthcare, Pan-United, Japfa
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has announced that it will commence charters for four rig assets in Saudi Arabia in October, yielding total charter revenue of about S$250 million over three to five years. AEM Holdings has raised its revenue guidance for the full year to between S$820 million and S$850 million, up from its previous FY2022 guidance.

images.alt_text: Delivery of the remaining two of five rigs will be deferred to 2025.
Across the broader market, decliners outnumbered gainers 255 to 251 after 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion were traded on Oct 14.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street losses but sterling bounces
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, tracking a selloff on Wall Street amid concerns over rising interest rates and inflation. Hong Kong and Shanghai fell over 1%, while Tokyo and Sydney also lost ground. The pound rose after British Prime Minister Liz Truss replaced her finance minister, sparking speculation she may roll back tax-cutting measures. The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes and inflation fears fueled recession concerns, with last week's strong inflation reading stoking bets on further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong and Taipei were up by more than 3 per cent apiece, while Seoul advanced more than 2 per cent on Friday.

site_title: Tokio Marine leads Series B round of insurtech startup bolttech with US$50m investment
summary: Japanese insurance company Tokio Marine has invested $50 million in Series B funding for insurtech startup bolttech, valuing the company at $1.5 billion. This marks the largest Series B funding round for an insurtech. Bolttech, Singapore's only home-grown insurtech unicorn, uses its technology-enabled insurance exchange to connect insurers with distributors and customers, and quotes $50 billion worth of annualised premiums. The investment aims to enhance distribution strength, product innovation, and balance-sheet capacity.

images.alt_text: A record year for Singapore fintech
Using smart technology to facilitate the insurance purchase process can help reduce current protection gaps in Singapore.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Grand Venture Technology on possible delayed recovery
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded its rating on Grand Venture Technology from "add" to "reduce" due to delayed net profit recovery until 2024. The research house reduced its target price from S$0.85 to S$0.40, citing slower economic growth and longer time needed to onboard new customers. Revenue forecasts for FY2022 to FY2024 were reduced by 4.2% and EPS forecasts by 8.1%. The analysts expect no EPS growth for FY2023, citing an expanded cost base and revenue shortfall.

images.alt_text: Grand Venture 'well-poised' to gain across segments: DBS
Grand Venture Technology posted a first-quarter net profit after tax of S$3.6 million, up 8.9 per cent from S$3.3 million a year ago.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to combine investment banking and trading businesses: WSJ
summary: Goldman Sachs is reorganizing its businesses by combining its investment banking and trading units into one division, while merging asset and wealth management into another. The move aims to cut reliance on volatile trading and investment banking revenues by boosting fee-based businesses. CEO David Solomon's plan to build a mass-market digital bank via consumer banking unit Marcus will be put on hold. The changes are expected to be announced on October 18 with Goldman's third-quarter earnings.

images.alt_text: Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan, says: “In the US, consumers continue to spend with solid balance sheets, job openings are plentiful and businesses remain healthy.”
The partnership could encourage users to store the cash they get back with Goldman rather than Green Dot Bank, Apple’s existing partner for its legacy credit card.

Goldman’s 2023 annual growth projection for the UK has dipped from minus 0.4 per cent to minus 1 per cent. Now, core inflation is seen at 3.1 per cent at the end of 2023, versus 3.3 per cent previously.

site_title: September new home sales hit 987 units, more than double August’s 438 units
summary: Singapore's new home sales in September more than doubled to 987 units, excluding executive condominiums, from August's 438 units, a 125.3% increase. The sales were driven by two major launches, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok, with median prices above S$2,100 per square foot. Despite rising interest rates and economic uncertainties, demand for suburban housing remains strong, with more than two-thirds of sales in the suburbs or outside the central region. Experts expect the market to slow down, with private residential price growth expected to soften to 9% in 2022.

images.alt_text: With the increase in the RCR’s psf price since Jun, the median price paid for a new non-landed home there has exceeded that in the CCR., says Huttons.
The Lentor Modern condominium is one of many new launches this year that commanded psf prices of above S$2,100.

site_title: Economists see Bank of Korea ending rate hikes in first quarter
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea is expected to end its rate hike cycle in the first quarter of 2023, with economists predicting a 25 basis point increase in the seven-day repurchase rate to 3.25% at its November meeting. The terminal interest rate is expected to reach 3.5% by the end of 2023, according to a Bloomberg survey. Economists also downgraded their GDP growth forecast for 2023 to 1.9% and inflation outlook to 5.5% for the current quarter, with annual forecasts revised to 1.3% and 3.1% respectively.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea raised its benchmark policy rate by 50 basis points to 3.00 per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: Broadcom banking on early EU approval of US$61b VMware deal: sources
summary: Broadcom is seeking early European Union (EU) antitrust approval of its proposed $61 billion acquisition of cloud computing company VMware. The deal, announced in May, aims to diversify Broadcom's business into enterprise software. The company is pointing to competition from Amazon, Microsoft, and Google to argue that the deal won't lead to a loss of competition in the cloud market. EU regulators are conducting a preliminary review, and Broadcom hopes to avoid a four-month second-phase investigation. The company believes that VMware's growth has been driven by competitive pressure from other major cloud services providers.

images.alt_text: Raghuram believes VMware’s revenues will improve in predictability as the company transitions its business model.
Broadcom forecasts current-quarter revenue of about US$8.9 billion.

site_title: The real-world impact of cyberattacks
summary: Cyberattacks on operational technology (OT) are becoming increasingly severe, with Gartner forecasting that attacks on OT will evolve to more severe attacks by 2025. The IT-OT convergence has opened the door to new security risks, with ransomware attacks on OT systems, such as the 2021 attack on Colonial Pipeline, demonstrating the real-world impact. To mitigate these risks, countries like Singapore are embedding OT security into their cybersecurity masterplans and strengthening their OT cybersecurity workforce. Holistic cybersecurity strategies, including network segmentation and automation, are needed to secure OT networks and ensure the benefits of interconnectivity.

images.alt_text: Tata Power said it has taken steps to retrieve and restore the systems, adding that all critical operational systems are functioning.

site_title: Oil futures rise on hopes of recovery in China’s fuel demand
summary: Oil futures rose 0.7% to $92.29 a barrel after China rolled over liquidity measures to support its pandemic-hit economy, sparking hopes for improved fuel demand. China's central bank kept interest rates unchanged and vowed to increase domestic energy supply capacity. Brent crude futures recovered from a 6.4% fall last week, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.6%. Analysts see the move as a signal of continued loose monetary policy and a positive outlook for demand. However, oil prices remain volatile due to production cuts by Opec+ and a strong US dollar.

images.alt_text: Oil workers pass a pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, left, at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Carbon capture projects hit record, but would mitigate less than 1% of emissions
summary: Carbon capture projects have reached record levels, with 153 new projects in development and 61 more than last year, but would only mitigate less than 1% of annual emissions. The US leads the way with 34 new proposed projects, while existing and proposed projects would store just 244 million tons of CO2 annually. Despite criticism, the Global CCS Institute sees CCS as crucial for meeting the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target, with around 1.3 billion tons of storage capacity needed by 2030.

images.alt_text: The firm is based in the eastern city of Nanjing where Sinopec has the strongest reserve of carbon industry know-how.
The airline industry, responsible for nearly 3% of global carbon dioxide emissions, faces significant challenges in meeting ambitious goals to cut emissions.

site_title: Gold recovers on technical buying, softer US dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% on Monday to $1,650.49 per ounce, supported by technical trading after a steep fall the previous session. A pause in the dollar rally and limited pressure from the US Federal Reserve's impending rate hike eased some pressure on gold. Despite this, gold remains sensitive to rising US rates, which increases the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US rates, which boost bond yields, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: China’s central bank rolls over policy loans for liquidity, keeps rate unchanged
summary: China's central bank kept interest rates unchanged for a second month, rolling over policy loans worth $99.2 billion to maintain liquidity. The move followed market expectations and was seen as a sign that strong lending data has reduced the need for an interest rate cut. Analysts expect further monetary easing, but with caution due to the risk of yuan depreciation and capital outflows. The People's Bank of China also injected liquidity through reverse repos and may consider cutting the reserve requirement ratio later this year.

images.alt_text: China’s consumer inflation has been relatively subdued this year in comparison with the soaring prices seen in other major global economies where central banks have raised interest rates repeatedly to tame costs
China's central bank will step up implementation of prudent monetary policy and provide stronger support for the real economy, its governor Yi Gang, said on Friday.

site_title: Truss in trouble amid Tory meltdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss faces possible replacement amid a "Tory meltdown." Conservative MPs are urging her departure, citing a series of negative developments, before the next general election, potentially before Christmas. Former minister Crispin Blunt stated that "the game is up" for Truss, and the succession process is uncertain. This follows a pattern of underlying UK political flux since the Brexit referendum in 2016.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends a news conference in London, Britain, October 14, 2022.  Daniel Leal/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Toshiba sale faces delay as banks wary on financing: sources
summary: A takeover of Toshiba, a potential buyout in Asia this year, is at risk of slipping behind schedule due to banks' concerns over financing commitments. The consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners and a rival group face obstacles securing financing from global banks amid rising borrowing costs. Four major Japanese lenders have only submitted indications of interest, and binding commitments cannot be made until the details of the equity partners are finalized. Toshiba's preferred bidder, JIP, is still in talks to form partnerships with domestic and global companies to fund the deal, but there's no certainty that talks will lead to a transaction.

images.alt_text: The Japanese conglomerate has been seeking strategic proposals for its future, including potential buyout bids.

site_title: Singapore’s inflation expectations at 11-year high amid global economic uncertainty: poll
summary: Singaporeans' inflation expectations for the year ahead have reached an 11-year high of 4.6% in a September poll, surpassing the historical third-quarter average of 3.2% from 2012 to 2021. The surge in expectations is attributed to global economic uncertainty and disruptions, such as the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict and supply chain issues. This marks the highest recorded figure since December 2011, exceeding the Monetary Authority of Singapore's forecasted median of 3.5% for consumer price index (CPI) inflation in 2023.

images.alt_text: Visitors gather on the jetty by the Merlion statue in Singapore on July 27, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

Many Asian currencies depreciated “quite sharply” as US monetary tightening led to widening interest rate differentials, helping push up import costs for the countries, Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific Department said.
Singapore’s growth is helping it withstand the global slowdown that threatens to push many economies into recession as early as next year.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as miners, energy stocks drag
summary: Australia's shares plummeted 1.6% to 6,651.4 as mining and energy stocks declined due to weaker iron ore and oil prices. Mining giants Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals Group fell between 2.8% and 3.2%. The decline was also driven by persistent recession fears and inflation concerns. Financials and technology stocks also fell, with gold stocks reaching their lowest since September 30.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.8 per cent higher at 6,758.8.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lower at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the trading day on October 17, 2022, with a 0.65% decline, resulting in a 107.95-point drop to 16,479.74. This decline followed the end of a rally at the end of the previous week, with investors shifting focus to the upcoming earnings season. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also experienced losses, with declines of 0.37% and 0.50%, respectively.

site_title: Global inflation fight stirs risks for Australia, treasurer says
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers warns that the country faces "pretty tricky territory" in the near term due to global inflation and pandemic aftermath. The global economy is treading a "narrower and more perilous path," with inflation a major concern. Chalmers notes that rising prices are partly driven by the war in Ukraine and supply chain issues. He emphasizes the need for responsible budgeting and economic management to mitigate risks, and the Labor government's upcoming budget will aim to provide inflation relief and invest in supply chains and skills training.

images.alt_text: The Australian economy will likely avoid a recession despite the world economy being in “a dangerous place right now”, Treasurer Jim Chalmers (right) said on Tuesday, ahead of the government’s first budget in two weeks.

site_title: India says new digital banking units to spur financial inclusion
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the rollout of 75 digital banking units (DBUs) to bolster financial inclusion in the country. The DBUs, to be set up in 75 Indian districts, will provide basic banking facilities such as opening accounts, loans, transferring funds, and paying taxes online. ICICI Bank and HDFC Bank have also announced the setup of four DBUs each in smaller Indian towns, aiming to increase access to banking services for citizens, particularly in rural areas. The move is part of the government's efforts to make banking services more accessible to its population of 1.4 billion people.

site_title: The pitfalls of Brexit are no longer taboo in UK politics
summary: The UK's Brexit experience is gaining recognition as a "calamitous loss of international standing" and "damage" with the governing Conservative Party acknowledging the negative consequences. A column in the Telegraph, traditionally a Brexit supporter, claims the pre-Brexit warnings "have turned out to be overwhelmingly correct." The shift in tone is mirrored by Prime Minister Liz Truss's more conciliatory approach, including apologizing to the EU and attending the European Political Community. The UK is now open to rebuilding ties and considering more visas for foreign workers to address labor market shortages.

images.alt_text: A surge in borrowing costs triggered by interest rates from the Bank of England are likely to quell activity in the months ahead.

Goldman’s 2023 annual growth projection for the UK has dipped from minus 0.4 per cent to minus 1 per cent. Now, core inflation is seen at 3.1 per cent at the end of 2023, versus 3.3 per cent previously.

site_title: Japan will respond to excessive FX moves, says country’s top currency diplomat
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Masato Kanda, stated that the country will respond firmly to excessive currency fluctuations, following the yen's sharp fall to a 32-year low. The yen's decline, despite Japan's intervention in the foreign exchange market, poses risks to households and companies due to high import costs. Authorities will take decisive steps against excess currency moves driven by speculation, according to Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki. Japan's currency fluctuations are also influenced by the Bank of Japan's loose monetary policy, which contrasts with the interest rate hikes by global peers.

images.alt_text: The currency fell to its lowest since August 1990 in the aftermath of Thursday’s hotter-than-expected US inflation report.
The dollar’s rally to successive records has currencies across the world in a spiral of doom.

A warning by G7 finance leaders, including a phrase in a statement on Wednesday saying they will closely monitor “recent volatility” in markets, failed to prevent the yen from sliding to fresh 32-year lows against the dollar as the week came to a close.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 1.03% or 278.86 points at 26,811.90. The decline follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where investors were disheartened by solid bank earnings and concerns over bond yields and recession risks.

site_title: Endowus acquires HK-based multi-family office, expands into ultra-wealthy market
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based digital wealth platform, has acquired Hong Kong-based multi-family office Carret Private, expanding into the ultra-wealthy market. The deal gives Endowus a foothold in Hong Kong and a minority stake in Singapore-based Lumen Capital Investors. The acquisition increases Endowus' assets under advisory to $4 billion and solidifies its position in the region's growing wealthtech sector. The partnership is expected to benefit from trends such as the influx of family office monies into Singapore and the growing demand for independent wealth advisory among ultra-wealthy clients.

images.alt_text: (from left) Endowus chairman and chief investment officer Samuel Rhee said digital banks aren't competing directly with wealthtech players. CEO Gregory Van believes Asia is heading in the direction of mature wealth management markets in emphasising the independence of advisers.
Single family offices in Asia Pacific tend to participate in private equity at a later stage than their European counterparts, according to Credit Suisse.
Endowus CEO Gregory Van said it had received licences under Types 1, 4 and 9 in the first quarter of the year, for dealing and advising in securities, and asset management

site_title: South Korea aims to boost economy with digital ID on blockchain
summary: South Korea plans to launch a digital identity system secured by blockchain, allowing citizens to access services and cast votes using their smartphones. The system aims to boost economic growth by simplifying verification processes, reducing administrative work, and increasing consumer credit. With an estimated 60 trillion won (S$59 billion) in economic value within a decade, the plan is seen as a "game-changer" by the World Bank and McKinsey & Co. The system will be decentralized, with no central server storing information, and users' data will be protected by advanced blockchain technology.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea raised its benchmark policy rate by 50 basis points to 3.00 per cent on Wednesday.
Rising commodity prices, supply-chain snags and slowing demand for semiconductors have been among the factors weighing on exports.

site_title: Japan PM orders probe into Unification Church
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida ordered a government probe into the Unification Church amid renewed scrutiny following the assassination of former premier Shinzo Abe. The sect, officially known as the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification, has been accused of pressuring members to make hefty donations. The church was founded in Korea by Sun Myung Moon and has been the subject of controversy, with some members reportedly motivated by resentment against the church in the Abe assassination. The investigation aims to determine the church's involvement in Abe's death.

images.alt_text: Hideyuki Teshigawara, general manager of the Japan branch of the Family Federation for World Peace and Unification (FFWPU), widely known as the Unification Church, speaks during a press conference at the FFWPU Tokyo headquarters on Sept 22, 2022.
Liberal Democratic Party Secretary-General Toshimitsu Motegi said a probe found some lawmakers had accepted support for election campaigns from the church and its spin-off groups.

site_title: Lawmakers will try to oust UK PM Truss this week: Daily Mail
summary: UK lawmakers will try to oust Prime Minister Liz Truss this week, despite Downing Street's warning of a potential general election. Over 100 Conservative Party MPs plan to submit letters of no confidence to Graham Brady, citing Truss's decision to ditch key parts of her tax-cutting program. The move could lead to a change in party rules to allow an immediate vote of confidence, but Brady is resisting, arguing for a chance to set out an economic strategy in the upcoming budget.

images.alt_text: epa10243731 Britain's newly-appointed Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt departs 10 Downing Street in London, Britain, 14 October 2022. The British prime minister on 14 October 2022 appointed Hunt to succeed Kwarteng as chancellor of the exchequer who accepted the prime minister's call for him resign after 38 days in office.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL

Goldman’s 2023 annual growth projection for the UK has dipped from minus 0.4 per cent to minus 1 per cent. Now, core inflation is seen at 3.1 per cent at the end of 2023, versus 3.3 per cent previously.
Questions about what would it take to bring back investor confidence and British PM Liz Truss’ own future are swirling.

site_title: Indonesia’s defences start crumbling against a relentless US dollar
summary: Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, is experiencing a downturn, with a 2.5% monthly fall in September, its largest this year. Foreign investors are withdrawing from the bond market, with outflows reaching $11 billion in the first three quarters of 2022. Analysts attribute the decline to the US dollar's relentless climb, but also note that Indonesia's relatively solid economy and monetary policy may help it resist past battering. The rupiah's historic vulnerability has been mitigated by rising commodity prices and lower foreign ownership of Indonesian bonds.

images.alt_text: Joko Widodo, President of Indonesia, says: “I will ask to speak to several ministers regarding a stress test to see how far our strength lasts when the storm comes, regarding our currency, inflation, growth, and matters related to food and energy.”

site_title: London leads UK home asking prices to biggest gain in 5 months
summary: London home prices surged 1.9% in October, the strongest pace in five months, driven by a jump in high-end homes. This marks a slight softening in the pace of growth, according to Rightmove. The UK's property boom, which lasted through the pandemic, is likely to be quelled by rising borrowing costs triggered by interest rate hikes from the Bank of England. Buyer demand has fallen 15% in the past two weeks, and only 3.1% of sales fell through in the same period.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s 2023 annual growth projection for the UK has dipped from minus 0.4 per cent to minus 1 per cent. Now, core inflation is seen at 3.1 per cent at the end of 2023, versus 3.3 per cent previously.

site_title: Singapore key exports growth eases to 3.1% in September on continued electronics slump
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 3.1% year-over-year in September, down from 11.4% in the previous month, due to a contraction in electronic shipments and declining deliveries to top markets including China and Hong Kong. Electronic exports fell 10.6% year-over-year, while non-electronic products grew 7.6%. Total trade grew 20.7% year-over-year, but economists expect NODX to slow further in the fourth quarter due to weaker demand from East Asia.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 11.4 per cent year on year in August, faster than the previous month’s 7 per cent expansion, on the back of an increase in non-electronics shipments.
Stacks of containers sit in the Tanjong Pagar terminal port in Singapore on June 17, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: The time to buy the dip is fast approaching - for one country
summary: Investors predict the US will emerge as the relative winner from this year's serial crises, with 69% saying it will weather the downturn best and recover first. The US is expected to lead the way out of the current market turmoil, with 86% of investors expecting US markets to recover first. The survey suggests the US will stop interest-rate hikes first, allowing the economy and asset markets to recover, and that the Federal Reserve is more likely to stop rate hikes than the European Central Bank or the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: Concerns are mounting anew over supplies out of the Black Sea region as the war in Ukraine escalates and there are questions over the future of the deal to ship grains out of Ukrainian ports.

site_title: Australia casino firm Star to be fined A$100m following inquiry: newspaper
summary: Australia's casino firm Star Entertainment Group will be fined A$100 million for failing to prevent money laundering and criminal activity in its Sydney casino. The New South Wales Independent Casino Commission found "systemic governance, risk and cultural failures" at the casino, which disguised huge amounts of money as hotel expenses and evaded anti-money laundering protocols. Star has accepted the findings but claims it should be allowed to continue operating under "strict supervision" with a remediation plan. The fine follows similar sanctions imposed on Star in neighboring Queensland and comes as Australia's casino sector faces intense scrutiny over money laundering allegations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Veteran Macau tycoon Stanley Ho, Managing Director of Sociedade de Jogos de Macau (SJM), attends a news conference during the opening of SJM's flagship casino Grand Lisboa in Macau, China February 11, 2007.   REUTERS/Paul Yeung/File Photo
Star was accused of misleading the regulator and allowing a Macau-based junket operator, Suncity, to operate a prohibited money-for-chips desk.

site_title: Vietnam’s VinFast recalls a third of its sold EVs to replace sensors
summary: Vietnam's VinFast recalls 730 of its model VF e34 electric cars due to an incompatibility error with the side crash sensors, which may send incorrect signals to the airbag controller. The recall affects vehicles sold on the domestic market and has not resulted in any reported breakdowns or complaints. The move comes as VinFast gears up to expand into the US market, where it aims to deliver its first batch of 5,000 all-electric SUVs in November. The company has sold 2,208 EVs since its launch last year and expects to sell 750,000 EVs per year by 2026.

images.alt_text: VinFast, which said in July that it had signed agreements with banks to raise at least US$4 billion to help its US expansion, has about 73,000 global reservations for its EVs.
The upstart EV maker, little known outside Vietnam, has ambitions to deliver as many as 1 million cars globally within 5 to 6 years.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Critical illness coverage - insurance for your income (Ep 129)
summary: BT Money Hacks podcast episode 129 discusses critical illness coverage, exploring how to ensure "lost earnings" are covered while recovering from an illness. Managing director Colin Chan from Great Eastern debunks misconceptions and discusses the affordability of critical illness plans, noting their evolution in an inflation-ridden environment. The conversation highlights the importance of having a plan in place to provide certainty despite uncertainty, and emphasizes the need for individuals to seek advice from professional advisors.

images.alt_text: Khor Hock Seng, Group CEO, Great Eastern

site_title: Opec+ members line up to endorse output cut after US coercion claim
summary: US claims OPEC+ member states, including Saudi Arabia, coerced them into a production cut, which will boost Russia's foreign earnings and potentially blunt sanctions over its Ukraine invasion. However, OPEC+ member states, including Saudi Arabia, denied any political motivations, stating the cut was based on economic factors and aimed at market stability. The decision was unanimously approved, with support from several countries, including the UAE, Iraq, Kuwait, Oman, Bahrain, and Algeria.

images.alt_text: The East Coast’s refining capacity has steadily declined over the years, while Europe, a key swing supplier to the region, is facing its own diesel crisis.
Brent crude futures dropped US$2.94, or 3.1 per cent, to settle at US$91.63 a barrel.

site_title: London Stock Exchange’s Voluntary Carbon Markets designation
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has launched its Voluntary Carbon Market designation, allowing listed funds and companies to raise capital for high-quality carbon reduction and removal projects. The designation requires entities to invest in certified projects, distribute, retire, or sell carbon credits, and provides no assurance of project success. Issuers must disclose adverse developments and the LSE retains discretion to remove the designation. This move aims to increase transparency and support for carbon reduction efforts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.56 points or 0.04% to 1,381.91. The market saw 187.72 million lots traded worth RM95.22 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 234 to 127.

site_title: Teradata betting big on the cloud
summary: Teradata's CEO Steve McMillan is sticking to his "cloud first" strategy, despite a 50% decline in shares over the past year. The company's latest quarterly revenue fell 12% to US$430 million, and it reported a loss of US$0.04 per share. McMillan believes the cloud business could be worth US$1 billion by 2025 and generating recurring revenue, with margins 10 times higher than on-premise business. The company's cloud ARR rose 68% to US$234 million, but growth has slowed. McMillan remains optimistic, citing benefits from cloud migration, such as faster data queries and increased flexibility.

images.alt_text: The market for semiconductor chips used in servers is getting bigger, more crowded and more complex. The business of memory chips, which store data rather than crunch it, is more commoditised and less lucrative.

The demand for workers with skills in software engineering, cloud and analytics is likely to increase with the rise of tech trends in 5G, cloud computing and AI, according to the Jobs Transformation Map for tech workers.
Manoeuvre with greater agility

site_title: Asean companies turning to debt capital markets, as equity nervousness reigns
summary: Asean companies are turning to debt capital markets as equity markets remain volatile, with fundraising challenging due to investor selectivity. Bond markets, particularly in local currencies, have shown resilience, with primary bond offerings reaching a three-year high of US$3 trillion. Industry experts expect fund managers and financial sponsors to deploy their high cash levels, focusing on more defensive plays, and anticipate a recovery in capital markets as uncertainties around rate hike cycles end.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 Index was down about 25 per cent through the end of the third quarter, its third-worst performance at that point of the year since 1931. And while the benchmark kicked off October with its biggest two-day rally since 2020, that soon fizzled.
FOMC participants are now projecting US GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent for 2022, and 1.2 per cent for 2023
Piggy bank with stacked coins. Pig with money savings on blue background.

site_title: G7 fails to reach intervention deal to ease pain of soaring dollar
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) finance leaders failed to reach a deal to intervene in the market to ease the pain of a soaring US dollar. Despite warnings and a Japanese Finance Minister's threat of another yen-buying intervention, the yen slid to fresh 32-year lows against the dollar. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that Washington has no appetite for concerted action, citing the dollar's overall strength as a "natural result" of different monetary tightening paces. Emerging markets are taking steps to mitigate the impact, but policymakers acknowledge the need for international cooperation to address the rising dollar's impact.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Mercedes unveils latest electric SUV aimed at Tesla’s Model Y
summary: Mercedes-Benz unveiled the EQE SUV, its latest electric vehicle aimed at Tesla's Model Y. The EQE features a 590-kilometre driving range and starts at around 70,000 euros (S$97,115) when sales begin later this year. The SUV is the fourth model to use Mercedes' dedicated EV platform, with plans to offer electric siblings for all combustion-engine models by the end of the year. Mercedes aims to go all-electric by 2030, with a focus on introducing new platforms and models in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz and Microsoft collaboration should lead to a 20 per cent increase in vehicle production efficiency by 2025 from 2022 levels.
Mercedes-Benz delivered 517,800 vehicles globally in the third quarter, up 21 per cent compared to the same period a year ago with demand in China leading strong growth in all key regions.

site_title: Divisive startup kingpin doubles down on EVs to undercut Musk
summary: Bhavish Aggarwal, founder of India's Ola Electric Mobility, aims to displace Tesla and BYD as the industry leader for electric vehicles by offering lower-cost designs. However, his relentless pace and management style have raised concerns about safety and the business model among some managers and board members. The company has faced supply chain problems, delayed sales, and product recalls due to issues with scooters catching on fire or having faulty batteries. Aggarwal's aggressive approach has led to a high turnover rate among senior executives, with around 30 executives quitting within a year or two of joining. Despite the challenges, Aggarwal remains committed to his vision, which has promise in India's growing electric vehicle market, expected to reach $150 billion by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: The company will start taking bookings on Oct 10 and deliveries will begin in December.

site_title: ESG funds are having a bad year
summary: Socially conscious stock funds, also known as ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) funds, have underperformed the market this year, with a 26.4% decline compared to the S&P 500's 23.9% drop. The funds often hold growth stocks, particularly tech shares, which have been hit hard this year. In contrast, value stocks in sectors like energy and industrial companies have fared better. Many ESG funds prioritize growth stocks due to their focus on environmentally responsible companies, but this approach has led to underperformance. Some funds, like Vanguard's ESG Select Stock Fund, offer a balanced mix of growth and value stocks to mitigate this risk.

images.alt_text: ABS’s new sustainable guidelines, which were developed with technical input from WWF-Singapore, cover private banking activities ranging from wealth planning and investments to financing.
PwC projected that ESG AUM in Asia Pacific will grow at a faster clip than Europe and the US, more than tripling to US$3.3 trillion by 2026, from a low base of US$1 trillion in 2021.
Coal generates around half of the country’s electricity and produces 70 per cent of carbon emissions from its power sector.

site_title: New Hub Synergy Point emerges, spruces up Anson office locale
summary: A new office tower, Hub Synergy Point, has been completed in Singapore's Anson Road area. Developed by Ho Kian Cheong, the 27-storey building features 118,000 sq ft of office space and 4,000 sq ft of retail area. Global chemical company Celanese is the first tenant, signing a 7,300 sq ft floor. The project is targeting gross effective monthly rentals of S$9-11 per square foot and aims to cater to SMEs and MNCs with small regional offices. The building's design includes flexible workspace, meeting rooms, and outdoor spaces.

images.alt_text: IOI Central Boulevard Towers, which is expected to be completed in October 2023, will have a podium and 2 towers.

When completed in 2026, Solitaire on Cecil will rise to 127 metres and comprise predominantly office space, which will be on 15 levels ranging from 11,000 sq ft to 13,000 sq ft.




Source: Solitaire Cecil Pte Ltd

site_title: Goldman downgrades UK growth outlook after government tax U-turn
summary: Goldman Sachs has downgraded its UK growth outlook to minus 1% in 2023, citing tighter financial conditions and higher corporation tax. The downgrade follows Prime Minister Liz Truss's decision to remove Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng and reverse plans to abolish the top income tax rate. Goldman now expects a more significant recession and a lower terminal interest rate, forecasting 75 basis point hikes in November and December, followed by smaller increases. Core inflation is now seen at 3.1% by the end of 2023, down from 3.3%.

site_title: Your big opportunity
summary: Inflation and economic uncertainty threaten businesses worldwide, but this crisis also presents opportunities for growth and change. To seize these opportunities, leaders must prioritize sustainability, creativity, and employee well-being. A bold and thoughtful approach to business can make it more sustainable and resilient. Employees must also take control of their careers, seeking their innate talents and making a positive impact on the world. By doing so, individuals can create a fulfilling life and leave a lasting legacy.

images.alt_text: I was 13 when an old Polish soldier, living out the war as a refugee in Britain, taught me how to plough. He showed me that aiming for the “Tree on the other side of the Field” would achieve a straight furrow, and all subsequent furrows would follow the line of the first. Ever since then I have known each morning, when rising from bed, where my Tree is.

Across the span of societies, from the wealthy to those near or at starvation point, consumers are both better and worse informed than they have ever been before.  The internet and the mobile phone have precipitated the greatest change in the distribution of information that humanity has ever seen.

People widely have a poor view of planning, especially in times of emergency. This may be partly because they see the process of planning as something you do for a posh wedding, where everything must be tickety-boo and there is no room for mishap.  The point is: How much worse would they have been without planning?

Why do humans blame their work for their misery? Why do many find themselves lacking in confidence, bereft of enthusiasm, tempted to opt out? The answer to this is another question. What do you think is the purpose of your life and the lives of those who work with you?

site_title: Over 1.5 million apply for World Cup pass, says Qatar
summary: Over 1.5 million people have applied for the compulsory Hayya pass for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, with the pass acting as a visa, match ticket, and transport ticket. All travellers to Qatar will need the pass to enter from November 1, regardless of their intentions. The Hayya pass service expects to handle 150,000 entries per day at Doha's international airports. Officials have prepared for the influx of foreign visitors, including domestic fans, with border officials processing 4,000 people per hour at the Abu Samra land crossing.

images.alt_text: Sri Lankan skipper Dasun Shanaka (second-left) said his team had also struggled to acclimatise.

site_title: Limited office space, need for flexibility could support demand for co-working market
summary: Co-working demand in Singapore is expected to remain firm amid tight office market conditions, rising rents, and economic headwinds. Occupancy rates have recovered from pandemic lows, with co-working operators like JustCo, WeWork, and IWG reporting increased demand. Average occupancy globally for JustCo has recovered to over 80%, while WeWork's Q2 occupancy stood at 87% and daily footfall rose 21% quarter-over-quarter. The co-working market is expected to benefit from the need for flexibility as hybrid working grows, with operators potentially hiking rates in an up-trending market.

images.alt_text: The Central Business District filling the Singapore skyline on 14 Feb 2018.

site_title: Climate fintech: Good progress in S-E Asia, but time to double efforts
summary: Singapore has made significant strides in climate fintech, with the hope that other Asian markets will follow. According to Jonas Thuerig, head of F10 Singapore, the growing number of climate fintech companies has helped the global financial sector transition towards a more sustainable future. Despite progress, efforts need to be doubled to support the development of climate fintech in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: STACS' Benjamin Soh says the volume of green finance is on the rise, which raise demand for ESG data and monitoring services.
A Fukushima Hydrogen Energy Research Field and an adjoining solar power in Namie Town, Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.

site_title: Transformation of London's iconic Battersea power station unveiled
summary: Battersea Power Station in London has reopened after a £9 billion redevelopment, transforming the iconic 1930s coal-fired power station into an office, shopping, and restaurant hub, plus apartments. The site features over 250 shops, cafes, and restaurants, as well as a theatre, hotel, events venue, and six-acre public park. The original Art Deco Turbine Hall has been preserved, and the chimneys have been rebuilt to their original precise specification. The redevelopment aims to create a successful new piece of city, with an estimated 25,000 people living or working on the site.

images.alt_text: Members of the public visit the Turbine Hall A inside Battersea Power Station, a newly redeveloped shopping and leisure complex, on its opening day in London, Britain, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

Members of the public are reflected in a mirrored underpass at Battersea Power Station as they queue to enter the newly redeveloped shopping and leisure complex on it’s opening day in London  London, Britain, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: Japfa unit applies to extend Hong Kong listing application
summary: Japfa's China dairy unit, AustAsia Investment Holdings, has filed an application to extend its proposed listing on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong. The company warned that there is no assurance the proposed distribution or listing will materialize due to factors such as regulatory approvals and market conditions. Japfa's board can decide not to proceed with the proposed listing or distribution if deemed not in the interests of Japfa or AustAsia. The company will make announcements when required or when developments arise.

images.alt_text: Japfa chief executive officer, Tan Yong Nang says the company will remain focused being efficient and lowest cost producers in their markets
Japfa to list China dairy unit in Hong Kong; proposes distribution-in-specie of its shares
Japfa jumps 10.8% on plans to list separate China dairy unit

site_title: AUDUSD: downward pressure expected to continue
summary: The Australian dollar (AUDUSD) is expected to face downward pressure due to a strong US economy and rising interest rates. Recent CPI numbers indicate a 40-year high in core inflation, and the Fed is expected to hike interest rates in November. The RBA's interest rate hike is seen as insufficient to keep pace, exacerbating the downward pressure. A recession is expected by next year, and a slowdown in global growth will further decrease demand for commodities. The AUDUSD is expected to remain shorted unless a short-term rally occurs, with key technical levels at 0.6410 and 0.6740.

site_title: London’s voluntary carbon market model could work for Singapore: CIX product head
summary: Singapore's Climate Impact X (CIX) is watching the London Stock Exchange's (LSE) Voluntary Carbon Market designation closely, with its product head Tom Enger saying it's possible for Singapore to adopt a similar model. The LSE's designation allows carbon reduction and removal projects to raise capital via a public listing, attracting a global supply of carbon projects. Enger believes Singapore's financial hub status and existing financial institutions make it probable to adopt a similar model, but notes that investors should exercise caution and consider the risk profile of funds with early-stage or high-risk projects.

images.alt_text: The LSE’s rules aim to encourage investment funds and operating companies to raise billions of pounds through LSE listings to fund climate-friendly projects.

The London Stock Exchange's Voluntary Carbon Market designation indicates listed funds or companies that are committed to investing in projects expected to yield high-quality carbon credits, and to distribute, retire or on-sell those credits.

site_title: Forex traders eye Japan response as yen approaches 150 level
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, reached a 32-year low, closing at 148.70 on Friday, amid speculation of possible intervention to support it. The currency has lost 23% against the US dollar this year due to monetary policy differences between the US and Japan. Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki expressed concern over market volatility, while chief currency official Masato Kanda warned of "bold action" if necessary. Some strategists believe the 150 per US dollar level is a key psychological threshold for Japanese citizens, potentially prompting government intervention if breached.

images.alt_text: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Truss faces market judgment as BOE exit leaves UK exposed
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss' economic program is facing market judgment after the Bank of England's exit, leaving the country exposed. The pound has reached record lows, and Truss' government has been forced to rollback tax cuts. The UK's new chancellor, Jeremy Hunt, has agreed with the BOE's governor, Andrew Bailey, on fiscal sustainability. However, investor confidence remains uncertain, and the market is set for another volatile start to the week. Traders are watching gilt auctions on Tuesday and Wednesday, which could lead to further moves from Downing Street or a fresh support plan from the BOE.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s 2023 annual growth projection for the UK has dipped from minus 0.4 per cent to minus 1 per cent. Now, core inflation is seen at 3.1 per cent at the end of 2023, versus 3.3 per cent previously.

site_title: As central banks tighten, investors should be as selective in Singapore as anywhere else
summary: Singapore's economy has rebounded strongly post-pandemic, but growth is slowing due to a tight labor market and elevated inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has re-centered the mid-point of its policy band to contain inflation, but did not steepen the slope or increase the width. This less-hawkish stance suggests MAS is being cautious about over-tightening monetary policy. The Singapore market has held up relatively well, but investors should be selective, considering depressed valuations and potential risks from slowing growth and inflation. Interest rate hikes will boost bank profitability, but also increase provisions and dividend payouts.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore tipped core inflation to "remain high" in the first half of the year, before "slowing more discernibly in the second half as cost pressures gradually ease".
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: ‘Knives Out’ sequel stars laud Angela Lansbury at Europe premiere
summary: Angela Lansbury made a cameo appearance in the European premiere of "Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery," a whodunit sequel to the 2019 film. Daniel Craig, who reprises his role as detective Benoit Blanc, praised Lansbury as a household name and expressed gratitude for her appearance in the film. Director Rian Johnson said Lansbury's cameo was a highlight of the movie, which also features an ensemble cast including Edward Norton and Kate Hudson. The film's success has been attributed to its subversive take on the genre, emulating the style of Agatha Christie.

site_title: With Kwarteng out, the hope is a steady Hunt can calm the jittery markets
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is under pressure to calm the jittery markets after Prime Minister Liz Truss' future is "hanging by a thread". Hunt, a former health secretary and foreign secretary, has taken over as Chancellor after Kwarteng's resignation and is seen as a potential successor to Truss. Hunt aims to demonstrate fiscal rectitude with a new budget by October 31, including tax hikes and spending cuts to address the UK's budget deficit of £72 billion. His success will be crucial in preventing Truss' ouster and stabilizing the economy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England (BoE) has raised its benchmark borrowing rate from 0.1 per cent last December to 2.3 per cent now.
Truss, speaking just hours after she fired Kwarteng, said she had decided to keep the rise, a move which would boost the public finances by US$20 billion.
UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng's sacking makes him Britain’s shortest serving chancellor since 1970.

site_title: Emerging markets hurt less as dollar’s wrath sinks rich nations
summary: Emerging markets have bucked the trend of a strong US dollar, posting relatively low losses compared to developed nations. Despite commodity prices tumbling, emerging markets have outperformed their peers, with 21 of 23 developing currencies beating the British pound, 19 outperforming the euro, and all doing better than the Japanese yen. Higher interest rates in emerging markets, driven by early rate hikes, have attracted investors, with some central banks seeing a "reward for proactiveness". However, experts caution that most emerging-market currencies are still falling and will remain on the back foot until the Fed halts rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknote is seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: The Great Resentment: Why Beyoncé holds the key to office culture
summary: Beyoncé's 2022 song "Break My Soul" is seen as a rallying cry for workers rejecting old constraints in new times, embodying the sentiment of "The Great Resentment." A growing culture of dissatisfaction in the workplace, marked by a dip in well-being and plateaued satisfaction, is attributed to outdated corporate culture. To address this, leaders should prioritize comfort, security, and certainty, and co-create new rules and norms through authentic, employee-focused feedback. This approach complements strategy, rather than competing with it, and can help leaders win the hearts and minds of their workers.

burnout, burned out, disease

Examples of quiet firing include denying raises for years on end, blocking employees from opportunities for growth or promotion, or neglecting to give direct and timely feedback. Employers may use this as an intentional strategy to get people to quit without firing them, or they may simply be new to management and not even realise the impact of their actions.
Rachel Bentley, a 31-year-old from Austin recently boomeranged back to her former employment with Duo.

Workers who shifted to 32-hour workweeks logged 7.58 hours per night of sleep, nearly a full hour more than when they were keeping 40-hour workweeks, according to lead researcher Juliet Schor, a sociologist and economist at Boston College who is tracking over 180 organisations globally as they shift to truncated schedules through six-month pilot programs.

site_title: Science fiction on the factory floor is more real than you think. How good is the tech?
summary: The article discusses the growing trend of smart manufacturing, also known as Industry 4.0, which is transforming the industry with advanced technologies such as industrial IoT, robotics, and AI. The estimated annual spending on manufacturing tech is $300 billion, with companies like Johnson & Johnson and BT using IoT-enabled energy management to reduce energy consumption. The article assesses the effectiveness of these innovations, including latency, integration, and user adoption, and highlights the emergence of unicorns in the manufacturing sector, such as Spark Cognition and Agile Robots.

site_title: Soaring US dollar leaves food piled up in ports as world hunger grows
summary: A surge in the US dollar is exacerbating global food shortages, particularly in Africa and Asia, as importers struggle to pay for food due to dwindling foreign-currency reserves. Thousands of containers of food are piling up at ports in Pakistan, and private bakers in Egypt have raised bread prices due to wheat shortages. The International Monetary Fund has warned of a catastrophic food emergency, and the World Food Programme has described the current crisis as the largest in modern history.

images.alt_text: Rice fields in Thailand. Asia is home to the world’s smallest-sized farms and largest number of smallholder farmers, generally defined as those with fewer than two hectares of land.

site_title: New York diesel is so scarce, traders are turning to unusual source
summary: East Coast diesel fuel has become scarce and expensive, prompting traders to seek an unusual source: the New York Mercantile Exchange. Record-low seasonal inventories and rising demand ahead of the winter heating season have driven New York Harbor diesel fuel to its highest premium over Nymex futures in five months. To avoid paying the premium, traders are opting for physical delivery of fuel a week or two after contract settlement. This shift highlights the tight market for diesel, which is used to transport goods and heat homes in the Northeast, due to declining East Coast refining capacity and Europe's own diesel crisis.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market showed modest improvements this week, with Aframax rates in the Mediterranean increasing by three points to WS225. Capesize rates softened due to a lack of fresh cargo, with the 5TC settling at $17,965. Panamax vessels saw a steady flow of tonnage, with the NoPac market active but insufficient Australia demand. Ultramax and Supramax rates remained positive overall, with a 60,000-dwt open China fixed at the low $18,000s. Handysize rates showed a positive trend in the Atlantic, with a 43,000-dwt fixing from the Black Sea to the Continent at $23,000. VLCC rates recovered, with the Middle East Gulf/China voyage rates rising six points to WS87.5. Suezmax rates also recovered, with the Black Sea/Augusta rate gaining 10 points to WS185.

site_title: Hong Kong to outline ambition to become top virtual asset hub
summary: Hong Kong aims to become a top virtual asset hub, seeking to revitalize its status as a global financial center after years of political turmoil and economic disruptions. The government will outline its framework for virtual assets, including a regulatory system and trial programs, during Fintech Week from Oct 31 to Nov 4. This move follows Hong Kong's loss as Asia's top financial center to Singapore and comes as the city considers policies to attract workers from mainland China and overseas.

site_title: Australia PM tours flood-hit Victoria state; evacuations, sandbagging underway
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese toured flood-hit Victoria state on Sunday, October 16, as three southeastern states grappled with a flood crisis. Heavy rain dumped over a month's worth of rain on the region, causing widespread flooding. Albanese announced emergency payments to Victorians affected by the disaster and deployed 60 Australian Defence Force personnel for evacuations and sandbagging. The crisis comes as Australia endures its third consecutive La Nina weather event. One flood fatality was reported in Victoria, with 74 flood warnings in place in New South Wales and 22 in Tasmania.

site_title: Guardians of world economy told to ‘buckle up’ as outlook dims
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the world's economies to "buckle up" as the outlook dims due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, higher interest rates, and the US dollar's surge. Finance ministers and central bankers discussed the challenges of sustaining the world economy's recovery, with concerns over debt distress, energy crises, and inflation. The IMF lowered its growth outlook, warning that higher interest rates might cause a recession. The group also criticized China's lack of participation in debt restructuring efforts, and urged fiscal and monetary policy coordination to avoid conflicting measures.

site_title: Companies, individuals recognised for their giving efforts
summary: The President's Volunteerism and Philanthropy Awards (PVPA) celebrated its 10th edition, recognizing individuals, organizations, and leaders for their generosity and giving efforts. The awards, held at the Istana on October 11, 2022, honored 11 winners across four categories, including 31 organizations. Notable winners include Agape Connecting People, which collaborated with Barclays Bank to help underserved communities, and the National Library Board, recognized for its inclusive hiring practices. The awards reflect the "strong desire and huge potential of Singaporeans to uplift one another," according to NVPC CEO Tony Soh.

site_title: China may further ease border curbs with Hong Kong, reports say
summary: China may further ease border restrictions with Hong Kong, including reducing the mandatory hotel quarantine period for arrivals from the city to four days by the end of the year. This decision is based on the incubation period for most Covid variants being about three days. The mainland may also allow more daily visitors from Hong Kong to cross the border, addressing the current intense competition for limited slots. However, discussions on a "reverse quarantine" system are stalled due to technical issues, including staffing and liability concerns.

site_title: Gloom grips China investors like never before ahead of Congress
summary: China's stock market has suffered its worst pre-Congress performance since 1991, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing over 5% in the past month. The yuan has fallen over 10% against the dollar this year, and China's dollar-denominated junk bonds have plummeted to near record lows. Investors are concerned about the country's economic growth and strict Covid Zero policy, which may hinder market recovery. Despite potential policy changes after the National People's Congress in March, analysts expect volatility to persist and a significant market turnaround to be unlikely.

site_title: How should a business bro dress?
summary: Finance bros in lower Manhattan's financial district have largely stuck to traditional office attire despite the pandemic, with many wearing crisp white shirts, slim-fit trousers, and dress shoes. Brands like Suitsupply, Lululemon, and Brooks Brothers remain popular among bankers and investment analysts, who prioritize a polished, professional look. The trend is driven by company policies, with some firms mandating in-person work three days a week and allowing flexibility on Fridays. This reflects a return to pre-pandemic office norms, with finance bros embracing classic business attire as a symbol of elevated status.

site_title: Xi says China’s power has increased, warns of ‘dangerous storms’
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping declared China's global power has increased while warning of "dangerous storms" ahead, striking a defiant tone at the start of the twice-a-decade Communist Party meeting. Xi emphasized the need for "self-reliance" in technology and vowed to focus on domestic development, while repeating the party's economic goals and pledging to "balance development and security." He defended China's Covid-zero strategy and praised the party's efforts to oppose Taiwan independence, amid heightened tensions with the US. Xi is expected to clinch a precedent-busting third term in office.

site_title: China will never renounce right to use force over Taiwan: Xi
summary: President Xi Jinping stated that China will never renounce its right to use force over Taiwan, but will strive for a peaceful resolution, in a speech at the ruling Communist Party's 20th party congress. China views Taiwan as its own territory, while Taiwan maintains its sovereignty and independence. The comments came amid ongoing tensions between Beijing and Taipei, which rose after China staged war games near Taiwan in August following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit. Xi emphasized that resolving the Taiwan issue is the Chinese people's responsibility, but China will not promise to give up the use of force.

site_title: Lifting of VDS for Mice events reduces manpower cost, brings in foreign attendees
summary: The lifting of vaccination-differentiated safe management measures (VDS) for events with over 500 participants in Singapore has reduced manpower costs and increased foreign attendees, easing restrictions. This move, made on October 10, will ease 40-50% of labor costs and give foreign participants peace of mind. The Singapore Tourism Board expects more contracts to be signed, accelerating the restoration of the MICE sector, which previously accounted for 0.8% of Singapore's GDP.

The rate is now 2.3%, with further increases expected, causing widespread living standards pain, with nearly half of mortgagor households on course to see their family budgets fall by at least 5%.

summary: Six S-Reits in September made acquisitions valued at approximately S$2.7 billion, including data centres, logistics, healthcare, and retail properties in Germany, the US, Japan, and Singapore. summary: The Philippine central bank is monitoring the peso for potential speculation amid its sharp decline of over 13% against the US dollar, one of the steepest drops among major Asian currencies. The bank will take measures to manage financial-market disruption and may raise interest rates to manage inflation, which has hovered above the central bank's target of 2-4%. Governor Felipe Medalla said the economy is "strong enough to withstand" rate increases, citing calculations that a 25 basis-point hike would only cut output growth by about five basis points.

summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) startups have defied the global venture capital slump, securing US$6 billion in deals this year, with over 147 EV-related funding deals amounting to US$5.95 billion, according to Preqin. The sector's growth is attributed to ample state support, including tax breaks, cheap loans, and capital investment, as well as provincial and municipal governments taking minority stakes in EV companies. Despite a slight decline in overall deal value, the EV market remains buoyant, with many startups backed by local governments and state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Astronomers are captivated by brightest flash ever seen
summary: Astronomers have observed the brightest flash of light ever seen, a gamma-ray burst (GRB) 221009A, 2.4 billion light years from Earth, likely triggered by the formation of a black hole. Detected on Oct 9, the burst released 18 teraelectronvolts of energy, impacting Earth's ionosphere and causing long wave radio communications to be disrupted. The event is believed to have originated from a massive star explosion, with scientists monitoring its afterglow to confirm their hypothesis and gather insights into black hole formation.

This move has raised concerns about US support for Taiwan's sovereignty and has complicated diplomatic efforts to end Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

Non-critical operations will be postponed to prioritize resources for Covid-19 patients. The Ministry of Health has activated 200 additional beds and is preparing more beds and holding spaces to cope with the increase in cases.

summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Canberra from Oct 16-18 for the seventh Leaders' Meeting, marking the latest in an annual series under the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership. The two leaders will discuss bilateral cooperation and regional developments, with Lee also visiting Sydney to meet senior business leaders and academics. site_title: Katharine Briggs and Isabel Myers, creators of a personality test
summary: Katharine Briggs and her daughter Isabel Myers created the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI), a widely used personality test, during World War II. Briggs, a mother of two, was inspired by an article on "Fitting the Worker to the Job" and sought to develop a tool to match people with jobs. She collaborated with her daughter, who had experience as an aircraft spotter and nurse, to create the test. The MBTI assesses four dimensions of personality: introversion/extroversion, sensing/intuition, thinking/feeling, and judging/perceiving. The test has become a standard at hundreds of corporations and universities, with over two million people taking it each year. Despite criticism of its scientific basis, the MBTI has remained popular due to its ability to provide a judgment-free framework for understanding individual differences.

site_title: Biden arrives in Oregon as Democratic hold on governorship is threatened
summary: US President Joe Biden arrived in Oregon on Friday, Oct 14, to rally support for Democratic gubernatorial candidate Tina Kotek, who is in danger of losing the state's governorship. Biden's visit comes as recent polls suggest Republican candidate Christine Drazan has pulled into the lead, and Kotek trails independent candidate Betsy Johnson. Biden will deliver an address on combating inflation and participate in a reception for Kotek on Saturday, as the state's gubernatorial election is set for Nov 8.

The renowned observatory has been operating since 1990 about 540 kilometres above Earth, in an orbit that slowly decays over time.

Dart’s celestial target is an asteroid “moonlet” about 170 metres in diameter that orbits a parent asteroid 5 times larger called Didymos as part of a binary pair with the same name, the Greek word for twin.

The Artemis I unmanned lunar rocket sits on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center on September 2, 2022. - NASA will make a second attempt to launch its powerful new Moon rocket on September 3, after scrubbing a test flight earlier in the week. The highly anticipated uncrewed mission will bring the US a step closer to returning astronauts to the Moon five decades after humans last walked on the lunar surface. (Photo by CHANDAN KHANNA / AFP)

site_title: Gold heads for worst week in 2 months as dollar rises
summary: Gold prices fell over 1% on Friday, heading for their worst week since mid-August, due to a stronger US dollar and concerns over the Federal Reserve's rate hikes to curb inflation. Spot gold fell 1.3% to $1,643.90 per ounce, with US gold futures settling 1.6% lower at $1,649.50. The dollar's rise made greenback-priced bullion more expensive for overseas buyers, and gold prices are increasingly correlated with the dollar's moves, potentially falling to $1,600 an ounce.

images.alt_text: Although traditionally considered an inflation hedge, interest rate hikes to combat soaring prices have reduced bullion’s appeal since it yields no interest.

site_title: Tesla fires after hurricane raises alarm for Florida officials
summary: Florida Senator Rick Scott is calling for action from the Transportation Department and automakers after a series of electric vehicle fires tied to Hurricane Ian. The fires, caused by saltwater damage, have diverted resources from hurricane recovery efforts. Scott and Florida's chief financial officer and state fire marshal, Jimmy Patronis, have asked manufacturers, including Tesla, Ford, and General Motors, for guidance and potential recalls. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is aware of multiple Tesla fires and has pointed to existing technical information and guidance.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of the destruction left by Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Florida, on Sunday (Oct 2). Fort Myers Beach sustained severe damage by the Category 4 hurricane.

site_title: Harry Styles’s former Los Angeles home hits market for US$8 million
summary: Harry Styles's former Los Angeles mansion, a 11,000 sq-ft contemporary home, is on the market for US$8 million. The property, located in the Hollywood Hills, features four bedrooms, six bathrooms, and a range of amenities including a home theatre, gym, and pool. Styles purchased the property in 2016 for US$6.9 million but sold it in 2019 at a loss. The listing agent is Emma Hernan of the Oppenheim Group.

site_title: Japan voices concern on currency swings after 32-year yen low
summary: Japan's currency official Masato Kanda warned the country will take "bold action" to stem currency volatility if needed, after the yen touched a 32-year-low of 148.86 against the dollar. The yen's sharp movements, driven by speculative activities, have raised concerns about economic and financial stability. Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki also expressed concern, stating that excessive volatility can have adverse implications. The country is prepared to intervene if necessary, with Kanda declining to comment on specifics, but emphasizing the need to address excessive currency moves.

images.alt_text: The currency fell to its lowest since August 1990 in the aftermath of Thursday’s hotter-than-expected US inflation report.
Markets are focusing on whether Japan will step in again, as stronger-than-expected US inflation data pushed the dollar to a fresh 32-year high against the yen of 147.665.

site_title: Global finance leaders single out China as barrier to faster debt relief
summary: Global finance leaders, including US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and German Finance Minister Christian Lindner, have criticized China as the main obstacle to debt restructuring agreements for developing countries. China's lack of participation in debt talks has been highlighted, with Yellen stating that China's role is crucial to making progress. The IMF and World Bank have launched a Common Framework to bring creditors like China and India to the negotiation table, but China has not yet participated fully. The world's poorest countries face $35 billion in debt-service payments in 2022, with over 40% due to China.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen walks to a meeting between G20 finance ministers and central bank governors at the 2022 IMF/World Bank annual meeting in Washington, DC on Oct 13, 2022,
Scale will be the new umbrella trust fund for the bank’s results-based climate finance activities.

Speaking at the Atlantic Festival, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said there is likely “some inflationary pressure” caused by the shortage of workers in the labour market, which has driven wages up.

site_title: Oil prices fall more than 3% on recession worries
summary: Oil prices fell more than 3% on Friday, with Brent crude futures dropping $2.94 to $91.63 a barrel, and US WTI crude futures falling $3.50 to $85.61, amid recession fears and weak oil demand in China. The US core inflation recorded its biggest annual increase in 40 years, reinforcing views that interest rates would stay higher for longer, and the US dollar index rose 0.8% due to a stronger dollar reducing oil demand.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for December delivery rose US$2.12 to US$94.57 a barrel, a 2.29 per cent gain.

site_title: Lombard Odier taps local alliances to capture Asia’s growth
