summary: Lombard Odier, a Swiss private bank, is increasing its presence in Asia through strategic local alliances and growing its Singapore-based management team. The bank has set up three Asia hubs, including its Singapore office in 2008, and has formed partnerships with local financial institutions in South-east Asia. Lombard Odier is bullish on China's stocks, holding a 2.1% overweight position, and is focusing on the country's fiscal support and pragmatic public health policy for a better second-half of the year. The bank is also exploring sustainability and crypto movements, but has not seen significant interest from clients in these asset classes.

images.alt_text: Lombard Odier is holding its 2.1 per cent overweight position on Chinese equities, which now make up 4.3 per cent of its portfolio.
They’ve increasingly shunned stocks and bonds to focus on their own companies or assets deemed safer such as gold and cash.

site_title: S’pore’s Covid-19 XBB infections to peak in mid-Nov, cannot rule out bringing back mask rules
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 XBB infections are expected to peak at 15,000 daily cases by mid-November. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung has warned that stricter mask mandates or safe management measures cannot be ruled out. Public hospitals have already increased bed capacity to cope with the rise in cases, with 200 additional beds provided for Covid-19 patients. The Ministry of Health believes Singapore has adequate healthcare capacity to handle the surge, but further measures may be necessary to control the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: The spike, while largely driven by the XBB variant, is seeing low severe cases, said the MOH.
The Moderna bivalent vaccine targets the original Sars-CoV-2 strain of the virus as well as the Omicron BA.1 variant.

site_title: Frasers Property to reappoint Siripen Sitasuwan as independent director
summary: Frasers Property will reappoint Siripen Sitasuwan as an independent director, effective October 17. The appointment aims to enhance diversity on the board and provide further expertise. Siripen previously served as an independent director from 2013 to 2014 and will join the audit and information technology committees. Additionally, Pramoad Phornprapha was also appointed as an independent director with experience in consulting and advisory work. The move follows a flat close of Frasers Property's shares on Friday at S$0.93.

images.alt_text: Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within Frasers Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Does China really need that much more coal-fired electricity?
summary: China is reversing its climate ambitions and increasing coal-fired electricity production after severe power shortages in 2021 and 2022. The Guangdong province has approved construction of six new coal-fired power plants with a total capacity of 9.7 million kilowatts, surpassing the capacity of all plants built from 2016 to 2020. The move is seen as a reversal of China's goal to reduce carbon emissions by increasing non-fossil fuel use. Proponents argue that severe power shortages harm the economy, while opponents say managing peak demand is more economical and better for meeting climate goals.

images.alt_text: China consumes over 4 billion tons of coal a year, most of it domestically mined with imports making up less than a tenth of its needs.
The main driver for solar’s dominance is larger and more sophisticated factories that increase economies of scale.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain but uncertainty over UK's fiscal plan weighs
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Friday, building on Thursday's rally, despite uncertainty over the UK's fiscal plan. The Stoxx 600 index closed near session highs, erasing some losses from the week's first three days. The pound fell 1.2% against the dollar, and two-year gilt prices dropped. The UK's decision to retain corporation tax plans, despite scrapping unfunded tax cuts, provided some relief, but markets remain cautious due to aggressive interest rate hikes and an energy crisis.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index shuttled between positive and negative territory throughout the session before closing up 0.9 per cent and snapping a six-day losing streak.

site_title: A unique moment for venture debt investing in Asia
summary: Venture debt, a type of private credit lending to startups, is gaining traction in Asia as traditional VC funding pulls back. Unlike conventional bank loans, venture debt is made based on growth potential rather than collateral and cash flow. This non-dilutive financing allows startups to raise extra capital without diluting founders' shareholdings. With venture debt funds often offering warrants to investors, the market is poised for growth, driven by a pullback in VC funding and increased awareness of venture debt in Singapore. The government's Enterprise Financing Scheme – Venture Debt programme also supports the growth of venture debt in Asia.

images.alt_text: The founders of Genesis Alternative Ventures from L-R:  Martin Tang, Ben J Benjamin, Jeremy Loh and Eddy Ng.
Even as startups face a tighter funding environment and macroeconomic headwinds, venture debt firms are still seeing opportunities in this climate.

site_title: 2022 Audi S8: Fast laps, in the lap of luxury
summary: The 2022 Audi S8, Audi's flagship luxury sedan, boasts a V8 engine producing 571 horsepower, all-wheel drive, and a range of comfort features, including massage chairs. The car's size may be intimidating, but it's surprisingly agile, with a 0-100km/h time of 3.8 seconds. A facelift has given the S8 a new grille and redesigned bumpers, but its core appeal lies in its speed and exclusivity. With a price tag of S$739,546, the S8 is a niche product for those seeking a high-performance, luxurious driving experience.

images.alt_text: The most striking thing about the new RX is probably its distinctive face.
Maserati MC20 on the left and Levante Trofeo on the right.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch is considering reuniting Fox with News Corp
summary: Rupert Murdoch, 91, is considering reuniting his Fox Corp and News Corp businesses, a move that would reunite his media empire after a 9-year split. News Corp has set up a special board committee to study the potential deal and evaluate possible terms. The Murdoch family holds a 39% voting stake in News Corp and 42% in Fox. A reunion could give the Murdochs a broader portfolio of opportunities and consolidate power for Rupert's son Lachlan, who is co-chairman of News Corp and executive chairman of Fox.

images.alt_text: Jerry Hall, 65, filed a petition in Superior Court of California, citing “irreconcilable differences” as legal grounds for divorce.

MEDIA tycoon Rupert Murdoch's TalkTV launches in Britain on Monday (Apr 25), entering a crowded news market, but leveraging his star interviewer's familiarity with trash-talking former US president Donald Trump.

site_title: How to talk to clients about inflation
summary: Financial advisors should be prepared to explain inflation to clients, as it can significantly impact their investments. Inflation is the increase in prices of goods and services, and while consistent inflation is necessary for a healthy economy, high inflation can slow the economy and erode savings. The current persistent inflation has multiple causes, including supply-chain issues, trillions of dollars in US government stimulus, and the Russia-Ukraine war. The US Federal Reserve raises interest rates to contain inflation by increasing the cost of borrowing, reducing demand, and potentially leading to lower prices. Advisors should help clients manage the impact of inflation by reviewing their long-term financial strategies and diversified portfolios.

images.alt_text: Employers, many still short-staffed, continue to hire at a solid pace.

A small chorus of researchers has for months warned of a potential hazard to earnings should the campaign to tamp down inflation succeed. Specifically, the squeeze on margins that could occur should an indicator known as corporate operating leverage suffer in an environment where sales flatten out.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit misses estimate as deals drought extends
summary: Morgan Stanley reported a 30% slump in third-quarter profit, missing analysts' estimate, due to a slowdown in global dealmaking. Investment banking revenue more than halved to $1.3 billion, with declines across various segments. The bank's wealth management business, however, posted a 3% rise in revenue. Morgan Stanley's CFO attributed the decline to a need for cost stabilization and valuations to stabilize for a dealmaking rebound. The bank's shares fell 1.7% in early trading.

site_title: Wells Fargo profit falls on sales scandal costs, higher reserves
summary: Wells Fargo reported a 31% decline in third-quarter profit due to operating losses from the fake accounts scandal and higher loan loss reserves. The bank posted $2 billion in operating losses, excluding items, earning $1.30 per share, beating analyst expectations. Noninterest expense rose 8% while net interest income jumped 36% due to higher interest rates. The bank's average loans rose to $945.5 billion, and its net interest income is expected to rise 24% this year. Wells Fargo's CEO, Charlie Scharf, emphasized the bank's focus on strengthening its risk and control infrastructure.

site_title: Marking milestones with timepieces
summary: Stephanie Soh, a watch collector, has been collecting timepieces for 25 years. She treasures her first watch, a self-winding Bradley watch given to her by her father for her fifth birthday, featuring Mickey Mouse on its face. Soh's passion for watches has endured despite not wearing them frequently.

images.alt_text: Art collector Sun Lulu

site_title: India’s rising tycoons take global spotlight
summary: India's wealthiest individuals saw their collective wealth increase by $25 billion to a record $800 billion in 2022. Adani topped the list with a net worth of $150 billion, followed by Mukesh Ambani with $88 billion. Falguni Nayar, founder and CEO of Nykaa, is now India's richest self-made woman, with a net worth of $4.08 billion. Other notable debutants include Venu Srinivasan, chairman emeritus of TVS Motor Company, and the Kamath brothers, founders of Zerodha Broking. The rise in wealth is attributed to a combination of factors, including a weaker rupee and the growth of India's economy.

images.alt_text: The boom in India comes despite economic challenges elsewhere in the world, with broadening inflation in the aftermath of the Russia-Ukraine war and sharply higher interest rates.

The RBI’s informal communication to local bankers is a step back from the directions it issued in June 2020, when it allowed banks operating from the International Financial Services Centre Banking Units to trade in the NDF segment.
The platform has more than 3 million active users, with over 25,000 vehicles registered by their owners.

site_title: Setting the pace for consistent leadership
summary: Thomasin Crowley, global director of Asia Pacific at WiredScore, attributes her consistent leadership to her morning runs. She started running at 16 to relieve pressure and improve fitness, and it helped her "switch off" during long work hours. Crowley now runs 4-5 times a week and believes it sets her up for success, both physically and mentally. She emphasizes the importance of self-care and finding individual activities that work for each person, allowing them to recharge and decompress without pressure. This approach enables her to lead with energy and confidence.

images.alt_text: On the bike leg of the Roth Ironman race in Germany, 1997. The event covers a 3.8km swim, 180km cycling, and then a 42km run.

Andermatt Swiss Alps' Maureen Yeo participating in the Mongolia Sunrise to Sunset, an event consisting of 10 to 15 days of horse-riding treks before a full marathon around the craggy mountain past west of the stunning Lake Hovsgol.

site_title: UK corporation tax to rise to 25% on PM Truss' U-turn
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has U-turned on a planned corporation tax freeze, deciding to raise it to 25% instead. The move, announced just hours after firing finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng, is expected to boost public finances by $20 billion. The decision comes amid a tax-cutting program that has roiled financial markets and led to a pound slump. British companies have largely opposed the freeze, citing concerns over economic stability. Truss stated that fiscal discipline is needed to reassure markets, despite criticism from economists and business groups.

images.alt_text: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng's sacking makes him Britain’s shortest serving chancellor since 1970.

site_title: Glove maker UG Healthcare to operate active retirement homes
summary: UG Healthcare, a glove manufacturer, plans to diversify into operating active retirement homes in Malaysia through a joint venture with Indigo Teguh and Lumayan Sejati. The first homes will be built 21km south of Desaru Coast Ferry Terminal, with Indigo Teguh providing RM33.3 million in funding for the project. The venture aims to generate additional revenue streams and capitalize on the growing demand for retirement facilities in Malaysia, which is aging rapidly. The company's shares rose 1.1% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Although analysts expected the weaker financials, they said the rate at which the declines are taking place is alarming. Companies did not buffer themselves sufficiently during their heydays.

site_title: US retail sales stagnate as inflation, rates hit consumers
summary: US retail sales stagnated in September, with overall sales remaining little changed after a 0.4% gain in August. Seven retail categories declined, including auto dealers, furniture outlets, and electronics merchants. The data reflects consumers' guarded spending amid high inflation and rising interest rates, with the Federal Reserve expected to hike interest rates further. This could tip the US into recession, exacerbating the pain of inflation, which has reached a 40-year high.

images.alt_text: The average for a 30-year, fixed loan climbed to 6.92 per cent from 6.66 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said in a statement on Thursday (Oct 13).

site_title: Fed is set to target even higher rates as inflation stays stubborn
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are likely to raise interest rates further in response to persistent inflation, with core consumer price index rising 0.6% for the second month and 6.6% from a year ago. Several policymakers want to see a decline in core inflation before slowing rate increases, and data suggests they may need to lift rates higher than expected. The next forecast publication is in mid-December, and officials may signal they're willing to get interest rates as high as 5.5% to control price pressures.

site_title: US tech firms hid lobbying efforts, European Parliament says
summary: The European Parliament has accused major US tech firms, including Meta Platforms, Amazon.com, and Alphabet's Google, of hiding lobbying efforts and failing to disclose their connections. Three lawmakers filed complaints, requesting the transparency register to revoke the companies' access to EU institutions if they're found to violate transparency rules. The tech companies allegedly lobbied under the guise of a group representing small businesses to influence EU tech laws, including the Digital Markets Act and Digital Services Act.

site_title: US: Wall Street slides, dollar gains on sterling and yen
summary: US stocks declined sharply on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.3% to 29,634.83, the S&P 500 losing 2.4% to 3,583.07, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 3.1% to 10,321.39. The decline was driven by concerns about inflation and rising interest rates, as well as the UK's sacking of its finance minister and the subsequent weakening of the British pound. The dollar rose against the yen and sterling, and oil prices fell 3% as recession fears weighed on demand.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 153.5 points, or 0.51 per cent, at the open to 30192.21.

site_title: Racecourse memories at Farrer Horse
summary: Farrer Horse, a two-storey gastrobar within The Sultan hotel in Kampong Glam, pays tribute to the former Farrer Park Racecourse, relocated to Bukit Timah in the 1930s. The venue features an equestrian theme, with decor and cocktails inspired by horse racing. The Stable cocktail bar offers six racecourse-inspired drinks, including the Secretariat, which combines hay-infused bourbon and apple puree, while the Dining Room serves pan-Asian cuisine. The venue is open until 12 am on weekends, offering a refined and energetic atmosphere for diners and cocktail enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: The Kongsee's namesake cocktail is a refreshing sweet-and-sour concoction featuring Tanglin Gin and a dash of local craft lager, topped with passionfruit sorbet.
The Other Room's cocktail menu is divided by era, with the Merry Go Round falling within the 1929-2019 section of the timeline.

site_title: India’s Tata Power says hit by cyberattack
summary: Tata Power, an Indian power company, reported a cyberattack on its IT infrastructure on October 14, 2022, impacting some systems. The company stated it has retrieved and restored critical operational systems and implemented restricted access and preventive checks on employee and customer-facing portals. All critical operational systems are now functioning, and the company has taken steps to mitigate the attack's impact.

site_title: AEM Holdings raises revenue guidance for full year
summary: AEM Holdings raised its full-year revenue guidance to between S$820 million and S$850 million, up from the previous range of S$750 million to S$800 million. The revised guidance is attributed to increased demand from new and existing companies. The company's shares initially saw huge sell-offs due to concerns over semiconductor demand, but recovered after the revised guidance announcement.

site_title: IMDA mandates SMS sender ID registration; telcos to filter potential scam messages
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore mandates SMS sender ID registration for all organisations using SMS sender IDs, with registrations starting on October 31. A one-time set-up fee of S$500 and annual fee of S$200 per sender ID will be required. Non-registered sender IDs will be channelled to a "Likely-SCAM" header for six months. Telcos will also implement anti-scam filtering solutions in their networks from October 2022, and aggregators must obtain a Services-Based Operations (Class) licence and verify organisations' UENs.

images.alt_text: In the full registration regime, IMDA proposes that merchants and organisations that use SMS sender IDs must register with the SSIR using a Unique Identity Number.

site_title: JPMorgan posts record net interest income on Fed rate hikes
summary: JPMorgan Chase reported a record $17.6 billion in third-quarter net interest income, driven by Federal Reserve interest-rate hikes. CEO Jamie Dimon cited solid consumer spending, plentiful job openings, and healthy businesses as positives, but also warned of headwinds including high inflation and the war in Ukraine. Dimon predicted the US may avoid a recession but expects interest rates to rise higher than 4% to control inflation. JPMorgan raised its guidance for the year, citing a $61.5 billion net interest income excluding its markets business, and plans to resume share buybacks early next year.

site_title: Citigroup profit falls on higher loan-loss reserves, weak dealmaking activity
summary: Citigroup reported a 25% drop in third-quarter profit due to increased loan-loss reserves and weak investment banking activity. The bank added $370 million to its reserves, pushing up credit costs to $1.36 billion, the highest in eight quarters. Investment banking revenue fell 64% to $631 million. Analysts expect Citi to take 3-5 years to hit normalized profitability measures. The bank's shares have been trading at half of its net worth, and revenue from its Treasury and Trade solutions business rose 40% to $3.2 billion.

site_title: Upside surprise in Singapore’s Q3 GDP unlikely to last into Q4: economists
summary: Singapore's Q3 GDP expanded 4.4% year-over-year, beating economists' expectations, prompting upgrades to the full-year growth forecast to 3.7%. However, economists warn that this growth is unlikely to be sustained in Q4 and beyond due to headwinds from tighter monetary conditions, high inflation, and geopolitical tensions. The services sector, particularly accommodation and food services, drove the growth, while the manufacturing sector is expected to slow down. Economists now predict a slowdown in Q4, with some forecasting full-year growth near the bottom end of the forecast range.

images.alt_text: Visitors gather on the jetty by the Merlion statue in Singapore on July 27, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
The Monetary Authority of Singapore tipped core inflation to "remain high" in the first half of the year, before "slowing more discernibly in the second half as cost pressures gradually ease".
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: Kitchen Culture rejects requisition to remove five directors
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings' board of directors, excluding Hao Dongting, rejected a request from a group of shareholders to voluntarily resign five directors. The five directors, Lau Kay Heng, Lim Wee Li, William Teo Choon How, Ang Lian Kiat, and Peter Lim King Soon, were requested to resign by Ooway Group, the company's largest shareholder, who owns 21.7% of the shares. The board cited no grounds for the resignations, suggesting Ooway may have its own reasons. An extraordinary general meeting (EGM) has been scheduled for November 1.

images.alt_text: A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.

site_title: Pan-United to dispose stake in Indonesian aggregate producer for S$3.5m
summary: Pan-United Corporation agreed to sell its 49% stake in Indonesian aggregate producer Pacific Granitama (PTPG) to Mega Alam Perkasa for S$3.5 million. The sale, valued at approximately S$5 million, will incur a loss of about S$1.5 million for Pan-United, with the remaining proceeds going towards working capital and future projects. The transaction is part of PTPG's requirement to be 100% owned by Indonesian nationals to apply for a new mining licence.

images.alt_text: Worksite safety issues and dengue outbreaks have impacted the productivity of construction companies.
Pan-United's mixer trucks

site_title: Economists not ruling out further scheduled, off-cycle tightening moves by MAS in 2023
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised its inflation forecasts, expecting core inflation to remain high in the first half of 2023 before easing in the second half. Economists are not ruling out further tightening moves, including off-cycle ones, at the next policy meeting in April 2023, citing a "far cry" from previous expectations. The MAS has narrowed its full-year inflation forecasts, with core inflation expected to average around 4% and headline inflation around 6%.

images.alt_text: Visitors gather on the jetty by the Merlion statue in Singapore on July 27, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

ST20221014_202297491764: Gin Tay /pixmof15/ Goh Yan Han /

 Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong announces a $1.5 billion support package to Provide Further Relief for All Singaporean Households,
with more support for Lower- to Middle-Income Groups during a press conference at National Press Centre on Oct 14, 2022.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO sees sector growth buoyed by pickup in travel demand
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr expects the aviation sector to continue growing despite war in Ukraine, inflation, and recession. Travel demand is expected to hold up, driven by the re-opening of Japan to tourists and a rise in business travel. Lufthansa aims to reach 87% of pre-pandemic capacity in 2023, with 86% of seats now filled. The airline also expects to return to group operating profit this year, driven by short-haul flights in Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Carsten Spohr, CEO of German airline Lufthansa AG speaks at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Bonn, Germany, May 7, 2019. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
European airline stocks have plunged over the last six months over worries that rising household bills will dampen appetite for travel, but IAG said it was confident on future demand.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Putin comments, mixed bank earnings
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Friday, October 14, after Russian President Vladimir Putin eased geopolitical worries by stating there were no plans for further military mobilization. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 153.5 points, or 0.51%, to 30,192.21. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, rising 20.5 and 93.7 points, respectively, at the open.

site_title: ABS launches new guidelines for sustainable private banking, wealth management practices
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has launched new guidelines for sustainable private banking and wealth management practices, developed in collaboration with the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF). The guidelines cover four sustainable investment approaches, including ESG factors and thematic investing, to help private banks transition towards a low-carbon economy. A common industry training benchmark was also launched to upskill relationship managers in sustainability. The guidelines and training benchmark aim to support private banks in integrating sustainability into their business models and practices.

images.alt_text: WWF-Singapore to teach public about responsible investing after strong uptake for industry courses
From left to right - Frederick Chin, Head of Group Wholesale Banking and Markets, and Eric Lian, Head of Group Commercial Banking, launching the UOB Sustainability Compass.

site_title: US dollar edges higher, pushing yen to new 32-year low
summary: The US dollar rose to a 32-year high against the yen, reaching 147.785 yen, and was last up 0.34% to 147.705. The stronger-than-expected inflation data on Thursday initially triggered a rally in global stock markets, but the US dollar ultimately fell. Meanwhile, the British pound slipped after reports of a potential U-turn on the government's tax plans. The US dollar index was up 0.35% to 112.97, and the Australian dollar was up 0.1% versus the greenback.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) adjusted its policy band to reduce imported inflation, keeping core inflation around 5% for the rest of the year. The central bank also announced a S$1.5 billion support package for lower- to middle-income groups, with up to S$500 for eligible adults. Singapore's economy grew 4.4% in Q3, beating expectations, and businesses must adjust to high energy prices and a tight labour market.

site_title: UK’s Truss sacrifices finance minister, scraps tax plan in fight to survive
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss fired her finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng and scrapped parts of their economic package in a bid to stay in power amidst market and political turmoil. Kwarteng resigned at Truss's request after being forced to rush back to London from IMF meetings in Washington. Truss accepted that the economic package had gone "further and faster" than markets had expected and scrapped a key business levy, raising £18 billion. The move comes after Truss's 37-day tenure as prime minister, which was marked by economic instability and market volatility.

images.alt_text: Truss and Kwarteng are now under huge pressure to reverse course as polls show their support has collapsed and colleagues have started openly discussing whether they should be replaced.

site_title: Motorola rejects UK regulator’s claim of radio network-monopoly profit
summary: Motorola Solutions has rejected the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) claim that the company's monopoly on emergency mobile radio communications services in the country led to £160 million in excess profits annually. The US-based company stated that the CMA's calculation is based on an arbitrary time period of the Airwave project and is unfounded and incorrect. Motorola Solutions disputed the CMA's findings, which were published in a provisional assessment after a probe last year.

site_title: No longer a title-decider as free-scoring Man City look to slay Liverpool
summary: Manchester City faces off against Liverpool in the English Premier League, with City's star striker Erling Haaland looking to continue his record-breaking form. Meanwhile, La Liga rivals Real Madrid and Barcelona meet in a high-stakes El Clasico match, with Barcelona's defense under scrutiny after recent errors. Both matches are expected to be high-scoring and intense, with City's dominance and Haaland's goalscoring exploits likely to be a major factor in the Liverpool game, and Real Madrid seeking revenge against Barcelona in the El Clasico.

images.alt_text: The compensation will be paid to “all clubs” for which the footballer has played in the two years before the World Cup.
Officials are saying that only World Cup ticket holders and their guests, media personnel and other tournament-related visitors will be allowed to enter the country from Nov 20 to Dec 18.

Former England and Tottenham Hotspur striker Teddy Sheringham in action at the AIA Better Lives Fund charity golf event at Tanah Merah Country Club. The tournament and a charity dinner raised more than S$370,000 for a good cause.

site_title: Slowing Chinese growth is a recipe for global instability
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow, with the country's population decline and diminishing returns to infrastructure development weighing heavily on its growth trajectory. A future where China remains below the US in income levels is now more probable, potentially leading to a world of two competing superpowers. The US aims to hobble China's economy, but Beijing's internal shift towards statism and authoritarian rule may ultimately cripple itself, leading to a more unstable global economic landscape.

images.alt_text: China's central bank will step up implementation of prudent monetary policy and provide stronger support for the real economy, its governor Yi Gang, said on Friday.

As Xi Jinping prepares to extend his tenure as China’s leader at next week’s Communist Party Congress, he faces once-in-a-generation economic challenges and decisions that will significantly shape the lives of the country’s 1.4 billion people.
The PBOC may still need to tread cautiously on further easing.

site_title: China trade data delayed without reason from customs authority
summary: China's General Administration of Customs delayed the release of September trade data without providing a reason, contrary to its usual schedule. Economists had predicted exports would slow further and imports would remain stagnant, with overseas shipments expected to rise just 4% from last year. This would be the slowest pace of growth since April and the second time shipment figures would be that low, amid warnings from Chinese officials of waning overseas demand due to a slowing global economy. The delayed data release has left investors and economists uncertain.

site_title: Eurozone posts record trade deficit in August amid soaring energy prices
summary: The eurozone recorded its largest trade deficit since 2015, with a deficit of nearly 51 billion euros in August, driven by soaring energy prices. The deficit ballooned from 34 billion euros in July, marking the 10th consecutive month of a negative balance. Despite a 24% increase in exports to 231.1 billion euros, the import bill rose by 53.6% to 282.1 billion euros. The EU's trade deficit for the period from January to August reached 309.6 billion euros, largely due to increased energy imports from Russia and Norway.

site_title: Ringgit hits fresh low as concerns mount over political uncertainty: analysts
summary: Malaysia's ringgit hit a fresh low against the US dollar, reaching nearly RM4.70, amid growing concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and ongoing political uncertainty in Malaysia ahead of a general election. The ringgit has fallen by over 12% year-to-date against the US dollar. Analysts attribute the weakening exchange rate to the Fed's tightening of the international money supply and the potential impact of a change in government on policy risk. A snap election is expected to take place within 60 days, with analysts predicting a difficult outcome for the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia and industry observers said structural reforms are needed to build solid economic fundamentals to provide a more enduring support for ringgit.
Malaysia's prime minister Ismail Sabri announced the dissolution of Parliament on Oct 10, 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.21% to 16,587.69, following a rally on Wall Street despite disappointing US inflation data. Asian markets tracked the US market's gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increasing. The gains were attributed to investor confidence in the rally on Wall Street, despite expectations of another interest rate hike.

site_title: China Q3 growth seen bouncing 3.4%, but 2022 set for worst performance in decades
summary: China's economy is expected to grow 3.4% in the third quarter, a rebound from the 0.4% pace in the second quarter, according to a Reuters poll. Despite this, 2022's growth is forecast to be the worst in almost half a century, at 3.2%, due to COVID-19 curbs, energy and food supply disruptions, and slowing global growth. Growth is expected to pick up in the fourth quarter, but analysts warn of downward pressures and a weak recovery in 2023.

site_title: Reits lead Singapore stocks lower on Friday, as STI falls for 7th day
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.03% for the 7th consecutive day, reaching a 19-month low of 3,039.61. The market barometer was down 3.4% for the week. Reits, including Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust and Mapletree Pan-Asia Commercial Trust, were major losers. However, Capitaland Ascendas Reit was the only STI Reit to end the day higher. The economy beat expectations, growing 4.4% in the third quarter, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore tightened monetary policy to fight inflation.

images.alt_text: Visitors gather on the jetty by the Merlion statue in Singapore on July 27, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

A McDonald's restaurant in Garden Grove, California, making its hiring spree known in April. The US labour market  remains tight. There were 1.7 job openings for every unemployed person on Aug 31. Layoffs remain low.

site_title: Japan LDP tax chief says corporate tax hike an option for defence funding: Nikkei
summary: Japan's tax chief, Yoichi Miyazawa, suggests raising corporate taxes as an option to fund the country's defense build-up. He stated that a "somewhat large tax" could be considered if there is a significant tax revenue expectation. This proposal comes as Japan's defense ministry seeks to increase spending to 5.6 trillion yen, which would be about 1% of the country's GDP. Miyazawa played down concerns about adding to Japan's massive debt burden, which is over twice the size of GDP.

site_title: High energy prices, tight labour market a new state of affairs businesses must adjust to: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a S$1.5 billion support package for Singapore residents, focusing on lower- and middle-income individuals. The package includes cash and vouchers, aimed at helping individuals cope with high energy prices and a tight labour market. Wong emphasized that businesses must adjust to this new state of affairs by restructuring and transforming to become more energy and manpower efficient, as the government will continue to study other help for businesses in future budgets.

site_title: Malaysia GE will end up with another fractious coalition, with splintering support
summary: Malaysia's parliament was dissolved on October 10, paving the way for a general election (GE) that is expected to take place in November. The election is unusual due to the absence of state elections and potential flooding during the monsoon season. The GE will include new voters aged 18-21, increasing the total number of voters to 21 million. However, the outcome is uncertain, with a crowded political landscape and no single party likely to secure a majority, leading to a potential fractious coalition government.

images.alt_text: The ringgit may face some weakness amid the uncertainty ahead of the elections.

Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad at a press conference in Putrajaya on Oct 11. The 97-year-old said he will defend his Langkawi seat at the upcoming general election, widely expected to take place in November.

site_title: Gazprom CEO says big part of Nord Stream may need to be replaced
summary: Gazprom CEO Alexei Miller stated that a significant portion of the damaged Nord Stream pipelines may need to be replaced due to the extent of the damage. Repairs are expected to take over a year. Russia plans to boost gas exports via the Black Sea and Turkey, with proposed new pipelines capable of transporting 63 billion cubic meters of gas per year. The incident has been described as an "act of international terrorism" by Russia and a "sabotage" by the European Union.

images.alt_text: Germany's former chancellor Angela Merkel was In Lisbon, Portugal, to serve as president of the jury of the Gulbenkian Prize for Humanity. She says her move to engage Russia as a supplier for Germany's gas was a correct decision at that time.

Russia's President Vladimir Putin said that Russian gas could still be supplied to Europe through one remaining intact part of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline but the ball was now in the EU’s court on whether it wanted that to happen.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: European stocks rallied on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index jumping 1.0% to 6,918.28 points, and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices also increasing 1.1% and 1.2% respectively. The gains came despite a hotter-than-expected US inflation report and UK finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng's early return from the IMF in Washington to face a budget storm. Investors cited a technical rebound, unwinding defensive positions ahead of the inflation report.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pushed other Opec nations into oil cut, White House claims
summary: The US claims Saudi Arabia pressured other Opec nations into cutting oil production by 2 million barrels per day, contradicting the Saudi foreign ministry's statement that the decision was based on supply and demand balance. More than one Opec member reportedly disagreed with Saudi Arabia's push, feeling coerced into the vote. The US presented an analysis showing the cut was not market-based, potentially to blunt the effectiveness of sanctions on Russia. The move is the latest sign of deteriorating US-Saudi relations since President Biden took office.

images.alt_text: “The relentless deterioration of the economy and higher prices sparked by an Opec+ plan to cut supply are slowing world oil demand,” IEA said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, Oct 14, with a 9.11-point gain to 1,382.47. The index saw 2.253 billion lots traded worth RM1.761 billion, with 481 gainers and 335 losers.

site_title: Indian, South Korean films win key prize at BIFF
summary: Indian film "Shivamma" and South Korean film "A Wild Roomer" won the New Currents award at the Busan International Film Festival, with each film receiving the US$30,000 prize. "Shivamma" is director Jaishankar Aryar's feature debut, and "A Wild Roomer" is filmmaker Lee Jeong-hong's first feature film. The films were recognized for their originality and intensity, and "A Wild Roomer" was praised for its innovative filming techniques. The festival, which returned after South Korea lifted pandemic restrictions, featured 242 films from 71 countries and drew 161,145 attendees.

site_title: India festival spending booms despite inflation worries, global slowdown
summary: India's festival season has seen a significant surge in spending, with estimated sales of over $27 billion, more than double the amount in the pre-Covid period in 2019. Despite global economic challenges, including inflation and interest rate hikes, Indian consumers are lapping up goods and services, including cars, houses, and jewelry. The surge is attributed to pent-up demand, rising wages, and economic recovery, with online sales rising by nearly one-fifth in the first week of the season. This boost is expected to support India's economic growth of around 6.5% in the fiscal year ending March 2023.

images.alt_text: The RBI’s informal communication to local bankers is a step back from the directions it issued in June 2020, when it allowed banks operating from the International Financial Services Centre Banking Units to trade in the NDF segment.

Fueled by erratic rainfall and supply shocks from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, prices of daily consumables like cereals and vegetables which form the largest category in the inflation basket have climbed over the past two years.

site_title: Seoul: Shares join global rally to end higher; online marketplaces jump
summary: South Korean shares rose 2.3% on Friday, driven by internet platform operators, despite US inflation data and a strong dollar. The Kospi index ended at 2,212.55, its third-best daily performance this year, while the won strengthened and bond yields fell. Heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and LG Energy Solution also jumped. Foreigners were net buyers of shares for the 10th session in a row, while the currency weakened 1.13% against the dollar for the week.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 10.4 points or 0.47 per cent at 2,202.47.

site_title: Carrier Garuda Indonesia’s shareholders approve rights issue plan
summary: Garuda Indonesia's shareholders approved a rights issue plan to raise up to 14.3 trillion rupiah (S$132 million) in December. The plan, which had been approved by Parliament in April, will allow the government to top up the airline's capital by 7.5 trillion rupiah. The airline aims to use the funds for maintenance, aircraft restoration, and fuel, with the goal of strengthening its business outlook. Shareholders also approved the conversion of 4.2 trillion rupiah worth of liabilities into equity as part of the debt restructuring agreement.

site_title: South-east Asia central banks digging into toolkit to fight risk
summary: South-east Asian central banks are using a range of unconventional tools to combat plunging currencies and cooling price gains. The region, facing its biggest challenges in decades, has seen countries such as the Philippines and Malaysia raise interest rates and deplete foreign exchange reserves. Monetary tightening, open-mouth operations, and using bond yields to arrest capital outflows are among the measures being taken. Despite efforts, central bankers are struggling to maintain a balance between stability and growth, with declining reserves potentially limiting room for further intervention.

images.alt_text: Many Asian currencies depreciated “quite sharply” as US monetary tightening led to widening interest rate differentials, helping push up import costs for the countries, Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific Department said.

site_title: Private bets shield world’s largest investors from market mayhem
summary: The world's largest investors, including China's US$1.2 trillion sovereign wealth fund and California's public pension, have shifted to private markets to cushion losses from runaway inflation and spiraling interest rates. Since the global financial crisis, the top 10 global funds have doubled their combined weightings in private assets such as private equity, credit, real estate, and hedge funds, now accounting for about a quarter of their portfolios. This pivot has helped mitigate losses, but the question remains how long these private bets will remain insulated as the economic outlook darkens.

images.alt_text: Piggy bank with stacked coins. Pig with money savings on blue background.

site_title: China oil demand in limbo as virus saps travel before party Congress
summary: China's oil demand remains uncertain due to ongoing COVID-19 lockdowns and travel restrictions. Despite increased fuel export quotas, refiners are expected to only partially raise production, citing weak domestic consumption and global demand uncertainty. This has led to downward pressure on global oil prices, with spot market purchases subdued. China's energy demand is expected to grow 7% this quarter, but the impact of the upcoming Communist Party congress on energy policies is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Oil surged early this year, bringing Brent close to its record high of US$147 as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to supply concerns, but prices have slid on economic fears.

site_title: Royal Mail to cut 10,000 jobs as strikes blamed for loss
summary: Royal Mail plans to cut 10,000 jobs due to a projected £350 million operating loss, largely attributed to industrial action, delays, and lower parcel volumes. The cuts, which will be phased over the next 8 months, are part of a restructuring effort to address changes in the parcel market. Strikes by 115,000 sorting and delivery workers over improved pay and working practices have contributed to the losses. The company aims to transform its business to grab a bigger share of the next-day parcels market.

images.alt_text: Royal Mail’s top shareholder Vesa Equity had in July informed the British government that it was planning to increase its stake in the 500-year-old firm to more than 25 per cent from the 22 per cent that it currently owns.

site_title: Malaysia keeps November crude palm oil export duty at 8.0%
summary: Malaysia has maintained its 8% export tax on crude palm oil for November, with a reference price of RM3,575.80 per tonne, down from RM4,033.51 in October. This is the third consecutive month the tax remains unchanged. The export tax structure ranges from 3% to 8% based on price thresholds.

site_title: UK's Kwarteng flies back for crunch talks over tax plans
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng cut short his trip to Washington to return to London amid mounting pressure to reverse the government's economic policy, which has caused financial market turmoil. The policy, announced just three weeks ago, includes unfunded tax cuts that have sent borrowing costs surging and forced the Bank of England to intervene. Pressure is growing for the government to scrap the policy, with polls showing a collapse in support for Prime Minister Liz Truss and her Chancellor Rishi Sunak.

images.alt_text: epa10224652 British Prime Minister Liz Truss delivers her keynote speech at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Britain, 05 October 2022. Truss' first conference speech as party leader comes after a few turbulent weeks, with the mini budget causing turmoils in markets and uprisings in her party, only one month into her premiership.  EPA-EFE/ISABEL INFANTES

site_title: Indonesia's fatal soccer stampede caused by tear gas, say investigators
summary: A fact-finding team in Indonesia has concluded that tear gas was the main cause of death in a deadly soccer stampede that killed over 130 people on Oct 1 at Kanjuruhan stadium in East Java. The team found that police fired tear gas indiscriminately, with no knowledge of FIFA's ban, and employed excessive measures. The Indonesian football Association and match organiser have been accused of negligence, and dozens of police officers are under investigation. The findings have been handed to the president, with FIFA forming a taskforce with the PSSI to improve crowd control and safety measures.

images.alt_text: People stand next to a torched vehicle outside the Kanjuruhan stadium in Malang, East Java, on October 2, 2022. - At least 127 people died at a football stadium in Indonesia when fans invaded the pitch and police responded with tear gas, triggering a stampede, authorities said on October 2. (Photo by Juni Kriswanto / AFP)

site_title: PropertyGuru acquires home service technology startup
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based online real estate firm, has acquired home-service technology startup Sendhelper for an undisclosed sum. Sendhelper's platform connects homeowners and tenants with freelance service providers for cleaning, maintenance, and repair services. The acquisition marks PropertyGuru's entry into the home-services industry and is expected to have long-term growth opportunities, particularly as it expands into fintech and data. The deal will enhance PropertyGuru's offerings, aiming to provide a one-stop destination for property seekers to find, finance, own, and manage their homes.

images.alt_text: Staff, partners, investors and other guests celebrated PropertyGuru’s listing at an event held at Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre Hybrid Experience on March 18, 2022.
Hari Krishnan, chief executive officer, PropertyGuru believes that investments in talent and technology has delivered positve results for Q1 FY2022
PropertyGuru starts trading on NYSE

site_title: Thai economy constrained by trade deficit, to see smaller surplus in 2023: Barclays
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to see a smaller current account surplus in 2023, revised down to US$5.3 billion from US$9.1 billion, according to Barclays. The country has seen persistent large deficits since April 2022, driven by high energy prices and slowing exports. Analysts attribute the decline in exports to trade partner China's lockdown and sluggish recovery, as well as a slowdown in demand for Thai electronic exports. A return to a surplus in 2023 is unlikely, and the country's current account balance may take time to recover.

images.alt_text: The Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) said its industries sentiment index rose to 91.8 in September from 90.5 in the previous month.
Central bankers across emerging Asia have relied on reserves to protect their currencies against a resurgent dollar as aggressive Federal Reserve policy tightening spurred flows back to the US.

site_title: Longer-dated JGB yields fall amid UK U-turn talk
summary: Japanese five-year bond yields fell 0.5 basis points to 0.065% amid speculation that the UK government may backtrack on its mini-budget, leading to a decline in overseas yields. Short-dated JGB yields rose, while the 30-year yield eased to 1.465%. The market expects a potential U-turn in the UK's tax cut plan, which could lead to a decrease in global yields. A bounce-back in the yen also calmed Japan's bond market, despite ongoing monetary policy tightening in the US.

images.alt_text: Supporting sterling, longer-duration British gilt yields fell on Thursday, easing back from 20-year highs struck on Wednesday.

site_title: 2.5m Singaporean adults will get up to S$500 in December as part of new S$1.5b support package
summary: Singapore will provide a S$1.5 billion support package to help offset the effects of inflation, including a S$500 payment to 2.5 million eligible adult Singaporeans earning below S$100,000, and an additional S$100 in Community Development Council vouchers per household. The package also includes 600,000 public transport vouchers worth S$30 each to help with the recently announced 10.6-percentage-point fare increase. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the measures are aimed at helping lower-income and vulnerable groups disproportionately impacted by inflation.

images.alt_text: High energy prices and tight labour conditions are likely to be the new state of affairs for businesses, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo
Another 10.6 percentage points in fare hikes will be carried forward to future fare reviews.

site_title: China’s central bank governor says policy measures will be stepped up to boost economy
summary: China's central bank governor, Yi Gang, announced that the People's Bank of China will implement more prudent monetary policy and provide stronger support for the real economy. The PBOC will focus on infrastructure construction and quicken the pace of loan utilization for home projects, as well as issue equipment upgrade loans to key sectors, including manufacturing. This move aims to boost the economy, which is expected to slow down. The statement follows a G20 meeting where Yi emphasized the need for supportive policies to stabilize the economy.

site_title: Australia: Financials and energy stocks boost  shares
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.8% to 6,758.8 on Friday, its largest gain in over a week, as financials and energy stocks surged. The benchmark index recouped losses for the week after a 4.5% gain the previous week. Energy stocks led gains, with oil prices reversing earlier losses, while financials rose 1.6% for the third straight session. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates to over 3% this year, according to market strategist Kerry Craig.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 1.5 per cent to 6,743.7, as of 0020 GMT on Friday, heading for its biggest single-day jump since Oct 5.

site_title: Chipmaker TSMC’s shares leap after profit beats estimates
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, reported an 80% on-year surge in profit for the July-September period, the strongest growth in two years. The company's shares jumped over 4% after beating profit estimates, despite trimming capital spending by 10% for 2023. Analysts see the move as a cautious but optimistic sign for the tech sector, citing long-term growth prospects in areas like artificial intelligence and high-performance computing.

images.alt_text: TSMC said it expects to spend about US$36 billion in 2022 on capital equipment, down from at least US$40 billion previously.

site_title: Asia spent US$50b in September to defend currencies from strong US dollar
summary: Asian governments spent approximately US$50 billion in September to defend their currencies against the strong US dollar, the highest level since March 2020. This comes as the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reached an all-time high, reducing the value of other currencies in central banks' portfolios. Countries including South Korea, India, Taiwan, and Japan sold dollars, while others, such as Hong Kong and the Philippines, were net sellers. The surge in dollar sales is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding high US interest rates and the need for central banks to maintain cash reserves.

images.alt_text: The yen and yuan are both tumbling due to the growing disparity between an uber-hawkish Federal Reserve and dovish policy makers in Japan and China.
Central bankers across emerging Asia have relied on reserves to protect their currencies against a resurgent dollar as aggressive Federal Reserve policy tightening spurred flows back to the US.

site_title: Japan keeps up yen warnings, won’t say if it intervened
summary: Japan maintained its warnings about speculative currency moves, following the yen's slump to a 3-decade low after a hotter-than-expected US inflation report. Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated that excessive moves triggered by speculation won't be tolerated, and the country is watching the foreign exchange markets with a high sense of urgency. The yen traded around 147.40 against the dollar, with speculation of potential Japanese intervention keeping the currency's downward trend in check.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on September 24, 2022 shows Japanese 10,000 yen notes (apprx. 69 USD) on display in Tokyo. - Japan's finance ministry on September 22 intervened in the currency market to bolster the yen, which has plummeted against the US dollar in recent months on the widening policy gap between the US and Japanese central banks. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Markets are focusing on whether Japan will step in again, as stronger-than-expected US inflation data pushed the dollar to a fresh 32-year high against the yen of 147.665.

site_title: China’s inflation remains subdued on lockdowns, commodity prices
summary: China's consumer inflation remained subdued in September, rising 2.8% from a year earlier, driven by pork prices and softer commodity prices. This is the highest CPI since April 2020 and marginally weaker than forecast. Core inflation, excluding food and energy costs, slowed to 0.6%, the weakest pace since March 2021. Economists warn of potential deflation due to weak demand, while the government emphasizes stability. The slowdown in producer inflation was driven by declining global commodity prices, with mining, raw materials, and manufacturing prices all decreasing.

images.alt_text: As Xi Jinping prepares to extend his tenure as China’s leader at next week’s Communist Party Congress, he faces once-in-a-generation economic challenges and decisions that will significantly shape the lives of the country’s 1.4 billion people.
The PBOC may still need to tread cautiously on further easing.

site_title: G20 meets amid Ukraine war, US-Saudi tensions
summary: The G20 finance ministers and central bank governors met in Washington, amid tensions between the US and Saudi Arabia over OPEC+ oil production cuts, and the ongoing Ukraine war. Despite divisions, Western officials emphasized the importance of the forum for discussing global crises, including soaring inflation and a climate crisis. The G20 is unlikely to agree on a joint communique, with the US and Saudi Arabia at odds over the decision. The meeting comes ahead of the UN's COP27 climate summit in Egypt and the G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, next month.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration accused the country and its de facto leader Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, of ignoring US requests not to go ahead with the cut.

Germany's former chancellor Angela Merkel was In Lisbon, Portugal, to serve as president of the jury of the Gulbenkian Prize for Humanity. She says her move to engage Russia as a supplier for Germany's gas was a correct decision at that time.
Commercial and residential buildings in Hong Kong. The amount of vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled in Hong Kong over the last three years

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee’s Altara Ventures leads US$5m fundraise for Thai proptech
summary: Altara Ventures, backed by Koh Boon Hwee, has led a US$5 million fundraise for Thai proptech platform PropertyScout. The funds will be used to build its technology platform and expand into South-east Asian markets. PropertyScout connects property agents, buyers, renters, and owners to solve the fragmented property market issue and digitalize transactions. The company aims to make buying, selling, or renting a home easy and trusted, starting in Thailand and then across South-east Asia.

site_title: Facebook parent seeks dismissal of US challenge to Within Unlimited deal
summary: Meta Platforms, parent company of Facebook, has asked a US judge to dismiss a lawsuit filed by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) over its proposed acquisition of Within Unlimited, a reality content maker. The FTC claims the deal would "tend to create a monopoly" in the virtual reality-dedicated fitness app market, but Meta argues the allegations are "conclusory, speculative, and contradictory" and do not plausibly plead any facts to support the claims. The FTC filed a lawsuit in July, and Meta is seeking dismissal of the lawsuit.

images.alt_text: A logo of Meta Platforms Inc. is seen at its booth, at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups, at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France June 17, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

site_title: Importers like Sheng Siong among winners from MAS tightening: DBS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has tightened monetary policy, causing the Singapore dollar to appreciate against other currencies. This is expected to benefit importers like Sheng Siong, as their overseas input costs are now relatively cheaper in Singapore dollar terms. However, companies that earn more than 80% of their profits abroad, such as Singtel, may face challenges due to the stronger dollar. The MAS has forecasted core inflation to average 4% in 2022, slightly higher than estimates, and growth in Singapore's major trading partners is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: TSMC said it expects to spend about US$36 billion in 2022 on capital equipment, down from at least US$40 billion previously.

site_title: Australia suffers flash floods in south-east, Melbourne suburb evacuated
summary: Australia's south-east region experienced severe flash flooding, prompting thousands to evacuate their homes, including a Melbourne suburb. The intense weather system, which dumped over a month's worth of rain in some areas, caused rivers to burst their banks and fast-moving waters to flood streets. Emergency services warned that river systems were reaching major flood levels, with the situation expected to persist through the weekend and next week.

images.alt_text: epa10242589 A submerged car is seen in flood waters in Maribyrnong, Melbourne, Australia, 14 October 2022. Victorian residents have been told to move to higher ground as rain continue to pummel vast swathes of the state, causing flooding and thousands of power outages.  EPA-EFE/JAMES ROSS  AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT
Rivers around the world are drying up.
By Thursday morning, Sydney had received 2,157 mm of rains for the year, just shy of the record 2,194 mm set in 1950, official data showed.

site_title: Asia: Markets surge after sharp Wall Street swing, pound holds gains
summary: Asian markets surged on Friday, extending a Wall Street rebound after a forecast-beating US inflation report. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Taipei rose over 3% each, while Seoul advanced more than 2%. Sterling held gains after UK government speculation, while the yen remained near 32-year lows against the dollar. Analysts attributed the market reversal to expectations of aggressive Fed rate hikes and a possible bottom in equities after a year of selling, but warned that the reversal may not last long.

images.alt_text: Asia was again in the red with traders in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Manila selling.
Never before has the market experienced such extreme readings in both directions in one day, according to Bloomberg data going back to 1990.

site_title: New video shows leaders’ alarm as US Congress attacked
summary: Disturbing video footage shows US Congress leaders, including Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate leader Chuck Schumer, desperately calling for help as the US Capitol was ransacked by a mob sent by former president Donald Trump in January 2021. The footage, previously unreleased, captures lawmakers' panic and vulnerability as they discuss sending for security and demanding the president intervene. The footage underscores how vulnerable lawmakers were during the violent insurrection.

images.alt_text: Wesley Hunt (left), a Republican who is likely to win his House race, during a campaign event in Cibolo, Texas., April 13, 2022.

Google said Truth Social has since been updated to comply with its policies barring objectionable posts, and has built in effective systems for reporting and removing unwanted content as well as blocking abusers.

site_title: Shell ties up with renewables firm for Australia battery storage project
summary: Shell Energy Australia and AMPYR Australia signed an agreement to develop a 500 megawatt battery energy storage system in New South Wales, Australia. The project, expected to begin construction in mid-2023, will provide energy storage and charging capabilities. Shell Energy will hold the rights to charge and dispatch energy once the project is operational. The project aims to support Australia's renewable energy goals and contribute to the country's energy security.

images.alt_text: A total of four wells are expected to be drilled in Block 2K and four other ultra-deepwater blocks off the coast of Sabah in 2022 and 2023.
Shell’s partners in the GKGJE project include ConocoPhillips Sabah, Petronas Carigali, PTTEP Sabah Oil Limited, PT Pertamina Malaysia Eksplorasi Produksi and others.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks ended sharply higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed sharply higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 rising 3.25% or 853.34 points to 27,090.76. This followed robust gains on Wall Street, where shares made a rapid U-turn after beating inflation data. The broader Topix index also rose 2.35% to 1,898.19, as investors responded to the positive economic indicators.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.77 points or 0.78% to 1,384.13, driven by a gain of 284 to 71 stocks. Volume reached 190.74 million lots worth RM80.03 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track US rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.72% on Friday, October 14, 2022, following a US inflation report that fueled a rollercoaster day on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 16,671.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rally came after a week of selling in Hong Kong markets.

site_title: Xi faces painful gear shift as China’s investment-led growth sputters
summary: China's economic growth, fueled by investment, is sputtering, posing significant challenges for President Xi Jinping as he prepares to extend his tenure. The country faces record youth unemployment, a property crisis, and high debt levels, with economists warning of a sharp slowdown. China's reliance on investment as a source of demand is unsustainable, with household consumption lagging behind global averages. The government has taken steps to address the issues, but a complete re-modeling of the economy is unlikely, and economists predict average annual GDP growth will halve to 4.5% this decade and slow to 3% in the next.

images.alt_text: Commercial and residential buildings in Hong Kong. The amount of vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled in Hong Kong over the last three years
A customer takes a photo of ice cream at a Gelato Dal Cuore store in Shanghai, China September 6, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song
The PBOC may still need to tread cautiously on further easing.

site_title: Europe’s right-wing is adopting the Left’s look
summary: Women and minorities are increasingly joining the top ranks of hard- and far-right parties in Europe, challenging left-wing parties' assumptions about their support base. Notable examples include Italy's Giorgia Meloni, UK's Liz Truss, and France's Marine Le Pen. This shift is partly due to the right's populist messaging and the desire to connect with "common people" and overcome perceived social hurdles. However, it also reflects a more nuanced and complex reality, where individuals from underrepresented groups are not always aligned with progressive ideologies and may be drawn to conservative politics due to social conservatism and a desire for personal merit.

images.alt_text: "Diverse” hires can be every bit as diverse on the inside as they are on the outside. Apparently, we need constant reminders that there’s more to people than meets the eye and that in multicultural societies, an acceptance of diversity must be more than skin deep.
Liz Truss, UK prime minister, delivers her keynote speech during the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference on Wednesday Oct 5.

Giorgia Meloni has only slight government experience, and has been rocketed to the top of Italian politics in great part thanks to her boycotting Draghi’s technocratic administration over the past 18 months

site_title: Indonesian waste management platform Waste4change snags US$5m Series A funding
summary: Waste4change, an Indonesian waste management platform, secured a $5 million Series A funding round led by AC Ventures and Barito Mitra Investama. The startup plans to increase its waste management capacity to 100 tonnes a day and reach 2,000 tonnes per day over the next five years. The funds will be used to expand its reach, automate material recovery facilities, and add 52 employees to its current team. Waste4change is riding on Indonesia's government-initiated "Indonesia Bersih Sampah 2025" programme, aiming for a 30% reduction in waste from source by 2025.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in funding for Indonesian startups is giving founders a taste of a downturn, and potentially giving rise to companies that will make an impact
As macroeconomic headwinds and inflation impact Indonesia, the startups there are feeling the pinch even as long term prospects still appear bright.

site_title: The censor cannot hold: the pressure of controlling China’s Internet
summary: A former Chinese censorship team member, Zeng Jiajun, shares his experience working for ByteDance, a Chinese social media company, in the US. Zeng, who was tasked with filtering out content deemed sensitive by the Communist Party, became disillusioned with the system after witnessing the censorship of a banned documentary about the Tiananmen Square crackdown. He quit his job in 2020 after the censorship of Dr. Li Wenliang, who raised alarm about COVID-19, and now advocates for internet freedom in the US. Zeng's story highlights the blurred lines between censorship and free speech in China, and the personal costs of speaking out against the government.

images.alt_text: As Xi Jinping prepares to extend his tenure as China’s leader at next week’s Communist Party Congress, he faces once-in-a-generation economic challenges and decisions that will significantly shape the lives of the country’s 1.4 billion people.

China’s consumer inflation has been relatively subdued this year in comparison with the soaring prices seen in other major global economies where central banks have raised interest rates repeatedly to tame costs

site_title: Dubai’s US$73,000 a year villa rentals come with a warning
summary: Dubai's real estate market is experiencing a surge in luxury rentals, with the average annual rent for a villa reaching US$73,171 in October. This marks a 26% increase from the previous year, driven by a growing number of expatriate workers moving to the city. Luxury real estate prices have also jumped 89% over the past year, according to Knight Frank. The influx of newcomers, including bankers and wealthy Russians, is attributed to Dubai's favorable business environment and economic stability.

images.alt_text: The X2 is a two-seater eVTOLaircraft that is lifted by eight propellers.
Demand for space in the skyscraper and across Dubai is surging as the emirate attracts more wealth and expats due to its nimble response to the pandemic and relatively easy access to visas.

The Justice Department’s money laundering section asked Binance to voluntarily hand over messages from Zhao (above) and 12 other executives and partners on matters including the exchange’s detection of illegal transactions and recruitment of US customers.
Dubai is emerging as a favourite market for the ultra-rich, whom the government has actively courted by offering long-term “golden visas” and relaxing curbs on home ownership for foreigners.
Emaar will buy Dubai Holding’s 50 per cent stake in the Dubai Creek Harbour project and finance the deal equally in cash and shares, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum’s holding firm says.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher on Friday
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.5% to 6,743.7, its largest single-day jump since October 5, driven by financial, technology, and energy stocks following Wall Street's rebound from US inflation data. Financials advanced 1.8%, with the "big four" banks rising between 1.3% and 2.2%. Energy stocks jumped 3.7% and technology stocks rose 2.4%, while miners advanced 1.4% despite a slump in iron ore prices.

images.alt_text: epa10182902 Indicator boards are seen as people are reflected in the window of the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) in Sydney, Australia, 14 September 2022. The Australian stock market is on pace for its worst day since 14 June after falling in early trading in the wake of a worse-than-expected US inflation report.  EPA-EFE/STEVEN SAPHORE AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT
The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.04 per cent higher at 6,647.5.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Kuroda brushes aside chance of interest rate hike
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that raising interest rates now is not appropriate due to Japan's slow economic recovery compared to the US. He emphasized the need to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy to support the economy, which is emerging from the Covid-19 pandemic's effects.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SIA, Stamford Land
summary: Singtel's Australian unit Optus will not require customers to replace their passports after a recent cyberattack exposed passport numbers. Singapore Airlines is in confidential discussions to explore a potential transaction with Tata Group. Stamford Land expects a net loss for the six months ended Sep 30 due to foreign exchange losses and investment property losses.

site_title: Philippines central banker makes case for 75 basis-point rate hike
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) central bank in the Philippines is considering another 225 basis point interest rate hike to stabilize the peso and control inflation, which has been the worst in South-east Asia this year. Governor Felipe Medalla said a 75 basis point move could ease peso pressure and cool inflation, but may impact economic recovery. The move aims to halt the peso's slide and rein in price gains, which could erode President Ferdinand Marcos Jr's popularity.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos has pledged to prioritise energy security and lowering power costs, as imported oil fans inflation.
Commercial and residential buildings in the Central Business District in Makati City, the Philippines. The country posted a trade deficit of US$6 billion in August.

site_title: Singapore stocks open stronger on Friday; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened stronger on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 1.1% to 3,074.65. Gainers surpassed losers 126 to 22, driven by offshore and marine plays. Sembcorp Marine rose 2.5% and Marco Polo Marine inched up 2.7%. The market's gains echo overnight gains on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Singtel's Australian unit Optus said customers whose passport numbers were exposed in its recent cyberattack will not need to replace their passports.

site_title: China seen halting cash drainage as party congress kicks off
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, may refrain from draining cash via medium-term loans for the first time in three months, boosting market confidence during the Communist Party's leadership congress. Economists expect at least 500 billion yuan of one-year medium-term lending facility to be offered on October 17. This move aims to smooth out liquidity and support growth, particularly after the demand for loans recovered more than expected in September. The PBOC may also consider a 25-basis-point cut in the reserve requirement ratio in the remaining year to prioritize growth.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Wednesday, Sept. 21, 2022. China's current interest rates are "reasonable" and provide room for future policy action, the People’s Bank of China said, adding to expectations it may resume lowering rates in coming months. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Gold slides as US inflation data boosts rate-hike bet
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,660.10 per ounce as of Friday, Oct 14, amid a hotter-than-expected US inflation reading that solidified bets of another interest rate hike. This marks the third weekly decline for gold, which has lost 3.4% in the past week. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, aimed at combating soaring prices, have reduced gold's appeal as it yields no interest.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered as an inflation hedge, but rising interest rates reduce the appeal of bullion, which yields no interest.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after Wall Street bounces back
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following Wall Street's robust gains despite US inflation data exceeding expectations. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 1.59% to 26,654.15, while the Topix index rose 1.49% to 1,882.21. The gains were driven by investors' confidence in the US market, despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions and inflation.

site_title: Rising rates evoke fears of 1990s Asia crisis for emerging markets
summary: Emerging market governments face a surge in refinancing costs, reminiscent of the 1997 Asia debt crisis, as sovereign dollar bonds trade with a spread of 1000 basis points or more over US Treasuries. The surge in yields is forcing a painful realization of "original sin" - the reliance on foreign currency debt. Analysts warn that rising debt burdens are crowding out investment and reducing growth, with some countries at risk of default and restructuring. The fallout could have far bigger implications for the global economy, with developed markets also vulnerable to higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Central bankers across emerging Asia have relied on reserves to protect their currencies against a resurgent dollar as aggressive Federal Reserve policy tightening spurred flows back to the US.

site_title: Rents accelerate most since 1990, keeping US cost of living high
summary: US shelter costs accelerated 0.8% in September, the most since 1990, with rent and owners' equivalent rent posting record 6.7% annual gains. Housing costs make up about a third of consumer prices, contributing to the largest year-over-year increase since 1982. The Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes have sent mortgage rates to a 20-year high, slowing demand and expected to lead to a further retreat in asking prices, while experts warn that affordability issues will persist.

images.alt_text: The average for a 30-year, fixed loan climbed to 6.92 per cent from 6.66 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said in a statement on Thursday (Oct 13).

site_title: No replacement of passport needed for those affected in cyberattack, says Optus
summary: Optus, an Australian telco, has announced that customers affected by a recent cyberattack will not need to replace their passports, as previously agreed upon with the Australian government.
