The company's 2.1 million customers had their passport numbers exposed in the breach, but the government will now cover the cost of passport replacements. The Australian government has also provided advice to impacted customers on safeguarding against identity crime.

site_title: Apple teams with Goldman Sachs to offer savings accounts
summary: Apple is partnering with Goldman Sachs to offer high-yield savings accounts to users of its credit card, allowing them to earn interest on their cash back rewards. The partnership builds on the existing credit-card partnership between the two companies, with no fees, minimum deposits, or minimum balance requirements. This move aims to encourage users to store their cash with Goldman rather than Green Dot Bank, Apple's existing partner, as part of Apple's strategy to shift more financial services offerings in-house and drive growth through services.

images.alt_text: “We are working with our carrier partners in India to bring the best 5G experience to iPhone users as soon as network validation and testing for quality and performance is completed,” Apple said in a statement.

site_title: Hong Kong budget deficit set to triple from earlier estimates
summary: Hong Kong's budget deficit is expected to triple from earlier estimates, reaching HK$159 billion (5% of GDP) for the 2022-23 financial year. The shortfall is attributed to economic turmoil, including a pandemic brain drain, and rising global interest rates. The city's reserves are falling fast, putting future government spending at risk, and increasing the chance of more borrowing or tax hikes. The government is considering easing property taxes and visa restrictions to address the brain drain.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has been left reeling from almost four years of political turmoil and Covid border closures that largely cut the city off from the outside world.

site_title: EU, US eye level playing field for EU electric cars in US market
summary: EU and US officials are set to reach an agreement to grant EU electric car makers the same status as US companies in the US market, addressing EU concerns of discrimination under the US Inflation Reduction Act. The US law offers tax breaks for US-made electric cars but conditions support on US production. European Commission Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis is holding talks with US Trade Representative Katherine Tai and other officials. An agreement is expected to resolve EU concerns on a range of "green economy" goods, including batteries and renewable energy equipment.

images.alt_text: Carmakers are under pressure to make better use of resources as they navigate strained supply chains, sky-rocketing energy prices and geopolitical tensions that are limiting access to raw materials.

site_title: Renault sets up recycling unit with US$2.2b sales goal
summary: Renault is setting up a new recycling unit to capitalize on the growing demand for closed-loop recycling solutions in the automotive industry. The entity aims to generate over $3.2 billion in sales and a 10% operating margin by 2030. Renault plans to recycle car components and materials, including batteries, to bring in revenue and reduce reliance on scarce raw materials. The move is part of the company's efforts to address climate change and regulatory pressures, with CEO Luca de Meo stating the goal is to become the European leader in the automotive circular economy.

images.alt_text: Renault's chief executive officer Luca de Meo has pledged to give details of the planned carve-outs on Nov 8, when it updates its investors on its financial targets.

site_title: Posh ice cream, craft beer in vogue as Chinese downsize their love of luxury
summary: Chinese consumers are shifting away from luxury spending and towards "little luxuries" such as artisanal food and drinks, smart appliances, and premium beer. Economic uncertainty, including frequent lockdowns and a declining property sector, has led to a decrease in high-end spending. As a result, brands like Kweichow Moutai and Budweiser Brewing Asia-Pacific are seeing increased sales of their products, with some reporting sales four times higher than last year. Consumers are opting for smaller, more affordable indulgences, with many opting to "treat themselves" to dining out or specialty items.

images.alt_text: Sales in Europe, the United States and Japan were up sharply since the start of the year.
Though LVMH posted stellar third-quarter results, risks are growing even for such luxury giants.

site_title: MAS recentres mid-point of policy band again in bid to reduce imported inflation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has re-centered the mid-point of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) to its prevailing level, reducing imported inflation and curbing domestic cost pressure. The policy shift aims to dampen inflation in the near term and ensure medium-term price stability, providing a basis for sustainable economic growth. MAS expects core inflation to stay around 5% for the rest of 2022 and into early 2023, with headline inflation expected to average around 6% in 2022 and 5.5-6.5% in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) manages the exchange rate to ensure price stability.

site_title: Biden says prices “too high” as inflation rises before midterms
summary: US President Joe Biden said the latest inflation report shows progress but prices are still too high. The consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.4% last month, up 8.2% from the 12 months through September. Biden stated that fighting inflation remains his top priority, despite averaging 2% inflation over the last three months. The report comes ahead of the critical midterm elections in November, where Biden's Democratic Party faces questions on managing soaring prices of food, fuel, and other consumer products.

site_title: US: Dow gains 2.8% as stocks end rollercoaster day higher
summary: US stocks ended a rollercoaster day higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 2.8% to 30,038.72. The S&P 500 jumped 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 2.2% after disappointing US inflation data showed a 0.4% rise in September, twice the expected level. Early losses reversed after stocks refused to drop below key trading levels, with individual companies like Delta Air Lines and Netflix gaining due to robust travel demand and a new ad-supported streaming option, respectively.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 455.0 points, or 1.56 per cent, at the open to 28755.83.

site_title: Canada’s housing agency sees ‘modest’ recession with 15% price drop
summary: Canada's housing agency forecasts a 15% drop in housing prices by the second quarter, citing a "modest recession" by the end of the year. Despite a softening market, high borrowing costs will offset the benefit of lower prices, leaving housing affordability unchanged. The drop in housing prices is attributed to higher-than-expected interest rates and deteriorating economic and income conditions.

images.alt_text: Travellers, regardless of citizenship, will not have to submit health information through the ArriveCAN app or provide proof of vaccination from Oct 1.

site_title: Pontiac’s Regent hotel in Cuscaden Rd set to be rebranded Conrad: sources
summary: Pontiac Land Group is set to rebrand its 440-room Regent Singapore hotel in Cuscaden Road as Conrad, marking the second Conrad hotel in Singapore. Hilton will manage the property, and owners are expected to invest significantly in renovations to raise the hotel's standards. The move comes ahead of new hotel openings in the area, including Artyzen and The Singapore EDITION, and aims to increase exposure to the high-yielding luxe market.

images.alt_text: Visitor arrivals in September hit 752,305, from 728,744 in August, recording eight straight months of growth, according to data from the Singapore Tourism Board (STB).

site_title: UK finance minister says ‘not going anywhere’ amid talk of new U-turns
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng insisted he's safe in his job amid speculation of a potential U-turn on the government's economic policies. The government has been under pressure since unveiling a "mini-budget" that spooked financial markets and put pressure on households. Prime Minister Liz Truss is reportedly considering replacing Kwarteng, with potential replacements including former finance minister Rishi Sunak. The International Monetary Fund's Kristalina Georgieva warned the government to keep fiscal policy coherent and consistent to avoid jitters in the economy.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 4, 2022 Governor of the Bank of England Andrew Bailey addresses the media on the Monetary Policy Report at the Bank of England, in London. - The Bank of England may decide to extend its emergency bond buying, despite governor Andrew Bailey warning that the intervention will end this week, the Financial Times reported Wednesday, October 12. (Photo by Yui Mok / POOL / AFP)

The British pound hit a record low against the US greenback in late September (above).  The currency's crash followed Britain's Chancellor of Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng promise of more tax cuts on top of the biggest tax cuts in decades announced the week before.

epa10224652 British Prime Minister Liz Truss delivers her keynote speech at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Britain, 05 October 2022. Truss' first conference speech as party leader comes after a few turbulent weeks, with the mini budget causing turmoils in markets and uprisings in her party, only one month into her premiership.  EPA-EFE/ISABEL INFANTES

site_title: Singapore GDP beats expectations to grow 4.4% in Q3: flash estimates
summary: Singapore's economy beat expectations, growing 4.4% year-on-year in Q3, according to flash estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry. This surpasses private sector economists' expectations of 3.5% growth. The services industry drove the growth, while the manufacturing sector expanded 1.5% year-on-year, its slowest growth since Q2 2020. The construction sector also grew 7.8% year-on-year. However, economists warn that global headwinds, persistently high inflation, and rising interest rates will likely slow down growth in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: Private-sector economists are now expecting full-year gross domestic product (GDP) to grow 3.5 per cent, slightly worse than the 3.8 per cent projection they made in June.
Watchers do not expect Singapore to enter a technical recession in 2022, though they are not ruling the scenario out entirely.

Singapore's official full-year growth forecast has been narrowed to between 3 per cent and 4 per cent, with second quarter growth revised downwards to 4.4 per cent year on year, slower than the earlier advance estimate of 4.8 per cent.

site_title: US FCC set to ban approvals of new Huawei, ZTE equipment: document
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is set to ban approvals of new telecommunications equipment from China's Huawei Technologies and ZTE in the US due to national security concerns. The ban, which has been in the works since 2021, would prohibit the sale of new equipment without equipment authorisations. The FCC has designated these companies as national security threats, following a 2019 law aimed at protecting US communications networks. The move comes amid strained US-China relations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks snap six-day losing streak in turbulent session
summary: European stocks closed up 0.9% on Thursday, snapping a six-day losing streak, after hot US inflation data sparked bets of aggressive interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The Stoxx 600 index shuttled between positive and negative territory throughout the session. The data showed US consumer prices increased more than expected in September, bolstering the case for a fourth straight 75 basis point rate hike from the Fed next month.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.6 per cent to 6,788.85 points, one day before the end of the Bank of England’s (BOE) emergency bond-purchasing drive that sought to calm post-budget turmoil.

site_title: Netflix ad-supported plan to launch in November at US$7 a month
summary: Netflix plans to launch an ad-supported plan in November for $7/month in the US, targeting new subscribers who left the service in the first half of the year. The "Basic with Ads" plan will cost $6.99 and have limited advertising, preserving the cinematic experience for newly released films. The plan will roll out in 12 countries, including the US, Brazil, and Japan, with 4-5 minutes of ads per hour.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage at the Netflix booth is seen on the convention floor at Comic-Con International in San Diego, California, U.S., July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Bing Guan/File Photo
Netflix currently has 31 mobile games in its catalogue, which are free of ads and in-app purchases but only available to subscribers.

site_title: Merkel says no regrets over Germany's Russia gas deals
summary: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she has no regrets over Germany's reliance on Russian gas during her 16-year tenure, citing the need to fill an energy gap as the country phased out nuclear energy. Merkel acknowledged that Germany's current dependence on Russian energy is a vulnerability, but argued that her decisions were rational at the time, particularly given Russia's reliability as an energy supplier.

images.alt_text: In her first major interview since stepping down six months ago, former German chancellor Angela Merkel insisted she had not been naive in her dealings with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The UN refugee agency highlighted how Merkel had called on her fellow Germans to reject divisive nationalism, urging them instead to be “compassionate and open-minded”.
Surging gas prices and Moscow’s move to squeeze supplies to Europe have already prompted a series of government bailouts and rescue loans for energy firms.

site_title: IMF urges most Asian central banks to tighten policy further
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged most Asian central banks to tighten monetary policy further due to rising inflation and currency depreciation. The IMF cites US monetary tightening as a major factor, which has led to widening interest rate differentials and increased import costs. Exceptions include China and Japan, where economic recovery has been weaker. The IMF warns that large currency depreciations and rising interest rates could trigger financial stress in countries with high debt, particularly those in Asia.

images.alt_text: Among the indicators to gauge stress in the world economy is global demand for US dollars, which has soared as investors seek shelter in the US currency from volatile asset markets.
Commercial and residential buildings in Hong Kong. The amount of vacant top-tier office space has more than doubled in Hong Kong over the last three years
US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen walks to a meeting between G20 finance ministers and central bank governors at the 2022 IMF/World Bank annual meeting in Washington, DC on Oct 13, 2022,

site_title: Big Tech’s hiring freeze unlocks rich talent pool for US startups
summary: US tech startups are benefiting from Big Tech's hiring freezes, luring experienced engineers and project managers with rich pay packages. A survey found 40% of executives boosted hiring plans in the first half of 2022, with companies like Stack Overflow and X1 Card doubling their headcounts. This trend comes despite a slowdown in startup funding, with venture capital funding falling by nearly a third. Companies with viable products are taking advantage of a softening tech hiring market to make key hires.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US surge to 20-year high, reaching 6.92%
summary: Mortgage rates in the US have surged to a 20-year high, reaching 6.92% as of October 13, according to Freddie Mac. This marks a significant increase from the previous week's rate of 6.66%. The surge is attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to curb inflation, which has led to higher borrowing costs and reduced housing demand. The average monthly payment on a $300,000 mortgage has increased by $679, affecting both homebuyers and refinancers.

site_title: Ikea reports record sales as price hikes offset weakening consumer confidence
summary: Ikea reported record sales of 44.6 billion euros (S$62.2 billion) in the 12 months through August, growing 6.5% from the previous year, despite weakening consumer confidence and supply chain issues. Price hikes offset the decline, with sales volumes not increasing. Ingka Group, which owns the majority of Ikea stores, also reported 5.6% sales growth, with sales improving in most markets and product availability increasing. The company remains cautious, citing a tough winter ahead and ongoing impact from the pandemic and energy crisis.

site_title: Britain's NatWest closes another 43 branches as banks cut costs
summary: NatWest is closing 43 branches in Britain, the latest move by lenders to cut costs and adapt to customers shifting to mobile and online banking. The closures, set to occur between January and March, follow previous branch closures in February. The bank stated that most customers prefer mobile and online banking due to its speed and convenience. NatWest will invest in alternative services to replace the closed branches, following tougher guidance from the Financial Conduct Authority on branch closures.

site_title: Oil prices rise 2% on low diesel stocks ahead of winter
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, driven by low diesel inventory ahead of winter. Brent crude futures for December delivery increased by 2.29% to $94.57 a barrel, while US crude rose 2.1% to $89.11 per barrel. The price gain reversed early losses on high stocks of crude and petrol, as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The increase is expected to be sustained as winter approaches.

images.alt_text: “The relentless deterioration of the economy and higher prices sparked by an Opec+ plan to cut supply are slowing world oil demand,” IEA said.

President Joe Biden said fighting inflation is his top priority after spending much of the past two years trying - with modest success - to curtail price surges driven by an economy emerging from Covid lockdowns and oil-rich Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Yields for 6 and 12-month T-Bills rise as high as 3.77% in October auction
summary: Yields for Singapore's 6-month and 12-month T-Bills rose to 3.07% and 3.35% per annum, respectively, in the latest auction, driven by strong demand. The 12-month T-bill's cut-off yield reached 3.77%, up from 3.32% previously. The increases follow rising interest rates, impacting fixed-income products.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates are making bonds an interesting alternative for investors seeking attractive returns.
Singapore Savings Bonds have gotten higher interest from investors amid a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Recession risk raises urgency to grant gig workers CPF, full benefits
summary: Singapore is reviewing ways to better safeguard gig workers, who are vulnerable to the rising cost of living and lack job and benefits protections. The government is considering mandatory CPF contributions, expansion of work injury compensation, and unionization for these workers. Some experts expect a definition of gig workers as employees to be debated, with a similar proposal in the US aiming to grant gig workers full benefits and protections. The move is seen as a necessary step to protect the vulnerable workers, despite potential risks to the gig economy and Singapore's business-friendly image.

images.alt_text: As the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers prepare their recommendations, it is clear that platform workers would want one of their own as their representative to both companies and authorities.

site_title: US consumer prices up more than expected in September; weekly jobless claims rise
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in September, exceeding expectations, with underlying inflation pressures remaining high. The annual CPI increased 8.2% from the same period last year, the highest since 1981. The Federal Reserve is expected to deliver a fourth 75-basis points interest rate hike in October to combat inflation. Meanwhile, weekly jobless claims rose, maintaining a tight labor market with 1.7 job openings for every unemployed person.

images.alt_text: Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
Employers, many still short-staffed, continue to hire at a solid pace.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2022, a "We Are Hiring" sign is posted in front of a restaurant in Los Angeles. - US employers slowed the pace of hiring in August after the surprising surge in the prior month and the jobless rate edged up, the government reported on September 2, 2022. Even with the slowing pace, the job gains bring employment above the pre-pandemic level, the Labor Department said. US employment increased by 315,000 jobs last month, the report said, which was in line with what economists were expecting after the 526,000 hires in July. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)
While there have been reports of some companies laying off workers, claims have remained at the lower end of their 168,000-252,000 range for this year.

site_title: Pound and gilts surge as UK officials mull U-turn on tax cuts
summary: The British pound surged 1.8% to a record high against the US dollar after UK officials reportedly considered a U-turn on sweeping tax cuts proposed by Prime Minister Liz Truss. The yield on 30-year bonds dropped 46 basis points, and traders pared bets on the Bank of England's interest rate hike in November. The FTSE 100 Index rose 0.6%. A potential reversal of the tax cuts has lifted market confidence, with some analysts saying it may mark a "fundamental basis" for traders to turn bullish on the pound.

site_title: SIA, Tata in talks to potentially integrate Vistara and Air India
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is in confidential talks with Tata Group to explore a potential transaction involving Vistara and Air India. SIA holds a 49% stake in Vistara, while Tata holds 51%. The discussions aim to deepen the existing partnership and may include a potential integration of Vistara and Air India. A definitive deal has not been agreed upon, and regulatory approvals would be required. This move aligns with SIA's multi-hub strategy, gaining access to India's growing aviation sector.

images.alt_text: Now that Singapore and most other countries around the world have opened again for quarantine-free travel, SIA was able to increase traffic to more than 1 million passengers in April, the most since the pandemic began.

site_title: Hot inflation torches bears in a stock reversal for the ages
summary: US stocks experienced a historic reversal, with the S&P 500 wiping out a 2.4% loss and closing 2.6% higher, marking the first time since July that it reversed a decline of 2%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 1,400 points from its low. The reversal was attributed to various factors, including chart support, options hedgers, and early results from the earnings season. Short sellers were forced to cover their positions, fueling the gains, but market strategist Matt Maley remains pessimistic, citing that the market is not cheap and earnings are likely to fall in the coming weeks and months.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 30,038.72 on Thursday, up 2.8 per cent and nearly 1,400 points above its session low point.

site_title: Global chips are down: AEM, UMS and other Singapore tech stocks join rout
summary: Singapore's tech manufacturing stocks plummeted on Thursday, with AEM and UMS leading the decline. The negative sentiment is attributed to weaker consumer demand and macroeconomic headwinds, as chipmakers worldwide experience lower valuations. AEM sank to a two-year low, while UMS lost 8.5% during the afternoon trading session. The Straits Times Index also fell 1.3%, with Venture Corporation being the least affected. The US's recent export controls on China for advanced semiconductor equipment have added to the uncertainty and poor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect demand to slow as consumers tighten their wallets going amid a weaker macroeconomic environment.

The US is seeking to ensure that Chinese companies don’t transfer technology to the country’s military and that chipmakers in China don’t develop the capability to make advanced semiconductors themselves.
The US planned to review licences for non-Chinese factories in China hit by the new restrictions on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Sterling volatile ahead of BOE deadline, fragile yen tests 1998 low
summary: Sterling rose 0.44% to $1.1147 ahead of the Bank of England's (BOE) deadline to end an emergency bond-buying program. This move came after the BOE signaled it was prepared to extend the program if market conditions demanded it. Meanwhile, the yen fell near a 24-year low due to market volatility, and investors await US inflation data for possible clues on interest rate hikes.

site_title: 5.3 billion cell phones to become waste this year: report
summary: Over 5 billion cell phones, estimated to be around 31% of the 16 billion global mobile phones, are expected to be discarded or stashed away this year, contributing to significant health and environmental harm due to the hazardous materials they contain. Experts warn that if these devices are not recycled, the valuable metals like gold, copper, and silver will be mined in countries like China or Congo, highlighting the need for increased recycling and legislation to address the issue of electronic waste.

images.alt_text: This year’s Congress will highlight the human impact on the environment with targets to promote economic growth, increase efficiency in production and consumption, sustainably manage waste and resources, and to take action to tackle climate change.
Google’s new smartphones are available in 17 markets, including France, Germany, some of the Nordics and the UK in Europe alongside Japan, India, Singapore and Taiwan in Asia.
Pixel Watch is equipped with an on-board app store, Google Wallet for mobile payments and Fitbit health sensors and workout services.
Octopus currently works with 60,000 waste collectors and plans to have a total of 100,000 on board by 2024.

site_title: Pfizer says updated booster protects against Omicron subvariants
summary: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech reported that their Omicron-adapted Covid-19 vaccine booster generated a strong immune response against the BA.4/BA.5 subvariants of Omicron. Data from a trial in adult patients showed a substantial increase in neutralizing antibody levels against the variants. The preliminary results suggest that the bivalent vaccine may provide better protection against Omicron subvariants than the original vaccine, and the companies are seeking US authorization for this updated booster.

site_title: Pinterest leaves peers in the dust with 34% rally
summary: Pinterest Inc has seen a 34% rally in shares from a two-year low in mid-June, outperforming peers Facebook and Snapchat. The platform's reliance on search-driven advertising has contributed to its growth, as it targets ads based on user searches rather than activity. Pinterest's cash-flow-positive business and double-digit growth year-over-year have made it a "disruptive asset with incredibly high margins." Despite a 37% decline in shares this year, Pinterest is still seen as a potential takeover target, with some analysts predicting a deal could become more likely if the company reports weak Q3 results.

images.alt_text: The disclosure came as Pinterest reported a lower-than-expected profit due to higher costs and users spending less time on the digital pin-board platform.
Like its peers, Pinterest posted strong user growth in the early months of the pandemic as home-bound consumers sought projects to keep themselves entertained.
As digital advertising enters a period of transformation, the challengers to the duopoly of google and Meta look well-placed to increase their gains.

US social-media companies saw nearly US$80 billion wiped off their stock-market values Friday(Jul 22), after disappointing revenue from Snap and a lackluster report from Twitter raised concerns about the outlook for online advertising.

site_title: Ryanair slashes Berlin winter schedule, blaming high airport fees
summary: Ryanair is slashing its winter schedule at Berlin airport by 40% due to high airport fees, citing unjustified increases in charges. The airline will operate 19 fewer routes and 230 fewer weekly flights in and out of the airport compared to 2019. CEO Michael O'Leary stated that higher airport costs make it more attractive to switch aircraft to lower-cost alternatives in regional Germany and Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Passengers alight from a Ryanair aircraft at Ferenc Liszt International Airport in Budapest, Hungary, August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Bernadett Szabo/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street opens sharply lower after hot inflation data
summary: US stocks plummeted sharply at the open on October 13, with the Dow Jones falling 455 points (1.56%) to 28,755.83, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 285.3 points (2.74%) to 10,131.82. The decline came after data showed a bigger-than-expected rise in consumer prices, fueling expectations of continued Federal Reserve rate hikes. The S&P 500 fell 56.7 points (1.58%) to 3,520.37, amidst concerns over US-EU trade tensions and a slowdown in global economic growth.

site_title: Glum Hong Kong dealmakers pin hopes on China Congress to revive economy, IPOs
summary: Hong Kong dealmakers are pinning hopes on China's 20th Party Congress to revive the city's economy and IPO market, which has fallen to a nine-year low due to tumbling Chinese markets and a tightening regulatory environment. A shift in focus towards business and economic issues could stimulate demand and prop up confidence. Despite this, economists doubt policymakers will offer concrete signals of a relaxation of zero Covid policies or a roadmap for border reopening, with policy certainty likely to come after China's annual two sessions in March.

images.alt_text: Even with an extra US$4 billion in IPO proceeds, Hong Kong’s share of the Asia total would still be the smallest since 1999.

The HKEX is “studying how best to create a listing chapter to cater to the funding needs of large-scale advanced technology companies that are at an early stage of product commercialisation,” a spokesperson said in an email statement.
The afternoon session will begin on time at 1.00 pm in accordance to its rules.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended the day lower, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.21 points or 0.52% to 1,373.36. The index saw a significant decline, with a volume of 2.03 billion lots worth RM1.692 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 521 to 321.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losing streak to close at 19-month low; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% to close at 3,040.45, its lowest level since March 2021, extending a six-day losing streak. Local tech manufacturers, including AEM Holdings and UMS Holdings, were among the biggest losers due to reports of Intel's planned job cuts. The market decline mirrored losses across regional indices, with investors awaiting US inflation data for further guidance.

images.alt_text: Intel is facing a steep decline in demand for PC processors, its main business, and has struggled to win back market share lost to rivals like AMD.

AEM, which derives over 60 per cent of its group revenue from Intel, could ultimately be affected by any further weakness or drop in capital expenditures from the US-based chipmaker, DBS said in a report on Thursday.
Chipmakers around the world have already begun to trade at significantly lower valuations, and that negative sentiment is spreading to Singapore’s shores.

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo-TBS joint venture targets electric scooter production in 2024
summary: Indonesia's joint venture, Electrum, between GoTo Group and TBS Energi, aims to produce electric scooters in 2024. The company, which currently provides services like battery swapping and leasing, will set aside US$350 million of its own funds for the venture. TBS Energi, a coal miner, plans to stop mining coal in five years and reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2030, with a majority of its revenue coming from non-coal sources. The company will also invest in renewable energy projects.

site_title: UK PM faces fresh political woes after difficult MPs meeting
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss faces fresh political woes after a prominent Conservative party insider said some of her MPs are considering replacing her with two former rivals, including Rishi Sunak and Boris Johnson. The move comes amid growing concerns over the government's handling of the cost-of-living crisis and a recent YouGov poll that gave the main opposition Labour party a huge lead. Truss has already enjoyed the shortest honeymoon period of any British leader in living memory, and her government's plans to slash government department budgets have sparked fears of a return to austerity policies.

images.alt_text: Asked if she remained committed to an earlier pledge to maintain spending levels,Truss replied: “Absolutely, absolutely."

site_title: Stamford Land expects to record H1 net loss on FX, fair value loss
summary: Stamford Land Corporation expects to record a net loss for the six months ended Sep 30, 2022, primarily due to foreign exchange losses and fair value loss on its London investment property. The company attributed this to FX and fair value loss. Despite this, Stamford Land expects to record a gain on the disposal of two properties in Sydney and Auckland in its unaudited consolidated management accounts for the six months ended Mar 31, 2023.

site_title: Potato Head shows how to do good while having a good time
summary: Indonesian entrepreneur Ronald Akili has transformed his hospitality firm, Potato Head, into a sustainability-led business after a surfing incident prompted him to pivot his mission. Akili's company, which started in 2010, has made significant progress in reducing waste, from nearly 70% landfill waste a decade ago to 5% currently. Potato Head incorporates sustainable design elements, such as hand-pressed bricks, recycled materials, and upcycled waste, to promote the beauty of sustainability. Akili emphasizes the importance of making progress, not perfection, and aims to achieve "zero waste" through small daily changes.

images.alt_text: Innsbruck’s Old Town (Alstadt) boasts cobbled-stone lanes and ancient architecture such as the Golden Roof, completed in 1500 for Emperor Maximilian’s wedding.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's tech manufacturing stocks plummeted, mirroring a global decline in chipmakers worldwide. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at a 19-month low, down 1.4%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) named Gillian Tan as its new chief sustainability officer. Meanwhile, a freehold sea-fronting property, Meyer Park, was relaunched for collective sale at the unchanged reserve price of S$420 million. The Asia-Pacific region has the second-highest level of climate-related financial disclosures, according to a report.

site_title: Opec+ oil supply cuts could tip world into recession, IEA says
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that Opec+ oil supply cuts could push the global economy into recession due to higher prices and slowing world oil demand. The cuts, which will reduce output by around 1 million barrels per day, have already driven up prices and are expected to have a significant impact on the global economy. The IEA's warning highlights a rift with Saudi Arabia, the world's top oil exporter, and raises concerns about the potential for further disruptions to Russian oil flows and the impact on global inflation and costs of living.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration accused the country and its de facto leader Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, of ignoring US requests not to go ahead with the cut.

site_title: Singapore Biennale 2022: Challenges abound
summary: The seventh Singapore Biennale, opening on Oct 16, features works by over 50 artists across 13 locations, including two offshore islands. The biennale's concept is complex, with a focus on community consciousness and global perspectives, but it lacks visual spectacle, making it challenging for a layperson. Notable works include Haegue Yang's sonic sculptures, Pierre Huyghe and Philipe Parreno's virtual avatar project, and Joo Jae-hwan's bricolage paintings. The biennale's curated team, comprising four women from diverse backgrounds, has chosen the name "Natasha," which has sparked controversy due to its Russian origins.

images.alt_text: (From left)  August Hatecke, Co-Head Global Wealth Management Asia Pacific, Country Head UBS Singapore at UBS; ART SG fair director Shuyin Yang and ART SG co-founder Magnus Renfrew pose before a UBS-commissioned painting by Hilmi Johandi.
Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.
In Venice, minimalist Singapore show speaks volumes

site_title: BA owner IAG summer profit beats expectations, no weakness in forward bookings
summary: IAG, the owner of British Airways, reported better-than-expected summer profits due to strong demand and pricing. The company expects pre-exceptional operating profit to be around 1.2 billion euros for the three months ended September 30. IAG is confident in future demand, contradicting the decline in European airline stocks over concerns about rising household bills affecting travel appetite. The company's shares rose up to 10% following the announcement, beating expectations.

site_title: Echoes of a world war in wines from the early 1940s
summary: A recent dinner in Connecticut featured wines produced during World War II, offering a unique opportunity to taste and experience history. The event showcased French wines, including Bordeaux and Burgundy, as well as wines from Spain and California, all produced under challenging wartime conditions. The wines, some over 80 years old, were remarkably well-preserved and showcased their complexity and character. The event highlighted the courage and ingenuity of French winemakers who continued to produce wine despite Nazi occupation and scarcity of resources. The experience was described as "miraculous" and served as a poignant reminder of the power of wine to bring people together and evoke emotions.

images.alt_text: Fred Franzia built a cult following with his Trader Joe's wine, but it comes at a cost to the wine business.

site_title: UBS’s top Asia investment banker retires, Takahashi succeeds
summary: UBS Group's Asia-Pacific investment bank head, David Chin, has resigned, effective November 1, to be succeeded by Taichi Takahashi, the region's head of global markets. Chin's retirement comes amid increased geopolitical tension between the US and China, and a sharp slowdown in the world's second-largest economy, which has led to a 57% decline in global investment banking revenue at UBS in the second quarter. The move follows Chin's earlier step aside as country head of UBS's China business, where revenue more than doubled to $1 billion in 2021.

site_title: TSMC cuts capital spending 10% in a warning for tech sector
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) cut its 2022 capital spending target by 10% to US$36 billion, signaling a broader-than-anticipated downturn in the tech sector. The move comes as the US imposes sweeping restrictions on doing business with China, affecting global semiconductor industry. TSMC's shares have tanked, and the company projects revenue of US$19.9-20.7 billion in the December quarter, with about 5-8% of its total revenue restricted due to US curbs. Despite this, TSMC is betting on its massive size and technology to navigate challenges.

images.alt_text: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) headquarters in Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Wednesday, Oct. 12, 2022. Taiwan's flagship semiconductor industry will not need to be destroyed in a Chinese invasion, the island’s security chief said, amid growing US concerns that Beijing could move to forcibly acquire the crucial Taiwanese chip technology. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg

site_title: Lack of sustainability practices to become increasingly costly for businesses
summary: Businesses in the Asean region will face increased costs due to the European Union's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), set to be introduced in 2023. To mitigate these costs, companies are embracing sustainable practices, finding opportunities to reduce costs while improving their reputation. A new tool, the UOB Sustainability Compass, was launched to guide small and medium-sized enterprises in their sustainability journeys, providing customized reports and financing solutions. As the deadline approaches, businesses will need to adopt digitalization and sustainable practices to stay competitive, with one in five Asean exports to the EU expected to be impacted.

images.alt_text: There is growing acceptance among businesses that sustainability, as manifested in environmental, social and corporate governance factors, has to be at the top of management’s priorities.

site_title: Fifa and Indonesian football body form taskforce after fatal stampede
summary: Indonesian Football Association (PSSI) and FIFA form a joint taskforce to improve crowd control and safety measures following a deadly soccer stampede that killed over 130 people at the Kanjuruhan Stadium in East Java on October 1. The stampede was triggered by the firing of tear gas by police inside the stadium, a measure prohibited by FIFA. The taskforce aims to overhaul soccer safety standards in Indonesia and implement measures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

images.alt_text: In one of the world’s worst soccer disasters, hundreds of fans were crushed as they tried to flee the overpacked stadium in Indonesia’s East Java region on Saturday.
People attend a memorial remembering victims of the football match riot and stampede in Denpasar, Bali, Indonesia on Oct 2, 2022.
Indonesia announced that at least 130 people were killed and 180 others were injured after Indonesian soccer fans entered the pitch causing panic and stampede on Oct 1.

site_title: India’s RBI asks banks to stop building positions in offshore market
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has asked local banks to stop building positions in the non-deliverable forward market, a move aimed at arresting the rupee's slide. This move could lead to offshore volatility spilling into local markets. The RBI's decision is a step back from its 2020 policy, which allowed Indian banks to trade in the NDF segment, giving the RBI more control. The central bank is concerned that increased trading in the segment is forcing it to intervene through US dollar sales, potentially nullifying its intervention efforts.

site_title: Friday deadline for BOE aid looms as Kwarteng scapegoats its governor
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is set to end its £65 billion emergency bond-buying program on Friday, which has sparked concerns that pension funds may not have unwound their positions in time. Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng is under pressure to make the BOE governor, Andrew Bailey, a scapegoat for the impending market chaos. The BOE has urged pension funds to close their positions, but some experts fear that the funds may not have raised the necessary cash, potentially leading to further market turmoil and calls for a U-turn on the government's tax cuts and public spending reductions.

images.alt_text: Prices for index-linked gilts, which offer holders protection against inflation, rose modestly on Wednesday, avoiding the slump afflicting conventional gilts.

site_title: High demand for skills in 5G, cloud, AI, based on tech Jobs Transformation Map
summary: Singapore's Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) forecasts high demand for workers skilled in emerging tech trends such as 5G, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence (AI) in the next three to five years. The JTM, launched by Communications and Information Minister Josephine Teo, aims to guide employers in providing necessary training or reskilling for workers to take on evolving job roles. Skills in software engineering, cloud, mobility, AI, and analytics are expected to be in high demand.

images.alt_text: Half of all logistics sector jobs to change or be displaced with Industry 4.0
Jobs Transformation Map launched for wholesale trade sector
S$10m for jobs transformation maps to study impact of tech on jobs: Josephine Teo

site_title: China’s digital currency passes 100b yuan in spending: PBOC
summary: China's central bank digital currency, e-CNY, has surpassed 100 billion yuan (S$20 billion) in spending, with 360 million transactions in pilot areas in 15 provinces and municipalities as of August 31. The People's Bank of China reported that over 5.6 million merchants now accept e-CNY payments. This marks a significant milestone in China's development of central bank digital currencies, putting the country at the forefront of the global race.

images.alt_text: China is well advanced with real-life trials of an e-yuan.
The RBA is seeking submissions from industry participants ranging from financial institutions, fintech, public sector agencies and technology providers.

site_title: Driving Asian food security amid Covid, climate change and conflict
summary: Asia is home to the world's most hungry people, with 425 million people affected by hunger, up from 418 million in 2021 and 340 million in 2019. The region is also vulnerable to Covid-19, conflict, and climate change, which are exacerbating food insecurity. Climate change is particularly devastating to smallholder farmers, with rising temperatures, droughts, and floods affecting yields, livelihoods, and food security. To address these challenges, the private sector, governments, and civil society must work together to develop and share innovative agricultural technologies and promote sustainable food systems.

images.alt_text: Farmer collects rice that has been dried for storage along the sidewalk in Kim Son, Ninh Binh province, Vietnam; June 2022. A perfect storm of factors is putting a huge strain on food systems.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen called on G20 countries to increase financial aid to initiatives such as the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program, to which Washington just gave US$155 million, and to avoid all food export restrictions.

site_title: The last days of Judy Garland
summary: Judy Garland, a Hollywood star, died at 47 due to an accidental drug overdose six months after her final London stage performance. A new bio-play, End Of The Rainbow, depicts her tragic life, including her struggles with addiction and the pressures of fame. Actress Mina Kaye shines as Garland, but the play's dark script and limited comic relief hold it back from delivering its emotional potential. The production, which ran from October 2022 to October 2023, explores Garland's final series of concerts in London, where she was broken and desperate.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Writers Festival, headed by Pooja Nansi (centre), returns post-pandemic more ambitious than ever. This year's festival stretches over 3 weekends and has more than 200 in-person programmes.
Shen the T-Rex will be the first Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton to be offered at a Christie's auction in Asia.

site_title: Google allows Donald Trump’s Truth Social in Play Store
summary: Google has allowed Donald Trump's Truth Social app into its Play Store for Android devices after the app's developer, Trump Media and Technology Group, agreed to update its content moderation policies. The app, which Trump launched after being banned from Twitter, had previously been kept out of the store due to its lack of moderation tools. Truth Social has since been updated to comply with Google's policies, including effective systems for reporting and removing unwanted content and blocking abusers.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump accused CNN of waging a campaign of “libel and slander” against him because it “fears” he will run for president again in 2024.
Wesley Hunt (left), a Republican who is likely to win his House race, during a campaign event in Cibolo, Texas., April 13, 2022.

site_title: Creating spaces for discerning jet-setters
summary: Belgian designer Jean-Michel Gathy is the go-to luxury hotel and resort architect, with 40 years of experience and a portfolio of high-end projects. His clients include Aman, One&Only, Four Seasons, and Park Hyatt. Gathy credits three men for his success: Hans Jenni, Adrian Zecha, and Sol Kerzner. He credits luck and opportunity for his career, but passion drives him. Gathy's definition of luxury is comfort, and he prioritizes both aesthetics and service in his designs. He is selective about projects, focusing on locations, hotel operators, and his own creative vision.

images.alt_text: Aman New York, better known as the Crown Building, opened last month and features 83 hotel suites as well as residences. Its luxury spa has an indoor swimming pool surrounded by fire pits. It features 22 private residences, its website shows.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.89% on October 13, 2022, as global markets dropped ahead of US inflation data, sparking fears of further interest rate hikes that could lead to a recession. The Hang Seng Index fell to 16,389.11, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.30%. The decline follows a losing streak for Hong Kong stocks, with the Shanghai Composite Index also falling 0.30% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gaining 0.25%.

site_title: Asia's top film festival roots for regional talent
summary: The Busan International Film Festival is showcasing a diverse range of Asian films vying for the New Currents award, which honors first- or second-time Asian directors. Ten films from 10 countries, including South Korea, Singapore, Vietnam, Japan, Thailand, and India, are in competition for the $60,000 prize. The festival aims to nurture regional filmmakers, with a focus on supporting Asian talent, and has selected films that explore universal themes such as identity, family, and social issues. The winners will be announced at the closing ceremony on Friday.

images.alt_text: Top Korean actors and Asian stars are set to attend the Busan International Film Festival, which opened with a red carpet event and will run until Oct 14.
Of the more than 50 Bollywood films released in the past year – fewer than normal because of the pandemic – just one-fifth have met or surpassed revenue targets.

site_title: New Zealand houses take longer to sell as rates put off buyers
summary: New Zealand houses are taking longer to sell due to rising interest rates, which are deterring buyers. The median time to sell a house in September was 47 days, the highest in over a decade. House sales fell below 16,000 in the three months through June, and prices have dropped by 12.6% from their peak in November 2021. Experts expect further price declines, with a peak-to-trough fall of 17% predicted, as property owners adjust to lower prices and buyers wait for more favorable market conditions.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s economy rebounded strongly from sharp slowdowns when Covid-19 outbreaks stalled activity over the past year.
Prices in Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, fell 4 per cent in the three-month period to an average of NZ$1.39 million (S$1.1 million).

site_title: China’s September exports likely cooled further on weakening global demand: poll
summary: China's export growth is expected to have slowed further in September, with outbound shipments likely rising 4.1% from a year earlier, according to a Reuters poll of 30 economists. The slowdown is attributed to weakening global demand due to surging inflation, higher interest rates, and the Ukraine war. This is the latest evidence of a turning point in foreign demand, potentially leading to a double-digit contraction in Chinese exports.

images.alt_text: Home sales and prices remain sluggish amid an economic slowdown and Covid Zero restraints.
TOPSHOT - People stand in front of images of Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Museum of the Communist Party of China in Beijing on September 4, 2022. (Photo by Noel Celis / AFP)

Behind the excellent balance sheet of China's central government is a vast array of contingent liabilities. Beijing thus prioritises the strength of its own balance sheet, as during a crisis, any or all of those borrowers could requite a bailout.

site_title: Chinese local governments buying houses to aid property sector
summary: Chinese local governments are buying homes in bulk to prop up the real estate market, with cities like Suzhou, Jinan, and Huzhou purchasing thousands of units. The city government of Suzhou plans to buy about 10,000 new units, while Jinan city proposes to rent out 3,000 units. State-owned companies are also being encouraged to buy houses from struggling developers. These efforts follow a series of mortgage-rate cuts and relaxation measures, but the sector remains weak, with residential transactions plummeting 38% in 20 major cities.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower after US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on October 13, 2022, as US shares eased ahead of inflation data release. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.60% to 26,237.42, and the Topix index dropped 0.77% to 1,854.61. This follows a mixed day on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff concerns. The US inflation data release is expected to impact market sentiment, but for now, Tokyo stocks are down, marking a lower close.

site_title: Worries over global financial stability mount as central banks tighten policy
summary: Global financial stability is under threat as central banks tighten monetary policy to combat inflation, sparking worries of contagion and financial instability. Global demand for US dollars has surged as investors seek shelter in the US currency, while risk aversion in credit markets and corporate debt shows increasing financial stress. The IMF has warned of "disorderly asset repricings" and "financial market contagions," and experts predict a looming recession. Despite reassurances from US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, few believe the gyrations in global markets will subside soon, with volatility in stocks and Treasuries rising ahead of inflation data.

site_title: MAS names new head of expanded sustainability group
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has appointed Gillian Tan as its new Chief Sustainability Officer, effective October 17. Tan will lead an expanded sustainability group to coordinate MAS's various initiatives, enhance its climate change and sustainability ambitions, and engage with external stakeholders. She replaces Dr. Darian McBain, who is leaving MAS in December. Tan's appointment aims to strengthen MAS's sustainability work and contribute to Singapore's growth as a sustainable finance hub.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: Europe's stocks dropped 0.6-0.5% at open on Oct 13, 2022, as markets mirrored Asian losses ahead of US inflation data. London's FTSE 100 index fell to 6,788.85 points, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices lost 0.3-0.5%. The Bank of England's emergency bond-purchasing drive ends on Friday, aiming to calm post-budget turmoil. US inflation data will determine the pace of Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

site_title: 65% of Apac institutional investors plan to raise ESG allocation in next 2 years; figure over 80% in Europe, US: PwC report
summary: Institutional investors in the Asia-Pacific region plan to increase their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) allocations, with 65% of investors in the region set to raise ESG AUM over the next two years. This figure is lower than the global average, but higher than those in the US, where 81% of investors plan to increase ESG AUM. ESG assets under management in the Asia-Pacific are expected to more than triple to $3.3 trillion by 2026, driven by a growing willingness of investors to pay higher fees for ESG performance, with 72% of Asian-Pacific investors willing to do so.

images.alt_text: Coal generates around half of the country’s electricity and produces 70 per cent of carbon emissions from its power sector.
Not just to please investors, transition plans should be part of a company’s overall strategy: climate bonds panel

site_title: Raffles Family Office rolls out integrated digital-asset platform
summary: Raffles Family Office (RFO) has launched Revo, a digital asset platform that hosts both digital and fiat-currency assets, aiming to facilitate investment and custody services for wealthy families. The platform is a partnership with Huobi Technology Holdings and is expected to support a smooth transition from traditional to digital assets as central banks issue their own digital stablecoin-equivalents. A study by Accenture found that three-quarters of wealthy investors are interested in digital assets, with over half already investing in them.

images.alt_text: Blockchain.com, which was valued at US$14 billion in March views Singapore as an attractive location to grow its institutional customers and team.
The 238-year-old bank won the approval of New York’s financial regulator earlier this fall and is the first of the eight systemically important US banks to store digital currencies.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Q&M Dental to ‘add’, says valuation now ‘attractive’
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded its rating on Q&M Dental Group to "add" from "hold", citing the group's attractive valuation and the potential for revenue growth from a recent tender win. The win for the medical technology subsidiary Acumen Diagnostics to operate a joint testing and vaccination centre is expected to alleviate short-term woes and lift profitability. CGS-CIMB maintains a target price of S$0.44, representing a 33.3% potential upside. The research house believes the stock's valuation is undervalued and near its all-time low.

images.alt_text: The 15-month contract ends on Dec 31, 2023 and is estimated to be worth at least S$3.6 million.
Q&M unit Acumen Diagnostics to explore Nasdaq listing
Q&M Dental's Q4 earnings fall 47% on higher costs, expenses

site_title: Dress up in style with Tudor
summary: Tudor has unveiled the Black Bay GMT S&G, a two-tone timepiece featuring a stainless steel case, brown and black bezel, and a steel and yellow gold bracelet. The watch boasts a Tudor-developed self-winding movement, three time zones, and a "24-hour" hand, all certified by the Official Swiss Chronometer Testing Institute (COSC). The watch is available in various sizes, including 31, 36, 39, and 41mm, and comes with interchangeable straps, including a leather or fabric band. The Black Bay GMT S&G is priced at S$5,970 (leather or fabric strap) to S$7,710 (steel and gold bracelet).

images.alt_text: Tudor Ranger

site_title: Will Elon Musk-owned Twitter end up as a ‘deal from hell’?
summary: Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter is facing uncertainty, with a judge giving the parties until October 28 to reach a deal. Musk's plan to reduce Twitter's reliance on advertising and incorporate it into an "everything app" called X, with online payments, has raised concerns about hubris, sloppy financing, and strategic misalignment. The deal's failure could result in significant financial losses for banks involved and damage Musk's reputation. The acquisition's outcome may also pit Musk against tech regulators and geopolitically stir up trouble, particularly with China.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk stressed that he uses Twitter a lot and that he has ideas on ways to make the platform “radically better”.
Twitter shares, which ended the day down 3.7 per cent at US$49.39, rose 1 per cent after hours as investors appeared reassured after days of confusion.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes property tax cut, visa moves to reverse Covid brain drain
summary: Hong Kong is considering easing property taxes and visa restrictions to curb a pandemic brain drain that has threatened the city's status as an international financial hub. The city is also exploring measures to attract highly skilled professionals, including exemptions from proving local recruitment efforts for key professions and relaxing rules on a 15% stamp duty for non-resident property buyers. These moves aim to reverse the trend of residents fleeing key industries and entice workers back to the city, which has been hit by prolonged recession and economic devastation.

images.alt_text: Real estate has remained at the centre of Hong Kong’s US$368 billion economy, mainly through wealth created by high valuations - a result of the territory’s scarce land resources.
Hong Kong's raison d'etre would be further accentuated for as long as China remains closed, with the city serving as an important "halfway house" while the mainland forges its way forward.

site_title: Sony, Honda aim to deliver premium EV that comes with subscription fees in 2026
summary: Sony and Honda's joint venture, Sony Honda Mobility, plans to deliver its first electric vehicles by 2026, with premium pricing and online sales starting in the US and Japan. The vehicles will feature a new software system developed by Sony, generating recurring revenue through monthly billed services. The move aims to create a new revenue stream for the companies.

images.alt_text: Sony Corp's and Honda Motor's logos are pictured at their joint news conference venue in Tokyo, Japan, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
Honda will separately invest US$700 million to retool three Ohio plants and add 300 new jobs, as it seeks higher electric-vehicle production.
Honda’s production at the two plants returned to normal for June after an earlier reduction but it began making adjustments again for August.

site_title: Bitcoin becoming less volatile than stocks raises warning flag
summary: Bitcoin's 30-day realised volatility has dropped sharply to around 52% after spending the past month above 64%, according to Coin Metrics data. Crypto traders are warning that this low-volatility environment could lead to faster price drops in the event of a sell-off, as low trading volumes exacerbate market instability. Experts point to the BitVol index, which has fallen to near its lowest levels since the spring, as a sign of a potentially volatile market. This shift raises concerns among traders and investors.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has dipped as much as 2.8 per cent on Friday (Oct 7) morning to trade as low as US$19,485.
While only 9 per cent of Singaporeans believe Bitcoin is a scam, 49 per cent would not recommend cryptocurrency to their family and friends.
Ether mining consumed about half of the energy used for Bitcoin mining before the Merge.

site_title: Crypto.com chooses Paris for European headquarters
summary: Crypto.com has chosen Paris as its European headquarters, investing 150 million euros in France to support market operations. The company, with over 50 million users worldwide, received regulatory approval in France, the UK, and Italy, allowing it to offer products and services to customers in these countries. Crypto.com plans to hire local talent in compliance, business development, and product fields. This move follows Binance's registration with France's market regulator earlier this year.

site_title: Petronas to hunt for hydrocarbons off Malaysia with TotalEnergies, Shell
summary: Petronas has signed a production sharing contract with TotalEnergies and Shell for an ultra-deepwater block off Malaysia's coast. The block, called 2K, covers 1,952 square kilometers and has promising hydrocarbon potential. TotalEnergies will be the operator with a 34.9% participating interest, while Petronas will hold 40%. Four wells are expected to be drilled in Block 2K and other ultra-deepwater blocks in 2022 and 2023.

site_title: Crypto hackers set for record year after looting over US$3b
summary: Crypto hackers are on track to steal a record-breaking $3 billion this year, with at least $718 million stolen in October alone. The majority of targets are DeFi (decentralized finance) protocols, which have weaknesses in security and coding. Two major exploits recently occurred, with a hacker stealing $100 million from DeFi service Mango and another $570 million from Binance's blockchain. Chainalysis estimates that North Korea-affiliated groups have stolen around $1 billion of crypto from DeFi protocols this year. The hackers' success highlights the need for crypto players to find solutions to prevent future attacks.

images.alt_text: The heist began with two accounts funded with the stablecoin USD Coin. The accounts took large positions in Mango perpetual futures, causing the price of the Mango token to spike.

“Software code is never bug free,” Binance’s CEO, Changpeng Zhao, said in an interview with CNBC. He emphasised that no users had lost money in the hack but said that so-called cross-chain bridges were particularly vulnerable to hacks and the industry needed to get better at learning from them.
The theft targeted the decentralised finance operations of London-based Wintermute, CEO Evgeny Gaevoy said in a tweet.

site_title: Avengers assemble: Republicans plot payback after US midterms
summary: Republicans, confident of regaining the House of Representatives in November's US midterm elections, are plotting revenge against their opponents in Congress, the White House, and law enforcement. Investigations into Trump's foes are expected, targeting those who have fended off probes against the former president. This strategy aims to exact revenge and assert control in the new Congress.

images.alt_text: Just 35 per cent of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer Biden for the nomination, while 56 per cent say the Democratic Party should pick someone else.

site_title: Singapore’s shophouse sales dip in Q3 as market sees price resistance
summary: Singapore's shophouse sales plummeted 49.3% in Q3 2022, with 34 transactions, down from 67 in Q2 and 194 in the same period last year. Freehold shophouses accounted for 73.5% of transactions, while leasehold sales declined by over a third. Average transaction value rose 30% to S$9.7 million, with top transactions including a S$71.3 million sale of 161 Lavender Street. Investors are shifting focus to areas like Joo Chiat and Jalan Basar, seeking reasonably priced shophouses, but supply is limited, and existing owners are holding onto their assets.

images.alt_text: TOTAL property investment sales in Singapore dropped 48.9 per cent in the third quarter to S$4.8 billion, marking a negative turnaround from previous quarters of growth.

CMG20210213-ChanBK01陈斌勤/岛国掠影 Generic pics of shophouse, CBD, centrel business district, Tanjong Pagar, Chinatown, Maxwell.

在许多国人的记忆中，昔日的丹戎巴葛人声鼎沸、车水马龙，是牛车水的核心地域。
五角基的一步一景、一砖一瓦，还有蜿蜒幽深的古街老巷，像串珠般串连起这里丰富的历史文脉，娓娓讲述着这片土地的开埠史。
时至今日，这里不仅保留了原有的旧建筑肌理，近年来不少韩式饭馆、婚纱店、咖啡馆注入新活力，使丹戎巴葛华丽转身，还有了“小韩国”之称，渐渐成为市区的新地标。

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as traders brace for key US inflation data
summary: Asia's stock markets declined as traders awaited US inflation data, which could impact the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The dollar strengthened, and oil prices remained flat. Minutes from the Fed's September meeting suggested a potential fourth consecutive 0.75 percentage-point rate hike, with policymakers seeking to tame inflation. The market is uncertain, with traders bracing for potential volatility.

images.alt_text: Investors are now nervously looking ahead to Thursday’s US inflation report, with observers warning that a strong reading could spark another rout.

site_title: Gold prices steady ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,672.79 per ounce ahead of US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's next interest rate hike. Spot gold held its ground despite rising interest rates reducing the appeal of bullion. US gold futures rose 0.1% to $1,679.80. The US Consumer Price Index, due Thursday, may provide cues on the Fed's next rate hike move.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered as a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, rising interest rates reduce the appeal of the asset, which pays no interest.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Bowman says more big rate hikes on table if inflation will not cool
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman stated that if inflation doesn't cool, she will continue to support aggressive rate hikes. She believes that bringing inflation back to the target is necessary for meeting Congress's goals of price stability and maximum employment. Bowman said sizable increases in the federal funds rate should remain on the table if inflation doesn't decrease, but a slower pace of rate increases would be appropriate if inflation starts to cool. She also stated that rate cuts are not expected for now.

images.alt_text: Cities have already been grappling with supply-chain issues, which have impacted their cost of operations and made infrastructure projects challenging.

Some of the Federal Reserve officials cited in the minutes noted that “it would be important to calibrate the pace of further policy tightening with the aim of mitigating the risk of significant adverse effects on the economic outlook.”

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers ComfortDelGro target price amid forex headwinds
summary: Analyst Ong Khang Chuen of CGS-CIMB lowered the target price of ComfortDelGro (CDG) from S$1.75 to S$1.56 due to forex headwinds affecting overseas profits, potentially dampening earnings recovery in H2 2022. The "add" rating is maintained, but the analyst expects a 23.8% downside from the current price. Despite this, CGS-CIMB views CDG as a defensive pick due to its strong balance sheet and expected recovery in key geographies.

images.alt_text: (From left) George Schulze, Dalmore whisky expert for Asia at Emperador; Bryan Donaghey, chief executive of Whyte & Mackay and head of whisky business at Emperador; Loh Boon Chye, SGX chief executive; Dr Andrew Tan, chairman of Emperador; Gerard Ho, Singapore’s Ambassador to the Philippines and Kevin Andrew Tan, director of Emperador at the listing of Emperador at the Singapore Exchange on 14 July 2022.
Another 10.6 percentage points in fare hikes will be carried forward to future fare reviews.

site_title: Apac has second-highest level of climate-related financial disclosures at 36%: TCFD report
summary: The Asia-Pacific region has the second-highest level of climate-related financial disclosures at 36% based on the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) report. This is an improvement of 11 percentage points from 2019, with Japan driving the increase. Despite this, disclosure rates in Asia still lag behind Europe, which has a 60% average disclosure level. Companies in the energy, materials, and buildings sectors have higher disclosure rates, while those in the transport, technology, and media sectors have lower rates. Asset managers and asset owners also report a high level of disclosure, with 93% of asset managers having implemented TCFD recommendations.

images.alt_text: Widely accepted global standards may boost the utility of independent assurance but, as long as companies can pick and choose what to subject to such assurance, the risk of greenwashing remains, says Professor Mak Yuen Teen. (PHOTO: MAK YUEN TEEN)
Getting the ISSB's expected global standards on sustainability and climate disclosures to reflect local realities will be a complex undertaking.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Thursday; STI down 0.03%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Thursday, down 0.03% or 0.79 point to 3,082.40. The market followed global losses amid inflationary pressures, with US stocks falling overnight. Banking stocks were mixed, while property management company OEL traded flat. In Europe, the Stoxx 600 index closed down 0.5% and Asian markets, including Tokyo, also opened lower ahead of US inflation data.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp said it will speed up the delivery of three out of five undelivered jackup rigs to Borr Drilling.

site_title: Taiwan welcomes back visitors after ending Covid-19 quarantine rules
summary: Taiwan welcomed back tourists on October 13, 2022, after ending mandatory COVID-19 quarantine rules, allowing visitors from Thailand to step off the plane without quarantine. The move aims to revive cross-border tourism, with the government citing high vaccination rates and a need to return to normal life. Some rules remain, including self-monitoring health for seven days and rapid testing. Airlines have increased flights, and Taiwan is preparing to welcome more tourists, including those from Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Asia’s aviation recovery has lagged other parts of the world in large part because of China’s ongoing border closures that have kept its international passenger numbers averaging only 2 per cent to 3 per cent of pre-pandemic levels, according to Iata data.
Taiwan has been carefully studying the lessons of the Ukraine war to inform how it may react should China.

site_title: Saudi Arabia rejects US criticism of Opec+ quota cut decision
summary: Saudi Arabia has rejected US criticism of its decision to cut oil production quotas, stating the move was based on "noble objectives" to avoid oil-market volatility. The country's Foreign Ministry said the decision was unanimous and not taking a stance against the US, despite US President Joe Biden's threat of consequences. Saudi Arabia reaffirmed its strategic relationship with the US and vowed to preserve its relations with all friendly countries, while also stressing its rejection of any dictates or efforts to distort its objectives.

images.alt_text: Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz Salman cited a “variety of convoluted uncertainties” last week for the Opec production cutback.

Oil pumpjacks in California. The most effective way that the US could respond to rising oil prices would be by encouraging domestic production, but this runs counter to the views of the environmentalist lobby and progressive Democrats.
The full supply allocation comes despite a decision by the Opec+ to lower their output target by 2 million barrels per day.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as banks, Qantas jump
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to 6,671.6, driven by gains in financials and Qantas' forecast of a return to profit in the first half of 2023. Qantas surged 13%, while banks rose 2.4-4.1%. Mining stocks fell 0.9% due to iron ore price slumps. Despite a decline in New Zealand's benchmark index, the Australian market closed higher, as global investors await US inflation data and interest rate hike clues.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.04 per cent higher at 6,647.5.

site_title: Meyer Park relaunched for en bloc sale at unchanged S$420m reserve price
summary: Meyer Park, a 96,672 sq ft freehold seafront site in District 15, Singapore, has been relaunched for collective sale at the unchanged S$420m reserve price. The site, completed in the 1980s, offers unobstructed views of landed homes and the sea. Sole marketing agent Edmund Tie said the site can be redeveloped into a mid-sized luxury high-rise condominium with up to 251 residences. The tender closes on Nov 2, and developers will need to prepare for a harmonisation of floor area definitions by Jun 1, 2023.

images.alt_text: 曾四度寻求集体出售的Meyer Park项目，首次获得超过八成业主同意，以4亿2000万元求售。 （戴玉祥产业提供）Meyer Park in Marine Parade.
The site is presently occupied by condominium development Meyer Park, which was completed in the 1980s and houses 60 apartment units ranging from 168 sq m to 258 sq m.

site_title: Indian car-sharing platform Zoomcar to go public via SPAC deal
summary: Zoomcar, an India-based car-sharing platform, has agreed to go public via a merger with blank-cheque firm Innovative International Acquisition. The company, with over 3 million active users and 25,000 vehicles, operates in 50 cities across India, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Egypt. The merger values the business at approximately $456 million. Zoomcar, founded in 2013, takes 40% of each transaction, and its investors include Sequoia Capital India and Waze co-founder Uri Levine. The merged company, Zoomcar Holdings, is expected to trade on the Nasdaq.

images.alt_text: Investor appetite for these blank-check firms, also called special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), has cooled over the past year due to tougher regulations, rising interest rates and a downturn in public market valuations.
TPG Pace Beneficial Finance Corp said it would begin returning money to investors after reaching the 2-year deadline for finding a target company.

Intuitive Machines is 1 of NASA’s contractors and its lunar payload delivery services were selected by the space agency for 3 lunar missions to send the first American spacecraft to the surface of the Moon since the Apollo Program.

site_title: South-east Asia’s biggest economy needs US$37b to shut coal-fired plants
summary: Indonesia, the world's third-largest economy, may be able to shut down its coal-fired power plants with a $37 billion investment, potentially reducing carbon emissions by 1.7 gigatons and tripling its annual emissions. This is 10 years ahead of the country's official target. The investment would cover the cost of buying out existing coal plants and up to 10 years of contracted coal power generation, allowing Indonesia to transition to cleaner energy sources. The move aims to balance economic growth with reducing emissions, but investors have shown muted interest in the country's $600 billion plan to retire coal plants and develop renewable energy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the start of trade on October 13, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index inching down 0.38 points to 16,700.65. Investors awaited US inflation data release later in the day. In China, the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.57% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.61%.

site_title: ByteDance plans music-streaming expansion to take on Spotify: WSJ
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, is in talks with music labels to expand its music-streaming service, Resso, globally to compete with industry leaders like Spotify. The company plans to integrate music streaming into its short-video service and scale it to become a major platform for music distribution.
