This move aims to help ByteDance take on Spotify and other music streaming giants. Shares of Spotify and Warner Music Group reacted positively to the news, with Spotify's shares trading flat and Warner Music Group gaining 4%.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM nears 2-year low on news of job cuts at key customer Intel
summary: Shares of AEM plummeted to a near 2-year low after Intel announced plans for a major reduction in headcount. AEM derives 60% of its revenue from Intel, making it vulnerable to any weakness or drop in capital expenditures from the US-based chipmaker. DBS Group Research downgraded AEM to "hold" and slashed its target price by half due to earnings uncertainty, citing prolonged weakness from Intel. AEM's counter fell 12.5% or S$0.46 to S$3.21, its lowest level since November 2020.

images.alt_text: Above: Chairman Loke Wai San from AEM Holdings. Revenue was up 181.1 per cent on the year at S$540.5 million, delivering the highest half year revenue in the group’s history, said AEM.
Loke Wai San, chairman of AEM Holdings. AEM’s H1 FY2022 earnings came in above expectations to form 75 per cent of UOBKH’s full-year estimate.
Intel is facing a steep decline in demand for PC processors, its main business, and has struggled to win back market share lost to rivals like AMD.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.57 points or 0.04% to 1,381.14. The market saw 100.77 million lots traded worth RM60.21 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 150 to 137. The flat opening comes amidst global market trends, with stocks in Europe and the US experiencing declines due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, as well as US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Medibank becomes latest target of cyber attack in Australia
summary: Health insurer Medibank Private detected a potential cyber attack on its network, enlisting cybersecurity firms to assist. The incident occurred on Wednesday with no evidence of sensitive data being accessed. This incident adds to the growing list of Australian companies falling victim to cybercrime, following the recent major hack of mobile phone provider Optus, which affected almost 10 million customers.

images.alt_text: epa07261855 ILLUSTRATION - A person sits in front of a computer screen in Moers, Germany, 04 January 2019. Reports on 04 January 2019 state personal data of hundreds of German politicians, celebrities and journalists have been hacked and posted online. The compromised data reportedly includes credit card details, private chat protocols and contact information. The data was allegedly shared via a Twitter account under the name G0d (@_0rbit) prior to Christmas 2018, which has been suspended in the meantime.  EPA-EFE/SASCHA STEINBACH

site_title: IMF stands by BOJ governor Kuroda’s rock solid easing stance
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reaffirmed the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) easing stance, advising against policy adjustments to improve the sustainability of yield curve control. IMF mission chief Ranil Salgado stated that any changes to yield curve control could be interpreted as tightening, supporting BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's dovish view. The yen has hit a 24-year low, and the IMF believes a weak yen is positive for Japan's economy, despite hurting some import-dependent households and businesses.

images.alt_text: Haruhiko Kuroda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during the Institute of International Finance (IIF) annual membership meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Oct. 12, 2022. This year's conference theme is "The Search for Stability in an Era of Uncertainty, Realignment and Transformation." Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg
IMF believes an ad hoc windfall profits tax violates the principle of tax certainty.
The IMF says global growth profile is its “weakest” since 2001, apart from during the global financial crisis and the worst of the pandemic.

site_title: Amazon to shut down ‘Explore’ virtual tour product in latest cut
summary: Amazon is shutting down its "Explore" virtual tour product, a feature launched in 2020 to provide guided tours during the pandemic. The decision is part of the company's efforts to reduce costs as sales slow. Other experimental programs, such as Scout and Amazon Glow, have also been curtailed or cancelled. Amazon plans to continue innovating and investing in new ways to delight customers while supporting affected employees during the transition.

site_title: Oil down on strong dollar, recession worries and hawkish Federal Reserve talk
summary: Oil prices fell for a third consecutive day, dropping 2% to $92.45 a barrel, amid concerns about demand, a strong dollar, and interest rate hikes by major central banks. Opec and the US Energy Department slashed their demand outlooks, citing China's Covid-19 containment measures and high inflation. The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance also contributed to the decline, with Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari reaffirming the central bank's commitment to raising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Oil surged early this year, bringing Brent close to its record high of US$147 as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to supply concerns, but prices have slid on economic fears.
Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz Salman cited a “variety of convoluted uncertainties” last week for the Opec production cutback.

site_title: Amazon shifts prototype Internet satellites to ULA rocket for 2023 launch
summary: Amazon has shifted its prototype Internet satellites to a United Launch Alliance (ULA) rocket for a 2023 launch, replacing ABL Space Systems due to launch delays. The debut orbital flight of the new Vulcan rocket will be the first quarter of 2023. The satellites will be the first to launch as part of Amazon's Kuiper network, a planned constellation of 3,236 low-Earth orbiting satellites aiming to beam broadband Internet to remote areas. Amazon plans to invest $10 billion in the project, competing with SpaceX's Starlink network.

images.alt_text: Amazon launched Explore in 2020, targeting those suffering cabin fever during pandemic lockdowns.
Amazon launched Prime Day in 2015 to attract new subscribers who now pay US$139 a year for shipping discounts, video streaming and other perks.

site_title: UK estate agents turn pessimistic seeing drop in house prices
summary: UK estate agents have become pessimistic about the housing market, anticipating a decline in house prices for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a 15% drop in price expectations, citing interest rate hikes and turmoil in mortgage markets. Inquiries by potential homebuyers have fallen for five consecutive months, and some sellers are reluctant to list properties. The RICS expects further pressure on the housing sector as the economy adjusts to higher interest rates and a tight labor market.

site_title: Microsoft avoids paying tax in many countries: study
summary: Microsoft has avoided paying billions in taxes in countries where it has lucrative public sector contracts due to its complex corporate structure. A study by the Centre for Corporate Tax Accountability and Research (Cictar) found that the company paid zero tax in 2020 through its Irish subsidiary in Bermuda and had a tax liability of just $15 on profits of $22.4 billion in Singapore. Microsoft claims it respects local laws and regulations, but analysts say the discrepancy is a "huge red flag" for tax avoidance.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz and Microsoft collaboration should lead to a 20 per cent increase in vehicle production efficiency by 2025 from 2022 levels.
Microsoft says the Competition and Markets Authority adopted the complaints of market leader Sony without the “appropriate level of critical review.”

site_title: Biden to prioritise China competition amid ‘dangerous’ Russia
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration has prioritized competition with China over Russia, citing China's rapid technological advances and authoritarian model as a threat to global order. The national security strategy, unveiled at Georgetown University, emphasizes reducing conflict, promoting democracy, and addressing climate change. China is seen as a key rival to the US, with ambitions to create an enhanced sphere of influence in the Indo-Pacific and become the world's leading power. The US will work to maintain a competitive edge while constraining a "dangerous" Russia, which poses an immediate threat to the free and open international system.

images.alt_text: Oil pumpjacks in California. The most effective way that the US could respond to rising oil prices would be by encouraging domestic production, but this runs counter to the views of the environmentalist lobby and progressive Democrats.
The Labor Department said it will consider workers’ opportunity for profit or loss, the permanency of their jobs, and the degree of control a company exercises over a worker, among other factors.
The US planned to review licences for non-Chinese factories in China hit by the new restrictions on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: US growth slowdown ‘required’ to beat inflation: Federal Reserve minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve stated that a slowdown in US economic growth and the job market is "required" to bring down inflation, which remains "unacceptably high." Fed officials noted that inflation has not yet responded to increased interest rates and that a significant reduction in inflation would likely lag aggregate demand. The Fed aims to return inflation to its 2% objective, with a strong commitment to doing so. The central bank's policy-setting committee increased interest rates by 0.75 percentage points for the third consecutive time in September.

images.alt_text: OECD forecast the US economy would grow 1.5 per cent this year and 0.5 per cent in 2023.
With growing fears of a recession, the reserve build out in the third quarter could be the biggest drag on bank profits, analysts said.

site_title: China’s pain from deflating housing bubble will linger for year
summary: China's housing market remains sluggish amid an economic slowdown and Covid Zero restraints, with home sales and prices showing no significant improvement. Despite government stimulus measures, including lower mortgage rates and tax breaks, the market continues to struggle, with consumer confidence at a record low and property prices expected to drop further. The government's efforts to curb credit risk and make homes more affordable have created a vicious cycle, with many economists predicting a prolonged downturn. The potential spillover effects on the economy are significant, with millions of households seeing their nest egg lose value and consumer demand weak.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - People stand in front of images of Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Museum of the Communist Party of China in Beijing on September 4, 2022. (Photo by Noel Celis / AFP)

Behind the excellent balance sheet of China's central government is a vast array of contingent liabilities. Beijing thus prioritises the strength of its own balance sheet, as during a crisis, any or all of those borrowers could requite a bailout.

site_title: Qantas sees first-half profit of up to A$1.3b on travel demand
summary: Qantas Airways has reported its first-half profit of up to A$1.3 billion, ending a streak of five consecutive half-yearly losses, due to booming travel demand after pandemic-era curbs were lifted. The airline's underlying profit before tax is seen at A$1.2 billion to A$1.3 billion. Qantas shares gained 11.8% in early trading, with CEO Alan Joyce expressing optimism about the airline's turnaround. Joyce said the airline will spend A$200 million to maintain operational buffers and reward workers with a 3% wage increase.

images.alt_text: Qantas signed a contract for 12 A350-1000s this year after its board stood by the Project Sunrise programme as aviation began to emerge from the coronavirus crisis.
Rex, best known for flying small propeller-driven aircraft between regional towns, is fast building out a new jet division plying busy domestic routes including Sydney-Melbourne.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sats, LHN
summary: Keppel to speed up delivery of three jackup rigs to Borr Drilling, with full payments due. Sats shares fell 2.7% after Temasek's subsidiary sold 1.2 million shares, reducing its stake to 39.9%. LHN Space Resources leased a 59,000 sqm industrial property for 3.5 years, valued at S$53.1 million. Trading halts were called for Colex and Bonvests pending announcements.

site_title: China set to import Brazilian corn in challenge to US supply
summary: China is set to import Brazilian corn as early as December, diversifying its supply amid disruptions from the war in Ukraine and tensions with the US. Pre-approved facilities in Brazil, including those owned by Bunge, Cargill, and Archer-Daniels-Midland, are expected to export to China, potentially threatening the US share of Chinese corn purchases. The move aims to reduce dependence on the US and replace supplies from Ukraine cut off by the Russian invasion, following a surge in US corn futures and a surging US dollar.

images.alt_text: Yangtze Memory was among more than 30 organisations that the US Commerce Department put on its so-called unverified list, which restricts their ability to buy American technology.

Behind the excellent balance sheet of China's central government is a vast array of contingent liabilities. Beijing thus prioritises the strength of its own balance sheet, as during a crisis, any or all of those borrowers could requite a bailout.

site_title: E-wallet fintechs prosper in the Philippines by targeting the unbanked
summary: The Philippines has seen a significant increase in bank account ownership, with 56% of the population holding accounts as of 2021, up from 29% in 2019. This growth is attributed to the adoption of digital banking solutions during the COVID-19 pandemic, with e-wallets such as GCash benefiting the most. E-wallet players are targeting the unbanked population, offering cheaper financial products and innovative solutions. The government aims to have half of all transactions digital and 70% of adults with formal banking accounts by 2023, with e-wallets playing a key role in achieving these targets.

images.alt_text: Digital banks such as Trust Bank could be partners rather than competitors to some fintechs.
MAS said in December 2020 that there were 14 "eligible applications" for the new digital bank licences
Digital wallets continue to displace cash; data shows opportunities in Malaysia, Thailand

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open softer on Thursday after US falls
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index decreased 0.04% to 26,386.44 on Thursday, following a softer US market. The move came ahead of US inflation data and amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions. The broader Topix index also slipped 0.21%.

site_title: US: Stocks edge down ahead of consumer price data
summary: US stocks declined slightly on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.1% to 29,210.85, ahead of the release of the September consumer price index (CPI) report. Wholesale inflation rose 0.4% last month, exceeding expectations, but investors largely shrugged off the data, anticipating further Federal Reserve actions to contain inflation. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the tech-rich Nasdaq dipping 0.1% to 10,417.10.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 6.1 points, or 0.02 per cent, at the open to 29,233.06.

site_title: Green finance can help ensure the energy transition is a just one
summary: Asia's green energy evolution is gaining momentum, with countries like Singapore, India, and Indonesia launching pilot schemes for green hydrogen and fuel cell systems. However, the region remains heavily dependent on fossil fuels. To ensure a just transition, policymakers must balance environmental goals with social inclusion, investing in people and places. Financial institutions can facilitate climate goals by providing capital and incentives for low-carbon solutions, and governments must ensure that climate action does not widen the gap between rich and poor nations. A just transition requires public and private collaboration, with blended finance and green bonds playing a crucial role.

images.alt_text:
Achieving a just transition to net zero will require addressing the high costs of decarbonisation.

Source: Energy Market Authority
The need to act on climate adaptation often precedes perception of the need to act.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble as fears around inflation, earnings grip investors
summary: European shares plummeted, falling 0.5% for a sixth straight session, due to concerns over inflation, rising interest rates, and mixed earnings reports. The Stoxx 600 index is on track for its worst annual performance since 2008. Inflation data from the US showed producer prices increased more than expected, while the International Monetary Fund and World Bank warned of recession risks. The UK's FTSE 100 index also fell, with British bond yields rising sharply ahead of a Bank of England interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index was marginally lower at 6,884.16 points, as investors digested news of shrinking UK economic growth in August.

site_title: Microsoft says Sony bias on US$69b deal swayed CMA
summary: Microsoft accused Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) of relying on "self-serving" input from rival Sony in its decision to probe the tech giant's $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard. The CMA cited concerns the deal could restrict players of Activision's Call of Duty to Microsoft's Xbox console. Microsoft claimed the CMA adopted Sony's complaints without a "critical review" and that Sony's statements "exaggerate" the importance of Call of Duty. The CMA is set to make a final decision on the deal by March 1.

images.alt_text: The launch of Overwatch 2 already had long queue times for players waiting to get a chance to play the new game.

site_title: LHN unit takes lease on Tampines property to grow space optimisation business
summary: LHN Space Resources, an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of LHN Limited, has taken a three-year and 11-month lease on a 59-unit industrial property, Space @ Tampines, for approximately S$53.1 million. The property, with an estimated 42,000 square meters, will be used to host companies in general and special industries under the company's space optimisation business. The lease terms include an option to renew for a further three years at a revised rent of up to 110% of the initial rent. The acquisition was approved by Fragrance Limited, the company's largest shareholder.

images.alt_text: The 404 Pasir Panjang Road property, which currently operates as Pasir Panjang Inn, will be turned into a co-living space, said LHN Group.

site_title: Google’s Pixel phone and watch seen as best Apple alternative yet
summary: Google's new Pixel 7 and 7 Pro smartphones, along with the Pixel Watch, are seen as the best Apple alternative yet, offering a cohesive ecosystem of devices with Google Assistant at its core. The Pixel 7 and 7 Pro feature enhanced AI-powered features, including smarter transcription and upgraded cameras. The Pixel Watch, running WearOS, replicates Fitbit's health-tracking experience and offers Google Pay and an on-board app store. With the Pixel 7 generation, Google has made its strongest attempt to emulate Apple's ecosystem, but still lags behind in supply chain management, which may impact sales.

images.alt_text: An undated handout image from Google shows the Google Pixel 6 smartphone, the company's latest effort in a market it has failed to conquer.
The launch event will take place at 10.00 am ET (2.00 pm GMT) in the Williamsburg neighbourhood of New York.

site_title: WWF-Singapore to teach public about responsible investing after strong uptake for industry courses
summary: WWF-Singapore's Asia Sustainable Finance Initiative plans to educate retail investors on responsible investing after its online sustainable finance courses for professionals attracted 5,000 participants in the first year. The initiative aims to mainstream sustainable finance by establishing risk identification mechanisms, monitoring ESG indicators, and providing guidelines on green programs. WWF-Singapore's CEO R Raghunathan emphasizes the need for both supply-side and demand-side education to make sustainable finance the norm.

images.alt_text: Sustainable development investing does not require a trade-off between returns and social value. Instead, it seeks to identify investment opportunities that generate returns while delivering net-positive outcomes.
The need to act on climate adaptation often precedes perception of the need to act.

site_title: UN General Assembly condemns Russia ‘illegal annexation’ of Ukraine land
summary: The UN General Assembly has overwhelmingly voted to condemn Russia's annexation of parts of Ukraine, with 143 countries supporting the resolution and 5 opposing it. The US had made a major diplomatic effort to secure a clearer condemnation, but 35 nations abstained, including China and India. The resolution "condemns the organisation by the Russian Federation of so-called referendums within the internationally recognized borders of Ukraine" and "the attempted illegal annexation" of four regions by President Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz will use the talks in Beijing to also seek clarification on China’s ambivalent role in the conflict over Russia’s military invasion in Ukraine.
Russia launched 83 missile strikes at Ukraine on Monday (Oct 10) fired from Astrakhan in southern Russia, 43 of which were intercepted.

site_title: US faces ‘larger-than-usual’ risks in inflation battle, OECD says
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has stated that the US economy faces increased uncertainty due to rapid interest rate hikes, with risks tilted to the downside. The OECD forecasts the US economy to grow 1.5% this year and 0.5% in 2023, citing the potential for persistent inflation and a substantial negative impact on real GDP growth. The Federal Reserve is expected to adjust policy as needed to monitor global events and their impact on the domestic economy.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda warns against fast, one-sided yen falls
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that fast and one-sided yen falls would be bad for the economy, signaling that the speed of the currency's decline is the key concern for policymakers. The yen hit a 24-year high against the dollar, prompting Japan's currency intervention last month. Kuroda reiterated the BOJ's commitment to keep interest rates ultra-low, citing the economy's fragile state and the need for cautious withdrawal of stimulus to avoid pushing the global economy into recession.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation, which has pushed the yen to 24-year lows against the dollar.

site_title: Merck opts to develop, sell cancer vaccine with Moderna
summary: Merck has opted to jointly develop and sell a personalized mRNA cancer vaccine with Moderna for a $250 million upfront payment. The vaccine, mRNA-4157, is being tested in a mid-stage trial combining with Merck's Keytruda immunotherapy to treat melanoma patients. Data is expected in the fourth quarter of this year. This deal follows a 2016 strategic partnership between Merck and Moderna, and comes after Merck sold its equity investment in Moderna in 2020, benefiting from a surge in the vaccine-maker's stock price.

site_title: Temasek’s Fullerton Fund Management disposes of 1.8m Sats shares for S$5.4m
summary: Temasek's Fullerton Fund Management sold 1.2 million Sats shares for S$3.5 million and another 629,500 shares for S$1.9 million, reducing Temasek's deemed interest in Sats from 40.02% to 39.96%. Sats shares have been on a decline since the company announced plans to acquire Worldwide Flight Services in September. The company's CEO, Kerry Mok, has stated that the acquisition is one of four funding sources for the deal, which is valued at S$1.9 billion.

images.alt_text: SATS logo on 15 December 2016.

site_title: US cities preparing for an impending recession, survey shows
summary: US cities are preparing for an impending recession, with nearly a third of city finance officers expecting to struggle with meeting financial needs in fiscal year 2023. The National League of Cities survey found cities expect a 2.5% decline in sales-tax receipts and a 4% drop in property taxes due to a housing market slowdown and the Federal Reserve's policy tightening. Cities are budgeting conservatively, citing supply-chain issues and inflation concerns. The survey's findings indicate cities are bracing for "stagflation and possible economic downturn."

images.alt_text: Shoppers cross 34th Street in New York, U.S., on Monday, Dec. 27, 2021. U.S. holiday sales jumped 8.5% from last year as consumers spent more money on clothes, jewelry and electronics, a report from Mastercard SpendingPulse showed. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: GuocoLand can unlock value just by listing Guoco Tower as a single-property Reit
summary: GuocoLand, a Singaporean real estate group, may unlock value by listing Guoco Tower, a prime office building, as a single-property Reit. The introduction of Reits allows retail investors to own fractions of properties, but exposure to one asset can be diluted. By listing Guoco Tower in a Reit, GuocoLand could potentially attract institutional investors and increase the asset's value. The hypothetical Guoco Tower Reit could offer a mid-4% annual dividend yield, comparable to a recent green bond, and potentially trade at a lower yield than acquisitive Reits.

images.alt_text: Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands
VivoCity Mall, a key retail mall in Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s portfolio, saw shopper traffic  grow 50.9 per cent  yoy and tenant sales increase 53.3 per cent yoy in Q1 FY2022/2023.

site_title: German union demands 10.5% pay rise for public-sector staff
summary: Germany's largest services union, Verdi, is demanding a 10.5% pay rise for public-sector employees to counter record inflation, with an additional 500 euros per month for apprentices and students. The union's demands would cost 1.4 billion euros per year, but Interior Minister Nancy Faeser is confident of reaching an agreement, citing the need for "appropriate salary responses" to the energy crisis and inflation surge.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher after selloff
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 2.0 and 10.8 points, respectively. However, gains were capped by concerns over potential rate hikes following a higher-than-expected rise in producer prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 6.1 points, or 0.02%, to 29,233.06. Market worries persist over rising US-EU tariffs and the impact on global trade.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: US producer price growth tops forecasts, keeping pressure on Fed
summary: US producer price growth exceeded forecasts in September, rising 0.4% from August and 8.5% from a year ago, driven by increases in services and volatile food and energy costs. The core PPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.3% and 7.2% from a year earlier. This inflationary pressure is expected to keep the Federal Reserve on its aggressive interest rate-hike path, potentially leading to another 75 basis point rate hike next month.

images.alt_text: Prices at the grocery store are a chief concern, with year-ahead expectations for food inflation climbing a full percentage point to 6.9% in September.

site_title: US chip suppliers pull back from China’s Yangtze Memory after Biden ban
summary: US chip suppliers, including Applied Materials, KLA, and Lam Research, are withdrawing staff from China's Yangtze Memory Technologies due to new US regulations banning Chinese companies from buying advanced chip-making equipment or employing American citizens without a licence. Yangtze Memory was added to the US Commerce Department's unverified list, restricting its ability to buy American technology. The move is expected to have a significant impact on China's semiconductor industry, potentially jeopardizing hundreds of companies.

site_title: UK borrowing costs hit 20-year high as BoE sticks by bond deadline
summary: UK borrowing costs surged to a 20-year high as the Bank of England stuck to its bond-buying deadline, despite warnings from pension funds. Governor Andrew Bailey told pension funds they had three days to fix liquidity problems before the bank ends emergency support. The pound strengthened after Bailey's message, but 20 and 30-year gilt yields hit their highest since 2002 at 5.195% and 5.1%, respectively. The BoE's decision is seen as a test of its ability to balance economic growth with inflation concerns, with markets expecting a 1 percentage point rate hike on November 3.

images.alt_text: Funds, which hold assets ranging from US Treasuries to European corporate bonds, are expected to exit positions that were only tenable because the BOE stepped in last month to support the UK gilt market.

site_title: How these small, little-known startups are accelerating their expansion to the world
summary: Singapore-based startups Tagvance and Performance Rotors accelerated growth by participating in open innovation challenges. Tagvance, which initially developed asset-tracking technology for the local market, won contracts with global companies like SAP and Amazon Web Services after co-creating a workforce tracking platform with a local construction company. Performance Rotors, a drone maker, expanded its customer base and revenue after developing solutions for tree inspections and confined spaces through open innovation challenges. These startups benefited from infrastructure access, support, and funding, while corporates accessed a bigger pool of ideas and competencies.

site_title: UK government rules out spending cuts, reversal on tax cuts
summary: The UK government, led by Prime Minister Liz Truss, has ruled out reversing its tax cuts or reducing public spending, despite financial markets' turmoil and concerns over its economic policy change. Truss reiterated her commitment to maintaining spending levels, stating "Absolutely, absolutely," when asked in parliament. The government aims to reduce public debt by improving spending efficiency, rather than through cuts, and has brought forward the budget date to October 31.

images.alt_text: The government of new Prime Minister Liz Truss last month sparked turmoil with a costly tax-cutting budget that triggered panic over ballooning state debt.

site_title: Blockchain.com gets Singapore licence, second crypto firm to obtain approval this week
summary: Blockchain.com, a cryptocurrency exchange valued at US$14 billion, has received approval from Singapore's central bank to offer payment services in the city-state. This comes a day after Coinbase, another major crypto firm, also received the same approval. With this, 18 out of 180 firms have been granted a crypto payments licence in Singapore, solidifying the city-state's position as a major hub for digital asset services in Asia.

site_title: Eurozone industry output up in August much more than expected
summary: Eurozone industrial production increased 1.5% month-on-month in August, exceeding expectations, with a 2.5% year-on-year rise. This was driven by a 2.8% rise in capital goods output and increased consumer goods production, despite a 0.5% decline in Germany's output. The better-than-expected data failed to dispel recession fears, with economists predicting a significant contraction in the coming months.

site_title: Indonesian president to order stress test for economy amid global uncertainty
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced plans to conduct a stress test to assess the country's economy's resilience to global economic shocks, amid fears of a recession. The test will evaluate factors such as currency, inflation, growth, food, and energy. The move comes after the International Monetary Fund cut its 2023 global growth forecast due to war in Ukraine, high energy and food prices, inflation, and higher interest rates. The test is part of the administration's efforts to anticipate a worsening global economic outlook and devise plans for different scenarios.

site_title: IMF sees ad hoc taxes on excess profits as 'problematic'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed concerns over an ad hoc windfall profits tax on excess profits, calling it "problematic" as it violates the principle of tax certainty. IMF head of fiscal affairs department Vitor Gaspar believes such a tax would provide permanent revenue but only if clearly communicated and only for future profits, not existing ones. The IMF supports taxing excess profits to raise permanent revenue, but the European Commission's plan to tax windfall profits is seen as problematic.

images.alt_text: The IMF says global growth profile is its “weakest” since 2001, apart from during the global financial crisis and the worst of the pandemic.

site_title: US mortgage interest rates rise to highest level since 2006
summary: US mortgage interest rates have reached their highest level since 2006, averaging 6.81% for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. The Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation have led to a surge in mortgage rates, which have more than doubled since the start of the year. The housing sector continues to bear the brunt, with homebuilding and sales weakening and home prices remaining high despite slowing growth, eroding affordability for buyers.

site_title: SGX’s proposed tenure limit for independent directors  advances board diversity: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is introducing a tenure limit for independent directors, aiming to advance board diversity. The limit will help drive a renewal process, and combined with the requirement to consider diversity, it's seen as a "tailwind" for boards in their diversity journey. The move is based on studies showing that a diverse board is better equipped to assess future risks and opportunities. While the limit doesn't directly increase diversity, it's expected to push boards further along their diversity path.

site_title: Crypto attack swipes US$100m from DeFi service Mango
summary: A hacker exploited a security weakness in Mango, a decentralized finance (DeFi) service, to steal approximately $100 million. The attacker manipulated the price of Mango's token, taking large positions in perpetual futures and leveraging up profits to withdraw funds. The platform has temporarily disabled deposits and is negotiating with the attacker. The incident highlights the security risks of decentralized exchanges, which lack effective standards, regulation, and investor protection. This is the latest in a series of multimillion-dollar hacks of DeFi protocols this year.

site_title: Opec trims oil-demand outlook, making case for its supply cut
summary: Opec has reduced its oil-demand outlook, citing "variety of convoluted uncertainties" and a possible resurgence of Covid restrictions in China. The organization trimmed its required production forecast for the fourth quarter by 440,000 barrels a day and slashed estimates for global demand growth by more than twice as much. The move supports the Opec supply cut of 2 million barrels a day announced last week, despite criticism from US officials. The International Monetary Fund warned of economic turmoil ahead, and oil prices have slumped 23% in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Oil surged early this year, bringing Brent close to its record high of US$147 as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to supply concerns, but prices have slid on economic fears.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.25 points to 1,380.57. 1.847 billion lots worth RM1.559 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 490 to 344.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's rental market remains strong, with both HDB and condo prices increasing by over 3% in September. Public transport fares will rise by 2.9% on Dec 26, capped at 5 cents per journey. SIA Engineering extended its airframe maintenance agreement with Hawaiian Airlines, while ECs are fetching strong resale profits. TikTok is launching its e-commerce push in South-east Asia.

site_title: Yen weakens to new 24 year low; sterling cautiously rebounds
summary: The US dollar reached a 24-year high against the yen, surpassing levels that prompted Japan's first yen-buying intervention since 1998. The yen fell 0.48% to 146.6 yen, while sterling rebounded 0.9% to $1.1062 after the Bank of England's governor hinted at prolonging its bond purchases. The euro and Australian dollar also declined, while bitcoin struggled around $19,000. The Bank of Japan may focus on slowing the US dollar-yen rise rather than defending specific levels, according to analysts.

site_title: Volkswagen closes in on US$1b joint venture with Chinese chipmaking startup
summary: Volkswagen is close to a $1 billion joint venture with Chinese chipmaker Horizon Robotics to develop autonomous driving technologies and wireless connectivity software for its vehicles. The deal is at an advanced stage, with talks between the two parties private. Volkswagen aims to expand its digital innovation skills in China, following a recent investment in Ford-backed driverless tech startup Argo AI. The joint venture will focus on developing technologies for VW vehicles, following Horizon's existing partnership with Audi.

site_title: Putin moots major gas hub in Turkey with Nord Stream supplies
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin proposed redirecting gas supplies through the Black Sea to create a major European gas hub in Turkey or utilizing the intact Nord Stream 2 pipeline to supply the EU. An investigation is underway into explosions that damaged the Nord Stream pipelines. Putin stated that Russia could repair the pipelines but left the decision to Europe, citing economic feasibility as a factor. The one remaining functional Nord Stream 2 line has an annual capacity of 27.5 billion cubic meters, which Russia could open if Europe desires it.

images.alt_text: The construction site of a new liquefied natural gas terminal in Germany. Europe is discussing the possibility of a gas price cap to reduce revenue flows to Russia.

site_title: Bailey’s warning sends shivers through fragile global bond markets
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey warned fund managers to cut vulnerable positions before the central bank ends debt purchases, sending UK gilts and global bond markets into a shiver. UK government bond yields surged, with 20-year gilts reaching a 14-year high, as investors braced for another wave of selling from British pension funds. The BOE's decision to end its bond-buying intervention on Friday has raised concerns about the global economy and the ability of central banks to tighten policy when government spending is rising, with implications for bond markets worldwide.

images.alt_text: Protesters at a demonstration against the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference on Oct 2. There might have been plausible economic arguments for the UK's new policies, but political blunders have all but guaranteed that the Tories will lose the next election.

site_title: Clubs to receive over US$209m World Cup compensation
summary: FIFA will distribute US$209 million to clubs releasing internationals for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. Each club will receive approximately US$10,000 per day a player remains with their national team, including preparation periods. This compensation is paid to all clubs where the player has played in the two years before the World Cup, following a system established ahead of the 2010 World Cup.

site_title: Malaysia’s August industrial production index up 13.6%, beating expectations
summary: Malaysia's August industrial production index rose 13.6% year-over-year, exceeding expectations of 9.5% growth. The increase was driven by robust mining, manufacturing, and electricity output. The manufacturing sector grew 15.2%, with transport equipment and electronics products contributing significantly. Domestic-oriented industries recorded a 22.5% growth, while export-oriented industries grew 12.4%. The growth is a larger increase than the 12.5% growth reported in July.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's exports continued recorded double-digit growth for consecutive 13 months, thanks to higher exports of electrical and electronic products, petroleum products, optical and scientific equipment as well as machinery, equipment and parts.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz and Microsoft collaborate on supply chain data platform
summary: Mercedes-Benz and Microsoft have partnered to create a data platform called MO360, aiming to improve production efficiency at over 30 global passenger car plants. The platform gathers data from various stages of production to identify supply chain bottlenecks, expected to increase vehicle production efficiency by 20% by 2025 compared to 2022 levels. MO360 is already available in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, the US, and China, and will be launched in these regions.

site_title: Curbs on number of visitors at hospitals, residential care homes as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Singapore has introduced new visitor restrictions at hospitals and residential care homes due to the rising number of Covid-19 cases. Starting October 14, visitors will be limited to two per patient, with one visitor allowed at the bedside at any time. Residential care homes will have up to four visitors, with one visitor allowed per visit, for 30 minutes. The measures aim to reduce Covid-19 transmission in healthcare institutions.

images.alt_text: The spike, while largely driven by the XBB variant, is seeing low severe cases, said the MOH.

site_title: Public transport fares to rise by 2.9%; hike capped at 5 cents per journey
summary: Public transport fares in Singapore will rise by 2.9% starting Dec 26, with half of Singaporeans seeing a 1-cent increase per journey and adults capped at 5 cents. The fare increase is attributed to rising energy prices, manpower costs, and inflation. The remaining 10.6 percentage points will be carried over to future fare reviews. The government has also provided additional support for lower-wage workers and households with low incomes, including concession card fare increases and public transport vouchers.

images.alt_text: Revenue from the group's taxi business declined 6.5 per cent to S$211.3 million

site_title: Barratt says UK house reservations drop as mortgage rates surge
summary: Barratt Developments, the UK's largest homebuilder, reported a decline in house reservations due to a cost-of-living crisis and soaring mortgage rates. Net private reservations per week fell to 188 from July 1 to October 9, down from 281 in the same period in 2021. The company's shares fell 7% and those of its peers dropped between 1.6% and 3.2%. Barratt warned of a "less certain" outlook and attributed the decline to mortgage affordability, particularly for first-time buyers.

images.alt_text: Some of Britain’s top open-ended property funds are rolling out new measures to manage investor exit requests.

site_title: France starts forced return to work at fuel depot in showdown with union
summary: France has started requisitioning staff at an Exxon Mobil fuel depot in Gravenchon-Port Jerome, defying the hardline CGT union's strike, to ensure petrol supplies amid weeks-long strikes. The government had previously threatened to force staff back to work, sparking a wider conflict with trade unions. The CGT has vowed to challenge the requisition in court, while other unions have shown signs of support for the strike. The move aims to address fuel shortages and follow an agreement between management and other unions over pay.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment at near 3-year high in September on tourism rebound
summary: Thai industrial sentiment reached a 32-month high in September, rising to 91.8 from 90.5 in the previous month, according to the Federation of Thai Industries. The improvement was driven by a recovery in the tourism sector and domestic demand, as well as a weak baht at a 16-year low against the US dollar. This is the fourth consecutive month of growth in industrial sentiment.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s key interest rate is just 1.00 per cent.

Phuket was Thailand’s test case for the revival of its tourism industry last year, as the province was used for the government’s “sandbox” project that allowed fully vaccinated foreigners to visit starting in July 2021.

site_title: Champions of Good team up to do more
summary: The Pro Bono School, a programme by Empact in partnership with Procter & Gamble (P&G) and Credit Suisse, has partnered with three winners of the President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards to enhance their individual capacities for making a positive impact. Since its inception in 2016, the school has facilitated over 37 sessions, with 1,289 social sector leaders from 413 social organisations participating. The programme aims to make capability building and skills development affordable and accessible to non-profit organisations and social enterprises, with 94% of volunteers reporting an increased sense of responsibility towards their community.

images.alt_text: Push Pull Give's initiative to inspire the at-risk youths from Muhammadiyah Welfare Home to take charge of their health and fitness.
This year marked the return of Children for Children to a physical event after two years of virtual activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall for fifth day amid mixed regional trading; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% for the fifth consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,083.19. The decline was led by Jardine Cycle & Carriage, Sats, City Development, and Wilmar International, which fell between 2.5 and 2.7%. Only three index stocks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose 0.5%, 0.3%, and 0.6% respectively. Investors are closely watching US inflation data and Federal Reserve meeting minutes for guidance.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index shed 0.78 per cent, or 131.33 points, to 16,701.03.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index inched down 0.02 per cent, or 4.42 points, to end at 26,396.83.
Investors are now nervously looking ahead to Thursday’s US inflation report, with observers warning that a strong reading could spark another rout.

site_title: Art in surprising places at Singapore Biennale
summary: The seventh Singapore Biennale, nicknamed "Natasha," is set to kick off with over 50 artists showcasing their works in unconventional locations across the city, including Tanjong Pagar Distripark and the Southern Islands. The biennale features a diverse range of artistic practices, from visual to literary arts, and will run across various venues until its conclusion.

site_title: UK economy on brink of recession as it shrinks in August
summary: The UK economy is expected to enter a technical recession as it unexpectedly shrank in August by 0.3% from July, its first decline since early 2021. Manufacturing and maintenance work in North Sea oil and gas fields contributed to the slowdown, while surging inflation and rising interest rates are hitting households. Economists predict the recession will last until late 2023, with the International Monetary Fund forecasting a 0.3% growth in 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end volatile day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a volatile day with losses, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.78% to 16,701.03. This follows a Bank of England announcement that it will end support for financial markets at day's end. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.53% and the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange rallied 2.53%. The US stock market had previously reached records, but edged down amid tariff threats.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drift down in early deals
summary: European stocks drifted lower in early deals on October 12, 2022, as investors digested news of shrinking UK economic growth in August. London's FTSE 100 index was marginally lower at 6,884.16 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index shed 0.3% to 12,177.31 points and Paris' CAC 40 lost 0.3% to 5,816.28. The losses were attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Cisco partners with Microsoft to add Teams to its meeting devices
summary: Cisco Systems is partnering with Microsoft to add the Teams messaging app to its meeting devices, offering an alternative to its Webex video conferencing app. The move aims to position Cisco as a hardware platform for various conferencing software, following the trend of consumers having multiple subscriptions to streaming services. Webex, once a widely used platform, has lost market share to newcomers like Zoom Video Communications. The Teams Room software will be available on Cisco devices starting from the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on central bank's dovish stance; bond yields dive
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.47% on October 12, 2022, led by chipmakers after the Bank of Korea's dovish stance on monetary tightening. The benchmark Kospi index ended at 2,202.47, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rising 0.72% and 4.21% respectively. The won jumped 0.72% and the benchmark bond yield fell 23.3 basis points to 4.109%. Foreigners were net buyers of shares for an eighth straight session, extending their buying streak.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi fell 40.77 points or 1.83 per cent to 2,192.07.

site_title: Chinese ‘flying car’ makes first public flight in Dubai
summary: A Chinese "flying car" built by Xpeng made its first public flight in Dubai, marking a significant step towards launching the electric aircraft on international markets. The two-seater eVTOL, lifted by eight propellers, completed a 90-minute test flight. Xpeng aims to expand its presence in the global market, citing Dubai's reputation as the most innovative city in the world.

site_title: October will be more volatile than ever for China stocks
summary: China's stock market is expected to be particularly volatile in October due to the looming 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, which may lead to leadership reshuffles. The country's economic health, as indicated by the Caixin China General Services Purchasing Managers' Index, has been declining, with business activities recovering from June to August but disrupted by Covid-19 outbreaks. Economists predict gradual relaxation in the first half of 2023, but optimism is tempered by the Party's continued pandemic controls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo
Unlike the US, Europe is more exposed both to the geopolitical and economic risks

site_title: The rich are living in a different economic world
summary: LVMH, the luxury giant, reported a 19% increase in sales excluding mergers and acquisitions and currency movements in its third-quarter results. Fashion and leather goods organic revenue rose 22%, beating analysts' expectations. Despite this, investors should remain cautious due to growing risks, particularly in the US and Chinese markets. The US is vulnerable to economic shocks, while China's demand remains uncertain due to pandemic lockdowns and economic concerns. LVMH, however, appears best placed among luxury companies due to its diversified portfolio, strong balance sheet, and ability to invest in marketing and acquisitions.

images.alt_text: A woman takes photos of the Louis Vuitton store in Miami, Florida on November 30, 2021. - Artistic director for Louis Vuitton men's collections, Abloh, whose family was from Ghana, died on November 28 of cancer aged 41, after becoming the first major black designer to be recognised in an industry often criticised for its lack of diversity. (Photo by Eva Marie UZCATEGUI / AFP)

site_title: Keppel O&M to accelerate delivery of three jackup rigs to Borr Drilling
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) will accelerate the delivery of three jackup rigs to Borr Drilling, with the remaining two rigs to be delivered in 2025 instead of their original delivery date. The delivery of the first three rigs will be completed between October 2022 and July 2023, with all three sold without any seller's credit arrangement. This move comes after Keppel O&M entered into an amended framework deed with Borr Drilling.

images.alt_text: Keppel O&M has delivered a significant number of projects for Brazil and Petrobras over the years, including the P-69 FPSO (pictured).

site_title: Australia: Shares close flat as banks offset miners' drag
summary: Australia's shares closed flat on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.04% to 6,647.5. Financial stocks surged 1.9% after a four-session losing run, while commodity stocks declined 1%. The US Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its aggressive interest rate hike path, benefiting banks but posing a risk to miners and energy stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia's neutral rate remains uncertain, and global central banks continue to raise rates to curb inflation, sparking recession fears.

images.alt_text: Market participants across the world are looking forward to US inflation readings that are expected to show persistently strong price pressures and cement the Federal Reserve’s hawkish rhetoric on monetary policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge lower at close
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat on October 12, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.02% and the Topix index down 0.12%. Investors took a wait-and-see approach ahead of US inflation data.

site_title: Apple, Samsung to upgrade phone software in India for 5G roll out by December
summary: Apple and Samsung plan to upgrade their 5G phone software in India by December, allowing users to access the high-speed network. Apple will push updates to recent models, including the iPhone 14 and iPhone SE, while Samsung will roll out updates to all its 5G devices by mid-November. The move comes after Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi launched 5G services on October 1, with major telecom operators Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel targeting cities nationwide.

images.alt_text: India has said that launch of 5G will bring high-speed Internet to consumers, with simultaneous socio-economic benefits in sectors like agriculture and health.

site_title: GM takes on Tesla with its own solar power and energy storage system
summary: General Motors (GM) is launching a new business unit, GM Energy, to provide solar panels and home energy storage systems for residential and commercial users. The company is partnering with SunPower to offer a sun-generated power and storage system, similar to Tesla's energy business. The system will be available alongside GM's electric vehicles, including the Chevrolet Silverado, and will also enable buyers to use their vehicle's battery to power their home during blackouts. The initiative aims to provide customers with sustainable energy products and services to mitigate the effect of power outages.

images.alt_text: GM said it sold 555,580 vehicles in the quarter through Sepember, 24 per cent higher than last year when inventory shortages hit sales.

site_title: Japan warns against yen sell-off, eyes intervention
summary: Japan's policymakers warned against yen sell-off, with the currency trading at a 24-year high against the dollar. The US dollar rose to 146.35 yen, prompting speculation about a second round of intervention. Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno said Japan would take "appropriate steps" if necessary, while Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated there was no change in the country's stance. However, neither official used strong language, suggesting intervention may not be imminent, following a previous intervention in September.

images.alt_text: Industries such as autos, steel and textiles weighed on overall manufacturers’ sentiment, while communications, transport and utilities led non-manufacturers.
The Bank of Japan remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation, which has pushed the yen to 24-year lows against the dollar.

site_title: Amro forecasts 7% rebound for Vietnam’s GDP amid demand recovery
summary: Vietnam's GDP is forecast to grow 7% in 2022 and 6.5% in 2023, according to a report by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro). The country's diversified export mix has aided the export sector's recovery, with both manufacturing and services sectors surpassing pre-2019 levels. Private consumption, foreign direct investment, and a supportive fiscal stance have also contributed to the robust recovery. However, tourism and other services continue to lag behind due to the effects of border reopening.

images.alt_text: As governments begin to focus more on solar panel supply chain diversification, South-east Asia could emerge as an important player in sustainable energy production.
A tuk-tuk driver on the streets of Bangkok, Thailand. The post-Covid recovery is well underway in Asean countries, thanks in part to relaxed pandemic measures and border curbs.
The impact of the detention adds to recent pressures on Vietnam’s benchmark index – the world’s second-worst performing primary index over the last month – according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Taiwan says China looking at Ukraine war to develop ‘hybrid’ strategies
summary: China is studying the Ukraine war to develop "hybrid warfare" strategies against Taiwan, including using drones and psychological pressure, according to a senior Taiwanese security official. Taiwan has been monitoring China's military activities, including recent drills, and is preparing for potential threats. China views Taiwan as its own territory and has blamed the island for increasing tensions. Taiwan is seeking support from the US and its allies to deter China's plots to attack the island.

images.alt_text: A United States Navy ship on a transit through the Taiwan Strait. In a hypothetical Taiwan Strait crisis, it is possible that out of the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue – Australia, India, Japan, and the United States – the US would be left to act alone.

site_title: Chip firm Socionext to debut in Tokyo after Japan’s biggest 2022 IPO
summary: Socionext, a Japanese chip design firm, debuted in Tokyo with a 15% jump in its stock price, becoming Japan's largest IPO this year. The company, which develops customised systems-on-chips for clients in the consumer, automotive, and industrial fields, raised 66.8 billion yen ($657.3 million) in its IPO. This performance contrasts with a chip-related stocks rout that wiped out over $240 billion from the sector's global market value, and is in line with recent data showing that semiconductor listings in Tokyo tend to perform well in their first session.

images.alt_text: The US planned to review licences for non-Chinese factories in China hit by the new restrictions on a case-by-case basis.

The US is seeking to ensure that Chinese companies don’t transfer technology to the country’s military and that chipmakers in China don’t develop the capability to make advanced semiconductors themselves.
Lenovo Group remained the top global PC maker, although its shipments fell around 15 per cent, according to Gartner.

site_title: US scrambles to prevent export curbs on China chips from disrupting supply chain
summary: The US is scrambling to address unintended consequences of new export curbs on China's chip industry, which could disrupt the semiconductor supply chain. A temporary fix allowed non-Chinese companies like SK Hynix and Samsung to receive goods for their Chinese chip production facilities without additional licensing. The US plans to review licenses on a case-by-case basis, but this may create delays in shipments. Chinese chip factories are unlikely to receive any reprieve from the restrictions, which aim to slow China's technological and military advances.

images.alt_text: The US is seeking to ensure that Chinese companies don’t transfer technology to the country’s military and that chipmakers in China don’t develop the capability to make advanced semiconductors themselves.

site_title: BOE signals to lenders it is prepared to extend bond purchases: FT
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has signaled to lenders it is prepared to extend its emergency bond-buying program beyond its current deadline of October 14 if market conditions demand it. The central bank has been expanding its daily bond purchases to include inflation-linked debt to address concerns about British financial stability and the potential for a "fire sale" in the bond market. Sterling rose 0.4% to $1.1008 after the report, but volatility remains due to uncertainty about government debt sustainability and pension fund dislocations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England building, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

After finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng alarmed investors with a string of unfunded tax cuts last month, the central bank said on Sep 28 that it would temporarily buy up to £5 billion (S$7.9 billion) a day of gilts with a maturity of at least 20 years.
On Sep 28, the BOE launched a programme to potentially buy up to £65 billion of gilts with a maturity of 20 years in a series of operations running until Oct 14.

site_title: Toyota opens new Myanmar plant put on hold following coup
summary: Toyota has restarted assembling cars at its new Myanmar plant, which was initially put on hold after a military coup in 2021. The plant, located in the Thilawa Special Economic Zone, began producing one or two vehicles a day using parts kits shipped in September. Despite other multinationals pulling out of Myanmar, Toyota aims to contribute to the country's industrial development and support its employees' lives. The decision to restart production was made to comply with relevant laws and regulations, following pressure from Japanese companies and other investors to reevaluate their investments in the country.

images.alt_text: Toyota recalled 2,700 bZ4X sports utility vehicles globally in June, less than two months after it was first rolled out.
GM said it sold 555,580 vehicles in the quarter through Sepember, 24 per cent higher than last year when inventory shortages hit sales.

site_title: Uniqlo owner set for record annual profit, but all eyes on China showing
summary: Fast Retailing, the owner of Uniqlo, is expected to post a record annual profit of 291 billion yen (S$2.9 billion), up 17% from the previous year, driven by strong performances in North America and Europe. The company's overseas sales have benefited from the yen's slump, but investors will closely monitor China, its largest foreign market, for signs of a recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Customers line up outside store of the Uniqlo fast fashion retailer to attend its opening in the Sanlitun shopping district on a polluted day in Beijing, China, November 6, 2021. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: Windfalls from resale exec condos make them an alluring buy for HDB upgraders
summary: Nearly 300 executive condominiums (ECs) yielded at least S$500,000 in resale gross profit, with some units achieving record profits of S$1.38 million and S$1.02 million in 2021. This trend is attracting HDB upgraders, driven by demand exceeding supply. According to OrangeTee analysis, nearly all sampled ECs netted around S$300,000 in gross profits, highlighting the lucrative resale market for ECs.

images.alt_text: Mass market condo sales expected to remain firm despite softening demand from HDB upgraders
Condo resale prices for the rest of the central region (RCR) and the core central region (CCR) were up 1.3 per cent and 1.1 per cent, respectively, on a month-on-month basis.
Copen Grand is the first EC to be built in the Tengah Town area, which is envisioned as Singapore’s first smart and sustainable precinct.

The supply of new ECs will remain limited, according to real estate agency OrangeTee & Tie. Apart from the newly launched North Gaia (pictured) at Yishun Close, most ECs are completely sold or have a handful of balance units.

PropNex anticipates that the median selling price of overall new OCR projects may hover around the S$2,000 psf range in the near-term with Sky Eden@Bedok transacting 118 units at an average price of S$2,100 psf, and Lentor Modern selling 84 per cent of its units also at an average price of about S$2,100 psf.

site_title: Asia: Stocks dive, dollar rallies as dazed traders gird for inflation data
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, with Hong Kong leading losses, as investors await the US inflation report, which could spark another market rout. The dollar surged against the yen and sterling, while the Bank of England announced it will stop emergency bond-buying efforts, sparking concerns about the UK economy. Recession fears and China's economic woes also dragged oil prices down, with many warning of a potential demand plunge.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was hit again by hefty selling in tech firms, dropping the Hang Seng Index below 17,000 points for the first time since late 2011.

site_title: Thailand plans to sell US$1.3b of govt savings bonds by year-end
summary: Thailand plans to sell up to $1.9 billion of government savings bonds by the end of the year to finance its budget deficit. The bonds are part of a planned issue of $1.3 billion, and the central bank's low interest rate of 1.00% is seen as sufficient to attract investors. The move aims to help the country manage its budget deficit and is part of a larger plan to issue $1.3 billion in government savings bonds for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Nasa says Dart mission succeeded in altering asteroid’s trajectory
summary: NASA's Dart mission successfully altered the trajectory of an asteroid, Dimorphos, by 32 minutes after colliding with it on September 26, 2022. The mission, a proof-of-concept for planetary defense, demonstrated the ability to deflect an asteroid from a collision course with Earth. Dimorphos, an egg-shaped asteroid, orbits a larger companion, Didymos, and the Dart spacecraft was designed to create enough force to shift Dimorphos' orbital track. The successful test marks a watershed moment for planetary defense and humanity.

images.alt_text: The renowned observatory has been operating since 1990 about 540 kilometres above Earth, in an orbit that slowly decays over time.

Dart’s celestial target is an asteroid “moonlet” about 170 metres in diameter that orbits a parent asteroid 5 times larger called Didymos as part of a binary pair with the same name, the Greek word for twin.

site_title: Strong interest in auction properties in Q3 prior to Sep 30 cooling measures: SRI
summary: In Singapore, auction properties saw strong interest prior to the Sep 30 cooling measures, with a total of nine properties sold in Q3 2022 for S$18.9 million, bringing the year-to-date sales value to S$70.2 million. Despite the sudden implementation of measures, two units received almost 50 cumulative bids, with one retail unit selling for S$3.43 million and a house for S$3.6 million. Experts predict mortgagee sales may increase in FY2023 as borrowers face rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Owner sale listings more than doubled to 62 properties last quarter, up 121.4 per cent from Q1’s 28.
Knight Frank’s auction and private treaty sales on Wednesday (Jun 29) also boasted several luxury properties.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.44% on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping to 16,758.27. Recession worries and US inflation data are driving investor caution, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision next month. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.08%.

site_title: Gold slips as Fed minutes, inflation data loom
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,663.60 per ounce, near a one-week low, ahead of US Federal Reserve minutes and inflation data. The dollar index and US 10-year Treasury yields were steady. Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester said the central bank needs to press forward with tightening monetary policy despite large rate hikes this year. The International Monetary Fund warned of a recession due to inflation, war-driven crises, and higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainties, rising interest rates reduce the appeal for the asset, which pays no interest.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.11 points to 1388.93. A total of 117.48 million lots were traded worth RM48.47 million, with 149 gainers and 90 losers.

site_title: The global echoes of a British near-collapse
summary: Britain's Conservative Party has implemented a mix of fiscal stimulus and price controls, sparking concerns about an impending economic collapse. This move mirrors past British financial crises that foreshadowed global upheavals, including the 1931 gold standard abandonment, 1976 IMF bailout, and 1992 European exchange-rate mechanism breakup. Political blunders are expected to guarantee the Tories' loss in the next election, drawing lessons from other countries on the effectiveness of such policies in avoiding economic collapse.

images.alt_text: Liz Truss, UK prime minister, delivers her keynote speech during the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference on Wednesday Oct 5.
Finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng will unveil debt-slashing plans and predictions sooner than expected.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall in early trade on Wednesday; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks fell in early trade on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.04% or 1.1 points to 3,103.91. Gainers outnumbered losers 49 to 41, following a volatile session on global stock markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell, while European shares also declined due to concerns about a global economic downturn and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering on Wednesday announced the extension of its partnership with Hawaiian Airlines to perform maintenance checks for 11 of the airline’s A330-200 aircraft into 2027.

site_title: TikTok dives into South-east Asia with e-commerce push
summary: ByteDance's TikTok is expanding its e-commerce presence in South-east Asia, launching businesses in Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Singapore. The platform's e-commerce marketplace, TikTok Shop, has seen significant growth, with sales campaigns in Indonesia doubling and tripling GMV. The region's growing population and improving e-commerce infrastructure are expected to benefit future growth, making South-east Asia a key area for TikTok's global retail push. ByteDance aims to turn a profit through its e-commerce efforts, which are also being tested in the US and Europe with limited success.

images.alt_text: Chinese technology brand Xiaomi is enjoying growing popularity in South-east Asia, overtaking Samsung as market leader in the second quarter of 2021.
Customers queue at a Shein pop-up shop in San Francisco, June 2022.

site_title: China’s economic recovery is balance sheet constrained
summary: China's economic recovery is hindered by balance sheet constraints, with a vast array of contingent liabilities, including local government debt and state-owned policy bank debt. The central government prioritizes maintaining its balance sheet, fearing that a large bailout could destabilize the entire system. Local governments, already over-indebted, struggle to stimulate the economy, and pushing stimulus through them is becoming less feasible. As a result, China's stimulus package has been underwhelming, and the era of fiscal trade-offs has begun, potentially leading to a large-scale stimulus in the future, but with unsustainable financial pressure on local governments.

images.alt_text: China authorities have sought to defuse the deepening property crisis with a raft of measures.
The problems at CIFI highlight the challenges for Chinese authorities as they seek to prevent a slump in the property industry from fuelling broader financial market contagion.
The People's Bank of China said Chinese banks extended 2.47 trillion yuan (S$481.3 billion) in new yuan loans in September, jumping from 1.25 trillion yuan in August.

site_title: Residential property rents, volumes up in September amid ‘landlord’s market’
summary: Residential property rents in Singapore increased by 3-4% in September, with condo rentals rising for the 21st consecutive month. Condo rental prices grew 30.9% year-over-year, while HDB rents rose 24.7% on year. Volumes also remained strong, with an estimated 4,760 condo units rented out and 1,809 HDB units. Experts predict continued growth, with some estimating a 10% increase in rents for the fourth quarter of 2022. The "landlord's market" is expected to continue, driven by strong rental demand and limited housing options.

images.alt_text: The robust take-up of new project launches, such as Piccadilly Grand and Liv@MB in the RCR, have re-ignited market engines and contributed to an acceleration of home prices in Q2 2022. In the OCR, the launches of AMO Residence (pictured) in July and, more recently, Sky Eden@Bedok, were also met with positive reception.
According to Huttons, rents of private homes are estimated to increase up to 10 per cent in H2 2022.
pixgenerics/ST20220629_202283358097/Ng Sor Luan/Generic photos of HDB flats for story on home loans rates increasing.

site_title: South Korea delivers another big hike as Fed rates sink local currency
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea raised its benchmark policy rate by 50 basis points to 3.00% as inflation continues to rise, largely due to a strong US dollar and higher import prices. The move aims to combat inflation, which has surged to near a 24-year high in July. Analysts expect further rate hikes, with some predicting the base rate could reach 3.75% by next year. The decision contrasts with the Reserve Bank of Australia's smaller-than-expected hike last week.

images.alt_text: Rising commodity prices, supply-chain snags and slowing demand for semiconductors have been among the factors weighing on exports.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher as financials advance
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% to 6,662.7 as financials gained ground, outweighing losses in mining and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 0.3% on Tuesday. The gains were driven by a 6.5% rise in Coronoado Global Resources, which is in talks with Peabody Energy for a potential merger. Financials, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Bank of Queensland, also rose, while mining stocks fell due to a drop in iron ore prices.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.3 per cent lower at 6,645 points.

site_title: Hot stock: Leader Environmental Tech hits year-to-date high after investment announcement
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies, a mainboard-listed company, received a US$15 million, zero-coupon convertible bond investment commitment from China's InnoVision Capital. This investment led to the company's shares reaching a year-to-date high of S$0.082, up 36.7% from Monday's closing price. The conversion bonds have a three-year tenure with an option to extend the maturity date. The investment is expected to accelerate the company's growth in sludge treatment and artificial intelligence water management businesses.

images.alt_text: Leader Environmental Tech enters S$10m JV with Nanosun to set up membrane-making facilities
Leader Environmental Tech tumbles on CAD probe of two executives
Leader Environmental Tech CEO, deputy CTO in CAD probe on insider trading
Leader Environmental Tech terminates proposed placement, mulls rights issue instead

site_title: Disney pushes back several Marvel movie release dates
summary: Disney is pushing back release dates for several Marvel movies, including Avengers: Secret Wars, Blade, Fantastic Four, and an untitled Marvel project. Blade was initially set for November 3, 2023, but has been rescheduled for September 6, 2024, due to director Bassam Tariq's departure. Deadpool 3 and Fantastic Four have also been moved, with Deadpool 3 now set for November 8, 2024, and Fantastic Four for February 14, 2025. Avengers: Secret Wars has been pushed back to May 1, 2026. The delays are reportedly to find a suitable replacement for Tariq.

images.alt_text: Arts Minister Tony Burke announced the deal on Monday (Oct 10) at Sydney’s Disney Studios, which has been renamed from Fox Studios Australia.
Insider Intelligence analyst Ross Benes estimates that advertising revenues from streaming could reach US$30 billion in two years in the United States alone.

site_title: Toshiba chooses JIP-led group as preferred bidder for buyout
summary: Toshiba has chosen a consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) as the preferred bidder for a potential buyout, according to people familiar with the situation. The JIP-led group, which includes Orix and Chubu Electric Power, aims to acquire Toshiba while keeping the company as one entity. Toshiba had targeted second-round offers by the end of September and shares rose 2.2% following the announcement. JIP has a month to negotiate terms, but it's unclear if an agreement can be reached.

images.alt_text: The logo of Japanese industrial group Toshiba is seen on top of a building at its headquarters in Tokyo on June 2, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Real estate’s ESG push needs resilience as a fourth pillar
summary: Real estate players must consider the importance of resilience beyond the ESG framework to address global challenges. As climate change and extreme weather events become more frequent, buildings and spaces must be designed to adapt and be resilient. This involves three key areas: the resilience of buildings themselves, the resilience of technology within buildings, and how technology supports building resilience. Implementing technology to optimize building performance and gather data for better decision-making is crucial to achieving ESG and resilience goals, and avoiding "stranded assets" that become unusable.

images.alt_text: The design of this commercial building in Bukit Timah Road incorporates a new overhang to expand the amount of rooftop space available for solar panels.
