JLL's study found that 42 per cent of corporates has already signed a lease incorporating green clauses as at June 2022.

site_title: Deutsche Bank taps Credit Suisse executive as Asia wealth head
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Young Jin Yee, a veteran Credit Suisse executive, as head of private banking in Asia-Pacific. Yee, who has over 20 years of experience at Credit Suisse, will start at Deutsche Bank next year and be based in Singapore, replacing Lok Yim. This is one of the most senior hires from Credit Suisse, and follows the promotion of Benjamin Cavalli to regional head of private banking. The move aims to bolster Deutsche Bank's wealth management services in the region, which has seen weak revenue momentum in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank has signed a 25-year lease for the 568,500 square foot property and will pay rent of £38 million a year.
Sharma's appointment follows a slew of changes at the German investment bank, including the appointment of Darren Boulos in Sydney as co-head of gobal foreign exchange (GFX) for APAC.

site_title: Japan manufacturers’ mood sours, higher costs dim outlook: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence among big manufacturers fell for the second consecutive month, reaching its lowest level in five months, according to a Reuters poll. The decline is attributed to global inflation, a weak yen, and increased import costs. The poll also predicts a further deterioration in manufacturers' mood over the next three months, while the service sector is expected to rebound. A weak yen and price hikes are particularly affecting the materials sectors among manufacturers, with the specter of a global slowdown also weighing on the outlook.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation, which has pushed the yen to 24-year lows against the dollar.

site_title: Intel plans thousands of job cuts in face of PC slowdown
summary: Intel plans to cut thousands of jobs due to a decline in demand for PC processors, a major contributor to the company's revenue. The layoffs, potentially affecting around 20% of staff, will be announced alongside the third-quarter earnings report on October 27. This move aims to reduce costs by 10-15% and follows a broader slowdown in the tech industry, with PC sales tumbling 15% in Q3. Intel's shares have fallen over 50% in 2022, and the company faces pressure to shore up its profits amid intense competition and US export curbs on China.

images.alt_text: Intel’s latest Core desktop processors will provide gamers and other high-performance users with a significant boost.

site_title: SIA Engineering extends maintenance agreement with Hawaiian Airlines, inks new deal with MYAirline
summary: SIA Engineering Co, a Singapore-based aircraft maintenance provider, has extended its maintenance agreement with Hawaiian Airlines for 11 A330-200 aircraft until 2027. The company has also signed a 10-year agreement with MYAirline to provide support services for the airline's Airbus A320 fleet. The deals are not expected to significantly impact SIAEC's earnings or net tangible assets. The agreements demonstrate confidence in SIAEC's technical capabilities and capabilities, with senior executives citing best-in-class on-time performance and quality services.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering opens new S$9m aircraft engine services facility in Singapore
SIA Engineering inks 10-year maintenance deal with Rolls-Royce
SIA Engineering reported a 15.3 per cent fall in profit after tax even as the aviation industry shows signs of recovery

site_title: Regulators propose first global rules before ‘crypto winter’ thaw
summary: Regulators have proposed the first global rules for cryptocurrencies, aiming to prevent a potential "crypto winter" that wiped US$2 trillion off the sector. The Financial Stability Board recommends that cryptoasset companies set aside capital like banks, establish oversight frameworks, and manage risks and data. The proposals seek cross-border consistency and are part of efforts to regulate the sector before a likely recovery. The rules are expected to be finalized by mid-2023 and implemented by G20 members, with the European Union set to finalize its own regulations in 2024.

images.alt_text: Coinbase has around 100 employees in Singapore.
Before the clampdown, China was emerging as the epicentre of the crypto world, spawning giant exchanges like Binance Holdings and the biggest Bitcoin mining firms.

site_title: Singapore’s reopening boom draws big money and bubble fears
summary: Singapore is experiencing a significant economic boom, attracting big money and talent from around the world. The city-state's reopening has drawn record crowds to events like the Formula 1 car race, with some attendees paying up to $70,000 for a nightclub table. Foreign investors, including hedge fund titan Ray Dalio and Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani, are setting up offices in Singapore, driving up property prices and rents. The government is introducing new visa rules to attract high-skilled talent, but faces challenges in balancing the cost of living surging with the influx of foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Visitor arrivals in September hit 752,305, from 728,744 in August, recording eight straight months of growth, according to data from the Singapore Tourism Board (STB).

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (extreme left), at a dialogue with social service practitioners, outlined his vision for a fairer and more inclusive society with better support for lower-income families, seniors and those starting and raising families.

site_title: Google expands cloud to more regions, adds new AI capabilities
summary: Google has expanded its cloud infrastructure to more regions, including Austria, the Czech Republic, Greece, Norway, South Africa, and Sweden, with plans to build data centers locally or partner with existing players. The company also introduced new AI capabilities, such as Vertex AI Vision and Translation Hub, and updated its Tensor processing unit and C3 machine series with fourth-generation Intel chips. Additionally, Google announced new cryptocurrency support and cybersecurity initiatives, including a partnership with Nvidia and Coinbase.

images.alt_text: Google's new facility, based in Inzai City, Chiba, will accelerate the operation of its tools and services, and support economic activity and jobs.
Pixel Watch is equipped with an on-board app store, Google Wallet for mobile payments and Fitbit health sensors and workout services.

site_title: F1’s lessons for mental health
summary: Formula One's return to racing in Singapore has drawn parallels with the need for workplace mental health. A new index, developed by a coalition of corporate, academic, and nonprofit partners, aims to measure and improve mental health in the workplace. The index assesses programmes and practices that support workforce mental well-being and provides recommendations for enhancements. With over 75% of full-time workers in the US reporting symptoms of mental health conditions, the index seeks to introduce a more quantitative and objective approach using data. Employers are encouraged to use the index to define what "good" mental health looks like in the workplace, and to reduce the costs associated with mental health issues, estimated to be between $17 billion and $44 billion annually in the US.

images.alt_text: Towards sustainable giving : Instead of only writing that big cheque in a very profitable year, Corporate Singapore can lead by allowing customers to “round up” credit card or utility bill payments for charity.
Employers can tap various people data sources to identify those at risk of mental health issues.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, October 12, 2022, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.08% at 26,380.04. The decline follows a mixed close on Wall Street amid a downcast IMF economic outlook and concerns over inflation. The broader Topix index slipped 0.16%. Investors remain cautious about the impact of inflation, with US-EU tariffs in focus.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA Engineering, Q&M Dental, Trek 2000, Singtel
summary: SIA Engineering extended its partnership with Hawaiian Airlines to maintain 11 A330-200 aircraft until 2027. Q&M Dental won a Ministry of Health contract worth at least S$3.6 million for Joint Testing and Vaccination Centres. Trek 2000's founder was sentenced to 16 months' imprisonment for conspiracies to falsify accounts. Singtel's Optus received notices of intention from Australian authorities to investigate a cyberattack.

site_title: BNY Mellon to offer crypto services in digital asset push
summary: BNY Mellon, a 238-year-old bank, is expanding its services to include cryptocurrencies, becoming the first systemically important US bank to store digital currencies. The bank has won New York's financial regulator approval and will offer cryptocurrencies alongside traditional assets. This move aims to attract investors and traders, following a surge in trading popularity. BNY Mellon formed a unit in 2021 to develop digital asset solutions, citing over 90% of institutional investors' interest in the segment.

site_title: Meta debuts US$1,500 VR headset targeting working professionals
summary: Meta has unveiled the Meta Quest Pro, a high-end virtual reality (VR) headset designed for working professionals and creators, priced at $1,500. The device features face- and eye-tracking, a "full-colour mixed reality experience", and new "self-tracking" controllers. The headset aims to broaden Meta's audience beyond gamers and is part of the company's vision for the metaverse, a immersive digital future. Meta is partnering with Microsoft to offer office productivity software on the new devices, as the company seeks to promote the Quest Pro as a tool for working remotely.

images.alt_text: Facebook and Instagram have been inaccessible in Russia since March.
Meta executives said the new formats could lure Reels creators with ways to earn money from ad placements next to their videos.
Meta has been consolidating its New York workforce, building out offices in Hudson Yards and moving ahead with plans for the Farley Building near Pennsylvania Station.

site_title: Russia adds Meta to ‘terrorist and extremist’ groups list
summary: Russia has added Meta, the parent company of Instagram and Facebook, to its list of "terrorist and extremist" organizations. This move comes after the social media platforms allowed statements against Russian invaders, despite earlier restrictions. Meta had previously announced changes to its policies, but the ban on Facebook and Instagram remains in place. The decision puts Meta on the same list as groups like the Taliban and Russian opposition groups, and could lead to prosecution for users and companies that advertise on the platforms.

images.alt_text: Meta executives said the new formats could lure Reels creators with ways to earn money from ad placements next to their videos.
Meta has been consolidating its New York workforce, building out offices in Hudson Yards and moving ahead with plans for the Farley Building near Pennsylvania Station.

site_title: Crypto startup funding plunges to lowest level in over a year
summary: Crypto startup funding plummeted to its lowest level in over a year, with venture capital investments declining 37% to $4.44 billion in the third quarter of 2022. This drop mirrors broader declines in technology investing, but crypto's high risk and plunging cryptocurrency prices are particularly severe. Despite this, dedicated crypto funds continue to back startups, and some founders remain committed to their decentralized visions. Exceptions include NFT and gaming investments, where investors are interested in use cases and potential advertising opportunities.

images.alt_text: Coinbase has around 100 employees in Singapore.
The proposals seek cross-border consistency to regulating crypto-assets, particularly as the European Union finalises groundbreaking rules to regulate the sector from 2024.
The 238-year-old bank won the approval of New York’s financial regulator earlier this fall and is the first of the eight systemically important US banks to store digital currencies.

site_title: Central banks 'must act resolutely' to lower inflation: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged central banks to "act resolutely" to lower inflation, warning that entrenched inflation pressures could have severe consequences for the global economy. The IMF's Global Financial Stability Report notes that central banks should bring down inflation figures, echoing earlier comments from the fund's chief Kristalina Georgieva. The report also highlights the challenges faced by both advanced and emerging economies, citing supply chain problems, rising interest rates, and volatile commodity markets.

images.alt_text: The IMF calculates that about one-third of the world economy will have at least two consecutive quarters of contraction this year and next, and that the lost output through 2026 will be US$4 trillion.

site_title: Thai buyer pays record S$3,850 psf for top floor of Suntec Tower One
summary: A Thai buyer has paid a record S$3,850 per square foot (psf) for the top floor of Suntec Tower One in Singapore, valued at S$39.7 million. This is the highest whole-floor price in Suntec City. The two-tier office investment market in Singapore continues, with institutional investors cautious due to rising interest rates, while ultra-high-net-worth individuals and family offices are buying choice commercial properties as a hedge against inflation. This marks a fresh record psf price for a whole office floor at Suntec City.

images.alt_text:
When completed in 2026, Solitaire on Cecil will rise to 127 metres and comprise predominantly office space, which will be on 15 levels ranging from 11,000 sq ft to 13,000 sq ft.




Source: Solitaire Cecil Pte Ltd
Two of the 3 residential blocks of the Draycott Eight condo.

krcommercial16 - Exterior shots of the three-storey shophouse property at 11 Bali Lane on 15 August, 2022.

ST PHOTO: SYAMIL SAPARI

site_title: Asean set to play key role in global solar supply chain
summary: South-east Asia, comprising Asean countries, is poised to play a significant role in the global solar supply chain, driven by high electricity demand and government policies. The region's solar energy development has accelerated, with countries such as Thailand, Vietnam, and Singapore embarking on various solar power projects. The Asean region has the potential to become a key player in the solar industry, with an estimated US$20 billion opportunity by 2030. Despite challenges, such as land scarcity and transportation infrastructure issues, Asean countries are expected to continue stepping up efforts to develop sustainable solar energy through regulatory policies, technology, and regional collaborative partnerships.

images.alt_text: Growth of the Islamic financing industry in South-east Asia is mainly led by Malaysia and Indonesia, amid supportive regulatory environment and strong government support.
South-east Asia's favourable climate and fertile soil make it a major crop grower. The region is home to key producers of  palm oil, rice and dried beans.

site_title: IMF cuts 2023 global growth, warns major economies to stall
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its 2023 global growth forecast to 2.7%, citing the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, soaring food and energy prices, and economic downturns. The fund warns that more than a third of the global economy is headed for contraction this year or next, with the US, EU, and China expected to stall. Global inflation is expected to peak at 9.5% this year before dropping to 4.1% by 2024, and the IMF cautions that central banks' efforts to control inflation could have detrimental effects on macroeconomic stability.

images.alt_text: Trucks drive past stacked containers at the Sun Kwang Newport Container Terminal (SNCT) in Incheon New Port in Incheon, South Korea, on Wednesday, June 15, 2022. Striking truckers in South Korea reached an agreement with the government, ending a weeklong strike that threatened the nation’s economy and added to strains on global supply chains. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

The IMF calculates that about one-third of the world economy will have at least two consecutive quarters of contraction this year and next, and that the lost output through 2026 will be US$4 trillion.

site_title: Ex-HBO CEO Albrecht on leave at Legendary amid book scandal
summary: Former HBO CEO Chris Albrecht has been placed on leave at Legendary Entertainment amid allegations in a new book that he disparaged a staffer who left HBO decades ago. Albrecht denies the allegations, stating he has apologized to those he offended. The move comes after a settlement and allegations of misconduct at HBO in the past, including a $400,000 payment to a female subordinate in 1991. Albrecht has served as president of Legendary Television since joining the company in 2019.

site_title: Amazon’s second Prime Day sale falls flat on social media
summary: Amazon's second Prime Day sale has generated little enthusiasm on social media, with 70% fewer Twitter mentions compared to the previous event in June. This may indicate consumer fatigue and a potential harbinger for the holiday shopping season, which is expected to see a 2.5% growth in US online spending. Despite this, Amazon has an opportunity to win market share and stand out from traditional retailers. However, some experts warn consumers to be cautious of "Price Increase and List Price Synchronisation," a phenomenon where merchants increase prices to make discounts appear more attractive.

site_title: Honda to build JV US battery plant, retool Ohio plants
summary: Honda and LG Energy Solution have announced a US$4.4 billion joint-venture battery plant in Ohio, initially investing US$3.5 billion and creating 2,200 jobs. Honda will also retool three Ohio plants, investing US$700 million and adding 300 jobs. The plant aims to produce 40GWh of annual capacity, starting mass production of lithium-ion batteries by the end of 2025. Honda plans to begin EV production in North America in 2026, with a goal of 100% EV sales by 2040.

site_title: Oil settles lower on China Covid flare-up, recession fear
summary: Oil prices settled 2% lower on October 11, extending a decline, due to recession fears and a China Covid flare-up. Brent crude fell to $94.29 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude to $89.35 a barrel. The World Bank and IMF warned of a growing risk of global recession and ongoing inflation issues.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$96.19 a barrel, down US$1.73, or 1.8 per cent on Monday.

site_title: China new bank lending nearly doubles after central bank help
summary: China's banks extended 2.47 trillion yuan in new loans in September, nearly doubling from August and exceeding expectations. The central bank's efforts to spur economic growth after a property crisis and Covid-19 resurgence appear to be paying off. Household and corporate loans rose significantly, with total social financing growing 10.6% in September. Analysts expect the economic recovery to continue, but policymakers face challenges due to capital flight and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: The PBOC said that China’s solid economic fundamentals were the best stabiliser for exchange rates, adding yuan assets were safe and “global recognition of the yuan will keep rising.”

site_title: More concerted efforts needed to help retail investors make informed decisions
summary: Singapore needs a more concerted effort to provide retail investors with high-quality investment research, enabling them to make informed decisions in today's uncertain economic environment. Initiatives such as the Grant for Equity Market Singapore (Gems) scheme have been successful in developing local equity research talent, but more needs to be done to spur public market activity and address market gaps. Private companies can consider partnering with the Gems Initiative Grant, and innovative methods of partnership can also be explored to extend equity research services to more retail investors.

images.alt_text: smartphone, hand, stocks
An earlier attempt by the Singapore Exchange to boost research coverage of smaller firms started strong but eventually petered out.
Sias working on new initiatives to stay relevant to investors

site_title: Placing sustainability at the heart of business
summary: Businesses are recognizing the importance of sustainability as climate change becomes increasingly evident. Companies must adjust their business models to accommodate environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) issues to remain relevant. Integrating sustainability through the entire value chain, including suppliers, can mitigate environmental and reputational risks. Firms can start by measuring and tracking data for key ESG issues, and adopting sustainable practices can ultimately make economic sense in the long run, with benefits exceeding initial investment costs.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit over one-week low as recession worries weigh
summary: European shares plummeted to a one-week low, falling 0.6% on the Stoxx 600 index, amid recession worries and rising interest rates. The decline marks the fifth straight session of losses, with financials and technology stocks bearing the brunt. The European market's decline is fueled by concerns over a global economic downturn and aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, which is expected to continue its fight against inflation.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.7 per cent to 6,913.13 points.

site_title: European weapons manufacturers scramble to adapt to wartime demand
summary: European arms manufacturers are scrambling to adapt to wartime demand for the war in Ukraine, with industry executives urging the EU to coordinate weapons procurement to boost production and replenish stocks. The industry has been geared up for EU states spending less on defence, not more, after decades of peace. Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg has started dialogue with industry and allies to address the surge in demand for military equipment. The EU has agreed to provide more financial and military aid to Ukraine, and manufacturers are seeking help to recruit staff and increase production capacity.

images.alt_text: Russia launched 83 missile strikes at Ukraine on Monday (Oct 10) fired from Astrakhan in southern Russia, 43 of which were intercepted.

site_title: US banks seen building US$5b in reserves as recession risks grow
summary: US banks are expected to set aside nearly $5 billion in the third quarter to cover potential loan losses amid growing fears of a recession. The reserve build out could be the biggest drag on bank profits, according to analysts. JPMorgan Chase's CEO warned of a recession in the next six to nine months, while Citigroup is expected to build the biggest reserves, totaling $1.51 billion. Despite this, some analysts believe the banking industry is more resilient than before, with higher interest income from Fed rate increases.

site_title: ‘Fire sale’ risk in bonds pushes BOE to step up measures
summary: The Bank of England has stepped up measures to prevent a disorderly market from threatening the UK's financial stability, amid a "fire sale" risk in bonds. The central bank expanded its bond purchases to include inflation-linked debt, buying up to £10 billion in conventional and index-linked gilts. The move aimed to calm market turbulence, with the yield on 10-year inflation-linked securities dropping 12 basis points and a £900 million government bond sale seeing strong investor appetite. However, investors warn that the repeated interventions are eroding the central bank's credibility and that addressing the underlying cause of the problem is key.

images.alt_text: The number of people classed as inactive - neither in work nor looking for it - rose by 252,000 from the three months to May, the biggest such increase since records began in 1971.
Despite the raft of announcements, yields shot up across the range of British debt maturities including in the long-dated conventional gilt market.

site_title: STI 10-year return beats SSB’s 3.21% interest, but only by a shade
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) offer a 10-year average interest rate of 3.21% per annum, beating the Straits Times Index (STI) return over the same period. While the SSB's return is lower than that of US stock indices, it is comparable to regional stock indices. Investors favor SSBs for their low risk and attractive returns, with nearly S$3.5 billion issued in the past five months. The current SSB interest rate is favorable, with potential for further hikes from the US Federal Reserve, making it an attractive option for diversifying a portfolio in uncertain times.

images.alt_text: Singapore Savings Bonds have gotten higher interest from investors amid a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases in Singapore more than double from previous day, but severe cases remain low
summary: Singapore reported 11,732 new Covid-19 cases on October 11, more than doubling from the previous day. The spike is largely driven by the XBB variant, but severe cases remain low, with 11 ICU cases and 50 requiring oxygen supplementation. The Ministry of Health attributes the low severe cases to vaccination and previous waves of infection. Most patients report mild symptoms, with a large majority experiencing sore throats or slight fevers.

images.alt_text: The Moderna bivalent vaccine targets the original Sars-CoV-2 strain of the virus as well as the Omicron BA.1 variant.

site_title: Yellen calls on G20 to boost aid for food insecurity, offers debt freeze
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged G20 countries to increase aid for food insecurity, particularly for 70 million people at risk due to Russia's war in Ukraine. Yellen called for debt freeze and opposed food export restrictions, stating that US sanctions do not target agricultural commodities. The US has pledged nearly $10 billion in assistance this year and will support temporary debt service standstills for countries in need.

site_title: US consumers’ inflation views ease for next year but worsen for long term
summary: US consumers expect inflation to cool moderately over the next year, with median one-year ahead inflation expectations falling to 5.44% in September, down from 5.75% in the prior month. However, expectations for inflation three years from now (2.91%) and five years ahead (6.6%) have increased. Grocery prices remain a major concern, with food inflation expectations rising to 6.9%. The Federal Reserve prioritizes controlling inflation, with interest rates expected to rise by 75 basis points for a fourth-straight meeting next month.

site_title: Representation from the ranks is what platform workers want
summary: Platform workers are seeking representation from within their ranks to ensure their concerns and views are heard by companies and authorities. A dialogue session with the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers found that 77% of platform workers are paying off a housing loan and 66% have been injured while working, with 84% feeling inadequately covered by companies for work-related injuries. The committee recommends that platform workers have their own representative to advocate for their needs, which would provide a collective voice to fight for basic protections and conditions.

images.alt_text: The TWG includes members from ComfortDelGro, Grab, Lalamove and foodpanda.
Extending Wica to platform workers will likely introduce new complexities for the companies and their insurers.

site_title: Pregnant flight attendants can now keep jobs: Singapore Airlines
summary: Singapore Airlines has ended its practice of terminating flight attendants after they become pregnant, allowing eligible cabin crew to keep their jobs. Pregnant flight attendants will now receive paid maternity leave and can resume flying duties after their leave. Those who want to return to flying after giving birth must apply for a temporary ground position, which is subject to availability and relevant skills. The airline's change comes after criticism from women's rights groups, with the Association of Women for Action and Research calling it a "major step forward."

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways has been named the world’s best airline at the Skytrax World Airline Awards 2022.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly down amid growing recession fears
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly down amid growing recession fears, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1% to 29,239.19. The International Monetary Fund's 2.7% growth forecast for 2023, down 0.2 points from July, contributed to the decline. Investors are also wary of a difficult earnings season and the potential end of emergency bond-buying efforts by the Bank of England, which may destabilize markets.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 opened lower by 16.53 points, or 0.46 per cent, at 3,595.86, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 57.73 points, or 0.55 per cent, to 10,484.37 at the opening bell.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 19.18 points lower on Tuesday, at 1,386.82, with 786 losers outweighing 197 gainers. The index saw a trading volume of 2.349 billion lots worth RM1.859 billion.

site_title: Q&M subsidiary wins tender to operate joint testing and vaccination centre
summary: Q&M Dental Group's subsidiary, Acumen Diagnostics, has won a 15-month contract to operate a Joint Testing and Vaccination Centre, with operations starting from Nov 21. The contract is estimated to be worth at least S$3.6 million. The Moderna/Spikevax bivalent vaccine will be available from this Friday, targeting those who have yet to achieve maximum protection and those aged 50 and above.

site_title: LVMH sales jump as strong dollar boosts Europe demand
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods group, reported a sharp rise in sales in the third quarter, driven by strong demand in Europe, the US, and Japan. The company attributed the growth to a strong dollar and improved business in China, where Covid-19 curbs have eased. Despite this, Tiffany & Co sales in the US were slowing. Affluent consumers have shown resilience to inflationary pressures, maintaining demand for luxury goods despite a cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: LVMH said 27,000 of its staff in France would be able to qualify for this bonus, which would range from 1,000-1,500 euros.

FILE PHOTO: Customers wearing face masks following the COVID-19 outbreak walk past a store of French luxury brand Louis Vuitton inside a shopping mall in Beijing, China September 19, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: New Biden labour rule would make some contractors employees
summary: The US Department of Labor proposed a rule that would make it more difficult for companies to treat workers as independent contractors, potentially leading to more workers being classified as employees and receiving benefits and protections. The rule considers factors such as profit or loss, job permanency, and company control to determine employee status. The move is expected to shake up industries that rely on gig workers, including ridesharing and delivery services, and could increase costs for companies by up to 30%.

site_title: Europe rushing to secure gas sparks record high LNG ship rates
summary: Europe's surge in securing gas for winter has led to record-high liquefied natural gas (LNG) ship rates, surpassing $397,500 per day in the Atlantic, a new high set in the Pacific last year. The shortage of available ships is forcing buyers to pay astronomical rates or risk not being able to transport the fuel. Energy majors are refusing to lease their vessels due to fear of being left without ships during winter. LNG exporters in Asia are selling gas directly from loading ports, further exacerbating the shortage.

site_title: Germany’s Scholz to visit China next month; trip to focus on business, Russian ties
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz plans to visit China around November 3-4 to discuss business interests and human rights violations. The trip aims to clarify China's role in the Russia-Ukraine conflict and will be part of a broader effort to reshape Germany's strategy in the Asia-Pacific region. Scholz seeks better ties with Chinese President Xi Jinping despite differences and aims to diversify business ties, not decouple from China. This visit comes as European companies continue to invest in China, with investment from the EU increasing by 15% in the first half of 2022.

images.alt_text: Surging gas prices and Moscow’s move to squeeze supplies to Europe have already prompted a series of government bailouts and rescue loans for energy firms.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on earnings anxiety
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Tuesday, October 11, 2022, due to investor anxiety over the upcoming earnings season, which will assess the impact of rising interest rates and inflation on corporate profits. The S&P 500 fell 16.53 points, or 0.46%, to 3,595.86, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 57.73 points, or 0.55%, to 10,484.37.

site_title: Thailand plans 5 billion baht Phuket Medical Hub to boost tourism
summary: Thailand's government approved a 5 billion baht (S$188.6 million) international medical hub in Phuket, aiming to boost health and wellness tourism. Construction will start next year, with completion by 2027. The hub will include a hospital, research facility, and training center, generating 62 billion baht in annual revenue from health and tourism services. The project aligns with Thailand's 20-year national strategy to become a high-income country by 2037.

site_title: China central bank says will ‘resolutely’ curb big currency swings
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, announced it will take measures to stabilize exchange rates and curb big currency swings. The bank stated that China's solid economic fundamentals will stabilize exchange rates and that yuan assets are safe, with global recognition of the yuan expected to rise. The yuan has slumped over 11% against the US dollar this year, but the PBOC has ample policy room and experience to manage market expectations and maintain stability. The bank will deepen currency market reforms and improve flexibility of the yuan.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was up 0.1 per cent at 113.14, inching towards the 20-year high of 114.78 it touched late last month.

site_title: Families gather for cremation of Thai nursery attack victims
summary: Families in Thailand gathered for the cremation of 19 victims killed in a nursery massacre, marking the end of three days of rites. The mass ceremony is unusual as bodies are normally cremated alone, but the area's small temples have been overwhelmed by the number of victims. The attack, which claimed 36 lives, including 24 children, was carried out by a former police officer who was armed with a gun and knife and took his own life. An investigation into the massacre has been ordered, with police planning to interview 180 witnesses.

images.alt_text: The motive behind the crime was unclear but the suspect, identified as Panya Kamrab, was believed to be under the influence of drugs, a local police official said.

site_title: US dollar edges higher, yen slips towards level that prompted intervention
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 113.14, nearing a 20-year high of 114.78, due to concerns over rising interest rates and geopolitical tensions. The yen slipped to 145.86 per US dollar, near the level that prompted Japan's intervention last month, while the euro and pound also faced downward pressure. Risk appetite was hurt by ongoing conflict in Ukraine and new US export controls, with analysts warning of potential further intervention from the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Mercedes car sales jump defying growing global economic gloom
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a 21% increase in global vehicle sales to 517,800 units in the third quarter, defying the growing economic gloom. Demand in China led strong growth in all key regions, with deliveries in Europe rising 18% despite energy bill concerns. The luxury car maker's electric vehicle sales more than doubled to 30,000 units. This contrasts with key competitor BMW's flat quarterly sales, highlighting Mercedes' resilience in the market.

site_title: Singapore’s visitor arrivals at new high in September, but tourism recovery is slowing
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals reached a new high of 778,141 in September, with eight consecutive months of growth, according to the Singapore Tourism Board. This marks a significant increase from August's 728,744 arrivals, but still falls short of the 1.46 million visitors in September 2019. Analysts attribute the slowdown to global and regional macroeconomic challenges, as well as increased competition from other destinations. Despite this, the tourism sector is expected to exceed 6 million visitors this year, within the upper band of the official forecast, with corporate travelers driving the recovery.

images.alt_text: Singapore has received some 3.7 million international visitor arrivals this year, with about 2.2 million arriving in Q3.

site_title: India to press Apple, Samsung for faster 5G software upgrades in phones
summary: India's government will push Apple, Samsung, and other mobile phone manufacturers to prioritize software upgrades for 5G support in the country. Many Apple and Samsung models, including the latest iPhone 14 and several Samsung premier phones, are not compatible with India's 5G network. Industry sources and Airtel's website confirm that Apple and Samsung are working on software upgrades, with a meeting scheduled to discuss prioritization and release of these updates. The goal is to ensure high-speed internet access for consumers, particularly in sectors like agriculture and health.

site_title: Citi Private Bank sees strong growth in family office business in Asia
summary: Citi Private Bank reports strong growth in its family office business in Asia, with a 40% increase in the past two years. The Asia-Pacific accounts for a quarter of the bank's topline revenue and 40% of its headcount. Global head Ida Liu attributes the growth to proactive hedging on portfolios and allocations into alternative investments, with clients prioritizing concerns such as recession, interest rates, and Russia. The bank has seen double-digit topline revenue growth in the region for five-plus years, with a focus on helping families establish their family office presence in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Mukesh Ambani is the latest in a series of ultra-rich people to pick Singapore for their family offices.

site_title: Credit Suisse may face US$8b capital shortfall in 2024
summary: Credit Suisse is facing a potential capital shortfall of up to $8 billion in 2024, according to Goldman Sachs analysts. The Zurich-based firm needs to restructure its investment banking operations, which is expected to result in a minimum capital shortfall of 4 billion francs ($5.76 billion). To address this, Credit Suisse may consider raising capital, but executives prefer not to issue equity due to low share prices. The bank is exploring asset sales, including its securitized products unit, and may bring in an outside investor to support a spinoff of its advisory and investment bank businesses.

images.alt_text: “The transactions are consistent with our proactive approach to managing our overall liability composition and optimising interest expense and allow us to take advantage of market conditions to repurchase debt at attractive prices,” the bank said in a statement

site_title: Integrity disclosures improve among South-east Asia listcos, but Singapore loses ground on regional leaders
summary: South-east Asia's listed companies have improved their integrity disclosures, with Thailand and Malaysia taking the top spots. Thailand led with an 83% disclosure level, followed by Malaysia with 81%, and Singapore in third place with 69%. The study, conducted by the Securities Investor Association (Singapore) and others, found that Singapore's performance was dragged down by weaker external commitments to anti-corruption. Overall, the average disclosure level for the five countries improved to 69% from 63% in 2020.

images.alt_text: The G20/OECD Principles of Corporate Governance are well-regarded, but are they still relevant to markets today? Panellists at the Sias Corporate Governance Conference debate their merits.
Mercer has advised clients to invest 5 to 10 per cent of portfolios in China A-shares, which it says has potential for "outsized alpha''.
Efforts to capture carbon, such as in this facility in Shanghai, need to take in the views of and weigh the impact on the communities that will be affected by them.
Investing in environmental technology, while paying heed to national agenda, can deliver not just financial returns, but environmental impact as well.

site_title: Berlin has no plans to support joint EU debt for loans: source
summary: Germany has no plans to support a joint European Union debt issuance, according to a government source, contradicting a media report that suggested Chancellor Olaf Scholz backed the plan. The German Economic Council criticized the EU plan, calling it irresponsible due to current inflation levels, which is causing market fluctuations. The council's secretary general warned that a worsening of government budgets could result from more debt. The report's announcement caused significant market movements, prompting the council to intervene.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: European stock markets fell further at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.7% to 6,913.13 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX index and Paris CAC 40 also declined 0.8% each. Investors are worried that massive interest rate hikes will tip the global economy into recession. The losses come as traders weigh the impact of US-EU trade talks and the ongoing US Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the entrance of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain. Aug 23, 2018. REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Mahathir to defend Langkawi seat at Malaysia election, but no plans to become PM again
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has confirmed he will defend his Langkawi parliamentary seat at the upcoming general election, set to take place within the next 60 days. Mahathir, 97, stated he has no intentions of becoming prime minister again, but a prime minister candidate will be relevant only if his party wins. The dissolution of parliament triggered by Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has led to speculation about the election outcome, with investors advising a defensive posture due to election uncertainty and global recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's prime minister Ismail Sabri announced the dissolution of Parliament on Oct 10, 2022.
The ringgit may face some weakness amid the uncertainty ahead of the elections.

site_title: Roll-out of Moderna Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine brought forward to Oct 14
summary: The roll-out of Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore has been brought forward by three days to October 14. The vaccine targets the original Sars-CoV-2 strain and the Omicron BA.1 variant, and is also effective against other variants. Those aged 50 and above, or medically vulnerable individuals under 50, can receive the vaccine without an appointment at nine joint testing and vaccination centers. The vaccine provides better protection against newer Covid-19 variants, with a 75% greater antibody response against the Omicron variant, and has a similar safety profile to the original Moderna vaccine.

site_title: US small-business optimism improves for a third straight month
summary: US small businesses have seen optimism improve for the third consecutive month, with the National Federation of Independent Business's overall optimism index rising to 92.1 in September. Despite a slight increase in concerns over inflation, the majority of respondents (51%) reported raising prices, and only 30% cited inflation as the single most important issue. Labour challenges remain a significant concern, with 46% of owners reporting open positions. Despite this, owners are still seeking opportunities to grow their business, and the number of respondents planning to hire in the next three months has reached its highest level since May.

images.alt_text: The Asia Pacific accounts for a quarter of Citi Private Bank's topline revenue and 40 per cent of headcount.

site_title: Decoupling from China not an option for EU firms:  Dombrovskis
summary: EU trade commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis stated that decoupling from China is not an option for EU firms, emphasizing the need for pragmatism and balance in the EU-China trading relationship. He also highlighted concerns about the US Inflation Reduction Act, which he believes discriminates against EU industries. The EU will engage with China with a focus on better risk management and diversification, while Germany plans to discuss the act with the US. Dombrovskis' comments come amid a redefined relationship between the EU and its key trade partners due to the Ukraine war.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condo resale prices rose 1.7% in September, marking the 26th consecutive month of growth, with central region prices increasing 1.3% and core central region prices up 1.1%. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a 6% increase in securities turnover value in September, while derivatives activity reached an all-time high. Trek 2000's founder, Henn Tan, was sentenced to 16 months' imprisonment for financial offenses. Meanwhile, Optus and its subsidiaries received notices of an Australian probe into a cyberattack, and private credit is expected to play a larger role in financing clean energy transition.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall for fourth day as most Asian markets tumble; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell for the fourth consecutive day, closing 0.1% lower at 3,105.00, as most Asian markets declined following a negative US session. The decline was attributed to semiconductor stocks and tech manufacturers, with some counters such as AEM Holdings and Jardine Cycle & Carriage falling between 2.5 and 4.2%. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) was also influenced by the US-China trade tensions, with semiconductor stocks spurring a sell-off in the region.

images.alt_text: The Apple logo at the tech giant's outlet in Brooklyn, New York. Sixty per cent of those who took part in the MLIV Pulse survey said the iPhone maker, which has the heaviest weighting on the S&P 500, will provide insight into key themes such as consumer demand, supply chains, the effect of the soaring greenback and higher rates.
The Hang Seng Index sank 2.23 per cent, or 384.30 points, to 16,832.36 - ending below 17,000 for the first time since 2011.

site_title: Listed property groups worth a look despite lack of share price catalysts for now
summary: Investors can consider buying shares of deeply discounted listed property groups in Singapore, which can provide long-term exposure and upside potential. Shares of property groups like Frasers Property, GuocoLand, and Wing Tai are trading at discounts of 48-64% to their last reported net asset values. These groups offer a decent income stream through dividends and potential long-term upside from growing book values and privatization offers. However, investors should be aware of the potential risks, including small free floats, lumpy profits, and unexciting returns on equity.

images.alt_text: A 7% jump in suburban condo prices leads a 3.4% qoq rise in Singapore’s Q3 private home prices: URA
Stocks are riskier than bonds and investors need time to get compensated with higher returns

site_title: Tokyo opens same-sex partnership system for applications
summary: Tokyo has opened a same-sex partnership system for applications, allowing registered couples to apply together for local government services, such as public housing. The system, which does not offer legal benefits, has been welcomed by LGBTQ rights groups as a step forward, but advocates say it is not enough and that legal marriage is needed. The system is open to couples living or working in Tokyo, and applications will be certified starting November 1. The move is seen as a symbolic step forward for Japan, which is the only Group of Seven major democracy without same-sex marriage or civil unions.

images.alt_text: Man, woman or... X: US rolls out gender-neutral passports

site_title: China developer seeks to assure investors after missed trust payments
summary: China developer SCE Group Holdings has assured investors that a 1.6 billion yuan trust product, used to finance a residential and commercial project, is backed by sufficient assets valued at 3 billion yuan. The company's subsidiary missed payments last month, but sales of the development remain normal, reaching over 50 million yuan in September. SCE Group's statement aims to alleviate concerns among investors and maintain trust in the project.

images.alt_text: Construction workers at a site in Beijing. China’s home sales have fallen for more than a year, squeezing a key source of property firms’ liquidity and leading to rising defaults on everything from public debt and bank loans to trust borrowings for property projects.

site_title: Golden Energy shares have trebled this year, but  potential buyout hints they are still undervalued
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) shares have tripled this year, driven by higher coal prices amid the Russia-Ukraine war. The company is now being considered for a potential buyout by the Widjaja family of Indonesia's Sinar Mas empire. Gear's stock has broken through a key resistance level and is undervalued, with an intrinsic value of around S$2, according to Jitta. The company's leverage has increased following its Australian subsidiary's acquisition of BHP Mitsui Coal, and rising interest rates may prompt Gear to restructure debt.

images.alt_text: Group revenue trebled to US$2.4 billion in the first 6 months of FY2022, from US$806.7 million in the previous year.
Pipes at the landfall facilities of the Nord Stream gas pipeline in Germany. Russia is suspected of having attacked the pipeline.
The palm oil plantation is in talks with certain shareholders, including shareholder Indra Widjaja, regarding a potential deal.

site_title: Japan’s Nissan sells Russian assets to state, trade ministry says
summary: Japan's Nissan is selling its Russian assets to the Russian state, with an option to buy back the business in six years. The deal includes Nissan's production and research facilities in St Petersburg and sales and marketing centre in Moscow. Nissan expects to incur a 100 billion yen loss from the asset transfer. This marks the latest major company exit since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February, following Renault's sale of its majority stake in Russian carmaker Avtovaz for a symbolic sum.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall 1.8% in post-holiday session
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi fell 40.77 points, or 1.83%, to 2,192.07, marking its sharpest drop in two weeks. The decline was driven by concerns about faster inflation and higher interest rates, which could crimp economic growth. The Korean won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 199.7 billion won, while the won was quoted at 1,435.2 per dollar, down 1.59% from its previous close.

images.alt_text: The Kospi ended down 5.02 points or 0.22 per cent at 2,232.84.

site_title: SPH Media to see new editorial leadership; new editors for ST and BT
summary: SPH Media has announced new editorial leadership for its English/Malay/Tamil Media (EMTM) group, with Wong Wei Kong taking over as editor-in-chief, Jaime Ho succeeding Warren Fernandez as The Straits Times editor, and Chen Huifen succeeding Fernandez as The Business Times editor. The changes take effect on October 26. Wong, who has been BT editor since 2016, aims to lead the EMTM group to be credible voices in a polarized world. Fernandez will leave the company to pursue other opportunities, and Khaw Boon Wan, chairman of SPH Media Trust, thanked Fernandez for his dedication to ST.

images.alt_text: SPH Media Trust will invest more in talent and technology in coming years, says chairman Khaw
SPH completes transfer of media business to CLG

site_title: Philippines posts record US$6b trade deficit in August
summary: The Philippines recorded its largest monthly trade deficit of $6 billion in August, driven by a 26% increase in imports to $12.4 billion and a 2% decline in exports to $6.4 billion. The country aims to maximize its oil and gas resources, with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. announcing plans to attract more investors. The energy sector tax breaks are expected to be retained to support the initiative. The trade deficit is likely to put pressure on the Philippine peso in the near term, according to economists.

images.alt_text: The IPO of Prime Infrastructure Capital, originally set for October, could have been the Philippines’ largest this year.
“We take a very balanced view because the truth of the matter is, we may have to deal with Russia for fuel, for fertiliser,” said Marcos.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower again
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.23% on Tuesday, falling below 17,000 for the first time since 2011, as traders remained cautious due to central bank interest rate hikes aimed at taming inflation. The Hang Seng Index ended at 16,832.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.61%. The decline reflects fears of a recession in major economies.

site_title: UK labour market exodus drives jobless rate down to 3.5%
summary: The UK's unemployment rate fell to 3.5% in August, its lowest since 1974, driven by a record jump in the number of people leaving the labor market. However, the increase in inactive individuals, up 252,000, is the largest since records began in 1971, raising concerns about fueling inflation pressures. The Bank of England is worried about the shrinking labor market, which is also linked to financial market turmoil triggered by the new Prime Minister's tax cuts and unfunded pledges.

images.alt_text: The government of new Prime Minister Liz Truss last month sparked turmoil with a costly tax-cutting budget that triggered panic over ballooning state debt.

site_title: Mass market condo sales expected to remain firm despite softening demand from HDB upgraders
summary: Mass market condo sales in Singapore are expected to remain firm despite the latest property cooling measures, which primarily target HDB upgraders. According to ERA Research & Consultancy, buyers with private addresses account for 45.2% of non-landed Outside Central Region (OCR) private home transactions, while those with HDB addresses contribute 36.7%. The impact of the measures on mass market homes is expected to be less significant due to the limited dependence on HDB upgraders, with transaction volumes in the private residential market expected to decrease in the final quarter of 2022 but recover in the first half of next year.

images.alt_text: pixgenerics/ST20220629_202283358097/Ng Sor Luan/Generic photos of HDB flats for story on home loans rates increasing.

site_title: Rough ride in the final lap
summary: Investors face unprecedented volatility as the year comes to a close, with US equities down 25% and bond prices hit by record Treasury volatility. Amidst inflation, geopolitical shifts, and energy security concerns, a cautious stance on risk assets is advised, with a focus on cash. Equities with exposure to the hospitality sector are seen as benefiting from positive re-opening trends, and Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification.

images.alt_text: The Apple logo at the tech giant's outlet in Brooklyn, New York. Sixty per cent of those who took part in the MLIV Pulse survey said the iPhone maker, which has the heaviest weighting on the S&P 500, will provide insight into key themes such as consumer demand, supply chains, the effect of the soaring greenback and higher rates.

site_title: Visiting Qatar for Fifa 2022 World Cup? Here’s where to stay
summary: Qatar is opening thousands of hotel rooms for the 2022 FIFA World Cup, with options ranging from all-inclusive, five-star hotels to hostel-like rooms for $80 a night. However, only World Cup ticket holders and their guests, media personnel, and other tournament-related visitors will be allowed to enter the country from November 20 to December 18. Day trippers can stay in nearby cities like Dubai or Riyadh, but must book flights that arrive four hours before kick-off and depart four hours after the match ends.

images.alt_text: Besides some 130,000 hotel rooms available for the World Cup in Qatar, other lodging options include purpose-built housing, tents, Airbnb-style accommodations and at least two cruise ships with almost 4,000 cabins.

site_title: Block 'busted': India's Bollywood faces horror show at box office
summary: India's Bollywood film industry is facing its biggest crisis due to the rise of streaming services and non-Hindi language rivals. Only one-fifth of the over 50 Bollywood films released in the past year met or surpassed revenue targets, down from 50% pre-pandemic. The usually bankable megastar Akshay Kumar had three back-to-back films tank, and Aamir Khan's Forrest Gump remake failed to entice audiences. Analysts attribute the decline to streaming services offering affordable, high-quality content, and Bollywood's failure to create compelling stories and experiences.

images.alt_text: Left to right: US chief executive officer of Paramount Pictures Brian Robbins, actor Susie Bacon, and Smile writer-director Parker Finn at the film's premiere in California on Sep 27. Smile topped North America’s box office for a second weekend with US$17.6 million.
Arts Minister Tony Burke announced the deal on Monday (Oct 10) at Sydney’s Disney Studios, which has been renamed from Fox Studios Australia.

site_title: Philippines to maximise oil and gas resources, Marcos says
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has pledged to prioritize energy security and lower power costs amid high inflation fueled by imported oil. The country plans to maximize its oil and gas resources, with the potential for early oil production from the Cadlao oil field off the western coast by the second half of 2023. The administration is also seeking a compromise with Beijing on oil exploration in the South China Sea and has allowed Nido Petroleum to proceed with site surveys for drilling locations. Marcos aims to attract more investors by keeping tax breaks in the energy sector.

site_title: Asia-Pacific airline traffic recovery to accelerate as rules ease: Iata
summary: Asia-Pacific airline traffic is expected to recover to around 73% of 2019 levels by year-end as travel restrictions relax, according to Iata data. The region's recovery has been hindered by China's ongoing border closures, which have kept international passenger numbers at 2-3% of pre-pandemic levels. Major markets in the region, except China, have reopened, and estimates suggest it will take until 2025 to reach pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: HSBC extends Chinese private banking network to lure new digital millionaires
summary: HSBC has expanded its Chinese private banking network to Chengdu and Hangzhou, aiming to capture a larger share of the local market amid uncertainties in China's wealth growth. The bank plans to explore opportunities in the southwest region, where demand for wealth management is expected to grow. China's number of millionaires is projected to double to 12.2 million by 2026, driven by the growth of the digital economy in cities like Hangzhou, where tech giant Alibaba is headquartered. Regulatory uncertainties may still impact the bank's prospects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A branch of HSBC bank is seen, in central London, Britain, August 3, 2009.     REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth/File Photo
Last week, HSBC said it was examining a sale of its Canadian business that could be worth about US$10 billion.

site_title: BYD enters India’s passenger car market amid global push
summary: Chinese electric carmaker BYD launched its first passenger car in India, the Atto 3 electric SUV, marking its entry into the mainstream market. The company plans to sell 15,000 units in India over the next year and set up a local manufacturing facility. BYD has invested over $200 million in India and already produces electric buses and vehicles for corporate fleets. The move comes amid a global push by BYD, which has expanded to markets like Norway, New Zealand, and Japan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BYD logo is pictures on its Qin EV300 model during the Auto China 2016 auto show in Beijing, China April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: What did we wish for when we cut sulphur in marine fuel – accelerated global warming?
summary: Researchers at Oxford University's Climate Processes Group have found that air pollution from shipping, which was previously thought to counter global warming, actually has a larger cooling effect than previously thought. The study, published in Nature, used satellite data to analyze the impact of human aerosol emissions on climate change, revealing that clouds may react more strongly to air pollution, becoming brighter and having a stronger cooling effect. This discovery suggests that reducing air pollution, such as through the use of cleaner fuels, may not be as effective in mitigating global warming as previously believed.

images.alt_text:
ships / ST20210823_202127136955 / Alphonsus Chern //

Hong Kong bulk carrier Cherry Point bunkering in Singapore waters 23 August 2021.

site_title: Volkswagen gets US$8.8b by selling preferred Porsche shares
summary: Volkswagen sold 25% plus one ordinary share of Porsche AG to Porsche SE for 19.2 billion euros (S$26.8 billion), generating US$8.8 billion. This sale partially exercised a greenshoe option, resulting in a 24.2% free-float of Porsche's preferred shares. Volkswagen had previously estimated it would receive 9.4 billion euros if the greenshoe option was fully exercised.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, October 11, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index down 2.64% to 26,401.25, and the Topix index down 1.86% to 1,871.24. The decline was attributed to speculation over US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes following the release of US employment data last week.

site_title: How great value is being created in the stock market today
summary: The article discusses the value of investing in the stock market, focusing on the free cash flow per share (FCF per share) and the price-to-FCF ratio (P/FCF ratio) as key drivers of share prices. Despite growth in FCF per share, shares of companies like Apple have fallen due to a shrinking P/FCF ratio, influenced by market sentiment. To make informed investment decisions, investors should focus on the business performance represented by FCF per share, rather than relying on market sentiment. A long-term perspective is crucial, as business growth tends to outperform market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The annual Computex computer exhibition in Taipei, Taiwan June 1, 2016. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: ECB window for big rate hikes narrows with recession nearing
summary: The European Central Bank's window for large interest-rate hikes is narrowing as a recession looms, with record inflation and winter energy shortages eroding confidence in the euro-zone economy. The ECB's hawks have a limited opportunity to deliver big hikes, with the next two meetings in October and December potentially being the last chance. Economists warn that the battle with inflation will become harder to justify as growth slows, and the ECB's dovish cohort may struggle to push through larger hikes once recession risks become a reality.

images.alt_text: The ECB has told individual lenders recently that it expects restraint in variable pay and dividends as it is concerned that the energy crunch could result in a wave of defaults.

site_title: Australia: Shares reverse course to end lower as commodity stocks weigh
summary: Australia's shares closed 0.3% lower at 6,645 points, pressured by financials and commodity stocks, ahead of key US inflation data that may indicate another 75 basis point Fed rate hike. Domestic financial stocks fell, while energy stocks dropped 1.6% due to concerns over slowing demand in China. Miners also declined, with sector heavyweights Woodside and Santos falling 2.1% and 0.9%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.3 per cent to 6,687.6, as of 0022 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: Trek 2000 founder sentenced to 16 months’ jail for offences including cooking the books
summary: Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan was sentenced to 16 months in jail for conspiring to falsify accounts, forge documents, and deceive external auditors. Tan, 66, had pleaded guilty to five charges related to inflating revenue and pre-tax operating profit between 2006 and 2015. His crimes "made a mockery of corporate governance in Singapore," the prosecution argued. Tan's lawyer sought a 10-month sentence, while the prosecution requested a deterrent sentence. Tan's son, Wayne Tan, is the current deputy chairman of Trek 2000.

images.alt_text: Henn Tan has been in remand for 1.5 months, according to the court system.

site_title: India will weigh what Russia has to offer on Sakhalin-1 ownership revamp
summary: India is "actively monitoring" Saudi Arabia's Asia premium over oil prices amid Opec+ production cuts. Petroleum Minister Hardeep Singh Puri said India will weigh what Russia offers on the Sakhalin-1 ownership revamp after Russia seized Exxon Mobil's 30% stake. India maintains a "healthy dialogue" with Russia and is open to discussions on the project. Puri also discussed collaborations with US energy officials on biofuels and clean energy, and expressed interest in US companies' technical expertise in offshore production.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil holds a 30 per cent operator stake in Sakhalin-1, with Russian company Rosneft, India’s ONGC Videsh and Japan’s Sodeco as partners.
Exxon has been trying to exit its Russia operations and transfer its role in Sakhalin-1 to a partner since March, after international sanctions were imposed against Moscow.

site_title: Sri Lanka to keep ‘middle-income’ status but seek concessional loans
summary: Sri Lanka will remain a middle-income country despite facing its worst economic crisis in over seven decades. The country, with a predicted 8.7% GDP contraction, will seek concessional loans from the World Bank, specifically from the International Development Association (IDA), which aids the world's poorest countries. Sri Lanka's economy is valued at around $75 billion, with a per-capita income of $3,400, falling short of the World Bank's definition of low-income countries.

images.alt_text: Central Bank of Sri Lanka’s governor P Nandalal Weerasinghe said the bank needs to keep rates high to bring down inflation, adding prices are expected to slow in December and January.
Food prices continue to bear the brunt of the inflationary impact, climbing to 93.7 per cent, while prices of non-food items rose 50.2 per cent, the Sri Lanka's statistics office said.

site_title: PC shipments plummet as macroeconomic worries bite
summary: The global PC market experienced its steepest decline on record, with shipments falling 19.5% in the third quarter of 2022 compared to the year-ago period. Lenovo remained the top PC maker, but its shipments fell around 15%. The decline is attributed to economic uncertainty, a glut of unsold inventory, and concerns over a market slowdown. Analysts predict a market recovery in the second half of 2023, but new curbs on chips and electronics trade with China may weigh on prospects for a recovery.

images.alt_text: Weaker-than-expected demand for consumer electronics is hitting companies along with surging shipping and materials costs.
Supply chains are being reshaped for greater resilience, but this process can take years. In the meantime, cooling global demand is providing some relief.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says “no legal basis” to act on Russian superyacht
summary: Hong Kong leader John Lee stated there is "no legal basis" for the city to act on Western sanctions imposed on Russian oligarch Alexey Mordashov, despite a luxury yacht belonging to him being docked in Hong Kong waters. Lee emphasized Hong Kong will only abide by United Nations sanctions, citing a need to protect the city's interests. This comes as the US State Department criticized Hong Kong for allowing the yacht to dock, raising concerns about reputational risks and transparency in the financial hub.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority doesn’t maintain any form of sanctions or designations lists but said in March that it’s up to banks to assess such risks.
Real estate has remained at the centre of Hong Kong’s US$368 billion economy, mainly through wealth created by high valuations - a result of the territory’s scarce land resources.

site_title: Macro bets help hedge funds ride rough Chinese markets
summary: Hedge funds have successfully navigated China's volatile markets by making macro bets, with funds posting significant returns despite the country's sharp economic slowdown. The Golden Nest Greater China Fund, for example, posted a 2.4% net return in September, outperforming the 30% decline of MSCI China's index over the same period. Macro strategies have been key to winning, with top-down research helping funds avoid panic selling and seize opportunities created by global rate rises and regulatory changes.

images.alt_text: Equity hedge funds posted gains of 2.89 per cent, underperforming the S&P 500, which went up 9.11 per cent last month. For the year, equity hedge funds were down 9.2 per cent.
China-focused funds have traditionally kept a large portion of portfolios in American Depository Receipts (ADRs) of mainland firms.

site_title: As more nations aspire to join CPTPP, upholding agreement’s high standards is key
summary: Singapore's Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has shown positive impacts on trade and investment in the region, with intra-CPTPP trade increasing by 4% to $467 billion in 2019. The pact, which has 11 members representing 13% of global GDP, is expected to grow with new members joining, with the UK likely to be the first. Malaysia has completed its ratification process and will become the ninth party on November 29, leaving only Brunei and Chile to follow. The CPTPP's high standards must be upheld to ensure its continued success and economic benefits for all members.

images.alt_text: “The CPTPP places Malaysia in a strategic position, elevating our competitiveness in the global arena,” the trade ministry said.

Britain has opposed expanding the target of tariff-free items, particularly among agricultural products, to near 100 per cent as set by the CPTPP and instead agreed to lift tariffs for only 90 per cent of imported products, Jiji said.
President Joe Biden discusses American Rescue Plan investments in regional and community economic strategies at the White House in Washington on Sept 2, 2022.

site_title: Gold flat as firm dollar, US rate-hike outlook dent appeal
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,668.29 per ounce on Tuesday, a week after hitting a low, due to a stronger US dollar and expectations of further interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The dollar index rose 0.2%, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. The Fed's focus on inflation and economic uncertainties, despite a stronger-than-expected US labor data, will continue to influence gold prices.

images.alt_text: Physical gold prices flipped to a discount in India last week as elevated local rates amid a dive in the rupee dampened festive demand.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on SPH Reit’s near-term prospects as tenant sales recover
summary: Singapore Reit SPH Reit has seen improved operating metrics and tenant sentiment, with a 2.2% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the 12 months ended August 2022. Analysts from CGS-CIMB and DBS Group Research maintain their "hold" calls on the company, citing Paragon Mall as a key beneficiary of Singapore's reopening. Tenant sales recovery at its Singapore assets has boosted the Reit's DPU, with brokers optimistic about its near-term prospects.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH initiates coverage on Emperador with ‘hold’
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has initiated coverage on Emperador with a "hold" call and a target price of S$0.53, citing the company's strong brand portfolio and ability to address shifting consumer preferences. The analyst projects Emperador's revenue to grow at a 5.7% CAGR from 2021 to 2024, driven by premiumization and growth in China. The target price implies a 10.4% potential upside, based on a 30 times multiple of the stock's 2023 price-to-earnings estimates.

images.alt_text: While there may be merit in indices evolving to track a wider portion of the local equity market, it is also clear that companies need to battle to grow and deliver returns amid stiff competition for investor attention and dollars.

A non-alcohol "beer garden" in Tokyo, Japan, Aug 26, 2022. Facing a steady decline in revenue from alcohol sales, Japan’s tax office in July launched a contest seeking ideas on how to stimulate demand among younger people.

site_title: The new era of sustainable development investing
summary: The article discusses the shift towards sustainable development investing, which seeks to identify investment opportunities that generate returns while delivering net-positive outcomes. The UN's Global Investors for Sustainable Development Alliance aims to mobilize trillions of dollars to address pressing global issues such as climate change, poverty, and inequality. The article highlights the growth of sustainability bonds and loans, and sector-based investments in developing countries, as commercial opportunities that can contribute to sustainable economic growth. To achieve scale, the alliance needs multilateral development banks to enhance blended finance activities and policymakers to implement systemic changes.

images.alt_text:
Pixgeneric / generic activity pictures of Lakeside Garden / Jurong Lake Garden and Jurong Lake taken on 13 March 2022.


The authorities are seeking proposals to develop and operate an integrated tourism development in Jurong Lake District.
In a statement on Tuesday (March 15), the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) said it expects the new lifestyle and tourism hub to comprise high-quality accommodation as well as a mix of attractions, retail, food and beverage and entertainment offerings.
The development should place emphasis on technology, "edutainment" and sustainability, STB added.
Not just to please investors, transition plans should be part of a company’s overall strategy: climate bonds panel
CFOs are primed to steer the ESG agenda

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 6% in September; derivatives activity at all-time high
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 6% increase in securities turnover value in September to S$25.8 billion, driven by strong performance of Straits Times Index (STI) constituent stocks and real estate investment trusts (Reits). The STI saw over S$300 million in net institutional flows, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and Singtel being among the top recipients. Meanwhile, derivatives activity reached an all-time high, with a single-day record of 2.97 million contracts on September 27.

images.alt_text: While there may be merit in indices evolving to track a wider portion of the local equity market, it is also clear that companies need to battle to grow and deliver returns amid stiff competition for investor attention and dollars.

site_title: Condo resale prices up 1.7% in September; volumes rise 1.1%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore's central region rose 1.7% in September, driven by the recent launches of Sky Eden@Bedok and Lentor Modern. Volumes also increased 1.1% month-over-month. The highest transacted price was S$17.6 million at Reflections at Keppel Bay. Experts believe the recent cooling measures may slow down HDB resale price growth, potentially affecting the condo resale market, but demand for larger resale units may remain.

images.alt_text: Buying a home with a pricey home loan can still make sense

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.

PropNex anticipates that the median selling price of overall new OCR projects may hover around the S$2,000 psf range in the near-term with Sky Eden@Bedok transacting 118 units at an average price of S$2,100 psf, and Lentor Modern selling 84 per cent of its units also at an average price of about S$2,100 psf.
DBS, HSBC, Standard Chartered bank buildings in the CBD area.

Canada’s spiralling house prices have long been led by feverish price gains in Toronto, where the detached house price, adjusted for buying patterns, now sits at just under C$1.6 million, and in Vancouver, British Columbia, where it is at about C$1.9 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin day on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, extending a sell-off due to concerns over central bank interest rate hikes potentially leading to a recession. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.13% to 17,194.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.13% to 2,978.06. This follows a global trend of declining stocks, with the US and Europe also experiencing losses.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing on recession fears as inflation data looms
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday, with many experiencing significant losses due to recession fears and worsening inflation data. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped below 17,000 points for the first time since 2011, while Tokyo lost over 22% and Seoul declined over 2%. The US dollar remained strong, and analysts warn of a potential global recession in 2023. Investors are also concerned about the impact of the Ukraine war and China's economic outlook, with the World Bank's David Malpass predicting a "real danger" of a global contraction.

images.alt_text: The flag of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEx), top center, the Chinese national flag, bottom center, and the Hong Kong SAR flag, bottom right, fly in the Central district of Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, March 2, 2016.
