HKEx, owner of the London Metal Exchange, posted a 68 percent increase in profit from commodities last year as expanding fees from trading countered the first decline in metals volume since 2009. Photographer: Justin Chin/Bloomberg

Pedestrians walk past the Apple Inc. store at Wangfujing in Beijing, China, on Thursday, Jan. 3, 2019. Apple cut its revenue outlook for the first time in almost two decades citing weaker demand in China, triggering a slump for Asian suppliers and a wave of lower price targets on Wall Street. Photographer: Shawn Koh/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia hopes to fend off recession despite global economic dangers: Treasurer
summary: Australia's economy is expected to avoid a recession despite global economic dangers, according to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The global economy is heading for a substantial downturn, but the Australian government's budget, set to be released on October 25, will not forecast a recession. Aggressive rate hikes, high food and energy prices, and geopolitical risks are heightening concerns for a global recession, with the World Bank and IMF warning of growing risks. The Reserve Bank of Australia has slowed the pace of rate hikes, but warned of rising financial stability risks.

images.alt_text: The Aussie slid to as low as US$0.6343 on Monday, the weakest since April 2020, before trimming some losses.

The Reserve Bank of Australia said some households are already feeling the strain from higher interest rates and inflation, after six consecutive rate hikes since May, and this will likely continue for some time.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida backs Bank of Japan’s ultra-loose policy despite yen plunge: FT
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has expressed support for the Bank of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy despite the yen's 24-year low against the dollar. Kishida stated that the central bank needs to maintain its current policy until wages rise, and he is not considering shortening Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's 10-year term. The Bank of Japan remains an outlier among central banks tightening monetary policy globally to combat inflation.

site_title: Local tech startup Luwjistik acquired by Australian logistics platform Shippit for A$18m
summary: Luwjistik, a Singaporean tech startup, has been acquired by Australian logistics platform Shippit for approximately A$18 million. Luwjistik, founded in 2021, created a unified API connecting freight forwarders and logistics companies globally. The acquisition will allow Shippit to expand its presence in South-east Asia and cater to local SMEs, with Shippit's co-founder relocating to Singapore to lead a team of 50.

images.alt_text: Larger retailers would rather pay to store their goods in warehouses than risk having them sitting outside the port on a vessel.
Grab, foodpanda and Deliveroo has banded together to form their own industry association, the Digital Platforms Industry Association.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling launched the Retail Industry Transformation Map 2025 at the official opening of Castlery’s flagship store.

site_title: A Nobel for an economic model with real world application
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chair Ben Bernanke, along with economists Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig, have been awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Research for their work on bank runs. Their model, developed in the 1980s, explains how banks are vulnerable to deposit runs and established the central argument for government deposit insurance. The work's real-world impact is evident in how policymakers have responded to financial crises, including the 2008-2010 global financial crisis, and its influence continues to shape economic policy today.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 12, 2018 former Federal Reserve Board Chairman Ben Bernanke answers questions at a conference at the Brookings Institution. The Nobel Economics Prize was on October 10, 2022 awarded to a US trio for their contributions on explaining the role of banks in the economy. - Ben Bernanke, Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig were given the nod for having "significantly improved our understanding of the role of banks in the economy, particularly during financial crises, as well as how to regulate financial markets", the jury said. (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

Economist Ha-Joon Chang's life was changed by the sci-fi novel 'The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy' that, as he put it, "deployed off-the-wall humour and industrial-grade satire to discuss serious issues".

From left: The 2022 Nobel Economics Prize laureates Ben Bernanke, Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig on a display at a press conference to unveil the as winners at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm on Monday (Oct 10).

site_title: Optus, units receive notice of Australia’s probe into cyberattack
summary: Optus and its subsidiaries have received notices from the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) and Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) to commence formal investigations into a cyberattack that occurred in September 2022, resulting in the breach of 2.1 million customer personal identification data. The investigations will focus on whether Optus took reasonable steps to protect customer data and comply with privacy laws, as well as its obligations as a telecommunications provider in terms of data retention and disposal.

images.alt_text: Singtel said Optus, its unit under cyberattack in late September, has reported of personal identification data of some 2.1 million of its 9.8 million customers having been leaked.

Optus must pay the cost of replacing the passports and drivers' licences of millions of customers whose personal information was stolen in one of the country’s biggest data breaches, the Australian government said on Thursday.

Singtel’s share price has been on a downturn since the telecommunications giant on Monday announced the appointment of Deloitte to undertake an independent review of Optus’ cybersecurity systems following the cyberattack.

site_title: Private credit to play bigger role in clean energy transition: Blackstone Credit’s Robert Horn
summary: Private credit markets are poised to play a larger role in financing the clean energy transition as public markets become less favorable due to heightened volatility. According to Robert Horn, global head of the sustainable resources group for Blackstone Credit, private credit offers a scalable and efficient way to fund the transition, particularly for hard-asset sectors such as cars, real estate, and power plants. Blackstone Credit has committed over $16 billion to energy transition projects, with a goal of investing $100 billion over the next decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 10.50 points lower, or 0.75%, at 1,395.50 on Tuesday. The market saw 300.73 million lots traded worth RM134.27 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 379 to 93.

site_title: Malaysia assets decline on Parliament dissolution, Asia selloff
summary: Malaysia's stocks and ringgit declined after Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced the dissolution of Parliament, paving the way for polls this year. The benchmark KLCI Index fell 1.6% and the ringgit slid 0.5% versus the dollar. The 10-year yield rose 5 basis points to 4.46%. Investors are cautious due to uncertainty and potential for a hung Parliament, advising a defensive stance. Some sectors, such as construction and regulated assets, may benefit in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's prime minister Ismail Sabri announced the dissolution of Parliament on Oct 10, 2022.
Malaysians celebrating National Day in August. About 21.1 million Malaysians are eligible to vote in the upcoming election, with some 5 million voting for the first time

site_title: Chipmaker rout engulfs TSMC, Samsung with US$240b wiped out
summary: The US has imposed sweeping curbs on companies that conduct technology business with China, limiting the ability of US firms to sell equipment and tech to their Chinese counterparts. This has led to a significant decline in chipmaker stocks, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Samsung Electronics, and Tokyo Electron, resulting in a loss of over US$240 billion from the sector's global market value. The move aims to prevent Chinese companies from transferring technology to the country's military and developing advanced semiconductor capabilities.

images.alt_text: The China Securities Regulatory Commission has given the greenlight to the country’s first mutual fund targeting top Chinese and South Korean chipmakers.
In China, bellwether Semiconductor Manufacturing International  fell 4 per cent in Hong Kong, the most since Sept 2.
The manufacture and export of semiconductors has been a subject of competition between US and China, as they battle for tech dominance.

site_title: Singapore shares buck global trend to open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,127.46, bucking the global trend of declining markets, which saw declines for stock markets worldwide. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 37, with top-traded counters including Sembcorp Marine, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also opened in positive territory, despite global markets being affected by US consumer price index data and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Jumbo announced on Monday (Oct 10) that it officially opened its fourth franchised Seafood outlet in Hanoi, Vietnam on Oct 8.

site_title: Singapore HRtech startup Workmate acquired by Japan’s Persol
summary: Singapore HRtech startup Workmate has been acquired by Japan's Persol Holdings for an undisclosed eight-figure sum. Founded in 2016, Workmate operates an on-demand staffing platform in Thailand and Indonesia, placing over 120,000 frontline workers in roles and serving over 800 companies. The acquisition combines Workmate's technology with Persol's expertise, elevating the startup's position, according to CEO Mathew Ward. Workmate will continue to operate independently from Persol, with plans to launch operations in Singapore this month.

site_title: HSBC looks to deals and disposals as part of battle against breakup
summary: HSBC is shifting its focus from strategic disposals to acquisitions, aiming to increase the amount of deals it makes in the coming years. Despite being pressured by its largest shareholder to split up, the bank is ramping up its dealmaking program, with disposals expected to be matched by purchases. The lender has already announced plans to sell its Canadian business for around $10 billion and has been exploring the sale of its Indonesian operations. This move is seen as part of HSBC's Asia pivot, with the bank seeking to regroup its operations and capitalize on the region's rising economies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A branch of HSBC bank is seen, in central London, Britain, August 3, 2009.     REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth/File Photo
Executives at HSBC Indonesia have met with a group of fund managers in Singapore since last week to discuss details of the potential IPO, ahead of an official roadshow, the sources said.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals grow for 8th straight month in September to 778,141
summary: Singapore has set a new monthly record for international visitor arrivals, with 778,141 arrivals in September, the eighth consecutive month of growth. Indonesia remains the top source of arrivals, followed by India and Malaysia. China, however, saw a significant decline in visitors, down 85% from 2019 levels. This brings the total international visitor arrivals for the year to 3.7 million, below the Singapore Tourism Board's expectation of 4-6 million.

images.alt_text: Singapore has reported some 3 million international visitor arrivals so far in 2022, against STB’s expectation of 4 to 6 million international visitors for the year announced in July.

The number of flights that airlines have filed to operate at Changi Airport by year is more than 80 per cent of pre-Covid-19 levels, and Transport Minister S Iswaran expects this to increase further following an easing of border restrictions in Hong Kong, Japan and Taiwan.
A record crowd of 302,000 have showed up to attend the Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix 2022.

site_title: Russian firms turn to Hong Kong in bid to avoid sanctions
summary: Russian firms are exploring Hong Kong as an alternative to Western financial capitals to avoid sanctions, amid concerns from US officials that the Asian hub will become a haven for businesses sanctioned over the war in Ukraine. At least two law firms in Hong Kong have been approached by Russian companies seeking to engage in activities in the city, with some looking to raise capital and others seeking to change registrations to Hong Kong while keeping operations in Russia. However, questions remain about banks and auditors' willingness to deal with Russian firms given the threat of secondary sanctions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's raison d'etre would be further accentuated for as long as China remains closed, with the city serving as an important "halfway house" while the mainland forges its way forward.

site_title: PayPal says it never intended to fine users for ‘misinformation’
summary: PayPal has denied its intention to fine users for spreading misinformation, after publishing a new user agreement that outlined a penalty of $2,500 for each violation. The policy update, set to take effect on November 3, prohibits users from spreading misinformation on the platform. PayPal stated that the language was never intended to be inserted in the policy and that users will not be fined for misinformation. The company's move was criticized by conservative politicians and social media personalities, who called on users to delete their PayPal accounts.

images.alt_text: The PayPal logo is seen on a smartphone in front of the same logo displayed in this illustration taken September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
PayPal has faced pressured in recent quarters from supply-chain disruptions and once-in-a-generation levels of inflation that hindered e-commerce spending.

site_title: US: Stocks turn lower in early trade, dollar gains
summary: US stocks declined in early trade, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 falling amid concerns over inflation and economic growth. The dollar rose as investors weighed the impact of policy-tightening on company earnings. The Nasdaq 100 was pressured by the semiconductor sector, while a hotter-than-expected inflation reading is expected to put pressure on policymakers to extend interest rate hikes. The fragile market mood is ahead of Thursday's US inflation data and bank earnings, with over 60% of respondents predicting a decline in the S&P 500 Index.

images.alt_text: The Apple logo at the tech giant's outlet in Brooklyn, New York. Sixty per cent of those who took part in the MLIV Pulse survey said the iPhone maker, which has the heaviest weighting on the S&P 500, will provide insight into key themes such as consumer demand, supply chains, the effect of the soaring greenback and higher rates.

A small chorus of researchers has for months warned of a potential hazard to earnings should the campaign to tamp down inflation succeed. Specifically, the squeeze on margins that could occur should an indicator known as corporate operating leverage suffer in an environment where sales flatten out.
All 11 major S&P 500 sectors declined, with technology falling the most, down 4.1 per cent.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as miners outweigh losses in energy stocks
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 6,687.6, driven by miners' gains due to higher iron ore prices. Top gainers included BHP group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group. Healthcare stocks advanced, while technology stocks weakened. Energy stocks fell 1.6% after oil prices sank overnight. The benchmark closed 1.4% lower on Monday.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.4 per cent lower at 6,667.8 in broad-based selling.

site_title: Glencore faces flood of UK litigation following bribery charges
summary: Glencore, a mining giant, faces a wave of UK litigation following its guilty plea to bribery and corruption charges in May. Over a dozen UK investment and pension funds have filed class-action lawsuits against Glencore and its executives, linked to the company's $1.1 billion fine. Funds from Phoenix Group, Standard Life, and HSBC are among the claimants, with a sentencing hearing set for November to determine the UK fine amount. Glencore has pledged to implement a world-class ethics and compliance program.

images.alt_text: The Horne Smelter in Rouyn-Noranda is emitting 165 nanograms of arsenic per cubic meter of air on site, according to a recent study by public health authorities in the Canadian province.
The headquarters of Glencore International AG stand in Baar, Switzerland. A total of 24 vessels were supplied with the affected fuel by Glencore in the Port of Singapore from Mar 22 to Apr 1, 2022.

site_title: UK to auction more offshore wind sites to the highest bidder
summary: The UK will auction seabed rights in the Celtic Sea to the highest bidder, with the goal of developing up to 4 gigawatts of new renewable power capacity by 2035. European oil majors, such as BP and Shell, are expected to dominate the auction, leveraging their experience in building offshore wind projects. The Crown Estate will award the leases to the developer who pays the most, potentially allowing fossil fuel companies to expand their low-carbon portfolios using their record profits. The auction is expected to launch in mid-2023.

images.alt_text: Despite the raft of announcements, yields shot up across the range of British debt maturities including in the long-dated conventional gilt market.

site_title: Airbus delivered 55 jets in September, making 2022 target tough
summary: Airbus delivered 55 jets in September, surpassing the 39 aircraft handed over in August but still short of the monthly average needed to reach its 2022 year-end goal of 700 jets. The company must ship an average of 88 aircraft per month to meet the target, with labour and raw-material shortages at suppliers complicating production. Despite booking 13 new orders in September, including six A320-family aircraft for Sichuan Airlines, Airbus faces significant challenges in achieving its goal. CEO Guillaume Faury stated that hitting 700 jets will require "a hell of a lot of work to be done".

site_title: Payment startup Airwallex secures another US$100m in Series E extension
summary: Airwallex, a fintech startup, has secured an additional US$100 million in Series E funding, bringing its total funding to over US$900 million. The funding round, led by new investors HostPlus and an unnamed North American pension fund, will be used to accelerate international expansion. The company's valuation remains at US$5.5 billion, and its customer base has more than doubled with a 184% year-on-year revenue increase. The funding will also support new product launches, including improvements to its expense management platform and a credit solution.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase secures Singapore digital-asset permit
summary: Coinbase Global has secured a digital-assets license in Singapore from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), marking the company's entry into the Asian market. The license, granted under the Payment Services Act, allows Coinbase to provide regulated services in the city-state. The move is part of Coinbase's expansion plans in the Asia-Pacific region, with Singapore serving as a "beachhead" for growth. The company has around 100 employees in Singapore and plans to bolster growth overseas, including in markets like Indonesia and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Before the clampdown, China was emerging as the epicentre of the crypto world, spawning giant exchanges like Binance Holdings and the biggest Bitcoin mining firms.
This year is the first year that Token2049 has been held in Singapore. Last year’s event was in London, and there were two pre-Covid iterations in Hong Kong.
Coinbase said in a statement that it made the shifts “to account for changes in global crypto trading volumes and asset prices”.

site_title: Exxon Mobil weighs takeover of oil recovery specialist Denbury
summary: Exxon Mobil is considering a potential takeover of Denbury, a US-based oil and gas producer with a large carbon dioxide pipeline network. The deal would be Exxon's biggest carbon-management investment, following the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act, which provides tax incentives for carbon capture. Denbury aims to be "carbon negative" by 2030, and a takeover would give Exxon critical infrastructure to pursue its climate strategy of eliminating operational emissions by 2050. No final decision has been made, and Exxon could opt against proceeding.

images.alt_text: The incident occurred on Tuesday (Sep 20) near Hawkins, about 110 miles east of Dallas. The US Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating, the Harrison County Sheriff’s Office said.

Walkouts caused the gradual shut down of Exxon’s Port Jerome-Gravenchon oil refinery and Notre Dame de Gravenchon (NDG) petrochemical site in France on Sep 20 before spreading to Fos-Sur-Mer 24 hours later.

site_title: UK spy chief to warn of ‘huge’ China tech threat
summary: UK GCHQ director Jeremy Fleming is set to warn Western countries of a "huge threat" from China's tech dominance, viewing satellite systems and digital currencies as tools to gain advantage. The Chinese Communist Party seeks to exploit its tech to control its citizens and gain influence abroad. Fleming will urge the UK and its allies to respond urgently to this "huge threat to us all."

images.alt_text: Analysts expect demand to slow as consumers tighten their wallets going amid a weaker macroeconomic environment.

American companies aren’t the world’s leading manufacturers of the chips Washington is seeking to deny to China; firms in other markets such as Japan and especially Taiwan are. But US firms and technology are deeply involved in designing high-end semiconductors, which gives Washington influence over the entire supply chain.
A majority of the 451 survey contributors see Chinese equities gaining ahead of and over the 6 months following the confirmation of President Xi’s third term in power.

site_title: UK facing ‘painful’ cuts to fix public finances: study
summary: The UK government faces "big and painful" cuts to public spending to fix state finances, according to a leading think tank. The Institute for Fiscal Studies warned this comes after a costly tax-cutting budget and a debt-reduction plan by finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng, which sparked market panic. The government has already reversed a tax cut for the richest earners due to public backlash. UK inflation is around 10%, exacerbating the economic crisis, and the think tank's warning suggests a need for significant spending cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends the annual Conservative Party conference, in Birmingham, Britain, October 2, 2022. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
Finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng will unveil debt-slashing plans and predictions sooner than expected.

site_title: US airport websites hit by suspected pro-Russian cyberattacks
summary: US airport websites were targeted by suspected pro-Russian cyberattacks after the hacking group "KillNet" published a list of sites and encouraged its followers to attack them. The DDoS attacks briefly knocked offline airport websites in major cities, including Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York, Phoenix, and St Louis. However, the disruptions did not impact airport operations. The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is coordinating with affected entities and offering assistance as needed. Most airport websites appear to be functioning normally after being temporarily shut down.

images.alt_text: Facebook identified more than 400 malicious Android and iOS apps this year that target Internet users in order to steal their login information.
Law firm Maurice Blackburn said it lodged a formal complaint with the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner.

site_title: Designer collectibles maker heads abroad – and into the metaverse, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 applications are now open, with a deadline of June 30. The awards recognize and celebrate innovative and ambitious businesses, honoring their achievements and contributions to their respective industries. The awards aim to provide a platform for emerging enterprises to gain recognition, network with peers, and gain access to resources and opportunities that can help drive their growth and success. The awards are open to businesses from various sectors and will be presented in different categories to acknowledge diverse achievements. The winners will be announced later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong’s property market is tumbling as unsold homes pile up
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a downturn, with unsold homes piling up. The territory's US$368 billion economy has traditionally relied on high property valuations, driven by scarce land resources. Recently launched projects have seen poor sales, with one 139-unit development remaining unsold after its first day and another finding buyers for just two units. This marks a stark contrast to the city's previous robust market, where projects often sell out quickly.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong apartments housing property Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Colombia’s state oil company Ecopetrol pushing harder into Asia, renewables
summary: Colombia's state oil company Ecopetrol is expanding its presence in Asia, particularly in Singapore, with a new corporate office. The company estimates that 60% of its crudes were sold to Asia in 2021, with this share expected to grow to half by this year and potentially more in the future. Ecopetrol aims to increase its crude sales through the Singapore office to 6-8 million barrels per month. The company is also shifting towards renewable energy, with plans to increase its solar power capacity to 400 MW by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
This week traders look to Asia, with palm oil stockpiles in No 2 grower Malaysia seen hitting the highest in almost three years, industry estimates show.
Next week traders look to Asia, with palm oil stockpiles in No. 2 grower Malaysia seen hitting the highest in almost three years, industry estimates show.
Weeks after Biden took office as president, Washington released a report tying the 2018 killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
The Nopec bill has been called a “nuclear option” that could have wide-ranging effects for not just energy markets, but the defence industry and geopolitics as well.

One of the ways the World Bank continued to fund fossil fuels was by exploiting a “major loophole” by lending to intermediaries such as banks or financial institutions and by acting as a guarantor in case a country did not meet its obligations, the report by NGO coalition, The Big Shift Global. said.

site_title: International ‘groupthink’ in a hypothetical Taiwan Strait crisis
summary: The US and its allies in the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue (Quad) may face "groupthink" in a hypothetical Taiwan Strait crisis, where senior bureaucrats prioritize consensus over critical thinking. If a crisis occurs, the Quad's response would depend on how deep they want to dig themselves into the issue. Experts warn that a blockade of Taiwan could lead to an escalation of the crisis, similar to the Cuban Missile Crisis. The US may be left to act alone, and its response would need to be carefully considered to prevent a nuclear war.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden's trip to Japan and South Korea from May 20 to 24 will be his first to the region since he took office last year.
A cold economic war between the US and China, while not as devastating as a “hot” conflict, would be disruptive and costly for the global economy and almost all of us.

site_title: Singapore to refresh social support measures amid signs of stratification: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to refresh Singapore's social support measures to address growing income inequality and stratification. The government will review leave measures, reduce fee caps at government-supported pre-schools, and develop better senior living options in housing estates. Wong emphasized the need for a holistic approach to social support, integrating various services and interventions across the whole of government. He also highlighted the importance of addressing respect and status gaps, particularly among lower-income families and seniors.

images.alt_text: Far left : DPM Lawrence Wong joined together with  Ms Ang Bee Lian, Director-General of Social Welfare, MSF interacting with social service practitioners to seek their views and ideas on the Forward SG exercise – a collective effort to refresh Singapore’s social compact on October 10 2022 at Lifelong Learning Institute (Level 2, Lecture Theatre) To kickstart the Ministry of Social and Family Development’s (MSF) engagements with Singaporeans under Forward Singapore’s Care pillar, we are organising a Conversation between DPM Lawrence Wong and Social Service Practitioners on Monday 10 October 2022. 2 DPM Lawrence Wong will be joined by i) Ms Indranee Rajah, Minister in the Prime Minister’s Office, Second Minister for Finance and National Development, ii) Ms Sun Xueling, Minister of State for Social and Family Development & Home Affairs and iii) Mdm Rahayu Mahzam, Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Health & Law. 3 DPM Lawrence Wong will deliver an opening address, in which he will speak about how we, as a nation and as a community, can better support families. DPM’s speech is open for media reporting. 4 This will be followed by a dialogue moderated by Ms Ang Bee Lian, Director-General of Social Welfare, MSF, with social workers, social service practitioners and leaders as well as academia, to seek their views and ideas on the Forward SG exercise – a collective effort to refresh Singapore’s social compact. 5 Media is invited to – (i) cover DPM Lawrence Wong’s speech; (ii) observe the dialogue with social service practitioners. Event Details Date: 10 October 2022 (Monday) Time: 3pm – 5pm Venue: Lifelong Learning Institute (Level 2, Lecture Theatre) 11 Eunos Road 8, Singapore 408601

site_title: Weinstein sex assault trial opens in Los Angeles
summary: Harvey Weinstein's Los Angeles trial began with jury selection, where five alleged victims are expected to testify against him. Weinstein, already serving 23 years in New York for sex crimes, faces 11 new charges, including sexual battery by restraint, forcible rape, and forcible oral copulation. If convicted, he could face over 100 years in prison. Weinstein has pleaded not guilty to all counts and maintains that all his alleged encounters were consensual. The trial is a significant development in the #MeToo movement, with nearly 90 women accusing Weinstein of harassment or assault.

images.alt_text: Kevin Spacey has been ordered to pay US$31 million to the production company that fired him from House of Cards after allegations of sexual harassment emerged.

site_title: Electric-car battery maker CATL’s profits jump 200%
summary: CATL, the world's largest electric-car battery maker, expects a 200% profit jump to 9.8 billion yuan (S$1.63 billion) in the third quarter, driven by strong sales to the automotive industry. The company has made US$20 billion spending commitments to expand production capacity at home and abroad, including in Hungary with Mercedes-Benz. Net income could reach 18 billion yuan in the nine months through September, up 132% from the same period last year.

site_title: China’s crypto holdouts test the boundaries of Xi’s crackdown
summary: China's crypto industry, severely impacted by a 2021 crackdown, is finding ways to adapt and thrive in a "grey area." Despite the government's ban on crypto trading and mining, companies are exploring state-sanctioned blockchains and digital yuan, while rogue Bitcoin miners and entrepreneurs try to expand their firms without crossing perceived red lines. The Chinese government's "one eye open, one eye closed" approach to regulating Web3, a decentralized version of the internet, has created an environment where developers can experiment with products like NFTs, but with caution. The sector's future remains uncertain, with some fearing stifling innovation and isolation from the global community.

images.alt_text: Chinese flags are seen among representations of Bitcoin, Dash, Ripple, Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Oil falls by nearly 2% as recession fears outweigh tight supply prospects
summary: Oil prices fell by nearly 2% on Monday, as recession fears outweighed tight supply prospects. Brent crude futures settled at $96.19 a barrel, down $1.73, and West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $91.13 a barrel, losing $1.51. US Federal Reserve officials' comments on rising interest rates and their effect on the economy contributed to the decline. A strengthening US dollar and concerns over global demand also impacted prices, despite Opec+ oil supply cuts.

images.alt_text: The Opec+ cuts will squeeze supply in an already tight market.

site_title: Ford, GM and other carmakers face 50% profit slump next year, UBS analysts say
summary: Automakers Ford and General Motors are expected to face a 50% profit slump next year due to a glut of cars emerging as supply chains weaken demand. UBS analysts predict a decline in earnings for US and European car companies, citing supply-chain shortages, rising costs, and a cash-strapped consumer. Shares of Ford and GM fell 6.9% and 3.9% respectively, adding to a rough year for the companies, which have seen their shares tumble 45% so far.

images.alt_text: The F-150 Lightning Pro now starts at US$51,974, up 30 per cent from the original starting price of US$39,974 when the truck went on sale in May.
GM said it sold 555,580 vehicles in the quarter through Sepember, 24 per cent higher than last year when inventory shortages hit sales.

site_title: Bitcoin mining surges to a record as Merge opens up capacity
summary: Bitcoin mining surged to a record as the Ethereum network's Merge upgrade freed up computing power and data centre space, allowing more companies to tap into the energy and infrastructure. The surge in computing power led to a 13.6% increase in mining difficulty, with around 4% of current Bitcoin mining power coming from Ether mining. The higher level of computing power will likely lower Bitcoin mining revenue, as it increases competition and reduces the token reward for each miner.

images.alt_text: Energy consumption has plummeted by more than 99 per cent on Ethereum after "the merge".
Ether mining has evolved into a multi-billion dollar industry over the last several years.
Crypto miners currently account for about 1.2 gigawatts of electricity demand in Texas, according to the Texas Blockchain Council, which represents miners.

site_title: Europe: Shares subdued amid growth concerns, geopolitical tensions
summary: European shares declined, with the Stoxx 600 index closing 0.4% lower, extending a fourth consecutive session of losses. Investors remain cautious ahead of major corporate earnings, amid concerns over rising interest rates and escalating geopolitical tensions, including Russia's air strikes on Ukraine. The region's Stoxx 600 index briefly rose before closing down.

images.alt_text: Stock price information in the lobby of the Euronext stock exchange in Paris.  The Stoxx Europe 600 slipped 0.4 per cent at 8.05 am in London on Monday (Oct 10).

site_title: Four factors shaping Malaysia’s general election
summary: Malaysia is set to hold a general election within 60 days of parliament's dissolution, with a stormy election expected due to the timing coinciding with the north-east monsoon season. The election will affect approximately 5 million voters, with about 21.1 million eligible to cast their ballots, including 5 million first-time voters. The election's timing has sparked controversy, with the hashtag #UndiBanjir trending on social media, highlighting the potential for flooding and disruptions during the election.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz has tabled Budget 2023, announcing an allocation of RM372.3 billion federal spending.
Malaysia's prime minister Ismail Sabri announced the dissolution of Parliament on Oct 10, 2022.

site_title: Stamford Land to sell Auckland hotel to Albert Street Hotel for NZ$170m
summary: Stamford Land Corporation is selling its 5-star hotel, Stamford Plaza Auckland, in New Zealand for NZ$170 million. The hotel's business and business assets will be sold separately for NZ$18 million. The sale price is 8.5% higher than the property's valuation, which stood at NZ$140.2 million. The transaction will fund future acquisitions and loan repayments, and the company expects the hotel's projected gross operating profit to be 50% below pre-Covid levels.

site_title: Big-spender conferences: the silver lining to Singapore’s strengthening crypto connections
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has seen a surge in cryptocurrency activity despite its intention to tighten regulations. The Token2049 conference in Singapore drew over 7,000 attendees, 2,000 exhibitor companies, and 250 sponsors, generating significant revenue and branding opportunities. Industry participants believe Singapore remains a crucial center for the cryptocurrency industry, despite the regulator's efforts to curb enthusiasm. The event's success has sparked hopes for future conferences in the city-state, with some speculating that Singapore could once again host the event in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Some of the biggest casualties of the crypto downturn, such as hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, operated out of Singapore.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as markets await bank earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the S&P 500 dropping 0.8% to 3,612.43 and the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 1.0% to 10,542.10. Investors await major economic reports, including the US consumer price index data and earnings from companies like Delta Air Lines and JPMorgan. Analysts project a 2.9% earnings increase for S&P 500 companies, down from the 10.5% forecast in June. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.3% to 29,202.94.

images.alt_text: The Apple logo at the tech giant's outlet in Brooklyn, New York. Sixty per cent of those who took part in the MLIV Pulse survey said the iPhone maker, which has the heaviest weighting on the S&P 500, will provide insight into key themes such as consumer demand, supply chains, the effect of the soaring greenback and higher rates.
The markets' mood remains fragile ahead of Thursday’s US inflation data and a raft of bank earnings that will kick off the third-quarter season in earnest.

site_title: Powell set to rebuff pressure on Fed as finance chiefs meet
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to resist pressure to ease interest-rate hikes at upcoming international meetings, despite criticism from global leaders and economists. The Fed's aggressive tightening has sent the US currency surging, affecting developing countries and richer nations with high inflation. Powell and colleagues are on track to deliver their fourth consecutive 75-basis-point hike, citing the need to control inflation. Critics warn of a rising risk of global recession, but Fed officials argue their actions are necessary to restore price stability.

images.alt_text: Fears are mounting that the US Federal Reserve is overtightening interest rates, a policy mistake that could cause a deep recession or a major market breakdown.

site_title: Tech manufacturers could see demand shrink amid looming recession: analysts
summary: Analysts predict a slowdown in demand for tech manufacturers amid a looming recession, driven by high energy costs, inflation, and rising interest rates. Consumer electronics are expected to be more vulnerable to shifts in consumer sentiment, while semiconductor equipment makers and tech solutions providers may still see strong order books. However, some analysts have downgraded their expectations for certain companies, citing concerns over slower growth and potential demand drops.

images.alt_text: Demand for higher-priced iPhone 14 Pro models is stronger than for the entry-level versions.
Weaker-than-expected demand for consumer electronics is hitting companies along with surging shipping and materials costs.

site_title: Rivian shares skid after EV maker recalls nearly all vehicles
summary: Rivian shares fell 7% on Monday after the electric vehicle maker recalled nearly all its vehicles due to a possible loose fastener that could cause driver loss of steering control. The recall affects about 13,000 vehicles, exacerbating concerns about the company's ability to meet its annual production target. Rivian has already delivered 13,198 vehicles since its third-quarter sales began last year, and shares have fallen 67.3% this year due to production forecast cuts and supply-chain issues.

images.alt_text: Rivian will recall the vehicles because a fastener “may not have been sufficiently torqued,” chief executive officer RJ Scaringe said in a letter to customers that was seen by Bloomberg News.
The company is pulling back after roughly doubling its headcount over the past year to support a ramp-up in production.
Rivian Automotive reaffirmed guidance to deliver 25,000 battery-electric vehicles this year, despite ongoing supply chain snarls hampering its ramp in production.
The new credits favour companies, like Tesla and General Motors, that have been selling electric cars for years and have reorganised their supply chains to produce vehicles in the United States.

site_title: UK gilts slump as government fails to woo investors
summary: UK government bond prices plummeted, with yields rising across the range of British debt maturities, despite Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng's efforts to shore up fiscal credibility. The sharp rise in yields, particularly in the long-dated conventional gilt market, was driven by investor nerves over Britain's new economic agenda. The Bank of England expanded its emergency intervention measures, while French, German, and Italian bonds showed smaller increases in yields. The UK's 20- and 30-year gilt yields rose over 30 basis points, with the 20-year yield reaching 4.945%.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng will unveil debt-slashing plans and predictions sooner than expected.

site_title: Oil steadies as supply tightness duels with recession fears
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday, recovering from earlier losses, as investors weighed supply cuts by Opec+ against recession fears. Brent Crude futures fell 1.1% but recovered to be down 0.2% at $97.75 a barrel. Opec+ cut output by 2 million barrels per day, squeezing supply in a tight market. EU sanctions on Russian crude will take effect in December and February, potentially reducing supplies. Fitch Ratings warned of recessionary economic outlook and pricing volatility, with analysts expecting large fluctuations in prices due to geopolitical factors.

images.alt_text: The full supply allocation comes despite a decision by the Opec+ to lower their output target by 2 million barrels per day.

site_title: US dollar rises after case for US rate hikes strengthens
summary: The US dollar rose 0.33% to 113.18, its highest level since October 2021, amid expectations of strong inflation data and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index surpassed last month's 20-year high of 114.78, while the euro slipped 0.4% to US$0.9692. The pound also fell for a fourth consecutive session, despite the Bank of England's efforts to ease concerns about its emergency bond-buying scheme. Geopolitical tensions and higher oil prices contributed to the dollar's rise, as investors sought safe-haven assets.

images.alt_text: US dollar strengthened against major currencies on Friday (Oct 7) after US data showed employers hired more workers than expected in September, suggesting the Federal Reserve will likely stick to its aggressive tightening policy for now.

site_title: Jumbo opens fourth franchised outlet in Vietnam
summary: Jumbo Group officially opened its fourth franchised outlet in Vietnam on Oct 8, marking its first location in Hanoi. The 6,373 sq ft outlet, seating 174, is situated near major landmarks such as the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and One Pillar Pagoda. Group CEO Ang Kiam Meng expressed gratitude to franchise partner Nova F&B Joint Stock Company, stating plans to open more outlets in Vietnam. The announcement resulted in a 2% decline in Jumbo Group's shares.

site_title: IMF, World Bank warn of increasing risk of global recession
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank have warned of a rising risk of a global recession due to faster inflation forcing central banks to raise interest rates, crimping growth. The IMF estimates that one-third of the world economy will experience two consecutive quarters of contraction this year and next, resulting in a lost output of $4 trillion by 2026. Policymakers must balance controlling inflation with avoiding a global contraction, according to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva.

site_title: Stocks face brutal earnings season with all eyes on Apple, investors say
summary: Investors expect a brutal earnings season, with over 60% predicting the S&P 500 Index will fall further, amid concerns about consumer demand, supply chains, and inflation. Apple, with the heaviest weighting on the S&P 500, is seen as a bellwether for global economic conditions, with 60% of respondents citing it as crucial to watch. The earnings season is expected to disappoint, with 40% of survey participants inclined to invest in value stocks, and nearly 40% expecting references to inflation and recession to dominate earnings calls.

images.alt_text: The Paris court of appeals reduced Apple’s total fine on Thursday (Oct 6) to about 371.6 million euros.
FILE PHOTO: The annual Computex computer exhibition in Taipei, Taiwan June 1, 2016. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Binance shakes up landscape for most-traded crypto tokens
summary: Binance's shift in prioritizing its BUSD stablecoin has disrupted the competitive landscape for top stablecoins, including USDC. The exchange's auto-conversion policy, which converted USDC deposits into BUSD, has led to a decline in USDC's value by over 12% since September. Binance's CEO, Changpeng Zhao, claims the move aims to increase liquidity on the platform, making BUSD more appealing to traders. However, this strategy has raised concerns of anti-competitiveness and has led to a decline in USDC's trading volumes, with most of the lost volume shifting to Tether-denominated trading pairs.

images.alt_text: “Software code is never bug free,” Binance’s CEO, Changpeng Zhao, said in an interview with CNBC. He emphasised that no users had lost money in the hack but said that so-called cross-chain bridges were particularly vulnerable to hacks and the industry needed to get better at learning from them.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob announced the dissolution of Parliament on October 10, 2022, triggering a snap general election within 60 days.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah (in green) being greeted by Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob (in black) at an event to mark Maulidur Rasul, in Kuala Lumpur, on Oct 9, 2022.
Malaysia's Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz has tabled Budget 2023, announcing an allocation of RM372.3 billion federal spending.
Malaysia expects to spend a record 80 billion ringgit (S$24.7 billion) in subsidies this year, and that expenditure is forecast to go up next year due to rising global inflation.
Analysts expecting a “feel good” election budget will be announced on Oct 7 to win voters’ hearts.

site_title: Heatwaves will make regions uninhabitable within decades: UN, Red Cross
summary: The UN and Red Cross warn that heatwaves will make certain regions, including the Sahel, Horn of Africa, and South and South-west Asia, uninhabitable within decades due to extreme heat. The predicted heatwaves will exceed human physiological and social limits, leading to large-scale suffering and loss of life. The organisations urge countries to take immediate action to mitigate the worst effects of extreme heat, citing steps such as providing early information, testing thermally-appropriate emergency shelters, and altering development planning.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Waves generated by Typhoon Muifa along the coast in Hangzhou. China has higher exposure to physical hazards relating to climate change, including floods and tropical cyclones.

site_title: The sooner Hong Kong moves to ‘0+0’, the more it can serve as gateway to China
summary: Hong Kong is poised to move towards a '0+0' approach, where it serves as a gateway to China, with the city's tourism and business travel expected to boost its economy. The city's '3+4' quarantine regime has been criticized, with some calling for a complete relaxation of border restrictions. Despite China's zero-Covid policy, Hong Kong remains a key conduit for businesses entering the Chinese market. The city's chief executive has announced the scrapping of hotel quarantine, but the 'amber code' restrictions and repeated PCR tests may continue to deter visitors.

images.alt_text: A flight attendant for Cathay Pacific Airways at Hong Kong International Airport.
In a sign of how isolated Hong Kong has become, in the first 8 months of this year, the city’s airport handled just 3.4 per cent of passengers that it did before Covid, and 30 per cent of flights.
The move to cement testing in the city underscores the balance authorities are attempting to strike between re-opening with a world that’s living with the virus.

site_title: Bernanke, Diamond, Dybvig share Nobel prize in economics
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chair Ben Bernanke, along with economists Douglas Diamond and Philip Dybvig, have been awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Economics for their research on banking and financial crises. The prize recognizes their work on the vulnerability of banks to rumors of collapse and how governments can prevent such crises. Bernanke's studies on the Great Depression demonstrated that bank runs contributed to the crisis, while Diamond and Dybvig's research identified the importance of deposit insurance in preventing bank runs. The trio will share the $1.27 million award.

images.alt_text: Annie Ernaux, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, calls herself a "class defector" for leaving behind the humble neighbourhood of her childhood. But in her writing and her politics, she has never turned her back on her working class roots.

The Nobel Chemistry Prize was awarded to a trio of chemists from the US and Denmark who laid the foundation for a more functional form of chemistry.
Americans Carolyn Bertozzi and Barry Sharpless, together with Denmark's Morten Meldal, were honoured "for the development of click chemistry and bioorthogonal chemistry," the jury said.

site_title: Britain unveils fresh action to calm market turmoil
summary: Britain is taking steps to calm market turmoil after a heavily criticized budget, with Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng unveiling debt-slashing plans and predictions sooner than expected. The Bank of England has also boosted liquidity, launching a temporary facility to ease liquidity pressures. The government has brought forward key economic forecasts and the chancellor has axed a tax cut for the richest earners. The moves come after markets reacted negatively to the budget, with UK bond yields soaring and the pound tumbling to a record low.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Prime Minister Liz Truss attends the annual Conservative Party conference, in Birmingham, Britain, October 2, 2022. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Putin threatens more strikes on Ukraine after missile blitz
summary: Russia launched 83 missile strikes at Ukraine on October 10, targeting energy and communications infrastructure, as well as military command installations. President Vladimir Putin threatened further strikes, saying Russia will respond harshly to any threat. At least 10 explosions were reported in Kyiv, with five people killed and 12 wounded. The strikes mark a significant escalation in the war, prompting international leaders to condemn the attack and pledge additional military support. Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelensky, accused Russia of trying to destroy Ukraine and urged people to stay in bomb shelters.

images.alt_text: Pipes at the landfall facilities of the Nord Stream gas pipeline in Germany. Russia is suspected of having attacked the pipeline.

site_title: Chinese regulator gives green light to fund targeting Korean chipmakers
summary: The China Securities Regulatory Commission has approved the country's first mutual fund targeting top Chinese and South Korean chipmakers amid escalating Sino-US tech war tensions. The move comes after the Biden administration published export controls on China's chip industry. The fund aims to capitalize on the investment opportunities in the sector, which is expected to be significantly impacted by the export controls. The approval is seen as a positive sign for China's chip industry, but the Sino-US tech war is expected to continue to pose challenges for the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) building on the Financial Street in Beijing, China July 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: OCBC appoints Goh Chin Yee CFO with retirement of Darren Tan
summary: OCBC appoints Goh Chin Yee as its new CFO, replacing Darren Tan who is retiring early. Tan will step down on Nov 1, 2022, and hand over to Goh, who has been head of group audit since 2013. Goh's appointment reflects OCBC's strong internal talent base for succession planning, according to CEO Helen Wong. Goh brings 11 years of experience to the role, including implementing data analytics and risk management systems. OCBC shares closed 1.4% lower following the announcement.

images.alt_text: The revised interest rate now applies across all four of the DBS' fixed rate packages with commitment periods ranging from two to five years.

site_title: Vietnam regulator calms market after bank run tied to probe
summary: Vietnam's central bank has calmed the market after a bank run tied to a police probe into a prominent real estate tycoon. The probe into Truong My Lan, chairperson of Van Thinh Phat Holdings, has led to the detention of Lan and other company officials for allegedly obtaining property through fraudulent means. The State Bank of Vietnam assured customers of Saigon Commercial Bank (SCB) that deposits are guaranteed by the state, and the central bank applied measures to ensure SCB's liquidity. The benchmark VN Index recovered after falling earlier in the day, with banking stocks also recovering.

images.alt_text: Vietnam recently broadened its anti-graft drive with a series of high-profile corporate arrests, including top stockbrokers, property developers and even regulators.

site_title: London’s most expensive mansion is on sale again
summary: London's 45-bedroom mansion, previously sold to a British Virgin Islands-based company for £210 million in 2020, is being offered for sale again. The property, located in Knightsbridge, is owned by the family of Hui Ka Yan, chairman of China Evergrande Group, and was acquired through a deal fronted by fellow Chinese billionaire Cheung Chung Kiu. Hui's net worth has decreased to around $6 billion from $30 billion in 2019, prompting the sale of assets. The mansion is being sold through Beauchamp Estates, with the exact sale price remaining private.

site_title: Smile beats Lyle to top North American box office
summary: Smile, a horror film starring Sosie Bacon, topped North America's box office for a second weekend with an estimated US$17.6 million. Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile, a live-action/computer animated musical comedy, placed second with US$11.5 million. Amsterdam, a comedy thriller, took third with US$6.5 million, despite poor reviews. The Woman King and Don't Worry Darling rounded out the top 10, with smaller box office earnings.

images.alt_text: Canadian-American actor Luke Macfarlane (left) and US comedian Billy Eichner at the premiere of the movie Bros in Los Angeles late last month. The R-rated Bros was heavily promoted as historic – a first for mass-market, studio-driven cinema because it focuses on homosexuality.
Top Korean actors and Asian stars are set to attend the Busan International Film Festival, which opened with a red carpet event and will run until Oct 14.
Arts Minister Tony Burke announced the deal on Monday (Oct 10) at Sydney’s Disney Studios, which has been renamed from Fox Studios Australia.

site_title: Even a Lula victory may not restore Brazil’s forests
summary: Brazil's presidential hopeful Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's forest policies, aimed at protecting the Amazon rainforest, may not be enough to restore the country's forests. Lula's policies involve loosening restrictions on farming in other areas, such as the cerrado savannah, in exchange for Amazon protection. This compromise has allowed for significant deforestation in the Amazon, but may help slow emissions elsewhere. A Lula victory may lead to increased environmental protections, but it's unclear if it will be enough to reverse the damage and make Brazil a climate leader.

images.alt_text: Cutting down trees to clear land for cattle or to sell timber is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, and banks and fund managers add to the problem by providing the financing needed to enable deforestation.

Bolsonaro has enraged environmentalists by championing large agricultural companies involved in the deforestation of the Amazon, a crucial “sink” for carbon emissions blamed for the planet’s rising temperatures.
The unexpectedly strong showing by President Bolsonaro on Sunday revitalized Brazil's presidential election campaign, setting the stage for a highly competitive and tense run-off on Oct 30.

site_title: Inflation and early shopping to slow US online holiday spending, says report
summary: US online holiday sales are expected to rise 2.5% to $209.7 billion in November and December, the slowest pace since 2015, due to decades-high inflation and soaring interest rates. Shoppers are returning to in-store shopping and bringing forward purchases, leading to a slowdown in shopping for the holidays. FedEx Corp's Ground division and Mastercard's SpendingPulse report also forecast lower volume forecasts and a slowdown in holiday shopping.

images.alt_text: Larger retailers would rather pay to store their goods in warehouses than risk having them sitting outside the port on a vessel.
British consumers are up against the highest inflation in 4 decades already and this could lead to a recession lasting more than a year, threatening to push many into poverty.

Visitors in Times Square in midtown Manhattan on May 21, 2022. Pedestrian traffic is making a comeback — in the garment district, weekly foot traffic rose to 3.5 million people in mid-May — about 77 per cent of the pre-pandemic level — according to the Garment District Alliance
FedEx reinstates 2022 profit target, shares soar

site_title: Hot stock: Golden Energy hits all-time high on news of potential buyout
summary: Golden Energy and Resources' shares surged 11.3% on Monday, reaching an all-time high of S$0.935, following news of a potential buyout by certain shareholders, including Indra Widjaja. The company is in discussions regarding the deal, with no concrete outcome or definitive agreements. This is the highest the counter has been since 2015.

images.alt_text: Group revenue trebled to US$2.4 billion in the first 6 months of FY2022, from US$806.7 million in the previous year.
Golden Energy and Resources to pare stake in Stanmore through entitlement offer
Fitch revises outlook on Golden Energy to 'positive' from 'stable'

site_title: EU gas cap breakthrough remains on the table
summary: The European Union is considering a landmark gas price cap to reduce revenue flows to Russia, following last week's eighth package of sanctions, which included an oil price cap. The cap is seen as a high-priority measure to address the energy crisis, with gas prices nearly four times higher across Europe than a year ago. Energy ministers will meet on October 11 to discuss options, including a temporary ceiling on prices and joint purchasing of gas. The EU leadership summit on October 20-21 may also agree on a gas price cap, although a consensus may take longer to emerge.

images.alt_text: European countries have filled storage tanks to around 90 per cent of their capacity after Russia cut gas supplies in response to Western sanctions imposed over its invasion of Ukraine.

A Ukrainian tank moving through a recently recaptured area in the country's Donetsk region. Following Russia's annexations of Ukraine territory, the European Union and other G7 states are ramping up the pressure with more sanctions.

site_title: 'Human billiards' installation rolls into Danish museum
summary: A museum in Copenhagen has installed a recreation of a 1970s art installation called 'Giant Billiard', a playful and anarchic game where visitors bounce three large, inflatable balls across a white mattress. The installation, created by Austrian architect/artist group Haus-Rucker-Co, aimed to break down power hierarchies and create utopian urban spaces. The re-creation, now on display at the Arken Museum of Modern Art, has been deemed timely, addressing social inequality and isolation in today's society, with visitors encouraged to interact with each other while having fun.

images.alt_text: Shen the T-Rex will be the first Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton to be offered at a Christie's auction in Asia.

site_title: Era of peak yields signals entry point for emerging-market bets
summary: Emerging-market investors are taking bets on rate hikes by central banks in the US, UK, and Europe as moderation signals an entry point for emerging-market bets. After two years of high inflation, developing nations are reporting declines in consumer-price growth, and monetary tightening is moderating. This combination of trends has led to lower equity and bond valuations, higher real yields, and beaten-down currencies, making the developing world more attractive for investors. Expectations for a peak in borrowing costs next year are encouraging investors to re-engage with emerging-market assets.

images.alt_text: Fears are mounting that the US Federal Reserve is overtightening interest rates, a policy mistake that could cause a deep recession or a major market breakdown.
India’s stockpile has tumbled US$96 billion this year to US$538 billion.

The IMF estimates countries accounting for about a third of the global economy will experience at least two consecutive quarters of contraction this or next year, IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva said.

Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.

site_title: Renault gains on talks that may lead to paring of Nissan stake
summary: Renault's stock surged 6.8% to €32.75 after the company confirmed talks with Nissan that could lead to a potential sell-down of Renault's €6.1 billion stake in the Japanese manufacturer. Renault is open to reducing its stake, which could yield €4 billion in cash before tax, and is discussing several initiatives, including a potential investment in Renault's new electric vehicle entity. The French state and Nissan also need to approve any plan, which could take years and involve concessions from both parties.

images.alt_text: French car firm Renault owns about 43 per cent of Nissan, while the Japanese firm owns 15 per cent of its top shareholder, but without voting rights.
The Megane E-Tech model, which is being widely advertised in French media, was the country’s best-selling EV in July.

JAPAN'S Mitsubishi Motors and Nissan Motor unveiled their first jointly developed light electric vehicles (EVs), aiming to draw more Japanese drivers to battery-powered cars by offering low-priced micro models.

Renault's plan to carve out separate electric-vehicle and combustion-engine businesses isn't aimed at disrupting its global alliance with Nissan Motor and Mitsubishi Motors, the French carmaker's chief executive officer said.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down on rate hike fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.95% on Monday, Oct 10, following a US jobs report that fueled expectations of larger interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 17,216.66, mirroring losses in mainland Chinese markets, which fell 1.66% and 2.17% on the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes, respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns over potential COVID flare-ups and painful lockdowns in China.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional decline on Monday; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore stocks closed lower on Monday, October 10, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 1.2% to 3,107.47, as regional markets declined due to a robust US jobs report. Losers outnumbered gainers 360 to 191, with Thai Beverage and local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB leading the decliners. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the only index counter in positive territory, rising 2.5%. Investors remain cautious ahead of the US Consumer Price Index (CPI) data release on Thursday, which may impact inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: Shanghai dropped as traders returned from a weeklong holiday, with rising Covid numbers in the country leading to worries of more economically painful lockdowns ahead of a key Communist Party gathering.
Employers, many still short-staffed, continue to hire at a solid pace.
Markets across the globe are down amid economic uncertainties and fears of tax hikes.

site_title: BOE doubles size of bond buybacks as emergency plan nears expiry
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has doubled its bond buyback plan to calm concerns about the expiry of its emergency program, which nears its end this week. The central bank will buy up to £10 billion daily, up from £5 billion, to ease turmoil in the government bond market. The move comes after finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng's unfunded tax cuts alarmed investors last month. The BOE also launched a temporary expanded collateral repo facility to ease liquidity pressures on banks and pension funds.

images.alt_text: On Sep 28, the BOE launched a programme to potentially buy up to £65 billion of gilts with a maturity of 20 years in a series of operations running until Oct 14.

site_title: Asia must tailor, tighten OECD’s one-size-fits-all corporate governance principles: panellists
summary: Panellists at the Sias conference in Singapore emphasized the need for tailored and tightened corporate governance principles to effectively address Asia's unique challenges. Proposed revisions to the OECD's Group of 20/OECD Principles of Corporate Governance aim to address growing concerns on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. Experts stress that ESG investing should focus on compelling companies to make better choices, rather than solely chasing returns, and that engagement with companies, rather than exclusion, is a more effective approach.

images.alt_text: “We are a body that exists to advance the interests of investors. Surely, this award exercise must be in their interests,” said David Gerald, president and CEO of Sias.
Investing in environmental technology, while paying heed to national agenda, can deliver not just financial returns, but environmental impact as well.

The panel on why ESG matters in business valuation, organised by the Institute of Valuers and Appraisers and International Valuation Standards Council, was moderated by BT correspondent Wong Pei Ting.

site_title: China SCE, Shimao units miss US$225m in trust payments
summary: China SCE Group Holdings and Shimao Group Holdings missed payments on $323.5 million of trust borrowings, adding to a string of defaults by Chinese developers amid a liquidity crunch. Construction workers at a site in Beijing. Xiamen Zhongjun Industrial Co and Shanghai Shimao Jianshe Co had their bank accounts frozen after a court lawsuit, while the companies didn't immediately respond to requests for comment. This is the latest in a series of defaults by Chinese property firms struggling with falling home sales and reduced liquidity.

images.alt_text: Construction personnel work on scaffolding at a construction site in Beijing on September 14, 2022. (Photo by Noel Celis / AFP)

site_title: MAS bans ex-BSI deputy CEO over neglect in 1MDB debacle; police issue warning
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned Raj Sriram, former deputy CEO of BSI Bank Singapore, from providing financial advisory services due to his neglect in filing suspicious transaction reports on 1MDB-related transactions. Sriram received a 10-year prohibition order and a 24-month conditional warning from the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department. The MAS deemed Sriram's neglect contributed to BSI's failure to file reports, which was a key conduit for tainted funds in the 1MDB debacle.

site_title: A pleasant surprise may be in store for consumers this Christmas
summary: The global supply chain crunch is easing, with a decrease in shipping demand and increased warehouse capacity. As a result, retailers are expected to clear part of their abundant inventory at a discount, providing consumers with a pleasant surprise this Christmas. Larger retailers have ordered early to boost supply chain resilience, and alternative sourcing options are being explored to reduce lead times. However, consumer sentiment remains weakened due to high energy costs and interest rates, and shipping volumes are expected to remain relatively flat over the next few months, with aggressive sales campaigns and discounting instead.

images.alt_text: US consumers are not buying as much as they did during the pandemic, and confidence has been hurt by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Supply chains are being reshaped for greater resilience, but this process can take years. In the meantime, cooling global demand is providing some relief.

site_title: Hollywood Down Under lures Disney’s Planet of the Apes
summary: The Australian government has announced a deal to lure 20th Century Studios to produce the latest "Planet of the Apes" movie at Disney Studios in Sydney, as part of efforts to bolster the city's reputation as "Hollywood Down Under". The production is expected to create over 400 jobs and inject A$128 million into the Australian economy. The government will contribute A$17 million, while additional funding will come from Screen NSW's Made In NSW fund.

site_title: Rethink investment objective and risk tolerance, urges Mercer chief investment strategist
summary: Mercer's chief investment strategist, Rich Nuzum, advises clients to rethink their investment objectives and risk tolerance due to the current macroeconomic environment. The traditional 60/40 bond-equity portfolio has failed to provide diversification benefits, and fixed income yields remain uncertain. Investors are also advised to consider investing 5-10% of portfolios in China A-shares, which Mercer believes has potential for "outsized alpha". This shift is driven by the growing importance of Asia in the global economy and the need for dollar asset diversification.

images.alt_text: Travellers arrive at the Hong Kong International Airport on Sept 26, the first day the COVID hotel quarantine was scrapped

site_title: Europe: Stocks tick lower at open as inflation data, earnings loom
summary: European stocks declined 0.4% at the open on Monday amid concerns over higher interest rates and inflation, following Asian peers. US futures also fell, with semiconductor stocks dropping due to fresh curbs on China's access to American technology. The US inflation data, due Thursday, is expected to pressure policymakers to extend rate hikes beyond this year, with the Federal Reserve showing hawkish stance. The Bank of England increased its emergency gilt buying measures to support market functioning, while oil prices eased due to tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The continent-wide Stoxx 600 index was down 1.2 per cent, logging a third straight session of declines.
Frankfurt’s DAX index has dipped 0.4 per cent to 12,419.72 points at the open on Friday (Oct 7).

A sign outside the London Stock Exchange in London, UK, on Friday, Sept. 23, 2022. The UK Government wants to supercharge the City of London's growth, arguing it will boost the whole country's post-Brexit prospects. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia: Financials and gold stocks drag shares lower
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% on Monday, led by financials and gold stocks, after a surprise drop in US unemployment data raised hopes for a slower pace of monetary policy tightening. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,667.8, its biggest daily fall since September 26. Financials dropped 1.5% and gold stocks fell 4.7% as investors awaited US inflation data for further clues about the pace of Fed rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.4 per cent to 6,665.9 by 0013 GMT on Monday in its biggest intraday percentage drop since Sept 26.

site_title: Collective action is necessary to fight global inflation
summary: A "reverse currency war" is underway, where central banks, including Japan, Switzerland, and Norway, are raising their benchmarks to keep pace with the rapidly appreciating US dollar. This is driven by the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes to combat high inflation, which is forcing other countries' central banks to follow suit. The US dollar's strength is reducing import costs and is seen as a key factor in the global economy's current challenges, including the risk of a worldwide economic recession.

images.alt_text: Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
Prices in the US have surged over the past year, partly due to global supply chain problems.
Fears are mounting that the US Federal Reserve is overtightening interest rates, a policy mistake that could cause a deep recession or a major market breakdown.

site_title: 'Born to fly' – Indian pilot blazes trail for women in aviation
summary: Indian pilot Zoya Agarwal, who became the first woman to fly the longest non-stop Indian commercial flight, says she won't be happy until women make up half of pilots in the country. Agarwal, who has been a trailblazer for women in aviation, faces a conservative upbringing that discouraged her from pursuing a career in flying. Despite facing numerous challenges, including her parents' initial disapproval and financial struggles, Agarwal persevered and now advocates for greater opportunities for women in aviation, aiming to empower them to take control of their careers.

images.alt_text: In this photograph taken on September 11, 2022, captain Zoya Agarwal leaves for the airport from her residence in Greater Noida. - India has the world's highest rate of women pilots but when Zoya Agarwal said she dreamed of conquering the skies, her mother cried and told her to wait for a "suitable boy" to marry instead. (Photo by Money SHARMA / AFP) / To go with 'India-Social-Gender-Women-Aviation', INTERVIEW by Laurence THOMANN

In this photograph taken on September 11, 2022, captain Zoya Agarwal speaks during an interview with AFP in Greater Noida. - India has the world's highest rate of women pilots but when Zoya Agarwal said she dreamed of conquering the skies, her mother cried and told her to wait for a "suitable boy" to marry instead. (Photo by Money SHARMA / AFP) / To go with 'India-Social-Gender-Women-Aviation', INTERVIEW by Laurence THOMANN

site_title: Philippine tycoon postpones US$474m prime infrastructure IPO on bearish market
summary: Philippine tycoon Enrique Razon has delayed the IPO of his infrastructure and energy holding firm, Prime Infrastructure Capital, due to a bearish market. The IPO, originally set for October, could now occur in May or June next year, allowing the company to wait for the global economy to recover and markets to stabilize. The IPO was expected to be the Philippines' largest this year, with a valuation of up to $474 million. Razon's company plans to use the funds to finance its energy, water, and waste businesses.

images.alt_text: pixphililipines - Traders work on the floor of the Philippine Stock Exchange in the Makati district of Manila, the Philippines, on Monday, May 2, 2016. Philippine stocks fell the most since February after a poll showed tough-talking Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte maintaining a comfortable lead a week before the presidential election. Photographer: Taylor Weidman/Bloomberg

site_title: First foreign 737 Max flight takes to skies in China after almost four years
summary: The first commercial Boeing 737 Max flight took to the skies in China after almost four years, marking a major breakthrough for the US planemaker. Miat Mongolian Airlines operated a round-trip flight between Ulaanbaatar and Guangzhou on October 10, with scheduled flights on October 17 and 24. Boeing's resumption of deliveries in China is crucial for rebuilding its balance sheet, which was damaged by the Max grounding and the Covid pandemic. China was the last major market to permit the Max's return, following US and European regulators' approvals in 2020 and 2021, respectively.

images.alt_text: Boeing, which hasn’t signed a major plane deal with China since 2017, took the unusual step of issuing a statement after the July Airbus order was announced.

site_title: China job market prospects drop to record low as economy weakens
summary: China's job market prospects have hit a record low, with the central bank's Employment Sentiment Index declining to 35.4 in the third quarter, the lowest since data began in 2010. The survey found 45.2% of households said finding a job was "tough" or "hard to judge," and only 9.7% said it was easy. The unemployment rate for young people is nearly 19%, and the housing market is also weak, with only 14.8% of respondents expecting home prices to rise in the next quarter.
