Apollo Global Management and Sixth Street Partners are no longer providing financing to Elon Musk earlier this year for his proposed US$44 billion buyout of Twitter, two sources revealed.
Elon Musk has offered to push through with his buyout of Twitter at the original agreed price, just weeks before the opening of a bitter court case over his effort to withdraw from the deal.

site_title: Nissan presses partner Renault to sell down stake: WSJ
summary: Nissan is pressuring partner Renault to sell down its 43% stake in the Japanese automaker, citing a desire to revamp their over 20-year-old alliance. Nissan owns 15% of Renault but lacks voting rights. Talks center on whether Nissan will invest in Renault's electric vehicle business in exchange for Renault winding down its stake. Renault is pushing ahead with plans to split its EV and combustion engine businesses to catch up with rivals. A detailed blueprint for the new EV entity is expected to be unveiled this autumn.

images.alt_text: Japan’s Toyota suffered a 7 per cent drop in sales in the latest three months, to more than 526,000 units in the US.

Robotic arms bring together car frames for welding at Nissan Motor Co's manufacturing plant in Smyrna, Tennessee. site_title: Brazil's Cosan acquires 4.9% of miner Vale, plans to buy more
summary: Brazilian conglomerate Cosan SA has acquired a 4.9% stake in Vale SA, a major iron ore miner, and plans to increase its stake to 6.5% pending approval. The deal is valued at around 21 billion reais (S$5.8 billion) and marks a major breakthrough in Cosan's push into the iron ore industry. Cosan, controlled by Brazilian billionaire Rubens Ometto, aims to use the stake to transport iron ore via its Sao Luis port company. The deal is Cosan's first major move into the mining sector, following its joint venture with Aura Minerals last year.

images.alt_text: A truck transports nickel materials to the plant owned by PT Vale Indonesia Tbk in Sorowako of Indonesia's South Sulawesi province February 29, 2012. Indonesia's new mining law is aimed at generating more funds for government from the mining sector, the energy and minerals minister said on March 7, 2012. The law announced on the energy ministry website will require foreign firms to sell down stakes in mines by the 10th year of production and also require companies to increase domestic ownership to at least 51 percent. site_title: US fund managers bet on poker while market wagers loom large
summary: Hedge fund managers and traders gathered for a charity poker tournament at New York's Gotham Hall, setting aside concerns about market volatility and recent economic challenges. The event, sponsored by Morgan Stanley and other prominent hedge funds, raised nearly $2 million for education reform. Despite discussions about the market, participants found the competition to be a welcome distraction, with the tournament's champion, a real estate agent and model, being crowned after 1 am. The event provided a lighthearted and entertaining atmosphere amidst market uncertainty.

site_title: US tightens chip export controls to China
summary: The US has announced new export controls to restrict China's ability to buy and manufacture high-end semiconductors with military applications. The rules, announced by the US Department of Commerce, include export restrictions on supercomputing chips and tougher requirements for semiconductor equipment sales. The move aims to prevent sensitive technologies from being acquired by China's military and intelligence services, amid growing tensions between the two countries. This comes ahead of China's party congress, where President Xi Jinping is expected to secure a historic third term, and follows a multibillion-dollar US bill boosting domestic semiconductor manufacturing.

site_title: UN rights council extends Ethiopia commission by a year
summary: The UN Rights Council voted 21-19 to extend a commission of experts investigating human rights in conflict-torn Ethiopia for another year. The commission, which has been mired in conflict since 2020, will make a verbal report to the Human Rights Council in early 2023. The extension was supported by human rights groups, including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, who called it a "powerful message" to warring parties that those who commit abuses could face justice.

site_title: Spotify podcast union says corporate decisions led to audience collapse
summary: Spotify is ending 11 podcasts and terminating 38 employees after a decision to put shows exclusively on its own streaming service led to a significant drop in listeners. Union representatives claim that 30% of their members were let go, with some programs losing up to 75% of their audience. The employees argue that Spotify did not provide enough marketing support or clear audience goals, leading to the decline of their shows. The union is seeking to allow affected employees to take their contacts, sources, and unfinished work with them.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends sharply lower as jobs report cements rate hike regime
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, October 7, as a strong jobs report in September increased expectations of another 75 basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The unemployment rate fell to 3.5%, lower than expected, while nonfarm payrolls rose by 263,000 jobs. Despite the robust labor market, the Fed's efforts to combat inflation are likely to continue, with money markets raising the probability of a fourth straight rate hike to 92%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.1%, and the S&P 500 lost 2.8%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 241.7 points, or 0.81 per cent, at the open to 29,685.27.

site_title: Deal reached for civil aviation to try for net-zero emissions by 2050
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) reached an agreement with 193 nations to strive for net-zero carbon emissions in air travel by 2050. The non-binding goal is seen as a historic step forward, with only four countries expressing reservations. Airlines and industry representatives welcomed the agreement, but critics say it is not ambitious enough and lacks legal binding. The aviation sector is responsible for 2.5-3% of global CO2 emissions, and experts estimate it will require $1.55 trillion in investments between 2021 and 2050 to decarbonize.

images.alt_text: Countries typically take a “production-based” accounting approach in quantifying their greenhouse gas emissions.

More aggressive climate policies are par for the course if Singapore embarks on a more definitive plan to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, economists, academics and consultants told The Business Times.

site_title: India's Hero MotoCorp launches first electric scooter worldwide
summary: Hero MotoCorp, an Indian motorcycle maker, launched its first electric scooter worldwide, the Vida Plus, with a starting price of 145,000 rupees (S$2,519) and a minimum range of 143 km on a single charge. The company will begin taking bookings on October 10 and deliveries in December. This move aims to catch up with newer businesses in India's clean mobility push, where electric vehicles currently account for only 2% of total two-wheeler sales. Hero MotoCorp aims to increase electric vehicle sales to 70% by 2030.

images.alt_text: The operating cost of the Tiago EV is expected to be about a seventh of the gasoline version.

site_title: China holiday tourist trips fall 18% on year on broad Covid curbs
summary: China recorded 422 million tourist trips over the National Day holiday, down 18.2% from last year, due to stringent Covid-19 curbs. Domestic tourism revenues fell 26.2% to 287.2 billion yuan, 44.2% of pre-pandemic levels in 2019. One popular destination, Xishuangbanna, was severely impacted by Covid restrictions, leading to increased per capita local tourism expenditure. The decline in tourism is expected to continue, with China's GDP growth set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: The cloud is the fiercest front in the chip wars
summary: The global market for server chips is becoming increasingly crowded and complex, with the business of data centre chips being a bright spot in the semiconductor industry. The market size and growth are driving competition, with specialist chip designers expanding their server chip businesses and cloud providers designing their own processors. Companies like Intel, Nvidia, and AMD are investing heavily in server chip technology, with Intel aiming to close the gap with Taiwanese manufacturer TSMC. The growing sophistication of cloud computing is also driving the demand for more advanced chip architectures, with companies repurposing existing technology and developing new designs.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor demand is weakening as consumers tighten their belts and companies including Apple Inc freeze hiring or cut staff.
Intel’s latest Core desktop processors will provide gamers and other high-performance users with a significant boost.

site_title: Aspen proposes sale of its factory building and leased land for RM200m
summary: Aspen, a property developer, proposes selling its glove-making subsidiary's factory building and leased land in Kulim, Kedah, Malaysia, for RM200 million. The sale, which accounts for over 20% of the group's total net asset value, is expected to book a gain of RM14.9 million. The sale is subject to shareholder approval and will increase the net tangible asset value per share to 39.22 sen from 37.84 sen. The move comes as demand for gloves has decreased since the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as strong US jobs data fans rate hike fears
summary: European shares fell 1.2% on Friday, logging a third straight session of declines, as strong US jobs data fueled rate hike fears. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates for a fourth straight month, despite the unemployment rate dropping and inflation remaining high. Investors will watch next Thursday's consumer prices report for further policy tightening guidance.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index reversed early session gains and was down 0.6 per cent, extending losses to a second straight session.

site_title: BT’s Raphael Lim wins Sias Investor Education Journalist of the Year award
summary: Raphael Lim, correspondent at The Business Times, has won the Investor Education Journalist of the Year award at the Securities Investors Association (Singapore)’s Investors’ Choice Awards 2022. He received the award for his coverage on special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) in Singapore. Lim's work aimed to educate retail investors on the new investment vehicle. Other notable winners include Lianhe Zaobao’s Chew Boon Leong, The Straits Times’ Chor Khieng Yuit, and CNA938’s Gerard Wong.

images.alt_text: SPACs entry opens exciting chapter for Singapore market, but do your homework before investing
First SPACs take steps to go beyond SGX's minimum requirements
Keen interest could see first Singapore SPAC listings within 3 months
SPACs' impact on Singapore market will depend on their long-term performance
BT's Ben Paul named Sias Financial Journalist of the Year

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as jobs growth boosts rate hike bets
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, October 7, 2022, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.81% to 29,685.27, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declining. Solid job growth and a drop in unemployment rate pointed to a tight labor market, giving the Federal Reserve more room to raise interest rates. The solid job growth and low unemployment rate is a key factor in the US rate hike bets.

site_title: US Treasury sets new tax credit rule to expand affordable housing
summary: The US Treasury has finalized a new tax credit rule to expand affordable housing by allowing a broader mix of income levels among residents of qualifying projects. The rule, which clarifies a 2018 law, also extends deadlines for when projects must be placed in service. Additionally, the Federal Housing Finance Agency has taken steps to allow Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to provide an additional $6 billion in financing per year to secure long-term financing for affordable housing projects. This move aims to preserve and expand the supply of affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Investors should therefore not assume that Singapore property prices are a one-way street and will continue to rise unhindered.

Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
Services activity is being supported by a shift in spending from goods, though demand for services is starting to slow.

A pro-choice rally in Tucson, Arizona on Jul 4. Earlier expectations that the Republicans would emerge as clear winners in the United States' Nov 8 midterm elections are being eroded, partly due to the Supreme Court's decision to put abortion rights in the hands of US state legislators.

site_title: Reasons to be optimistic about Asean equities
summary: Asean economies are experiencing a comeback as North Asian growth falters, driven by relaxed pandemic measures and border curbs. Asean markets have outperformed their northern counterparts and most developed markets year-to-date, with recovery underway since 2022. The region's growth outlook has improved due to economic reopening and relaxed social distancing measures, while low inflation and reduced stagflation risks provide a tailwind. Supply chain disruptions have been relatively isolated to the region, benefiting Asean countries. With 6 of the 10 largest Asean economies growing faster than inflation, the region is well-positioned to deal with market challenges.

images.alt_text: The Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta; the composition of South-east Asia’s equity benchmarks – low tech weighting and relatively high ratio of bank shares – is favourable in a rising global interest-rate environment.
Investors are paring their holdings in the once-booming economy, despite their conviction that long-term growth will continue.

site_title: Berlin stages light festival despite energy crunch
summary: Berlin's annual Festival of Lights began despite an energy crisis, with organisers reducing energy consumption by 75% and powering displays from renewable sources. The event, which attracts over 2 million spectators, was initially criticized for its timing, but the measures taken were deemed sufficient to minimize its environmental impact. The festival runs until October 16 and aims to showcase the city's festive spirit while promoting sustainability.

images.alt_text: The landfall facilities of the Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany. Nord Stream 1, which runs under the Baltic Sea to Germany, historically supplied about a third of the gas Russia exported to Europe.
Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government is set to approve the plan – which is designed to help energy companies forced to pay higher prices due to Russian supply cuts.
Germany is at the centre of Europe’s energy crunch as Russian President Vladimir Putin slashes supplies in retaliation for sanctions related to the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Don’t mistake corporate social responsibility for corporate decency
summary: A corporate culture of decency can be a key differentiator for businesses, attracting and retaining talent in a post-pandemic labor market. Decency is about doing the right thing by one another, even when no one's looking, and requires a nuanced approach that involves leaders setting the tone and ensuring it's reflected at all levels. Rewarding cooperation over competition and making decency a foundation rather than an add-on can foster a culture of decency that promotes trust, safety, and innovation. By recognizing and rewarding qualities like cooperativeness and compassion, companies can create a workplace where decency is valued and self-perpetuates.

images.alt_text: In 'toxic' workplaces, the rot starts at the top
The business case for positive workplace culture

site_title: Thailand's deadly mix of guns, drugs and domestic violence
summary: A mass shooting in Thailand's northeastern region, Uthai Sawan, has killed 36 people, mostly children, after a former police officer stormed a daycare center, killing his wife, son, and himself. Authorities attribute the violence to a deadly mix of gun addiction, domestic violence, and mental illness. Experts say Thailand's support systems for family violence, drug addiction, and mental illness are in crisis, with an urban-rural divide and stigma discouraging those from seeking help. The country's high gun ownership and easy access to firearms also contribute to the violence.

images.alt_text: The motive behind the crime was unclear but the suspect, identified as Panya Kamrab, was believed to be under the influence of drugs, a local police official said.

site_title: Gold slides after US jobs data keeps pressure on the Fed to hike
summary: US jobs data showed a tight labor market, dashing hopes for the Federal Reserve to ease rate hikes. Nonfarm payrolls rose 263,000, and the unemployment rate declined, leading to a 0.9% drop in gold to $1,696.70 an ounce. The data keeps the Fed on a hawkish track, putting pressure on gold, which has slid 18% from its March high. The central bank's rate hikes are expected to continue, affecting gold prices.

site_title: Japan Foods clarifies MOM has not given details of potential employment breach
summary: Japan Foods clarified that its unit Japan Foods Enterprises (JFE) is temporarily prohibited from applying or renewing employees' work passes, not the whole group, amid an Employment of Foreign Manpower Act breach. The company stated it was not informed of any details by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and did not want to speculate on past hiring practices. JFE is allowed to hire local staff without work pass requirements.

images.alt_text: Cortina Holdings will be buying over the fourth level of 15 Scotts Road (pictured) for S$49 million.

site_title: Bitcoin drops as strong jobs data seen keeping Fed on rate-hike path
summary: Bitcoin dropped 2.8% to US$19,485 after the US jobs report showed a faster-than-expected expansion of payrolls and a decline in the unemployment rate, bolstering expectations of continued aggressive rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. This strengthened investors' perception that risk assets will remain under pressure. Experts, including Katie Stockton, expect the bear-market cycle to continue, with the labor market remaining resilient despite high inflation.

site_title: China EV stocks tumble amid concerns over slowing sector growth
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) stocks plummeted, with Nio and XPeng falling over 6% and BYD declining 3.7%, amid concerns over slowing sector growth and a shift in demand. Li Auto shares dropped 15%, the largest decline since March, due to speculation about weaker-than-expected holiday orders. The decline was also fueled by concerns over EV demand in 2023 and a lackluster delivery performance by Tesla. The sector's expensive valuations and negative headlines have hurt sentiment, with investors worried about the EV growth outlook for next year.

images.alt_text: The strong quarter came despite challenges that LG Energy has faced since its initial public offering in January, with the whole industry battling supply chain disruptions and rising raw material prices.

site_title: Vaccination-differentiated measures to be lifted from Oct 10: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) announced that vaccination-differentiated safe-management measures (VDS) will be lifted from October 10, allowing non-vaccinated individuals to dine-in at food and beverage establishments and attend events with over 500 participants. However, the government may reinstate VDS if necessary to protect medical workers and the public. Additionally, the government will shift its vaccination tracking system to focus on up-to-date vaccination status rather than individual shot counts.

site_title: Is property still a good investment for Singaporeans?
summary: Singaporeans view residential properties as a good investment, despite recent turbulence in financial markets. The property market has seen a 36% gain in the past five years, outperforming the local stock market and global equities. However, authorities have introduced property cooling measures, which may impact the private residential property segment. Investors should not assume that property prices will continue to rise unhindered, and instead, should consider a more nuanced approach to investing in the Singapore property market.

images.alt_text: HDB flats in the Queenstown area and Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) as viewed from Block 90 Tanglin Halt on May 27, 2021.
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

site_title: Facebook warning a million users about stolen usernames, passwords
summary: Facebook has notified around a million users that their account credentials may have been compromised due to security issues with malicious apps downloaded from Apple and Google stores. Meta identified over 400 malicious Android and iOS apps this year, which target users to steal login information. The apps disguised themselves as photo editors, mobile games, or health trackers. Apple removed 45 problematic apps from its App Store, while Google removed all malicious apps. Meta is sharing tips with users on how to avoid being re-compromised by learning to spot problematic apps.

images.alt_text: Facebook will use that feedback to temporarily alter the kinds of content  people see as it works to improve “discovery” across the company’s apps

site_title: Not so solitary
summary: Running is a team sport that involves more than just individual competition. Amateur and professional runners rely on volunteers, coaches, and teammates to support their training and performance. Claus Henning-Schulke, a 56-year-old amateur triathlete, has volunteered as a bottle passer for elite runner Eliud Kipchoge since 1998. This role, and others like it, demonstrate the importance of teamwork in running and highlight the benefits of building communities through the sport.

site_title: US jobs rise while unemployment drops, keeping pressure on Fed
summary: US employment continued to rise at a solid pace in September, with 263,000 new jobs added, the smallest monthly advance since April 2021. The unemployment rate dropped to 3.5%, and average hourly earnings rose 0.3% from August. The labor market remains tight, despite interest-rate hikes, and the Fed aims to see a softening in labor market conditions to cool wage growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: Fears are mounting that the US Federal Reserve is overtightening interest rates, a policy mistake that could cause a deep recession or a major market breakdown.

site_title: Fu Yu’s CFO to leave firm after mutually agreeing to part ways
summary: Fu Yu Corp has agreed to part ways with its CFO Hee Siew Fong through a settlement agreement. The 51-year-old CFO, who joined the firm in 2016, is leaving the company without any material disagreements or concerns about financial reporting. Fu Yu did not disclose the reasons behind the decision in a statement to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The firm stated that Hee and the board did not have any disagreements that would impact the company's financial reporting.

site_title: China’s holiday spending slumps as consumer demand in Asia slows
summary: China's National Day holiday saw a 26% decline in tourism revenue to 287 billion yuan (S$57.6 billion), a 56% drop from pre-pandemic levels in 2019. The decline in consumer spending is attributed to strict Covid-19 rules and a broader slowdown in Asia. The slump in the property market, slowing global demand for Chinese goods, and a plunging currency further exacerbate economic concerns. Several economists predict Beijing won't ease Covid Zero policies until after March next year, potentially prolonging the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: At a meeting on Sep 8, Premier Li called for efforts to solve the “key problem of insufficient demand” in the economy and boost consumption as a main growth driver.

site_title: US targets firms based in Singapore, Marshall Islands in new North Korea sanctions
summary: The US has imposed new sanctions on North Korea, targeting two Singapore-registered companies and a Marshall Islands-registered company for supporting Pyongyang's weapons programs. The sanctions aim to hold North Korea accountable for ship-to-ship transfers that circumvent UN sanctions. The move follows recent missile launches, including two short-range ballistic missiles fired into the sea on Thursday. The US will continue to enforce multilateral sanctions and pursue North Korea's sanctions evasion efforts worldwide. The Treasury Department designated the companies, accusing them of involvement in delivering refined petroleum to North Korea.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past a television report showing a news broadcast  of a North Korean missile test at a railway station in Seoul on Oct 6, 2022.

site_title: Forced selling makes Vietnam stocks world’s worst performer
summary: Vietnam's stocks plummeted 4.9% to their lowest in almost two years due to forced selling amid concerns over rising interest rates and a weak Vietnamese dong. The VN Index declined 18% over the last month, ranking as the world's worst-performing major gauge. Outflows from overseas investors and margin call pressure have contributed to the sell-off, with total withdrawals so far this year reaching US$95 million. Retail investors are panicking, selling off stocks without regard for the companies they are selling.

site_title: Four Malaysian telco firms agree to take stakes in govt 5G agency
summary: Four Malaysian telco firms, Maxis, U Mobile, Celcom, and DiGi, agree to take stakes in government-owned 5G agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB), resolving a months-long impasse over pricing and rollout plans. The operators are expected to make 5G services available to end users from this month onwards. The agreement follows a failed attempt by two major operators to drop out of negotiations in August, which disrupted the government's plans. The deal aims to move forward with the 5G rollout, despite ongoing talks with carriers on agreements to use DNB's network.

images.alt_text: UOBKH’s top pick is Time Dotcom for its “good growth prospects”.

site_title: LG Energy profit, sales easily beat forecasts on EV demand
summary: LG Energy Solution reported a strong quarter with operating profit of 522 billion won (S$558.7 million) and sales of 7.7 trillion won, beating forecasts. Despite industry challenges and a weak Korean won, the company's demand for electric vehicles and weak currency offset high commodity prices. Analysts expect LG Energy's outlook to remain positive, citing accelerated production at Tesla's Shanghai plant and pilot production of batteries with General Motors.

images.alt_text: The agreements were part of an effort to expand mid- to long-term supply contracts with companies that mine and process key battery materials in North America.
LG Energy Solution batteries will power Mahindra's SUVs, likely scheduled for delivery between the fourth quarter and January.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccination for children aged six months to four years from Oct 25
summary: Singapore will allow children aged six months to four years to receive the Moderna Spikevax Covid-19 vaccine starting October 25. The recommended dosage is two 25-microgram doses spaced eight weeks apart. Children aged five to 11 will also be eligible for a Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty booster dose from October 25. The move aims to provide a minimum level of protection against Covid-19, with the risk of severe disease being low but higher for hospitalization in young children.

images.alt_text: The Health Sciences Authority has authorised the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine for children, including those as young as 6 months old.

site_title: Good corporate governance beneficial to investment community, bottom lines: Sias
summary: Sias, a Singapore-based investors association, found that companies with good corporate governance practices tend to outperform the market and are more defensive. A study by Sias tracked the performance of companies that won the Singapore Corporate Governance award from 2008 to 2022 and found a cumulative total return of 110% compared to the Straits Times Index's 59%. The study also showed that the portfolio had a higher Sharpe ratio and beta, indicating better risk-adjusted returns. Sias aims to construct a model portfolio of award-winning companies to help investors make informed decisions.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim, correspondent at The Business Times, was presented one of three awards for Investor Education Journalist of the Year for his work on special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs).
SGX RegCo's stiffening regulatory attitude is unlikely to be popular among corporate boards
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan speaking in Parliament on 4 April 2022.
The presence of independent directors alone does not address the sometimes divergent interests of controlling shareholders and minority investors

site_title: Bank of America to pay Ambac US$1.84b to settle crisis-era mortgage case
summary: Bank of America has agreed to pay bond insurer Ambac US$1.84 billion to settle a crisis-era mortgage case stemming from its ill-fated purchase of Countrywide in 2008. The settlement concludes the lender's major lawsuits and results in a US$354 million expense for Bank of America, which will record a US$390 million gain in its third and fourth quarter results. Ambac had initially sought US$3 billion in damages.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Bank of America sign stands on the side of a building in New York U.S., July 16, 2018. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo/File Photo
BofA’s report also found strong payroll spending per small-business client, the result of both higher wages and increased hiring.

site_title: World food prices fall for sixth straight month: UN
summary: World food prices have fallen for a sixth consecutive month, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization. The price index averaged 136.3 points in September, a 1.1% drop from August. The decline was driven by a sharp fall in vegetable oil prices, offsetting moderate decreases in sugar, meat, and dairy products. However, wheat prices rose due to uncertainty over a UN-brokered grain deal. The FAO lowered its world cereal production forecast for this year, citing dry conditions in Argentina and the US. 45 countries are in need of external food assistance.

images.alt_text: World Bank president David Malpass called for major policy changes to boost growth and help jumpstart efforts to eradicate poverty.

site_title: Retail’s updated industry transformation map focuses on Singapore brands, innovation, talent
summary: Singapore's updated Retail Industry Transformation Map 2025 aims to help local brands go abroad, encourage experiential concepts, and position the country as a lifestyle hub for global brands. The map has four key strategies: supporting innovation and experiential retail, strengthening Singapore's position as a lifestyle hub, and upskilling local talent in emerging retail roles. The move is driven by the post-Covid-19 quest for unique consumer experiences and a shift towards digital-first business models and omni-channel retail.

images.alt_text: Almost all retail sales categories saw growth in August, with the exception of supermarkets and hypermarkets; motor vehicles; and mini-marts and convenience stores.
Establishing a flagship store is a natural step forward for Castlery, given its increased recognition among Singapore consumers, said co-founder Declan Ee.

site_title: Malaysia unveils tighter 2023 Budget amid worries of slower growth
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz has unveiled the country's 2023 budget, allocating RM372.3 billion in federal spending. The budget aims to balance fiscal discipline and support economic growth, with a forecast of 4-5% moderate growth in 2023 due to geopolitical uncertainties. Key measures include an income tax cut for low- to middle-income earners, cash aid for low-income households, and incentives for foreign investors and small businesses. The government also allocates funds for infrastructure development, poverty eradication, and environmental initiatives, aiming to achieve net zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: An UMNO statement said that Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob intends to present to the King a proposed date to dissolve Parliament, sparking speculation of a general election later this year.
An election is not due until September 2023, but Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob is under pressure from some factions of his ruling coalition to hold the vote earlier.

site_title: Part of Malaysia's LNG exports hit by Petronas pipeline leak
summary: Malaysia's LNG exports, primarily from the Sabah-Sarawak Gas Pipeline, have been disrupted due to a pipeline leak. Petronas, the majority owner of Malaysia LNG, declared force majeure on LNG supplies to its customers, affecting about 2-3 cargoes per month, or 3% of Japanese LNG imports. The disruption occurs ahead of the Northern Hemisphere's winter season, a peak demand period, and may impact energy supply disruptions from Russia this year. Japan's Toho Gas and Tokyo Gas have been informed of the supply disruption and are working to ensure stable supply.

images.alt_text: LNG consumers elsewhere in Asia are also suffering from tight supply and soaring spot LNG prices, bolstered by a global battle for the fuel.

site_title: Singapore stocks retreat as investors await US non-farm payroll numbers; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks retreated 0.2% on Friday, October 7, amid a dismal Wall Street showing and anticipation of US non-farm payroll data. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 5.75 points to 3,145.81. Shares of Nio slid 9.6% to US$14.47, while ComfortDelGro closed 0.8% lower at S$1.28. Sembcorp Marine rose 1.7% to S$0.117, driven by institutional inflows.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt’s DAX index has dipped 0.4 per cent to 12,419.72 points at the open on Friday (Oct 7).
As at 9.01 am, the Straits Times Index gained 3.19 or 0.1 per cent to 3,154.75 after 32.25 million securities worth S$48 million changed hands.
The total orders secured by Yangzijiang Shipbuilding year to date is at 40 vessels with a total value of US$3.6 billion, exceeding its FY2022 target of US$2 billion.

site_title: If the Fed refuses to pivot, economic and financial stability outlooks soon will
summary: The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are raising concerns that it may be over-tightening, potentially leading to a deep recession or market breakdown. Economists warn that the Fed's single-minded focus on fighting inflation, akin to Paul Volcker's approach in the 1970s, may be too aggressive. Despite signs of moderating price increases, the Fed is unlikely to pivot, which could lead to financial instability and further economic downturn. Analysts predict more financial stress events, and some strategists advise preparing for a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Potential flash points may not flare up immediately, given how much money is still swirling around as a result of past loosening. But if central banks keep hiking rates, funding will shift too.
Prices in the US have surged over the past year, partly due to global supply chain problems.
As benchmark Treasury yields eased this week, the average for a 30-year, fixed home loan has dropped to 6.66 per cent

site_title: Taiwan September exports drop for first time in two years, outlook poor
summary: Taiwan's exports dropped 5.3% in September to US$37.53 billion, marking the first decline in over two years, due to weak demand from China and stagnant consumer spending. Despite a resilient chip demand, the contraction was worse than forecast, with the government predicting more economic turbulence ahead.

images.alt_text: The island’s export orders, a bellwether of global technology demand, unexpectedly fell in July.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, October 7, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.43 points to 1,406.00. A total of 1.910 billion lots worth RM1.434 billion changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 485 to 308.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate dropped to 1.9% in August, with resident unemployment at 2.7% and citizen unemployment at 2.8%. The country's retail sector is expected to benefit from an updated industry transformation map focusing on local brands, innovation, and talent. Industrial prices and rentals are predicted to stabilize and grow 3-5% in 2022. Meanwhile, a tech startup, klikit, raised US$2m in pre-seed funding to improve restaurant efficiency, and billionaire Mukesh Ambani plans to open a family office in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Million-dollar transactions were recorded in areas such as Bishan, Kallang/Whampoa, Bukit Merah, Ang Mo Kio and Clementi.

site_title: Swedish housing market slump deepens on rate, energy worries
summary: Sweden's housing market has deepened its slump, with apartment prices declining 6% from last year and house prices easing 3%, the fastest annual decline since August 2018. The market's cooling is attributed to interest rate hikes and concerns over energy costs, which may worsen in the winter. The Riksbank expects borrowing costs to rise to 2.5% in a year, and prices are projected to weaken further, with a potential 15-20% drop from all-time highs.

images.alt_text: August is traditionally a strong month for the Swedish housing market, and on seasonally adjusted terms, prices overall fell by 1.2 per cent.
With Swedish housing prices projected to fall as much as 20 per cent in one of the world’s bubbliest property markets, SSB's business model faces renewed pressure.

site_title: Gojek alumnus raises US$2m in pre-seed funding for tech startup
summary: Klikit, a food delivery software startup co-founded by ex-Gojek vice president Christopher Withers, has raised US$2 million in pre-seed funding led by Global Founders Capital and Wavemaker Partners. Founded in 2021, klikit aims to help restaurants operate efficiently with its software-as-a-service platform. The startup has serviced over US$2.8 million in food delivery orders across 150 brands in several countries, and has partnered with Max's Group and other brands. Klikit's platform aggregates and analyzes orders, providing seamless updates and data analytics to restaurants.

images.alt_text: FoodPanda rider on his bicycle at Northpoint mall, Yishun on Feb 24, 2022.
Sea’s e-commerce arm Shopee is axing more employees as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable.

site_title: The billionaire trying to turn Kazakhstan into a tennis nation
summary: Billionaire Bulat Utemuratov is investing heavily in Kazakhstan's tennis infrastructure, turning the Central Asian republic into an emerging tennis force. He has built 38 tennis centers, subsidized coaching for young players, and attracted top players like Elena Rybakina and Alexander Bublik. Utemuratov's strategy, which includes offering financial support to Russian players, has helped Kazakhstan go from 1,800 registered players in 2007 to 33,000 today. His efforts have earned him a vice-president position at the International Tennis Federation, and he is set to host a Masters 500 tournament this week, marking a significant step for Kazakhstan's tennis scene.

images.alt_text: Former England and Tottenham Hotspur striker Teddy Sheringham in action at the AIA Better Lives Fund charity golf event at Tanah Merah Country Club. The tournament and a charity dinner raised more than S$370,000 for a good cause.
Switzerland's Roger Federer leaves the sport with 20 Grand Slams, including eight Wimbledons, 103 titles and more than US$130 million in prize money alone.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with a big loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with a 1.51% loss, or 272.10 points, to 17,740.05 on Friday, October 7, 2022, due to profit-taking and anticipation of US jobs data. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Steady demand to support industrial prices and rentals in 2022, despite Q3 bumps: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank reports steady demand for industrial properties in 2022, driven by sustainable business models and international investments. Despite a 12.2% drop in industrial sales to S$773.1 million in Q3 2022 and a 28% decline in industrial tenancies, prices and rentals are expected to stabilize this year. The slowdown in manufacturing growth is attributed to global geopolitical and economic challenges, but Knight Frank believes steady demand will continue to support the sector.

images.alt_text: Logistics investments are a significant proportion of APAC industrial investment sales, taking up about a third of total industrial investment volume over the last five years.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan.
Industrial space prices rose 2.1 per cent on the quarter and 5.6 per cent on the year in Q1, while rents added 1 per cent quarter on quarter and 2.4 per cent year on year.

site_title: Google to open first Japan data centre to accelerate Asia push
summary: Google plans to open its first data centre in Japan, based in Inzai City, Chiba, in 2023, as part of a $730 million investment in local infrastructure. The facility will accelerate Google's tools and services, support economic activity and jobs, and connect Japan to the global economy. This is part of Google's broader push into the Asian market, with the third data centre in Asia after Taiwan and Singapore. The move aims to deepen Google's partnership with Japan, which has a history of advanced technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: 11 TEL3 stations from Stevens to Gardens by the Bay to open on Nov 13, free rides on Nov 11
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that 11 TEL3 stations from Stevens to Gardens by the Bay will open on November 13, increasing the resilience of Singapore's MRT lines and reducing the load on the North-South Line. To celebrate, passengers can ride for free on November 11. The third stage of the Thomson-East Coast MRT Line spans 13.2 km and will eventually serve 500,000 daily passengers, with all 32 stations expected to open by 2025, helping to reduce journey times by 40% for over 180,000 households.

images.alt_text: Announcing the alignment for phase 2 on Tuesday (Sep 25), Transport Minister S Iswaran said it will provide greater public transport access to areas in the west such as Jurong Lake District and West Coast, and improve connectivity between the eastern, western and north-eastern parts of Singapore.

site_title: Samsung's earnings slump on rapid drop-off in chip demand
summary: Samsung's quarterly operating earnings dropped 32% due to a decline in demand for electronic devices and memory chips. The company's estimated profit fell to 10.8 trillion won (S$10.9 billion) in July-September, the first year-on-year decline in nearly three years. Analysts expect memory chip prices to continue to plummet, causing a further dip in Samsung's profits, with demand not expected to recover until early next year.

images.alt_text: South Korean rival SK Hynix has purchased Intel’s Nand flash memory chip manufacturing business in Dalian and produces Dram chips at another China-based facility.

site_title: Credit Suisse to buy back 3b Swiss francs of debt securities
summary: Credit Suisse has made an offer to repurchase up to 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.3 billion) of senior debt securities, with two separate offers for euro and US dollar-denominated securities. The lender aims to take advantage of market conditions to repurchase debt at attractive prices, reducing its interest expense. The offers will expire on November 3 and November 10, subject to terms and conditions.

site_title: Japanese aluminium buyers negotiate 33% drop in Q4 premiums
summary: Japanese aluminium buyers have agreed to a 33% drop in Q4 premiums to US$99 a tonne, marking the fourth consecutive quarterly decrease. The lower premium reflects weak demand and ample inventories, amid delays in automobile manufacturing recovery due to a global semiconductor shortage. This decrease is below producers' initial offers of US$115-US$133 and the benchmark LME cash price for the first time since 2020.

images.alt_text: Copper prices inched higher on Friday(Aug 19) but were set to end the week slightly lower as traders balanced hopes for solid demand in China with pessimism about the global economy.

site_title: Future of world order will not be defined by just the US and China alone: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong said the future of the global order will not be defined solely by the US and China, but also by other economies, such as India and those in South-east Asia. India is expected to become the third-largest economy by 2030, while South-east Asia's combined GDP is expected to double or quadruple over the next two decades. Wong warned that strained US-China relations could lead to further bifurcation of technology, supply chain splitting, and unintended consequences. He emphasized the need for multilateralism and an open, inclusive rules-based order to address these challenges.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that while Singapore may not be able to do much to influence the course of US-China relations, the city state will do all that it can to keep the region open and inclusive.
FILE PHOTO: A worker adjusts an ASEAN flag at a meeting hall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Simon says: Here’s why I bought a 99-year terrace house
summary: A Singapore couple, Simon Ang and his wife Josephine, purchased a 99-year terrace house in 2017 for S$1.82 million, opting for the lease instead of a freehold property due to affordability concerns. They renovated the 2,174 sq ft property to accommodate their family of seven, boosting its value. With a balance lease of 69.5 years, the couple is open to selling but acknowledges the challenges in securing a good price due to the shorter lease. They plan to rent out the property as a co-living offering in the future, generating passive income.

images.alt_text:
krlanded - Villa Verde

COPYRIGHT: CHEONG CHOON GHEE, LIST SIR
Condition: For editorial use only.

One of the 3 bungalow properties along Nassim Road.




Copyright: Realstar Premier

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.

site_title: Cathay Pacific recruits staff, plans jet orders as Hong Kong Airport expands
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is recruiting staff and planning to expand its fleet, including passenger aircraft and freighters, as the Hong Kong Airport's third runway opens in 2025. The airline is in talks with Boeing and Airbus to add new planes, aiming for consistency and synergy with its existing fleet. Cathay expects to return to normal levels of passenger capacity by the end of 2024 or early 2025, with freight capacity reaching two-thirds of 2019 tonnage this year. The airline is hiring 8,000 staff, including 4,000 pilots and flight attendants, to support its recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: A staff member speaks with applicants during a Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. flight attendant recruitment event in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, Oct. 7, 2022. Just over 1,000 people have signed up for Cathay's flight attendant recruiting drive, around half of the 2,000 targeted by the end of 2023, underscoring the labor challenges the airline faces as it seeks to to fully restore flights in and out of the Asian financial hub. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Along with its subsidiaries, the company had 20,800 employees globally by Jun 30, after cutting thousands of roles during the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open, before US jobs data
summary: European stocks fell at the open on Friday, October 7, with Frankfurt's DAX index dropping 0.4% to 12,419.72 points, and London's FTSE 100 index losing 0.1% to 6,989.65 points. The decline came ahead of US jobs data, which is expected to provide insight into the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike pace. Investors are adopting a cautious approach, with markets pricing in a less aggressive pace of rate tightening, easing concerns of a global recession.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index reversed early session gains and was down 0.6 per cent, extending losses to a second straight session.

site_title: ECB steps up pressure on banks to exercise bonus caution
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is urging banks to exercise caution in variable pay and dividends due to concerns about a wave of defaults resulting from the energy crunch. The ECB has warned individual lenders to keep bonuses in check, citing a sharper slowdown in Europe next year as a likely scenario. Despite this, several euro area banks, including UniCredit, Commerzbank, and Deutsche Bank, have given bullish guidance, downplaying the risks. The ECB believes lenders may be underestimating the risks, and has previously shown it is ready to intervene if it believes a bank's bonus plans are excessive.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, April 26, 2018. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach//File Photo

Eurozone inflation was still driven mainly by volatile energy and food prices but continued to broaden out, with virtually all categories, from services to industrial goods, now showing painfully high readings.

Ending an 8-year experiment with negative interest rates, the ECB also increased its main refinancing rate to 0.50 per cent and promised further rate hikes possibly as soon as its next meeting on Sep 8.

site_title: Crypto fugitive Kwon gets boost as Terra aide avoids detention
summary: Crypto fugitive Do Kwon received a boost after a South Korean court allowed an executive linked to his collapsed Terraform Labs ecosystem to avoid detention. The court indicated room for dispute over allegations the individual breached the nation's capital-markets law, charges Kwon and four others also face. The decision may be seen as a setback for prosecutors, but they may still charge Kwon with other offenses. The development comes as Kwon faces an Interpol red notice and is required to hand back his South Korean passport or risk it being revoked.

images.alt_text: Kwon was behind the TerraUSD stablecoin, which was meant to have a constant US$1 value in a complex arrangement with sister token Luna.

site_title: India’s market regulator orders ratings agency to shut down
summary: India's market regulator, SEBI, has ordered Brickwork Ratings, a credit assessor, to shut down within six months due to lapses in its rating process. The regulator found failures in disclosures, conflict of interest, and record-keeping. Brickwork was one of seven SEBI-registered credit rating agencies in India, and its clients will need to undergo a fresh process for credit ratings. The agency's license has been cancelled, and it is barred from taking on new mandates, with existing clients informed of the closure.

images.alt_text: State Bank of India (SBI) expanded its domestic loans by 14.93 per cent year-on-year in the last quarter, led by strong growth in retail loans.

site_title: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui slapped with administrative order over rules breach
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG) has been ordered by the Financial Services Agency to improve compliance after its banking and securities arms were found to have shared confidential client information without consent. The violations included tender offers and mergers, potentially hindering the banking industry's push for deregulation of rules restricting client information sharing. SMFG's securities and banking arms were found to have breached intra-group information firewall rules, which are modelled on the US Glass Steagall Act. The group must devise measures to improve compliance, which could impact its lobbying efforts for further deregulation.

images.alt_text: A woman pushes a door of  Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation's branch in Tokyo April 9, 2009. Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (SMFG), Japan's third-largest bank, said it faced a net loss of $3.9 billion in the financial year just ended and would raise up to $8 billion through a share sale.   REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon (JAPAN BUSINESS)

site_title: Local tourism spending rises during China’s Golden Week despite lockdowns
summary: China's local tourism spending rose 30% during the Golden Week holiday, despite ongoing lockdowns and travel restrictions, according to data from Ctrip. Per capita spending increased, with 65% of tourism coming from short-distance, local trips. Analysts attribute the surge to new packages catering to those who want to explore without traveling far. This marks a significant rebound from last year's 5% decline in tourism revenues during the same period.

images.alt_text: The move to cement testing in the city underscores the balance authorities are attempting to strike between re-opening with a world that’s living with the virus.

Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that while Singapore may not be able to do much to influence the course of US-China relations, the city state will do all that it can to keep the region open and inclusive.
The problems at CIFI highlight the challenges for Chinese authorities as they seek to prevent a slump in the property industry from fuelling broader financial market contagion.

site_title: Four flashpoints that could threaten financial stability
summary: Financial instability risks are emerging, with four key flashpoints: open-ended investment funds, government bonds, housing markets, and private capital. Liquidity mismatches in funds and evaporating liquidity in bonds could contribute to volatility, while a surge in housing prices may lead to a decline in house prices. Private capital, particularly in venture capital and private equity, is also at risk due to the lack of transparency in asset values. Central banks' rate hikes may exacerbate these issues, prompting investors to brace for more surprises.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England is studying patterns of demand, and will continue to set a maximum price it is willing to pay to ensure the “backstop objective of the tool is delivered”, it has said in a market notice.
The United Kingdom's pensions industry has had a mentality that the risks lay largely in the direction of lower bond yields, but higher yields can bring their own problems.

site_title: Bank of Korea to go for second big hike on Wednesday: poll
summary: The Bank of Korea is expected to hike interest rates by another half-point next week, surpassing earlier forecasts, to support the weakening Korean won and combat inflation. The move comes as the US Federal Reserve signals a more aggressive stance on interest rates. Economists predict the base rate will reach 3.25% by year-end and peak at 3.50% in the first quarter of 2023, with inflation expected to average 5.2% this year and 3.0% next year. The decision aims to fend off foreign exchange pass-through onto inflation and maintain control over the economy.

images.alt_text: Inflation has been fuelled this year by a jump in consumer demand for dining and travel as the grip of the pandemic eased on the economy.
Rising commodity prices, supply-chain snags and slowing demand for semiconductors have been among the factors weighing on exports.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest weekly gain in nearly two years
summary: South Korean shares closed with a 0.22% drop on Friday, ending a three-session gain streak, but still posting the largest weekly gain in nearly two years. The Kospi rose 3.59% for the week, with foreign investors buying shares worth 100.5 billion won. The won weakened, while bond yields rose, with the benchmark 10-year yield increasing 11.2 basis points to 4.214%. The government plans to spur capital inflows to address a widening current account deficit and potential rate hikes by the Bank of Korea.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 22.64 points or 1.02 per cent at 2,237.86, hitting its highest since Sep 23.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer more losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.89% at the open, extending losses from the previous day, amid anticipation of US jobs data. The Hang Seng Index fell to 17,851.62, its lowest point in several days. The decline follows recent gains and coincides with the closure of mainland Chinese markets for a national holiday.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as miners, banks decline
summary: The Australian S&P/ASX 200 closed 0.8% lower at 6,762.8 on Friday, driven by losses in miners and banks, amid fears of a looming recession. Investors remain cautious, awaiting US non-farm payrolls numbers for signs of the Fed's policy tightening path. Despite this, the sub-index of financials gained 5.2% for the week, its best in over six months. Energy stocks rose 1% for the week, their best since November 2020.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.71 per cent to 6,769.1 by 0013 GMT on Friday, but was on track to post its biggest weekly gain in nearly two years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.71% to 27,116.11, as investors reacted to sagging US stock futures and anticipation of a US employment data release. The broader Topix index also declined 0.82%. The decline follows a record-breaking close on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore’s August jobless rates fall to 6-year low, but MOM warns of weaknesses ahead
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate fell to a 6-year low of 1.9% in August, with resident and citizen unemployment rates at 2.7% and 2.8% respectively. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) warned of potential economic slowdown risks due to manufacturing contraction, soaring inflation, and interest rate hikes. This marks the lowest unemployment rate since March 2016, but MOM cautioned that labor market activity could be dampened despite the current low rates.

images.alt_text: The overall unemployment rate held steady at 2.1 percent, unchanged from the previous month.

site_title: Tokyo exchange to name hundreds of firms it will remove from its Topix index
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) plans to remove hundreds of companies from its Topix index, a move aimed at attracting foreign investors. Over 2,000 firms, including those not meeting the prime market's governance standards, will be gradually removed due to low market capitalization (less than 10 billion yen). The elimination process will be neutral, with companies that remain experiencing increased buying pressure. The TSE will review the affected companies next October, with all eliminated companies removed by January 2025.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Sparks of optimism fizzle (Ep 15)
summary: Market optimism has fizzled out due to recent market movements, according to a podcast by The Business Times. The episode, titled "BT Market Focus: Sparks of optimism fizzle," discusses how market drivers and movements have led to a decline in investor confidence. Key takeaways include insights from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk, as well as analysis on what investors should consider in the current market climate.

images.alt_text: What's causing intensifying fears and volatility?
Why are recession fears dominating markets?
How are markets reacting to looming interest rate hikes?

site_title: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani to open family office in Singapore
summary: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani is setting up a family office in Singapore, following a trend of ultra-rich individuals choosing the city-state for their private wealth management. The Reliance Industries chairman has chosen a manager to hire staff and has selected real estate as one of the areas to focus on. The move is part of Ambani's efforts to diversify his wealth management services and provide more personalized support to his family.

images.alt_text: JioBook will run on the JioOS operating system, the sources said, adding that some of Microsoft’s apps will also be available.

site_title: Thomson Medical hires Gleneagles’ Melvin Heng as group CEO
summary: Thomson Medical Group has appointed Melvin Heng, current CEO of Gleneagles Hospital, as its new executive director and group CEO, effective December 1. Heng succeeds Wong Chiang Yin, who resigned in late August to pursue personal interests after more than two years in the role. Heng will serve until October 31 before joining Thomson Medical, where he will oversee the healthcare provider until at least December 1.

images.alt_text: Thomson Medical said net profit for the 6 months ended Jun 30 stood at S$41.3 million, compared with a net profit of S$6.1 million posted the same period a year ago.
The group also announced the resignation of chief executive Wong Chiang Yin, who is leaving to pursue personal interests.
Dr Kelvin Loh, Managing Director and CEO of IHH Healthcare, in his office on May 11, 2021.

site_title: The triumph of the Ukrainian idea
summary: The war in Ukraine is not only a military event, but also an intellectual one, with the Ukrainians fighting for a superior idea - a combination of liberalism and nationalism. Liberalism promotes democracy, individual dignity, and a rule-based international order, while nationalism fights for a country's culture, land, and people. This kind of nationalism is forward-looking, inclusive, and builds a society around the rule of law, not personal power. It's a counter to authoritarianism and can mobilize a society to achieve fantastic things, as seen in Ukraine's tenacity.

images.alt_text: Sources say the Biden administration is willing to support Ukraine with US$1.5 billion a month in aid throughout the war.

People approach screens located near the Kremlin and Red Square before the live broadcast of a ceremony to declare the annexation of the Russian-controlled territories of four Ukraine's Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions.

site_title: A summary of Singapore’s property cooling measures: 1996 to present day
summary: The Singapore government introduced property cooling measures in 1996 to maintain price stability. Key measures include increasing additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates, particularly for foreign buyers and entities, and implementing cooling measures when housing prices deviate from economic fundamentals. Notable recent measures include doubling ABSD rates for foreign buyers in 2023 and introducing a prime project benchmark of S$3,000 psf in 2025. These measures aim to curb excessive speculation and maintain a balanced housing market.

images.alt_text: HDB flats in the Queenstown area and Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) as viewed from Block 90 Tanglin Halt on May 27, 2021.
pixgenerics/ST20220629_202283358097/Ng Sor Luan/Generic photos of HDB flats for story on home loans rates increasing.
Mortgage brokers polled by The Business Times also said the new rules are unlikely to have a direct impact on mortgage rates.
A 7% jump in suburban condo prices leads a 3.4% qoq rise in Singapore’s Q3 private home prices: URA

PropNex anticipates that the median selling price of overall new OCR projects may hover around the S$2,000 psf range in the near-term with Sky Eden@Bedok transacting 118 units at an average price of S$2,100 psf, and Lentor Modern selling 84 per cent of its units also at an average price of about S$2,100 psf.
According to Huttons, rents of private homes are estimated to increase up to 10 per cent in H2 2022.

The robust take-up of new project launches, such as Piccadilly Grand and Liv@MB in the RCR, have re-ignited market engines and contributed to an acceleration of home prices in Q2 2022. In the OCR, the launches of AMO Residence (pictured) in July and, more recently, Sky Eden@Bedok, were also met with positive reception.
The Pinnacle@Duxton on 7 April 2021.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida warns against sharp, one-sided yen falls
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida warned against sharp, one-sided yen declines, citing the negative effects on the economy. The yen touched 145.04 per dollar, near its 24-year low, prompting government intervention last month. Kishida said the government cannot ignore "repeated, excessive volatility" driven by speculative trading. The yen's weakness is attributed to policy divergence between the Bank of Japan and the US Federal Reserve, with investors focusing on the interest rate differences.

site_title: UK hiring plans grind to a halt with recession concerns rising
summary: The UK labour market is showing signs of cooling due to recession concerns, with hiring plans grinding to a halt. Vacancies and job placements rose at the slowest pace in over a year and a half, as workers and businesses prepare for a possible recession. Despite this, candidates remained in short supply, forcing firms to pay higher salaries to fill positions. The tight labour market is a concern for the Bank of England, which has raised interest rates to prevent a wage-price spiral.

site_title: Chipmakers see ‘breathtaking’ drop in demand as recession looms
summary: Chipmakers are experiencing a significant drop in demand due to a looming recession, with companies like Samsung Electronics and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) reporting disappointing results. Demand for consumer electronics is weaker-than-expected, leading to surging shipping and materials costs. Analysts describe the situation as "breathtaking" and "Uff-da!", with AMD shares falling and sparking losses in related companies. The decline in demand is prompting chipmakers to slash spending and output in an effort to stabilize plummeting prices.

images.alt_text: South Korean rival SK Hynix has purchased Intel’s Nand flash memory chip manufacturing business in Dalian and produces Dram chips at another China-based facility.
South Korea, home to the world’s two largest memory chipmakers, reported a decline in chip output in August for the first time in more than four years.

site_title: Gold steady ahead of US jobs data, but heads for best week since March
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,709.69 per ounce ahead of the US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate-hike path. Prices have risen 3% this week, driven by a dollar retreat and Treasury yields from multi-year peaks. Investors await the nonfarm payrolls report, forecasting 250,000 jobs added last month. New Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook supports continued interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$1,719.19 per ounce, as of 1.44 am GMT.

site_title: China builder CIFI falls deeper into distress despite state help
summary: China's 15th-largest developer, CIFI Holdings Group, has faced significant financial distress despite receiving state guarantees on local debt sales. Its dollar bonds plummeted to a record low of 27 US cents, and shares dropped 15% to tie a record low. The developer is in talks to extend interest payments on an offshore loan, and Moody's Investors Service cut its ratings citing elevated refinancing risks. The crisis highlights the challenges for Chinese authorities in preventing a slump in the property industry from fuelling broader financial market contagion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men work at a construction site of apartment buildings in Beijing, China, July 15, 2022. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
In Shanghai, bonds issued by property firms including CIFI Holdings, Sunac Real Estate and Gemdale were among the biggest losers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.58 points or 0.32% to 1,415.85. Volume was 217.11 million lots worth RM89.99 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 185 to 114.

site_title: US adds China’s BGI Genomics and drone maker DJI to investment ban
summary: The US Defence Department has added 13 Chinese companies, including DJI Technology and BGI Genomics, to a blacklist due to alleged ties to the Chinese military-industrial complex. The list bars Americans from investing in these companies, which include surveillance equipment maker Zhejiang Dahua Technology and rail transit equipment manufacturer CRRC. The move is part of the US government's efforts to counter China's Military-Civil Fusion strategy, which aims to acquire advanced technologies and expertise. The blacklist follows an initial list of 50 Chinese companies added last year, including telecoms equipment maker Huawei.

images.alt_text: South Korean rival SK Hynix has purchased Intel’s Nand flash memory chip manufacturing business in Dalian and produces Dram chips at another China-based facility.

site_title: Malaysia’s palm planters eye robots, drones to combat labour crunch
summary: Malaysian palm oil producers are racing to mechanize due to a third consecutive annual fall in output and estimated losses of RM20 billion (S$6.2 billion) due to a labor crunch. Plantation firms are investing in wearable exoskeletons and drones to reduce labor needs, with companies like Sime Darby and IOI doubling their automation budgets. Experts say automation will not replace manual labor immediately, but new tools can ease Malaysia's woes, with a long-term goal of reducing the workforce to one worker for every 50 hectares.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Indonesian migrant worker, Ari Rohman, pushes a cart as he collects bunches of palm oil fresh fruit during harvest at a plantation in Banting, Selangor, Malaysia, June 10, 2022. Picture taken June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Samsung, SK Hynix to be spared brunt of China chip crackdown by US
summary: The US government plans to spare South Korean companies SK Hynix and Samsung from the impact of new restrictions on memory chipmakers in China, aiming to thwart Beijing's technological ambitions and block its military advances. The new curbs target China-based producers of advanced Dram and Nand chips, but will allow US suppliers to sell equipment to foreign companies making those chips in China on a case-by-case basis. The move is seen as a more expansive view of American national security, targeting Chinese producers like YMTC and CXMT without specialized military applications.

images.alt_text: South Korea, home to the world’s two largest memory chipmakers, reported a decline in chip output in August for the first time in more than four years.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% on Friday, driven by gains in Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Asian Healthcare Specialists. The STI ended at 3,154.75, with 32.3 million securities changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 56 to 52. Global markets were mixed, with US stocks retreating due to anticipation of a jobs report impacting US monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The total orders secured by Yangzijiang Shipbuilding year to date is at 40 vessels with a total value of US$3.6 billion, exceeding its FY2022 target of US$2 billion.

site_title: South Korea posts worst deficit in goods balance as trade slows
summary: South Korea posted its worst goods deficit on record in August, with a shortfall of US$4.4 billion, due to rising commodity prices, supply-chain snags, and slowing demand for semiconductors. The overall current account deficit also worsened to US$3.1 billion, the worst in over two years, amid elevated oil prices and rising interest rates. Policymakers expect the annual balance to exceed US$30 billion, despite concerns that the deficit could trigger a significant fallout. The won has been Asia's worst performer this year.

site_title: Baghdad's historic homes crumble as real estate booms
summary: Baghdad's historic homes, including a 100-year-old mansion, are crumbling due to decades of neglect, political turmoil, and rising real estate prices. The city's roughly 2,500 remaining historic houses are falling apart, with many being torn down for development. The Burj Babel Initiative, which aims to preserve the city's cultural history, is warning of the danger of collapse at many of these buildings. Conservation efforts are needed to protect Baghdad's architectural past, but funding is scarce.

images.alt_text: Some 40 visitors, most of them Iraqis, were allowed to walk around the more than 2,000-year-old archaeological site in the golden hour of twilight.
The clay-based murals reflect the country's long history - from the Assyrian period through to the Islamic State occupation.

site_title: Singapore-China ties to open up new opportunities for businesses in both countries: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong of Singapore emphasized the potential for collaboration between Singapore and China in emerging areas of the new economy, such as the digital economy and green development. He highlighted the growth of their economic ties, with China as Singapore's largest trading partner and Singapore as China's largest foreign investor. Wong encouraged all major partners to foster economic interdependence and integration in the region, rather than choosing sides in US-China relations.

images.alt_text: A much greater focus on transition finance is needed to help ensure a green transition that is just and fair for the region, says Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (on screen) noted that the world has not reached an equilibrium in its transition from a "unipolar world" to a "multipolar world".
DPM Lawrence Wong met India's Power and New and Renewable Energy Minister R K Singh (above) on Tuesday, as well as Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will first arrive in New Delhi where he will participate in the inaugural India-Singapore Ministerial Roundtable.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop, dollar holds rally as US jobs report looms
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney in negative territory, amid growing concerns about the US jobs report and potential Federal Reserve rate hikes. The dollar held steady, while sterling remained below US$1.12 due to UK tax-cutting plans. Oil prices edged down but are expected to rise this week, with some analysts predicting a return to US$100 a barrel by year-end. Investors await the non-farm payrolls report, which is expected to show 250,000 job creations, and the consumer price index report next week.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Jakarta financial markets all rose again, but Hong Kong retreated after blasting almost 6 per cent higher on Wednesday.
A tuk-tuk driver on the streets of Bangkok, Thailand. The post-Covid recovery is well underway in Asean countries, thanks in part to relaxed pandemic measures and border curbs.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on Thursday, ahead of jobs data
summary: US stocks fell 1.0% on Thursday ahead of the release of the September jobs report, which is expected to show 250,000 new jobs added and a 3.7% unemployment rate. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1.0% and 0.7% respectively, while the Dow Jones industrial Average fell 1.2%. Investors are cautious due to expectations of potential interest rate hikes and a speech by IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warning of a painful process to address inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 67.7 points, or 0.22 per cent, to open at 30206.13 on Thursday (Oct 6).

site_title: Australia seeks to grow plants on Moon by 2025
summary: Australia plans to grow plants on the Moon by 2025 as part of a mission to pave the way for a future lunar colony. Plant biologist Brett Williams will use seeds carried by the Beresheet 2 spacecraft, which will be watered in a sealed chamber after landing and monitored for germination and growth. The goal is to choose plants that can thrive in extreme conditions, providing a sustainable food source for future lunar missions.

images.alt_text: Moon is seen in the sky during the closest visible conjunction of Jupiter and Saturn in 400 years, in Tejeda, on the island of Gran Canaria, Spain December 21, 2020. REUTERS/Borja Suarez/File Photo
The renowned observatory has been operating since 1990 about 540 kilometres above Earth, in an orbit that slowly decays over time.

site_title: Twitter rolls out edit button to paid subscribers in US
summary: Twitter has rolled out the edit button to paid subscribers in the US, following its launch in Canada, Australia, and New Zealand. Users of Twitter Blue, paying $4.99/month, can edit their tweets a few times within 30 minutes of publication. Edited tweets will have an icon and timestamp to display their edit history and previous versions. This feature has been widely requested by users to fix errors, but Twitter has also raised concerns about the potential spread of misinformation.

images.alt_text: Twitter shares, which ended the day down 3.7 per cent at US$49.39, rose 1 per cent after hours as investors appeared reassured after days of confusion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Friday over caution on US rate hikes
summary: Tokyo shares fell 1.23% on Friday due to concerns over US rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 336.46 points to 26,974.84, while the Topix index fell 1.26% to 1,898.29. The decline follows global shares due to the US rate hike campaign to combat inflation.

site_title: Japan’s Aug household spending rises annually on reopening, falls month-on-month
summary: Japan's household spending rose 5.1% in August from a year earlier, but fell 1.7% on a seasonally-adjusted, month-on-month basis. This was lower than economists' median estimate of a 6.7% gain and followed a 3.4% rise in July. Rising prices and real wages that have fallen for a fifth month are expected to cloud the outlook for further gains. The government is set to ease border control restrictions to attract foreign tourists, and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged to compile a fresh stimulus package by end-October.

images.alt_text: Japan will loosen its border policies from Tuesday (Oct 11) next week.
Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida says the government will compile another economic stimulus plan by the end of October.
Toyota recalled 2,700 bZ4X sports utility vehicles globally in June, less than two months after it was first rolled out.

site_title: Hong Kong cements Covid tests with centres just a 15-minute walk
summary: Hong Kong is expanding its Covid testing network, with 85 community testing centers to be established, covering about 70% of the population within a 15-minute walk.
