The city aims to make PCR tests available within walking distance for approximately 5 million people, with prices slashed to HK$150 (S$27) for a 24-hour result. This move reflects the city's balance between re-opening with the ongoing global pandemic.

images.alt_text: A healthcare worker directs residents at a Covid-19 testing facility in Hong Kong in February. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg
A flight attendant for Cathay Pacific Airways at Hong Kong International Airport.

site_title: Binance-backed blockchain probes US$100m hack of tokens
summary: A Binance-backed blockchain, BNB Chain, is investigating a potential hack that may have resulted in the theft of between US$100 million and US$110 million of digital tokens. The blockchain has been temporarily suspended and is working with security services to freeze transfers of stolen funds. At least US$7 million of stolen funds have already been frozen. The affected token, BNB, fell 3.3% in value on Friday and is trading around US$287. A Binance backup fund will cover the losses.

site_title: Australia’s central bank warns of rising financial stability risks, households under pressure
summary: Australia's central bank warns of rising financial stability risks due to higher interest rates and inflation. The Reserve Bank of Australia notes that some households are already feeling the strain from six consecutive rate hikes since May and that housing prices are declining. Financial stability risks are heightened by a global economic uncertainty, including high inflation, rising interest rates, and high energy prices. The bank expects housing loan arrears rates to increase and total scheduled payments to rise to 9% of household disposable income by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: The nation is also a major exporter of commodities such as wheat that have also surged. Rural goods climbed 6.8 per cent in August from a month earlier.
September central bank decisions did little to soothe these fears with the Federal Reserve hiking interest rates by 75 basis points for a third straight time.

site_title: Musk says Pepsi to receive Tesla’s first Semi trucks in December
summary: Elon Musk announced that PepsiCo will receive Tesla's first semi-electric truck deliveries on December 1. The production of the semi-truck, unveiled in 2017, has been delayed multiple times due to part shortages. The truck has a range of 805 km and is expected to cost $180,000, with a potential tax break of up to $40,000. PepsiCo reserved 100 semi-trucks in 2017 to reduce fuel costs and emissions, with plans to use them to ship snack foods and beverages between manufacturing and distribution centers.

images.alt_text: Pepsi is getting convertible preferred stock equating to 8.5 per cent ownership in Celsius, the companies said on Monday (Aug 1) in a statement.

site_title: Nobel winner Ernaux: godmother of French grit lit
summary: Annie Ernaux, a French novelist and Nobel laureate, has been hailed as the "godmother of French grit lit" for her unflinching exploration of class and gender in her works. Born in a working-class neighborhood, Ernaux's writing has offered a literary lifeline to young writers from humble backgrounds. Her autobiographical works, such as "The Years" and "Happening," have tackled painful and personal topics, including abortion and the #MeToo movement. Ernaux's commitment to her working-class roots has earned her recognition as a feminist icon, and her influence can be seen in writers like Virginie Despentes and Edouard Louis.

images.alt_text: Last year, the Academy bestowed the prestigious prize on Tanzanian author Abdulrazak Gurnah (left). His work had not been widely translated and was not known to the broad public – or even some publishers.

In explaining its choice, the Swedish Academy said French author Annie Ernaux “consistently and from different angles, examines a life marked by strong disparities regarding gender, language and class”.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall but set for best week in nearly 2 years
summary: Australian shares fell 0.71% to 6,769.1 on Friday, but are on track for their biggest weekly gain in nearly two years. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed flat on Thursday. Global shares have been on edge due to the US Federal Reserve's continued interest rate hikes to combat inflation, with investors awaiting a potential pivot from rate hikes. Despite the decline, the week is shaping up to be a strong one for Australian stocks.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 closed little changed at 6,817.5, also weighed down by recession fears.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as investors fret about inflation, aggressive interest rates
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, extending losses to a second straight session, as minutes from the European Central Bank's meeting highlighted concerns about inflation and aggressive policy moves. Retail sales data also pointed to a weakness in consumer demand, fueling recession fears. The Stoxx 600 index reversed early gains, with miners and utilities leading the decline.

images.alt_text: A sign outside the London Stock Exchange in London, UK, on Friday, Sept. 23, 2022. The UK Government wants to supercharge the City of London's growth, arguing it will boost the whole country's post-Brexit prospects. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Asian Healthcare Specialists
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured new orders for 22 vessels, raising its total order book value to a record high of US$10.27 billion. This brings total orders secured year to date to 40 vessels, valued at US$3.6 billion. Asian Healthcare Specialists received a take-private offer from Doctor Anywhere at S$0.188 a share, valuing the company at S$109 million.

site_title: ‘Nopec’ bill is off table as response to Opec+ oil production cut - for now
summary: The Nopec bill, which would allow the US to sue Opec nations for manipulating energy markets, is being considered as a response to Opec's production cut. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer expressed outrage over the move benefiting Russian President Vladimir Putin, while the White House has left the possibility of backing the bill open. Despite initial concerns about its "potential implications and unintended consequences," the bill has gained bipartisan support in Congress, with a move to revive it made by Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Dick Durbin and Republican Senator Chuck Grassley.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$94.42 a barrel, up US$1.05, or 1.1 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: AMD sinks after early peek at revenue shows steep shortfall
summary: AMD's preliminary third-quarter sales fell short of projections, with revenue of $5.6 billion, missing the average analyst estimate of $6.7 billion. The company attributed the shortfall to weaker PC demand and a build-up of inventory. AMD blamed the PC market for hurting sales, citing weaker demand and a significant inventory correction. The stock fell 4% in extended trading, adding to its 53% decline this year. The company plans to report full earnings on November 1.

images.alt_text: Meta’s new open-source AI platform is based on an open-source machine learning framework called PyTorch.

site_title: Samsung profit sinks 32% as memory chip downturn worsens
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its first profit drop since 2019, with operating profit falling 32% to 10.8 trillion won (S$11 billion) for the three months ended September. The company attributed the decline to a global PC and memory chip downturn, with inventories building up and orders being cut by data centers and consumer tech clients. Analysts expect the memory market to remain sluggish throughout next year, with Samsung's chip business head Kyung Kyehyun warning of no momentum for recovery.

images.alt_text: Samsung aims to triple its capacity of leading-edge manufacturing by 2027.
With India’s festive season underway, Samsung on Monday (Sep 26) launched a new credit card with India’s Axis Bank to offer 10 per cent cashback all year round to customers buying Samsung products.

site_title: Bringing down inflation will take time, more rate hikes: Federal Reserve officials
summary: US Federal Reserve officials say bringing down inflation will take time, with further interest rate hikes likely this year. The US economy is experiencing its fastest inflation in 40 years, driven by global supply chain problems, a shortage of workers, and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook and Board Member Christopher Waller warned that inflation remains stubbornly high and will require ongoing rate hikes and restrictive monetary policy to achieve the Fed's 2% goal.

images.alt_text: Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.
The US dollar index was 0.3 per cent higher, down from a 20-year peak of 114.78 hit in late September.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2022, a "We Are Hiring" sign is posted in front of a restaurant in Los Angeles. - US employers slowed the pace of hiring in August after the surprising surge in the prior month and the jobless rate edged up, the government reported on September 2, 2022. Even with the slowing pace, the job gains bring employment above the pre-pandemic level, the Labor Department said. US employment increased by 315,000 jobs last month, the report said, which was in line with what economists were expecting after the 526,000 hires in July. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Wall Street desire for Xi to pivot to growth faces reality check
summary: President Xi Jinping's upcoming Communist Party congress is expected to solidify his control over the party's 25-member Politburo, with little indication of a shift towards a more benign investing environment. Despite concerns over China's slowing economy and property crisis, Xi is unlikely to pivot away from his "Covid Zero" policies or ease restrictions. Instead, his focus will likely remain on domestic stability and financial security, potentially leading to a retreat from integration with the global market. Wall Street investors remain skeptical, with forecasts for a more stabilizing next five years falling on deaf ears.

images.alt_text: The increase in Chinese exports is likely to help stabilise global oil markets and partly replace supplies from Russia which will be hit by European Union embargoes in coming months.

site_title: Yellen calls for World Bank revamp to tackle global challenges
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has called for the World Bank to revamp its business model to address global challenges such as climate change and shift from country-specific financing. She plans to develop an "evolution roadmap" for changes by December, with "deeper work" beginning in spring 2023. Yellen aims to mobilize more private capital and deploy a broader range of financial instruments, including loan guarantees and insurance products, to tackle the scale of global challenges.

site_title: France is a friend, says UK’s Truss after previous wavering
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss has mended fences with France, just weeks after expressing doubts about the relationship with French President Emmanuel Macron. Truss and Macron met to discuss tackling illegal migration and agreed on "ambitious" measures to address the issue. The two leaders also pledged to hold the next UK-France Summit in 2023 and deepen cooperation on migration within international law. Truss had previously described Macron as a "friend," after initially saying the jury was out on their relationship.

images.alt_text: Addressing Conservative lawmakers and members at an annual conference overshadowed by internal bickering and confusion over policy, Truss said the party needed to unite to kick-start stagnant growth and tackle the many problems facing Britain.
British Prime Minister Liz Truss delivers her keynote speech at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Britain, Oct 5, 2022.
Liz Truss, UK prime minister, delivers her keynote speech during the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference on Wednesday Oct 5.

site_title: Not just to please investors, transition plans should be part of a company’s overall strategy: climate bonds panel
summary: Companies in hard-to-abate sectors, such as steel and shipping, should integrate transition plans into their overall strategy and business, rather than producing standalone plans, according to Eugene Wong, CEO of Sustainable Finance Institute Asia. This approach is necessary for structural transformation and is increasingly becoming a condition for obtaining loans or investments. Financial institutions can support companies in these sectors by raising awareness and drawing up strategies to achieve decarbonization, while governments and industry bodies also play a key role in charting financing pathways.

images.alt_text: The need to act on climate adaptation often precedes perception of the need to act.

site_title: Celsius says execs withdrew millions before bankruptcy, court filings show
summary: Celsius Network's top executives withdrew at least $30 million in cryptocurrencies in May before the company suspended customer withdrawals and filed for bankruptcy. CEO Alex Mashinsky, co-founder Daniel Leon, and CTO Nuke Goldstein made the withdrawals, denominated in Bitcoin, Ether, and Celsius's own token. The withdrawals, totaling $30 million, were made before the broader crypto market soured, raising questions about the company's financial management and potential misconduct. An examiner has been appointed to explore allegations of misconduct against Celsius and its executives.

images.alt_text: Bankman-Fried already scooped up the assets of bankrupt crypto brokerage Voyager Digital in an agreement valued at about US$1.4 billion.
The leadership change represents a major shift for the company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in July.
Celsius has filed for bankruptcy in July, a high profile casualty of this year’s meltdown in digital assets.

site_title: Inflation burst could hit Indonesian startups hard after era of fast growth
summary: Indonesia's inflation, triggered by a 30% fuel price hike, is affecting startups, particularly consumer-facing businesses. While some companies, like Jiwa Group, which sells coffee and baked goods, have been cushioned by long-term contracts, others are feeling the pinch. Businesses that deal in daily essentials have reported a rise in traffic, and the economy remains resilient despite macroeconomic headwinds. However, startups will need to focus on revenue and profitability to improve their business fundamentals, with venture capital firms optimistic about the long-term prospects of the Indonesian digital economy.

images.alt_text: Xendit helps businesses in South-east Asia easily process payments from a variety of payment methods.
Indonesia raised subsidised fuel prices by about 30 per cent in early September as the government moved to rein in ballooning subsidy bills.
WeLab founder and CEO Simon Loong says that plans for the Indonesian digital bank would be informed by its Hong Kong experience.

site_title: World Bank spent almost US$15b on fossil fuel projects since Paris deal: report
summary: The World Bank spent nearly $15 billion on fossil fuel projects globally since the Paris climate accord in 2018, despite pledging to end financing for upstream oil and gas. The report by NGO coalition The Big Shift Global found that the bank exploited loopholes by lending to intermediaries and acting as a guarantor for countries that failed to meet their climate obligations. The bank's own assessments of some projects highlighted significant environmental and social impacts, but it still approved them.

images.alt_text: A vessel docks along the Shell Petroleum refineries on Pulau Bukom in Singapore; June 2022.
The potential climate-related losses associated with these assets aren’t covered by the companies’ existing capital.
A wind turbine is seen in front of a coal-fired power plant operated by German energy supplier RWE in Niederaussem, Germany.

Petrol prices at a Shell station in San Francisco, California, Oct 3, 2022. Unlike other areas of inflation, fuel prices are literally emblazoned on large signs at gas stations, while motorists in many cases have no option other than to pay up.

site_title: US dollar gains as Friday’s US jobs data looms
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.3% on Thursday, edging closer to its 20-year peak of 114.78. Investors anticipate the release of US jobs data on Friday, which could signal slowing rate hikes and weaken the dollar. Meanwhile, the euro fell 0.27% to $0.9859, while sterling dropped 0.6% and the Japanese yen and Swiss franc remained steady. The moves come as European Central Bank minutes showed policymakers worried about inflation getting stuck at high levels.

site_title: Twitter lawsuit halted so Elon Musk can close deal
summary: A Delaware judge halted Twitter's lawsuit against Elon Musk, giving Musk time to close his $44 billion takeover of the social media platform. The ruling removed the threat of Musk testifying under oath about his claims of Twitter's fraudulent misrepresentation. Twitter shares rose 1% after hours, following days of uncertainty, and ended the day down 3.7% at $49.39. The judge set a deadline of October 28 for Musk to close the deal, or a trial would be scheduled for November.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has offered to push through with his buyout of Twitter at the original agreed price, just weeks before the opening of a bitter court case over his effort to withdraw from the deal.
Elon Musk stressed that he uses Twitter a lot and that he has ideas on ways to make the platform “radically better”.
Apollo Global Management and Sixth Street Partners are no longer providing financing to Elon Musk earlier this year for his proposed US$44 billion buyout of Twitter, two sources revealed.

site_title: Citi Ventures makes first crypto seed investment in xalts
summary: Citi Ventures led a US$6 million initial capital financing round for Hong Kong-based digital-asset management firm xalts, co-founded by former HSBC and Meta executives. The firm aims to capitalize on increased institutional participation in the digital asset ecosystem despite recent market fluctuations. xalts plans to launch multiple fund products linked to digital assets, including mutual funds and exchange-traded funds, and is expanding to multiple locations including Dubai, Singapore, and New Delhi. Citi Ventures views the digital asset space as a stable opportunity.

site_title: UK business pessimism worsened by fears of sticky inflation
summary: British businesses are becoming increasingly pessimistic about the coming year due to fears of lingering inflation and weak profits. According to the British Chambers of Commerce, about 4 in 10 companies expect their profitability to drop over the next 12 months, with only 44% expecting sales to rise. The survey also found that nearly two-thirds of respondents plan to keep lifting prices, with inflation showing no signs of letting up. This pessimism comes after the Conservative government's mini-budget triggered market chaos and led to the Bank of England launching a new bond-buying program.

images.alt_text: Almost half of the 501 firms surveyed said there is a likelihood they could face bankruptcy or insolvency in the coming months
UK homebuilding was the best performer last month, while civil engineering fell for a third month.

site_title: What nominating committees should do in a criminal investigation
summary: In a criminal investigation involving a listed company's director, the nominating committee (NC) should prioritize the best interests of the company and its shareholders. The NC must assess whether the director's continued appointment would cast doubt on their suitability or affect investor confidence. If an investigation is underway, the NC should consider appointing new independent directors, designating a Lead ID, and implementing measures to safeguard against risks. The NC's primary focus should be on charting a course for the company's best interests, rather than the director's personal fate.

images.alt_text: It depends on whether the investigation is for activities done inside or outside the company, to begin with.

site_title: Oil prices rise 1% on cuts to Opec+ output targets
summary: Oil prices rose 1% to three-week highs after Opec+ agreed to cut production targets by 2 million barrels per day, the largest reduction since 2020. Brent crude futures settled at $94.42 a barrel, up $1.05, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 0.8% to $88.45 a barrel. The agreement, ahead of a European Union embargo on Russian oil, is expected to squeeze supplies and add to inflation, with some analysts predicting prices could reach over $100 per barrel by December.

images.alt_text: Oil had been rising this week in anticipation of the cuts, said Fiona Cincotta, senior financial markets analyst at City Index.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa treat for 1,000 kids as in-person celebration of Children's Day returns
summary: Resorts World Sentosa hosted a treat for 1,000 primary school pupils on Children's Day, marking the return of the in-person celebration after two years of virtual activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The event, organized by Children for Children, provided opportunities for low-income children to visit iconic attractions, including Universal Studios Singapore. The fundraiser raised S$233,000 for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, supporting artistically talented children from less-privileged households.

images.alt_text: A million magical moments at Resorts World Sentosa

site_title: Apple’s 1.1 billion euros antitrust fine slashed by French court
summary: A French court reduced Apple's 1.1 billion euros antitrust fine to approximately 371.6 million euros, a 728 million euros reduction. The penalty was initially imposed in 2020 for anti-competitive agreements with favored distributors. The Paris court of appeals ruled that the fine should be reduced, with the competition agency considering an appeal to France's top court. Apple had accused the regulators of bending antitrust rules for political objectives.

site_title: Google unveils new phones, watch that undercut Apple on price
summary: Google has unveiled its new Pixel phones, the Pixel 7 and 7 Pro, with improved voice and camera features, facial recognition, and the second-generation Tensor chip. The devices start at US$599 and US$899, undercutting Apple's prices. The Pixel Watch, priced at US$349, also debuted, featuring an on-board app store, Google Wallet, and Fitbit health sensors. The new phones and watch aim to help Google compete with Samsung and Apple, with analyst Carolina Milanesi stating that Google needs to focus on its own hardware to showcase its AI capabilities.

images.alt_text: The launch event will take place at 10.00 am ET (2.00 pm GMT) in the Williamsburg neighbourhood of New York.

site_title: Voluntary offer for Asian Healthcare Specialists at S$0.188 in cash
summary: A healthtech startup unit, Labrador Park, has made a voluntary cash offer of S$0.188 per share to take over Asian Healthcare Specialists, valuing the company at S$109 million. The offer requires securing 90% of shares and landlord approvals. Labrador Park's offer is at a 18.3-22.3% premium to the volume-weighted average prices for the past year. The valuation puts the target above trading peers, with a price-over-earnings ratio of 20.5 times, compared to 13.6 times for peers.

images.alt_text: Asian Healthcare Specialists H2 profit up 56.4 per cent to S$2.45m

site_title: Britain could face three-hour power cuts this winter, National Grid warns
summary: Britain may face three-hour power cuts this winter due to a potential shortage of gas, which could limit supplies to households and businesses. The National Grid warns that if gas imports from Europe are disrupted, the UK would prioritize households and cut off large industrial users and power plants first. The British government is confident of securing power supplies, citing its diverse energy system, North Sea gas reserves, and imports from Norway and clean energy sources.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on fears of aggressive rate hikes
summary: US stocks opened lower on October 6, 2022, due to concerns over inflation and the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 67.7 points, or 0.22%, to 30,206.13, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors assessed data showing an increase in weekly jobless claims, further fueling worries about the economy.

site_title: One in five UK firms unsure of surviving slump: study
summary: A UK study by Evelyn Partners found that nearly half of 501 firms with revenue over £5 million are uncertain about surviving a looming recession. Almost half of the firms recognize a likelihood of bankruptcy or insolvency in the coming months. Soaring inflation, rising borrowing costs, and a weaker pound contribute to the pressure. M&A activity has decreased, with one in five business owners postponing or pulling out of deals. A quarter of business owners have already refinanced their debt, while 43% are considering it.

site_title: Global economy could lose US$4 trillion in output, IMF chief warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that the global economy is at risk of recession and could lose US$4 trillion in output through 2026, equivalent to Germany's economy. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says the situation is "more likely to get worse than to get better" due to high uncertainty, particularly after Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the pandemic. The IMF projects global economic growth of 3.2% in 2022 and 2.9% in 2023, which is expected to be lowered next week. Georgieva calls on policymakers to "stay the course" to bring down inflation and urges international cooperation to address global challenges.

site_title: Sri Lanka holds rates as crisis-hit economy banks on government reforms, IMF bailout
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank held interest rates steady at 15.50% and 14.50% as the country grapples with a debt crisis, inflation, and a shortage of US dollars. The bank aims to keep rates high to bring down inflation, with prices expected to slow in December and January. The country is also awaiting an IMF bailout, with officials predicting a $2.9 billion loan by year-end.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding garners 22 contracts, order book at record high of US$10.27b
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured 22 new vessel orders, increasing its total order book value to a record US$10.27 billion, with orders worth US$3.6 billion for the year. This brings the company's total orders to 40 vessels, exceeding its FY2022 target of US$2 billion. With 51 vessels delivered as of end-September, the company is on track to achieve its FY2022 delivery target of 70 vessels. The new orders include four bulk carriers, six bulk carriers, and twelve liquefied natural gas dual-fuel containerships.

site_title: US mortgage rates slip to 6.66%, the first drop in 7 weeks
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to 6.66% this week, the first decline in 7 weeks, after benchmark Treasury yields eased. This marks a shift in direction after a 6-week streak of gains, which sent borrowing costs to a 15-year high. Despite the decline, mortgage costs have more than doubled since the start of the year, affecting the pandemic housing rally and pushing more buyers to the sidelines, leading to a decline in home prices.

images.alt_text: Over the past seven weeks, US mortgage rates have soared 1.30 percentage points, the largest surge over a comparable period since 2003.

site_title: BOE says it will unwind gilt market intervention once risks have subsided
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) plans to unwind its gilt market intervention once market risks have subsided, based on an assessment of market conditions and the scale of purchases made. The intervention, launched on September 28, aimed to calm soaring yields threatening financial stability. The BOE will unwind the operation in a smooth and orderly fashion, depending on factors such as the scale of purchases, market conditions during and after the purchases, and the bank's assessment of market risks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.42% on October 6, 2022, due to profit-taking after a 6% gain the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 18,012.15. The move comes ahead of key US jobs data release later in the week, with traders bracing for potential market volatility. Mainland Chinese markets remain closed for a week-long holiday.

site_title: New AI platform launched to train and upskill financial workforce
summary: Singapore has launched a new AI platform, the Future Skills Accelerator, to train and upskill the financial workforce. The platform, developed by the Institute of Banking and Finance, AI startup JobTech, and PricewaterhouseCoopers, aims to automate workforce planning and personalize career development. It offers features such as internal career mobility, strategic workforce planning, talent marketplace, and talent acquisition. The platform is scalable and will enable employees to do more self-directed learning, promoting a dynamic learning and development culture. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for such efforts to strengthen Singapore's finance sector amid digitalization.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Reinventing skills and developing talent lie at the heart of the financial sector's rapid transformation.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Institute of Banking and Finance noted that annual funding support for financial sector training grew to S$140 million during the pandemic – more than 10 times the pre-pandemic level.
Digital skills, sustainability expertise needed to build talent pool
The upcoming revisions essentially make it harder for employers to hire foreigners here. But is that necessarily a bad thing?

site_title: Brave investors could reap double-digit returns from China equities, says Value Partners chief
summary: Value Partners Group co-chairman Cheah Cheng Hye expects China equities to experience a substantial upward re-rating as the country is likely to ease its zero-Covid policy in late October or early November. He predicts a 20% gain if Chinese stocks re-rate from a PE ratio of 11 to 13 or 15. Cheah also advises investors to allocate a third of their portfolio to cash, a third to stable equities and fixed income, and the remaining third to higher-risk opportunities like China stocks. The company aims to expand its Singapore office to capitalize on family-office monies and double its headcount in the city-state.

images.alt_text: A flight attendant for Cathay Pacific Airways at Hong Kong International Airport.
On top of Covid restrictions, the country is also contending with a severe property market downturn.

site_title: SGX will look beyond equities to stay relevant, says chairman Kwa Chong Seng
summary: SGX chairman Kwa Chong Seng emphasized the bourse operator's need to look beyond equities to stay relevant, citing Singapore's small market size. SGX will focus on areas like foreign currencies and commodities, where it sees a competitive edge, and collaborate with end clients and other exchanges. The bourse operator recorded a 1.3% increase in net profit to S$451.4 million for the full year ended June 30, with revenue rising 4% to S$1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo's stiffening regulatory attitude is unlikely to be popular among corporate boards
While Q3's total consideration was down from S$657 million the previous quarter, it was higher than the S$241 million in consideration recorded in Q3 of 2021.
Funan The IT Mall was one of the three properties in the IPO portfolio of Singapore's first Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust (now known as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust) in 2002.

site_title: After tough first month in charge, UK PM Liz Truss needs to quickly steady rocky Tory ship
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss faces a challenging first month in office, with polls showing a 14-point lead over the opposition Labour party. Truss delivered a speech at the Conservative Party conference, emphasizing her focus on economic growth, tax cuts, and deregulation. However, economists warn that the government needs to quickly deliver on promised free enterprise zones and fracking plans to achieve growth targets. With a troubled economic outlook, including a declining purchasing managers' index and rising interest rates, Truss must quickly steady the ship and regain public confidence to survive her first year in office.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Liz Truss delivers her keynote speech at the Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Britain, Oct 5, 2022.

Addressing Conservative lawmakers and members at an annual conference overshadowed by internal bickering and confusion over policy, Truss said the party needed to unite to kick-start stagnant growth and tackle the many problems facing Britain.
Attendees at the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference in Birmingham, UK, on Oct 3, 2022.

site_title: Porsche overtakes Volkswagen as Europe's most valuable carmaker
summary: Porsche has overtaken Volkswagen as Europe's most valuable carmaker, with a market valuation of 85 billion euros (S$119.6 billion) following a surge in its shares to 93 euros. Porsche's share price rose after investment banks purchased 3.8 million shares for 312.8 million euros as part of a greenshoe option, supporting its listing. This surpasses Volkswagen's valuation of 77.7 billion euros, with Mercedes-Benz and Stellantis following in third and fourth place, respectively. The rise is attributed to market fluctuations and stabilisation measures following recent economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Shares of the sports-car maker had debuted at 82.50 euros, the high end of the range VW sought, on Sep 29 in Europe’s biggest IPO since miner Glencore raised almost US$10 billion in 2011.

site_title: Live and Let Buy: James Bond auction nets record haul for charity
summary: A "Sixty Years of James Bond" auction in London featuring 25 films' props, memorabilia, and experiences raised a record £6.9 million (S$11.1 million) for charity, surpassing previous sales combined. The two-part sale, held to mark the 60th anniversary of the first film "Dr. No," featured items such as Aston Martin cars, watches, and costumes. The auction concluded on October 5, with proceeds going to charities including BAFTA, British Red Cross, and The Prince's Trust.

site_title: French author Annie Ernaux wins 2022 Nobel Prize for Literature
summary: French author Annie Ernaux won the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature for her "courage and clinical acuity" in uncovering the roots and restraints of personal memory. Ernaux, 82, was recognized for her autobiographical works that examine disparities in gender, language, and class. Her debut novel, "Les Armoires Vides," was published in 1974, but it was her 2008 book "Les Années" (translated as "The Years") that earned her international recognition and a large following. The prize is worth 10 million Swedish krona and marks a significant boost to her already established literary reputation.

images.alt_text:
The Nobel Chemistry Prize was awarded to a trio of chemists from the US and Denmark who laid the foundation for a more functional form of chemistry.
Americans Carolyn Bertozzi and Barry Sharpless, together with Denmark's Morten Meldal, were honoured "for the development of click chemistry and bioorthogonal chemistry," the jury said.

site_title: New BMW dealership comes with new generation of leader
summary: Charmain Kwee, 26, has taken on the role of executive director at Eurokars Group, the largest privately-held auto business in Singapore, after her father's prompting. Eurokars launched its BMW franchise last week, marking the second authorized BMW dealer in the country. Kwee, who had to give up a law career to join the family business, is tasked with overseeing the new BMW dealership and ensuring its showroom is up to scratch. Her father, executive chairman Karsono Kwee, is overseeing the entire operation, with Charmain working closely with the team to build the business from scratch.

images.alt_text: After booking record sales last year, Bentley, Ferrari and Rolls-Royce look on track to surpass 2021’s numbers with 74, 58 and 67 registrations respectively in the first eight months of this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close marginally lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed marginally lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.12 points to 1,420.43. 2.249 billion lots worth RM1.589 billion were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 435 to 328.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A record number of million-dollar HDB flats were sold in September 2022, with the highest sales recorded in areas such as Bishan, Kallang/Whampoa, and Ang Mo Kio. The HDB resale prices rose 1.2% in September, according to SRX and 99.co. CDL will start previews for its Copen Grand EC project in Tengah on October 7, with prices starting from S$1.08 million. Six adjoining Geylang Road shophouses were put up for sale, while Hong Kong's private sector activity contracted in September for the first time in six months.

site_title: Singapore stocks lose momentum as rally fizzles out; STI dips 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,151.56, due to a proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services by air catering company SATS. Despite a rebound in SATS' stock after its CEO announced plans to reduce the size of a proposed rights issue, the broader market registered 217 losers against 256 gainers. Oil price increases also weighed on Singapore Airlines, which fell 1.2%. Market analysts suggest the decline may be a temporary setback ahead of the US jobs report release tomorrow.

site_title: Lack of data, disclosure disparities form main barriers to valuing ESG: Panellists
summary: Valuers face significant challenges in incorporating Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into their business valuation reports due to the lack of objective data and disparities in disclosure. The International Sustainability Standards Board aims to issue final sustainability reporting standards in 2023, focusing on quantitative data for all companies. However, the current variability in disclosure standards poses risks of greenwashing, and the social and governance dimensions require more work to achieve consensus.

images.alt_text: Demonstrating a commitment to sustainability driven by ESG factors creates value for businesses in a variety of ways, from internal cost reductions to improved stakeholder relationships.
Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.

site_title: HDB to exercise flexibility to waive wait-out period for some downgraders to purchase resale flat
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) may waive the 15-month wait-out period for private property downgraders who obtained an option to purchase a HDB resale flat before the cooling measures kicked in. As of Tuesday, about half of the 450 appeals received by HDB fall under this category, and the Board is reviewing these cases. This move aims to provide flexibility for downgraders to purchase resale flats, addressing the current restrictions imposed since September 30.

images.alt_text: HDB flats in the Queenstown area and Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) as viewed from Block 90 Tanglin Halt on May 27, 2021.
New HDB flats more affordable than housing in comparable cities: Desmond Lee

site_title: Peugeot e-2008 review: A lion with li-ion
summary: The Peugeot e-2008 is a compact SUV that offers a practical and family-friendly electric vehicle option. With 130 horsepower and a 50 kilowatt-hour lithium-ion pack, it achieves a range of 345 kilometers on paper. The car features a discreet electric design, with a low-cost Category A COE and $45,000 worth of rebates. Inside, the cabin is driver-focused with layered screens and a vibrant green upholstery stitching. The e-2008 has a firm ride but is quiet on the move, and the sound system is better than expected. Its medium range and fast charging capabilities make it suitable for those looking to test drive an electric vehicle.

images.alt_text:
jumercedes22 - 

credit, source: Mercedes-Benz Singapore

site_title: Fei Siong Group inks exclusive franchise deal to develop and run Popeyes in Singapore
summary: Fei Siong Group has signed an exclusive franchise deal with Popeyes Louisana Kitchen Asia-Pacific to develop and operate new Popeyes restaurants in Singapore. The group plans to "refresh and modernise" existing outlets, introduce new menu items, and automate kitchen processes. The agreement, which lasts for 20 years, aims to replicate Popeyes' success in Singapore and potentially expand to Malaysia. Fei Siong Group, a Malaysian-based restaurant operator, will invest in new equipment and increase productivity to increase the outlet operations.

images.alt_text: Eric Foo is the president of Subway's Asia-Pacific region where he is responsible for leading, developing and expanding the sandwich chain's presence in the region
Burger King parent restaurant Brands misses revenue estimates

site_title: Honda to cut car output at two Japanese plants in October
summary: Honda plans to reduce car output by up to 40% at two Japanese plants in October due to persistent supply chain and logistical problems. The Suzuka plant will cut production by 20% and the Saitama plant by 40% for the month, affecting vehicles such as the Vezel, Stepwgn, and Civic. The move follows earlier production adjustments and comes as rival Toyota also lowered its October production target due to semiconductor shortages. Honda blames Covid-19 outbreaks and part shortages for the production cuts.

site_title: T-Rex to be displayed in Singapore
summary: A 12-meter Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton, named Shen, will be displayed in Singapore's Victoria Theatre & Concert Hall from October 28-30 before being auctioned at Christie's Hong Kong Autumn Auction Week in November. Shen is estimated to be worth between $15 million and $25 million and is the first T-Rex skeleton to be auctioned in Asia. The skeleton will be accompanied by other auction highlights, including artworks and luxury items, and is believed to have lived 68-66 million years ago during the Cretaceous Period.

site_title: Biden to tout IBM’s US$20b investment in New York over next decade
summary: US President Joe Biden will tout IBM's $20 billion investment in New York over the next decade in development and manufacturing of semiconductors, mainframe technology, artificial intelligence, and quantum computing. This announcement comes after the Chips and Science bill, which funded $52 billion for semiconductor chips manufacturing and research. The investments aim to bolster US competitiveness and create jobs, as China and the European Union have been offering billions in incentives to chip companies.

site_title: Malaysian bubble tea chain brewing up rapid expansion, to revisit IPO plans
summary: Malaysian bubble tea chain Loob Holding, owner of South-east Asia's largest bubble tea brand, plans to revisit its initial public offering (IPO) once it reaches 1,000 stores in Malaysia by 2024. The company, which opened its 800th store last month, had previously put its IPO plans on hold due to the coronavirus pandemic in 2020. Loob's CEO, Bryan Loo, stated that the company may consider an IPO if the timing and pricing are attractive.

site_title: UK construction outlook dims with increase in interest rates
summary: The UK construction industry turned pessimistic in September due to rising interest rates and recession risks. Despite an unexpected increase in output, business expectations fell to its lowest in over two years, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. The construction industry's forward-looking survey indicators worsened, with civil engineering falling for a third month. This marks a reversal from the previous month, when homebuilding was the best performer.

site_title: Three bunker clerks charged with receiving S$43m of gasoil stolen from Shell
summary: Three bunker clerks, Wong Wai Meng, Wong Kuin Wah, and Boo Pu Wen, have been charged under Singapore's Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act for receiving S$43 million of stolen gasoil from Shell Eastern Petroleum between 2014 and 2018. The clerks allegedly accepted bribes of S$250,000 to S$300,000 to avoid police investigations. Sentek Marine & Trading's former managing director, Pai Keng Pheng, also faces 42 counts under the same act for allegedly consenting to the acquisition of stolen property. All three clerks were granted bail.

site_title: Taiwan September inflation rate edges up slightly, but still below 3%
summary: Taiwan's September inflation rate rose 2.75% from a year earlier, in line with economists' predictions but below 3%. The central bank slightly revised its 2022 CPI forecast to 2.95%, up from 2.83% in June. The core CPI, excluding volatile energy and food prices, rose 2.79% in September, slightly higher than August. The central bank expects inflation to abate as the year progresses, with Director Tsao Chih-hung stating that inflation has peaked in the second quarter.

site_title: Supply chain disruptions are abating, though constraints remain
summary: Global supply chains are slowly recovering from pandemic-era disruptions, with delays in supplier delivery times decreasing and freight rates falling. The easing of supply chain pressures is attributed to cooling global demand, which has reduced the pressure on inflation. However, challenges persist, including labor shortages, warehouse space constraints, and empty containers at ports. Supply chains are being reshaped for greater resilience and flexibility, but it may take years to develop effective risk management capabilities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A cargo ship is seen at the port of Oakland as independent truck driver continue protesting against California's new law known as AB5, in Oakland, California, U.S., July 22, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
Increased value concentration with ever larger vessels and massive ports increases the risk of large event losses.

site_title: Volkswagen plans over 1b euro investment in software JV in China
summary: Volkswagen plans to invest over 1 billion euros in a joint venture in China for software production, according to sources. The investment is expected to be announced next week, following the results of the Lower Saxony state elections. The move is part of Volkswagen's existing research and development efforts in the country, where the company generates 40% of its sales and half of its profits. This investment will further solidify Volkswagen's presence in the digital innovation market in China.

images.alt_text: Porsche luxury automobiles outside the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, operated by Deutsche Boerse AG, in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Sept. 29, 2022. The sports-car maker rose as much 2.9% to €84.90 after slipping to its offer price of €82.50 apiece, the top end of VW’s initial range for the shares that valued the company at €75 billion ($73 billion). Photographer Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Luxury brands and used cars defy the worst car market in 8 years
summary: The Singapore car market is experiencing its worst year for new car sales in nearly a decade, with 21,470 new cars registered in the first eight months of 2022, a 25% decline from last year. However, luxury brands like Bentley, Ferrari, and Rolls-Royce are bucking the trend, with record sales in the first eight months of 2022. The used car market has also shown resilience, with 62,500 ownership transfers between January and August, but some experts question the accuracy of these numbers due to digital dealers buying and selling cars.

images.alt_text: Motorcycle COE premiums ended up with a hike of 1.4 per cent, while all other COE prices dipped.
Car sales have stayed below 2019 levels after surging demand for consumer products cleared out global inventories of semiconductors, forcing manufacturers to idle plants.
Luxury sports carmaker Maserati's GranTurismo, its first fully-electric car. Its indicative starting price is around 200,000 euros (S$279,591).

site_title: Will the Fed win the war on inflation? It’s complicated
summary: The US Federal Reserve is determined to raise interest rates higher to combat inflation, despite concerns about a potential recession. Core inflation remains at 4.9%, exceeding the Fed's 2% target, and the central bank has raised rates by 75 basis points for the third consecutive time. Fed leaders insist that restrictive monetary policy is needed to ensure inflation returns to target, despite global economic pain and potential costs to the US economy. Experts expect another 100-150 basis point rate increase this year, with the Fed showing no signs of easing its stance.

images.alt_text: After two hikes in July and September, it appears that the US Federal Reserve may have given up on trying to find a safe path between secular stagnation and stagflation, and started to hew toward the former.
Prices soared over the past year in part due to worldwide supply chain snags, creating shortages of key components like computer chips needed for cars and electronics.

site_title: Six adjoining Geylang Road shophouses put on the market
summary: Six adjoining freehold shophouses on Geylang Road have been put up for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) at an undisclosed price. The six two-story shophouses, with individual land titles, span 9,792 sq ft and 17,014 sq ft, offering potential for value-add through a five-storey rear extension. With a plot ratio of 3, the properties could fetch around S$50 million based on recent sales data, and are eligible for foreign buyers without additional stamp duties.

images.alt_text:
CMG20210213-ChanBK01陈斌勤/岛国掠影 Generic pics of shophouse, CBD, centrel business district, Tanjong Pagar, Chinatown, Maxwell.
图：陈斌勤 文：王彦燕 星期一　5月3号
在许多国人的记忆中，昔日的丹戎巴葛人声鼎沸、车水马龙，是牛车水的核心地域。
五角基的一步一景、一砖一瓦，还有蜿蜒幽深的古街老巷，像串珠般串连起这里丰富的历史文脉，娓娓讲述着这片土地的开埠史。
时至今日，这里不仅保留了原有的旧建筑肌理，近年来不少韩式饭馆、婚纱店、咖啡馆注入新活力，使丹戎巴葛华丽转身，还有了“小韩国”之称，渐渐成为市区的新地标。
##########pic##########陈斌勤
8M Real Estate buys island block of 5 shophouses in Jalan Besar for S$40m
Nestled within the Boat Quay conservation area, the 999-year leasehold property has a land size of approximately 1,410 square feet (sq ft) and a built-up area of approximately 4,000 sq ft.

site_title: Default by developer of Legoland Korea flags risks for nation’s developers
summary: South Korea's real estate market faces increased risks after the developer of Legoland Korea theme park, LL Development, defaulted on a 205 billion won loan. The missed debt payment, which occurred on September 29, is a reminder of the impact of interest-rate hikes on global real estate markets. Analysts predict a 10% decline in national house prices and a 18% drop in Seoul apartment prices over the next few years, potentially prompting the central bank to pivot to rate cuts. The default may further dent investor sentiment towards South Korea's real estate sectors.

site_title: India services activity drops to the lowest level in six months
summary: India's services sector activity declined to 54.3 in September, the lowest level in six months, according to the S&P Global India Purchasing Managers Index. New business inflows softened, and inflationary pressures restricted output and job creation. The Reserve Bank of India raised its key policy rate by 50 basis points to combat inflation. Despite weak external demand, business confidence remained high, boosted by sales growth forecasts. The sector's slowdown is attributed to higher energy, food, labor, and material costs.

images.alt_text: Motorcyclists travel past stores at a junction in Jamnagar, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, July 31, 2021. Indian pump prices are in uncharted territory as ever-increasing government levies coincide with crude’s recovery from the depths of the Covid-19 pandemic. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg##########1##########

site_title: Northern French spoil heaps warm to Charbonnay production
summary: Northern France's spoil heaps, once a symbol of industrial decline, are now warming up to wine production due to a changing climate. A decade ago, vines were planted on the heaps, and in 2018, the first "Charbonnay" wine was sold, mainly to locals. This year's heat is expected to triple production, with plans for more vineyards in neighboring Belgium. The rebirth of the Pas-de-Calais region is seen as a positive outcome for the area, which was once plagued by economic decline.

site_title: Share buybacks hit S$586m in Q3, pushing total 9-month consideration up 150% on year
summary: In Q3 2022, 46 primary-listed Singapore companies executed S$586 million in share buybacks, bringing the 9-month total to S$1.5 billion, a 150% increase from S$609 million in 2021. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.9% over the quarter, while dividends contributed 2.4% to total returns, outperforming the 3.2% decline in the international FTSE Developed Index.

images.alt_text: institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Sep 1, with S$38 million of net outflows.
Generic pictures of SGX
Office workers walking past the SGX logo outside the SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on 17 January 2020.

site_title: Toyota to resume sale of first mass-produced EV after recall: sources
summary: Toyota is set to resume selling its first mass-produced electric vehicle, the bZ4X, after a global recall due to a risk of wheels coming loose. The recall, announced in June, affected 2,700 vehicles worldwide. The problem occurred when sharp turns and sudden braking caused a hub bolt to loosen, posing a risk of a wheel coming off. Toyota will submit measures to fix the issue to Japan's transport ministry, and the automaker will resume selling the vehicle once the fixes are approved.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 2023 Toyota bZ4X all-electric SUV is displayed during the 2021 LA Auto Show in Los Angeles, California, U.S. November, 17, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.70% to 27,311.30, driven by rising US stock futures and hopes for monetary policy easing. The broader Topix index rose 0.50%. Investors were encouraged by the developments, which contrasted with a decline in European stocks.

site_title: A tale of two flats in Tiong Bahru
summary: French designer Yann Follain, founder of WY-TO Singapore, has designed six heritage flats in Tiong Bahru, Singapore, incorporating nostalgic features such as mosaic tiles and original architectural details. Two of his recently completed projects, Wanderlust and Blue Motifs, showcase the contrast between a casual tropical vibe and a more formal Art Deco style. Follain's clients, who are working professionals, sought his expertise to retain the unique charm of the long and narrow layouts, and he successfully incorporated original features and materials to create distinct yet authentic homes.

images.alt_text: As the desire for multi-generational living grows, architects are finding innovative ways to meet each family's requirements.

site_title: Nomura plans to hire more bankers to beef up green financing
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to hire more bankers to strengthen its sustainable financing business as global demand for decarbonization-related funding is expected to surge five to eight times by 2030. The expansion comes after the company added five managing directors to its Greentech unit in the last six months. Nomura aims to hire experienced bankers in fields such as advanced autos, supply chains, and transportation to support the growing need for green financing.

site_title: Chinese EV battery maker CALB targets top 3 rivals after IPO
summary: CALB Co, a Chinese EV battery maker, has listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange with a goal to become a top three player in the global EV battery industry within five years. The company, which is building out production lines with a combined annual capacity of over 200 GWh, aims to increase its battery capacity and market share. CALB's CEO, Jingyu Liu, stated that the company's IPO funds will be used for business expansion and R&D, and that it has sufficient capital for current needs.

images.alt_text: The portion of Leapmotor shares reserved for individuals in the IPO was lower than the amount offered, while those set aside for funds were “moderately” oversubscribed
CATL has maintained a lead over rivals, including the world’s second-biggest cell producer LG Energy Solution.

site_title: GE lays off workers at onshore wind unit as part of turnaround strategy: sources
summary: GE is laying off hundreds of workers at its onshore wind unit in the US, affecting 20% of the workforce, as part of a plan to restructure and reduce costs. The move is in response to weak demand, rising costs, and supply-chain delays. GE is also cutting its onshore wind workforce in Europe and Asia-Pacific. The cuts are part of the company's efforts to improve profitability ahead of a planned spin-off of its energy businesses in 2024.

images.alt_text: General Electric outlined a plan last November to split into three publicly traded companies focused on energy, healthcare and aviation to simplify its business and pare down debt.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on October 6, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.3% to 7,070.10 points, and Frankfurt's DAX index rising 0.7% to 12,606.62 points. The embattled pound also gained against the US dollar. The gains followed a previous day's losses due to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Art SG will be Asia’s second-biggest art fair
summary: Singapore's inaugural art fair, Art SG, is set to open in January 2023 with over 150 leading galleries across 30,000 square meters of exhibition space. The fair, co-founded by Magnus Renfrew and UBS, will feature works from world-famous artists such as Alex Katz, Louise Bourgeois, and Oscar Murillo. Despite concerns over the global economy, sales are expected to be strong, with collectors in the region spending more than doubling on art, rising from $72,000 in 2019 to $274,000 in 2021. The fair aims to prove Singapore's potential as a major art hub in Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore Biennale 2022 will be led by co-artistic directors (from left) June Yap, Nida Ghouse, Ala Younis and Binna Choi.
Distrik Seni is a new museum-like marketplace for quality art, with works by hot artists such as Mulyana, Hahan and Jompet Kuswidananto.

site_title: Mass shooting in Thailand leaves 38 dead, mostly children
summary: A mass shooting in northeastern Thailand's Nong Bua Lamphu province left 38 people dead, mostly children, after a 34-year-old former cop fired an automatic weapon at a daycare center. The suspect, Panya Kamrab, was believed to be under the influence of drugs. He killed 24 children, his wife, and child before taking his own life. Authorities have ordered a probe and closure of all daycare centers in the area, with the national police chief describing the crime as "horrifying".

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit two-week high on US futures' rise, foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares rose to a two-week high, driven by gains in US stock futures and foreign buying. The benchmark Kospi index ended 22.64 points higher, or 1.02%, at 2,237.86, its highest since September 23. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 253.6 billion won, and the Korean won strengthened. The index advanced for a third straight session and was on track for its first weekly gain in eight.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 5.84 points or 0.26 per cent at 2,215.22.

site_title: Indonesian nickel players likely beneficiaries of sanctions on Russian metals: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research predicts Indonesian nickel and Chinese aluminium players will benefit from sanctions on Russia's metal and steel sector due to tighter supply and higher metal prices. The research team recommends holding Aneka Tambang and Vale Indonesia for nickel players and buying Chalco and China Hongqiao for aluminium players, with target prices set at 2,100 rupiah and HK$5, respectively. The sanctions could have significant ramifications for global markets, potentially affecting the world's energy transition to renewables and electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Trading volumes of copper have tumbled by up to a third on global commodity exchanges so far this year.
LME aluminium inventories have risen in recent weeks, due to deliveries at Singapore and at Port Klang in Malaysia.
Metals world agonises over war but keeps buying from Russia

site_title: Australia: Shares close flat as two-day rally fizzles out
summary: Australia's shares closed flat at 6,817.5, after a two-day rally fizzled out due to recession fears. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 5.6% in the previous sessions following a smaller-than-expected interest rate hike from the Reserve Bank of Australia. However, gains in energy stocks were offset by losses in banks, with fund manager Magellan Financial Group being the top loser. The recent rally showed little predictability, with investors waiting for the macroeconomic landscape to improve.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.18 per cent at 6,815.7 points, as of 2356 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Adoption of green leases set to double by 2025, JLL study finds
summary: A JLL study found that 42% of corporates in the Asia-Pacific region had signed a green lease by June 2022, with 85% expected to sign by 2025. The main motivations for signing green leases are cost savings through energy efficiency (72%) and compliance with sustainability targets (67%). The study also revealed that building owners are not solely motivated by sustainability titles, but by the value of accredited buildings, which can lead to cheaper finance and increased property value.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Energy India's two thermal power plants in Nellore District, Andhra Pradesh, have four 660-megawatt supercritical coal-fired units and a total installed capacity of 2.64 gigawatts.
Countries typically take a “production-based” accounting approach in quantifying their greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades Astra to ‘hold’ on rate hikes, crude and coal price concerns
summary: UOB Kay Hian has downgraded its call on Astra International to "hold" from "buy" due to concerns over rate hikes, crude palm oil prices, and coal prices. The analyst expects a 10% year-on-year decline in domestic 4W automobile sales and a 17% decline in United Tractors' NPAT. Astra Agro Lestari is also expected to see a 15.4% decline in NPAT due to a decline in CPO prices. The analyst lowered the price target to 7,100 rupiah from 8,300 rupiah.

images.alt_text: WeLab founder and CEO Simon Loong said the company is focused on enhancing cross-country collaboration with partners.
The joint venture company, called PT Mobilitas Digital Indonesia, is expected to start operating in the fourth quarter of this year.
Jardine C&C sees a better Q1 driven by higher contribution from its 50.1 per cent-owned Astra International.
Broker's take: UOBKH upgrades Astra International to 'buy' on share price weakness
Astra Land taps rising demand for modern warehousing in Jakarta

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.95 points or 0.21% to 1,423.50 at 9:13 am on Thursday, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 161 to 97. Volume reached 303.72 million lots worth RM78.59 million.

site_title: Sex bomb: Abandoned bag in Japan turns out to contain ‘adult goods’
summary: Police in central Japan's Kakegawa received a call about an unattended silver briefcase in a municipal cemetery parking lot. The regional bomb squad was dispatched, and after a 3-hour containment, the team found "adult goods" inside, not threatening items. The incident occurred in the run-up to the state funeral for assassinated former prime minister Shinzo Abe, prompting criticism over security plans. The area is a popular spot for unauthorized dumping, and police were relieved to have made a safe resolution.

images.alt_text: Thousands of people are gathered in Tokyo to attend the state funeral for former prime minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: CDL to start previews for Copen Grand EC in Tengah on Friday, with prices from S$1.08m
summary: CDL and MCL Land will open applications for their Copen Grand executive condominium (EC) project in Tengah on Friday, with prices starting from S$1.08 million for a two-bedroom unit. The project, the first EC in the area, features smart and sustainable design, with units ranging from 807 sq ft to 1,722 sq ft. Despite recent market cooling measures, the developers believe it's the right time to launch, citing limited supply of new ECs and the project's unique features.

images.alt_text: The supply of new ECs will remain limited, according to real estate agency OrangeTee & Tie. Apart from the newly launched North Gaia (pictured) at Yishun Close, most ECs are completely sold or have a handful of balance units.
City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.

site_title: India September services growth slumped to 6-month low on cooling demand: PMI
summary: India's services sector growth slumped to a six-month low in September, according to a private survey, as demand slowed amid high inflation. The S&P Global India services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 54.3, lower than expectations. Despite this, the sector has expanded for 14 consecutive months, and the new business sub-index cooled but remained above 50. The Reserve Bank of India has raised interest rates to stem inflation, and the future activity sub-index rose, giving hopes of brighter growth.

images.alt_text: The monetary policy committee raised the key lending rate or the repo rate to 5.90 per cent with a 5 out of 6 majority.

site_title: Singapore stocks index is sole winner among developed markets this year
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index is the sole winner among developed markets this year, gaining about 1% in 2022. This is attributed to a rising interest-rate environment, cheaper valuations, and economic tailwinds from the pandemic recovery. Forward earnings estimates for Singapore stocks are up 16% year-to-date, significantly higher than the global gauge. The lack of exposure to tech shares and a focus on the Federal Reserve's inflation-targeting policies have contributed to Singapore's outperformance. The market is expected to continue to outperform developed markets until the Fed slows down.

images.alt_text: As at 9.01 am, the Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 0.4 per cent or 10.98 points to 3,164.21.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as global rally peters, focus now on US jobs
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as the global rally lost steam, with concerns over a massive oil output cut tempering hopes for central bank rate hikes. The US economy showed resilience despite multiple rate hikes, with private jobs hiring and a strong services sector report. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to ease rate hikes until inflation is tempered, despite some warnings of a recession. Oil prices rose after Opec and major producers led by Russia cut output by 2 million barrels a day, fueling concerns of higher energy costs and inflation.

images.alt_text: Asian bourses, including the Nikkei, were up on Wednesday.

site_title: TPG, Johor Corp talks to take KPJ private have stalled: sources
summary: TPG Capital and Johor Corp's talks to take KPJ Healthcare private have stalled due to disagreements over valuation and financing terms. The halt marks the second health-care deal in Malaysia to break down in recent weeks. KPJ, the country's largest private-hospital operator, has a market value of around $774 million. Negotiations could still resume, and other parties may be interested in pursuing the deal.

images.alt_text: Kulim has 55,796 hectares of planted areas with oil palm trees in Malaysia and 7,362 hectares in Indonesia, the website shows.

site_title: Crypto fugitive Do Kwon is set to lose his South Korean passport
summary: South Korea is set to revoke Do Kwon's passport, forcing him to hand it over or risk losing it in 14 days. The 31-year-old founder of Terraform Labs, behind the collapsed TerraUSD stablecoin, is wanted for breaching capital-markets law. He and five others have been accused of causing a $60 billion crypto crash and have denied the charges, which have become "highly politicized". Prosecutors have frozen $57 million in assets, bringing the total to $95 billion. Kwon's location is unclear and he is the subject of an Interpol red notice.

site_title: Gold gains as Treasury yields dip; hawkish Fed caps upside
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,719.19 per ounce, as Treasury yields dipped and the dollar index remained steady. The gains were limited by stronger US economic data that bolstered expectations of further Federal Reserve rate hikes to curb inflation. The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance was reaffirmed by San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly. Investors await the release of US nonfarm payrolls data on Friday, which may shift their focus away from gold.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, as they increase the opportunity cost of holding the metal and boosts the dollar in which the bullion is priced.

site_title: North Korea fires two ballistic missiles, blames US drills ‘escalation’
summary: North Korea fired two ballistic missiles on October 6, 2022, blaming US joint military drills with South Korea for the escalation of tensions. The missiles were launched from the Samsok area in Pyongyang towards the East Sea, with the first traveling 350km and the second 800km. The launches come after Pyongyang's Tuesday firing of an intermediate-range ballistic missile over Japan, prompting a UN Security Council meeting. Beijing blamed the US for provoking the launches, while the US called for strengthening existing sanctions on North Korea.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks to the media after North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan, at his official residence in Tokyo, Japan, Oct 4, 2022.
A surface-to-surface missile is fired into the East Sea, Oct 5, 2022.
North Korea fired “an unspecified ballistic missile toward the East Sea,” also known as the Sea of Japan, the South Korean Yonhap news agency said, citing the South Korean military.

site_title: Cathay Pacific union warns of higher fares caused by fewer staff
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways faces significant staffing and training shortages due to record pilot resignations, resulting in higher airfares and hindering its ability to resume full operations. The Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association warns that the airline's reduced workforce will keep airfares high and hinder Hong Kong's return as a global aviation hub. The situation is attributed to thousands of roles cut during the pandemic, leaving the airline with 20,800 employees globally as of June 30.

images.alt_text: The new rules should make it more attractive for pilots and flight attendants based in the Asian financial hub to resume flying more frequently and will reduce enforced downtime after trips, making rostering more efficient.
Hong Kong’s main carrier, also one of the world’s biggest cargo airlines by capacity, is mulling purchasing either Airbus A350 freighters or Boeing 777-8F jets, the people said.

site_title: Opec+ delivers Biden diplomatic slap with output cut
summary: US President Joe Biden received a diplomatic rebuke from Opec+, the cartel that controls oil production, as it announced a 2 million-barrel-a-day cut to its output limit. The move ignores Biden's efforts to isolate Russia and hold down fuel prices ahead of the midterm elections. The decision is seen as a shock, given Saudi Arabia's close ties to the US and its role in the US-led Western coalition confronting Russia. The cut is expected to increase fuel prices, which have already caused significant damage to Biden's standing this year.

images.alt_text: An OPEC flag is seen on the day of OPEC+ meeting in Vienna  in Vienna, Austria October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Leutner
Oil had been rising this week in anticipation of the cuts, said Fiona Cincotta, senior financial markets analyst at City Index.

site_title: Record number of million-dollar flats sold in September; HDB resale prices up 1.2%: SRX, 99.co
summary: A record 45 HDB flats were sold for S$1 million or more in September 2022, surpassing the previous high of 36 in December 2021. This represents about 1.7% of total resale volumes. HDB resale prices rose 1.2% for the 27th consecutive month, with prices for three-room and four-room units increasing by 0.9% and 0.7%, respectively. The overall year-on-year price increase for HDB resale flats in September was 11.1%.

images.alt_text: Investors should therefore not assume that Singapore property prices are a one-way street and will continue to rise unhindered.
New HDB flats more affordable than housing in comparable cities: Desmond Lee
HDB plans to launch up to 23,000 new flats in 2023.
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.
Overall resale flats transacted in August were lower at 2,323 – representing a 1.7 per cent decrease from July 2022, and 15.5 per cent down from the previous year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on October 6, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.07% or 12.51 points to 18,100.48, extending gains from a 5.8% surge the previous day. Traders await the release of key US jobs data this week. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for a national holiday.

site_title: Australia trade surplus unexpectedly narrows on import strength
summary: Australia's trade surplus narrowed to A$8.3 billion in August, below economists' estimates of A$10 billion, as imports surged 4.5% and exports grew 2.6%. The nation's exports of commodities like iron ore and natural gas contributed to the trade windfalls, while rural goods rose 6.8% and services imports advanced. Treasurer Jim Chalmers has warned of high export prices and is expected to unveil a budget on October 25, aiming to curb spending and reduce fiscal deficits.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia raised its cash rate to a nine-year peak of 2.60 per cent, the sixth hike in as many months which included four outsized moves of 50 basis points..

site_title: Amro cuts Asean+3 growth forecast on gloomier prospects for China, Japan, South Korea
summary: The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) has cut its 2022 growth forecast for the Asean+3 region to 3.7% due to gloomier prospects for China, Japan, and South Korea. For 2023, the region is expected to grow at 4.6%, down from the 4.9% forecast in July. The cut in forecast is attributed to weaker global demand, tighter monetary conditions, and the risk of a global recession. Inflation is projected to rise to 6.2% in 2022 and 3.4% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Ronald Chan, the founder of Hong Kong boutique investment firm Chartwell Capital, espouses a 'buy-and-hold and rebalancing approach' for growth and income.

This undated handout photograph released by Singapore's national water agency PUB on July 14, 2021 shows an aerial view of Sembcorb energy company's new floating solar power farm at Tengeh reservoir in Singapore. The Asian Development Bank cut China’s growth forecast for 2022 to 3.3 per cent from 5.0 per cent, as Beijing pursues a zero-Covid strategy that has devastated the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Ford hikes price of electric F-150 pickup again on rising supply costs
summary: Ford has raised the starting price of its electric F-150 Lightning pickup truck for the second time, citing rising material costs and supply shortages. The F-150 Lightning Pro now starts at $51,974, a 30% increase from its original price of $39,974. The price hike affects only the Pro model, with the XLT model remaining unchanged at $59,474. Ford cited ongoing supply chain constraints and market factors in its decision, which is the second price increase for the truck in about two months.

site_title: Apollo, Sixth Street no longer in talks to finance Twitter deal: sources
summary: Apollo Global Management and Sixth Street Partners, who were set to provide financing for Elon Musk's $44 billion Twitter buyout, are no longer in talks with the billionaire entrepreneur. The talks ended months ago after Musk had second thoughts about the deal. Musk is now expected to fund the deal through funds raised by selling down his Tesla stake and equity financing from large investors, while major banks are committed to providing $12.5 billion in debt financing. This development could result in significant losses for banks due to an unfavorable financing environment.

images.alt_text: A screengrab from Tesla AI Day 2022 livestream shows Elon Musk (L) presenting the humanoid robot in Palo Alto, California on Sept 30, 2022.
The tool will let users edit a tweet up to five times within 30 minutes of initially posting, Twitter said.
Elon Musk has offered to push through with his buyout of Twitter at the original agreed price, just weeks before the opening of a bitter court case over his effort to withdraw from the deal.
Elon Musk stressed that he uses Twitter a lot and that he has ideas on ways to make the platform “radically better”.

site_title: Hong Kong recovery falters as PMI falls to worst in six months
summary: Hong Kong's private sector activity contracted in September, with the S&P Global PMI falling to 48, its lowest reading since March. The contraction is attributed to Covid-19 disruptions and limitations on meeting up, impacting demand and activity. This marks the first time in six months the city's private sector activity has contracted. The city's monetary authority has been forced to follow the Federal Reserve in interest rate hikes, weighing down growth. Hong Kong's GDP forecast for the year is now expected to contract, with a range of -0.5% to 0.5%.

images.alt_text: A flight attendant for Cathay Pacific Airways at Hong Kong International Airport.
Retail sales value dropped 0.1 per cent in August from a year ago, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department said on Friday (Sep 30).

site_title: Mena emerges as world’s fastest-growing crypto adopter: study
