summary: The Middle East and North Africa (Mena) region is the world's fastest-growing cryptocurrency market, with a 48% increase in crypto received between July 2021 and June 2022. Turkey, Egypt, and Morocco are among the top 30 countries in Chainalysis' 2022 Global Crypto Adoption Index, with Turkey receiving the most crypto, worth US$192 billion. The region's rapid growth is attributed to fluctuating cryptocurrency prices coinciding with rapid fiat currency devaluations, particularly in Turkey and Egypt.

images.alt_text: The company will stay focused on its crypto custody services which Cohen says are foundational for clients, citing “massive” demand and opportunity there.
Energy consumption has plummeted by more than 99 per cent on Ethereum after "the merge".
Some of the biggest casualties of the crypto downturn, such as hedge fund Three Arrows Capital, operated out of Singapore.

site_title: The return of the strata retail market
summary: Singapore's strata retail market is showing promising signs of a rebound after a two-year slump due to the pandemic. Despite not reaching the peak sales performances of 2012 and 2013, interest in strata-titled retail space is rekindling, driven by the reopening of borders and growing momentum in revenge travel and shopping. Sales transactions at popular malls like Far East Plaza and Lucky Plaza have been consistent, and individual unit-size strata retail space is more accessible to retail investors. As the market evolves, investors must carefully evaluate properties based on location, accessibility, and catchment profiles to ensure long-term success.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales returning to pre-pandemic levels, but headwinds persist
The 6-storey Sim Lim Square, which has 492 units, was completed in 1987.

site_title: World currency reserves shrink by US$1t in record drawdown
summary: Global foreign-currency reserves have declined by about US$1 trillion, or 7.8%, to US$12 trillion this year, the largest drop since 2003. Central banks, including India and Japan, are intervening to support their currencies, with India's stockpile falling US$96 billion and Japan spending US$20 billion in September. The decline reflects stress in the currency market and the need for central banks to prop up their currencies, with some countries, like Pakistan, facing severe depletion of their reserves.

images.alt_text: China is well advanced with real-life trials of an e-yuan.

site_title: UK’s credit outlook cut to negative by Fitch on fiscal risk
summary: The UK's credit outlook was cut to negative by Fitch Ratings due to concerns over the government's fiscal risk. The downgrade follows the recent introduction of a tax cut package and large-scale borrowing, which led to a market tailspin and a decline in the pound's value. Fitch cited the lack of compensatory measures and an independent evaluation of the impact on public finances as key factors. The rating agency also expressed concerns over the government's ability to manage the nation's debt affordability, warning of lasting damage to the UK's debt situation.

images.alt_text: A man walks through the lobby of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain August 25, 2015. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers ST Engineering target price on higher interest rates
summary: CGS-CIMB analyst Lim Siew Khee lowered her target price on ST Engineering (STE) from S$4.53 to S$3.95 due to higher interest rates. The US Federal Reserve's 0.75% rate hike is expected to negatively impact STE's earnings through FY2023-2024, with a 6.2-8% EPS growth reduction forecasted. STE's shares are trading at 18 times FY2023 price-to-earnings ratio, 2 standard deviation points below its 6-year historical mean. Despite this, STE remains rated "add" for its defensiveness and strong net gearing position.

images.alt_text: Li Fuyun, head of sustainable cooling for urban solutions in ST Engineering, said the new cooling system would be able to reduce 7 per cent of urban heat island effect for tropical climates.
ST Engineering faces short-term headwinds as it grapples with chip shortages

site_title: 24,000 more nurses, healthcare staff needed by 2030 as S’pore ages
summary: Singapore to need 24,000 more nurses and healthcare staff by 2030 as the population ages, with locals forming the bulk of the workforce while foreign nurses play a growing role. The healthcare system aims to prevent illnesses and promote healthy living, laying the groundwork for an aged care system. The "Healthier SG" initiative, announced by Health Minister Ong Ye Kung, seeks to empower individuals and reform the public health system.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

About 10 per cent of the re-employment disputes that MOM received annually between 2016 and 2021 were escalated to the Minister for Manpower or the Employment Claims Tribunals, said manpower minister Tan See Leng.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Thursday as recession fears resurface
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.18% on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 6,815.7 points, as recession fears resurfaced. The energy sector was the only bright spot, rising 2.1% on the back of rising oil prices after OPEC+ agreed to deep cuts. Financials and technology stocks declined, with major banks and tech firms experiencing significant losses. The decline was attributed to ongoing hawkish talk from the US Federal Reserve and dwindling hopes for a pivot from rate hikes to fight inflation.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.7 per cent higher at 6,815.7.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% at the open on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing to 3,164.21 points. Marine logistics group Sembcorp Marine led gains, while Singtel, SATS, and MarcoPolo Marine also saw significant trading activity. The STI rose despite a volatile session on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 declined 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.3%. European shares also fell, with the Stoxx 600 index down 1%, while Tokyo shares opened slightly higher.

images.alt_text: Since inflight caterer and ground handler Sats announced details of a proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Service last week, details that included a potential rights issue, its shares has lost around 24 per cent of its value.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats
summary: Sats, an inflight caterer and ground handler, announced a proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services, prompting a 24% decline in its shares. The company's CEO stated that the proposed rights issue would be reduced and is one of four funding sources for the deal. Shares of Sats closed 1.3% lower on Wednesday at S$2.95.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Thursday despite Wall Street losses
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, defying global losses, as the Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% to 27,205.86. This follows a Wall Street slump, where recent global rallies are seen fizzling out due to profit-taking. The broader Topix index also rose 0.38%.

site_title: Jury finds former Uber security chief guilty of concealing data breach
summary: A US jury has found former Uber security chief Joseph Sullivan guilty of concealing a 2016 data breach that affected 57 million passengers and drivers. Sullivan was found guilty of obstruction of justice and deliberate concealment of a felony. The breach was not disclosed for a year, and Sullivan allegedly paid hackers $100,000 in bitcoin and had them sign nondisclosure agreements. Sullivan was originally indicted in 2020 and had agreed to cooperate with the prosecution as part of a settlement.

images.alt_text: Uber has contacted law enforcement, froze all Slack communications while it investigates the hacker’s claims.
Chief operating officer Alex Hungate, has spearheaded a push away from low-margin business lines as Grab races to turn profitable.
The production and sale of more electric and hybrid vehicles is also a key part of the plans set out in March by Stellantis chief executive Carlos Tavares.

site_title: EU to explore additional joint funds to support energy shift
summary: The European Union is considering raising additional joint funds to support its energy shift away from Russian gas, with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen proposing exploring other funding sources. The move comes amid growing concerns about the bloc's dependence on Russian energy and the need for significant spending to get through the next few winters without Russian gas. The EU will discuss the proposal with leaders in Prague, with some member states expressing skepticism about the need for fresh funding.

images.alt_text: Wednesday’s (Oct 5) data comes after a sister survey on Monday showed manufacturing activity across the eurozone declined further last month as a growing cost of living crisis hurt demand while soaring energy bills limited production.

site_title: Boeing’s China orders dry up on US tensions in boost for Airbus
summary: China has cancelled Boeing's 737 Max orders, following a 40-plane deal missed in September, and a nearly 300 Airbus aircraft deal in July worth around $37 billion. The cancellations reflect the impact of US-China tensions on Boeing's sales, with the company still waiting for its 737 Max to fly in China. The losses are expected to lengthen Boeing's recovery timeline and crimp its outlook. Airbus is now poised to dominate the Chinese market, with deliveries already falling to a "negligible level" since 2020.

images.alt_text: Boeing faces a December deadline to win approval of the 737 MAX 7 and 10 variants or it must meet new modern cockpit-alerting requirements, unless Congress extends the deadline.

site_title: North Korea fires ballistic missile toward sea: Yonhap
summary: North Korea fired an unspecified ballistic missile toward the East Sea, also known as the Sea of Japan, according to South Korean military. This comes as the UN Security Council met in New York over North Korea's recent missile firing over Japan, its first in five years. The move has raised concerns about North Korea's military activities and its potential impact on regional stability.

site_title: Climate change made 2022 drought ‘at least 20 times likelier’
summary: Climate change increased the likelihood of 2022's drought in the Northern Hemisphere by at least 20 times, making it occur once every 20 years at current warming levels. Without human-induced climate change, such a drought would only be expected to occur once every 400 years. This study, led by Sonia Seneviratne, highlights the growing risks of agricultural and ecological droughts in densely populated regions due to human-induced climate change.

site_title: Sydney set to smash rainfall records as Australia braces for more floods
summary: Sydney is on track to break its rainfall record, with 2,157 mm of rain already recorded in 2022, just shy of the 1950 record of 2,194 mm. Authorities warn of major floods and flash flooding in the city, with more heavy downpours expected over the next three days. The La Nina weather phenomenon has caused a multi-year rain event along Australia's east coast, leading to floods in Sydney suburbs and forcing tens of thousands to flee their homes. The New South Wales state government plans to raise the height of the Warragamba Dam to prevent future floods.

images.alt_text: Pertamina wants to double its secured supply of crude oil to 50 days from 21 as refinery capacity expands and the economy rebounds.
A wind turbine is seen in front of a coal-fired power plant operated by German energy supplier RWE in Niederaussem, Germany.
A drought across swathes of England in August, 2022.

site_title: The changing face of collective sales
summary: Singapore's collective sales market is shifting, with commercial collective sales making up over 50% of total volumes, up from 40% in previous years. This trend is driven by factors such as the government's push for rejuvenation in older commercial precincts, brighter prospects for commercial real estate, and punitive cooling measures targeting the residential sector. Owners of ageing assets have become more realistic in asking prices, with successful collective sales including Golden Mile Complex and Tanglin Shopping Centre selling at lower prices than prior to the pandemic. Developers are now more confident to undertake redevelopment projects, with a wider arena to deploy their capital.

images.alt_text: This isn’t the first time Horizon Towers has been put up for sale. It launched for sale in July 2018 at a reserve price of S$1.1 billion, just a day before the Jul 6 cooling measures kicked in that year. It then went on to relaunch for sale in early 2019 at the same price but was unsuccessful.

Trendale Tower was put up for sale in August at a guide price of S$178 million, which works out to S$2,386 per plot ratio after factoring in the seven per cent bonus gross floor area (GFA) for balconies.
Oxley Garden, sitting on a 58,207 square feet (sq ft) freehold plot in prime District 9, has been relaunched for collective sale.

site_title: Under-fire UK PM Truss fails to calm markets with growth pledge
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss failed to calm markets with a speech promising economic "growth, growth, growth" as she closes her party's conference, despite a humiliating U-turn on a pledge to cut income tax. The pound slid 2.01% against the dollar, and global ratings agency Fitch lowered its outlook for British government debt to negative. Truss's unapologetic pitch for economic growth has alienated voters, financial markets, and many in the ruling Conservative party, with critics accusing her of lacking a national mandate for her unpopular reforms.

images.alt_text: epa10221509 British Prime Minister Liz Truss (C) applauses Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng after his keynote speech at Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham, Britain, 03 October 2022. The government announced a U-turn on scrapping the 45p tax rate, which is paid by people earning over 150,000 British pound (171,080.80 euro) a year, following a week of market turmoil and the British pound going historic low against the US dollar.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN

A "For Sale" sign displayed outside a residential property in London. Many investors believe the pound’s slump will not last, with agents noting that many are buying up British pounds to gear up for a potential home purchase in the UK.
Britain’s most radical package of tax cuts since 1972, combined with plans for large-scale borrowing, sent UK markets into a tailspin last week.

site_title: Qantas CEO warns against lengthy delays to key Airbus order
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce warned that lengthy delays to key Airbus orders could significantly impact the airline's operations. He is set to meet with Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury to discuss progress on bespoke A350 deliveries for non-stop flights and A320 upgrades. Joyce emphasized the importance of certainty on delivery timelines, stating that delays of six months or a year could make a significant difference. Airbus has been struggling with labor and materials shortages, but Joyce reported no indication of slippage in deliveries.

images.alt_text: Rex, best known for flying small propeller-driven aircraft between regional towns, is fast building out a new jet division plying busy domestic routes including Sydney-Melbourne.
The airline is looking for at least 100 volunteers to carry out shift work at Sydney and Melbourne airports.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat amid interest rate jitters, recession fears
summary: European shares retreated on Wednesday amid interest rate jitters and recession fears. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 1% after New Zealand's central bank raised interest rates, and the euro zone business activity contracted for a third month in September, fueling fears of an economic downturn. Investors await a US nonfarm jobs report for further clues on the labor market and potential Federal Reserve policy shifts.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.5 per cent to 7,053.17 points.

site_title: As election talks hit fever pitch, Malaysians primed for ‘feel-good’ Budget on Oct 7
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob is set to announce the 2023 Budget on October 7, amid speculation that parliament could be dissolved before the election, expected to take place before the end of the year. Analysts predict the budget will be a "feel-good" budget with schemes and handouts to address the concerns of various groups, including low-income earners and SMEs. The government is expected to provide incentives and soft loans to encourage digitalization and promote technology adoption. However, some analysts warn that the budget may pose downside risks to Malaysia's fiscal outlook if the general election goes ahead this year.

images.alt_text: Azmin noted that Malaysia’s economy is among the best performers in Asean, a political and economic union of 10 countries in the region.
Malaysia expects to spend a record 80 billion ringgit (S$24.7 billion) in subsidies this year, and that expenditure is forecast to go up next year due to rising global inflation.

site_title: Singapore hotels remain an attractive asset class for investment as recovery takes hold
summary: Singapore hotels have experienced a rapid recovery in performance as travel rebounds with the full reopening of international borders in late April. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) performance doubled, achieving a near 20-per-cent year-on-year increase in occupancy rate. The market has seen almost S$1.2 billion in transactions, led by the sale of 28 and 30 Bideford Road at effectively S$1.3 million per key. Despite challenges such as reduced airlift capacity and a shortage of labor, the industry is expected to benefit from Singapore's return as a key transit hub and regional center for business and meetings.

images.alt_text: Oakwood Studios comprises 98 units of studio, 1- and 2-bedroom apartments and spans across a site area of approximately 18,000 square feet (sq ft).
The 18-storey freehold luxury mixed-used development along 28 and 30 Bideford Road was designed by Japanese architectural firm Nikken Sekkei.

site_title: Amid high US inflation, online insurance offers mislead elderly
summary: US congressional committee requests 15 states to investigate deceptive Medicare marketing, amid rising complaints from elderly Americans about misleading online insurance offers, including free grocery cards and dental care, which often promise benefits not available to the targeted audience. Big insurance companies are taking note, and watchdogs warn that these ads can mislead vulnerable citizens, potentially disrupting their health coverage. Experts advise consumers to "tread lightly and do their research" to avoid getting duped.

images.alt_text: Services activity is being supported by a shift in spending from goods, though demand for services is starting to slow.
The bank is due to unveil a strategic review on Oct 27, which is expected to include a large-scale investment-banking retreat.

site_title: Staying the course
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to weather external shocks due to sound fundamentals, boding well for its long-term prospects. Despite record-breaking fresh launches in the Outside Central Region and new highs in public housing sales, a recent round of property curbs may temper enthusiasm, prompting buyers to make more prudent decisions. A more sustainable market is considered healthier in the long run, as the global recession and higher mortgage rates pose challenges.

images.alt_text: PropNex anticipates that the median selling price of overall new OCR projects may hover around the S$2,000 psf range in the near-term with Sky Eden@Bedok transacting 118 units at an average price of S$2,100 psf, and Lentor Modern selling 84 per cent of its units also at an average price of about S$2,100 psf.

The robust take-up of new project launches, such as Piccadilly Grand and Liv@MB in the RCR, have re-ignited market engines and contributed to an acceleration of home prices in Q2 2022. In the OCR, the launches of AMO Residence (pictured) in July and, more recently, Sky Eden@Bedok, were also met with positive reception.

GCB land prices have continued to soar in 2022, rising 8.9 per cent between H1 21 and H1 22, to average S$1,839 per square foot (psf) according to JLL. This reflects a recovery of 25.3 per cent from the Covid trough of S$1,468 psf in H2 20.
The Pinnacle@Duxton on 7 April 2021.

site_title: Beware embracing blockchain as a way of doing good
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warns against normalizing the use of blockchain technology among retail investors, citing the high risks of cryptocurrencies. A project called Lifesdao, which sells non-fungible tokens (NFTs) promising monthly credits, may inadvertently lead vulnerable families to crypto assets despite MAS's warnings. Lifesdao claims to disburse S$50 to 1,200 beneficiaries over 10 years through a trust fund, but critics argue that a cash or voucher donation could achieve the same goal without the risks associated with blockchain.

images.alt_text: “(Consumers) seem to be irrationally oblivious about the risks of cryptocurrency trading,” Menon said at a seminar on the digital asset ecosystem in Singapore.
The roar of F1 is returning to Singapore and along with it crypto platform ads that have vanished since January.

site_title: US: Stocks decline, snapping two-day winning streak
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, snapping a two-day winning streak, after recent economic data showed signs of a slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.1%, 0.2%, and 0.3% respectively. The US private employment increased by 208,000 last month, but the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes may persist despite this data, with analysts suggesting that the economy is too strong for the Fed to ease off its aggressive posture.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 fell 37.7 points, or 0.99 stocks, at the open to 3,753.25​, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 153.7 points, or 1.38 stocks, to 11,022.672 at the opening bell.

site_title: Global car sales might stay below pre-pandemic levels for another year
summary: Global car sales are expected to remain below pre-pandemic levels for another year, with 85 million vehicles predicted for 2023. The decline is attributed to supply-chain constraints giving way to softening demand, inflation, and rising interest rates. This marks the fourth consecutive year of sales below 2019 levels, with the outlook remaining cautious due to a potential economic downturn, according to LMC Automotive's director of global sales forecasts, Jonathon Poskitt.

images.alt_text: Tesla said it will remove ultrasonic sensors from the Model 3 and Model Y globally over the next few months, followed by the Model S and Model X in 2023.

site_title: Best World gets regulator’s approval for share trading resumption
summary: Best World, a company that had its trading suspended for three years due to concerns over its business model in China, has received approval from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) to resume trading under certain conditions. The company must obtain an updated independent legal opinion on its business model, make changes to its directors' appointments, and disclose sufficient information to enable fair and orderly trading. The conditions must be met within four months of the company's financial year-end.

images.alt_text: On Jun 16, Best World had also received an improved audit opinion from its independent auditor for its audited financial results for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2021.
Best World International headquarters at Tai Seng

site_title: Good Class Bungalows attracting young and wealthy buyers
summary: Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore continue to attract young and wealthy buyers, with prices rising 8.9% in 2022 to an average of S$1,839 per square foot. The traditionally mature buyer profile has expanded to include young entrepreneurs, tech businessmen, and newly minted wealthy Singapore citizens. Notable buyers include CEOs of tech companies such as Grab and TikTok, who purchased GCBs for over S$50 million. Despite a slower sales volume in 2022, the GCB market is expected to remain attractive to wealthy buyers due to its exclusive lifestyle and long-term investment gains.

images.alt_text: House along Olive Road being sold for S$50.2 million

krpic - House along White House Park
Source:BT ReaderCopyright: BT ReaderBT editorial use only

krpark -  House in Belmont Park area

Source: BT Reader
Copyright: BT Reader
For BT editorial use only.

site_title: Sats aims to ‘reduce’ size of rights issue, says CEO, after sell-off over fears of potential S$1.7b cash call
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based inflight caterer and ground handler, is working on a funding plan for its proposed acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), the world's largest air cargo handler. CEO Kerry Mok aims to reduce the size of a potential rights issue to raise S$1.7 billion, instead opting for a mix of funding sources including an acquisition bridge facility and internal cash resources. The deal, valued at up to 1.3 billion euros, is expected to result in a significant shift in Sats' investor base and balance sheet, with concerns about increased gearing levels.

images.alt_text: Sats shares have fallen 22 per cent since unveiling deal to acquire WFS
The inflight caterer and ground handler on Wednesday announced its 1.3 billion euro (S$1.9 billion) deal to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.
SATS said this acquisition would result in an “unmatched global footprint” that would cover trade routes responsible for over 50 per cent of global air cargo volumes.

site_title: KKR backs cybersecurity firm NetSPI with US$410m funding
summary: KKR has agreed to provide cybersecurity firm NetSPI with an additional US$410 million in growth equity, bringing the private equity firm's total commitment to US$500 million. NetSPI, founded in 2001, will use the funding to drive growth and expansion, with plans to reach US$100 million in revenue this year. The deal follows KKR's previous US$90 million investment in the company, and existing investor Sunstone Partners will exit its position. The funding underscores KKR's focus on the cybersecurity sector, which it has been tracking for several years.

site_title: Pricing mass market homes for HDB upgraders
summary: PropNex predicts the median selling price of new Outside Central Region (OCR) projects will hover around S$2,000 psf in the near-term. Recent transactions, such as Sky Eden@Bedok and Lentor Modern, have sold units at an average price of S$2,100 psf. These projects are popular among HDB upgraders, offering a comfortable living space at a lower price point, typically in the 800-1,000 sq ft range, favored by families upgrading from public housing.

images.alt_text: AMO Residence is the first notable launch in the Outside Central Region (OCR) this year, as well as the first major project in Ang Mo Kio in over eight years.
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.
Lentor Modern is the largest private non-landed residential launch in 2022, said Huttons Asia.

site_title: Public housing with million-dollar price tags
summary: In Singapore, million-dollar HDB flats have become increasingly common, with a monthly average of 32 flats sold at S$1 million or more from May to August this year. This represents a 53.6% year-on-year increase. The growth is attributed to factors such as the end of the five-year minimum occupation period, increased demand for larger flats due to the pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and rising private housing prices. The most expensive HDB flats are found in the Central Area, particularly in the Pinnacle@Duxton project, with a median price of S$963 per square foot.

images.alt_text: At 48 storeys, 96A Henderson Road is likely the tallest HDB block in Singapore after Pinnacle @ Duxton, according to Lee Sze Teck, senior director (research) at Huttons.
Just in the first 8 months of this year, the price gap between new condos in the suburbs and 4-room million-dollar flats located in all regions stood at 53.6 per cent.
OrangeTee & Tie's Christine Sun thinks overall condo and HDB rental prices may either continue rising or remain at current levels in the coming months.

site_title: Luxury non-landed private residential market returns to a world without borders
summary: The luxury non-landed private residential market in Singapore has seen a resurgence in foreign buyer demand, defying expectations that the introduction of higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates would deter buyers. In Q2 2022 and Q3 2022, foreign buyers accounted for 12.3% and 11.9% of the market, respectively, surpassing 2011 levels. The high ABSD rates are attributed to the preservation of wealth and diversification of savings from global political uncertainty, rather than economic gains, with rental growth compensating for slower capital appreciation. The luxury segment is expected to continue attracting foreign buyers, despite ABSD rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Price gap narrows between RCR and CCR homes in March
Purchases of non-landed private homes by foreign buyers picked up in April with 93 transactions, up from 51 units in March.
To date, the property developer has sold 96 of the 115 units at 230-unit Perfect Ten that were released previously for a total sales value of about S$285 million.

site_title: Singapore residential real estate: It’s more than timing the market
summary: Singapore's private residential property market is experiencing a frothy market, driven by pent-up demand, low interest rates, and labor market tightness. Despite recent cooling measures, including a higher medium-term stress test interest rate and reduced loan-to-value limits, the market is expected to moderate but remain healthy in the long term. Home prices are expected to rise 9% in 2022 and 1-3% in 2023. Owner-occupiers should prioritize needs-based considerations, while investors can benefit from national policies and long-term capital appreciation. The market is expected to experience a bumpy ride ahead, with primary home sales moderating and resale transactions softening, but overall, the property market is expected to remain sanguine.

images.alt_text: AMO Residence is the first notable launch in the Outside Central Region (OCR) this year, as well as the first major project in Ang Mo Kio in over eight years.
Lentor Modern is the largest private non-landed residential launch in 2022, said Huttons Asia.
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok. Close to 75 per cent of its residential units were sold on the first day of the project's launch.

site_title: Baldwin settles with slain 'Rust' cinematographer's family
summary: Alec Baldwin has reached a civil settlement with the family of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, who was fatally shot by Baldwin on a film set in 2021. The settlement will dismiss the family's civil lawsuit against Baldwin and others, allowing filming of the movie "Rust" to resume in January with the original principal players. Matthew Hutchins, Halyna's husband and a lawyer, stated that they believe the death was a "terrible accident" and have no interest in assigning blame.

images.alt_text: Producers of Alec Baldwin film hire law firm for shooting probe

site_title: Businesses call for Hong Kong’s eased Covid-19 measures to be dropped entirely
summary: Hong Kong's eased Covid-19 measures have been met with criticism from businesses, who claim the new rules are not sufficient to attract visitors and are deterring them. The city's tourism sector is still struggling, with only 59,610 visitors in August, a far cry from pre-pandemic levels. Businesses are calling for the authorities to drop travel curbs entirely and for the borders with mainland China to reopen to boost the economy. Some travelers, like an Italian expatriate, are also expressing concerns about the relaxed rules, citing the need for frequent testing and the risk of quarantine.

images.alt_text: The new rules should make it more attractive for pilots and flight attendants based in the Asian financial hub to resume flying more frequently and will reduce enforced downtime after trips, making rostering more efficient.
Retail sales value dropped 0.1 per cent in August from a year ago, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department said on Friday (Sep 30).

site_title: Paris 2024 marathon to trace path of French Revolution
summary: The Paris 2024 marathon route has been unveiled, tracing the path of the 1789 Women's March on Versailles, a pivotal event in the French Revolution. The 42.195km course will start in central Paris, pass iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre Museum, and end in Versailles before returning to Paris. The marathon will be the first to salute women, with women concluding the athletics program a day after the men's event. The route is designed to celebrate women and inspire mass participation, with two mass events allowing non-Olympians to run the course.

site_title: Tokenisation of real estate – is it real estate securitisation 2.0?
summary: Real estate tokenisation, a process similar to securitisation, is being adopted in Singapore using blockchain technology. Fraxtor and other firms have tokenised redevelopment projects, allowing for fractional ownership and tradeable securities. However, the market's volatility and lack of liquidity may deter investors, and it's unclear if tokenisation will disrupt traditional real estate markets. The concept is seen as "Securitisation 2.0" by some, offering increased efficiency and reduced intermediaries, but it may not substitute the capital market in the short term. Accredited investors with financial buffers are allowed to invest in tokenised real estate, while retail investors face higher risks.

images.alt_text: Real estate blockchain firm Fraxtor obtains capital markets services licence from MAS
Investors snap up metaverse real estate in virtual land boom
Real estate tokenisation - what does it mean for investors?

site_title: Attracting and retaining office tenants in the post-pandemic world
summary: In the post-pandemic office market, corporate real estate professionals in Singapore prioritize quality over quantity, with 88% investing in better office space. The Marina Bay sub-market, featuring newer, high-quality, and green developments, has seen a tightened average vacancy rate of 3.6% by end Q2 2022. To attract and retain tenants, landlords should focus on providing flexible, amenity-rich spaces, health and wellness offerings, and modular designs. With 62% of respondents likely to adopt hybrid working by 2025, landlords who offer flexibility will gain an edge, while those providing tenant-tailored flex and amenity spaces can encourage long-term leases.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Citigroup Inc (Citi) logo is seen at the SIBOS banking and financial conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada October 19, 2017. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo
Luxe offices offer slides, nap pods, laundry, ball pits and streams of cold brew/

A future-fit office is one that incorporates quality spaces, sustainability and technology to elevate the workplace. Today, these elements come together to create a compelling offer for current and future employees, who will prioritise companies that align to their needs and values.

site_title: China, equities weigh as EM sees another month of outflows
summary: China's debt markets lost $1.4 billion in September, totaling $98.2 billion pulled out over eight months as investors shy away from a slowing economy. This marks the seventh consecutive month of foreign outflows from emerging market portfolios. Factory activity barely grew in September, and a slowdown in services sector growth points to further economic cooling. The economy is grappling with Covid-19 curbs and softening global demand.

images.alt_text: US president Donald Trump renewed his criticism of the Federal Reserve on Tuesday, describing the US central bank as a "problem" as he called for lower interest rates.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after rally in growth stocks falters
summary: Wall Street opened lower on October 5, 2022, due to weakness in growth and technology stocks. The Dow Jones fell 238.0 points, the S&P 500 dropped 37.7 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 153.7 points. This decline was sparked by rising Treasury yields, which were influenced by data showing resilient labor demand despite rising interest rates.

site_title: Facebook asks users for more help improving its algorithms
summary: Facebook is seeking user feedback to improve its algorithm and show users posts from others they don't follow. Users will see "show more" and "show less" buttons on posts in their feed, allowing them to directly influence the content they see. This feedback will be used to temporarily alter the types of content displayed and improve "discovery" across Facebook's apps, a key focus for the company.

site_title: Are landed homes becoming a wealth preservation asset?
summary: The landed property market in Singapore is expected to continue at its current pace for the rest of 2022 due to global geopolitical uncertainties. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units, with the URA price index for landed homes potentially gaining 10% for the year. This follows a strong 2021, with over 3,000 transactions, driven by the pandemic's need for bigger living spaces.

images.alt_text: Rare freehold landed site in Orchard area expected to draw offers of over S$300m
Lee Hsien Yang and wife sell Caldecott bungalow for S$13m; list another for S$16.8m

One of the 3 bungalow properties along Nassim Road.




Copyright: Realstar Premier

site_title: US mortgage rates rise for seventh week to highest in 16 years
summary: US mortgage rates have surged 1.30 percentage points over the past seven weeks, reaching a 16-year high of 6.75%, amid the Federal Reserve's inflation fight. This marks the seventh-straight weekly increase, resulting in a 14% slump in home loan applications and the lowest level since 2015.

site_title: US service sector growth solid in September; price pressures easing: ISM survey
summary: The US services industry slowed modestly in September, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) reporting a non-manufacturing PMI of 56.7, down from 56.9 in August. Employment surged, while prices paid by businesses for inputs fell to a 1.5-year low, suggesting underlying economic strength despite rising interest rates. The economy is slowing due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: A shift in consumer spending patterns that favours services and experiences – and comes at the expense of merchandise – is helping temper demand for products made overseas.

site_title: Oil rises to 3-week highs as Opec+ agrees to deep cuts, US stockpiles fall
summary: Oil prices rose to three-week highs, with Brent crude reaching $93.37 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude reaching $87.76 a barrel, after Opec+ agreed to its deepest cuts to production since 2020, totaling 2 million barrels per day. The cuts aim to alleviate concerns of a global economic recession and rising interest rates. However, the impact of the cuts may be limited due to production shortfalls by some Opec+ members. US stockpiles fell, with crude inventories drawing 1.4 million barrels and petrol stocks falling 4.7 million barrels.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled at US$91.80 a barrel, up US$2.94, or 3.3 per cent on Tuesday..
Brent crude futures for December delivery rose US$3.72 to US$88.86 a barrel, a 4.4 per cent gain.

site_title: Investment potential of executive condominiums
summary: Executive condominiums (ECs) in Singapore remain highly sought after due to their affordability and investment potential. The supply of new ECs is limited, with most units either sold out or having only a handful left. ECs are priced 20-30% lower than private condominiums, making them attractive to HDB upgraders. Resale ECs have also gained popularity among local and foreign tenants, driven by the widening price gap between condominiums and ECs.

images.alt_text: Spanning a land area of 16,623.7 square metres (sq m), the site can yield a maximum gross floor area of 49,872 sqm with a maximum building height of 60 metres Singapore height datum.

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

site_title: Swift sets out blueprint for central bank digital currency network
summary: Swift has outlined a blueprint for a global central bank digital currency (CBDC) network following an 8-month experiment. The trial involved France and Germany's national central banks, global lenders, and tested international CBDC use and conversion to fiat money. Around 90% of the world's central banks are exploring CBDCs, with Swift's main advantage being its existing network connecting over 11,500 banks and funds in 200 countries. The goal is to create a fast, efficient, and widely accessible CBDC system.

site_title: World Bank says goal of ending extreme poverty by 2030 unlikely to be met
summary: The World Bank reports that the goal of ending extreme poverty by 2030 is unlikely to be met due to the Covid-19 pandemic and ongoing war in Ukraine. The pandemic reversed decades of poverty reduction, with 71 million more people living in extreme poverty in 2020. An estimated 574 million people, or 7% of the world's population, would still be in extreme poverty by 2030, mostly in Africa. The World Bank calls for major policy changes, including boosting growth, cooperation, and adopting measures like property taxes and carbon taxes, to help jumpstart efforts to eradicate poverty.

site_title: Bank of England explains rejected offers at gilt buy-backs
summary: The Bank of England explained its rejection of offers at its gilt buy-back auctions, stating its purchases are subject to a reserve price not disclosed before the auction. The central bank aims to ensure financial stability, not cap yields, and allocates offers based on the spread between the offered yield and market mid-yields, with rejected offers below its reserve spread. The BoE bought less than £4 billion out of a potential £25 billion in the first five auctions, with 30-year yields creeping up to almost 4.2%.

images.alt_text: The United Kingdom's pensions industry has had a mentality that the risks lay largely in the direction of lower bond yields, but higher yields can bring their own problems.

site_title: Bertozzi, Meldal and Sharpless win 2022 Nobel Prize in Chemistry
summary: Carolyn Bertozzi, Barry Sharpless, and Morten Meldal were awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for their development of click chemistry and bioorthogonal chemistry, laying the foundation for a more functional form of chemistry. The prize, worth $915,072, was awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences on October 5, 2022, recognizing the trio's work in creating new tools to build molecules, aiding in the development of new drugs and plastics. The prize follows those for medicine and physics announced earlier in the week.

images.alt_text: Anna Wedell, a member of the Nobel Committee for Physiology or Medicine, explains the research field of Svante Paabo, the winner of the 2022 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine,  in Stockholm, Sweden, on Monday (Oct 3).

site_title: Amid Ukraine war, US set to fly Russian cosmonaut to ISS
summary: The US is set to launch a Russian cosmonaut, Anna Kikina, to the International Space Station (ISS) aboard a SpaceX ship, marking a symbolic gesture amid the Ukraine war. Kikina, the only female cosmonaut in service, will join an American and Japanese crew on a six-month expedition. The mission is part of a long-planned astronaut exchange program that has continued despite rising tensions between the US and Russia. The ISS relies on joint cooperation between the two countries for its operation, with the US providing power and life support and Russia maintaining orbit.

images.alt_text: The Artemis 1 space mission hopes to test the SLS as well as the unmanned Orion capsule that sits atop it, in preparation for future Moon-bound journeys with humans aboard.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows for a fifth month to smallest in a year
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed for a fifth month in August, shrinking to $67.4 billion, its smallest in over a year. A shift in consumer spending patterns favoring services and experiences has reduced demand for overseas-made products. The value of imports fell 1.1% to $326.3 billion, while exports eased 0.3% to $258.9 billion. The decline in imports is expected to support economic growth in the third quarter.

site_title: Opec+ agrees on 2 million-barrel-a-day cut to output limit
summary: OPEC+ agreed to cut its collective output limit by 2 million barrels per day, the largest reduction since 2020, to combat a weakening global economy and halt declining oil prices. However, the actual impact will be smaller due to several member countries already pumping below their quotas. The move risks adding to global economic woes and may irk the US, potentially triggering a response from Washington.

images.alt_text: Brent crude for November rose 65 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to US$92 a barrel on Monday, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) for October was up 62 cents to US$85.73 per barrel, or 0.7 per cent.

site_title: Europe's gas crisis set to deepen after winter drains reserves
summary: Europe's natural gas reserves are filled to around 90% capacity after Russia cut supplies due to Western sanctions. However, the EU faces a deeper energy crisis next year, with storage needs expected to drop to 25-30% by February or March. The International Energy Agency warns that Europe will "survive the coming winter with just some bruises" but predicts a more challenging winter in 2023. The EU is considering a price cap to tackle high gas prices, but is divided on the issue, with some countries opposing it as it could make securing supplies harder.

images.alt_text: Pipes at the landfall facilities of the Nord Stream gas pipeline in Germany. Russia is suspected of having attacked the pipeline.

site_title: No signs of cooling for the rental market in 2022
summary: The Singapore rental market experienced a significant surge in 2022, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) Rental Index of Private Residential Properties jumping 9.9% in 2021 and 11.2% in the first six months of 2022, reaching an all-time high of 127. This marks a reversal of the 2014-2020 tenant's market, where landlords were calling the shots. Experts predict rents may increase by up to 10% in the second half of 2022, further solidifying the landlord-dominated market.

images.alt_text: OrangeTee & Tie's Christine Sun thinks overall condo and HDB rental prices may either continue rising or remain at current levels in the coming months.
Rental volumes also rose month on month for condos and HDB flats, but were lower year on year and when compared to the average 5-year volumes for July.
Only 2 of the top 5 non-landed projects with the most leasing transactions in Q2 were in the Core Central Region (CCR), noted Savills.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund gets almost US$18b demand for debut green bonds
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has received over $17.85 billion in demand for its debut green bonds, the first of its kind by a sovereign wealth fund. The bonds, including a 100-year tranche, will raise approximately $500 million and are expected to close later this week. The deal is part of PIF's efforts to diversify the Saudi economy away from oil, with plans to invest over $10 billion in green projects by 2026. The issuance of green bonds has accelerated globally, with issuance jumping from $2.3 billion in 2012 to $511.5 billion last year.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia – one of the world’s largest oil exporters – seeks to increase the role that environmental, social and governance principles play in its investments.

site_title: Chaswood Resources kills proposed RTO, explores voluntary delisting
summary: Chaswood Resources has killed its proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal with HK Aerospace Beidou New Energy Technology due to COVID-19 movement restrictions in China. The company, citing the difficulties in due diligence and restructuring, will instead explore voluntary delisting options by proposing exit offers to major shareholders. The RTO costs incurred by the vendor will not impact Chaswood's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the fiscal year 2022. Trading of Chaswood shares has been suspended since 2018.

site_title: UK finance minister to meet banks after market chaos
summary: UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng is set to meet major high street banks, including Barclays, Lloyds Banking Group, and NatWest, amid market turmoil following his mini-budget. The meeting, planned for Thursday, aims to "quiz lenders on their plans" as mortgage rates surge, with average two-year fixed rates reaching 6.07% and five-year rates rising to 5.97%. The budget led to wild swings in sterling funding markets, causing investors to fret over government funding plans, resulting in record 935 mortgage products being pulled overnight.

site_title: Philippines' Marcos open to buying Russian fuel, proposes new Myanmar approach
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is open to buying fuel from Russia due to rising global energy prices, despite pressure from Western allies to shun Moscow. Marcos also plans to engage the Myanmar military government directly to promote regional peace, potentially involving dialogue with the junta. This approach contrasts with Asean's previous stance, which has barred the junta from regional summits due to its failure to implement a peace plan. Marcos aims to propose concrete proposals for dialogue at the upcoming Asean meeting in November.

images.alt_text: Philippine's e September inflation rate, which was above the 6.7 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll, was driven mainly by high food and utility prices and brought the average rate in the nine months to September to 5.1 per cent.

site_title: Asti shareholder could make exit offer as the company heads for delisting
summary: Asti Holdings, a Singapore-based chip manufacturing services company, announced that a substantial shareholder has expressed interest in making an exit offer to other shareholders, potentially leading to the company's delisting. The potential offeror has not yet appointed advisors and is finalizing the details of the offer. Asti Holdings had previously stated it would be delisted from the Catalist board due to failing to exit the watch list, with trading suspended since July. The outcome of the potential exit offer is uncertain.

site_title: IMF says wage-price spirals are rare, but rate hikes needed to quell inflation expectations
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has found that wage-price spirals, where wages and prices rise together, are rare in advanced economies. Research on 22 episodes of high inflation and falling real wages over the past 50 years shows most subsided quickly. Recent sharp interest rate hikes by central banks are likely to help prevent high inflation expectations from becoming entrenched. The IMF notes that wage and price dynamics in 2020-2021 were driven by pandemic shocks, unlike past episodes, and that past inflationary episodes usually ended when nominal wages caught up with prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund logo is seen at IMF headquarters in Washington, U.S., October 14, 2017. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam requests Netflix remove K-drama over war ‘distortion’
summary: Vietnam has requested Netflix remove its K-drama series "Little Women" due to alleged distortions of the Vietnam War, claiming the show glorified the actions of South Korean mercenaries and denied the nation's revolutionary achievements. The series, which aired in episode eight, mentioned a high "kill-to-death ratio" between South Korean troops and the Viet Cong. Netflix has previously removed content from the platform in Vietnam over similar complaints, with the streaming service yet to respond to the latest request.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined seasonally in August, but still grew year-on-year, with most categories experiencing growth except for supermarkets, motor vehicles, and mini-marts. Startup funding in Singapore increased 54% to $8.18 billion in H1, driven by venture investments. Sembmarine secured a $3.1 billion contract from Petrobras. The government is tracking the economic impact of grant projects through indicators such as skilled jobs creation and committed value-add.

site_title: Some UK property funds defer investor withdrawals
summary: Some of Britain's top open-ended property funds are introducing measures to manage investor exit requests amid a sell-off in UK risk assets. Columbia Threadneedle and Schroders have delayed paying out redemptions from their UK real estate funds due to liquidity constraints and market volatility. The funds are opting for monthly exit requests instead of daily, with some rescheduling payments until July. This move aims to maintain liquidity and manage committed capital expenditure requirements.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view is seen of the London skyline from Canary Wharf in London, Britain, October 19, 2016. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Qatar finally frees up hotel booking ahead of World Cup 2022
summary: Qatar has released thousands of hotel rooms previously blocked off for the 2022 World Cup to the public, bringing the total available rooms to over 117,000, including purpose-built housing, tents, and cruise ships. The move comes as the tournament is set to start on November 20, with occupancy expected to reach 90% or higher at participating hotels. Despite some hotels still under construction, the availability of rooms is easing concerns about accommodation for fans and visitors.

images.alt_text: The 80,000 capacity Lusail Iconic Stadium was full for the game in which Al Hilal beat Egyptians Zamalek on penalties after a 1-1 draw.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic pulls out of Hong Kong, closes offices
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways is pulling out of Hong Kong, cancelling flights and closing its offices after 30 years. The decision was made due to significant operational complexities caused by the ongoing Russian airspace closure and the impact on flight times. The airline, citing factors including Virgin Australia's previous service cancellations, will impact around 46 jobs. Passengers booked for March 2023 will receive a refund, voucher, or option to rebook on an alternative route. This marks the first major airline to pull out of Hong Kong since American Airlines Group in late 2022.

images.alt_text: A Virgin Atlantic Airbus A330 passenger plane is seen above a hotel coming in to land at London Heathrow Airport in west London on February 14, 2021. - A new 10-day hotel quarantine regime for travellers arriving in the UK from 33 coronavirus variant hotspots begins on February 15, despite concern from the country's busiest airport Heathrow that "significant gaps" remain in the plans. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: M&G Real Estate buys Japan office building for US$700 million
summary: M&G Real Estate has acquired the 21-story Minato Mirai Center Building in Yokohama's business district for over $700 million. The property, located in Japan's second-largest working population area, is now the largest asset in M&G Asia Property Fund. The acquisition is part of investors' bets on Japanese workers returning to offices as the pandemic wanes, with office investment values increasing by 20.5% in Tokyo's second quarter.

site_title: US private payrolls increase in September: ADP
summary: US private payrolls rose by 208,000 jobs in September, according to the ADP National Employment report. This increase suggests demand for workers remains strong despite rising interest rates and tighter financial conditions. The report, which resumed publishing after a two-month hiatus, was developed jointly with the Stanford Digital Economy Lab. Economists forecast private payrolls likely increased by 270,000 jobs in September, with overall nonfarm payrolls gains expected to be 250,000.

site_title: WTO slashes forecast for merchandise trade growth in 2023
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has slashed its forecast for merchandise trade growth in 2023 to 1%, citing multiple shocks including the Russia-Ukraine war, high energy costs, and US monetary policy tightening. This marks a significant deceleration from last year's 9.7% growth. The WTO warns that poor nations may suffer from food insecurity and debt distress due to growing import bills for fuels, food, and fertilizers. Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala cautioned against retrenching global supply chains, which would worsen inflationary pressures and slow economic growth.

images.alt_text: The World Trade Organization said on Tuesday(Aug 23) that its global goods barometer was stable, pointing to stagnant global trade growth following a Covid-19 triggered slowdown.

site_title: MAS launches ESG Impact Hub to drive collaboration between stakeholders
summary: MAS launches ESG Impact Hub to drive collaboration between stakeholders, aiming to address ESG data problems through technology. The hub, located in Singapore, will facilitate ESG initiatives, such as accelerator programmes and training workshops, among industry players. MAS managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the need for collaboration to solve real-world ESG challenges. The hub is anchored by sustainability initiatives, including the Point Carbon Zero Programme and KPMG's ESG Business Foundry, and will serve as a launchpad for public-private partnerships supporting Asia's low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Demonstrating a commitment to sustainability driven by ESG factors creates value for businesses in a variety of ways, from internal cost reductions to improved stakeholder relationships.

site_title: CBRE joins other UK property funds in deferring payments
summary: CBRE Investment Management has deferred redemption payments on its UK property fund due to challenging market conditions and liquidity mismatch. The decision, made to avert a cash crunch, follows sharp rises in interest rates this year, encouraging institutional investors to switch out of property funds. Several other funds, including those managed by Columbia Threadneedle, Schroders, and BlackRock, have also taken similar steps. This move aims to protect investors' interests in the best interest of the fund.

site_title: Japan to curb electricity costs amid weak yen, recession risks, PM says
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announces the government will compile another economic stimulus plan by the end of October to curb rising electricity bills amid a weak yen, fueling inflation and recession fears. The plan may include direct measures to ease electricity price hikes, such as cash payouts and subsidies to utility firms, marking "unprecedented" measures to support households and businesses.

images.alt_text: Fumio Kishida, Prime Minister of Japan, says: “From Oct 11, Japan will relax border control measures to be on par with the US, as well as resume visa-free travel and individual travel.”

site_title: Making workplaces safer with behavioural science and digital tech
summary: A recent surge in workplace deaths in Singapore has prompted the government to introduce measures to stem accidents, including a new code of practice on workplace safety and health. Behavioural science and digital technology are being used to shape safety behaviour beyond traditional carrot-and-stick approaches. This includes using data from "safety wearables" to identify high-risk situations and deliver timely reminders, as well as personalizing safety messages to reduce optimism bias. The goal is to create a culture of wariness and empower workers to report unsafe conditions anonymously, with the aim of reducing workplace accidents and improving safety.

images.alt_text: The new regulations come after a spate of workplace fatalities. In 2022, there have been 27 workplace deaths so far.
Worksite safety issues and dengue outbreaks have impacted the productivity of construction companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher after overnight Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.33 points or 0.46% to 3,153.23 points, with only 5 stocks in the red. Banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS jumped 1.3%, 0.5%, and 0.1% respectively, after local banks raised mortgage rates. CLSA stated that banks are the only clear sector beneficiary of the Fed's rate hikes. The regional markets performed well, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closing 5.9% higher.

site_title: Axiata’s tower arm Edotco weighing US$700m financing, sources say
summary: Edotco, the wireless tower business of Malaysian telecommunications group Axiata Group, is considering raising up to $700 million in loans to fund capital expenditures and overseas expansion. The financing would be used to support the company's portfolio of over 54,000 towers across nine Asian nations. Discussions with banks are preliminary, and the company could still decide against taking out the loans. This move is seen as an alternative to a potential equity offering that was previously discussed, which would have raised up to $600 million.

site_title: Lawmakers press US Commerce for tougher checks on semiconductor chip subsidies
summary: US lawmakers urge the Commerce Department to implement stricter controls on government subsidies for semiconductor chip manufacturing, citing concerns that funds may be used for stock buybacks rather than expanding domestic production. The Commerce Department aims to begin accepting applications for $39 billion in subsidies by February, with a focus on companies that commit to future investments in the US industry. Lawmakers request additional protections and guidance to ensure funds are used for intended purposes, and may require companies to attest that they will not engage in buybacks for a set period.

site_title: Spot prices for LNG double between January and August: MTI
summary: Spot prices for liquefied natural gas (LNG) in Singapore more than doubled between January and August 2022, tripling from the previous year, according to Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong. LNG prices tripled in August alone, while piped natural gas (PNG) prices increased by 21% and LNG prices under long-term contracts rose by 38% during the same period. The minister attributed the price increases to global energy price rises, which will flow into Singapore's electricity prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An LNG tanker passes boats along the coast of Singapore February 3, 2017. REUTERS/Gloystein Henning/File Photo##########udlng##########
A vessel docks along the Shell Petroleum refineries on Pulau Bukom in Singapore; June 2022.
The patchwork shipments mix supplies of LNG that are left over after partial deliveries from hubs like Australia and Oman to customers in North-east Asia.

site_title: UK business activity slides in Sep by most since early 2021: PMI
summary: The UK business activity slid to its lowest reading since January 2021, with the S&P Global UK Composite PMI falling to 49.1 in September from 49.6 in August. This contraction was the sharpest since early last year, driven by concerns over falling disposable income and a weaker global economy. The services sector PMI stagnated at 50.0, while new orders declined due to Brexit and subdued confidence. Inflation pressure remained high, with businesses reporting unavoidable price increases due to rising wages, energy, and supplies.

site_title: STB inks sustainability, expansion MoUs to grow Singapore’s Mice industry
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has signed three memoranda of understanding (MoUs) with key meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (Mice) players to support sustainability efforts and expand their presence in Singapore and South-east Asia. The Global Mice Sustainability Alliance aims to reduce exhibition waste and carbon footprint, setting sustainability targets within six months and trialing green initiatives at Food and Hotel Asia-Food & Beverage 2024. The signing underscores confidence in Singapore as a preferred destination for Mice events and a launchpad for international expansion.

images.alt_text: Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez (left) leads at the start of the Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sunday.
Singapore hosted more than 150 events attended by more than 37,000 people in the first 3 months of 2022.
STB to focus on business tourism as part of strategy to recapture tourism demand

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 11.19 points to 1,420.55. A total of 3.234 billion lots worth RM1.720 billion changed hands, with 518 gainers and 350 losers.

site_title: Rhinoceros horns worth S$1.2m recovered at Changi Airport in largest seizure to date
summary: Singapore authorities have intercepted the largest seizure of rhinoceros horns in the country's history, weighing 34kg and valued at S$1.2 million. The horns were discovered in transit baggage at Changi Airport, bound for Laos, and the owner was arrested. The seizure is in line with Singapore's zero-tolerance stance on illegal wildlife trade, and the horns will be destroyed to prevent re-entry into the market and disrupt the global supply chain.

site_title: NCS, IMDA to support 1,600 tech jobs in the next two years
summary: NCS, a Singtel subsidiary, has partnered with IMDA to support 1,600 tech jobs and training opportunities for polytechnic, ITE, and university graduates over the next two years. The Fusion programme will hire and train 400 polytechnic graduates and support 400 ITE graduates in a part-time work and study arrangement. The initiatives will provide work and study opportunities to 1,600 graduates, with the total number of tech jobs and training opportunities offered by NCS reaching 1,600.

images.alt_text: Staff at major banks and some of the world's biggest technology giants are increasingly leaving for fintech startups, new analysis shows.
The new hires would fill up roles such as data scientist, software engineer and others by the end of the year.
Singapore's agri-tech sector will add 4,700 jobs by 2030; new scheme launched to retrain mid-career workers for industry

site_title: Mizuho to buy 20% of Rakuten Securities for 80 billion yen: Nikkei
summary: Mizuho Financial Group is set to acquire around 20% of Rakuten Securities for approximately 80 billion yen (S$788 million). The deal, expected to close in November, could give Mizuho an opportunity to boost its digital business. Rakuten has outlined plans to raise capital by listing its securities and banking units, following losses in its wireless carrier business. This move follows a similar investment by Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in SBI Holdings earlier this year.

site_title: Biden says US willing to hold talks with South Korea on EV subsidy: Yonhap
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed willingness to hold talks with South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on the recent measure denying subsidies to automakers not assembling electric vehicles in North America. The Inflation Reduction Act, signed into law in August, requires EVs assembled in North America to qualify for US tax credits, excluding Hyundai Motor and Kia. Biden's assurance came in response to Yoon's request for help in addressing concerns that the new US rules would hurt South Korea's automakers. Talks are expected to address the issue and its impact on the automotive industry.

site_title: Apac hotels making slower recovery than in US and Europe, says study
summary: The Asia-Pacific hotel market is recovering more slowly than its US and European counterparts, according to a Deutsche Bank study. Hotel occupancies have bounced back with easing of domestic travel, but revenue per available room remains subdued at 50-60% of 2019 levels. Stricter border restrictions, high travel expenses, and visa requirements are major factors behind the lag. DWS estimates it may take 6-12 months for cross-border travel to pick up. Despite this, the market is expected to recover by 2026, driven by the return of Chinese outbound travelers.

images.alt_text: Arrivals will still need to monitor their health for a 7-day period and take rapid tests, but tourists will be allowed to return.
Thailand has seen a rush of tourists in recent months after the nation scrapped all travel restrictions in July.
Kyoto, one of the biggest beneficiaries of the tourism boom, is now anticipating a rebound in visitor traffic.
While hotels' average room rate in August fell 3.7 per cent from July, it was 62.7 per cent higher than the corresponding period in the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia ratifies trans-Pacific trade pact
summary: Malaysia's Cabinet has agreed to ratify the Comprehensive And Progressive Agreement For Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a free trade agreement linking 11 countries, including Canada, Australia, and Japan. The pact removes 95% of tariffs, elevating Malaysia's competitiveness in the global arena, according to the trade ministry. This move is expected to strategically position Malaysia in the global market.

site_title: Eurozone unlikely to avoid recession as downturn deepens: PMI
summary: The eurozone's business activity has dropped to a 20-month low of 48.1 in September, indicating a likely recession, according to a survey by S&P Global. The steepening decline in business activity and rising energy costs have led to a worsening economic downturn and elevated inflation, prompting the European Central Bank to consider further interest rate hikes. The ECB has already raised rates by 75 basis points, and policymakers face an increasing risk of a hard landing as they seek to curb inflation.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel hits three-month low in aftermath of Optus cyberattack
summary: Singtel's share price has touched its lowest point in three months after the Australian subsidiary Optus continued to grapple with the impact of a cyberattack. The telecommunications giant announced the appointment of Deloitte to undertake an independent review of Optus' cybersecurity systems, leading to a 2.3% decline in its share price. Optus confirmed the cyberattack resulted in the leak of 2.1 million customers' personal identification data. The incident is expected to have financial implications for Singtel, which is evaluating the potential costs.

images.alt_text: Singtel said its Australian subisdiary Optus is working closely with identity document-issuing authorities to determine the appropriate next steps for its customers.

Optus must pay the cost of replacing the passports and drivers' licences of millions of customers whose personal information was stolen in one of the country’s biggest data breaches, the Australian government said on Thursday.
The government blamed Singtel-owned Optus for the breach, which affected 10 million accounts, and urged the company to speed up its notification to the 10,200 affected customers.

The group’s Q1 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) fell 2 per cent to S$977 million from S$997 million, while operating revenue for the quarter slipped 5.6 per cent from S$3.8 billion to S$3.6 billion in Q1 2022.

site_title: Indonesia president says Fifa boss offered help to fix country’s football issues
summary: Indonesia President Joko Widodo said FIFA offered to help address the country's football issues after a deadly stadium stampede killed at least 131 people, including 33 minors. The disaster occurred when police fired tear gas to disperse agitated supporters of the losing side, leading to a crush. Widodo ordered a full audit of stadia to ensure safety and security protocols. FIFA has asked Indonesia's football federation for a full report and has offered support to help fix the country's football management.

images.alt_text: People attend a memorial remembering victims of the football match riot and stampede in Denpasar, Bali, Indonesia on Oct 2, 2022.
Indonesia announced that at least 130 people were killed and 180 others were injured after Indonesian soccer fans entered the pitch causing panic and stampede on Oct 1.

site_title: US dollar rebounds as global market rally fades
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.64% to 110.87, rebounding from a 1.3% drop the previous day, as investors lost enthusiasm for risk-friendlier currencies and stocks. The dollar's rally was fueled by hopes that the US Federal Reserve will slow down interest rate hikes, with recent data showing the US economy is slowing down. The euro fell 0.67% and sterling dropped 1.08% against the dollar, while the yen declined 0.14%. Investors remain cautious ahead of Friday's US labor data, which could influence the Fed's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one dollar banknotes are seen in front of displayed stock graph in this illustration taken February 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Motorcycle COE premiums hit S$11,751, all-time high for second tender in a row; other categories down
summary: Motorcycle COE premiums reached a new record high of S$11,751, a 1.4% increase, for the second consecutive tender. All other COE categories saw a decrease, with car premiums down 4.2%, and commercial vehicle premiums down 1.5%. The open category COE price decreased by 2.1% to S$105,001. The price hikes are attributed to high demand and limited supply of motorcycles.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rocket on rate hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 5.90% on Wednesday, October 5, 2022, driven by a global rally fueled by easing concerns about central bank interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index reached 18,087.97, surpassing a six-per-cent gain at one point. Mainland Chinese markets remain closed for a national holiday, contributing to the surge.

images.alt_text: The flags of China, right, and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) fly near an electronic screen displaying the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, March 15, 2022. Chinese stocks suffered another deep selloff on Tuesday as concerns about the country’s ties with Russia and persistent regulatory pressure sent shares on a downward spiral. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai economy seen up 3.0 to 3.5% this year: finance minister
summary: Thailand's economy is forecast to grow 3.0-3.5% this year, driven by a weak baht aiding exports, despite supply chain issues affecting the automobile and electronics sectors. Headline inflation was less than expected in September, but consumer prices remain above target, leading to expectations of another interest rate hike by the central bank in November.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop after surging
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Wednesday, October 5, 2022, after a surge on hopes of less aggressive interest rate hikes. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.5% to 7,053.17 points, while the DAX index in the eurozone dropped 0.4% to 12,624.61 points. The Paris CAC 40 lost 0.6% to 6,006.55 points. The decline was attributed to a drag from bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Singapore hawker fare hits the Big Apple
summary: Singapore street food has gained a following in New York with the opening of Urban Hawker, a Singapore-style hawker market in midtown Manhattan. The market features popular dishes such as chicken rice, chilli crab, and laksa, which have been enjoyed by food lovers in the Big Apple for some time due to the city's increasingly diverse population and adventurous palates. This marks a significant impact of Singapore street food on the international scene, with enterprising Singaporeans building steady businesses serving authentic hawker favorites in New York.

site_title: Rate hike bonanza among major central banks hits two decade peak in September
summary: Major developed central banks delivered a record 550 basis points of interest rate hikes in September, the largest in two decades, to combat multi-decade high inflation. The Federal Reserve hiked rates by 75 basis points for the third consecutive time, while the Bank of England and European Central Bank also raised rates. However, some central banks, such as Norway and Australia, signaled a potential slowdown in rate hikes. Emerging market central banks also delivered significant rate hikes, with ten out of 18 central banks raising rates by 600 basis points in September.

images.alt_text: The peso closed at a record 59 to the greenback on Monday, taking its year-to-date decline to 13 per cent, the most in South-east Asia.
The Reserve Bank of Australia raised its cash rate to a nine-year peak of 2.60 per cent, the sixth hike in as many months which included four outsized moves of 50 basis points..

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher on hints of cooling economy
summary: South Korean stocks ended 0.26% higher, with the Kospi rising 5.84 points to 2,215.22, driven by gains in chipmakers and electric-vehicle battery manufacturers, as investors speculated a slower pace of monetary policy tightening globally. A weaker US manufacturing data and smaller-than-expected interest rate hike by the Australian central bank contributed to the optimism. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose, while automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia fell.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 53.89 points or 2.5 per cent at 2,209.38.

site_title: Straits Trading eyeing strategic partnerships, continued diversification
summary: Straits Trading, a Singapore-based investment firm, is diversifying its investments across various sectors, including resources, property, and hospitality, to drive sustainable growth. The company's CEO Eric Teng revealed a three-pronged strategy of entering familiar markets, taking on risk-adjusted investments, and partnerships. Straits Trading's efforts have paid off, with a net profit of $673 million in the first half of 2022, up from $122.6 million in the previous year. The company targets returns of at least 10% over five to seven years and has formed partnerships with notable groups such as Far East Orchard and Nikko.

images.alt_text: Eric Teng, chief executive of Straits Development, will speak to The Business Times senior correspondent Ben Paul in a webinar on Oct 5.
Private housing, landed properties and condominiums as viewed from Blk 13A Bedok South Road on Feb 8, 2022.

site_title: Fintech unicorn Xendit cuts 5% of staff in Indonesia, Philippines
summary: Xendit, a fintech unicorn in South-east Asia, has cut 5% of its staff in Indonesia and the Philippines amid macroeconomic uncertainty.
