The affected employees will receive proper compensation and additional benefits. The company, which helps businesses process payments from various methods, had over 900 employees and saw its annualized transactions grow to 200 million and total payment value rise to $15 billion last year. This move follows several tech companies, including Shopee and foodpanda, laying off employees to conserve cash.

site_title: Equitable loss-sharing framework for scams taking ‘longer than expected’: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore is taking longer than expected to publish an equitable loss-sharing framework for financial scams. The framework aims to determine how different stakeholders share responsibility for scams and provide incentives for vigilance. The MAS had initially aimed to publish the framework within three months of February 2022 but is now working at a "very urgent pace" to seek public consultation as soon as possible. The framework was proposed after a scam resulted in the loss of S$13.7 million to scammers, and the MAS has proposed a draft set of responsibilities for financial institutions and consumers.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) building located along Shenton Way, taken on 20 April 2020.
Banks, customers to share scam losses; framework to seek views: Wong
MAS to draw up framework for 'equitable' sharing of scam losses

site_title: Asia-Pacific venture capital set for softer returns, but could outshine other regions
summary: Asia-Pacific venture capital funds are expected to post annualized returns of 16% from 2021 to 2027, lower than the 23.8% returns from 2018 to 2021. Despite softer returns, the region is still a bright spot globally due to favorable demographics and growth expectations. Preqin forecasts Asia-Pacific VC funds to outshine other regions, with assets under management expected to grow to $4.2 trillion by 2027. However, the firm notes that a sustained challenging macroeconomic outlook may pose a material downside risk to its view.

images.alt_text: money, burn, dollar
The startup funding party has ended with the onset of tough macroeconomic conditions
Blackstone headquarters in New York. Private market investors may have to tamp down expectations of returns going forward.

site_title: Taiwan vows to protect its firms’ interests at US-led ‘Chip 4’ group
summary: Taiwan has pledged to protect its firms' interests in the US-led "Chip 4" group, aiming to safeguard supply chain resilience. The group, which includes Taiwan, the US, South Korea, and Japan, was established amid a global semiconductor shortage. Taiwan Deputy Economy Minister Chen Chern-chyi stated that chipmaking requires collaboration to ensure a resilient supply chain, and Taiwan will use the platform to safeguard its companies' interests. The move comes as Taiwan seeks to counter China's growing influence in the region and amid US efforts to reduce reliance on Asian semiconductor manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The global chip shortage, which over the past 2 years has wreaked havoc on supply chains and forced automakers to halt production.
Micron’s commitment comes after the US government passed the CHIPS and Science Act in August, providing US$52 billion to boost domestic semiconductor research and development.

site_title: Canon to build 50b yen plant for key chip equipment
summary: Canon plans to build a 50 billion yen ($490 million) plant in Japan to expand its lithography machine production. Construction will begin in 2023 and the plant will start operation in 2025, potentially also producing next-generation chipmaking equipment. The move signals enduring demand for older chip technology, as Canon's machines can only make chips up to 130 nanometres, a technology from over 20 years ago.

site_title: Australia: Banks lift shares to near three-week high
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.7% higher at 6,815.7 on October 5, with major banks leading gains. The Reserve Bank of Australia's smaller-than-expected interest rate hike boosted market sentiment, and hopes for a potential pivot by the US Federal Reserve provided further support. Financials rose 2.3% to a three-week high, while miners and technology stocks also gained ground.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 1.76 per cent at 6,815.5 points, as of 0001 GMT on Wednesday.

site_title: Credit Suisse loses Asia deputy wealth head as departures mount
summary: Credit Suisse's deputy wealth management head for Asia, Young Jin Yee, is leaving the bank after about two decades, following a wave of departures. This is part of the bank's larger talent exodus in Asia, with five private bankers leaving its Hong Kong operations and two others departing last month. The bank is due to unveil a strategic review on October 27, which may include a large-scale investment-banking retreat. Credit Suisse's near-record low share price and erosion of talent in Asia have raised concerns about the bank's financial health.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse’s market capitalisation has dropped to around 10.4 billion Swiss francs, meaning any share sale would be highly dilutive to longtime holders.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end moderately higher
summary: Tokyo shares ended moderately higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.48% to 27,120.53, driven by global rallies. However, gains remained limited as investors sought new cues. The broader Topix index also rose 0.32% to 1,912.92.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians reflected on an electronic stock board outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 9, 2017. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 13% in August, extending July’s growth
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 13% in August, extending July's growth, but declined seasonally adjusted by 1.3%. The exception was supermarkets and hypermarkets, motor vehicles, and mini-marts and convenience stores. Most retail categories saw growth, with the wearing apparel and footwear category increasing 64.7% year-on-year. Economists expect retail sales to remain healthy due to the recovery of domestic consumption and international travel, with forecasts ranging from 8.5% to 10% growth for 2022.

images.alt_text: Meanwhile, food and beverage (F&B) services saw sales swell by 41.9 per cent from the previous year, extending the 59.1 per cent growth registered in June.
Dark clouds above Singapore's central business district. With growth slowing and inflation rising, tougher times may lie ahead.

site_title: Gold slips as dollar halts slide; markets await Fed clarity
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,722.69 per ounce, holding above the $1,700 mark, as the dollar stabilized after a 1.3% drop. Investors await clarity on the US Federal Reserve's future policy stance. A government survey showed a decline in US job openings, suggesting a cooling labor market. Gold is sensitive to rising US interest rates, which boost the dollar and increase the opportunity cost of holding the metal.

images.alt_text: Although gold is seen as a hedge against inflation, higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion that pays no interest.

site_title: The era of low interest rates may not be over
summary: The era of low interest rates may not be over, contrary to assertions from many commentators. The fundamental reasons for low interest rates, including a decline in investment demand driven by demographic and technological stagnation, remain unchanged. Investment spending is driven by growth and technological progress, which have lost momentum since the 1990s. While inflation has spiked in the past year and a half, it is likely to revert to pre-pandemic norms. As a result, the natural rate of interest, which matches saving with investment or promotes price stability, is unlikely to rise, suggesting that low interest rates may persist.

images.alt_text: As bonds become more attractive, investors may no longer need to reach for yield via higher-risk investments
Inflation in the Eurozone accelerated to 10 per cent in September, following Russia’s shutdown of crucial gas supplies as tensions soar over the Ukraine war.

site_title: Japan’s tourism restart stirs hope of service-sector recovery: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector activity growth expanded in September, driven by declining Covid-19 cases and easing restrictions on foreign tourism. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 52.2, returning to growth after a contraction in August. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to boost inbound tourism spending to over 5 trillion yen (S$49 billion) per year, citing the yen's recent fall to a 24-year low against the dollar. This move is seen as a step towards a stronger economic revival and service-sector recovery.

images.alt_text: Tokyo data is a leading indicator for nationwide inflation, and if gains are similar for the country overall, inflation could reach 3% in September.

site_title: EnterpriseSG eyes wealthy families as local startup funding jumps 54% in H1
summary: EnterpriseSG reports a 54% jump in venture funding to S$8.18 billion in the first half of 2022, driven by interest from wealthy family offices in Singapore. The agency aims to boost financing, talent development, and cross-border links, as Singapore continues to be a hub for venture capital flows in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: A shot of Singapore's central business district. Indonesia’s newly-minted tech billionaires are beginning to diversify their wealth and are increasingly looking to Singapore to set up family offices and seek new investment opportunities.

epa07757516 Chinese 100 yuan or renminbi (RMB) notes in Beijing, China, 05 August 2019. China's Yuan fell below the key level of seven to the US Dollar for the first time in eleven years, following the last week's US President Donald Trump's threat for more tariff on Chinese goods, according to media reports on 05 August 2019.  EPA-EFE/ROMAN PILIPEY

site_title: Asia’s biggest film festival back in top form in 2022
summary: The Busan International Film Festival, Asia's largest film festival, has returned to full power after the pandemic, with a red carpet event opening on October 5, 2022. Top Korean actors, Asian stars, and directors, including Tony Leung, are attending the festival, which will run until October 14. The festival comes after the success of South Korean films like "Parasite" and Netflix series "Squid Game," cementing the country's status as a global cultural powerhouse.

images.alt_text: epa10224082 A woman walks past a billboard promoting the 27th Busan International Film Festival (BIFF) in Busan, South Korea, 05 October 2022. The BIFF runs from 05 to 14 October 2022, with 353 films from 71 countries to be screened.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Musk’s everything app ‘X’ sounds a lot like China’s WeChat
summary: Elon Musk has teased the launch of "X, the everything app," which could resemble China's popular WeChat. The app is expected to be a comprehensive platform, offering a range of services including social media, messaging, payments, and more, similar to WeChat's mini-programmes. Musk has expressed admiration for WeChat's success and has hinted at making Twitter "radically better" through similar features. However, it's unclear if X will adopt WeChat's heavy censorship and moderation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says bottom is near for emerging market stocks
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts emerging market stocks, which have fallen 26% this year, are close to completing their bear-market cycle and will rally about 12% from now until June. The investment bank upgrades its view on Asian stocks, shifting recommendations to overweight for sectors such as Korea, Taiwan, semiconductors, and tech hardware. Key beneficiaries include South Korea, Taiwan, SK Hynix, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, with Morgan Stanley labeling them as "highest conviction opportunities" for a new cycle.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Surge in UK gilt yields exposes pension fund weaknesses
summary: The UK's pension funds are facing significant weaknesses due to a surge in gilt yields, which have increased the value of liabilities and exposed the industry's reliance on leverage. To mitigate this, pension funds must change their strategies, including reducing leverage, accepting lower returns, and increasing the use of liquid assets. The Bank of England's intervention, purchasing £65 billion of gilts, can only buy time, and pension funds must take proactive steps to address their vulnerabilities. A shift in mentality, from viewing higher yields as a benefit to recognizing their potential risks, is necessary to ensure the long-term solvency of UK pension funds.

images.alt_text: A worker crosses the road outside the Bank of England in The City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 15, 2022. The Office for National Statistics are due to the release the latest UK Labor Market Statistics on Tuesday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Government grant impact tracked by measures such as skilled jobs creation
summary: Singapore's government conducts regular studies on the impact of its grant schemes on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The impact is measured by indicators such as committed value add and projected skilled jobs created. According to a 2020 study, over 80% of Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) projects achieved productivity gains. The government also tracks approval rates, with 95% of PSG applications approved between 2019 and 2021. The data will be shared in due course, but not on a disaggregated basis.

images.alt_text: Businesses submitted more than 20,400 EDG applications and more than 116,100 PSG applications between FY2019 and FY2021, said Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong.

site_title: Renewables grow to meet global electricity demands: study
summary: A study by energy think tank Ember found that renewable energy sources, such as wind, solar, and hydropower, prevented a 4% increase in fossil fuel-based electricity generation in the first half of 2022, preventing $40 billion in fuel costs and 230 million tons of CO2 emissions. Global electricity demand grew by 389 terawatt hours, while renewables increased by 416 terawatt hours, meeting the growing energy demand and limiting fossil fuel use.

images.alt_text: The study highlights challenges that financial institutions face in assessing the suitability of corporate plans and projects for transition finance.
Compliance carbon markets have limited use as a strategic allocation given a dearth of political appeal, the Morningstar Equity Research analysts said.
The sale of its conventional energy assets is a key lever available to Sembcorp to meet its green-to-brown transformation goals, apart from adding more renewable energy projects
The potential climate-related losses associated with these assets aren’t covered by the companies’ existing capital.

site_title: The struggle for coverage of smaller companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange and Monetary Authority of Singapore have attempted to boost research coverage of smaller companies through various schemes, including the Grant for Equity Market Singapore (Gems) scheme, which ran from 2019 to 2023. Despite initial success, the take-up rate is uncertain, and research coverage remains limited. The schemes' failure can be attributed to the reduction in commissions following deregulation in the 1990s, which led to research outfits being downsized and becoming selective about which companies to cover. The lack of critical analysis and formal investment recommendations limits the usefulness of research, and it remains to be seen what more can be done to address the issue.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange has taken steps in response to the trend of delistings in recent years, including allowing dual-class capital structures and SPACs in the market.

site_title: Beaten and robbed: Vietnamese fisherman recounts China attacks
summary: Vietnamese fisherman Nguyen Van Loc recounts being attacked by Chinese coast guard vessels multiple times in the disputed South China Sea, including being beaten and robbed in 2020. Loc's boat was repeatedly rammed, and 13 crew members were left clinging to a fishing basket in the water. Since 2014, 98 Vietnamese boats have been destroyed by Chinese vessels, with hundreds of fishermen relying on these waters for their livelihoods. Loc remains committed to the waters, saying "This fishing ground belonged to our ancestors, we will never give it up."

images.alt_text: Joe  Biden vowed to make a priority of strengthening the US partnership with their countries and to help them address what he called the “existential threat” posed by the climate crisis.

Kuomintang (KMT) chairman Eric Chu makes a speech during the party congress in Taiwan on Aug 28. Though the Kuomintang has been derided for being "China-friendly", it plays a key role in maintaining a channel of communication between both sides.

This handout photo taken and released by the Taiwan Presidential Office on Monday (Oct 3) shows President Tsai Ing-wen (centre) at the launch of the new English-language TV channel TaiwanPlus in Taipei.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wednesday, extending global rallies
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.79% on Wednesday, following global rallies, as investors hopeful that soft economic indicators may slow US rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index reached 27,204.62, while the Topix index rose 0.90%. This uptrend is attributed to the anticipation of a slowdown in US interest rate hikes, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: High hopes for the new European Political Community
summary: The European Political Community (EPC) forum meets for the first time, bringing together 44 states, including 17 non-EU members, amid shared challenges such as energy, security, and immigration issues. The EPC aims to build a consensus between participating states and the EU, potentially serving as a bridge to a larger EU and a framework for more permanent continental integration. However, its purpose is unclear, and its success is uncertain, with some doubting its ability to last given the presence of bilateral foes and friends. The EPC may convene once or twice a year to address pressing issues and could pave the way for reform and cooperation on key topics.

images.alt_text: In her speech on Wednesday (Sep14), European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will outline her vision for the EU post-pandemic, including energy market reform post-Ukraine.
The EU needs to reset given the challenges on its Eastern doorsteps : European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: Asia: Equities extend rally on rate hopes, traders await Opec decision
summary: Asian stocks extended their rally on Wednesday, driven by hopes the Federal Reserve will temper its rate hike campaign amid weaker US economic data. The Nikkei, Hong Kong, and other Asian markets rose, with the dollar weakening against most peers. Oil prices also surged as Opec is expected to announce a massive output cut later in the day, potentially fueling further gains. Investors expect the Fed to ease its tightening campaign, supporting stocks, while officials continue to flag determination to crush inflation.

images.alt_text: Tokyo and Seoul were among the leaders on Tuesday, despite news that North Korea had fired a missile over Japan for the first time since 2017.

site_title: Blue skies ahead for green energy company EDPR Sunseap
summary: EDPR Sunseap, a green energy company, has seen a surge in growth since its Emerging Enterprise Award win in 2014. The company, operating as the Asia-Pacific platform for EDPR, has expanded its offerings to include a range of green products and services, covering markets in China, Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, and Southeast Asia. With fresh funding and new hires, EDPR Sunseap aims to capitalize on the global renewable energy trend, having previously installed solar panels on rooftops in Singapore, generating energy and exporting any excess to the power grid.

images.alt_text: Singapore CBD's largest EV charging hub launched at OCBC Centre
EDP Renewables buys stake in Sunseap; valuing company at S$1.1b
Lisbon, capital of Portugal, will once again host the Web Summit this year, in November.
Sunseap, Riau Islands to build large-scale solar energy plants

site_title: Tesla will remove more vehicle sensors amid Autopilot scrutiny
summary: Tesla will remove ultrasonic sensors from its vehicles starting this month, replacing them with cameras for its safety and driver-assistant features. The move aims to reduce costs and follows the removal of radar sensors amid a chip shortage. The transition will temporarily limit automated parking features but won't affect crash safety ratings. Tesla's reliance on cameras and artificial intelligence for self-driving technology has raised concerns about its effectiveness and safety. The company faces growing regulatory and public scrutiny over its Autopilot system following crashes.

images.alt_text: Tesla delivered a total of 343,380 vehicles around the world between July and September this year.
A screengrab from Tesla AI Day 2022 livestream shows Elon Musk (L) presenting the humanoid robot in Palo Alto, California on Sept 30, 2022.

site_title: MSD announces two new manufacturing plants as part of US$500m investment over five years
summary: MSD, an American pharmaceutical company, has announced two new manufacturing plants in Singapore as part of a $500 million investment over five years. The new facilities will produce vaccines and biologics, including the Keytruda immunotherapy for cancer patients and the HPV vaccine Gardasil 9. The investment is expected to create over 100 jobs and support Singapore's Manufacturing 2030 Vision, aiming to become a leading biopharma manufacturing hub. The facilities will also help MSD achieve its goal of being carbon neutral by 2030.

images.alt_text: Earlier this month, AstraZeneca and Daiichi secured US approval specifically targeting patients with so-called HER2-low breast cancer, paving the way for billions in sales.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near 3-week high on banks, tech boost
summary: Australian stocks reached a nearly three-week high on Wednesday, driven by gains in banking and technology shares. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.76% to 6,815.5 points, boosted by a surprise interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of Australia, which tempered the pace of rate hikes. Technology stocks advanced 3.9% and tracked a rally on the tech-heavy Nasdaq index. The index had settled 3.8% higher on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index settled 3.8 per cent higher at 6,699.3, with all sectors finishing in positive territory.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,154.69 on Wednesday, driven by a gain of 3.7% by Marine logistics group Sembcorp Marine and 3.1% by CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust. Banking stocks also opened higher, with OCBC up 0.8%, DBS gaining 0.2%, and UOB rising 0.3%. The gains followed global peers, with the Nasdaq Composite Index powering up 3.3% and the S&P 500 jumping 3.1%.

images.alt_text: Cortina Holdings will be buying over the fourth level of 15 Scotts Road (pictured) for S$49 million.

site_title: RBNZ delivers fifth half-point hike, signals more to come
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised interest rates by half a percentage point for the fifth consecutive meeting, increasing the Official Cash Rate (OCR) to 3.5% to maintain price stability and contribute to maximum sustainable employment. The decision signals more aggressive tightening, with the RBNZ stating that core consumer price inflation is too high and labor resources are scarce.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has been at the forefront of global rate hikes but the Fed has closed the gap with three 75-point moves, causing the greenback to surge against most other currencies.

site_title: Philippines’ 4-year high inflation boosts chances of more rate hikes
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate surged to 6.9% in September, the highest in four years, driven by high food and utility prices. This exceeded forecasts and pushed the average 9-month rate to 5.1%. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) is expected to hike interest rates further, with economists predicting a 50-basis-point increase at its November and December meetings to tame inflation. Core inflation eased to 4.5% in September, but food prices are expected to remain high due to crop damage from a recent typhoon.

images.alt_text: Vendors tend to their stalls as customers browse at a market in Manila on September 21, 2022. - The Asian Development Bank on September 21 cut its 2022 growth forecast for developing Asia, with crippling Covid-19 lockdowns in China, conflict in Ukraine and efforts to combat inflation dragging on the region. (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)

site_title: New Zealand budget deficit widened less than forecast on tax
summary: New Zealand's annual budget deficit widened to NZ$9.69 billion, less than forecast, as the economy rebounded strongly from pandemic-related slowdowns. Tax revenue jumped 11% to NZ$108 billion, while total expenses were NZ$2.8 billion lower than forecast. Despite a surge in net debt to 17.2% of GDP, Finance Minister Grant Robertson sees the better-than-expected budget numbers as a "strong starting point" to address the deteriorating global environment. The government aims to return to surpluses posted pre-Covid.

images.alt_text: Prices in Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, fell 4 per cent in the three-month period to an average of NZ$1.39 million (S$1.1 million).

site_title: Hard to say if inflation has peaked: ECB president
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said it's difficult to predict whether inflation has peaked, with the Eurozone's inflation rate hitting a record 10% in September due to rising energy costs. Lagarde emphasized the need to bring inflation back to the ECB's 2% target, warning that letting it run loose would be difficult to control. The ECB has already increased interest rates by a record 75 basis points and plans further hikes to cool prices, sparking fears of a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Eurozone inflation was still driven mainly by volatile energy and food prices but continued to broaden out, with virtually all categories, from services to industrial goods, now showing painfully high readings.
Euro area price increases have now outpaced the US for two straight months.

site_title:
Musk reverses again, ready to buy
Twitter at original US$44b price
summary: Elon Musk has offered to proceed with his original $44 billion buyout of Twitter, reversing his decision to withdraw from the deal. The move comes ahead of a court case scheduled for October 17, where Twitter was set to seek an order directing Musk to close the deal. Twitter shares jumped 22.2% in response to the news, while Tesla shares gained 2.9%. The agreement would end months of litigation and allow Musk to take over the company, which he originally committed to buying in April.

images.alt_text: A screengrab from Tesla AI Day 2022 livestream shows Elon Musk (L) presenting the humanoid robot in Palo Alto, California on Sept 30, 2022.
The tool will let users edit a tweet up to five times within 30 minutes of initially posting, Twitter said.
The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index led the major indices, powering up 3.3 per cent to close at 11,176.41 on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil stockpiles may surge to largest in three years
summary: Malaysia's palm oil stockpiles are expected to surge to the largest in nearly three years, reaching 2.26 million tons in September, according to estimates. Production rose 2.3% to a two-year high of 1.77 million tons, while exports are forecasted to jump 7.7% to 1.40 million tons. The increase in stockpiles and production has overshadowed robust shipments, leading to the worst quarterly slump in prices since 2008. Prices may fluctuate between 3,300 and 3,700 ringgit per ton in October due to macro headwinds and volatile market conditions.

images.alt_text: The production growth of palm oil stalled in recent years but farmers are now looking to replant or expand plantations amid rising prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rocket more than 4% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 4.29% at the open of trade on October 5, 2022, as investors took advantage of a global rally fueled by easing concerns about central bank interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index reached 18,811.97, driven by gains in tech firms such as Alibaba and Tencent. The move comes after months of heavy losses, with the Hang Seng losing about 25% this year, partly due to the impact of COVID restrictions and lockdowns in China.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index shed 0.83 per cent, or 143.32 points, to close at 17,079.51.

site_title: Amazon freezes corporate hiring in retail business with slowing sales
summary: Amazon has frozen corporate hiring in its retail business, citing slowing online sales. The company will pause recruitment until the end of the year, affecting corporate roles in the Worldwide Amazon Stores division. This move follows similar cost-cutting measures by other tech companies, such as Meta Platforms, amid signs of a weakening economy. Amazon has reduced its workforce by almost 100,000 people since March and is unwinding a pandemic-era expansion that added to its warehouse space and employee base.

images.alt_text: Some smaller European countries including the Netherlands, Poland and Sweden grew their marketplaces faster than Britain, but from a lower base, Amazon said.
Amazon has tied up with social media influencers to host live-streams during which they can interact with customers and also offer limited period deals.

site_title:
South Korea’s inflation edges down
 as rate hikes cool demand
summary: South Korea's inflation edged down to 5.6% in September, easing from August's 5.7%, as policy rate hikes cool demand. The Bank of Korea is under pressure to raise interest rates to bridge the gap with the Federal Reserve, which has been aggressively tightening monetary policy. The rate gap has led to a 13-year low won, boosting import costs and threatening inflation pressures. Policymakers meet on October 12 to discuss rate hikes, with inflation expected to remain in a 5-6% range for the time being.

images.alt_text: South Korea's output shrank for a fifth month and by the most since June 2020, with some companies also affected by a typhoon that hit industrial areas of South Korea, according to the S&P Global purchasing managers’ index.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Shipping containers are stacked at Gwangyang port in Gwangyang, South Korea, June 14, 2022.   Yonhap via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. SOUTH KOREA OUT. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVE./File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Manulife redoubles its Asia ambitions in a world of uncertainty
summary: Manulife Financial, a Canadian insurer, plans to increase its profit from Asia by 50% by 2025, aiming to generate half of its earnings from the region. Despite recent challenges, the company is confident in Asia's growing middle class and ageing population, which will drive growth. CEO Roy Gori has stated that the company will stick to its "all-weather" plan, focusing on high-potential businesses, technological improvements, and talent attraction. Manulife has operated in Asia for over a century and expects the region to remain a key driver of growth in an uncertain global market.

images.alt_text: Canada’s largest life insurer reported core earnings of C$1.56 billion (S$1.7 billion) in the 3 months ended Jun 30.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Cortina, EuroSports, Japan Foods
summary: Cortina Holdings to buy a 4th level of 15 Scotts Road for S$49 million, expected to increase earnings per share. Sembcorp Marine secured a $3.1 billion contract for a floating production vessel from Petrobras, and shares rose 2.8%. EuroSports' subsidiary will relinquish its Alfa Romeo distributorship in Singapore due to lack of commercial viability. Japan Foods' unit was suspended from renewing work passes amid hiring and payroll practices investigation, shares remained flat.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened higher on Wednesday, rising 11.44 points or 0.81% to 1,420.80. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw a significant increase in volume, with 637.69 million lots traded worth RM165.15 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 347 to 116, indicating a positive trend in the market.

site_title: BT’s Kenneth Lim bags Visual Treat prize at SGX Orb Awards
summary: BT's Kenneth Lim won the Visual Treat award at the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Orb Awards for his infographic "Carbon Credit Crash Course," which explains how carbon credits work in a visually engaging way. The award recognizes creative storytelling and experiential content in financial news. Lim's win is seen as an inspiration for other journalists to tell business stories in new and innovative ways.

images.alt_text: “I'm grateful to the support and mentorship of co-workers past and present - even, and maybe especially, the times we'd debated on issues close to our hearts,” said Kelly Ng, correspondent at The Business Times.

site_title: Amazon discontinues Glow video-calling device for kids
summary: Amazon is discontinuing its Glow video-calling device for kids, citing lacklustre sales and a shift in consumer behavior. Launched a year ago, the device was intended to help children stay connected with distant relatives during the pandemic. Despite praise for its concept, the device failed to gain traction, with only 500 customer reviews and a steep discount of 55% off its list price. The device's cancellation is part of Amazon's efforts to restrain costs as sales growth stagnates.

images.alt_text: Amazon is the latest tech company to try to control costs amid signs of a weakening economy.

site_title: New Zealand house prices suffer near-record quarterly slump
summary: New Zealand house prices suffered a near-record quarterly slump of 4.1% in the three months through September, with prices in Auckland falling 4% to an average of NZ$1.39 million. This is the second-largest quarterly decline since the global financial crisis 14 years ago. The annual rate of increase dropped to 2.8%, the lowest since 2019, as interest rates have increased and credit has become harder to attain. Economists predict the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may raise the Official Cash Rate further, prolonging the downturn in the housing market.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has been at the forefront of global rate hikes but the Fed has closed the gap with three 75-point moves, causing the greenback to surge against most other currencies.
Businesses are being buffeted by rising costs and slowing demand as the central bank raises interest rates.

site_title: Sembmarine clinches US$3.1b FPSO contract from Petrobras
summary: SembCorp Marine has secured a US$3.1 billion contract from Petrobras to build an FPSO vessel, the P-82, for the Buzios field in Brazil. The vessel is expected to start commercial operations in 2026 and features high production capacity and CO2 emission-reducing technologies. The contract is Sembmarine's largest from Petrobras, adding US$4.3 billion to its order book. The company does not expect the contract to impact its net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Activision Blizzard’s Overwatch 2 hit with cyberattack at launch
summary: Activision Blizzard's Overwatch 2 was hit with a cyberattack on Tuesday, causing wide-scale connectivity issues during its launch. The company experienced a mass Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attack, which directed traffic at its servers, knocking them offline. This added to the existing long queue times for players. The attack occurred just days after the National Labor Relations Board found that the company withheld raises from some staff for campaigning to form a union.

images.alt_text: Microsoft and Activision have until Sep 8 to offer an undertaking, the CMA said.

site_title: Inflation, rising debt and weak baht set to shape Thai election
summary: Thailand's upcoming election will focus on managing the country's economic challenges, including high inflation, rising debt, and a weak baht. The baht has lost 20% since 2020, while household debt stands at 88% of GDP, the highest in the region. The government faces a record budget deficit and a tepid economic recovery, with tourism making up only 12% of GDP. Voters will likely prioritize the next leader's ability to address these issues, with top contenders including Paetongtarn Shinawatra and Pita Limjaroenrat.

images.alt_text: Last week, the BOT raised its key interest rate by a quarter point to 1.00 per cent to tame 14-year high inflation.
The central bank earlier retained the economy’s annual growth outlook for this year at 3.3 per cent.

site_title: South Korea, US fire missiles after North Korea test: Yonhap
summary: South Korea and the US fired four ground-to-ground missiles into the East Sea in response to North Korea's ballistic missile launch over Japan for the first time in five years. The North Korean missile was fired on Tuesday, prompting a stern response from South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol and US President Joe Biden. The launches were in accordance with a joint military exercise between South Korea and the US, which took place on Tuesday. The move was condemned as "clearly an escalation" by UN chief Antonio Guterres and described as "in the strongest terms" by US and Japanese leaders.

images.alt_text: Commuters in Seoul watch the news about a North Korea ballistic missile launch on Sept 30, 2022.
Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks to the media after North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan, at his official residence in Tokyo, Japan, Oct 4, 2022.

site_title: Malaysia gears up for election-friendly budget with smaller deficit
summary: Malaysia's government is set to announce a budget that aims to narrow the fiscal deficit to 5% of gross domestic product, a goal that may be achieved through increased tax compliance and reduced subsidies. The budget is expected to be generous, with proposals for cash assistance to low-income households, loan moratoriums for small businesses, and increased allocations for healthcare. The move is seen as an attempt to win over voters ahead of the election, with economists predicting a focus on feel-good measures rather than new taxes.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has given the sector its backing and maintained its “overweight” rating in its report on Tuesday (Oct 4).
An election is not due until September 2023, but Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob is under pressure from some factions of his ruling coalition to hold the vote earlier.

site_title: Europe: Shares log best day since mid-March as interest rate angst eases
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 3.1% on Tuesday, its best session since mid-March, as interest rate angst eased following global manufacturing data and a surprise interest rate hike in Australia. The UK government's fiscal plans also calmed investors. The Stoxx 600 index has fallen 17.4% this year due to an energy crisis and recession concerns, but sectoral indexes, including travel and tech stocks, gained, with tech stocks rising 5.1% on a single charging port approval.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index rallied 1.4 per cent to 7,002.51 points compared with Monday’s closing level.

site_title: Hundreds of NFTs moved from Three Arrows Fund, tracker says
summary: Hundreds of NFTs, valued at around $35 million, were moved from a crypto address associated with Starry Night Capital, a fund launched by the co-founders of Three Arrows Capital, a now-bankrupt crypto hedge fund. The transfer, the first since the main wallet shifted assets to a new address four months ago, includes notable NFTs like "Pepe the Frog NFT Genesis." The move comes as the liquidators of Three Arrows, led by advisory firm Teneo, continue to unwind the fund's assets. Su Zhu and Kyle Davies, the fund's co-founders, have been sparring with the liquidators in court.

site_title: Oil jumps more than 3% ahead of Opec+ meeting on supply cuts
summary: Oil prices surged 3.3% on Tuesday ahead of the Opec+ meeting, with Brent crude settling at $91.80 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate closing at $86.52 a barrel. The group is expected to cut output in excess of 1 million barrels per day, tightening the physical fundamentals and signaling to the market. Analysts expect a substantial cut, which could boost oil prices further, with some predicting a potential 2 million-bpd cut.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for December delivery rose US$3.72 to US$88.86 a barrel, a 4.4 per cent gain.
OPEC+ is said to be weighing its biggest output cut since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic

site_title: Nasdaq to wait for regulation before launching crypto exchange
summary: NASDAQ plans to wait for regulatory clarity and institutional adoption before launching a crypto exchange, according to executive vice-president Tal Cohen. The company will instead focus on its crypto custody services, citing "massive" demand and opportunity. Cohen notes that the retail market is saturated, and NASDAQ aims to establish trust with clients before expanding into exchanges. This decision prioritizes the company's existing crypto custody services, which Cohen considers foundational for clients.

site_title: As pound slumps, cash-rich foreigners on the prowl for London homes
summary: Foreign investors, particularly those from the US, Middle East, and Asia, are taking advantage of the UK's financial crisis to buy London residential properties. With the pound hitting new lows, the UK's residential property sector has become a two-tier market, with local buyers struggling to afford mortgages and high-net-worth international buyers snapping up bargains. Experts predict house prices will fall by at least 10% in 2023 due to rising mortgage rates and the pound's devaluation, with some predicting a 7.5% decline in house prices.

images.alt_text: The average two-year fixed-rate on a home loan climbed to 5.97 per cent on Tuesday (Oct 4), according to Moneyfacts Group.
Despite slowing home prices, returns from real estate in parts of London remain strong,

epa10213780 A row of semi-detached houses in Holmfirth, Britain, 29 September 2022. The fall of the value of the pound following Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng’s mini-budget has resulted in banks withdrawing mortgage deals, with interest rates expected to rise to nearly six percent.  EPA-EFE/ADAM VAUGHAN

site_title: S-Reit acquisitions up in September, but smaller deals signal weakening appetite amid uncertainty
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) announced 26 proposed asset acquisitions in the first 9 months of 2022, with September being the most active month. The deals are smaller, with over half valued at under S$50 million, reflecting a cautious stance amid rising interest rates and a global economic slowdown. Despite this, the market remains encouraging, with S-Reits drawing acquisitions from directors and substantial shareholders. However, Reit managers are cautious about larger acquisitions, with some opting for smaller deals or debt-funded transactions to mitigate foreign exchange risks.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) received net inflows of S$9 million and S$39 million from institutional and retail investors respectively.

site_title: Meta pushes Reels monetisation with new ad formats
summary: Meta is introducing new ad formats for its Reels platform, aiming to create new revenue streams for creators. The new formats include a skippable "post-loop" video ad that plays after a Reel and a horizontally scrollable carousel ad that displays between two and 10 images at the bottom of a Reel. These formats are designed to encourage creators to monetize their content with ad placements, potentially increasing revenue for the platform. The new formats are part of Meta's efforts to grow its short video and business messaging products.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps 2% at open as Treasury yields ease
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 335.78 points, or 1.14%, to 29,826.67. The Nasdaq Composite led the gains, increasing 239.28 points, or 2.21%, to 11,054.72, as easing US Treasury yields boosted megacap growth and technology stocks. Investors await more economic data to gauge the Federal Reserve's rate hike path.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 9, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Pitt ‘choked’ one child, hit another in Jolie plane fight: court papers
summary: Brad Pitt allegedly physically abused his children during a fight with ex-wife Angelina Jolie on a private plane in 2016, according to court papers. Jolie alleges that Pitt choked one child and hit another in the face. The incident is part of a lengthy dispute over their marriage, custody of their six children, and shared assets, including a French winery.

images.alt_text: Covid-19 has clouded the outlook for Japan's famous Shinkansen, with Zoom calls increasingly taking the place of the business day-trips that are the backbone of bullet-train revenues, and foreign tourists still largely absent.

site_title: Banks divert gold supply from India to China, Turkey: sources
summary: Leading gold suppliers to India are diverting shipments to China, Turkey, and other markets with higher premiums, resulting in less than 10% of gold stored in vaults ahead of major festivals. This could lead to scarcity in India's second-largest gold market, forcing buyers to pay hefty premiums. India's gold imports fell 30% in September, while China's net gold imports jumped nearly 40% in August, and Turkish gold imports soared 543%.

site_title: Troubled Myanmar may return to financial crime watchdog’s blacklist
summary: Myanmar is at risk of being returned to the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) blacklist, a move that could further deter foreign investors and impose stricter financial regulations. The FATF, a global watchdog, is set to decide on the decision by October, amid concerns over money laundering and terrorist financing. If placed on the blacklist, Myanmar banks and companies would face significant compliance costs and restrictions, potentially hindering the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: The shrinking forex reserves and high inflation amid international sanctions following the 2021 coup have led to frequent power outages and commodity shortages, hampering Myanmar's economic recovery.
The Asian Development Bank cut China’s growth forecast for 2022 to 3.3 per cent from 5.0 per cent, as Beijing pursues a zero-Covid strategy that has devastated the world’s second-largest economy.
Thailand announced in late August that the national daily minimum wage would go up by an average of 5 per cent from October – the first such increase since January 2020.

site_title: Understanding the financial implications of sustainability
summary: Companies that incorporate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into their operations tend to benefit financially, with improved profitability, lower cost of capital, and valuation premium. Research shows that ESG-driven sustainability creates value through internal cost reductions, operational efficiencies, and improved stakeholder relationships. Leading capital providers are increasing ESG requirements, and successful ESG strategy execution can help combat rising operating expenses and reduce energy usage.

site_title:
US: Nasdaq jumps 3.3%, extending
stocks rally as Twitter surges
summary: The US stock market rallied for a second consecutive session, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the way, surging 3.3% to close at 11,176.41. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.8% and the S&P 500 jumped 3.1% as investors remained optimistic about a potential US monetary policy pivot. Twitter's surge on the revived chance of Elon Musk's takeover also contributed to the market's positive momentum.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 9, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Poor returns show expanding S-Reit market isn’t giving joy to investors
summary: The Singaporean S-Reit market, which has grown exponentially over the past two decades, is facing disappointing returns for investors. Despite the market's growth, many S-Reits with foreign assets have underperformed, with unit prices falling by up to 42.6% and annualized total returns ranging from -23% to -37.5%. In contrast, Singapore-centred Reits have seen more consistent growth, with some outperforming the market. Analysts point to the resilience of S-Reits with predominantly Singapore assets, but the disparity in performance raises questions about the market's sustainability and the need for further investigation into the reasons behind it.

images.alt_text: The Queen Mary property is a former ocean vessel-turned-floating hotel, and one of the 18 properties in EHT's portfolio.
SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye (centre), flanked by members of Reitas' exco and management, at an event celebrating 20 years of S-Reits.
Analysts expect further downside for the GBP/SGD rate in the near future.

site_title: Zee, Sony unit merger gets approval from India competition regulator
summary: The Competition Commission of India approved a merger between Sony's Indian unit and Zee Entertainment Enterprises, creating a US$10-billion TV behemoth. The regulator had warned of scrutiny due to the companies' significant market position. Sony and Zee had offered concessions, including pricing discounts, to alleviate concerns. The merged company will operate with certain conditions, and the companies will wait for remaining regulatory approvals before launching the merged entity.

site_title: Changi Airport’s 3-runway system expected to be operational in ‘latter half of this decade’: MOT
summary: Changi Airport's three-runway system is expected to be operational by the latter half of this decade, increasing flight handling capacity and passenger capacity by more than one-third. This is in line with the airport's previous target of mid-2020s. The development is seen as a significant upgrade for the airport, which currently handles over 100,000 flights per week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Singapore Airlines Airbus A330-300 takes off behind a Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner at Changi Airport in Singapore, March 28, 2018. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Blackouts hit 130 million Bangladeshis after grid failure
summary: A grid failure caused widespread blackouts in Bangladesh, affecting over 130 million people, or 80% of the country. The outage occurred shortly after 2 pm local time, with the capital Dhaka, home to 22 million people, expected to have power restored by 8 pm. The cause of the fault is under investigation, with a technical malfunction being the likely reason. This is the second major unscheduled blackout in Bangladesh in recent months, amid a power crisis driven by higher global energy prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Power lines and transmission towers at the site for Pharma City in Hyderabad, India. The blackouts were sparked by the scarcity of coal - the fossil fuel that accounts for 70 per cent of India’s electricity generation.

site_title: US job openings post biggest drop in nearly two-and-a-half years in August
summary: US job openings dropped 1.1 million to 10.1 million in August, the largest decline in nearly two-and-a-half years. This decrease follows the Fed's efforts to cool the economy and curb inflation, with interest rates at 3-3.25%. Despite the drop, job openings remain at high levels, suggesting demand for labor remains strong. This could keep the Federal Reserve on its aggressive monetary policy tightening path.

site_title: Micron plans investment of up to US$100b in New York chip factory
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest up to $100 billion over 20 years to build a chip factory in upstate New York, creating 50,000 jobs, including 9,000 high-paying positions. The $20 billion initial investment is expected to be completed by the end of the decade. The factory is part of Micron's strategy to increase American-made memory chip production to 40% of global output. The investment comes after the US government passed the CHIPS and Science Act, providing $52 billion for domestic semiconductor research and development.

site_title: Singapore records 6,888 new Covid-19 cases days after F1 weekend
summary: Singapore reported 6,888 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, Oct 4, following the return of the F1 Grand Prix weekend that drew over 300,000 people. This spike is consistent with the usual Tuesday increase due to weekend socializing. Most new cases were among middle-aged and young adults. The Omicron variant BA.2.75, detected in India, has not led to more severe disease or impacted the healthcare system. Experts are still studying the variant, which has infected people worldwide.

images.alt_text: Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez (left) leads at the start of the Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sunday.

site_title: World Bank sees weak growth in 2023 for eastern Europe, central Asian countries
summary: The World Bank has forecast weak growth in eastern Europe and central Asian countries in 2023, with an expected 0.3% contraction due to spillover effects from the war in Ukraine. The region's economic output is subject to considerable uncertainty, with high debt levels and inflation elevating the risk of financial stress. The prolonged war is causing greater physical and environmental damage, and trade and investment fragmentation, leading to a prolonged economic downturn.

site_title: Cortina Holdings to buy 15 Scotts Road floor for S$49 million
summary: Cortina Holdings has been granted an option to purchase the fourth level of 15 Scotts Road in Singapore for S$49 million. The luxury watch retailer and distributor foresees needing more office space due to expected "organic growth" and plans to own the space rather than rent. The acquisition is expected to increase the company's earnings per share to 41.7 cents from 41.5 cents. Cortina intends to pay for the property in cash, with the remaining amount to be paid by Dec 1, upon completion of the sale.

images.alt_text: Watch retailers could continue to enjoy boom time

site_title: Warren Buffett’s successor is building a US$68m Berkshire holding
summary: Greg Abel, Warren Buffett's successor at Berkshire Hathaway, has acquired about $68 million in stock, significantly increasing his stake in the company. The purchases, made in late September, address concerns about Abel's ownership and demonstrate his commitment to the company. As the likely CEO, Abel's increased stake aligns him more closely with shareholders, who had questioned his involvement in the company's operations. The move is seen as a positive signal for the company's valuation.

site_title: Stanley Ho’s family risks losing Portugal casinos to rival bidder
summary: The Ho family, led by chairwoman Pansy Ho, risks losing the concession of two Portugal casinos, Casino de Lisboa and Casino do Estoril, after a rival bidder made a higher offer. The licence expires at the end of December, and the Portuguese government is evaluating the tenders. Estoril Sol, owned by the Ho family, operates the casinos and has a 57.8% stake in the company. The rival bidder's offer is higher in value, but details are not provided.

images.alt_text: Macau’s new casino licences are expected to begin in 2023 and are crucial for the 6 incumbents to keep operating their multi-billion US dollar properties.

site_title: Singapore port plans new system to boost bunkering transparency
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) plans to launch a new system to boost bunkering transparency by registering sales of bunker fuel electronically over the next two years. The system will convert to electronic bunker delivery notes from physical documents in 2023 and register oil flows digitally in 2024. This move aims to improve efficiency, reduce risk of fraud, and streamline trade financing processes. The new system will also enhance trade transparency, benefiting the global bunkering industry.

site_title: Singapore’s household debt, public finances healthy despite volatile high-rate environment: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's household and corporate debt remain healthy despite rising interest rates, according to Senior Minister of State for Finance Chee Hong Tat. The government's finances are stable due to the net investment returns framework, which smooths out asset bases over the long term. However, Chee warned that high interest rates may persist for an extended period. The government will review the impact of interest rates on households and businesses, with plans to provide assistance. Essential areas such as public housing, healthcare, and education will remain affordable and accessible.

images.alt_text: The revised interest rate now applies across all four of the DBS' fixed rate packages with commitment periods ranging from two to five years.

site_title: Sixt agrees to purchase around 100,000 e-vehicles from China’s BYD
summary: Sixt has agreed to purchase approximately 100,000 electric vehicles from China's BYD by 2028, with the first stage including several thousand all-electric vehicles available to European customers in 2022. This partnership makes Sixt the first European car rental company to offer BYD vehicles, with the BYD ATTO 3 electric SUV being the first model available. The companies also plan to explore cooperation opportunities in various regions worldwide.

site_title: UK’s mortgage borrowers face squeeze as key rate nears 6%
summary: The UK's average two-year fixed-rate mortgage has risen to 5.97% as of October 4, according to Moneyfacts Group. This marks a 1.5% increase since the government's mini-budget, causing lenders to pull over 40% of mortgage products, leaving borrowers with limited options. Experts predict a double-digit house price decline, with 5% of mortgage holders facing negative equity, and households facing financial strain due to rising mortgage payments and inflation.

site_title: Tech can improve banking experiences, create opportunities
summary: Digital technologies are transforming the banking industry, enabling financial institutions to provide personalized products and services using artificial intelligence (AI). The use of AI can generate up to $1 trillion in additional value for the global banking industry annually. Banks can leverage AI to offer tailored products, personalized user experiences, and analytics services. Additionally, the integration of robo-advisors can help clients manage their investments and wealth needs more efficiently. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched the Singapore Financial Data Exchange (SGFinDex) to provide users with a view of their financial data, enabling banks to proactively spot gaps and grow their customers' money.

images.alt_text: Netflix, as with other household tech names, redefined the industry years ago when it launched its online streaming service in 2007. Can it maintain its dominance in the space it helped create?

site_title: Volkswagen brands prepare to list as training exercise
summary: Volkswagen brands, including Audi, Lamborghini, and Bentley, are preparing for stock market listings as a training exercise, according to a report by Handelsblatt. The move comes after Porsche's successful listing last Thursday, prompting speculation that the Volkswagen Group may also list its other brands to unlock value. The company's CEO, Oliver Blume, declined to comment on whether further listings were planned. Unlisted brands include Skoda, Seat, and Cupra.

images.alt_text: Shares of the sports-car maker had debuted at 82.50 euros, the high end of the range VW sought, on Sep 29 in Europe’s biggest IPO since miner Glencore raised almost US$10 billion in 2011.

Today’s ruling goes back to the tumultuous episode of Porsche trying to buy the much larger VW in 2008, only for the plan to falter and Volkswagen turning the tables to take over the sports-car maker instead.

site_title: US logistics managers’ gauge rises for first time since March
summary: The Logistics Managers' Index rose to 61.4 in September, its first increase since March, indicating a pickup in US supply-chain activity despite transportation costs sliding for the sixth consecutive month. Inventory levels and costs gained, while warehousing capacity remained below 50. The index's subcomponents show a nearly 50-point reversal in transportation capacity, with prices below 50 for a third month, and higher-than-usual inventory growth may be related to preparations for the holiday season.

images.alt_text: The agreement covers 29 Pacific Coast ports stretching from California to Washington State that handle almost 40 per cent of US imports.

site_title: Sen Yue’s outgoing CEO, executive director flag issues with judicial managers
summary: Sen Yue Holdings' outgoing CEO and executive director Neo Gim Kiong and Liew Nyok Wah have raised concerns over the judicial managers' handling of the company's affairs. They cited issues with a letter of demand sent to SYH Resources in 2021, inconsistent classification of goods to the National Environment Agency, and non-compliance with company protocols. The judicial managers have responded, denying the allegations and stating they had already addressed the concerns previously. The concerns have raised questions about potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act.

images.alt_text: Sen Yue and subsidiary placed under interim judicial management

site_title: EuroSports says ‘unable to achieve commercial viability’ of Alfa Romeo distributorship
summary: EuroSports Global, parent company of EuroAutomobile, has announced its intention to relinquish the Alfa Romeo distributorship in Singapore due to uncommercial viability. The decision comes after shutting down the showroom and laying off sales staff. EuroSports will continue to operate a workshop as an independent service provider. The company will focus on its existing Lamborghini distribution business and Scorpio Electric brand, with no expected impact on net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. Komoco Holdings is set to take over the exclusive distributorship next year.

images.alt_text: EuroSports Global's FY2022 revenue grew 10.7 per cent on-year to S$54.4 million from S$49.1 million, due to higher sales in Lamborghini automobiles.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS raised its fixed-rate home loan interest rate to 3.5%, a 0.75 percentage point increase from 2.75%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is injecting $5m into a blended finance innovation grant to scale up transition funding. 90% of re-employment disputes are amicably resolved through mediation, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Meanwhile, Kensington Park condominium in Singapore is relaunched for en bloc sale at $1.28b. Australia's Telstra suffered a data breach, two weeks after Optus was hit by a massive cyberattack, and Asian equities, including Singapore's, rallied on Wall Street's overnight relief rally.

site_title: White House guidelines for AI aim to mitigate harm
summary: The Biden administration proposed a non-binding Artificial Intelligence (AI) Bill of Rights, aiming to mitigate harm from AI's increasing use in education, healthcare, and employment. The guidelines, released Tuesday, suggest voluntary practices for developers and users to prevent AI from unfairly disadvantaging people. The proposal, similar to others, addresses issues like algorithmic bias, data collection, and privacy. The US has not yet implemented comprehensive AI regulations, unlike the European Union, which is moving towards high-risk system regulation. Existing rules will continue to apply to cutting-edge systems.

site_title: Japan Foods unit suspended from applying, renewing work passes on MOM investigation
summary: Japan Foods Holding's subsidiary, Japan Foods Enterprises, has been suspended from applying for and renewing work passes due to an ongoing investigation by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) into its hiring and payroll practices involving foreigners. The company will have to streamline operational workflows and employ more part-timers and contract staff to deal with the suspension. Japan Foods Holding will cooperate fully with the investigation and monitor its progress, with no immediate plans to shut down any operating outlets.

images.alt_text: Takahashi Kenichi, executive chairman and CEO of Japan Foods. The group on Thursday reported net profit of S$1.4 million for the first quarter ended Jun 30.

site_title: Book review: Just about all you need to know about convertible securities
summary: Convertible securities have historically returned approximately as much as common stocks over the long term, with less volatility. The book "Convertible Securities: A Complete Guide to Investment and Corporate Financing Strategies" provides a comprehensive overview of the asset class, covering topics such as diversification, capital structure optimization, and valuation methods. The authors emphasize the asymmetric behavior of convertibles, capturing upside while cushioning downside risk. The book is considered a "remarkably comprehensive" resource, offering insights for both lay investors and seasoned practitioners.

site_title: Malaysian gaming sector tipped to continue strong recovery through 2023
summary: Malaysia's gaming sector is expected to continue its strong recovery through 2023, according to a report by UOB Kay Hian. The sector has historically performed well during market sell-downs and is expected to benefit from the restoration of hotel and gaming capacity. Analysts project a steady upward trajectory in casino sub-sector earnings, with Resorts World Genting and Genting Group being key beneficiaries. However, they warn of a "sub-optimal recovery" due to structural challenges from illegal operators and slower-than-expected sales growth, with earnings expected to reach around 90% of pre-pandemic levels by next year.

images.alt_text: Tourism-dependent stocks to benefit from Malaysia reopening: UOBKH
Genting has casinos globally including in Malaysia, Singapore, the US and the UK. It does not currently operate in Macau.

site_title: PlayStation eyes new investment for PC, mobile push
summary: Sony is considering new investments to expand its gaming business into PC and mobile, with head of PlayStation Studios Hermen Hulst stating that further investments in live services and collaborations are possible. The company has recently acquired Bungie and taken a minority stake in FromSoftware, and is also producing game adaptations such as a Uncharted movie and The Last of Us TV series. Analysts expect Sony to continue making deals to strengthen its studio network, which has drawn praise as a key differentiator in the gaming industry.

images.alt_text: VR goggles remain a largely unproven category several years into the wide availability of commercial offerings from the likes of HTC and Oculus, now a part of Meta Platforms.

site_title: Depeche Mode just can’t get enough – it’s back with new album, tour
summary: Depeche Mode, a British electronic music pioneer, announced a comeback with a new album, "Memento Mori," set to release in March, inspired by the pandemic and the death of founding member Andrew Fletcher. Lead singer Dave Gahan confirmed the band's return with a series of big stadium shows in March, marking their first tour in over five years.

images.alt_text: For pop music, 2021 was the year of the deep dive

site_title: US dollar slips on euro as lower US yields give markets a breather
summary: The US dollar slipped against the euro and other currencies, with the euro rising 0.67% to a 20-year high, as US Treasury yields paused their upward climb, providing relief to share markets. The Australian dollar fell after the Reserve Bank of Australia raised rates by a smaller-than-expected amount. The US dollar index fell 0.55%, while the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield dropped to 3.58%. Market participants expect the Federal Reserve to end its rate hike cycle, supporting risk assets and high-beta currencies.

site_title: Angela Merkel wins UN refugee prize
summary: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel won the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Nansen Award for her leadership and compassion in protecting asylum seekers while in office. Merkel, who led Germany for 16 years, called on her fellow Germans to reject divisive nationalism and urged them to be "compassionate and open-minded" during the 2015 and 2016 migrant crisis. The UNHCR highlighted her efforts to welcome over 1.2 million refugees, citing her "moral and political courage" in standing up for human rights and humanitarian principles.

site_title: Going for zero by 2030?
summary: The 22nd edition of the Singapore International Bunkering Conference and Exhibition (Sibcon) took place from October 4-7, 2022, with a theme of "Driving the Transformation of Marine Fuels." The conference focused on developing alternative fuels to address the issue of decarbonization and achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions in the shipping industry. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has led efforts to ensure the port remains a top bunkering hub and has also been a leader in licensing and regulation.

images.alt_text: Increased value concentration with ever larger vessels and massive ports increases the risk of large event losses.

site_title: Former Formula One supremo Ecclestone to face fraud trial next year
summary: Former Formula One supremo Bernie Ecclestone, 91, will face a trial next year on charges of tax fraud related to £400 million in overseas assets. Ecclestone was accused of making "untrue or misleading" representations to the British tax authority between 2013 and 2016. He maintained an office in London but spends most of his time abroad, and was granted unconditional bail ahead of his trial, set to begin on October 9, 2023. Ecclestone had indicated a not guilty plea at a hearing last month.

images.alt_text: Winner Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez celebrates after the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on October 2, 2022. (Photo by MOHD RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 11.74 points to 1,409.36. A total of 1.916 billion lots worth RM1.455 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 568 to 280.

site_title: Truss hints at UK benefits cuts, courting new Tory rebellion
summary: British Prime Minister Liz Truss has refused to commit to a pledge to raise welfare payments in line with inflation, sparking a potential rebellion among Conservative MPs. Truss said pensioners will receive an inflation-matching boost, but those on welfare benefits can adapt to cost-of-living pressures. The decision has drawn criticism from senior MPs, including Penny Mordaunt, who says it would be unfair to reduce welfare payments. This comes as Truss faces internal Tory politics and mounting criticism over her economic plan, which includes tax cuts and deregulation.

images.alt_text: A protester at a demonstration against the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference organised by The People's Assembly campaign group in Birmingham, UK, on Sunday (Oct 2). At a time when the people are dealing with record inflation, the plan to scrap the cut in taxes for the country's highest earners has drawn a lot of unhappiness in and outside the Conservative party.

site_title: India’s Euler Motors raises US$60m in GIC Singapore-led funding round
summary: Euler Motors, an Indian electric vehicle maker, raised US$60 million in a funding round led by GIC Singapore. The startup plans to use the funds to speed up product development and expand its retail presence in 12 new markets by the end of the current fiscal year. This round is part of the company's Series C funding, which typically involves late-stage startups. The funding comes as India's EV sector sees increased interest from investors, with major players such as Mahindra & Mahindra and Tata Motors also investing heavily in the industry.

site_title: Bonds now more attractive than equities
summary: Global bond yields have surged, hitting levels not seen since 2009, making bonds more attractive than equities. Investors should consider increasing their fixed income allocations, as valuations of investment-grade bonds are relatively undemanding. Widening credit spreads and improved credit metrics of global bond issuers provide a cushion during economic slowdowns. Unconstrained bond strategies, which can adjust to market changes, offer higher flexibility and potential for better returns. Short-duration bonds with high-quality credits can provide attractive risk-return profiles, with funds such as Nikko AM Shenton Short Term Bond Fund and United SGD Fund offering yields of 4.3% and 4.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: This has been the most devastating time for bonds since at least 1926, and maybe in centuries. But much of the damage is already behind us.

site_title: EU lawmakers impose single charger for all smartphones
summary: The EU parliament passed a law requiring USB-C as the single charger standard for new smartphones, tablets, and cameras from late 2024. This measure will force Apple to switch from its outdated Lightning port to USB-C, a standard already used by many competitors. The law was adopted with a vote of 602 in favor and 13 against, aiming to reduce electronic waste and promote sustainability in the EU.

site_title: CP Group’s Chearavanont family launches US$300m equity-NFT fundraising campaign advised by Sygnum
summary: The Chearavanont family's Thai entertainment company, T&B Media Global, is launching a US$300 million equity-NFT fundraising campaign to finance a metaverse platform called Translucia, advised by Singapore-based Sygnum. The platform aims to leverage blockchain technology for corporate partners, with MQDC as its first partner. Sygnum will manage roadshows, pitch the project, and provide institutional-grade custody for the deal. The hybrid equity-NFT structure allows investors to potentially redeem their stakes later, and the funding will be used to build "an infinite universe of interconnected metaverses".

images.alt_text: Seba Bank's headquarters in Zug, Switzerland
Digital asset tech company Sygnum crosses S$1b valuation with S$120m in Series B funds

site_title: Singapore stocks up on Wall Street, regional markets rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.02% to 3,138.9 points, driven by Wall Street's overnight relief rally. US factory data showed the economy underperformed, sparking hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate easing. Shares rose despite Singtel's 0.4% gain after its Australian subsidiary Optus suffered a cyberattack, leaking personal data of 2.1 million customers. Singapore Airlines rose 1% after raising frequencies to East Asia.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index reversed earlier session losses to close Monday up 0.7 per cent.
The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.4 per cent or 42.2 points to 3149.3 as at 9.02am
Tokyo and Seoul were among the leaders on Tuesday, despite news that North Korea had fired a missile over Japan for the first time since 2017.

site_title: HSBC eyes sale of Canada business
summary: HSBC is considering selling its Canadian business, one of its largest international banking brands, as it seeks to boost returns for its largest shareholder. The disposal would be the latest in a series of divestments at the bank, following its exit from mass market banking in the US and sale of its French retail business. The review is at an early stage, and no final decision has been made, but a potential sale of the lender's 100% stake in HSBC Bank Canada is being considered.

site_title: Malaysia confirms budget announcement on schedule, amid election speculation
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has confirmed the country's 2023 budget will be presented on schedule, despite speculation of an early general election. The election, originally due in September 2023, is under pressure from some factions of his ruling coalition to be held earlier for a stronger mandate. However, the prime minister has stated that he will wait for the monarch's decision, emphasizing that the king has absolute power to dissolve Parliament. An election must be held within 60 days from dissolution.

site_title: Global capital markets overprice risks and overreact to shocks: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warns that global capital markets overprice risks in emerging economies and overreact to shocks, preventing gaps in climate finance from being filled. The tendency has led to a significant decline in private investment in infrastructure in developing countries, with a $65 billion exit from the developing world in the last six months. Tharman calls for a major pivot in public-sector institutions, shifting their focus from lenders of first resort to catalytic finance, to mobilize private finance and address the climate finance gap.

images.alt_text: Speaking at a transition finance conference on Tuesday (Oct 4), MAS' managing director Ravi Menon said that blended finance programmes are too few and too small, with global annual flows averaging less than US$10 billion since 2015.
A much greater focus on transition finance is needed to help ensure a green transition that is just and fair for the region, says Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Philippine central bank says ready to manage market disruption as peso slumps
summary: The Philippine central bank is prepared to manage potential market disruptions as the peso hits a record low of 59 to the US dollar, a 13% year-to-date decline. The decline is attributed mainly to the US dollar's strength. The bank urged market participants not to take advantage of the low peso, as it does not benefit the country. Instead, the bank plans to bring transactions into an organized and accessible formal market that offers consumer protection.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump at open
summary: European stocks surged at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 1.4% to 7,002.51 points. The eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 1.9% and 2.3%, respectively. The gains were driven by weak US manufacturing data, which tempered concerns about a Federal Reserve rate hike and sparked hopes of a potential pivot. Analysts attributed the positive sentiment to the data's signal that rising interest rates may be cooling demand for goods.
