British retailers are battling against weak consumer demand as prices hit a fresh record high this month, with brands increasingly having to pass costs on to consumers.
Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed retail sales rose 0.6 per cent in August from July to a record A$34.9 billion (S$32.4 billion).

site_title: Italian court scraps antitrust fine on Apple and Amazon
summary: An Italian administrative court has scrapped a 173.3 million euro fine on tech giants Apple and Amazon for alleged anti-competitive cooperation in the sale of Apple and Beats products. The fine was reduced from an initial 200 million euros due to a "material error" in the calculation. Both companies have been notified of the decision, with Amazon welcoming the outcome in a statement. The antitrust authority declined to comment, citing the ongoing nature of the case.

site_title: Inflation to put US auto industry in low gear
summary: The US auto industry is expected to experience a decline in new vehicle sales, primarily due to rising inflation and decreasing consumer willingness to make big-ticket purchases. Despite a shortage of cars, analysts believe the industry will react to concerns by offering more incentives, such as longer finance terms or discounts. Third-quarter sales are expected to be impacted by parts shortages, with General Motors, Ford, and Tesla set to outperform, while Japanese brands are expected to decline. New car sales are forecast to decrease by 0.9% in the third quarter, with 3,393,988 vehicles sold.

images.alt_text: Hertz’s current goal is for one-quarter of its fleet to be electric by the end of 2024.

GM and its self-driving technology unit Cruise in February disclosed they petitioned NHTSA for permission to deploy self-driving vehicles without steering wheels, mirrors, turn signals or windshield wipers.
Alternative view: The US economy is poised for significant sustained growth, with the removal of impediments to inclusive growth.

site_title: Singapore amends laws on business trusts for better governance, transparency
summary: Singapore has amended its laws on business trusts to enhance transparency and governance. The changes require unlisted business trusts to disclose beneficial owners and provide information upon request. Unitholders can now vote to remove trustee-managers with a 50% majority, down from 75%. The amendments also streamline regulatory requirements and reduce compliance costs, making the regulatory regime more efficient and robust. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan said the changes aim to mitigate the risk of illicit purposes and protect unitholders' rights.

images.alt_text: DBS, HSBC, Standard Chartered bank buildings in the CBD area.

site_title: Sterling helped by tax cut U-turn, yen steadies past 145 per US dollar
summary: The British pound rose to its highest level since September 22, touching $1.128 after the government reversed a plan to cut the highest rate of income tax. The yen weakened past 145 per US dollar, near the level where Japanese authorities intervened last month. The Bank of England's intervention is expected to be closely watched in a few weeks. The Japanese yen's decline is attributed to the country's policy of keeping interest rates pinned down, while the euro fell 0.2% to $0.97785 due to manufacturing activity decline in the eurozone.

site_title: Kim Kardashian to pay US$1.3m to SEC over crypto touting
summary: Kim Kardashian will pay the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) $1.26 million to settle allegations that she promoted a cryptocurrency token, EMAX, without disclosing she was paid. The SEC claimed she was paid $250,000 to post on her Instagram account about the token. This case highlights the importance of clear disclosure for celebrities endorsing investment opportunities, including cryptocurrencies. The SEC chair noted that investors should consider an investment's potential risks and opportunities based on their financial goals. Kardashian did not admit or deny the allegations in the settlement.

site_title: Sterling edges higher after British government tax U-turn
summary: The British pound edged higher after the government announced a U-turn on plans to cut the highest rate of income tax, reversing £2 billion of planned tax cuts. The move aims to restore investor confidence after the government's "mini-budget" triggered a crisis in the bond market, prompting the Bank of England to intervene with a £65 billion bond-buying program. The pound gained 1% to its highest level since the previous day, but analysts warn that more government action may be needed to support the currency.

images.alt_text: A protester at a demonstration against the Conservative Party's annual autumn conference organised by The People's Assembly campaign group in Birmingham, UK, on Sunday (Oct 2). At a time when the people are dealing with record inflation, the plan to scrap the cut in taxes for the country's highest earners has drawn a lot of unhappiness in and outside the Conservative party.

UK Prime Minister Liz Truss, at the Conservative Party's annual conference, also said the decision to remove the highest rate of income tax was taken by Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng and not put to her cabinet.
British finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng has vowed to publish a “credible” plan in November to reduce government debt.
FILE PHOTO: A bank employee counts pound notes at Kasikornbank in Bangkok, Thailand, October 12, 2010.  REUTERS/Sukree Sukplang/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: New register of overseas entities for properties will impact foreign-owned real estate in the UK
summary: The UK has implemented a new register of overseas entities for properties, requiring beneficial owners to register certain ownership information by January 31, 2023. The Register of Overseas Entities (ROE) is administered by Companies House and applies to entities owning or acquiring UK land, including residential and commercial properties. Failure to register can result in inability to acquire legal titles, sell, lease, or charge land, and severe criminal sanctions, including imprisonment and fines, for breaching regulations or providing misleading information. This regime differs from other transparency regimes and may impact foreign investors in the UK property market.

images.alt_text: A dramatic rise in swap rates after markets were roiled by Friday’s mini-budget suggested banks would have to substantially raise the cost of home loans in the coming weeks.

site_title: Singapore stocks start week with losses as growth fears linger; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.7% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,107.09, as growth fears lingered following Wall Street's downward trend. The decline was attributed to the continued weakness in US equity futures and the impact of property cooling measures on companies such as PropNex International. Jardine counters, however, closed with gains, while Wilmar International hit a 52-week low due to a 3.4% decline. The market saw 24 losers against 175 gainers, with a total turnover of 1.09 billion securities worth S$1.01 billion.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) rosefell to X.X percent, or XX.XX points, to X,XXX.XX as at 9.02am.

site_title: Tense run-off vote looms as Brazil’s Bolsonaro outperforms polling
summary: Brazil's presidential election entered a highly competitive and tense run-off on October 30, after far-right President Jair Bolsonaro outperformed polling in the first round, forcing a runoff against leftist ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Bolsonaro took 43.2% of votes, just shy of the majority needed, prompting a runoff. Despite Lula's 48.4% lead, Bolsonaro's strong showing has revitalized his campaign and raised concerns about a shift to the right in Latin America's largest country.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink at open
summary: European stocks sank at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.6% to 6,855.67 points. The eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined, with losses of 1.0% and 0.9% respectively. The decline follows pre-weekend losses on Wall Street and is attributed to investors digesting the UK government's U-turn on a proposed tax cut for the wealthiest earners.

site_title: Ikea’s home deliveries to be fully electric by 2025
summary: IKEA aims to make all home deliveries electric by 2025, with some cities already fully electric and many working to build infrastructure. CEO Jesper Brodin acknowledges potential challenges in certain regions, but expects customers to have electric vehicle deliveries by 2025. This move is part of IKEA's goal to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the next eight years.

images.alt_text: Ikea, the world’s biggest furniture brand, shut down its stores in March and said it would sell factories, close offices and reduce its 15,000-strong workforce in Russia.

“We remain hopeful that one day in the future, we will be able to bring back Ikea to the many people in Russia. However, today the preconditions are not in place,” Ingka Group said in a statement to Reuters on Wednesday (Jun 22).

Health authorities in the financial hub said that they imposed “temporary control measures” at the store, after they found out that a close contact of a 6-year-old boy with an asymptomatic infection had visited.

site_title: Policy reforms needed to reverse ringgit’s weakness, say industry observers
summary: The Malaysian ringgit continues to slide against the US dollar, with a 11% depreciation year-to-date. Industry observers, including the Federation of Sundry Goods Merchants Association, say structural reforms are needed to strengthen economic fundamentals and support the currency. Subsidies have helped alleviate consumer burden, but experts argue that they are a costly instrument in managing inflation and unsustainable in the long run. Policy reforms, enhanced political stability, and improved productivity are needed to move up the value chain and create a sustainable growth model, ultimately strengthening the currency.

images.alt_text: No more election play? Analysts said the excitement of the upcoming general election will be less pronounced due to political uncertainties and depleting government coffers.

Pedestrians walk past a Charles & Keith store in downtown Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Sunday, March 17, 2013. Malaysia is scheduled to release inflation data for February on March 20. Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg

site_title: The role of businesses in accelerating the energy transition
summary: Singapore's businesses play a crucial role in accelerating the energy transition to achieve net-zero emissions in a commercially viable way. The country aims to import up to 4 gigawatts of low-carbon electricity by 2035, primarily through cross-border power trade and renewable energy imports. Alternative low-carbon solutions, such as green hydrogen and ammonia, are also being developed. Businesses can contribute to the transition by championing energy efficiency, leveraging emerging technologies, and adopting novel business models that reduce upfront costs. Collaboration between industries, policymakers, and regulators is essential to grow the low-carbon energy ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Jopy Chiang assumed the role of chief executive at KIT’s trustee-manager just over a year ago.

site_title: Insurers may face up to US$57b in Hurricane Ian bills, says risk-modelling firm
summary: Insurance companies may face up to $57 billion in Hurricane Ian bills, according to risk-modelling firm Verisk. The estimate includes wind, storm surge, and inland flood losses from the Category 4 hurricane's landfalls in Florida and South Carolina. The actual loss could be higher, potentially reaching $60 billion, due to factors like litigation and social inflation. Meanwhile, an estimated 628,285 homes and businesses remain without power in Florida, and the death toll from the storm has surpassed 80.

images.alt_text: FORT MYERS BEACH, FLORIDA - OCTOBER 02: In this aerial view, the destruction left in the wake of Hurricane Ian is shown on October 02, 2022 in Fort Myers Beach, Florida. Fort Myers Beach sustained severe damage by the Category 4 hurricane which caused extensive damage to the southwest portion of Florida.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP
Natural disasters cost insurers US$120b in 2021, says Munich Re
Weather disasters cost US$20b more than last year: NGO
TOPSHOT - Waves generated by Typhoon Muifa along the coast in Hangzhou. China has higher exposure to physical hazards relating to climate change, including floods and tropical cyclones.
Australia floods leave A$1.5b of damage as thousands flee

site_title: Swedish geneticist wins Nobel Prize for Medicine for sequencing Neanderthal DNA
summary: Swedish geneticist Svante Paabo won the 2022 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for sequencing the Neanderthal genome and discovering the Denisova hominin. His research revealed genetic differences between humans and extinct hominins, showing that genes were transferred from these species to Homo sapiens around 70,000 years ago. This ancient gene flow has physiological relevance today, affecting the immune system's response to infections, and has implications for the risk of severe complications from Covid-19 in individuals with Neanderthal DNA.

images.alt_text: California scientists share Nobel for work on sense of touch

Dmitry Muratov, the Russian editor-in-chief of the independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta, on Monday auctioned off his Nobel Peace Prize gold medal for a whopping US$103.5 million to benefit children displaced by the war in Ukraine.
Journalists Maria Ressa and Dmitry Muratov win Nobel Peace Prize

site_title: 3 important things to remember as we test market lows
summary: Global stocks have declined by 20% and global bonds by 12% this year. Despite forecasts predicting a rebound, investors with a longer runway can consider investing in the market, taking advantage of lower starting points. Key takeaways include: forecasts are unreliable and should not dictate investment decisions; markets fluctuate but relative risk-return prevails over time; and investors should adopt a responsible, rational, resilient, and reasonable approach to investing, with a focus on diversified and low-cost portfolios.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse's branch office in Bern, Switzerland.

site_title: Taiwan launches first English TV channel as China pressure grows
summary: Taiwan launched its first English-language TV channel, TaiwanPlus, on October 3, 2022, as part of efforts to counter China's pressure campaign. The 24-hour channel will initially be available only on the island, but officials hope to expand its international reach in the future. TaiwanPlus aims to promote the island's values of freedom and democracy, and counter China's narrative. The launch comes as China has increased diplomatic and military pressure on Taiwan, with President Tsai Ing-wen stating that the channel will "bring Taiwan to the international community".

images.alt_text: This handout photo taken and released by the Taiwan Presidential Office on October 3, 2022 shows President Tsai Ing-wen (C) attending a ceremony to launch the new English-language TV channel TaiwanPlus in Taipei. (Photo by HANDOUT / Taiwan Presidential Office / AFP) / -----EDITORS NOTE --- RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / TAIWAN PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE" - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS  -

Kuomintang (KMT) chairman Eric Chu makes a speech during the party congress in Taiwan on Aug 28. Though the Kuomintang has been derided for being "China-friendly", it plays a key role in maintaining a channel of communication between both sides.
A Taiwan flag flutters behind a soldier statue on Dongyin island of Matsu archipelago in Taiwan, Aug 15, 2022.
An Air Force aircraft of China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) takes part in military exercises in the waters around Taiwan on Aug 4.
A cold economic war between the US and China, while not as devastating as a “hot” conflict, would be disruptive and costly for the global economy and almost all of us.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's ICT sector has grown, accounting for one-fifth of Employment Pass holders in 2021, with a 7% jump in suburban condo prices leading to a 3.4% quarterly rise in private home prices. Singtel's Optus has announced an independent review of its cybersecurity systems after a cyberattack. Changi Airport's average weekly passenger traffic reached 60% of pre-Covid levels in September. Moody's notes that while ASEAN countries face varying climate risks, regional cooperation will be key to managing their energy transition. Singapore stocks declined 0.7% at the start of the week.

site_title: Indonesia inflation hits new 7-year high after fuel price hike
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate surged to a 7-year high of 5.95% in September, driven by a 30% fuel price hike and higher transportation costs. This is slightly lower than expected. The annual core inflation rate rose to 3.21%, exceeding forecasts. The government's move to control subsidy bills and Bank Indonesia's interest rate hike of 50 basis points aim to tame inflation, which is expected to peak at 6% by year-end. Experts predict further inflationary pressures, with some revising up their inflation outlook to 6.5% by end-2022.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the government was still, however, expecting to pay large energy subsidies in the third and fourth quarters of this year.

site_title: Malaysia’s Permodalan to add infrastructure assets in diversification drive
summary: Malaysia's Permodalan Nasional (PNB) plans to add infrastructure assets to its portfolio starting next year to diversify its investments amid high inflation. The state-owned investment manager aims to increase its exposure to infrastructure, which is seen as a stable and long-term asset class. PNB's Group CEO Ahmad Zulqarnain believes the move will further diversify the portfolio and improve risk-return characteristics, as globally, funds are underallocated to infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Ahmad Zulqarnain Onn, president of Permodalan Nasional Bhd., speaks at the Milken Institute Asia Summit in Singapore, on Thursday, Sept. 29, 2022. The event started with invitation only sessions on Sept. 28, runs through September 30. Photographer: Bryan van der Beek/Bloomberg

site_title: Metro Group deepens presence in UK, Australia with acquisitions totalling S$204.7m
summary: Metro Holdings, a Singaporean retail conglomerate, has completed two acquisitions in the UK and Australia, totaling S$204.7 million. The acquisitions include a freehold retail centre in Australia and four freehold student accommodations in the UK, marking the company's efforts to deepen its presence in key markets. CEO Yip Hoong Mun stated that the joint venture partners' capability is a testament to the successful completion of the deals.

images.alt_text: The ongoing credit situation in China's property sector contributed to the S$36.3 million impairment losses taken in Metro Holdings' financial year ended March 31, 2022.

site_title: Credit Suisse risk gauge at record high, shares hit new low
summary: Credit Suisse's risk gauge has reached a record high, with its credit default swaps price rising to 293 basis points, up from 55 at the start of the year. The bank's shares have dropped 12% in Zurich and lost 60% this year, on track for the biggest annual drop in its history. CEO Ulrich Koerner's attempts to reassure markets have backfired, with some clients using the rising CDS levels to ask questions or negotiate prices. Analysts estimate the bank may need to raise 4 billion Swiss francs in capital to fund restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: Ulrich Koerner, who was named CEO in late July, has had to deal with market speculation, banker exits and capital doubts as he seeks to set a path forward for the troubled Swiss bank.

In a carefully worded memo to staff, new chief executive officer Ulrich Koerner and Chairman Axel Lehmann tried to ease internal jitters, though they stopped short of offering new information on the company’s strategic future.
Credit Suisse is also considering cutting around 5,000 jobs, about one position in 10, as part of the cost reduction drive.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bond’s November tranche offers record high interest rates
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) have hit record highs with the November tranche offering a 3.08% first-year interest rate and a 10-year average rate of 3.21%, both all-time highs. This follows a rising interest rate environment, with rates 0.4-0.5% higher than last month's rates. Approximately 72.3% of applicants were selected at random and allotted additional funds. The move is seen as a positive response to the interest rate environment and a boost to investor confidence.

site_title: SIA to add flights to Japan from Oct 30
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will launch an additional daily service to Tokyo's Haneda Airport on October 30, in addition to its existing services, as Japan lifts Covid border controls. SIA will also reinstate its Singapore to Osaka service and increase frequencies to Hong Kong, South Korea, Taiwan, and mainland China. Scoot, SIA's low-cost airline, will also increase daily flights to these cities. The move aims to capitalize on strong demand for air travel towards the year-end holiday season.

images.alt_text: Return flights from Singapore to other popular tourist spots in Japan, such as Sapporo, were also selling for above S$2,000.

site_title: Europe’s factory slump heightens recession risk as Asia mixed
summary: Europe's manufacturing industry continued to deteriorate, with the eurozone's PMI falling to 48.4 in August, marking the third consecutive month below the 50 threshold. This suggests a recession in the region is increasingly likely, particularly for the four largest economies, which also saw readings below the key level. The impact of the war in Ukraine remains a major concern, with heightened threats of power restrictions.

site_title: UK manufacturing PMI shows falling output, weak foreign demand
summary: UK manufacturing output fell for a third consecutive month in September, with orders declining for a fourth month, due to weak foreign demand. The S&P Global manufacturing PMI rose to 48.4, below the 50-level that separates growth from contraction. Manufacturers faced weak global market conditions, rising uncertainty, high transportation costs, and longer lead times, leading to cancelled orders. The UK economy is on the cusp of recession, with households and businesses struggling with rising energy costs and a volatile currency.

images.alt_text: The UK auto industry has been struggling for years, battered by crises ranging from Brexit to the Covid-19 pandemic.
Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng on Sep 23 unveiled £45 billion (S$69.9 billion) worth of tax cuts and other measures to revive the ailing UK economy.

Workers at the Newport Wafer Fab, owned by Nexperia Holding BV, in Newport, Britain on Aug 18, 2022. Britain's manufacturers association downgraded its forecast for manufacturing growth for next year to just 0.6 per cent, down from the 1.7 per cent forecast in June.

site_title: When the Fed stops trying
summary: The US Federal Reserve appears to have abandoned its efforts to find a safe path between secular stagnation and stagflation, instead opting for a path towards secular stagnation. After two 75-basis-point interest-rate hikes in July and September, Fed officials have signaled additional hikes, suggesting a loss of confidence in navigating between the two risks. This shift may lead to another lost half-decade of growth, widening income inequalities, and potentially even a return to a scenario with monetary policy stuck at the zero lower bound.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced that it will raise interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, Sept 21, 2022.
Deputy US Treasury chief Wally Adeyemo said there was “a path” to reduce price pressures while maintaining momentum in the US economy and a healthy labour market.

site_title: Manhattan’s charging sites for electric vehicles now outnumber petrol stations 10 to 1
summary: Manhattan now has over 320 publicly accessible electric vehicle charging locations, outnumbering its 29 remaining gas stations by more than 10 to 1. The US Department of Energy reports this, as gas stations still dominate citywide with 697 locations. Charging sites are catching up, with the country's largest EV-charging company, ChargePoint Holdings, predicting that petrol stations will eventually become obsolete due to real estate prices and declining sales. New York City officials aim to deploy more EV chargers across all five boroughs, with plans to have 400,000 EVs on city streets by 2030 and 1.6 million by 2050.

images.alt_text: Hertz plans to electrify a quarter of its rental car fleet by the end of 2024.
The production and sale of more electric and hybrid vehicles is also a key part of the plans set out in March by Stellantis chief executive Carlos Tavares.

site_title: A better way to protect personal data
summary: A major data security breach at Optus in Australia has highlighted the need for improved cybersecurity measures, with the company facing potential fines and a class action suit. The breach exposed 9.8 million Australians' personal data, including sensitive information such as passport numbers and Medicare details. The incident raises questions about why corporations hold so much customer data, with some arguing that governments should take over databases to protect personal information. A proposed overhaul of cybersecurity laws in Australia may include stricter regulations and the taxpayer paying for data storage, but a more radical solution involves encrypting and offline storage of client databases.

images.alt_text: The government blamed Singtel-owned Optus for the breach, which affected 10 million accounts, and urged the company to speed up its notification to the 10,200 affected customers.
Singtel said its Australian subisdiary Optus is working closely with identity document-issuing authorities to determine the appropriate next steps for its customers.

site_title: Porsche shares drop below IPO price within days of  debut
summary: Porsche shares dropped below their initial public offering (IPO) price of 82.50 euros, trading at 81 euros, within days of their debut on September 29. The sports-car maker's listing raised roughly 9.4 billion euros for parent company Volkswagen, defying market pressure. Porsche CEO Oliver Blume attributed the company's resilience to its strong financial profile, stating investors prefer stable businesses. The decline was in line with the Euro Stoxx 50 Index.

site_title: Bros fails at the box office, Smile arrives at No 1
summary: Bros, the first major studio-driven film to focus on homosexuality, opened to an estimated $4.8 million in ticket sales, significantly lower than expected. Despite mostly positive reviews, it ranked fourth at the weekend box office. In contrast, horror movie Smile took the top spot with $22 million in ticket sales. Industry analysts point to the film's marketing strategy, which may have alienated both straight and gay audiences, as a possible reason for the disappointing results.

images.alt_text: Australian actress Caitlin Stasey attends the premiere of the movie 'Smile' during Beyond Fest at Aero Theatre in Santa Monica, California, Sept 27, 2022.
DON'T WORRY DARLING movie still : Don't Worry Darling

site_title: German manufacturing shrinks in September as new orders slump: PMI
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector contracted for a third consecutive month in September, with S&P Global's PMI falling to 47.8, its lowest since June 2020. The decline was driven by a slump in new orders, with the index dropping to 39.1. Rising energy costs and the shutdown of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, which has led to a decrease in demand, are major contributors to the downturn. Economists warn that the pass-through of higher costs will become increasingly difficult, squeezing margins.

site_title: China and Taiwan: What role for the Kuomintang?
summary: China and Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) party chairman Eric Chu emphasized the importance of maintaining a channel of communication between the two sides to prevent conflict. Following a visit by US Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, KMT vice-chairman Andrew Hsia visited the mainland, meeting with officials to discuss issues such as job scams, telecoms fraud, and restoring flights between Taiwan's offshore islands and the mainland. Chu views the KMT's "China-friendly" reputation as beneficial for dialogue with Beijing, and is eyeing the 2024 presidential election. He reiterated the party's commitment to "principled dialogue" with Beijing to avoid conflict.

images.alt_text: Eric Chu, the chairman of Kuomintang (KMT) makes a speech during the party congress in Taipei, Taiwan, August 28, 2022. REUTERS/I-Hwa Cheng
China has warned America about its recent moves in support of Taiwan, including President Biden's remarks on defending the island in the event of an attack by Beijing.
The People's Liberation Army's Eastern Theatre Command said on its official Weibo account its troops will keep a close eye on changes in the situation in the Taiwan strait.

site_title: Hong Kong’s yuan-denominated stock trading plan gets support
summary: The Hong Kong government's plan to trade yuan-denominated shares for companies listed in the city has received support from major businesses, despite concerns over the weakening Chinese currency. The proposal, set to be submitted to lawmakers by the end of the year, aims to develop Hong Kong as an offshore yuan-funding hub and add new liquidity. Key supporters include Bank of China, Ping An Insurance Group, and Sun Hung Kai Properties. The plan may reduce currency risk for onshore investors and support yuan internationalization, but the current drop in yuan may make it less appealing to traders.

images.alt_text: Issuance in Hong Kong of corporate debt denominated in the offshore Chinese yuan has surged 45 per cent to US$21.7 billion so far this year, the most for the period since 2014.
Hong Kong has been seeking to build itself as a hub for offshore yuan trading by introducing more products denominated in the Chinese currency.

site_title: Financial stability keeps Thai rates from rising fast
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) has retained its annual growth outlook for this year at 3.3% and kept interest rates from rising too fast, citing the need for financial stability. The central bank aims to balance its three objectives: maintaining financial stability, controlling inflation, and supporting economic growth. BOT deputy governor Mathee Supapongse emphasized the need to protect indebted groups and prevent financial instability. The Thai economy is still recovering from the pandemic and inflation is expected to ease, with the central bank sticking to a gradual approach to monetary policy normalization.

images.alt_text: Rising costs and slower global demand were among factors to be monitored, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said in a statement.

Despite the hike, the BOT continues to be among the least hawkish in Asia, where many counterparts including India and the Philippines moved early and aggressively to tighten policy amid high inflation and weakening currencies.

site_title: Inflation in Europe now looks even less transitory than in US
summary: Euro area inflation has surpassed US inflation for two consecutive months, with the eurozone's inflation rate reaching 10% in September, compared to 9.1% in the US. Economists predict that European inflation will linger around 5% for a year, while US inflation is expected to drop to around 3%. The energy crisis, particularly Russia's invasion of Ukraine, has driven up energy prices, leading to a broader impact on the economy. European central bankers face a challenge in addressing the root cause of inflation, and their policy decisions may inadvertently hurt the economy.

images.alt_text: The change of tone comes as surging energy bills are threatening to put companies out of business and runaway inflation is leaving consumers struggling to pay their bills.

In a speech at Stanford University, World Bank President David Malpass said there was an increased likelihood of recession in Europe, while China’s growth was slowing sharply and US economic output had contracted in the first half of the year.

site_title: Asean faces varied climate risks, but cooperative stance will stand grouping in good stead: Moody’s
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that ASEAN economies face varying climate risks due to industrial structures and carbon-intensive electricity generation. Despite disparate policy approaches and commitments to curb emissions, regional cooperation will be crucial in managing energy transition challenges. The agency highlights the importance of developing common approaches to carbon pricing and sustainable finance, which will aid the grouping in overcoming common challenges such as physical climate risk and carbon transition costs.

images.alt_text: China will remain the main contributor to Asia’s non-hydropower renewables capacity growth - thanks to its robust solar and wind equipment manufacturing industry, says Fitch Solutions. (PHOTO: REUTERS)
Emerging economies, in particular, requires extra help in the form of investments in order to wean national dependencies on cheap fossil fuels used domestically and exported, said researchers.
A smart energy meter, used to monitor gas and electricity use, is pictured in a home in London. The world is currently facing its most severe energy crisis since the 1970s.

site_title: Hong Kong: Battered stocks hit 11-year low
summary: Hong Kong's stock market hit an 11-year low on Monday, closing at 17,079.51 after shedding 0.83% or 143.32 points. The Hang Seng Index has lost over 25% this year, with Chinese stocks particularly hard hit due to strict zero-Covid measures and concerns over China's economic health. The market's decline is attributed to various factors, including a global energy crisis, the Russia-Ukraine war, and inflation.

site_title: Shell to invest in second Malaysia oil, gas project in a month
summary: Shell is investing in phase 4 of the Gumusut-Kakap-Geronggong-Jagus East (GKGJE) deepwater offshore development project in Malaysia, with production expected to start in late 2024. This marks the company's second investment in Malaysia's oil and gas sector in a month, following a similar project with Petronas to develop the Rosmari-Marjoram gas fields. The investment aims to revive declining output of Kimanis crude, Malaysia's flagship export grade, and increase production capacity by adding 25,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Risk rises with Russian annexations in Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's announcement of the annexation of four Ukrainian regions has increased the risk of a long and potentially catastrophic war. The annexations, which cover around 15-20% of Ukraine, have turned the conflict into a "war of attrition" with Russia likely to defend its territory using any means necessary, including nuclear weapons. The move has sparked widespread condemnation, including from the US, EU, and Turkey, with the EU announcing an eighth package of sanctions. The annexations have also led to increased fears of escalation, with Russia's military mobilization and partial annexation of Ukrainian territory.

images.alt_text: People approach screens located near the Kremlin and Red Square before the live broadcast of a ceremony to declare the annexation of the Russian-controlled territories of four Ukraine's Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions.

Russian Ambassador to the United Nations Vasily Nebenzya speaks as members of the United Nations Security Council convene to discuss damage to two Russian gas pipelines to Europe, in New York, Sept 30, 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound after sharp selling
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded after sharp selling on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.07% to 26,215.79. Despite concerns over US monetary tightening, investors picked up bargains, driving the broader Topix index up 0.63% to 1,847.58. The rebound follows a previous day's losses, with the benchmark index falling earlier. The gains were attributed to investors seeking value amid ongoing market volatility.

site_title: Changi Airport’s average weekly passenger traffic reaches 60% of pre-Covid levels in first week of September
summary: Changi Airport's average weekly passenger traffic has recovered to 60% of pre-Covid-19 levels, with nearly two-thirds of pre-pandemic flights also operating. Transport Minister S Iswaran attributes the growth to easing border restrictions in Hong Kong, Japan, and Taiwan. However, China's border reopening status remains uncertain, posing a significant challenge. The airport has ramped up manpower to handle the increase in flights, with a plan to recruit 4,000 more workers by year-end to reach 90% of pre-Covid-19 levels.

images.alt_text: The airport reached 56 per cent of its 2019 passenger numbers in August and the government expects flights will reach 80 per cent of pre-pandemic levels by the end of the year.

Singapore will resume operations of the fourth terminal at its main airport on Sep 13, the Changi Airport Group (CAG) said on Friday (Jul 22), as the Southeast Asian travel hub recovers from the more than two years of Covid-19 pandemic-induced disruptions.

Linda Teo, country manager for ManpowerGroup Singapore, said aviation jobs that are customer-facing or related to operations and logistics may be difficult to fill in Singapore as the candidates for these roles are also in demand in various industries.

site_title: Rich kids’ boot camps return as private banks woo next-gen wealth
summary: Private banks in Asia are resuming in-person events for the children of wealthy clients, a crucial tool for retaining loyalty and building relationships as trillions of dollars in wealth are expected to shift to the next generation. Events, such as boot camps and dinners, are being held with tweaks to safety protocols due to the pandemic. The aim is to demonstrate value and build rapport with the affluent young, who will likely inherit significant wealth in the coming decade.

images.alt_text: Some observers think Asean banks will increasingly face a reckoning as the financial impact of climate change unfolds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.99 points to 1,397.62. The market saw 1.789 billion lots traded worth RM1.449 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 530 to 285.

site_title: Truss drops tax cut for top UK earners to fend off rebellion
summary: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss dropped a plan to cut taxes for the country's highest earners just 10 days after announcing it, citing a "distraction" and reversing the decision amid mounting rebellion within her Conservative Party. The move comes as the UK faces record inflation, and the plan to scrap the 45% income tax rate had drawn widespread unhappiness. Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng announced the reversal in a tweet, and the pound jumped 1% before giving up gains. The U-turn is a major embarrassment for Truss and Kwarteng, who have faced criticism for their economic approach and are facing speculation about their future.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Liz Truss, at the Conservative Party's annual conference, also said the decision to remove the highest rate of income tax was taken by Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng and not put to her cabinet.
British finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng has vowed to publish a “credible” plan in November to reduce government debt.
Liz Truss delivers her first speech as UK's prime minister outside 10 Downing Street in London on Tuesday, Sept. 6, 2022.

site_title: Asia’s factories paint uneven recovery picture in September
summary: Asia's factories displayed a mixed recovery picture in September, with manufacturing hubs in the south showing resilience amid China's growth slowdown. Key supply chain hubs such as Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines saw improvement in Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) readings, while Taiwan and Japan saw a drop in output and sales. North Asia's PMIs showed more pain, with Taiwan's PMI slumping to its worst since May 2020. The mixed results reflect the ongoing impact of China's economic slowdown and supply-chain disruptions on trade-reliant neighbors.

images.alt_text: The industry is also flush with potentially available assets, after a boom in infrastructure development fed by rapid economic growth.

site_title: Amid rising rates, tight borrowing limits a blessing for Reits, homebuyers
summary: Singapore's Reit and homebuyers markets are more robust due to tight borrowing limits, mitigating the risk of catastrophic mortgage defaults. Regulatory limits cap Reits' and individuals' debt, with Reits limited to 45% of deposited property and individuals limited to 75% LTV. These limits help prevent overly leveraged homebuyers from defaulting on mortgage payments. Despite rising interest rates, Reits and homeowners can benefit from being prudent with debt, as some have locked in fixed-rate loans or spread out debt maturities, giving them more confidence in the markets.

images.alt_text: HDB flats in the Queenstown area and Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) as viewed from Block 90 Tanglin Halt on May 27, 2021.
Ascendas Reit spent S$1.2 billion in the first quarter acquiring 11 data centres in Europe and 1-5 Thomas Holt Drive in Sydney’s Macquarie Park. Acquisitions are an effective way to grow Reits' DPU.
The daily Sora rate shot up by about 0.3 percentage points on Friday following the US Federal Reserve’s decision to raise interest rates by 0.75 per cent on Wednesday.

site_title: Shopback secures a further US$80m in funding from 65 Equity Partners
summary: ShopBack, a rewards platform, has secured US$80 million in funding from 65 Equity Partners, bringing the total funding in its Series F round to US$160 million. The investment will be used to launch new products, develop merchant solutions, and expand to more markets, with some funds earmarked for a potential public listing. 65 Equity Partners will join ShopBack's board of directors and support the startup's continued growth and development, aligning with their mandate of supporting high-growth businesses.

site_title: US home prices now posting biggest monthly drops since 2009
summary: US home prices have posted the largest monthly declines since 2009, with median home prices falling 0.98% in August and 1.05% in July, according to Black Knight. This marks two consecutive months of significant pullbacks after nearly two years of record-breaking growth. Rising mortgage rates, driving affordability to its lowest level since the 1980s, are contributing to the decline.

site_title: Australia: Banks drag shares lower, focus on RBA decision
summary: The Australian market slipped 0.3% to 6,456.9, weighed down by banks and tech stocks ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's expected 50-basis point interest rate hike to combat inflation. Financials fell to their lowest in three months, while technology stocks retreated 1.3%. Energy stocks, however, advanced 1% on strong crude prices. The benchmark closed 1.2% lower on Friday, marking its worst month since June.

images.alt_text: Australik closed 1.2 per cent lower on Friday, wrapping up its worst month since June.

site_title: Japan ready to take ‘decisive’ steps on yen:  finance minister
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned that the country is ready to take "decisive" steps in the foreign exchange market if the yen's recent sharp declines persist. Japan intervened in the market last month, spending up to 2.8 trillion yen (S$27.73 billion) to prop up the yen, which fell to a 24-year low near 146 yen. Suzuki emphasized the importance of stable currency movements, stating that Japan will take action as needed to prevent speculative moves. The intervention was seen as a response to investors selling off the Japanese currency.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on September 24, 2022 shows Japanese 10,000 yen notes (apprx. 69 USD) on display in Tokyo. - Japan's finance ministry on September 22 intervened in the currency market to bolster the yen, which has plummeted against the US dollar in recent months on the widening policy gap between the US and Japanese central banks. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia’s weakening ringgit not reflecting state of economy: central bank
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus, has stated that the country's weakening ringgit, which has lost 11.6% against the dollar this year, is not a reflection of the nation's economy. Despite the currency's decline, the economy is considered robust, with a healthy labor market and a resilient financial system. The central bank prioritizes sustaining economic growth with price stability, aiming to strengthen economic fundamentals and avoid measures like capital controls or re-pegging the ringgit.

site_title: Blackstone, KKR defy global private debt slump with bets on Asia
summary: Direct-lending behemoths Blackstone and KKR are expanding their presence in Asia's private-debt sector, defying a global slump. Blackstone aims to increase private credit assets to at least $5 billion, while KKR launched its first Asia-oriented private credit fund worth $1.25 billion. The companies prioritize lending to companies with growing sectors, such as tech and software, in the face of market volatility and uncertainty. Despite a slowdown in new private-debt funds and a drop in total raised funds, investors are increasingly allocating to these funds, driven by their competitiveness in sectors where banks once lent.

images.alt_text: Blackstone, in a statement, said it and Home Partners continue to actively buy homes in more than 20 of the country’s highest-growth markets.

site_title: Malaysia seen pushing ‘feel good’ budget ahead of elections
summary: Malaysia is expected to deliver a slightly expansionary budget ahead of a general election, likely in October, to boost voter support. The government plans to spend a record 80 billion ringgit (S$24.7 billion) in subsidies this year and next year due to rising global inflation. Economists predict more cash handouts and goodies, but with limited fiscal discipline due to ballooning subsidies. The budget will be the last before the next polls, and the government may refrain from new taxes to maintain voter support.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Home Affairs Ministry is looking at attracting at least 1,000 participants in the first year after the Premium Visa Programme kickstart on Oct 1, 2022.

site_title: HRnetGroup acquires majority stake in local fintech Octomate
summary: HRnetGroup acquired a majority 51% stake in fintech startup Octomate for S$676,530.61. The acquisition will integrate Octomate's instant payment solution with HRnetGroup's Ease Works app, offering earned wage access to contractors at no cost. Founded in 2019, Octomate provides cloud-based workforce management software built on blockchain technology. The deal is expected to complete by October 10 and will see Octomate remain an independent brand under HRnetGroup.

images.alt_text: Together with RFT’s 3 business leaders cum co-owners, HRnetGroup will also commit another million to fund further expansion in RFT.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Starhub to ‘buy’ on reopening potential
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded its rating on StarHub to "buy" from "hold" due to the company's potential benefits from the global economic recovery, particularly the reopening of the Chinese economy. The research house maintains a target price of S$1.32, implying a potential upside of over 20% from the current share price of S$1.12. Analyst Kevin Tan expects StarHub's earnings to be sluggish in the second half of 2022 due to rising operational costs, but is optimistic about the company's prospects for growth and dividend yield.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders eye US jobs, earnings
summary: Asian markets fluctuated at the start of the week as traders await US jobs data and corporate earnings season, which may highlight the impact of surging inflation and interest rates. Hong Kong and Sydney fell, while Tokyo rose, despite a decline in Bank of Japan's confidence survey. Oil prices rose 3% amid speculation of a major output cut by OPEC producers. The US Federal Reserve is expected to unveil a fourth rate hike at its November meeting, with Fed officials indicating borrowing costs won't be lowered until late 2023 or 2024.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index shed 1.00 per cent or 172.58 points to 17,050.25.
The Straits Times Index (STI) rosefell to X.X percent, or XX.XX points, to X,XXX.XX as at 9.02am.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.00% or 172.58 points to 17,050.25 on Monday, October 3, amid investors' focus on the US jobs report and upcoming earnings season. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for a national holiday. The decline is attributed to global market trends, with European stocks also down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.37 points or 0.17% to 1,392.26. The decline was due to a lower trading volume of 187.73 million lots worth RM82.01 million, with 282 losers outnumbering 114 gainers.

site_title: Sony betting big on next VR headset with increased production plan
summary: Sony plans to produce 2 million units of its PlayStation VR2 headset by March next year, defying the global economic malaise. The company's ambitious production plan follows the successful mass production of the headset, which began in September without supply chain constraints. Sony's roadmap anticipates greater popularity than its preceding PlayStation VR goggles, with a planned release in early 2023 coinciding with supply chain relief for the PlayStation 5 console. Despite economic concerns, Sony remains committed to boosting the PSVR2's launch with new VR titles and marketing efforts.

images.alt_text: The PS5 has been plagued by supply chain and logistics snarls since its debut in November 2020. Before the launch, Ito wrote on the PlayStation Blog about the challenges of developing the console through the pandemic.
The Columbia Pictures’ Aquaverse will open on Oct 11 in partnership with local developer Amazon Falls, according to a joint statement on Thursday (Sep 15).

site_title: Chinese property stocks watched as banks urged to offer funding
summary: Chinese property stocks surged as the country's financial regulators urged state-owned banks to offer at least $85 billion in financing to the battered property sector. The move, part of a series of easing measures, aims to arrest a property slump weighing on China's economy. Local governments have also been encouraged to ease curbs on homebuying, and lenders are required to meet reasonable financing needs of developers. Analysts see this as a positive step for lenders and developers, with the worst of property tightening likely behind China.

images.alt_text: China’s property market crisis worsened this summer, with official data showing home prices, sales and investment all falling in August, adding pressure on the world’s second-largest economy.
Following the rate cut, the 5-year-and-below interest rate for first-time buyers borrowing from China government’s housing provident fund to finance a home purchase would stay at 2.6 per cent.

site_title: Gold firms as dollar softens, but rate-hike fears limit gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,665.29 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar, but gains were limited by central banks' aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Federal Reserve, led by Lael Brainard, reaffirmed its "higher-for-longer" interest rate strategy, making gold less appealing. Despite this, the physical gold market in India saw a premium increase ahead of festivities, while Chinese premiums remained elevated.

images.alt_text: Although gold is considered a hedge against inflation, a series of aggressive US rate hikes this year has dented on the non-yielding metal’s appeal and lifted the dollar to a 2-decade peak.

site_title: Google pulls plug on translate app for China in ongoing retreat
summary: Google has shut down its Translate app for China, marking the end of one of the last services the US giant operates in the country's massive internet market. The decision comes after low usage, following Google's 2010 withdrawal of its search engine due to China's internet censorship. The move reflects Google's ongoing retreat from the Chinese market, which it had explored through a dedicated website and smartphone app since 2017. The service's web page now redirects to Google's Hong Kong translation site.

site_title: Philippine peso may slide to an all-time low as trade deficit widens
summary: The Philippine peso is expected to slide to an all-time low of around 62 against the dollar as the country's trade deficit widens, with imports boosting demand for dollars and leading to elevated trade deficits. The currency has slumped 13% this year, and policymakers are considering more aggressive interest-rate hikes and draining liquidity to stem losses. The central bank's inflation data this week will help determine the need for further rate hikes, with some predicting the peso could hit 60 by early November.

images.alt_text: Felipe Medalla sees inflation returning within its 2-4 per cent goal next year, saying it will be possibly closer to 3 per cent than 4 per cent.

site_title: Australia: Shares reverse early gains on recession fears
summary: Australian shares closed 1.2% lower on Friday, marking their worst month since June, amid fears of a recession due to aggressive interest rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.87% to 6,417.6, with technology and financials sectors taking a hit. Energy stocks, however, rose 0.2% as oil prices jumped ahead of an Opec+ meeting. The decline was also attributed to the resignation of Energy Resources Of Australia's chairman, material cost overruns at Rio Tinto, and changes to the board of asset manager Janus Henderson.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.2 per cent lower on Friday.

site_title: Rising share of EP holders in infocomms, but local PMET numbers up too: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's ICT sector has grown, accounting for 1/5 of Employment Pass holders in 2021, up from 1/6 in 2016. Despite this, the sector also saw an increase in local professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs), Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng noted. This suggests that the entry of foreign talent is not a zero-sum game, where local talent suffers.

images.alt_text: Safeguards will be put in place for the Overseas Networks and Expertise pass, said Minister of Manpower Tan See Leng in a ministerial statement where he also addressed the target nature of the government's recent work pass enhancements.

site_title: Factories making towels and bedsheets are shutting in Pakistan
summary: Pakistan's textile mills, which produce products for the US and Europe, are shutting down due to a shortage of good quality cotton, high fuel costs, and poor payment recovery from buyers in flood-hit areas. Over 100 smaller mills have suspended operations, affecting 10 million people and 8% of the economy. The sector faces challenges from high inflation, falling currency reserves, and a 10% decline in demand for their products by December. Cotton production is expected to slump to 6.5 million bales, forcing the nation to spend $3 billion importing cotton from other countries.

images.alt_text: Monsoon rains, which were delayed in parts of India’s northern and eastern rice producing regions, have improved over the last couple of weeks, boosting crop prospects in the world’s largest rice supplier, traders said.

site_title: EC World Reit proposes asset sale for loan repayment, to make special distribution
summary: EC World Reit is proposing to divest its indirect interests in Bei Gang Logistics and Chongxian Port Logistics for 1.2 billion and 820 million renminbi, respectively, to repay existing loans. The transaction will generate 1.3 billion renminbi in proceeds, with 450.9 million renminbi paid to unitholders as a special distribution. The divestment is expected to reduce the Reit's aggregate loan principal by at least 25% and is aimed at maintaining liquidity amid continued economic pressure in China.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX
The announcement comes after EC World Reit's auditors, PwC, had highlighted a material uncertainty in its FY2021 financial statements on the Reit's ability to continue as a going concern.
The city of Shanghai finally re-opened on 1 June while some districts of Beijing are allowed to return to work. e

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, extending falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.89%, or 231.30 points, to 25,705.91, while the Topix index fell 0.73%, or 13.48 points, to 1,822.46. Fears of global recession and monetary tightening led to the decline.

site_title: Singtel’s Optus says IDs of over two million customers compromised in cyberattack
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary Optus has confirmed that a cyberattack in late September resulted in the leak of personal identification data of 2.1 million customers, including 1.2 million with compromised current identification numbers and 900,000 with expired identification information. The breach contained details such as email addresses, dates of birth, and phone numbers. Singtel has appointed Deloitte to review Optus' cybersecurity systems and is working closely with identity document-issuing authorities to determine next steps for customers. The company faces potential fines and costs, estimated to be between $420 million to $560 million, and is preparing for a potential class action.

images.alt_text: Optus must pay the cost of replacing the passports and drivers' licences of millions of customers whose personal information was stolen in one of the country’s biggest data breaches, the Australian government said on Thursday.
The government blamed Singtel-owned Optus for the breach, which affected 10 million accounts, and urged the company to speed up its notification to the 10,200 affected customers.
Optus said last week that home addresses, drivers’ licences and passport numbers of up to 10 million customers were compromised in one of Australia’s biggest data breaches.

The group’s Q1 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) fell 2 per cent to S$977 million from S$997 million, while operating revenue for the quarter slipped 5.6 per cent from S$3.8 billion to S$3.6 billion in Q1 2022.

site_title: Taking bilateral ties to a higher level
summary: Germany and Singapore aim to deepen their economic ties through enhanced cooperation in innovation, sustainability, and digitalization. Ambassador Dr. Norbert Riedel announced a bilateral framework agreement to identify priority areas, share best practices, and set up regular exchanges. The plan includes a bilateral sustainability partnership to tackle climate change, a bilateral digital dialogue, and a proposed climate club for like-minded countries. Germany plans to use Singapore's strategic position in the Indo-Pacific region, leveraging its gateway to South-east Asia and the Asean region's growing economic bloc. German companies are committed to innovation and sustainability, with several launching research and training cooperations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Working together towards carbon-neutral societies

site_title: Growth in HDB resale prices slows slightly, up 2.4% in Q3: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 2.4% in Q3 2022, marking the 10th consecutive quarter of growth, according to flash estimates. Year-over-year, prices have increased by 11.4%, but slowed slightly compared to the previous quarter. Experts attribute the slowdown to rising interest rates and inflation, with some predicting prices may moderate further in Q4. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to launch up to 23,000 new flats in 2023, including around 9,500 BTO flats in November.

images.alt_text: Flats located in non-mature estate continued to lead resale volumes, comprising more than half (56.7 per cent) of transactions, while mature estate transactions made up the remaining 43.4 per cent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EC World Reit, ESR-Logos Reit, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit
summary: EC World Reit plans to dispose of indirect interests in two Stage 1 assets worth 1.2 billion renminbi and 820 million renminbi. The proceeds will be used to repay existing loans, with 450.9 million renminbi to be distributed to unitholders. The Reit's units ended flat at S$0.50.

site_title: MS Holdings chairman offers to privatise company at S$0.07 per share
summary: MS Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, has announced a voluntary unconditional cash offer to privatize the company at S$0.07 per share. The offer represents a 16.7% premium over the previous closing price and a 25% premium over the 12-month average price. The offer is made by the company's executive chairman, Ng Chui Hwa.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange has taken steps in response to the trend of delistings in recent years, including allowing dual-class capital structures and SPACs in the market.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within Frasers Hospitality Trust.

Moya Asia said the privatisation offer would provide an opportunity for shareholders to realise their investments amidst low trading liquidity, allow for greater management flexibility and save costs of maintaining listing.
This comes after the offeror had on Sept 1 raised the offer price to S$0.188 per share, from the initial S$0.168 per share announced on Jul 8.

site_title: Australian house prices drop as steep RBA rate hikes sour demand
summary: Australian house prices dropped for an eighth straight month in September, with Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane experiencing declines of 1.8%, 1.1%, and 1.7% respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points, adding pressure to the already weakening property market. While some signs of improvement, such as higher auction clearance rates and consumer sentiment, suggest the worst of the downturn may be over, economists warn that further rate hikes could accelerate the decline in housing values.

images.alt_text: Australia has been a rare beneficiary of Russia’s aggression towards Ukraine that sent commodity and energy prices soaring, pushing its terms of trade to new highs.
Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed retail sales rose 0.6 per cent in August from July to a record A$34.9 billion (S$32.4 billion).

site_title: Japan’s business mood worsens in Q3: BOJ tankan
summary: Japan's business mood worsened in Q3, according to the Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey, with the headline index for big manufacturers declining to +8 in September from +9 in June. Service-sector sentiment improved slightly, while retailers remained pessimistic due to rising costs. The country's big manufacturers expect business conditions to improve in three months, while non-manufacturers anticipate a worsening outlook. The weakening yen and global economic slowdown concerns weigh on the export-reliant economy, which is still recovering from the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Factory output gained a seasonally adjusted 2.7 per cent in August from a month earlier.
The intervention, conducted after the yen slumped to a 24-year low of nearly 146 to the US dollar, triggered a sharp bounce of more than 5 yen per US dollar from that low.

site_title: ‘Fans died in players’ arms,’ says coach at Indonesia football tragedy
summary: Indonesian football coach Javier Roca described the stadium disaster as "the most terrible thing" after at least 125 fans died in a stampede at the Kanjuruhan stadium in Denpasar, Bali. Fans stormed the pitch after Arema FC lost 3-2 to rivals Persebaya Surabaya, with police firing tear gas that allegedly fatally over-stepped the mark. Coach Roca said fans died in the arms of players, with many victims trampled or choked to death. Police described the unrest as "riots" and accused the stadium of being woefully under-prepared.

images.alt_text: Indonesia announced that at least 130 people were killed and 180 others were injured after Indonesian soccer fans entered the pitch causing panic and stampede on Oct 1.

site_title: A 7% jump in suburban condo prices leads a 3.4% qoq rise in Singapore’s Q3 private home prices: URA
summary: Singapore's Q3 private home prices rose 3.4% due to strong sales at new launches in the suburbs, driven by new benchmark prices. Non-landed home prices in the outside central region surged 7% quarter-over-quarter, the fastest pace since 2009. The median OCR new sale non-landed price reached S$2,092 psf. Despite government cooling measures, analysts project a 7-9% growth in overall private residential prices for 2022, driven by low inventory and limited launches.

images.alt_text: pixgenerics/ST20220629_202283358097/Ng Sor Luan/Generic photos of HDB flats for story on home loans rates increasing.

ST20211117_202146255160 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of private housing in Holland Road with the backdrop of D'Leedon condominium towering over properties in the central part of Singapore on 17 Nov 2021.

site_title: Rain delays start of Singapore Grand Prix
summary: The Singapore Formula One Grand Prix has been delayed by an hour due to heavy rain. The original start time of 8 pm has been pushed back to 9:05 pm. Charles Leclerc will start from pole position for Ferrari, while Max Verstappen will start eighth, potentially denting his hopes of securing a second successive title. Procedures are underway to clear standing water from the track.

site_title: BT Explains: What is limited assurance?
summary: Limited assurance is a type of external assurance for non-financial disclosures on sustainability and climate-related conduct, which can influence the degree of confidence in a company's sustainability and climate-related disclosures. It is a less rigorous form of assurance compared to reasonable assurance, with a lower level of evidence collected and a higher risk of material misstatement. Most companies opt for limited assurance due to cost considerations, but it is becoming increasingly important as more businesses seek external assurance for their sustainability reports. A study by KPMG found that 71% of the world's 250 largest companies have third-party assurance of sustainability data.

images.alt_text: Widely accepted global standards may boost the utility of independent assurance but, as long as companies can pick and choose what to subject to such assurance, the risk of greenwashing remains, says Professor Mak Yuen Teen. (PHOTO: MAK YUEN TEEN)

Leading Singapore organisations have raised concerns about aspects of draft sustainability- and climate-related disclosure standards by the global accounting body International Sustainability Standards Board.
Getting the ISSB's expected global standards on sustainability and climate disclosures to reflect local realities will be a complex undertaking.

site_title: Amazon boasts 25% increase in UK marketplace sellers
summary: Amazon has seen a 25% increase in UK marketplace sellers, with 85,000 small and medium-sized businesses now selling on its platform, responsible for over 950 million product sales. This represents 1,750 sales per minute. The growth is attributed to Amazon's efforts to promote small businesses, despite facing antitrust scrutiny in the UK, where the Competition and Markets Authority is investigating suspected breaches of competition law.

site_title: Catalans compete to build the biggest human towers in Spain
summary: Catalans gathered in Tarragona for the annual human tower competition, "castells", which attracted 11,000 spectators. The Vilafranca team took the top spot, constructing a 10-tier tower that reached 13 meters high, earning the 16,000 euro prize. The event, held every two years, requires teams to build the highest and most complicated tower by standing on each other's shoulders, with a focus on skill and coordination, particularly among younger team members. The competition saw 71 people receive medical attention, with 13 taken to hospital.

images.alt_text: Red Bull Racing's Dutch driver Max Verstappen leaves after the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Oct 2, 2022.

site_title: China tightens lending taps, leaving African markets vulnerable
summary: China, Africa's largest bilateral creditor, is scaling back lending in the region amid its worsening growth woes. This move leaves developing countries vulnerable, as rising interest rates and shrinking liquidity have already sent African bonds crashing and currencies plummeting. The loss of cheap Chinese funding threatens to push reluctant governments into the arms of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank for balance of payments support, potentially restricting commercial borrowing and requiring more comprehensive debt relief.

images.alt_text: Asia’s third-largest economy not only offers cheap labour but also a talent pool of largely English-speaking workers, even though rickety infrastructure keeps many investors away.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 Index treading on thin ice as it faces multiple headwinds
summary: The Nasdaq 100 Index is facing multiple headwinds, including persistent inflation, hawkish central banks, and geopolitical issues, which may lead to a decline in the fourth quarter. The index is on track for a loss of over 9% in September and is headed for its worst performance since 2002. Despite a potential relief rally in October, the Nasdaq 100 may continue its downtrend unless inflation is contained, with a possible support region at 11,000-11,200 and a 50-day EMA resistance level at 12,200-12,300.

site_title: India has a 100t rupee plan to snatch factories from China
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has launched a 100 trillion rupee (S$1.8 trillion) mega project called PM Gati Shakti, a digital platform that combines 16 ministries to streamline infrastructure projects. The goal is to implement projects without delays and cost overruns, making India a more competitive manufacturing hub, especially compared to China. The project aims to identify new production clusters, link them to the nation's railway network, and improve logistics. With China still closed to the outside world, India seeks to attract global companies through its affordable labor, talent pool, and digital platform.

images.alt_text: The monetary policy committee raised the key lending rate or the repo rate to 5.90 per cent with a 5 out of 6 majority.

site_title: Tesla says deliveries increased in Q3
summary: Tesla delivered 343,380 vehicles globally between July and September, representing a 43% increase from the same period last year and a 35% increase from the second quarter. This marks a return to growth, despite being at the lower end of analyst estimates. The company attributes the increase to better distribution among its factories, including new sites in Berlin and Austin. Tesla also produced 365,923 vehicles, a 54% increase from the same period last year, but fell short of its estimated 1.5 million vehicle target for the year.

images.alt_text: Tesla said it was not aware of any warranty claims, field reports, crashes, injuries, or deaths related to the recall.

A view of Tesla Inc's US vehicle factory in Fremont, California. Of the 5 biggest US companies by market value, Tesla’s shares are by far the most expensive, yet they’re the only ones whose performance comes close to Apple’s, which has been a rare bright spot for investors in the sector this year.
A screengrab from Tesla AI Day 2022 livestream shows Elon Musk (L) presenting the humanoid robot in Palo Alto, California on Sept 30, 2022.

site_title: India’s Reliance Jio to launch 4G enabled low-cost laptop at US$184
summary: Reliance Jio plans to launch a budget laptop, the JioBook, priced at $184, with an embedded 4G sim card, targeting India's highly price-sensitive market. The laptop will be powered by Qualcomm's technology and run on Windows OS, with a consumer launch expected within the next three months. The launch is expected to extend the total addressable laptop market segment by at least 15%. The laptop will be produced locally by contract manufacturer Flex, with Jio aiming to sell hundreds of thousands of units by March.

images.alt_text: Sephora’s operations will transfer from Arvind Fashions to Reliance Retail if an agreement is reached, according to the report.

site_title: China’s Xiaomi says will protect business interests after assets frozen in India
summary: China's Xiaomi says it will protect its business interests after Indian authorities froze $682 million of its assets, citing illegal remittances to foreign entities. The move follows a probe by India's Enforcement Directorate, which found Xiaomi had passed off royalty payments as legitimate transactions. Xiaomi claims 84% of the seized funds were for royalty payments to Qualcomm, a legitimate commercial arrangement. The company will continue to protect its reputation and interests, amid ongoing tensions between China and India following a 2020 border clash.

images.alt_text: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp posted a steep drop in second quarter revenue on Friday as the world’s biggest smartphone market shrank, hit by strict Covid restrictions.

site_title: Pessimism of disbelief - best foundation for stock market recovery
summary: Investors are increasingly pessimistic due to a cocktail of worries, including high oil prices, inflation, war, and a potential global recession. However, this pessimism, known as the "pessimism of disbelief," can serve as a foundation for a market recovery. Historically, it has fueled rebounds in latter-stage bear markets, as investors focus on negatives and ignore positives. Despite bleak headlines, the writer suggests embracing uncertainty and investing in stocks, as lower expectations often prime new bull markets.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (on screen) noted that the world has not reached an equilibrium in its transition from a "unipolar world" to a "multipolar world".

ROCKVILLE, MD - AUGUST 25: U.S. President Joe Biden speaks during a rally hosted by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) at Richard Montgomery High School on August 25, 2022 in Rockville, Maryland. Biden rallied supporters for Democratic candidates running in Maryland and to encourage Democratic voters nationwide to turn out in the November midterm elections.   Drew Angerer/Getty Images/AFP
== FOR NEWSPAPERS, INTERNET, TELCOS & TELEVISION USE ONLY ==
A stronger USD makes American exports relatively more expensive, but also lowers some costs for companies sourcing supplies overseas.

site_title: Paramount’s gruesome ‘Smile’ tops North America box office
summary: Paramount's psychological horror film 'Smile' topped the North American box office with an estimated US$22 million in weekend ticket sales. The film, starring Sosie Bacon, follows a therapist whose reality begins to slip after witnessing a gruesome event. 'Smile' outperformed Warner Bros.' 'Don't Worry Darling' and Sony's 'The Woman King', with analyst David A. Gross calling it an "excellent opening" for a horror series.

images.alt_text: epa10210893 Australian actor Caitlin Stasey attends the premiere of the movie 'Smile' during Beyond Fest at Aero Theatre in Santa Monica, California, USA, 27 September 2022.  EPA-EFE/ALLISON DINNER
Cineplex is in early talks with Cineworld’s lenders about taking over Regal in exchange for debt and stock backed by the combined business.
An Aston Martin DB5 stunt car from the film "No Time to Die" sold for nearly £3 million at auction on Wednesday, Christie’s said.
Telcos are now looking to use their broadband capacity to better define their consumer value proposition, by bundling their services with streaming offerings, including movies.

site_title: German firms stepping up local R&D ties
summary: German companies Hima and Schaeffler are strengthening their ties with Singapore's institutions of higher learning, including the National University of Singapore (NUS) and the Nanyang Technological University (NTU). Hima has partnered with NUS to develop competent engineers in functional safety and security, while Schaeffler is expanding its research collaboration with NTU to focus on robotics, mobility, and Industry 4.0. The partnerships aim to nurture young engineers, provide internship opportunities, and conduct joint research on safety and security technologies.

images.alt_text: From left: Jens Rübbert, President, SGC Board, Dr Frank-Walter Steinmeier, President of the Federal Republic of Germany, S Iswaran, Minister for Transport and Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations, Republic of Singapore, and Anja Hajduk, State Secretary of the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action.

site_title: Time to cast a critical eye on ESG investing
summary: Research suggests ESG investing may not deliver both financial success and social impact. Despite ESG funds outperforming non-ESG funds in the short term, a bear market has raised questions about the sustainability of these funds. Long-term data shows little evidence of a trade-off in returns, but critics argue that many ESG funds are driven by marketing rather than actual sustainability goals. Experts, such as Mercer's Rich Nuzum, welcome scrutiny, emphasizing the need for investors to define their ESG objectives and strategies.

images.alt_text: ESG was offered as a framework to understand the effect of ESG factors on company performance, and not to assess a company's impact on the world.

Former US vice-president Al Gore (in a 2018 photo) said in an interview before Climate Week in New York last week that net-zero commitments by bankers and investors are welcome, "but obviously they have to be followed up".

site_title: ‘Incredibly messy’: Verstappen frustrated after Singapore F1 slip
summary: Max Verstappen finished seventh in the Singapore Grand Prix, his second consecutive poor result, after a disappointing start and struggles with his car. The Dutch driver was under-fuelled in qualifying, starting eighth on the grid, and was never in contention for the win. Verstappen scored six points, cutting his world championship lead to 104 points over Charles Leclerc with five races remaining. His teammate Sergio Perez won the race, and Verstappen is now under pressure to secure the title at the next Japanese Grand Prix.
